visits.text: Colombier Beach Hike — Start from Petite Anse parking and take the coastal trail. 30-minute hike through tropical vegetation with sea views. The path descends to Colombier beach, a secluded cove accessible only by foot or boat. Protected marine reserve with crystal-clear water, white sand surrounded by hills.

Petite Anse — Small beach at the trailhead to Colombier. Less crowded than major beaches, calm water perfect for swimming. Rocky coast on both sides creates a sheltered bay. Several parking spots under trees. Good starting point for coastal exploration.
Colombier trail access — Landmark with brief island history.

Flamands Beach — Long crescent beach with white sand bordered by latanier palms. Popular with families for calm waters and gentle slope. Several restaurants and bars along the beach. Beautiful sunset views with the sun setting into the Caribbean Sea. Relaxed, authentic atmosphere.
Cliff lookouts — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Turtle grass flats — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

Corossol Village — Traditional fishing village preserving old island lifestyle. Older women still wear traditional costumes: white bonnets called quichenottes, long dresses. Small beach with colorful fishing boats. Browse stands selling woven latanier palm hats and baskets made by local craftswomen.

Inter Oceans Museum — Small private museum exhibiting over 9,000 seashells collected worldwide by founder Ingénu Magras. Impressive collection of rare specimens, fossils, semi-precious stones. Educational displays on marine biology and Caribbean ecosystems. Located in Corossol.
NW headlands — Landmark with brief island history.

Public Beach — Small public beach near Corossol with shade trees and picnic tables. Local atmosphere, few tourists. Calm water protected from waves. Free parking and facilities. Perfect spot to observe authentic island life away from luxury resorts.
Hidden coves — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Ridgeline track — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

activities.text: Full Day at Colombier Beach — After the morning hike, spend the day on this isolated beach. Snorkel along the rocks, the protected marine reserve hosts sea turtles, rays, tropical fish. Bring picnic and drinks as there are no facilities. Enjoy the peaceful atmosphere of this pristine cove.

Sunset at Flamands Beach — End the day on this west-facing beach to watch the sunset. The sun sinks directly into the sea creating spectacular colors. Calm atmosphere with local families enjoying the evening. Perfect spot to relax after the Colombier hike.

Latanier Palm Craft Workshop — Meet the women of Corossol who perpetuate traditional weaving techniques. Watch them create hats, bags, baskets from latanier palm fronds dried and braided. Buy unique handmade souvenirs while supporting local artisans. Fascinating cultural experience.

Traditional Fishing and Local Culture — Talk with fishermen on the beach about traditional fishing methods still used today. Observe colorful saintois boats, traditional Caribbean fishing craft. Learn about island history and how locals maintain their culture despite development around them.

days_plan.itin_title: St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour
St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour

visits.text: Grand Cul-de-Sac Lagoon — Shallow lagoon protected by an offshore reef creating calm turquoise waters. Popular spot for kitesurfing and windsurfing with steady trade winds. The reef keeps waves out while winds accelerate over the water. Beach lined with latanier palms, sea grape trees, beach bars.

Natural Pools and Tidal Exploration — Walk along the beach to discover natural rock pools filled by high tide. Observe small fish, crabs, sea urchins trapped in these natural aquariums. The barrier reef creates calm areas perfect for families with young children. Clear shallow water with sandy bottom.
Grand Cul‑de‑Sac lagoon — Landmark with brief island history.

Marigot Beach — Small quiet cove just before Grand Cul-de-Sac. Less crowded than the main beach, perfect for those seeking calm. Crystal-clear water, good snorkeling along the rocks on both sides. Shaded areas under trees, intimate relaxed atmosphere.
Reef shallows — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Pointe views — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

Fort Oscar — Swedish fortification from the 18th century protecting the west side of Gustavia harbor. The fort housed the governor's residence. Stone ruins partially preserved with visible foundations. Panoramic view of the harbor entrance and Corossol coast. Quiet spot for contemplating island history.

West Coast Scenic Drive — Drive the narrow winding road along the western coast. Pass through small villages, cross green hills, discover isolated coves. Stop at viewpoints to admire rugged coastline and turquoise waters. Authentic side of the island away from tourist centers.
Mangrove edges — Landmark with brief island history.

Anse des Cayes — Small pebble beach on the northwestern tip of the island. Often deserted, wild atmosphere. Strong waves, rocky coastline. Access via steep path. Spot for those seeking isolation and raw natural beauty.
Kayak launch — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Reef flats — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

activities.text: Kitesurfing or Windsurfing Lesson — Grand Cul-de-Sac is one of the Caribbean's best spots for these sports. Constant trade winds, shallow water with sandy bottom, protected lagoon. Several schools offer lessons for beginners and equipment rental for experienced riders. Stunning setting with white sand and turquoise water.

Stand-Up Paddle to the Reef — Rent a SUP to explore the lagoon and head toward the barrier reef. Paddle over the shallow turquoise waters, observe the sandy bottom and seagrass beds beneath you. Spot sea turtles that feed in the lagoon. Calm, gentle activity perfect for families.

Complete Island Loop Drive — Do a full circuit of the island stopping at all major viewpoints and villages. Rediscover places from earlier days with new perspective. Appreciate how compact the island is while each coast has its own character. Final synthesis of the stay.

Final Beach and Relaxation — Choose your favorite beach to spend the last full day. Whether Grand Cul-de-Sac's lagoon, St-Jean's buzz, or Saline's wilderness. Savor the island's beauty one last time, reflect on discoveries made during the stay. Relaxed pace to end the trip.

days_plan.itin_title: St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour
St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour

visits.text: Port of Gustavia — This U-shaped harbor was built in 1785 by the Swedes and renamed after King Gustav III. The free port welcomes luxury yachts and cruise ships in a sheltered natural bay. Watch the constant parade of exceptional boats anchored in the turquoise waters.

Wall House - Territorial Museum — This mysterious stone building has an enigmatic history: was it a theater, officers' hotel, or political hall? The ground floor hosts a permanent exhibition on Saint Barthélemy's history. In the courtyard, check out the ruins of a stone and brick bread oven.
Harbor quays — Landmark with brief island history.

Fort Gustav — Climb up to the ruins of the most important fort from the Swedish period, built in 1787 on the foundations of a 17th-century French structure. The Gustavia lighthouse (1961) now stands on the site. The panoramic view of the harbor, neighboring islands of Saint Eustatius and Saba makes the climb under the Caribbean sun worthwhile.
Wall House (ext) — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Fort Gustav viewpoint — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

Fort Karl — Explore the remains of this 18th-century fortification overlooking Shell Beach south of Gustavia. The cannons pointed toward the sea to protect the entrance to the free port. Accessible hiking trail with spectacular views of the jagged coastline and turquoise waters below.

Shell Beach — Discover this unusual beach covered with millions of crushed shells rolled by the waves, looking like coarse pinkish sand. Remarkable origin: dredging of Gustavia harbor in the 1960s-1970s, sand and shells deposited in Grand Galet cove created this 1 km artificial beach. Stunning view of Saint Eustatius and Saba islands offshore.
Fort Karl path — Landmark with brief island history.

Waterfront Promenade — Walk along the colorful quays lined with restaurants, duty-free shops and historic buildings. The Swedish-era warehouses have been converted into upscale boutiques. Stop at outdoor cafés to watch yachts, sailboats and the constant harbor activity. Relaxed, elegant atmosphere typical of the island.
Shell Beach overlook — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Lighthouse point — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

Lorient Beach — Long family-friendly beach with calm waters and gentle slope. Less crowded than St-Jean or Grand Cul-de-Sac. Several access points along the road. Mix of locals and tourists. Relaxed atmosphere, some restaurants and small shops nearby.

Notre-Dame de l'Assomption Church — Small Catholic church with simple architecture overlooking Lorient. Built in the 19th century on the site of the island's first chapel. Mass celebrated in French and Creole. Peaceful cemetery with old tombstones bearing Swedish and French names.
Old anchors — Landmark with brief island history.

Pointe Milou — Rocky headland east of Lorient offering coastal views. Luxury villas built on the cliffs. Scenic drive along the coast with ocean views. Strong waves crash against the volcanic rocks. Popular spot for photos at sunrise.
Customs house (ext) — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Quayside plaques — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

Sunset from the Harbor — Find a spot on Gustavia's quays to watch the daily spectacle of the sun setting behind the island's hills. The U-shaped harbor lights up with golden then orange reflections. Silhouettes of luxury yachts stand out against the fiery backdrop. Magical atmosphere perfectly ending a stay in Saint Barthélemy.

Historic Quays — Take one last stroll along the restored quays bordering the free port. Admire the colorful architecture of Creole houses with verandas, historic anchors on display, commemorative plaques telling stories of famous explorers and navigators. Soak in the unique atmosphere blending Swedish heritage and French Caribbean culture.
Harbor sunset — Landmark with brief island history.

Farewell Walk — Walk through the paved streets of the historic center for a final exploration. Pass by the Catholic and Anglican churches, Wall House, Rétrocession Square. Browse luxury duty-free shops. Enjoy a last cocktail on a terrace overlooking the harbor before leaving this Caribbean gem.
Quays — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Farewell promenade — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

activities.text: Fort Gustav-Lighthouse Urban Hike — Climb up to the lighthouse located on the old Fort Gustav site. Exceptional panorama of the harbor, town and neighboring islands. Well-maintained trail with stairs, easy path but exposed to the sun.

Walking Tour of Historic Center — Wander through the capital's streets to discover Swedish-influenced architecture: wooden houses with ornate balconies, typical verandas. Pass by Samuel Fahlberg Street, Vanadis Square with its Neptune trident, and Rétrocession Square commemorating the return to France in 1877.

Kayak or Stand-Up Paddle in the Harbor — Rent equipment on the docks to explore the bay from the water. Paddle between anchored yachts, get close to the historic forts, discover hidden coves along Shell Beach. Calm, clear water, activity suitable for all levels.

Fort Karl Sunset Hike — Take the coastal trail from Shell Beach to Fort Karl ruins at golden hour. Climb to the ramparts as the setting sun lights up the fortifications and harbor. Magical view of the town bathed in warm light. Bring camera for stunning photos.

Surfing at Lorient Beach — When conditions are right, Lorient gets good waves suitable for beginners and intermediate surfers. More consistent swell than sheltered bays. Local surf shops rent boards and offer lessons. Friendly surf vibe, popular with island residents.

Coastal Drive and Viewpoint Tour — Drive the scenic coastal road from Lorient to Toiny. Stop at multiple viewpoints to admire the wild Atlantic-facing coast. Dramatic cliffs, powerful waves, isolated coves. Beautiful scenic drive with photo opportunities at every turn.

Gourmet Dinner with Harbor View — Reserve a table at one of the renowned restaurants lining Gustavia harbor. Refined French cuisine or revisited Creole specialties by talented chefs. Savor grilled lobster, fresh catch of the day, tropical desserts while watching the nightly ballet of illuminated yachts. Elegant and relaxed atmosphere typical of St Barths lifestyle.

Last-Minute Shopping — Take advantage of the free port status for duty-free shopping before departure. Luxury boutiques offering perfumes, cosmetics, jewelry, watches, designer clothing at attractive prices. Art galleries displaying Caribbean artists' works. Local crafts: woven latanier hats from Corossol, spiced rums, natural cosmetics.

days_plan.itin_title: St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour
St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour
St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour
St. Barths Exploration: Gustavia Harbor to Eastern Lagoons Tour

visits.text: St-Jean Beach — This beach is split in two by Eden Rock promontory. Watch planes landing just meters above your head on the 646-meter runway ranked 3rd most dangerous airport in the world. White sand, turquoise water, beach clubs and restaurants. Perfect for swimming with gentle waves most of the year.

Gustaf III Airport Observation — Position yourself at the end of St-Jean beach or Remy de Haenen viewpoint to watch plane landings. Aircraft descend over the bay, clear the beach by a few meters, and touch down on the short runway bordered by hills. Daily spectacle of small planes and jets maneuvering in this constrained space.
St‑Jean bay views — Landmark with brief island history.

Eden Rock — This luxury hotel sits on a rocky promontory splitting St-Jean beach. Even without staying here, you can admire the architecture and impressive location. The rock serves as a natural diving spot. Snorkel around the formation to see tropical fish in clear waters.
Airport hill — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Boutique strip façades — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

Saline Beach — Wild beach accessible by 10-minute walk through sand dunes and low vegetation from the parking area. No buildings or facilities, pristine natural setting. Strong waves, undertow, swimming for experienced swimmers only. Nudism tolerated. Stunning scenery with white sand stretching along the coast.

Coastal Dunes Trail — Walk through the coastal ecosystem to reach Saline beach. The sandy path crosses low vegetation adapted to salt spray and wind. Observe local flora: sea grape, beach morning glory, agaves. The dune system protects the beach from erosion.
Airport end views — Landmark with brief island history.

Gouverneur Beach — Crescent beach framed by green hills. Access via steep winding road. Strong waves, powerful currents, experienced swimmers only. No facilities or shade. Spectacular beauty and wild feel. Often deserted even in high season.
Saline trailhead area — Natural viewpoint; best light near sunset.
Dune overlooks — Heritage element or interpretive signs.

activities.text: Snorkeling St-Jean Bay — Rent mask and fins on the beach to explore shallow reefs. Swim around Eden Rock and along the rocky coast. Observe parrotfish, angelfish, sergeant majors in their natural habitat. Clear water with excellent visibility year-round.

Beach Clubs and Local Cuisine — Try the famous beach clubs lining St-Jean. Relaxed atmosphere with feet in the sand, French and Creole cuisine, fresh seafood. Enjoy grilled lobster, local fish, tropical cocktails while watching planes land. Elegant casual vibe typical of St Barths.

Full Day at Saline Beach — Spend the day on this untouched beach. Bring everything you need: water, food, umbrella, sun protection. Swim in the waves (watch for currents), walk along the endless white sand, admire the wild beauty. Peaceful atmosphere far from tourist crowds.

Sunset at Gouverneur Beach — End the day at this west-facing beach for spectacular sunset. The sun sets behind the hills creating dramatic lighting. Often deserted at this hour. Romantic, wild setting perfect for evening contemplation.

days_plan.itin_title: A Road Trip Through the Somme Valley: Cathedrals, History & River Landscapes

visits.text: The royal city of Loches dominates the Indre valley from its rocky spur. Its fortified enclosure of more than a kilometer encloses one of France's best-preserved medieval ensembles: royal apartments, keep, and collegiate church.
The Porte Royale, sole access to the upper city, is flanked by two massive 13th-century towers. Cross it to travel back in time and enter the medieval enclosure.
The 11th-century square keep, one of France's oldest stone keeps, rises to 36 meters. Its underground dungeons were used as state prison: iron cages and prisoners' graffiti are still visible.
The royal apartments welcomed Charles VII and his mistress Agnès Sorel, whose white marble effigy rests in one of the halls. Joan of Arc met the king here in 1429 to convince him to march on Reims.
The collegiate church of Saint-Ours, recognizable by its two hollow pyramids (dubes) that cover the nave, is a unique Romanesque edifice in Europe. Its polychrome portal merits a prolonged stop.
Cité Royale de Loches, a fortified city commanding the Indre Valley from its rocky promontory
The monumental Royal Gate of Loches, a formidable entrance to the medieval fortress
The keep of Loches and its harrowing museum of medieval imprisonment—iron cages and all
The medieval-inspired garden of the Cité Royale de Loches, planted with herbs and medicinal flowers

activities.text: The HistoPad, an augmented reality tablet, reconstructs the halls of the royal apartments and keep as they appeared in the 15th and 16th centuries. Furniture, hangings, and characters emerge before your eyes.
Stroll through the medieval-inspired garden at the city's foot. Aromatic, vegetable, and dye plants are cultivated there according to period practices.
Interactive visit of Loches with the HistoPad, bringing the medieval fortress to life through augmented reality

The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Saint-Caprais Cathedral blends Romanesque and Gothic architecture in perfect harmony. This UNESCO World Heritage site houses 19th-century frescoes chronicling the story of Christianity in the Agen region.
The Musée des Beaux-Arts spans four Renaissance mansions, showcasing Goya's haunting self-portrait, the Venus du Mas, and Impressionist masterpieces by Sisley.
The Pont-Canal strides across the Garonne River on 23 stone arches spanning 539 meters—France's second-longest canal bridge after Briare.
Wander through Rue des Cornières with its medieval arcades and half-timbered houses now sheltering lively shops and sidewalk cafés.
Place des Laitiers marks where the ancient Saint-Étienne Cathedral once stood before the Revolution. Today it hosts the bustling local market.

activities.text: Head to the Halle du Pin market to sample legendary Agen prunes, hazelnuts from the Lot valley, and silky foie gras.
Bike or stroll the canal towpath along the Garonne, where tree-lined banks offer peaceful riverside views.
Explore the market stalls at Place Durand to discover Agen's authentic local produce and regional specialties.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: Ramparts of Aigues-Mortes, perfectly preserved 13th-century medieval fortified walls. The mile-long crenellated walls punctuated by 20 towers completely encircle the town. The walkway accessible along the entire perimeter offers panoramas over Camargue, pink salt marshes, and Mediterranean Sea. Military architecture designed under Louis IX (Saint Louis) illustrates medieval defensive art with loopholes, hoardings, and machicolations. Fortified gates—Porte de la Gardette, Porte de l'Organeau—controlled access to the port town. Sunset sets ablaze ochre stones of ramparts creating magical atmosphere.

Tour de Constance, 131-foot cylindrical keep dominating Aigues-Mortes since 1248. The massive tower served as state prison from the 17th century, imprisoning Protestants after Revocation of the Edict of Nantes. The upper room with impressive vaults imprisoned Marie Durand for 38 years, who carved "resist" on the well rim. The 196-step spiral staircase leads to circular panoramic terrace. The visit evokes the prison-tower's history and moving testimonies of female captives. The monument symbolizes Huguenot resistance and religious intolerance.

Salins d'Aigues-Mortes, 26,700-acre salt exploitation producing Camargue salt. Salt pans in pink hues due to halophilic microalgae create spectacular colorful landscapes. Camelles, white salt mountains rising 65 feet, sparkle in sunlight. Thousands of pink flamingos frequent evaporation basins feeding on brine shrimp and algae. Discovery circuit by small train tours industrial and natural site explaining ancestral harvest. Boutiques sell artisanal salt—fleur de sel, grey salt, flavored—and derivative products.

Historic center of Aigues-Mortes, medieval bastide with preserved grid plan. Straight streets intersect at right angles following regular 13th-century urbanism. Place Saint-Louis bordered by café terraces honors the king-builder who departed on crusade from the port. Notre-Dame-des-Sablons church in southern Gothic style shelters relics and marine ex-votos. Limestone houses with colorful shutters align facades along paved streets. Artisan shops offer Camargue specialties: fougasse, gardiane, rice, salt.

Plage de l'Espiguette at Le Grau-du-Roi, sand desert with wild dunes classified as Grand Site de France. The 3,700 acres of mobile dunes reach 40 feet high shaped by winds and tides. The six-mile nearly deserted beach offers Mediterranean swimming far from urbanization. Marram grass, glasswort, and immortelles anchor sand in fragile dune ecosystem. The Espiguette lighthouse, 89-foot white tower, marks channel entrance. The wild, preserved atmosphere contrasts with neighboring seaside resorts.
Ramparts of Aigues-Mortes and Tower of Constance.
Petite Camargue: ponds, salt marshes and flamingo watching.

activities.text: Excursion in Gard Camargue discovering fauna and landscapes. Roads traverse expanses of reeds, rice paddies, marshes, and lagoons populated with birds. Pink flamingos, grey herons, egrets, ibis, and avocets allow observation from ornithological observatories. Herds of Camargue bulls and white horses graze in wet meadows. Traditional Camargue farmhouses dot preserved territory. Camargue Regional Natural Park protects 212,000 acres of internationally important wetlands. Changing light sublimes aquatic landscapes stretching to infinity.

Visit salt marshes by tourist train touring salt pans and evaporation basins. The 45-minute narrated circuit reveals seawater crystallization process from seawater pumping. Small wagons wind between salt mountains, pink and green basins according to saline concentration. Explanations detail mechanized harvesting, storage, and salt packaging. Stops allow photographing flamingos in surreal colored décor. Boutique offers tastings and purchases of locally produced flavored salts.

Taste gardiane de taureau at a typical Camargue restaurant. Traditional stew simmers Camargue bull meat AOC with red wine, black olives, garlic, and aromatic herbs. The rustic dish accompanied by Camargue rice IGP illustrates authentic regional gastronomy. Restaurants near ramparts also serve tellines, local shellfish, brandade, grilled fish. Vins des sables IGP produced on Camargue terroir pair with specialties. Fougasse d'Aigues-Mortes, brioche with orange blossom seeds, concludes traditional meal.

Bike ride on cycle paths between Aigues-Mortes and Le Grau-du-Roi. Developed paths traverse salt marshes, canals, reedbeds, and beaches in horizontal Camargue landscape. The flat six-mile route accessible to all follows lagoons reflecting the sky. Stops allow observing flamingos, photographing pink salt pans, and enjoying marine panoramas. Bike rental in Aigues-Mortes facilitates day family excursion. Wind can blow hard requiring extra effort but guaranteeing invigorating fresh air.
Sunset at Étang du Ponant (photo walk).
Nature outing with Camargue guide (horses, herds; respectful observation).

Saint-Pierre Chapel and orientation table with view over the lake and the Verdon ridges.
Visit to the waterfall of Sillans and the village of Moustiers-Sainte-Marie.
Ascent to the chapel of Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir for the view over the lake.

visits.text: The Abbey Church of Saint-Pierre from the 11th-13th centuries is a jewel of Poitevin Romanesque art. Its historiated capitals and Plantagenet vaults are exceptional.
The 19th-century mechanical cylinder organ, listed as a Historic Monument, resonates in the nave during performances.
The cenotaph of Pierre de Saine Fontaine, founder who died in 1110, testifies to the antiquity of the site.
The underground fountain can be discovered with the key lent by the Tourist Office.
The 19th-century market halls and 15th-16th century half-timbered houses border Place Saint-Pierre.

activities.text: Climb up to the Old Castle for a superb panorama over the town and the Thouet Valley.
Follow Aldéarde's paths, ground-marked routes with medallions to discover the heritage.

visits.text: Discovery of the thermal center of Aix-les-Bains and its Belle Époque buildings.
Walk along Lake Bourget, the largest natural lake in France.
Lake Aiguebelette spreads its turquoise waters in a preserved mountain setting. Smallest of the great Alpine lakes, it offers the greatest tranquility as motorboats are banned.
The two islands in the lake's center shelter a chapel and the remains of prehistoric lake dwellings classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Lake Bourget stretches 18 kilometers between the mountains. France's largest natural lake, it inspired Lamartine who set his poetic meditations here.
The Royal Abbey of Hautecombe stands on Lake Bourget's western shore. Necropolis of the Princes of Savoy, it houses the dynasty's tombs.
Aix-les-Bains retains its elegance as a Belle Époque spa resort. The national thermal baths and palaces testify to past splendor.
The Temple of Diana and Roman remains recall that thermal waters already attracted spa-goers two thousand years ago.
Aix-les-Bains – thermal center & National Thermal Baths (exterior/architecture)
Lake Bourget promenade – esplanade & beaches (seasonal)
Hautecombe Abbey (wild shore of the lake)
Col de la Chambotte – belvedere over Lake Bourget (short walk)
Annecy: old town, canals and Pont des Amours.
Annecy: Palais de l'Isle (exterior and museography).
Aix-les-Bains: Faure Museum (Impressionists, Rodin).
Aix-les-Bains: Belle Époque stroll between casino, thermal baths and Lake Bourget esplanade.

The Thermes Nationaux of Aix-les-Bains, built in 1783 over Roman bath ruins, closed in 2008 and became a historic monument. Enter freely: glass elevators offer a plunging view into the 1st-century AD thermal remains.

The Arc de Campanus, a 1st-century monumental arch, rises opposite the baths. Erected by a Roman notable to honor his dead, it recalls Aix's importance since antiquity. The Temple of Diana, integrated into the town hall, completes this Gallo-Roman heritage.

The Musée Faure occupies Villa des Chimères, a Genoese-style mansion opened in 1949. It holds France's second-largest Rodin sculpture collection, plus canvases by Cézanne, Degas, Pissarro, and Sisley.
The Grand Cercle Casino, inaugurated in the mid-19th century, merits a visit for its Belle Époque decoration: mosaic ceilings, stained glass, and gilded frescoes evoke the spa's golden age.

Cross the lake by boat to Hautecombe Abbey. Founded in the 12th century by Cistercian monks, this necropolis of the Princes of Savoy was restored in the 19th century in flamboyant neo-Gothic style. Frescoes, marble sculptures, and princely tombs form a striking ensemble.
Stroll the Esplanade du Lac, an 800-meter promenade between the small and large ports. Plane trees shade the view across Lake Bourget—France's largest natural lake—and the Dent du Chat peak opposite.

activities.text: Introduction to paddleboarding on Lake Bourget.
Bike ride on the greenway around the lake, between beaches and forests.
Rent a paddleboard or kayak on Lake Aiguebelette to glide on its deep green waters in absolute silence.
Lake Bourget cruises allow visitors to reach Hautecombe Abbey by the waters once sailed by the Kings of Sardinia.
Kayak down the Guiers River. This family-friendly 7 km route passes through gorge and forest landscapes.
Treat yourself to spa treatments at the Aix-les-Bains thermal baths, where hot waters have soothed rheumatism since antiquity.
Wellness moment at the thermal baths (Chevalley or other, depending on opening)
Annecy: Pâquier promenade and partial lake tour (pedestrian/bike).
Annecy: mini-cruise on the lake (depending on season).
Narrated cruise on Lake Bourget. Departures from Aix's Grand Port, with a possible stop at Hautecombe Abbey. Panoramas of the Alps and the Épine range unfold over one to two hours.
Hike to Mont Revard viewpoint (1,538 m). From the summit, the vista sweeps over Lake Bourget, Aix-les-Bains, Mont Blanc, and the Bauges range. Picnic tables dot the trail.
Swimming or paddle-boarding at Lake Bourget. Several supervised beaches (Rowing, Grand Port, Mémard) let you enjoy waters that reach 26°C in summer.

visits.text: The Église Sainte-Croix, built in the 13th century, owes its name to a legend: a pilgrim returning from Jerusalem reportedly rested here with a fragment of the True Cross. Its Limousin portal and three naves shelter a remarkable treasure of 21 reliquaries, including two champlevé enamel shrines from the 13th century.

The Tour Jeanne d'Albret, a classified Historic Monument, is the last vestige of the fortress built on the rocky spur overlooking the confluence of the Aixette and Vienne. From the summit, views embrace both valleys.

The Pont de Malassert, called the 'Roman bridge,' spans the Aixette with a single stone arch dating from the 14th century. The sole remnant of a former wooden plank bridge, it reveals itself along a shaded path.

Reach the Sanctuaire d'Arliquet, a neo-Gothic brick chapel unique in Limousin, built between 1865 and 1868. Its contemporary stained glass by Francis Chigot replaced 19th-century windows. Four large shrines hold martyrs' relics brought from Rome in 1870.
The sanctuary park invites a quiet moment. A Way of the Cross with 14 stations winds through trees to the Grotte de la Passion, set in a landscape of woods and rocks.

activities.text: Aixe sits at the crossroads of GR 4 (Royan-Grasse) and GR 654 (Vézelay-Compostela). Follow a section of the trail along the Vienne for a 5 km hike between riverbanks and meadows.

Stroll through the old town's lanes, among remnants of three medieval gates — Lavaud, Auroux, and Guingand — which protected the town since the Middle Ages. Aixe was a strategic point on the via Lemovicensis to Compostela.
Settle in the medieval garden laid out along the Vienne for a break. The riverbanks offer a peaceful setting for a picnic facing the river.

visits.text: Pass through the Porte de Savoie, a remnant of the 14th-century ramparts, to enter the medieval citadel of Conflans. Built on a rocky spur at the confluence of the Arly and Isère rivers, this upper town guarded the entrance to Tarentaise. Cobbled lanes, artisan workshops, and colorful facades have kept their charm intact.

The Maison Rouge, a listed 14th-century building, houses the Musée d'Art et d'Histoire d'Albertville (labeled Musée de France). Gallo-Roman archaeology, baroque sacred art, rural Savoyard objects, and early skiing equipment form a diverse collection.

The église Saint-Grat de Conflans, recognizable by its onion-dome bell tower, was rebuilt in the early 18th century. Its baroque interior—gilded altarpiece, carved woodwork—illustrates the importance of this art in the Savoyard valleys.

The Tour Sarrasine, built between the 11th and 12th centuries, is the sole vestige of the Château de la Cour. From the garden surrounding it, the panorama embraces Albertville, the Isère valley, and alpine summits.

Descend to the lower town to discover the "Tremplin 92, Mountain and Olympism" visitor center. The space recounts the 1992 Winter Olympics through documents, artifacts, and testimonies. The Halle Olympique, renovated in 2015, remains a venue for cultural and sporting events.

activities.text: Guided tour of Conflans with a guide from the Pays d'Art et d'Histoire. The route details the fortified gates, Château Manuel de Locatel (16th century, built by a noble merchant from Bergamo), and the 1390 Château Rouge.
Want to gain altitude? A paragliding flight above the valley lets you soar over the confluence of the Arly and Isère, with the Tarentaise peaks as backdrop.
Taste Savoyard specialties in Conflans inns: crozets gratinéed with Beaufort, diots in white wine, and polenta. Terraces offer plunging views over the valley.

days_plan.itin_title: Savoie from Lakes to Glaciers: Yenne to Haute-Maurienne

visits.text: Exploration of the historic center of Albi and the Sainte-Cécile cathedral.
Visit to the Toulouse-Lautrec museum in the former episcopal palace.

Cathédrale Sainte-Cécile in Albi is the world's largest brick cathedral. Construction began in 1282, and it rises like a fortress with massive, imposing walls. Step inside and the contrast stuns: 18,500 square meters of frescoes make it Europe's largest painted cathedral. The deep blue vault dates from 1509-1512. The Last Judgment from the 15th century covers more than 200 square meters. The classical organ is one of France's grandest.

The Palais de la Berbie, the former bishops' palace, houses the Toulouse-Lautrec Museum. This is the world's largest collection of works by the artist born in Albi in 1864. You'll see his famous Moulin Rouge posters, paintings of Parisian nightlife, and intimate portraits. The museum holds over 1,000 works.

Collégiale Saint-Salvi is Albi's oldest church. Its 13th-century Romanesque cloister offers peaceful refuge. The church itself blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. The 12th-century bell tower leans slightly, lending it character and charm.

Sainte-Cécile Cathedral rises as a monolithic fortress: the world's largest brick cathedral, its single-nave interior soars 30 meters high. Italian frescoes cover more than two hectares of vaulted ceiling, while the 15th-century Last Judgment fresco dominates the entire western wall.

Step into the Palais de la Berbie, a 13th-century episcopal fortress built entirely of brick. It houses the museum dedicated to the painter born in Albi in 1864: posters, lithographs, early canvases, and scenes of Parisian cabarets form the world's largest collection devoted to this artist.

Descend into the palace gardens, classified as a Remarkable Garden. The terraces overlook the Tarn River, offering panoramic views of Pont-Vieux—one of France's oldest bridges—and the wild riverbanks below.

The Collégiale Saint-Salvi blends stone and brick, Romanesque and Gothic. Its cloister, hidden in the heart of the city, reveals Romanesque arcades and an interior garden where tranquility contrasts sharply with the bustling streets outside.

Cross the Pont-Vieux, built in the 11th century, then position yourself on the right bank at Botany Bay Square: the view of the episcopal city, with cathedral and palace mirrored in the Tarn, is Albi's most iconic postcard.

Lose yourself in the narrow streets of the UNESCO-listed historic center. Half-timbered houses stand alongside Renaissance mansions, testaments to the fortune amassed from pastel trade—the plant that yielded precious blue dye.

activities.text: Walk along the banks of the Tarn and view of the old bridge.

The gardens of Palais de la Berbie descend in terraces to the Tarn River. The view over the Pont Vieux and old town is magnificent, especially at sunset. The formal French gardens are beautifully maintained and offer a quiet place to rest.

Wander through the UNESCO-listed episcopal city. Cobbled lanes, half-timbered houses, and brick buildings create a unique atmosphere. The 11th-century Pont Vieux lets you cross the Tarn while enjoying beautiful views of the cathedral rising above the city.

Board a gabarre, a flat-bottomed boat that once transported goods along the Tarn. From the river, the episcopal city reveals another face: mills, quays, and the lockkeeper's house unfold along the water.
Follow the Échappée Verte, a 4 km urban hiking trail along the Tarn riverbanks. The route connects downtown to green spaces while following the GR 36 long-distance path.
Head to the covered market hall to taste local products: Lacaune cured meats, sheep's milk cheeses, and pink garlic from Lautrec. The market is liveliest on Saturday mornings.

visits.text: The Museum of Fine Arts and Lace occupies the former Jesuit college. Its flagship collection showcases the Point d'Alençon, a needlepoint lace technique inscribed on UNESCO's list in 2010. A single 19th-century bridal veil, stretching 11.5 feet, required up to 500,000 hours of painstaking work.

Step through the doors of Notre-Dame Basilica. Its three-bay Flamboyant Gothic porch, built in the early 16th century, ranks among Normandy's finest. Inside, the 15th-century nave glows with stained glass from 1530.
The Halle au Blé—a circular grain market built between 1811 and 1819—surprises visitors with its sweeping glass dome. Today it hosts cultural events beneath the striking architecture.
Visit the Maison d'Ozé, a medieval mansion from 1450 and former residence of the Duke of Alençon. Now home to the tourist office, it includes a heritage orchard in its courtyard.
The Château des Ducs d'Alençon preserves its machicolated towers, remnants of the medieval fortress. The entrance pavilion sets the tone for this ducal stronghold.

Wander the lanes of the Saint-Léonard quarter, Alençon's oldest neighborhood. Half-timbered houses, spiral staircases, and wrought-iron balconies line the Grande Rue. Don't miss the Maison des 7 Colonnes with its vividly painted timbers.

activities.text: Browse the town-center market on Thursdays or the Place Courteille market on Sunday mornings. Norman cheeses, cider, and regional produce fill the stalls.
Alençon sits along the Véloscénie, a cycle route connecting Paris to Mont-Saint-Michel. Ride a section alongside the Orne River on landscaped towpaths.
The Écouves Massif, just outside Alençon, peaks at 1,355 feet at Signal d'Écouves. Its oak and beech forests shelter red deer and roe deer.

days_plan.itin_title: Orne Road Trip: Norman Bocage and Prestigious Stud Farms

visits.text: Mine-témoin d'Alès, preserved historic mining site testifying to the Cévennes coal epic. Underground gallery descent recreates 19th-20th century miners' working conditions. Underground workings reveal extraction techniques, tools, wagons, and timbering. Museography traces industrial history of the Alès coal basin that employed up to 15,000 people. Collections display mine lamps, measuring instruments, installation models. The metal headframe dominates the site classified as Historic Monument. One-hour guided tours recount the dangerous daily life of the coal miners.

Saint-Jean-Baptiste Cathedral of Alès, 19th-century neoclassical building in the rebuilt city center. The monumental facade with Corinthian columns draws inspiration from Rome's Pantheon. The sober interior lit by a dome shelters a majestic organ and religious paintings. The cathedral quarter preserves Haussmannian buildings testifying to industrial urbanism. Place Gabriel-Péri bordered by cafés animates downtown. The neighboring Protestant temple recalls Protestantism's importance in Cévennes territory.

Musée-bibliothèque Pierre-André Benoît, modern and contemporary art collection installed in the former bishop's palace. The collection gathers 5,000 works by 20th-century creators: Picasso, Miró, Braque, Giacometti, Dubuffet. Artists' books, prints, drawings illustrate dialogue between poets and painters. Temporary exhibitions explore avant-garde artistic movements. The sculpted Mediterranean garden offers a plant setting for works. Free admission democratizes access to art.

Fort Vauban of Alès, 17th-century citadel dominating the city from Saint-Julien hill. The bastioned fortification designed by Vauban surveilled the Protestant region after Revocation of the Edict of Nantes. Pentagonal ramparts and casemates testify to classical military architecture. The panoramic site embraces the Alès agglomeration, Cévennes plain, and first mountain foothills. Ramparts now host walks and cultural events. Free access allows discovering fortifications and belvedere.

activities.text: Alès market at Place de la Mairie, daily gathering under Belle Époque metal halls. Cévennes producers offer organic vegetables, goat cheeses, charcuterie, honey, seasonal fruits. Colorful stalls overflow with olives, tapenades, flavored oils, Cévennes wines. The southern atmosphere resonates with singing accents and animated conversations. Rotisseries emit appetizing aromas of roasted chickens and paella. The particularly abundant Saturday morning market attracts residents throughout the agglomeration.

Evening at Le Cratère, Alès national performing arts center programming quality shows. The cultural center offers contemporary theater, dance, concerts, comedy, circus in a 500-seat modular hall. Eclectic programming mixes nationally significant productions and emerging artists. Artist meetings, workshops, and residencies enrich cultural offerings. The café-restaurant welcomes audiences before and after performances. Box office allows reserving seats for varied artistic evenings.

Walk towpaths along the Gardon d'Alès. Developed banks invite walks on foot or by bike in preserved natural setting. Century-old plane trees shade paths following the clear river. Equipped picnic areas allow bucolic breaks. Anglers practice their passion in calm banks. The route discovers Mediterranean fauna and flora: herons, kingfishers, tamarisk, poplars. The flat route accessible to all offers green escape near downtown.

days_plan.itin_title: Gard Road Trip: Roman Nîmes, Pont du Gard & Camargue Wilderness

visits.text: The "Potence" of Allègre: this name designates the spectacular ruins of the 14th-century feudal castle, built atop the Baury volcano. Two towers linked by a cornice of trefoil machicolations remain balanced above the void. Classified as a Historic Monument in 1935.
The original castle counted 23 towers across 3 enceintes. Built by Morinot de Tourzel starting in 1385, it was one of Auvergne's most imposing. A chimney fire ravaged it on November 15, 1698.
Pass through the Porte de Monsieur, the south entrance to the fortified town. It has retained its two towers, the portcullis housing, and the hinges of the original gate.
On the Place du Marchédial, surrounded by fortified houses, the Chapelle Notre-Dame-de-l'Oratoire shelters a 16th-century Pietà.
Allègre, labeled a "Petite Cité de Caractère," reveals itself through its charreyrons: narrow lanes once used by water carriers between houses staggered on the slopes of Mont Baury.

activities.text: Climb to the summit of Mont Bar (3,855 ft), unique in Europe: it's the only strombolian volcano sheltering a peat bog in its crater. An interpretive trail circles this Natura 2000 classified zone.
From the orientation table at the foot of the Potence, take in the Devès volcanoes, Mont Bar facing you, and the Velay mountains in the distance.
Allègre is the gateway to the Livradois-Forez Regional Natural Park. Several marked trails radiate from the village to explore the surrounding countryside.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Ambérieu-en-Bugey marks the gateway to Bugey, the transition between Dombes plains and Jura mountains. The town developed around its strategic position at the crossroads of major roads and its railway node. The Saint-Germain church, with its Romanesque bell tower, watches over the old center. The nearby Château des Allymes, perched on a rocky outcrop, testifies to medieval military architecture with its square keep and defensive walls.

The Château des Allymes, built in the 14th century by the Dukes of Savoy, dominates the plain from its 820-meter perch. The fortified ensemble, remarkably preserved, illustrates defensive architecture of the late Middle Ages. The keep, ramparts, and towers allowed control of roads leading to Geneva and Lyon. Guided tours reveal daily life of garrison soldiers. The panoramic view extends from the Alps to Mont Blanc.

Walk through the old town where 19th-century houses bear witness to industrial prosperity brought by the railway. The railway station, built in 1856, marked a decisive turning point in urban development. The adjacent railway museum recounts this epic through period locomotives, tools, and documents. Model trains recreate the network's different eras.

The Albarine gorges, a few kilometers from town, offer spectacular landscapes where the river has carved its bed through limestone rock. Steep cliffs, caves, and natural cavities dot the course of this tumultuous torrent. Marked trails allow safe exploration while admiring geological formations. The site attracts climbers who train on vertical walls.

activities.text: Taste Bugey wines at local producers cultivating terraced hillsides. This little-known appellation produces remarkable white, red, and rosé wines. Altesse, Mondeuse, and Jacquère grape varieties express themselves differently depending on exposure and soil. Independent winegrowers welcome visitors to explain their work and passion. Tastings reveal unexpected diversity of this mountain terroir.

Hike the Sentier des Crêtes which climbs to heights dominating the plain. The marked trail offers spectacular views of the Alps, Mont Blanc, and surrounding valleys. The route alternates between forests, meadows, and rocky passages. The varied flora includes rare orchids and mountain plants. The approximately 4-hour round trip is accessible to regular hikers.

Visit the Tuesday morning market that animates the town center. Stalls overflow with local products: mountain cheeses, Bugey charcuterie, vegetables from market gardens, regional wines. Producers sell directly to customers, perpetuating personal relationship. The friendly atmosphere makes shopping a pleasant moment of exchange.

Practice climbing on the limestone cliffs of Albarine gorges. The site offers routes of all difficulty levels, from beginner to expert. Local clubs organize initiations and supervised outings. The spectacular setting and rock quality attract climbers from the entire region. Equipment rental and professional instruction ensure safety.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: The Richard de Bas Mill, nestled in the Laga valley at the heart of Parc Livradois-Forez, is Auvergne's last paper mill. Since the 15th century, it has perpetuated ancestral rag paper production methods dating back to 1326. Two hundred sheets per day still emerge from its vats—paper of such quality it served for printing Diderot and d'Alembert's encyclopedia and is still used for art restoration. Labeled Living Heritage Company, the mill offers hour-long guided visits revealing papermaking secrets.

Ambert's round town hall is unique in Europe. This 19th-century circular building, whose shape recalls a wheel of Fourme d'Ambert cheese, houses administrative services, the municipal council chamber, and a wedding hall at the building's center. The ground floor's circular exhibition traces the town's history. Classified as a Historic Monument in 1975, the town hall was immortalized in Jules Romains' 1913 novel Les Copains.

The Maison de la Fourme d'Ambert presents the production, history, and tasting of this PDO blue cheese, one of France's oldest. Ambert is so closely tied to fourme that the town is twinned with Gorgonzola, Italy—another blue cheese capital. The Plus Beaux Détours de France label distinguishes this medieval town with narrow lanes, half-timbered houses, and Art Nouveau architecture.

Saint-Jean Gothic church dominates Ambert's historic center from its medieval streets. The old quarter reveals varied built heritage where half-timbered houses, Renaissance facades, and Art Nouveau elements testify to this papermaking and cheesemaking town's past prosperity.

The Richard de Bas mill, nestled in the Laga valley at the heart of Livradois-Forez Park, stands as Auvergne's last paper mill. Since the 15th century, it has perpetuated artisanal rag paper production using ancestral methods dating to 1326. Two hundred sheets per day still emerge from its vats—paper of such quality that it served for printing Diderot and d'Alembert's encyclopedia and is still used for artwork restoration. Labeled Entreprise du Patrimoine Vivant (Living Heritage Company), the mill offers hour-long guided tours revealing the secrets of papermaking pulp.

Ambert's round town hall is a unique case in Europe. This circular 19th-century building, whose shape recalls a wheel of Fourme d'Ambert cheese, houses administrative services, the municipal council chamber, and a wedding hall at the building's center. The ground-floor circular exhibition traces the town's history. Classified as a Historic Monument in 1975, the town hall was immortalized in Jules Romains's 1913 novel Les Copains.

La Maison de la Fourme d'Ambert presents the production, history, and tasting of this PDO blue cheese, one of France's oldest. Ambert is so closely linked to fourme that the town is twinned with Gorgonzola, Italy—another blue cheese capital. The Plus Beaux Détours de France label distinguishes this medieval town with narrow lanes, half-timbered houses, and Art Nouveau architecture.

Saint-Jean Gothic church dominates Ambert's historic center above medieval lanes. The old quarter reveals diverse built heritage where half-timbered houses, Renaissance facades, and Art Nouveau elements coexist, testifying to the past prosperity of this papermaking and cheesemaking town.

activities.text: Workshop: craft your own sheet of handmade paper at the Richard de Bas Mill. Each participant dips the mold into the pulp vat and creates their own sheet following centuries-old master papermakers' gestures. The mill shop offers notebooks, stationery, printed texts, and pressed flower papers.

Journey on the AGRIVAP tourist train between Ambert and La Chaise-Dieu. This historic line crosses Livradois-Forez's rolling landscapes—high meadows, pine woods, and small granite villages—offering an unusual railway perspective on the Regional Natural Park.

Explore Parc Naturel Régional Livradois-Forez around Ambert. Marked hiking trails, forest roads, and country paths lead through mid-mountain terrain where granite plateaus, steep valleys, and conifer forests alternate.

Craft your own sheet of handmade paper at the Richard de Bas mill. Each participant dips the mold into the paper pulp vat and creates their own sheet following the centuries-old gestures of master papermakers. The mill shop offers notebooks, stationery, printed texts, and pressed-flower papers.

Ride the AGRIVAP tourist train between Ambert and La Chaise-Dieu. This historic line crosses the rolling Livradois-Forez landscapes—high-altitude meadows, fir forests, and small granite villages—offering an unusual railway perspective on the Regional Nature Park.

Explore Livradois-Forez Regional Nature Park around Ambert. Marked hiking trails, forest roads, and cross-country paths wind through mid-mountain terrain alternating granite plateaus, steep valleys, and conifer forests.

visits.text: Amnéville Zoo spreads across 18 hectares with 2,000 animals from 360 species in natural habitats. Gorilla Island houses a family of 12 lowland gorillas, the Tropical Vivarium shelters 500 reptiles, and the polar bear enclosure recreates the Arctic tundra. The African savannah, Asian jungle, and American plains offer immersive scenographies. Educational shows (sea lions, birds of prey) punctuate the 5 km walk, about 4 to 5 hours for a complete visit.

The Amnéville thermal baths draw their 34°C water from a 1,500-meter-deep source rich in trace elements. The 6,000 m² complex features 25 pools (wave pool, whirlpools, aquatic jets), 14 saunas and hammams, and a wellness area. The outdoor lagoon, open year-round, offers winter bathing under snow. Aquagym sessions, underwater massages, and aquabike complement the facilities.

activities.text: Walygator Park, Lorraine's largest amusement park, offers 40 attractions on 45 hectares. The Monster wooden roller coaster reaches 90 km/h, Comet plunges from 35 meters in vertical drop, and Anaconda loops upside down at 80 km/h. Family areas (Octopus, Magic Carousel), water attractions (Colorado River, Gold Mine), and themed shows. May to September, 10 am to 7 pm, full day needed.

The Snowhall indoor ski slope, unique in eastern France, maintains -4°C year-round on its 620-meter main run. Skis, snowboards, sleds, and tubing suit all levels. The 35-meter-high slope includes red and blue runs, a snowpark, and a beginner area. Equipment rental on-site, 2-hour sessions, ski and snowboard lessons available. An alternative for off-season skiing.

visits.text: Bambouseraie en Cévennes in Générargues, a unique botanical garden in Europe created in 1856. The giant bamboo forest covers 84 acres sheltering over 1,000 bamboo varieties reaching 82 feet high. The Zen Japanese garden with red bridge, stone lanterns, and koi carp offers a meditative interlude. The reconstructed Laotian village presents traditional stilt houses surrounded by banana trees and lotus flowers. Tropical greenhouses gather tree ferns, orchids, and exotic plants. The maze-like park invites shaded strolling, refreshing in summer.

Village of Anduze, traditional Cévennes town and gateway to the Cévennes at the Gardon confluence. Tortuous medieval alleyways climb from quays bordering the river. The Protestant temple clock tower overlooks a covered square hosting weekly markets. Corbelled houses with colorful facades testify to traditional Cévennes architecture. Workshops perpetuate manufacture of famous Anduze vases, monumental glazed pottery adorning gardens since the 17th century. Shops offer chestnuts, Pélardon, chestnut honey, and local products.

Maison Rouge – Musée des Vallées Cévenoles, installed in a 17th-century mansion. Ethnographic collections reconstruct daily Cévennes life: traditional interiors, agricultural tools, silk weaving looms, domestic utensils. The exhibition evokes the silk-farming epic with silkworm breeding that enriched the region until the 19th century. Thematic rooms present chestnut groves, crafts, Cévennes Protestantism, Wars of Religion. Temporary exhibitions deepen local history and heritage.

Steam Train of the Cévennes, historic tourist line connecting Anduze to Saint-Jean-du-Gard. Century-old locomotives pull Belle Époque carriages for eight miles along the Gardon de Mialet. The winding route crosses tunnels, viaducts, and spectacular Cévennes landscapes. Commentary relates the railway's history, created in 1880 to transport silk, wood, and chestnuts. Restored stations preserve period railway architecture. The one-hour round trip plunges into retro railway atmosphere.
Bamboo Grove in Cévennes at Anduze: botanical park (Sequoia avenue, Japanese garden).
Steam train of the Cévennes (option) between Anduze and Saint-Jean-du-Gard.

activities.text: Canoe-kayak descent of the Gardon River from Anduze. The clear river winds between limestone cliffs and pebble beaches under forest cover. Moderate rapids alternate with calm sections suitable for swimming. Rental companies offer routes from 4 to 15 miles depending on level and available time. The Gardon canyon reveals caves, emerald pools, and preserved wild landscapes. Cliffs shelter reintroduced griffon vultures soaring over gorges. The family activity allows discovering the Cévennes from the river.

Explore Trabuc Cave, an underground network of five miles with 0.75 miles developed for visits. Galleries reveal millennial formations: stalactites, stalagmites, ochre-tinted calcite draperies. The Lake of One Hundred Thousand Soldiers astounds with its 100,000 threadlike stalagmites unique in the world. Cathedral-like chambers impress with their dimensions and exceptional geological formations. The constant 57°F temperature offers welcome coolness in summer. The 45-minute guided tours recount the cave's use as a Camisard refuge.

Taste Cévennes products at local farms and producers. Pélardon AOC, small aged goat cheese, comes plain, ash-covered, or with aromatic herbs. Dried, creamed, or candied chestnuts illustrate the historic importance of the chestnut tree, the Cévennes "bread tree." Full-bodied chestnut honey, heather, or wildflower comes from transhumant apiaries. Sweet onions of the Cévennes AOC cook as confit or raw in salads. Artisan canneries offer terrines, confits, and traditional Cévennes dishes.
Stroll through Anduze: pottery and artisan workshops.
Short Cevennes loop on trail (nearby viewpoint) for views over the valleys.

days_plan.itin_title: Gard Road Trip: Roman Nîmes, Pont du Gard & Camargue Wilderness
Languedoc-Roussillon, France: Medieval Carcassonne, Vineyards and Mediterranean Coast

visits.text: Château d'Anet, jewel of the French Renaissance built in 1548 for Diane de Poitiers, mistress of King Henri II. Philibert Delorme, Benvenuto Cellini, and Jean Goujon created a masterpiece that led Joachim Du Bellay to call it the 'paradise of Anet.' The surviving wing houses period furniture and sumptuous tapestries.

Diane de Poitiers' funeral chapel, built by her daughter to house her magnificent tomb, the work of Pierre Bontemps. After centuries of adventures, her remains were identified and placed here in 2010. The trompe-l'œil dome and checkerboard floor create a striking illusion.

Château entrance gate, a veritable triumphal arch in antique style with four gilded Doric columns. The monumental clock shows the moon phases, symbol of Diana the huntress. The sculpted group depicting Diana embracing a stag is a copy of the original in the Louvre.

Royal chapel of the château, a masterpiece with a Greek cross plan featuring a coffered dome and checkerboard floor creating a mirror effect. A unique example of Renaissance architecture where geometric decoration draws the eye toward the celestial heights.

activities.text: Walk through the royal Eure valley around Anet, where the river winds between meadows and groves. This bucolic landscape inspired Renaissance poets who praised the 'garden carpeted with eternal greenery' of Diane's estate.

Discover the village of Anet and the Church of Saint-Cyr-Sainte-Julitte, whose construction was financed by Diane de Poitiers. The stained glass windows and furnishings testify to the royal favorite's generosity toward her parish.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure-et-Loir Circuit: Chartres, Châteaux & Proust

visits.text: The château commands its promontory above the Maine River with 17 towers of black schist and sandstone. Inside these walls hangs the Apocalypse Tapestry—103 meters of UNESCO-listed medieval textile that tells the Book of Revelation in wool and silk.
The château gardens weave together Renaissance kitchen gardens and grapevines, offering sweeping panoramas over the city and the Maine valley below.
Saint-Maurice Cathedral showcases the distinctive domed vaults of Angevin Gothic architecture. Its stained glass windows have filtered light since the 12th century.

The 13th-century Toussaint Abbey houses the David d'Angers Gallery. A contemporary glass roof floods the space with light, illuminating the monumental sculptures of this local artist. His original plaster casts served as models for works now displayed in the Panthéon and Père-Lachaise Cemetery.
Step through the doorway of Maison d'Adam, a 15th-century half-timbered house adorned with intricate wood carvings that have survived five centuries.
The Museum of Fine Arts occupies the 15th-century Logis Barrault, presenting collections spanning from the Middle Ages to contemporary art.

activities.text: Terra Botanica is Europe's first theme park dedicated to plants. Its 5,000 species from five continents sprawl across 22 hectares. The tethered balloon lifts you 150 meters above the gardens for a bird's-eye view of this botanical universe.
Stroll along the Maine riverbanks and cross into the Doutre quarter via the bridges. The quays offer striking perspectives of the château rising above the water.
The Saumur region's wine cellars produce crémants and white wines. Several estates offer tastings in their troglodyte caves carved into the hillsides.

days_plan.itin_title: Maine-et-Loire Road Trip: Anjou and Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: Angles-sur-l'Anglin has been classified among the Most Beautiful Villages of France since 1982—the only one in the Vienne department. Medieval houses tumble down a rocky spur between the river and the plateau.
The 11th-century fortress towers 40 meters above the Anglin. Its majestic ruins—towers, ramparts, chapel—offer panoramic views over the valley and the village rooftops below.

The Roc-aux-Sorciers Interpretation Center presents a reconstruction of a 20-meter sculpted frieze, 15,000 years old. Considered the "Lascaux of sculpture," the original site is closed to the public for conservation reasons.
Step into the village's craft workshops. The Jours d'Angles embroidery technique, invented here, once employed over 300 needleworkers in the 1950s. Demonstrations are offered in season.

activities.text: Canoe or kayak down the Anglin. Rental facilities are available on-site, a few kilometers from the village.
Hike along the cliffs of the Anglin and then the Gartempe. The trail passes by troglodyte dwellings near Saint-Pierre-de-Maillé.
Want a fun outing? The Tèrra Aventura app offers "Les Jours d'Angles sont contés," a geolocated treasure hunt through the village.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: The Cité internationale de la BD occupies a former warehouse on the banks of the Charente. Over 20,000 original comic plates, cutting-edge temporary exhibitions, and Europe's largest comic book library. Allow 2 hours to make the most of it.

The Cathédrale Saint-Pierre is Romanesque, not Gothic — and that changes everything. The sculpted 12th-century façade tells the story of the Ascension and the Last Judgement across 70 stone figures. The contemporary Treasury by Jean-Michel Othoniel is worth a detour.

The ramparts walk offers a full panorama over the Charente below. Angoulême sits on a rocky spur — you can see why it served as a stronghold. It's also the best vantage point for spotting the comic book murals.
Over 30 monumental murals across the streets: Titeuf on a gable end, Lucky Luke at a crossroads, Blake and Mortimer round a corner. Free map at the tourist office. Kids love it — adults too.

Under the Halles centrales, producers sell pineau, rillettes and cagouilles (local snails). Around them, cobbled lanes climb towards the town hall housed in the former comtal castle. Good bistros in the area.

activities.text: Guided tour 'Comics in the City'. The guides know the stories behind every mural: who painted what, why there, the hidden details. Duration 1h30, departure from the tourist office.

Walk along the Charente riverbanks. The towpath runs from the Cité BD along the river. Canoe hire available at the watersports centre in season. Quieter option: traditional gabare boat with commentary.
Musée d'Angoulême in the former bishop's palace, behind the cathedral. Varied collections: Charente archaeology (the famous gold Agris helmet), African arts, regional paintings. Small but well done.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: Conflans raises its medieval town on a rocky spur overlooking Albertville. This upper town has preserved its ramparts, fortified gates, and arcaded houses.
The Grande Place opens onto a vertiginous panorama embracing the Isère Valley and the snow-capped Alpine peaks. Café terraces invite contemplation.
Cobbled lanes wind between artisan shops and art galleries. Passage under the arcades shelters from showers and sun.
The Red House owes its name to the bricks adorning its medieval facade. This jewel of Savoyard architecture now houses a contemporary art center.
The Baroque church displays its gold and stucco in the shadows. The monumental altarpiece illustrates the religious fervor of the Duchy of Savoy.
Annecy spreads its canals and flower-lined quays at the foot of the Alps. Nicknamed the Venice of the Alps, the old town enchants with cobbled lanes and pastel-colored houses.
The Palais de l'Île rises from the middle of the Thiou like a stone ship. This former 12th-century prison is the most photographed monument in the city.
Cross the Lovers' Bridge linking the Gardens of Europe to the Pâquier. Legend promises eternal love to couples who kiss there.
The Gardens of Europe form a green setting at the lakeside. Century-old plane trees shade the pathways where the statue of chemist Berthollet stands.
Annecy Castle has dominated the old town since the 12th century. Former residence of the Counts of Geneva, it houses a museum dedicated to regional history and Alpine traditions.
Saint-Pierre Cathedral blends Gothic and Renaissance styles. Saint Francis de Sales was ordained Bishop of Geneva here.
The arcades of Rue Sainte-Claire shelter the market on Tuesdays, Fridays, and Sundays. Stalls overflow with cheeses, charcuterie, and local products.
The Visitation Basilica crowns the heights of Annecy. Its soaring bell tower is visible from anywhere in town while interior mosaics illuminate the nave with shimmering colors.
The relics of Saint Francis de Sales and Saint Jeanne de Chantal rest in this basilica built in the early 20th century.
The Semnoz peaks at 1,699 meters offering a 360-degree panorama of Lake Annecy, Mont Blanc, and the Bauges. The winding road crosses forests and alpine pastures.
The Semnoz viewpoint allows a sweeping view of the entire lake, from Talloires to Duingt, with snow-capped peaks as backdrop.
The lake ecomuseum in Sevrier traces the life of fishermen and farmers who lived by the water before the rise of tourism.
Old Town of Annecy – canals, Pont Perrière, Palais de l'Isle (exterior)
Château d'Annecy (esplanades & museums)
Lake tour (Albigny–Sévrier sectors) – photo spots
Col de la Forclaz viewpoint above the lake (panorama, car access + short walk)
Planfait site – lake view & paragliding takeoffs

You can't miss this iconic 12th-century building perched on an island in the Thiou Canal, shaped like a ship's prow. Once a prison, mint, and courthouse, this architectural gem now houses a museum chronicling Annecy's fascinating history and unique architecture.

Rising above the old town, this fortress of the Counts of Geneva has watched over Annecy since the 12th century. Wander through medieval towers, explore galleries showcasing regional art and lake archaeology, then climb the ramparts for breathtaking panoramas sweeping across the old town, shimmering lake, and Alpine peaks beyond.

Regarded as Europe's purest lake, this 27 km² Alpine jewel dazzles with crystalline turquoise waters. Born 18,000 years ago from melting glaciers, the lake mirrors the majestic mountains that embrace it—a postcard scene that shifts with every hour of daylight.

Crowning the hillside above town, this Romano-Byzantine basilica built between 1922 and 1949 houses the tombs of Saint Francis de Sales and Saint Jane de Chantal. The terrace rewards visitors with a spectacular 360° panorama embracing Annecy, the lake, and the surrounding Alpine summits.

The Grotte de Choranche opens at the foot of the Presles cliffs, 500 meters above sea level. Two underground rivers flow through galleries reaching up to 15 meters in height. Thousands of fistulous stalactites—delicate calcite straws of crystalline white hanging over three meters long—create a spectacle unique in Europe.

Inside the cave, the proteus creatures fascinate: these blind, pigment-free cave dwellers from Slovenia can fast for months and live up to 80 years. The tour concludes with a sound-and-light show in the Cathedral Hall, 40 meters in diameter and 25 meters high.

The Palais de l'Île in Annecy, built in the 12th century on a rocky islet in the Thiou River, resembles a stone galley. Over the centuries it served as a prison, mint, courthouse, and old-age home. It's been a Historic Monument since 1900.

Cross the Pont Perrière for the iconic photo of the Palais de l'Île bathed by the turquoise waters of the Thiou. Inside, an exhibit traces the architecture and heritage of Annecy through the centuries.

The Château d'Annecy dominates the old town from its rocky promontory. The imposing Queen's Tower dates from the 13th century. The courtyard façades bear witness to four centuries of evolution, from the Middle Ages to Renaissance style.

Lose yourself in the old town's cobbled streets along canals lined with colorful houses. The ancient fortified city, born in the 12th century when artisans settled along the Thiou to harness its water power, has kept its medieval charm intact.

activities.text: The Conflans viewpoint offers a plunging view of Albertville and the confluence of the Arly and Isère rivers.
Sit down at one of the inns to taste Savoyard specialties: fondue, tartiflette, and diots sausages in white wine.
The discovery trail retraces the history of this stronghold that commanded access to the great Alpine valleys.
Rent a bike and ride the greenway encircling the lake for 42 kilometers between beaches, villages, and Alpine panoramas.
Lake Annecy, renowned as one of Europe's purest, invites swimming in its turquoise waters.
Pedal boats and electric boats allow sailing facing the Tournette massif that dominates the lake.
Treat yourself to artisanal ice cream while strolling along the quays where canals reflect colorful facades.
Head up to Semnoz at day's end to watch the sunset over the Alps. Colors set the sky ablaze and reflect on the lake.
The 42 km lake cycling loop follows the greenway winding through the villages of Menthon, Talloires, Duingt, and Saint-Jorioz.
Try stand-up paddle yoga on the calm lake waters at dawn. The experience blends sport, meditation, and communion with nature.
The sandy beaches of Saint-Jorioz and Sevrier allow swimming in 22-degree water in summer.
Boat or pedal boat rental on Lake Annecy (weather dependent)
Tandem paragliding experience (classic sites: La Forclaz 45.800700, 6.243600 / Planfait 45.843300, 6.211800)
Cycling greenway around the lake (Annecy–Saint-Jorioz section, round trip)

Glide across Lake Annecy on a 1- or 2-hour cruise. From the water, you'll witness the mountains framing the lake in dramatic fashion, picturesque villages dotting the shoreline, and elegant estates gracing the water's edge.

The Lake Annecy Greenway offers 40 km of safe, scenic cycling with stunning lake views at every turn. The flat, easy route welcomes riders of all abilities—perfect for families and leisurely explorers alike.
Try stand-up paddleboarding, rent a canoe or kayak to explore hidden coves, or take your first sailing lesson. The lake's calm waters create ideal conditions for water sports of all kinds.
Le Pâquier, a vast 7-hectare esplanade on the lakeshore, offers a panorama of mountains plunging into turquoise waters. An orientation table identifies each peak. The swans have made it their home.
Visit the Jardins de l'Europe, an English-style park filled with century-old trees, for a stroll between the lake and old town. Sculptures dot paths shaded by remarkable specimen trees.
The Lake Annecy bike loop follows a secure 42-km cycle path. Rental shops offer traditional and electric bikes starting from the old town.
In summer, swimming in the lake is essential. Public beaches in the city center provide access to some of the purest water in Europe.

Sandstone quarter — chaos of blocks and woodland paths.

visits.text: Ansouis — hilltop village facing the Luberon, sloping streets and stone houses on rocky spur.
Château d'Ansouis — dominant silhouette over the Aigues valley (exteriors and esplanades).
Museum of Wine Arts and Crafts (at Château Turcan) — immersion from vine to glass.

activities.text: Walking loop among vineyards, olive trees and cherry trees at the foot of the village.
Southern viewpoints over the Aigues valley (heritage route).

visits.text: The Picasso Museum sits enthroned in Grimaldi Castle overlooking the sea: 250 works by the master, influenced by Antibes' colors and light.
Lose yourself in Old Antibes: ancient ramparts, Provençal alleyways, colorful shutters, cathedral with carved wooden doors.
Fort Carré raises its bastions 26 meters above the sea: views over the Bay of Angels, Nice outlined on the horizon.
Saint Bernardin Chapel hides colorful ceilings and striking Baroque paintings behind its neo-Gothic facade.
Stroll along Port Vauban, one of the largest in the Mediterranean: legendary yachts moored at the "billionaires' quay."
The Safranier quarter, a "free commune" in the heart of Old Antibes, displays its flowered facades and bohemian atmosphere.
Antibes — old Antibes, ramparts and Grimaldi castle (Picasso museum).
Cap d'Antibes — coastal path (coves, rocks, pine trees).
Port Vauban — esplanades and panorama over the docks.
Biot — artisanal glassworks, Fernand Léger museum and stroll through shaded alleys.
Antibes — old town, Picasso museum, ramparts and port Vauban.
Cap d'Antibes — coastal path, coves and viewpoints.
Phare de la Garoupe — Shadows & storms.
Villa Ephrussi — Presences in the garden.
Port Grimaud Market (Provençal stalls)
Port Grimaud → Antibes route (A8)
Old Antibes (ramparts, narrow streets, Provençal Market)
Picasso Museum (Château Grimaldi)
Fort Carré (panoramas over Vauban harbor)
Juan-les-Pins: beach day (YOLO Plage / fine sand)

activities.text: The Tire-Poil trail follows Cap d'Antibes for 5 kilometers: mineral cliffs, secret coves, sumptuous villas hidden in vegetation.
Swim at Gravette beach: fine sand, crystal-clear waters, authentic setting at the foot of the ramparts.
Climb to La Garoupe lighthouse: one hundred steps, then a 180° panorama over the sea, Mercantour, and Estérel.
Discover Villa Eilenroc at Cap d'Antibes: neoclassical castle designed by Charles Garnier, remarkable gardens open on Saturdays.
The Provençal market on Cours Masséna overflows with scents and colors every morning except Monday.
Easy cycling loop Antibes ↔ Juan-les-Pins along the seafront.
Supervised swimming (seasonal): Garoupe beach.
Bike route between Antibes and Juan-les-Pins.
Swimming at la Garoupe beach or in Juan-les-Pins.
Access: public (lighthouse)
Access: public (villa)
Evening at the harbor / gentle nightlife
Sunset walk at cap d'Antibes (coastal path)

Provence, France: Lavender Fields, Hilltop Villages and Riviera Towns
Provence, France: Lavender Fields, Hilltop Villages and Riviera Towns

visits.text: Parc de Sceaux extends south to Antony. The Grenouillère pavilion offers dining by the Grand Canal.
The Saint-Saturnin church dates back to the 12th century. The Romanesque bell tower testifies to Antony's ancient history.

activities.text: The Vallée aux Loups shelters Chateaubriand's House. The writer lived here from 1807 to 1818 and penned his Memoirs from Beyond the Grave. The landscape park preserves centuries-old trees.
The Bièvre river flows through the wooded valley. Once polluted, the stream is gradually recovering its purity in preserved natural areas.

Discovery of the thematic gardens of the Saline.
Exploration of the Osselle cave and its limestone concretions.
Saline Royale (UNESCO).
Ledoux Museum.

activities.text: Walk through the villages of Salins-les-Bains and Port-Lesney to admire the Loue.

Gardens.
