days_plan.itin_title: Doubs, France Natural Tour: Gorges, Waterfalls & Craft Heritage
Jura Mountains Road Trip, France: Comtois Traditions & Emerald Lakes

visits.text: Arcachon's Winter Town is a unique quarter created in the 19th century to welcome spa visitors. Over 300 Belle Époque villas with eclectic architecture hide in a wooded park on the heights. Styles vary: colonial, Moorish, neo-Gothic, Swiss chalet. A stroll through the lanes reveals these architectural gems. Costumed guided tours are regularly organized by the tourist office.

The Dune du Pilat is Europe's highest dune at 104 meters tall and 3 km long. A member of the Grands Sites de France network, it's in perpetual motion, advancing 1 to 5 meters per year toward the forest. A 160-step staircase facilitates the climb from April to November. The panorama from the summit is spectacular: on one side the Atlantic Ocean and Banc d'Arguin, on the other the Landes forest stretching endlessly. Allow 30-45 minutes to climb and descend.

Arcachon Bay is a 155 km² lagoon connected to the ocean by channels. At its center, Île aux Oiseaux (Bird Island) and its two tchanquées cabins (cabins on stilts) are the bay's emblems. Strong tides (up to 4 meters amplitude) transform the landscape: at low tide, oyster parks are accessible on foot. The bay circuit by road measures about 80 km and lets you discover different oyster-farming villages.

Jetée Thiers extends 250 meters into the bay from Arcachon's central beach. It's the embarkation point for boat excursions to Île aux Oiseaux, Banc d'Arguin, and Cap Ferret. Built in 1865, it has been rebuilt several times after storms. The pier's end offers beautiful views of the Winter Town and villas. Pleasant stroll at any hour, particularly at sunset.

Cap Ferret's oyster villages (L'Herbe, Le Canon, La Vigne) have preserved their authenticity. Colorful oyster farmers' cabins line up along the piers. You can taste fresh oysters directly from producers, feet in the water facing the bay. The atmosphere is peaceful, far from tourist bustle. L'Herbe village, with its small Algerian chapel, is particularly photogenic.

Pereire Beach is one of Arcachon's four beaches, on the bay side. Quieter than the central beach, it's appreciated by families for its shallow calm waters and absence of waves. Colorful beach cabins line the seafront. The beachfront promenade offers beautiful bay and boat views. Several restaurants and ice cream shops are located along the waterfront.
Ascent of the Dune du Pilat, the highest dune in Europe.
Walk along the Arcachon seafront and in the Ville d'Hiver district.

activities.text: Oyster tasting in an oyster farmer's cabin. Arcachon Bay produces over 8,000 tons of oysters annually. Oyster farmers welcome visitors directly to their cabins for tastings. You'll taste oysters facing the bay, accompanied by bread, butter, and lemon, with a glass of white wine. Some cabins also offer seafood platters. Authentic atmosphere and affordable prices.

Boat excursion on Arcachon Bay. Several companies offer guided outings to Île aux Oiseaux and its tchanquées cabins, Banc d'Arguin, or Cap Ferret. Some cruises include onboard oyster tasting. Duration varies from 1 to 3 hours depending on circuits. Boats generally depart from Jetée Thiers in Arcachon. Remember to check tide schedules which influence departures.

Cycling around Arcachon Bay. The bike path network totals over 220 km around the bay. The complete circuit measures 80 km but you can choose shorter sections. The route is mostly flat and crosses pine forest. You'll pass through oyster villages, beaches, and the Dune du Pilat. Bike rentals available in all bay communes.

Excursion to Banc d'Arguin, a nature reserve at the foot of Dune du Pilat. This 4 km long sandbank emerges at low tide and hosts numerous migratory bird species. Access is by boat only (departures from Arcachon or Cap Ferret). On site, you can swim in shallow waters, picnic, and birdwatch. Watch tide schedules for the return.

Climbing Cap Ferret Lighthouse. This red and white striped lighthouse, 53 meters tall, can be visited from Easter to All Saints' Day. You must climb 258 steps to reach the summit but the 360° panorama is worth the effort. You'll discover Arcachon Bay, Conche du Mimbeau, Dune du Pilat, oyster parks, and the ocean. On clear days, views extend up to 40 km. Souvenir shop at the lighthouse base.

Low tide outing with an oyster farmer. This unique experience lets you discover the oyster farmer's trade from the inside. You'll board the boat to work on oyster parks at low tide. The oyster farmer explains farming stages, daily work, and trade challenges. The outing typically ends with a tasting. Duration 3 to 5 hours depending on tides. Reservations required several days in advance.

Swimming at Arcachon beaches. The town has four bay-side beaches (Eyrac, Thiers, Pereire, Abatilles) and several ocean beaches nearby (Moulleau, Pyla). Bay beaches are ideal for children with calm shallow waters. Ocean beaches offer waves for surfing and bodyboarding. All beaches are supervised in season. Deckchair and parasol rentals available on main beaches.
Cruise in the Arcachon basin to observe the tchanquées huts and Bird Island.

days_plan.itin_title: Gironde Road Trip: Bordeaux, Vineyards & Arcachon Bay
Southwest France Journey: Atlantic Coast to Pyrenees Mountain Peaks

visits.text: The Church of Saint-Germain, a historic monument since 1862, blends Gothic, Renaissance, and Classical styles. Its facade, richly adorned with expressive gargoyles, dominates downtown. The Gothic nave contrasts with the Renaissance chancel.

The Château des Ducs, rebuilt in the 14th century after the Hundred Years' War, was a royal residence of François I. Catherine de Medici and Henri IV stayed here. Nighttime lighting dramatizes the architecture.

Climb to the top of the Tour Marguerite, a 12th-century vestige of fortifications erected under Henry I Beauclerc, son of William the Conqueror. Its rampart walk offers a 360° panorama over the town and the Argentan plain.

The Maison des Dentelles, housed in a 19th-century bourgeois residence beside the Parc de la Noé, traces the history of Argentan needlepoint. From 17th-century pieces to contemporary creations, the collection spans four centuries of needlepoint lace.
The Church of Saint-Martin, dating from the 15th to 17th centuries, preserves beautiful old stained glass. Its Flamboyant Gothic style completes the town's religious heritage.

The Fernand Léger–André Mare Museum, in the childhood home of the Cubist painter, honors these two 20th-century artists from Argentan. Interactive exhibits and digital tools make modern art accessible to all.

activities.text: At the Abbey of the Benedictines, the nuns perpetuate the art of Argentan needlepoint. This lacemaking technique, distinct from Alençon needlepoint, was prized by the courts of France and Spain in the 17th and 18th centuries.
Along the Orne, a landscaped promenade passes Fernand Léger's birthplace. Verdant banks and a pond compose a peaceful waterside route.
Argentan lies at the heart of horse country. Nearby stud farms and the hippodrome shape local equestrian life. The Haras du Pin is just 9 miles away.

days_plan.itin_title: Orne Road Trip: Norman Bocage and Prestigious Stud Farms

visits.text: Quai Lestourgie. Row of houses with wooden balconies and slate roofs that testifies to Argentat's gabarier past. It was the main loading port and departure point to Aquitaine - gabares were also called "argentats" because many were built here. Three historic ports line the Dordogne.
Heritage House. Exhibition on the history of the gabariers and life in the Dordogne valley before the construction of the dams.

activities.text: Theatrical gabare cruise through the Dordogne gorges. Theatrical cruises with actor departing from Grafeuille (10 min drive from Argentat). Duration 1h15, minimum 8 people per departure. A storyteller brings to life the epic of the gabariers in the wild gorges upstream of the town.

Canoe trip down the Dordogne. Several routes possible from Argentat: sporty 8 km route (1h30-2h) with class 2 rapids to Monceaux, or adventure route of 22-25 km (full day) to Beaulieu. Wild landscapes, Corrèze forests, possibility of picnic break on pebble beaches.
"Tous sur le pont" Festival. First weekend of July, Argentat celebrates its gabarier past with entertainment, reenactments and the legend of the Coulobre, a monstrous serpent that terrorized boatmen.

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley

visits.text: Old bridges.
Saint-Benoît Chapel.

days_plan.itin_title: Indre, France: Secret Berry Region and Vallée Noire Rural Villages

visits.text: Fortified village clinging to a basaltic spur above the nascent Loire; remains of the county castle.
Romanesque church and successive viewpoints over the deep gorges.
Route through paved alleyways revealing low walls and lava stone houses.
The Château d'Arlempdes, the first castle on the Loire from its source, rises from an 260-foot volcanic dike that the river wraps in a meander. Its ruins date from the 12th to 14th centuries.
Climb up to the Saint-Jacques castle chapel, built in red stone and dating from the 11th or 12th century. Inside, the keep and the Guards' Hall were renovated in 2016.
The 11th-century postern, inscribed as a Historic Monument in 1971, served as the entrance gate to the castle town. Its high pointed barrel vault marks the entrance to the fortified village.

The Romanesque Church of Saint-Pierre (12th century) features a single nave and a gable bell tower with four arches. Outside, a 15th-century Gothic calvary in sculpted stone is the sole vestige of the old cemetery.
Arlempdes is classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages. Its volcanic stone houses huddle at the foot of the basalt spur whose vertical walls plunge toward the Loire.

The site is recognized by the BRGM (French geological survey) as rare in France: the rocky eminence is a "dike," a feeder conduit of an ancient volcanic chimney exposed by erosion. The stacks of basalt prisms heighten the spectacle.

activities.text: Arlempdes gorges loop (3-4 km, balcony passages).
Volcanic landscape reading from the summit esplanade.
Take the "Rocher d'Arlempdes" trail for a spectacular viewpoint over the village, its castle, and the Loire's meander from the heights.
Descend to the pebble beach by following the castle town's enclosure. The wild Loire, barely 25 miles from its source, flows between basalt flows sometimes resembling organ pipes.
In summer, the Loire offers a cool oasis for waterside picnics. Anglers find grayling, trout, and minnows here.

days_plan.itin_title: The Volcanoes of Auvergne: A Road Trip Through Medieval Towns & Lunar Landscapes
Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Arles — city of Art and History, Roman/Romanesque ensemble classified UNESCO (ext.).
Luminous old center: squares, private mansions and quays of the Rhône.
Exploration of the Arena of Arles and the ancient theater.
Walk through the historic center and discovery of the Saint-Trophime cloister.
Discovery of the arenas of Arles and the ancient theater.
Flamingo watching at Parc ornithologique du Pont de Gau.

activities.text: Classical Roman walking routes (amphitheater, theater, Alyscamps ext.).
Stroll on the quays at sunset.
Visit to the Arles Antique departmental museum to complete the Roman discovery.
Walk along the ponds of the Camargue and sunset over the salt flats.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage
Roman Provence Itinerary: Uzès, Nîmes, Arles and Orange
Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages

visits.text: Built in 1470 by Louis Malet de Graville, the Arpajon market hall stretches 35 meters. Its oak and chestnut framework rests on sandstone foundations.
Classified as a historic monument in 1921, the hall hosts a traditional market every Friday and Sunday. The Sunday market features about twenty stalls selling fresh produce.
Since 1922, the Bean Fair has been held in mid-September under the halls. This regional event celebrates the Chevrier bean, a local flageolet variety discovered in 1872.
The old town preserves historic houses around the market square. The Orthodox church testifies to the Russian presence in the region.

activities.text: Follow the banks of the Orge River downstream from Arpajon. The river flows through the valley between meadows and groves, creating a peaceful setting for hiking.
Discover the market gardening heritage in the surrounding area. The Arpajonnais was long known for its vegetable production destined for Paris's Les Halles market.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: Arras's twin squares—Grand'Place and Place des Héros—showcase 155 Flemish baroque gabled facades, every single one a protected monument. It's architectural harmony on a breathtaking scale.
The 75-meter belfry, built in 1463, rises above Place des Héros as a UNESCO symbol of communal freedom. Climb all 365 steps for sweeping views across the Artois countryside.
Descend 12 meters into the Boves, ancient chalk quarries carved out in the 9th century. These underground galleries sheltered thousands during World War I bombardments.
The town hall, rebuilt in the 1920s after its 1914 destruction, blends neo-Gothic elegance with Art Deco flair. Its sculptures were recreated from original molds salvaged from the rubble.
The Museum of Fine Arts occupies the 18th-century Saint-Vaast Abbey. Its collections span Flemish and French painting from the Middle Ages through modern art.

activities.text: Wander beneath the arcades to discover local specialties: Arras tripe sausage, gingerbread hearts, and chocolate rats—a quirky local tradition.
The Wellington Quarry plunges 20 meters underground into tunnels carved by New Zealand soldiers. These passages sheltered 24,000 troops before the Battle of Arras in April 1917.
Visit Vauban's 17th-century citadel, a UNESCO masterpiece. This star-shaped fortress showcases the genius of Louis XIV's legendary military architect.

days_plan.itin_title: Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: Arreau, at 700 meters altitude, occupies an exceptional position at the confluence of the Aure and Louron valleys, where the Neste d'Aure meets the Neste du Louron. Former capital of the Four Valleys and seat of the judicature until the 16th century, then of the lieutenancy until 1789, the town was an important economic center thanks to its fairs, markets, and cloth-making craft. Classified as a Great Occitanie Site and Land of Art and History, it is protected by a Heritage Protection Zone created in 1995 covering the entire municipal territory.

The Maison des Lys, classified as a Historic Monument, is a 16th-century Gothic building whose half-timbered facade is adorned with fleurs-de-lis in homage to Louis XI. Its base is in gray Pyrenean marble and its two cantilevered floors give it a slender silhouette characteristic of the valley's medieval civil architecture.

The Chapel of Saint-Exupère, classified as a Historic Monument, is distinguished by its 16th-century Gothic bell tower that dominates the village. Its Romanesque entrance consists of six columns topped by a tympanum adorned with a chrism. Inside, the stained glass, colored ceiling, and statues trace devotion to Saint-Exupère, 5th-century Bishop of Toulouse and supposed native of Arreau - the 16th-century school adjoining the chapel would be his birthplace.

The Church of Notre-Dame, listed as a Historic Monument since 1989, features a square tower bell tower and houses a remarkable 16th-century Pietà. Nearby, the chapels of Saint-Michel de Garian (12th century) and Notre-Dame-du-Bon-Rencontre, the latter called "pilgrims' chapel," complete the town's religious heritage.

The Château des Nestes, on the banks of the Neste du Louron, is a former 17th-century sawmill symbolizing the union of the two rivers. It now houses the Pyrénées2vallées Tourist Office and the Cagot Museum, dedicated to this marginalized community from the Middle Ages to the Ancien Régime. The museum is open daily. Two hundred meters away via rue Saint-Exupère, the Château de Ségure preserves a 16th-century square tower built directly on rock, replacing a keep four hundred years older. It is now the headquarters of the Aure Louron Community of Communes.

Arreau's remarkable houses line the streets: the Maison Foche (or Maison Pic-Molié), Maison Feraud, Maison Laguens, Maison Ducuing-Forgue and others testify to rich civil architecture from the Middle Ages to the 19th century. The Halle-Mairie, built in 1932 replacing a 16th-century wooden hall, hosts a traditional market every Thursday under its remarkable framework.

The Chapel of St. Exuperus, a classified Historic Monument, takes its name from the Arreau peasant who became the sixth bishop of Toulouse in the 5th century. The Romanesque porch (10th-12th century) shelters a tympanum adorned with a chi-rho. The octagonal bell tower and 16th-century Gothic nave are of exceptional structure. The chapel's grandeur stems from its political role: it served as a meeting place for representatives of the Aure valley, and the archives of the Four Valleys were kept in the bell tower chambers.

The Maison des Lys, a classified Historic Monument, is a magnificent late-16th-century Gothic residence. Its finely sculpted gray marble façade supports two corbelled half-timbered floors adorned with wooden fleurs-de-lis, honoring King Louis XI after the Four Valleys' allegiance to the French Crown in 1475.

The Château des Nestes (or Château Camou), a listed Historic Monument, recalls ten centuries of Aure valley history. A former military and hospitaller commandery built on the enclosure of the Neste du Louron quarter, it protected the sanctuary of St. Exuperus. Its central tower topped with a wooden bell turret served as a family astronomical observatory in the 19th century.

The market hall-town hall, built in 1932 on the site of the 16th-century wooden hall, houses the Thursday market on the ground floor. Its exterior walls are decorated with faux timber framing echoing the style of Aure valley houses. A three-faced clock turret crowns the building. The ensemble testifies to Arreau's role as economic capital of the Four Valleys since the Middle Ages.

The Church of Notre-Dame d'Arreau preserves a treasury of Pyrenean religious art, including a remarkable 16th-century Pietà. The village also harbors the Chapel of Notre-Dame-du-Bon-Rencontre (1761, pilgrims' chapel), the Romanesque-origin Chapel of St. Michael, and a small museum of the Cagots tracing the history of this marginalized Pyrenean population.

The marked historical circuit starting from the Château des Nestes lets you discover Arreau's remarkable residences: Maison Féraud with exceptional framework decoration, Maison Foch (which belonged to the marshal's grandfather), Maison Laguens with pink marble piers, Maison Ducuing-Forgue. The entire municipal territory has been protected by a Heritage Protection Zone since 1995.

activities.text: Tour the town on foot following the heritage circuit: from the Maison des Lys to the Chapel of Saint-Exupère, then along the Neste du Louron to the Château des Nestes, each facade tells a chapter in the Four Valleys' history.
Visit the Cagot Museum in the Château des Nestes to discover the little-known history of this excluded community that lived in the Pyrenean valleys for centuries.
On Thursday mornings, shop at the market under the Halle-Mairie to taste valley products: mountain cheeses, charcuterie, gâteau à la broche, and Pyrenean honey.

Climb the Col d'Aspin (1,489 m) via the D918, legendary stage of the Tour de France cycling race, for a panorama over peaks and valleys - cyclists can attempt the ascent from Arreau, about 12 km of climbing.
Families will appreciate the Aigles d'Aure, Pyrenean falconry center in Arreau, where free-flight bird of prey demonstrations are presented in a mountain setting.

Stroll along the flower-lined banks of the Neste d'Aure and Neste du Louron, the two rivers that give Arreau its unique charm. The village, at 2,306 feet elevation, is classified as a Grand Site of Occitanie and Art and History Region, a crossroads between the Aspin and Peyresourde passes.

Excursion to the Col d'Aspin (4,885 feet), a legendary Tour de France stage. Exceptional panorama over the central Pyrenees. In summer, you can hike toward the Signal de Bassia or Lake Payolle (3,051 feet), a verdant jewel at the foot of Pic du Midi.

Discover Pyrenean gastronomy in Arreau's restaurants: garbure, Barèges-Gavarnie lamb (PDO), sheep's milk cheese, black pork of Bigorre. The Thursday market under the halls perpetuates a centuries-old commercial tradition.
River fishing in the Neste, renowned for its brown trout. Arreau is an ideal starting point for whitewater fishing outings in a preserved mountain setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: From Tarbes to Cirques and Valleys
Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: Lourdes, Gavarnie & Pic du Midi

visits.text: The remains of the Mulberry B artificial harbour emerge from the sea like sleeping giants. At low tide, the concrete Phoenix caissons reveal the scale of this technical feat that enabled the landing of 2.5 million men and 4 million tonnes of equipment. The floating pontoons and breakwaters bear witness to Allied daring.

Explore the fully renovated D-Day Museum, facing the very remains it documents. The large 28 m² animated model and video mapping precisely illustrate the construction and operation of the Mulberry harbour. Archive films and period artefacts complete this 90-minute immersive experience.

At the Arromanches 360° circular cinema, immerse yourself in the history of the Battle of Normandy. Images projected across nine screens envelop you in the story of the 100 days following the landings through to the liberation of Paris.

activities.text: Climb to the museum's panoramic terrace. The viewpoint takes in the entire Bay of Arromanches and conveys the sheer scale of Operation Overlord.
Discover Norman gastronomy in the seafront restaurants. Moules-frites, sole meunière and farmhouse cider are enjoyed against the backdrop of the artificial harbour remains.
Visit the Battle of Normandy Museum in nearby Bayeux. This museum deepens your understanding of the Normandy campaign with its collections of vehicles and uniforms.

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy

visits.text: The Allymes Castle raises its medieval silhouette above the plain. This 13th-century fortress commands the passages between Bugey and Dauphiné.
The Cerveyrieu Waterfall tumbles through the Thurignin Gorges with a thunderous roar. A viewing platform allows admiration of this spectacular cascade.
Set off to discover the Clairefontaine Waterfall nestled in a green setting. The forest path leads to this curtain of water that cools the summer air.
The Niaz Waterfall surges from a rocky crack in a wild setting. Hikers appreciate this preserved site far from the beaten path.
Thirty-five minutes by road, the Glandieu Waterfall is undoubtedly the most beautiful in the Ain. Its 60-meter drop impresses visitors.
The Grand Colombier peaks at 1,534 meters offering a 360-degree panorama of the Alps, Jura, and Ain plain. On clear days, Mont Blanc stands out on the horizon.

activities.text: The Groin Gorges attract canyoning enthusiasts. Roped and helmeted, they navigate pools and natural slides.
The Lèbe Observatory offers fun astronomy activities for stargazing far from urban light pollution.
Experienced cyclists challenge the Grand Colombier slopes, a legendary pass used by the Tour de France.
Rent bikes and ride the Lock circuit winding to Belley, capital of Bugey.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: The Church of Notre-Dame-des-Vertus, listed as a historic monument since 1908, preserves a 17th-century organ still in service. In 1336, a young girl prayed for rain here and saw the eyes of the Virgin's statue streaming with tears: this miracle made Aubervilliers a major pilgrimage site until the 18th century.
The church's stained-glass windows, redone after World War I destruction, illustrate the various miracles that occurred here. The baroque facade was built by Louis XIII in 1628.

Les Laboratoires d'Aubervilliers occupy 900 m² of a former precision metalwork factory in the Quatre Chemins neighborhood. This transdisciplinary artistic creation venue features a garden designed by landscape architects, with a terrace, greenhouse, and pergola.
Aubervilliers town hall, housed in a former 19th-century farm, contains an ceremonial salon adorned with neoclassical frescoes depicting allegories of work and abundance.
The Théâtre de la Commune, a national theater, has presented contemporary creations since the 1960s. Its sober building integrates into the downtown urban fabric.

activities.text: Walk along the banks of the Saint-Denis canal on the Aubervilliers side to admire the footbridges inherited from the Paris Games: the Pierre-Larousse footbridge in recycled steel and the Lucie Bréard footbridge, 13 meters wide, dedicated to soft mobility.
Square Stalingrad, in the heart of downtown, offers a green pause enhanced by a fountain. Settle on a bench before setting off to explore the shopping streets.
Want to discover an unsuspected world? Aubervilliers's Chinese wholesale district constitutes one of Europe's largest wholesale trading centers.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: The underground church of Saint-Jean is the largest in Europe: 27 m long, 16 m wide, nearly 20 m high, carved into the cliff in the 12th century. Monumental nave, reliquary hewn from the rock, some 170 tombs in the floor. Stunning.

The church of Saint-Jacques at the top of the village: Romanesque façade with Hispano-Moorish carvings, a reminder of the pilgrims passing through on the Way to Compostela. Finely chiselled archivolt portal.

The village tiers like an amphitheatre above the Dronne. Cobbled lanes, white houses with tiled roofs, Spanish-style flower-decked balconies. Classified as one of the Most Beautiful Villages of France since 1993.
The Place Ludovic Trarieux, heart of the village, honours the founder of the League of Human Rights, born here. Lime-tree-shaded terraces, shops, artisans. The spot for a coffee.
Saint-Jean monolithic church and white alleyways.

activities.text: Visit the monolithic church. Open year-round except 25 Dec and 1 Jan. Bring a layer — it's cool inside. The exceptional acoustics occasionally draw concerts.
Swimming in the Dronne. The managed beach below the village has sand, a shaded lawn, slides. Lifeguards in summer. Canoe hire on site.
Canoeing on the Dronne. Gentle routes from the village base. Clear water, wooded banks. Return by shuttle.
Artisan workshops. The village is home to potters, painters, sculptors. Open studio-shops in summer. One-off pieces, meet the creators.
River beach on the Dronne; swimming break (summer).

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days
Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: Aubigny-sur-Nère is nicknamed "Scottish City." In 1423, Charles VII granted the lordship to Jean Stuart of Darnley, a Scottish captain who came to France to fight the English. His descendants kept Aubigny until 1672. The château, half-timbered houses, street names (Stuart, Darnley, Douglas) recall this surprising heritage.

The Château des Stuarts (16th-19th centuries) mixes Renaissance and classical styles. The interior houses the Auld Alliance museum, recounting Franco-Scottish relations since the Middle Ages. You'll learn everything about the Stuarts of Aubigny, Scots who fought for France, cultural exchanges. Guided tour, free for under 18s.

Aubigny's historic center survived a fire in 1512 relatively well. Many half-timbered houses date from the 16th century. Rue des Dames, rue du Charbon, place Adrien-Arnoux: each street has its share of sculpted beams and corbelled facades. The Maison Ronde, a remarkable 15th-century house, hosts temporary exhibitions.

activities.text: The Franco-Scottish Festivities, every year on Bastille Day weekend, are Aubigny's major event. Pipe bands, kilts, Highland Games (caber toss, tug-of-war), Scottish dancing, whiskies. Over 30,000 visitors, 20 Scottish pipe bands. The parade on Sunday morning is spectacular.

The Aubigny Pipe Band, founded in 1975, is one of France's oldest civilian pipe bands. Rehearsals Thursday evenings at the château, open to the public. If you've never heard bagpipes up close, it's an impressive experience.

The Auld Alliance Monument, facing the château, honors Scots who died for France. A plaque recalls the links between Aubigny and Scotland — links that endure: the town has been twinned with East Kilbride since 1990.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: The International City of Tapestry, inaugurated in 2016, celebrates six centuries of know-how inscribed on UNESCO's intangible heritage list since 2009. In the transformed former National School of Decorative Arts, the 600 m² Nef des Tentures (Tapestries Nave) with 7-meter ceilings presents masterpieces in theatrical scenography. From medieval tapestries to contemporary creations inspired by Tolkien or Miyazaki, the immersive journey fascinates.

The 'Hands of Aubusson' space within the City reveals what the UNESCO inscription covers: interpretive tapestry, the fruit of the meeting between an artistic project and the know-how of an art craftsman. Discover the daily life of weavers, dyers, cartoon makers, and restorers. A workshop allows observation of the essential touch of the weaver on their low-warp loom.

The City's resource center, heir to the former ENAD library, constitutes the first documentary collection on tapestry in Europe: 16,500 works, artist files, iconographic archives. Researchers and enthusiasts can consult unique documentation on this textile art.

The old town of Aubusson nestles in a meander of the Creuse. Weavers' houses with sloping roofs line the quays. The Clock Tower, remnant of fortifications, overlooks the historic center. At Place d'Espagne, terraces invite pauses. The peaceful atmosphere of this town in the countryside seduces with its preserved authenticity.

activities.text: The tapestry workshops of Aubusson, about twenty still in activity, keep alive the sector of 180 local jobs: spinning mills, dye works, cartoon makers, weavers, restorers. Some open their doors by appointment. The City offers immersive 24-hour 'textile tours' to discover the Aubusson textile ecosystem.

The banks of the Creuse in Aubusson offer a pleasant walk. A trail follows the river from the town center, passing under old bridges. The reflections of houses in the water create a peaceful tableau that the Impressionist painters of the neighboring valley would not have disowned.

days_plan.itin_title: Creuse Circuit: Valley of the Painters and Aubusson Tapestries

visits.text: Sainte-Marie Cathedral in Auch is a UNESCO World Heritage site. This Flamboyant Gothic cathedral built between 1489 and 1548 measures 102 meters long. The 18 stained glass windows by Arnaud de Moles (1507-1513) rank among the finest of the French Renaissance. The 113 oak choir stalls (1510-1552) present over 1,500 carved figures. Two monumental organs complete this exceptional ensemble.

The monumental staircase completed in 1863 links the upper and lower towns across 35 meters of elevation. Its 374 steps (234 in the central flight plus double flights) alternate with terraces and fountains. On the first landing, Jaume Plensa's contemporary sculpture Observatory of Time evokes the 1977 flood. Lower down, the statue of d'Artagnan watches over the Gers valley. On clear days, the Pyrenees form a backdrop on the horizon.

The Jacobins Museum presents Gallo-Roman archaeological collections, medieval artifacts, and sacred art. Egyptian antiquities and pre-Columbian art are also on display. The former Dominican convent housing it is a fine example of medieval architecture.

activities.text: Descend the monumental staircase to the lower town. Each landing offers a different view over the valley. The central fountain and terraced gardens bordered by vines create a pleasant atmosphere.
Thursday morning market spreads across several squares in the town center. It's one of the largest markets in the Gers with poultry, cheeses, vegetables, and Gascon specialties.
Wander the medieval lanes of the upper town. Rue Dessoles is the most commercial with its shops and restaurants. Half-timbered houses and private mansions testify to the past as capital of Gascony.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: The Church of Saint-Sulpice, built in the 12th century by stonemasons in service to the Abbey of Cluny, is Aulnay-sous-Bois's oldest structure. Its Romanesque transept and choir are listed as historic monuments.
The Vieux Pays neighborhood preserves the atmosphere of a village within the city. Around the church, the Ferme du Vieux-Pays and a few old houses bear witness to Aulnay's rural past.
The Demeure Gainville, likely the town's oldest house, was inhabited by the chemist who contributed to the discovery of bleach. It now hosts a space dedicated to art exhibitions.
Aulnay features lovely early-20th-century millstone villas inspired by Art Nouveau. Exposed brick, ceramics above windows, wrought-iron railings: set out to discover them along the streets.
Parc Dumont, laid out around the former villa of the founding abbot of the subdivision, offers a verdant setting with an adjoining municipal library.

activities.text: The Parc du Sausset covers 200 hectares north of the town. Its varied landscapes—meadows, woods, bodies of water—make it ideal terrain for walking, cycling, and birdwatching.
Reach Aulnay from Paris via the Ourcq canal bike path. A pleasant dozen kilometers through the landscapes of northeast Paris.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: Aumont-Aubrac is a major stop on the GR65, the Via Podiensis pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela, inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List. The village sits at the crossroads of the ancient Roman Via Agrippa (Lyon-Toulouse) and the Santiago trail.

Saint-Étienne Church blends Romanesque and Baroque. Its 11th-century semi-circular apse is the oldest section, vaulted with pointed-arch ribs. The 14th-century nave features ribbed vaults resting on corbels carved with human figures and grotesques.
The Maison du Prieuré, a 1684 building with a pointed-arch portal and mullioned windows, houses the Tourist Office. Its vaulted cellar hosts exhibitions and regional product sales.

Javols-Anderitum, 6 km away, was the Gallo-Roman capital of the Gabales, a Gallic people whose territory corresponds to present-day Lozère. The archaeological site covered 40 hectares in the 2nd century. A circuit of 19 information panels and a "Javols 3D" augmented reality app reconstruct the forum, baths, and theater-amphitheater.

The archaeological museum at Javols presents two major pieces: a limestone milestone and a life-size statue of Silvanus-Sucellus, a Gallo-Roman forest god, carved from local red sandstone—a unique artifact.

The statue of Christ the King, erected in 1946 on the Truc del Fabre hilltop, commemorates the absence of civilian casualties in the village during World War II. The promontory offers sweeping views across the Aubrac and Margeride ranges.

activities.text: Reach the Aubrac plateau via the Route des Lacs from Nasbinals. Vast pastures, stone burons (former shepherds' huts), Aubrac cattle with "mascara eyes." The Déroc waterfall plunges 33 meters through a basalt chaos.

Taste aligot, the Aubrac's emblematic dish: mashed potatoes worked at length with fresh Laguiole AOP tome cheese and garlic. Village restaurants prepare it by hand, in the dining room, in front of guests.

Hike the GR65 between Aumont-Aubrac and Nasbinals (27 km). The trail crosses vast high-altitude pastures, passes the Domerie d'Aubrac—a hospice founded in 1120 for pilgrims—and its "lost bell," which guided travelers stranded in fog.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes

visits.text: Descend the Rampes du Loch built on the ruins of the old fortress. The view plunges down over the rooftops of Saint-Goustan harbor and the Auray River.
The 13th-century stone bridge crosses the Auray River on four arches. It connects the upper town to the port of Saint-Goustan.
Place Saint-Sauveur is framed by half-timbered houses with overhanging upper floors. The oldest colorful façades date from the 15th century. This is where Benjamin Franklin landed in 1776.
Climb the steep lanes of Rue Saint-Sauveur and Rue Saint-René up to the church. The cobbled alleyways are lined with artist galleries and artisan workshops.
Saint-Gildas Church is entirely classified as a Historic Monument. Its architecture bears witness to the construction of the medieval fortress.
The neo-Gothic basilica of Sainte-Anne-d'Auray dominates Brittany's premier pilgrimage site. The cloister, miraculous fountain, and war memorial complete the ensemble.

activities.text: The grand Monday morning market attracts 400 vendors in summer. Seafood, local cheeses, and the buttery aroma of kouign-amann fill the air.
Follow the Loch River northward from Quai Franklin. The 75-acre wooded area shelters shelducks and gray herons.
From Port-Blanc in Baden, catch the ferry to Île aux Moines in just 5 minutes. Nicknamed the Pearl of the Gulf, it offers 10 miles of coastal trails and the Kergonan stone circle.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: The Château Saint-Étienne has raised its listed keep over the heart of the town since medieval times. Within its volcanic stone walls, the Muséum des Volcans spans 600 m² of permanent exhibits on the geology of Europe's largest stratovolcano: interactive models, rocks, minerals and collections of 30,000 pieces tell the story of Earth's upheavals. The garden terraces offer a panoramic view over the town.

The Abbatiale Saint-Géraud bears witness to Aurillac's religious prestige since the 9th century. Founded by Count Saint Géraud, it marked a major stop on the Way of Saint James. Admire the majestic nave, the Romanesque remains and the 18th-century organ that still resounds during concerts.

The historic centre reveals its Renaissance townhouses, witnesses to the past prosperity of the Cantal capital. Stroll through lanes where lava stone lends the façades an austere elegance. The Place du Square hosts the statue of Pope Gerbert, illustrious local son who became Sylvester II.

activities.text: The covered market reveals Cantal's gastronomic treasures inside its hall built in 1890. Local producers offer PDO cheeses, artisanal cured meats and regional products. On Saturday mornings, the outdoor market spills across the town centre squares in a warm and authentic atmosphere.

The International Street Theatre Festival transforms Aurillac into a giant stage every August. Companies from around the world take over streets and squares for free shows blending circus, dance and theatre in a festive and popular atmosphere.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions

visits.text: Rocamadour — tour of the castle ramparts (exterior) and lower streets.
Autoire — village of blonde stone houses at the foot of the cirque.

activities.text: Autoire waterfall — walking loop to the falls (short round trip).
Cornices of the Autoire cirque — viewpoints (one way from the village).
Site of the "châteaux des Anglais" (troglodytic shelters, view from the path).

days_plan.itin_title: Bastide Villages of France: Cliffside Abbeys & Medieval Fortified Towns

visits.text: Mountain town; houses grouped around the church and market.
Plateau meadows and forests; trail and path starting points.

activities.text: Easy forest loop to the clearings (4–6 km).
Heritage trail of the center and old farms.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: Visit of Notre-Dame d'Autrey Abbey and its gardens

activities.text: Walk in the Mortagne valley

days_plan.itin_title: Vosges Abbeys and Mountains: Monastic Heritage and Green Valley Silence

visits.text: Saint-Lazare Cathedral.
Roman theater.
Temple of Janus.
Ramparts.
Château de la Verrerie.
Museum of Man and Industry.

activities.text: Mâconnais Vineyards.
Bresse Ecomuseum.
Bresse poultry.
Market (Monday).
Park.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: Auvers‑sur‑Oise — Château d’Auvers: immersive parcours on Impressionism and the 19th‑century Paris region; formal terraces above the valley.
Auberge Ravoux (Maison de Van Gogh) — Final room of Vincent van Gogh (1890) and documented ambiance of a village inn.
Église Notre‑Dame‑d’Auvers — Romanesque‑Gothic church made famous by Van Gogh’s painting; 12th–13th century volumes, listed monument.
Cemetery of Auvers — Graves of Vincent and Theo van Gogh under ivy; moving site above the wheatfields.

activities.text: Waymarked painters’ trail through the fields and the Oise bluffs; start mid‑afternoon to catch soft light.
Dinner on the village square; book terraces on weekends.

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: Discovery of the classified village of Auvillar and its circular 18th-century market hall.
The circular grain market stands at the center of a triangular square. Unique in Southwest France, its Tuscan columns support timbers that have sheltered markets and fairs since medieval times.
The Clock Tower—a 17th-century monumental gate—combines brick and stone. The last vestige of fortifications, it houses the River Navigation Museum recounting the era of Garonne boatmen.
Saint-Pierre Church preserves exceptional Baroque furnishings. Its Flemish tapestries and classified organ case testify to the town's artistic prominence.
The Museum of Old Auvillar displays 18th-century faïence. Thirteen workshops once produced these ceramics exported via the Garonne to Bordeaux.
Descend to Auvillar Port where flat-bottomed boats once moored laden with faïence. The mariners' chapel of Sainte-Catherine still watches over the river.

activities.text: Walk along the Garonne and observation of the panorama over the valley.
Reach the belvedere overlooking the Garonne. The river winds through orchards and Gascon hillsides in a sweeping panorama.
Walk the Peyrat path, an ancient pilgrimage route to Compostela. Pilgrims have climbed from the port to the hilltop village for centuries.
Browse the Sunday morning market on Place de la Halle. Farmers and artisans animate this bastide classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages since 1994.

days_plan.itin_title: Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages
Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: Saint-Étienne Cathedral has towered over Auxerre since the 13th century. Its unique 68-meter tower can be spotted from miles away. Inside the Romanesque crypt lies the only known depiction of Christ on horseback.

Descend into the Carolingian crypt of Saint-Germain Abbey, built between 841 and 859. Its 9th-century frescoes—including the stoning of Saint Stephen—rank among France's oldest surviving wall paintings.
The Clock Tower, erected in the 15th century, marks the beating heart of the old town. Its two Gothic dials display both the hours and lunar phases—a proud symbol of Auxerre's communal independence.
Saint-Eusèbe Church, built in the 12th century, preserves a Romanesque bell tower and remarkable stained glass. It once housed Saint Germain's relics before their transfer to the abbey.

Head to Place Charles Surugue, the former pillory square. A fountain crowned by a statue of Cadet Roussel—a local bailiff turned folk-song hero—stands at its center, surrounded by colorful half-timbered houses.
Step into the Museum of Art and History, housed in the former monks' dormitories of Saint-Germain Abbey. The collections span from prehistory through contemporary times.

activities.text: Stroll along the Yonne riverbanks in the Marina quarter. Moored barges and evening views of the illuminated cathedral and abbey create Auxerre's most iconic panorama.
Follow the 'In the Footsteps of Cadet Roussel' trail: 67 curiosities dot the old town, winding through cobbled lanes, half-timbered houses, and Renaissance façades.
Cycle to the Caves de Bailly-Lapierre, birthplace of Crémant de Bourgogne, set in a former underground quarry spanning 4 hectares, 60 meters beneath the earth.

days_plan.itin_title: Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: Old town of Avallon: ramparts and half-timbered houses
Tour de l'Horloge of Avallon: climb and viewpoint
Collégiale Saint-Lazare: sculpted portal

The Collegiate Church of Saint-Lazare, founded in the 12th century, preserves a Romanesque portal of exceptional richness. Spiral columns, archivolts carved with a zodiac and labors of the months, scrollwork and Greek key patterns rival Vézelay and Autun.
The Clock Tower, erected in 1456, rises 49 meters high. A former municipal belfry, it marks the entrance to the old town. Its clock mechanism still functions.
The medieval ramparts, flanked by six circular towers, bastions, and sentry boxes, encircle the rocky promontory. The Gaujard Tower (1438) and Escharguet Tower (1522) are among the best preserved.
The Jean Després Museum of Avallonnais presents archaeological collections from Arcy-sur-Cure caves, Art Deco goldsmith works, and an ensemble of Yao people costumes.

The House of the Lords of Domecy, on the collegiate square, dates from the 15th century. Its corbelled turret houses a spiral staircase. The neighboring 1490 salt granary now hosts temporary exhibitions.
Avallon's terraced gardens, cultivated since the 10th century, descend in tiers beneath the ramparts. These green spaces offer multiple viewpoints over the Cousin valley below.

activities.text: Panoramic route on the viewpoints of Avallon
Descend into the Cousin valley via the Petite Porte promenade. The 70-meter elevation drop under linden trees opens a panorama over the first Morvan hills and converted old mills.
Follow the 'Frog Circuit,' a 3-km urban route marked by bronze studs in the ground. It passes all of Avallon's major monuments: Clock Tower, ramparts, collegiate church, and historic squares.
On Saturday morning, market day, the upper town comes alive. Morvan producers offer cheeses, charcuterie, and local specialties under the covered market and on the square.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul
Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: Palace of the Popes and episcopal complex at the heart of the ramparts.
Pont Saint-Bénézet and banks of the Rhône facing Villeneuve-lès-Avignon.
Place de l'Horloge and medieval layout of the old center.
Weekly market of L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue (flea market, stalls)
Lunch in L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue (e.g. Au Chineur)
Avignon: Palais des Papes and Place de l'Horloge
Discovery of the Palais des Papes and Pont d'Avignon.
Walk to Rocher des Doms with view over the Rhône.
Visit to Colorado Provençal and its ochre formations.
Discovery of the perched village of Gordes and panorama over the Luberon.
Walk to Fontaine-de-Vaucluse and observation of the chasm.

The Palais des Papes has towered over the city since the 14th century. The world's largest Gothic palace spans 161,000 square feet across 25 rooms open to visitors: chapels adorned with Matteo Giovannetti's frescoes, the pope's private apartments, and restored pontifical gardens.

Cross the Pont Saint-Bénézet, where four of the original twenty-two arches still stand. Built between 1177 and 1185, the bridge once stretched 3,000 feet across the Rhône. Two superimposed chapels survive on the second pier.

The Musée du Petit Palais occupies the former palace of Avignon's archbishops. Its collections bring together over 300 Italian medieval paintings and sculptures, including works by Botticelli and the Avignon School.

Climb to the Rocher des Doms, a public garden set on the rocky outcrop overlooking the Rhône. The panorama sweeps across the bridge, Villeneuve-lès-Avignon on the opposite bank, Mont Ventoux, and the Alpilles on clear days.
The 12th-century Romanesque Cathédrale Notre-Dame des Doms is crowned by a gilded Virgin atop the bell tower. Inside, discover Pope John XXII's tomb and a white marble episcopal throne.

Want to wander off the beaten path? Rue des Teinturiers follows the channeled Sorgue and preserves four ancient paddle wheels. Century-old plane trees, penitents' chapels, and weathered facades create a timeless scene.

activities.text: Intra-muros route along the ramparts and major squares.
Urban reading of Gothic and classical facades around the palace.
Bistronomic dinner within the walls (e.g. Le Bistrot de Florent)
Picnic on the banks of the Rhône facing the city of Avignon.
Discovery of the market of l'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue and its canals.
Walk Avignon's ramparts on foot. The 14th-century fortified ring stretches 2.7 miles and retains its towers and monumental gates.
Les Halles covered market welcomes around forty local producers every morning. Candied fruits, goat cheeses, olive oil, and Provençal tapenades.

In July, the Festival d'Avignon takes over courtyards, cloisters, and squares throughout the city. Theater, dance, and performances unfold in dozens of venues, from the Palais des Papes to the smallest chapels.
Savor a glass of Côtes-du-Rhône at one of the wine bars on Place de l'Horloge or Place Pie, in the heart of the old town.

visits.text: Immerse yourself in medieval scholarship at the Scriptorial d'Avranches, a remarkable museum housing the precious manuscript collection from the Mont-Saint-Michel abbey. This exceptional treasury preserves centuries of work by monk copyists, featuring illuminated texts, ornate calligraphy, and priceless documents that reveal the intellectual life of the medieval monastery. Interactive exhibits and meticulous displays unveil the secrets of manuscript creation.

Wander through the magnificent Jardin des Plantes d'Avranches, a member of the prestigious Union of Parks and Gardens of Normandy. This botanical paradise features twelve distinct thematic gardens showcasing diverse plant collections from around the world. The elevated position offers a spectacular panoramic vista across the entire bay to the Mont-Saint-Michel, making it one of the finest viewpoints in the region.

Pay respects at the American Military Cemetery in Montjoie Saint-Martin, a solemn memorial inaugurated in 1956 honoring nearly 4,000 American soldiers who gave their lives during World War II. This beautifully maintained site features rows of white marble crosses and Stars of David set amid immaculate lawns, offering a poignant reminder of the sacrifices made for liberation.

The Scriptorial is Europe's only museum dedicated to the manuscripts of Mont-Saint-Michel. Its collections comprise 200 volumes from the 8th to 15th centuries, including 70 produced directly by the abbey's scriptorium. The Treasure Room displays the most precious pieces, rotated every three months to preserve the ancient parchment.

Climb to the Jardin des Plantes, suspended above the Norman bocage. Created in 1796 for botanical experimentation and opened to the public in 1802, it comprises twelve themed spaces: camellia garden, hydrangea collection, cherry blossom meadow. From the belvedere, the panorama embraces the entire bay of Mont-Saint-Michel.

Saint-Gervais Basilica preserves the relic of Saint Aubert's skull, founder of Mont-Saint-Michel in 708. According to tradition, the hole visible in the frontal bone was left by the Archangel Michael's finger, who came three times to command the bishop to build a sanctuary on the rock.
Climb the keep and walk the ramparts of Avranches' castle. From the wall-walk, views extend over the town's slate rooftops and, on clear days, to Mont-Saint-Michel's silhouette on the horizon.

The Hortus medieval garden, at the ramparts' foot, recreates a Middle Ages orchard and vegetable garden. Aromatic, medicinal, and dye plants grow alongside a heritage fruit orchard, including the Louise Bonne d'Avranches, a pear born in the region.

The Patton Memorial, on the square of the same name, commemorates the July 31, 1944 breakthrough that allowed Allied forces to rupture the German front during Operation Cobra. A Sherman tank occupies the square's center, silent guardian of liberation.

activities.text: Visit the German Military Cemetery at Mont d'Huisnes, France's only German military mausoleum, a distinctive circular structure containing the remains of over 11,000 German soldiers. This unique architectural memorial provides a contemplative space for reflection on the shared human cost of war.

Explore the enchanting Parc du Château de Chantore, a magnificent 19-hectare landscaped estate featuring meandering rivers, cascading waterfalls, and an extraordinary collection of exotic trees. Discover spectacular rhododendrons, camellias, and rare botanical specimens in this romantic parkland that feels like stepping into a living painting.

At the Scriptorial, join a calligraphy or medieval illumination workshop. Parchment and vellum-making techniques are detailed according to the methods of monastic scribes who once labored by candlelight.
Avranches market runs Saturday mornings on place Littré and adjacent streets. Bay products, pre-salted lamb, bocage cider, and poiré (pear cider) tempt from every stall.
Reach the Avranches viewpoint platform at sunset. During spring tides, the spectacle of the sea encircling Mont-Saint-Michel is breathtaking—the tide rushes in at the speed of a galloping horse.

Set out on a guided bay crossing from the mudflats near Avranches. Barefoot in the shifting sands, naturalist guides explain tidal phenomena and the intertidal zone's wildlife, a fragile ecosystem between land and sea.

visits.text: Maison Bollinger has occupied the heart of Aÿ since 1829. Its cellars house 3,500 oak barrels maintained by Champagne's last working cooper.
The Deutz cellars burrow 20 meters into the hillside. Founded in 1838, the house produces champagnes composed of 80% grand cru grapes.
The Pressoir Henri IV dates from the 16th century. This historic press, now a protected monument, bears witness to the village's winemaking past.
The Église Saint-Brice dominates the village square. Its bell tower has watched over Pinot Noir slopes for centuries.

activities.text: Descend into the 19th-century cellars carved deep into the chalk. Millions of bottles age slowly in these underground galleries.
Walk through the grand cru parcels surrounding the village. Aÿ produces the Marne Valley's most powerful Pinot Noir.

days_plan.itin_title: Marne Road Trip: Reims, Épernay and the Champagne Route

visits.text: The château d'Azay-le-Rideau reflects in the waters of the Indre that surrounds it. Built on an island between 1518 and 1527, it embodies the perfect alliance between the French fortress tradition and the new Italian taste of the Renaissance.

The grand staircase, housed in a square tower open to the courtyard, marks an innovation: it's one of the first straight staircases with superimposed flights in the Loire Valley, breaking with the spiral staircase tradition.
Philippe Lesbahy's Renaissance chamber preserves a 16th-century Flemish tapestry and period furniture. The woodwork, hangings, and sculpted fireplace recreate the atmosphere of a seigneurial chamber.
Restored between 2015 and 2017, the château has recovered its roof in slate and tufa lozenges. The refurnished rooms present collections from the Mobilier National and Gobelins tapestries.
On the top floor, the timbered attics house an exhibition hall. The inverted ship's hull framework offers an impressive volume beneath the slate roof.
Château d'Azay-le-Rideau, a romantic jewel set upon the water like a mirage reflected in the Indre
The grand staircase of Château d'Azay-le-Rideau, an architectural innovation for its time with sculpted decorations
Philippe Lesbahy's Renaissance chamber at Azay-le-Rideau, a masterpiece of 16th-century interior design
The landscaped park surrounding Château d'Azay-le-Rideau, dotted with centuries-old trees and water features

activities.text: The English-style landscape park surrounds the château across several hectares. Lebanon cedars, sequoias, and remarkable trees border lawns descending gently toward the Indre and its reflecting pool.
In summer, the "Azay Remarquable" illumination show projects images and colors onto the château façades at nightfall, magnifying the reflections in the water.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The Baccarat Collection displays nearly 700 pieces along the Meurthe river. Chandeliers, tableware, and perfume bottles trace 260 years of craftsmanship since 1764.
The Harcourt glass commissioned by Louis-Philippe in 1841 ranks among the iconic pieces. Charles X's ewer and the Tsarina's candelabra testify to royal commissions.
The crystal armchair purchased by a Maharaja illustrates the relationship with India. The crystal works opened an office in Bombay in the 1880s.
Église Saint-Rémy forms a triangle symbolizing the Holy Trinity. Nicolas Kazis rebuilt it between 1953 and 1957 on the ruins of the old church.
Approximately 20,000 crystal plates compose Saint-Rémy's windows. The 150 different hues required 18 months of work by the Baccarat crystal works.

activities.text: Rue des Cristalleries features boutiques showcasing Baccarat crystal and Lorraine artisan creations.
Café Collection Baccarat overlooks the Meurthe river and Église Saint-Rémy. The terrace offers valley views.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: Bagnères-de-Bigorre, a thermal spa nestled at the entrance to the upper Adour valley and dominated by Pic du Midi, was known since Roman times as "Vicus Aquensis." The town has forty registered springs. A terrible earthquake in 1660 destroyed all dwellings, rebuilt in the same style. In 1823, construction of the Grand Thermes was launched, inaugurated in 1828, and the railway's arrival in 1862 accelerated resort development. In 1993, a "facades" operation restored the town's colors.

The Tour des Jacobins, classified as a Historic Monument in 1932, is the vestige of the former church and Dominican convent built around 1373. This thirty-five-meter-high belfry in Flamboyant Gothic features a square base over two levels then an octagonal section. Its first-floor bays offer 15th-century molding with round arches topped by accolades and finials. Partially destroyed by lightning, it was rebuilt in the 16th century.

The Church of Saint-Vincent, classified as a Historic Monument in 1990, constitutes an edifice of primary importance for High Pyrenean architecture after the 14th century. Built outside the walls in the 13th century on the site of older buildings, it was profoundly altered between the late 14th and early 16th century. Its bell-gable, portal, vaults mixing stone and wood, and frameworks are remarkable.

The Musée Salies, listed as a Historic Monument in 2014, occupies an Art Deco building designed by architect Léon Jaussely and completed in 1931, on Place des Thermes. Its facade is inspired by the 1925 Paris International Exhibition of Decorative Arts, with allegorical figures and bas-reliefs of female nudes. Collections include paintings from major 19th-century Paris salons, obtained thanks to deputy Achille Jubinal and his friendship with Princess Mathilde, as well as the Blanche Odin collection (1865-1957), watercolorist nicknamed "the Fairy of roses and flowers," and Pyrenean folk art objects bequeathed by Jeanne Sayous.

The Musée du Marbre, installed in the former Thermes du Salut whose main building dates from 1781, presents the Jacques Dubarry de Lassale collection: 320 European marble origins, including about a hundred Pyrenean quarries from the Spanish Basque Country to Languedoc. The historical gallery preserves original marble cabins and bathtubs, paving, and a stairway testifying to Pyrenean marble-working expertise. It is the only collection of this type displayed in France. The museum also houses a space dedicated to bats, with infrared camera observation of colonies nesting in the attics in summer.

The Médous Caves, located between Bagnères and Campan in Asté commune, were discovered by speleologist Norbert Casteret. The approximately forty-five minute to one-hour visit takes place at 13°C and crosses the Gallery of Wonders, where concretions, eccentrics, petrified waterfalls, gours, and draperies succeed one another, including a column twenty meters in circumference. The visit ends with a boat ride on the underground river in the cave's largest chamber.
Crossing the Aspin pass, famous Pyrénées route offering spectacular panoramas.
Discovery of Bagnères-de-Bigorre, charming spa town at the foot of Pic du Midi.

The Salies Museum, a listed Historic Monument since 2014, presents an Art Deco façade completed in 1931 by architect Jaussely, inspired by Paris's 1925 Exposition des Arts Décoratifs. Founded in 1852 by deputy Achille Jubinal, it brings together canvases from the great 19th-century Paris salons, Barbizon School landscapists (Daubigny, Dupré, Jongkind), an Orientalist room, and 48 watercolors by Blanche Odin, nicknamed the Fairy of Roses.

The Jacobins Tower, sole remnant of the 14th-century Dominican convent, stands in the heart of Bagnères. Its massive, austere architecture, typical of the mendicant order, testifies to the town's medieval past.

The Church of Saint-Vincent, a classified Historic Monument since 1990, constitutes the principal religious edifice of Bagnères-de-Bigorre. The Saint-Jean Cloister completes the downtown religious heritage.

The Marble Museum, installed in the former Salut thermal baths, displays France's only collection of over 400 varieties of European marbles, including about a hundred from Pyrenean quarries. The Espiadet marble from Payolle was used for Versailles, the Louvre, and the Paris Opera.

The Médous Caves, discovered in 1948 in Asté, rank among France's most beautiful underground wonders. Over a 0.6-mile course, stalactites, stalagmites, helictites, and calcite flowstones evoke cascades and draperies. The visit concludes with 820 feet by boat on the underground Adour—a moment of rare intensity. Constant temperature of 55°F.

The Pic du Midi de Bigorre (9,439 feet), a Grand Site of Occitanie, shelters an astronomical observatory founded in the 1870s. Accessible in 15 minutes by cable car from La Mongie, it offers 8,000 square feet of 360° panoramic terraces spanning 186 miles of Pyrenean chain. The Pont dans le Ciel, a 39-foot glass walkway jutting over the void, and Europe's highest planetarium complete the experience.

activities.text: Walk through Bagnères city center starting from the Tour des Jacobins toward the Baltard-style covered market (1896) with its metal framework and glass roof, then along the Grand Thermes in classical style to the Musée Salies.

Visit the Musée du Marbre in the Vallon de Salut, then continue the walk via the 4.5 km pedestrian circuit linking the Vallon to the Allées Maintenon, a classified natural site bordered by beautiful trees and named in honor of Louis XIV's second wife.
Descend into the Médous Caves for the underground boat crossing - a magical moment that delights children and adults alike, to combine with a stop at the Allées Maintenon leading to the site.

For an exceptional panorama, take the road toward the Pic du Midi de Bigorre (accessible from the Col du Tourmalet or by cable car from La Mongie), or simply climb to Parc Bédat for a transition between town and wild nature.

Additionally, the surroundings offer the Gargas Caves in Aventignan, a prehistoric sanctuary with negative hands dating back 27,000 years, the Esparros Caves with aragonite concretions, and the Château de Mauvezin, a medieval fortress ten kilometers away.
Relaxing experience at Aquensis: bubbling lagoons and oriental hammam under monumental framework.
Walk through the historic center of Bagnères and its local market.

Wellness cure at the Grand Thermes de Bagnères-de-Bigorre, a thermal spa since Roman times (Vicus Aquensis). The naturally hot waters (122°F) are renowned for their therapeutic virtues. The Aquensis spa space offers treatments and relaxation.

Stroll through the Vallon du Salut, a classified site since 2007 and gathering place for Bagnères residents since the 18th century. The path winds beneath the canopy of centuries-old trees, carried by the murmur of warm thermal springs.

Stargazing evening at Pic du Midi: observation from the world's largest International Dark Sky Reserve, certified since December 2013. Instant Science facilitators guide the discovery of constellations and celestial phenomena.

Excursion to Col du Tourmalet (6,939 feet), the highest paved pass in the Pyrenees and a legendary Tour de France stage since 1910. En route, stop at Lake Payolle (3,051 feet), a verdant jewel at the foot of Pic du Midi, ideal for picnicking and family walks.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: From Tarbes to Cirques and Valleys
The Pyrenees Spa Trail: Thermal Baths from Ax-les-Thermes to Bagnères-de-Luchon
Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: Lourdes, Gavarnie & Pic du Midi

visits.text: The thermal baths of Luchon rank among France's most renowned. Renovated in 2023, they treat rheumatological and respiratory conditions using the hottest sulfurous waters in the Pyrenees. Cures last 18 days but 5-day mini-cures are available. The Ressources & Vous spa with its thermal water pools and unique vaporarium in Europe is open to all.

The lime-tree-lined Allées d'Étigny link the baths to the town center. Created in the 18th century by the intendant of Auch, they give Luchon its spa town character. The Belle Époque façades of hotels and the casino testify to the golden age of thermal tourism.
The old town preserves 17th and 18th-century houses. The church of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption has a 12th-century Romanesque portal. The 19th-century covered market is still active.

activities.text: The Superbagnères ski resort is accessible by gondola from Luchon's center. In winter, 32 runs spread between 1,440 and 2,260 meters. In summer, the gondola operates for access to high-altitude hikes. The view from the summit embraces the entire Pyrenean chain.

The Lys valley is one of the most beautiful Pyrenean valleys. The road leads to the Hospice de France at 1,385 meters. From there, hikes depart toward high-altitude lakes and peaks over 3,000 meters. The Lys cirque with its waterfalls is spectacular.

Hikes around Luchon are countless. From Col de Peyresourde to Port de Venasque, passing by Lacs d'Oô or the Quayrats, there's something for every level. Trails are well marked and mountain refuges enable multi-day traverses.
The Luchon market operates daily in summer and three times weekly the rest of the year. You'll find mountain cheeses, artisan charcuterie, and local products.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: The Belle Époque Quarter, designed by Albert Christophle in 1886, unfolds its boulevards lined with sumptuous villas. Slate roofs, Armorican sandstone, sculpted balconies, and bay windows: a true open-air museum of the early 20th century.
Lake Bagnoles, shaped by human hands in the 17th century, is the heart of the resort. The casino from 1927, built on its shores, reflects Art Deco elegance in the calm waters.

The thermal establishment draws on a spring of aquamarine water, rich in trace elements, that has flowed for centuries. The first spa buildings date to the 17th century; the resort reached its zenith in the 1920s–1930s with the arrival of European aristocracy.

The Château de la Roche-Bagnoles, built in 1855 in neo-Renaissance style, now serves as the town hall. Its 15-acre arboretum shelters more than 150 tree species, including one of France's tallest giant sequoias.

Climb to the Roc au Chien, a natural lookout on a rocky outcrop of the Armorican Massif. The view sweeps over the lake, the thermal baths, and the forest. Two local legends surround the site—one involves a lord and his steed revived by the spring.

activities.text: The thermal spa treatments use natural mineral water with recognized benefits for phlebology and rheumatology. Half-day spa packages, hammam, or massage: the only thermal resort in northwest France.

The Andaines State Forest covers 13,350 acres around Bagnoles. Its trails traverse oak and beech groves; the Hippolyte oak is said to be over 300 years old. Arthurian legends cling to the gorges of Villiers.
The 16-mile cycling route from Bagnoles winds through the Andaines forest, suitable for the whole family. The Vélo Bocage greenway, a 12-mile path, links the resort to Briouze station.
