days_plan.itin_title: Hérault, France: Mediterranean Beaches and Languedoc Wine Country

visits.text: Biarritz: promenade from the Lighthouse (Pointe Saint-Martin) to Rocher de la Vierge, beaches and cliffs.
Anglet: seafront between Chambre d'Amour and Barre de l'Adour.
Bidart: center and coastal viewpoints; passage to Uhabia beach.
Rocher de la Vierge, Grande Plage and Saint-Martin lighthouse.

The Rocher de la Vierge rises dramatically from the ocean, connected to the mainland by a 76-meter iron footbridge built in 1887. The Virgin Mary statue installed in 1865 watches over seafarers from this windswept promontory.

Stroll along the Grande Plage, the resort's iconic beach since the Second Empire. Its striped cabanas and Casino Barrière evoke the golden age of aristocratic tourism when Empress Eugénie made Biarritz fashionable.

The Musée de la Mer showcases a fascinating collection of whale skeletons and taxidermied seabirds. Its aquariums recreate the Bay of Biscay ecosystem with live sharks and rays gliding through the waters.
Climb the Biarritz Lighthouse, built in 1834 on Pointe Saint-Martin. From the top, sweeping views stretch across the entire Basque coast to the Pyrenees rising in the distance.

activities.text: Surfing or bodyboarding introduction on supervised beach (conditions and season permitting).
Sunset at Uhabia: coastal walk and wave observation.
Coastal walk (Atalaye ↔ Côte des Basques).
Catch waves at Côte des Basques, the birthplace of European surfing since the 1950s when California surfers discovered these legendary breaks.
Dive into the Cité de l'Océan for an interactive journey through the marine world with surf simulators and immersive 3D experiences exploring ocean depths.
Relax at Port-Vieux, a sheltered cove where families have bathed safely since the 19th century, protected by natural rock formations from Atlantic swells.

days_plan.itin_title: Béarn & Basque Country: Pyrenean Passes to Atlantic Coast Soul
Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Pyrénées-Atlantiques Road Trip: Basque Country & Béarn

visits.text: Biot — alleyways and glassmaking tradition; glassblowing demonstrations.
Fernand Léger National Museum — works and monumental mosaics.

activities.text: Cool path along the Brague (departmental park).
Heritage trail through the village (doors, small squares).

days_plan.itin_title: French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary

visits.text: Seaplane Museum: 1,250m² retracing the transatlantic seaplane epic on the former Latécoère base. Starting in 1930, engineer Pierre-Georges Latécoère chose the lake for his routes to America and the West Indies. Mermoz, Saint-Exupéry, Guillaumet took off from these waters. Collection of restored seaplanes, period uniforms, models, engines and giant propellers. Interactive experiences and documentary films.

Lake Cazaux-Sanguinet: 5,600 hectares, France's second-largest freshwater lake. Crystal-clear waters with turquoise reflections nicknamed the Biscaraïbes. Fine sand beaches (Maguide, Navarrosse, Caton) bordered by pines. Gently sloping sandy bottom ideal for families. Clear view of the Dune du Pilat to the north on clear days.

Petit étang de Biscarrosse: Preserved fishing reserve in the forest's heart. Wild banks and absolute calm. Hiking trails allowing a complete loop. Wildlife observation: ducks, moorhens, herons. Access from the D652, developed parking.

activities.text: Seaplane discovery flight: Takeoff and water landing on the lake from Latécoère hydrobase. 20min flight over lakes, forest and ocean. Unique sensation of flying just above the water. Experienced pilots and maintained aircraft. Booking required, weather permitting.

Water activities on the lakes: Sailing, windsurfing, paddleboarding, water skiing. Several water sports centers around Lake Cazaux. Hourly or half-day rentals. Sailing lessons for children and adults in July-August. Designated zones for each activity. Mandatory life jackets provided.

Aquapark on the lake: Giant floating inflatable structures (slides, trampolines, obstacle courses). Accessible from age 6 who can swim. Renewable 1h sessions. Life jackets provided and mandatory. Lifeguards on site. Open June to September weather permitting.

Bike paths: 145km of greenways connecting Biscarrosse to neighboring towns and the Vélodyssée. Flat and shaded routes through the forest. Lake-beach-town loops. Classic and electric bike rental downtown and near beaches. Picnic areas along the routes.

days_plan.itin_title: Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: The Citadel of Bitche, a masterpiece by Vauban and Cormontaigne, dominates the town from its 330-meter-high sandstone peak. Redesigned between 1679 and 1754, it resisted the 230-day siege of 1870 without surrendering, an exceptional feat in the Franco-Prussian War. The audiovisual route 'L'Héroïque Siège' immerses visitors in 500 meters of underground tunnels: casemates, powder magazines, wells, and galleries where soldiers' voices echo. Above, the ramparts offer a 360° panorama of the Northern Vosges.

The Northern Vosges Regional Natural Park stretches over 130,500 hectares of sandstone forests and rock formations. The Park House in Bitche presents the local geology, biodiversity, and Alsatian-Lorraine traditions. Interactive exhibitions on endemic species (lynx, black grouse, peregrine falcon), hiking trails in preserved forests, and discovery of rock castles perched on sandstone peaks. UNESCO World Biosphere Reserve.

activities.text: Hike the Simserhof fortified line, the best-preserved Maginot Line fort. This underground city built between 1930 and 1935 housed 600 soldiers with dormitories, kitchens, infirmary, electric power plant, and ammunition depot. Electric trains circulated in 3 km of galleries connecting 17 combat blocks. The guided tour, enhanced with lighting and sound, recreates the daily life of soldiers. Bring warm clothing, constant 10°C.

Discover the Saint-Louis-lès-Bitche crystal works, founded in 1586 by Lorraine glassmakers. The museum showcases exceptional pieces: 19th-century chandeliers, Art Deco vases, and contemporary creations. Crystal blowing demonstrations by master glassmakers reveal ancestral gestures: harvesting, blowing, cutting, engraving. The company store sells signed pieces. France's oldest crystal works still in operation.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: Blaye Citadel is a military fortress designed by Vauban between 1685 and 1689. With 38 hectares of fortifications, 1.5 km of ramparts, and four bastions, it's an impressive defensive complex. UNESCO-listed along with Fort Pâté and Fort Médoc, it forms the Estuary Lock that was meant to protect Bordeaux from maritime invasions. The citadel now houses shops, restaurants, and accommodations. Free entry, paid guided underground visit.

The citadel ramparts offer spectacular panoramas over the Gironde estuary, Europe's largest. On clear days, you can see Fort Pâté on its islet and Fort Médoc on the opposite bank. The rampart walk circles the entire citadel. Several viewpoints and orientation tables help you get your bearings. Sunset from the ramparts is particularly beautiful with reflections on the estuary.

Château des Rudel, inside the citadel, is a 12th-century medieval vestige. It was the fortress dominating Blaye before Vauban integrated its ruins into the new fortifications. The famous troubadour Jaufré Rudel was reportedly born here. Part of the towers and curtain walls survive. The site now houses the Estuary Conservatory and a museum on citadel history. Panoramic views from the tower remains.

The Minimes Convent, built under Henri IV in the early 17th century, served as a place of worship for garrisons. Integrated into the citadel by Vauban, it retains its original architecture with cloister and convent buildings. Now transformed into a vacation center and event venue. The chapel can be visited and hosts temporary exhibitions. The cloister is a peaceful haven with its central garden.

The citadel's underground passages form a network of defensive galleries carved into limestone rock. The guided tour (about 45 minutes) reveals this ingenious system designed by Vauban. You'll explore galleries, vaulted rooms, and understand the defense strategy. Constant temperature of 14°C year-round, bring warm clothing. Reservations recommended through the tourist office.

activities.text: The Flowered Corniche Road connects Blaye to Bourg-sur-Gironde over 10 kilometers. This small road winds between limestone cliffs, dry stone walls, and the estuary. Landscapes are magnificent with views of carrelets (fishing huts on stilts), silvery Gironde waters, and vineyards. You'll pass through the troglodyte villages of Plassac and Mombrier. Many spots to stop and photograph. Narrow road, drive slowly.

Blaye wine tasting. The Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux appellation produces mainly powerful red wines and dry whites. Several cellars and châteaux in the region offer tastings. The Blaye Wine Center, in the citadel, presents an appellation selection and organizes guided tastings. Blaye's Spring Wines event in April gathers over 300 winemakers in the citadel for the season's biggest wine event.

Cruise on the Gironde estuary. Boat excursions depart from Blaye to discover the Vauban Lock: you'll pass Fort Pâté on its islet and Fort Médoc on the Médoc bank. Guided cruises explain the defensive system's history and estuary navigation. Some outings include a stop at Fort Médoc. Duration 2 to 3 hours. Departures vary by season and tides.

Blaye Market. The market is held three times weekly (Wednesday, Saturday, and Sunday mornings) on the citadel's alleys and in the lower town. You'll find local products: fruits and vegetables, cheeses, honey, wines, estuary oysters, fish. The atmosphere is friendly and authentic. It's a good opportunity to chat with producers and discover regional specialties. Saturday's market is the largest.

Horse-drawn carriage or tourist train ride through the citadel. These guided tours reveal the citadel's history and monuments in a fun way. The tourist train circles the ramparts with audio commentary. Carriages offer rides in and around the citadel. It's a pleasant option for families with children or people with walking difficulties. Regular departures in season.

days_plan.itin_title: Gironde Road Trip: Bordeaux, Vineyards & Arcachon Bay

visits.text: Royal Château of Blois forms a unique showcase of French architecture spanning the 13th to 17th centuries. Four wings surround the courtyard, each embodying a distinct style: medieval Gothic with the States Hall, flamboyant Gothic for the Louis XII wing, Italian Renaissance with François I's spiral staircase, and classical architecture by Mansart for the Gaston d'Orléans wing. The richly furnished royal apartments immerse you in the private world of seven French kings and ten queens. The Histopad—a digital tablet included with admission—reconstructs vanished décors through augmented reality and offers a treasure hunt that transforms the visit into an adventure for children.

Robert-Houdin House of Magic faces the château as Europe's only public museum dedicated to the art of illusion. The six-headed dragon bursting from the windows every half-hour sets the enchanting tone. Two thousand square meters overflow with automata, optical illusions, and interactive exhibits tracing magic's history from the 18th century to today. The Robert-Houdin room displays 170 objects belonging to Blois' famous magician. The grand theater presents several daily shows where prestidigitation acts follow one another in captivating succession.

Old Town of Blois unfolds its cobbled lanes and monumental staircases between the Loire and the château. Half-timbered houses stand alongside Renaissance mansions testifying to past prosperity. Saint-Louis Cathedral dominates the upper town with its baroque façade. The Bishop's Gardens offer panoramic views over the Loire and its bridges. The Louis XII fountain graces the lively central square. Secret passages and interior courtyards invite exploration. The Saint-Nicolas church presents remarkable Gothic architecture.

activities.text: Sound and light show on the château's façades after nightfall during the warmer months. Video mapping projections embrace the grandiose architecture of all four wings, animated by celebrated actors' voices. Visual and sound effects recount the dramas, conspiracies, and secrets of the French court that unfolded within these walls. The thirty-minute spectacle takes place in the main courtyard. The light displays transform the façades into living theater.

Stroll along the Loire riverbanks from the Bishop's Gardens to the Jacques-Gabriel bridge. The landscaped banks offer shaded paths with views of this royal river classified as world heritage. Sandbars and wooded islands create ever-changing landscapes with the water's flow. Successive bridges spanning the Loire offer remarkable architectural perspectives. Sunset sets the river ablaze with golden reflections. Moored barges and aquatic birds animate the riverside tableau.

Denis-Papin Staircase connects the upper town to the Vienne quarter below. This monumental 130-step stairway offers changing views of the city and Loire from each landing. The statue of Denis Papin—Blois' inventor of the steam engine—stands at the summit. Renaissance façades lining the staircase testify to Blois' architectural prestige. The ascent reveals the different levels of this city tiered on its limestone hillside.

days_plan.itin_title: Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley

visits.text: The MC93, Bobigny's national theater, occupies a building designed by architects Fabre and Perrotet in raw concrete, steel, and sandstone. The main Oleg Efremov hall seats 800. Since the 1970s, this theater has hosted creations by international directors.

The Seine-Saint-Denis prefecture, built between 1968 and 1971, marks the emergence of modern administrative architecture. Its buildings are organized around a square dominated by the triangular 1974 town hall, resembling a beehive.

The Memorial to the former Bobigny deportation station, inaugurated in 2023, occupies the site from which 21 convoys of Jewish deportees departed between July 1943 and August 1944. An educational trail traces this dark chapter of history.
The Bobigny Labor Exchange, designed by a Brazilian architect, displays characteristic curves in white concrete. Its auditorium regularly hosts cultural events.

Cross the town's wooded park to reach the Church of Saint-André. The route follows boules courts and opens onto Place de la Libération, bordered by the former town hall converted into a music conservatory.

activities.text: The Cité de l'Abreuvoir, designed in the 1950s by architect Émile Aillaud as a garden city of 1,500 housing units, is labeled "Remarkable Contemporary Architecture." Walk its paths to understand the post-war social housing utopia.
Reach the banks of the Ourcq canal on the Bobigny side. The towpath links Pantin to Bondy through a changing landscape punctuated by murals and new developments.

days_plan.itin_title: Southern Corsica Travel Guide: Corsican Mountains & Gulf Heritage Itinerary

visits.text: Rebuilt in the 15th century, the Château de Bonnétable was redesigned in the 19th century by architect Henri Parent for the Duke of Doudeauville.
The 11th and 19th-century Saint-Sulpice church houses a wooden organ from 1850 and magnificent stained glass windows by François Fialeix depicting the life of Saint Sulpice.
The vegetable garden, created by the Bühler brothers in 1885, remained functional for 80 years. Restored in 2002, it showcases heirloom vegetables and diverse plant species.
The castle's former stables now house the Tourist Office. Two tack rooms have been recreated and the stalls renovated.
The market hall, built in 1856, adorns the Place du Vieux Château. Its bell tower features two Wagner clocks.

activities.text: Stroll through the castle park bordered by the Tripoulain. Water features, re-excavated moats, and shaded pathways await.
Explore the Bonnétable Forest. Hiking circuits on foot or by bicycle through this Perche woodland.
Ride the Transvap, a steam train on the former Mamers-Saint-Calais line. An 18 km railway journey between Bonnétable and Beillé.

days_plan.itin_title: Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Bonneval, nicknamed the Little Venice of Beauce for its canals fed by the Loir. This medieval town founded in 857 around Saint-Florentin Abbey has preserved its water-filled moats, ramparts, and picturesque streets. An oasis of greenery in the heart of the Beauce plain.

Former Benedictine Abbey of Saint-Florentin-et-Saint-Hilaire, classified as a historic monument since 1883. The pointed-arch entrance gate from the 13th century remains, topped by the 15th-century abbot's lodging, with its checkerboard wall of white stones, bricks, and flint flanked by three towers.

Church of Notre-Dame de Bonneval, a jewel of early Gothic architecture built between the 12th and 13th centuries. It houses two paintings from the abbey's former refectory, including a copy of a canvas by Nicolas Poussin. Its bell tower dominates the medieval town's rooftops.

Medieval fortifications of Bonneval with the 15th-century Porte Saint-Roch and the 13th-century King's Tower, a former 22-meter-high keep. The ramparts still encircle the old town, offering a walk along the flower-lined moats.

activities.text: Electric boat ride on Bonneval's canals, a unique experience to discover the town from the water. No license required, these small boats allow you to pass under medieval bridges and admire ancestral wash houses. In the evening, the illuminations of 'Bonneval, lights along the water' enhance the journey.
Walk along Bonneval's medieval moats, where ducks and moorhens come to greet strollers. The 19th-century wash houses punctuate the route while old houses reflect in the calm waters of the Loir.
Tasting of local Beauce products at Vergers de Beauce, a shop offering exclusively local products in short supply chains. A gourmet stop to discover the authentic flavors of Eure-et-Loir.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure-et-Loir Circuit: Chartres, Châteaux & Proust

visits.text: Bonneval-sur-Arc is the only Savoyard village classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages. Perched at 1,800 m altitude at the far end of Haute-Maurienne, it lines up stone houses with 80-cm-thick walls, roofed with lauze slabs on larch timbers. No antenna or satellite dish disturbs the village silhouette.

The parish church raises its tower bell-spire of stone above the rooftops. Originally a simple chapel, it was enlarged in the 16th century to accommodate the parish newly established by the Bishop of Maurienne.

Push on to the hamlet of l'Écot, 4 km from the village (2,000 m). Classified as a historic site in 1971, this cluster of abandoned chalets and its Chapelle Sainte-Marguerite (Romanesque, adorned with medieval frescoes) served as a film set for Belle et Sébastien adaptations.

The Espace Neige et Montagne recounts daily life in the high mountains of yesteryear: wood crafts, pottery, weaving, and the beginnings of mountaineering at Bonneval. The old-timers heated themselves with "grébons," molded briquettes made from sheep dung.

Stop at the cooperative fromagerie to taste Bleu de Bonneval, a local blue-veined cheese, and Beaufort AOP d'alpage. Cows graze here between 1,800 and 2,500 m altitude, in the pastures of Vanoise National Park.

activities.text: Hike to the Cirque des Évettes. From l'Écot, the trail climbs alongside the Arc torrent to a glacial amphitheater dominated by the Albaron (3,637 m). Facing the Évettes glacier, silence and immensity reward every step.
Family walk on the Sentier des Agneaux, between the village and the hamlet of l'Écot. The path follows pastures where flocks spend the summer, with views of the border peaks of Italy.
Canyoning in the gorges of l'Écot. One of the Alps' finest spots: descent in the Arc's waters with natural slides, jumps, and rappels supervised by instructors.

days_plan.itin_title: Savoie from Lakes to Glaciers: Yenne to Haute-Maurienne

visits.text: Place de la Bourse is the symbol of the Port of the Moon, a UNESCO World Heritage site since 2007. Built in the 18th century, it reflects Bordeaux's maritime trade prosperity with symmetrical façades framing the Three Graces fountain. The location becomes particularly photogenic at sunset when lights reflect in the Miroir d'Eau (Water Mirror) just opposite.

La Cité du Vin is an interactive museum dedicated to wine cultures from around the world. Its architecture evokes a decanter swirling wine. The permanent exhibition Via Sensoria takes you through the four wine seasons via immersive sensory installations. The 8th-floor belvedere offers panoramic views over Bordeaux and the Garonne River, with a complimentary wine tasting included in the admission ticket.

Saint-André Cathedral has dominated old Bordeaux since the 12th century. This UNESCO World Heritage monument hosted the wedding of Eleanor of Aquitaine and Louis VII in 1137. The royal portal features remarkable medieval sculptures. The Pey-Berland Tower, standing separate from the main building, can be climbed for panoramic city views (231 steps).

Rue Sainte-Catherine is Europe's longest pedestrian shopping street at 1.2 kilometers. It connects Place de la Comédie to the historic center, running through the commercial districts. Covered passages like Galerie Bordelaise add architectural charm. It's the main shopping artery in Bordeaux.

The Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux, built by Victor Louis in 1780, is a masterpiece of neoclassical architecture. Its columned façade is topped with twelve statues representing muses and goddesses. The interior houses a sumptuous Italian-style auditorium that inspired the Paris Opera Garnier. Guided tours reveal the backstage and the building's history.

The Chartrons district, once home to wine merchants, preserves its 18th-century bourgeois atmosphere. Elegant façades line Rue Notre-Dame, now filled with antique shops, art galleries, and wine cellars. The Chartrons market on Sunday mornings buzzes with energy. It's a pleasant neighborhood for strolling along the quays.
Journey to Bordeaux and visit to the Musée d'Aquitaine.
Discovery of Bordeaux's historic center and tasting of regional wines.
Guided visit to the Capucins market and discovery of regional products.
Bike tour in Bordeaux's historic center: Place de la Bourse, Grand Théâtre, quays of the Garonne.
Oyster tasting in Arcachon and discovery of the basin.
Visit and tasting in the vineyards of Saint-Émilion, UNESCO World Heritage site.
Discovery of the historic center of Bordeaux, UNESCO World Heritage listed.
Stroll on the place des Quinconces, the largest square in Europe.
Walk along the quays of the Garonne and visit to the Miroir d'eau.

activities.text: The Miroir d'Eau (Water Mirror), facing Place de la Bourse, is the world's largest reflecting pool at 3,450 m². Inaugurated in 2006, it alternates mirror phases (2 cm of water) and mist phases every 15 minutes. Children love running through it barefoot in summer. It's one of Bordeaux's most photographed spots, especially at sunset.

Garonne River cruises let you discover Bordeaux from the water. Several companies offer departures from the quays, with commentary on the city's maritime history. Cruises typically last 1.5 to 2 hours. Some include a snack or aperitif with local wine tasting.

Wine tasting in Bordeaux can be enjoyed at several downtown cellars. The Bar à Vin du CIVB, near the Grand Théâtre, offers guided Bordeaux wine tastings. Les Bassins des Lumières, in a former submarine base, combines immersive art exhibitions with tastings. For a pedagogical approach, the École du Vin de Bordeaux organizes introductory workshops.

Cycling along Bordeaux's quays. The city has a well-developed network of bike paths. Several rental shops offer classic or electric bikes by the day or half-day. The quayside route, from La Cité du Vin to the Pont de Pierre, is particularly pleasant with views of the river and monuments.

Visit the Marché des Capucins, Bordeaux's largest market. Open every morning except Monday, it gathers local producers, fishmongers, greengrocers, and artisans. The atmosphere is lively and authentic. Perfect for discovering regional products: Arcachon Bay oysters, cheeses, charcuterie, wines. Several stalls offer on-site tastings.
Gourmet dinner in a traditional Bordeaux restaurant.
Wine tasting at the Cité du Vin museum.

days_plan.itin_title: Gironde Road Trip: Bordeaux, Vineyards & Arcachon Bay
Paris to Bordeaux Heritage Route: Castles, Vineyards & French Flavors
Paris to Bordeaux Heritage Route: Castles, Vineyards & French Flavors

visits.text: A 12th-century medieval village classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages, Bormes unfolds its flowered alleys, 'cuberts' (vaulted passages), and ochre-tinted facades. Over 700 plant species color the village—bougainvillea in summer, mimosa cascades in winter.

Climb up to the 13th–14th-century castle, a historic monument since 1931. From the village's highest point, the panorama embraces Lavandou Bay, the islands of Levant and Port-Cros, Favière harbor, and Cap Bénat—a view that captures the entire coast.

Saint-Trophyme church, built in the 18th century in Romanesque style, replaced the old castle church that had become too small. Its Chapel of Saint Francis honors the saint who reportedly delivered the town from plague in 1483.

Parc Gonzalez, classified as a Remarkable Garden, brings together 3,000 m² of plants from Australia and around the world, with 250 species arranged by landscape designer Gilles Augias. The terraces offer views over the Mediterranean.

The Museum of History and Art of Bormes, housed in the former town hall, offers an augmented reality tour via HistoPad tablets. The rooms reveal the village's secrets through the centuries with immersive storytelling.

activities.text: Fort de Brégançon, a state residence overlooking the sea, can be glimpsed from the coast. Head to Cabasson beach below: white sand, crystalline waters, and a direct view of the fort—presidential luxury from a beach towel.
Nine wine estates and one cooperative cellar offer tastings of AOC Côtes de Provence. The 'Vignobles & Découvertes' label guarantees quality hospitality in the cellars, where the rosé flows freely.
From Favière harbor, boat excursions head to Port-Cros, Porquerolles, or offshore to observe dolphins. Departures run from April to October, weather permitting.

visits.text: The Musée des Années 30 displays 3,000 m² of Art Deco and modern art. Paintings, sculptures, and furniture by Ruhlmann and Leleu testify to Boulogne's artistic ferment in the interwar years.
Île Seguin housed the Renault factory from 1929 to 1992, employing 30,000 workers. La Seine Musicale, inaugurated in 2017, now occupies the downstream tip, a work by Japanese architect Shigeru Ban.
Stroll along the Seine embankments between Boulogne and Sèvres. The redesigned quays offer views of Île Seguin and former industrial sites.

activities.text: The 4-hectare Albert Kahn gardens compose landscape scenes: a Japanese garden with tea pavilion brought over in 1909, Vosges forest, English garden, and French formal garden. The museum preserves 72,000 autochrome photographs from the Archives of the Planet.
Parc de Boulogne stretches across the southern commune. Perfect for a nature break.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: Nausicaá, Europe's largest aquarium, presents 60,000 animals in 16,000 cubic meters of water. The High Seas basin with its 100-square-meter viewing window shelters hammerhead sharks and manta rays.
Notre-Dame Basilica's 19th-century dome soars 101 meters above the upper town. Its architecture draws inspiration from Rome's St. Peter's and Paris's Les Invalides.
The 1,400-square-meter crypt, one of France's vastest, unfolds a labyrinth of 20 underground chambers. Walls and vaults covered with 19th-century frescoes narrate Christianity's history.
Walk the 13th-century ramparts, northern France's only intact medieval enceinte. The 360° views span the Boulonnais region and the fortified old town.
The 13th-century count's castle, built on a Roman camp, now houses Boulogne Museum. Eclectic collections range from ancient Egypt to indigenous arts.
The belfry, a 37-meter former 12th-century keep, has been UNESCO-listed since 1926. It symbolizes the city's communal independence.

activities.text: Stroll the Promenade du Général San Martin along the beach. It stretches from Nausicaá to Wimereux, perfect for walkers and cyclists.
Visit the fish market in France's leading fishing port. Guaranteed freshness and authentic atmosphere.
Discover the ephemeral garden on Place Godefroy de Bouillon. This green space transforms each season around a new botanical theme.
Climb the Column of the Grande Armée, erected in Napoleon's glory. Fifty-three meters high, 263 steps, and breathtaking views over the Boulonnais.

days_plan.itin_title: Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: The Bourbon castle ruins (13th-15th centuries) crown the town from their rocky spur. These impressive vestiges of the ancestral fortress of the Bourbon dynasty include the Qui-Qu'en-Grogne keep built by Louis II around 1400. Climb the 70 steps to reach the terrace offering panoramic views over Bourbonnais bocage and Tronçais forest.

The classified Belle Époque thermal baths (1886) perpetuate a tradition dating back to Romans. The preserved Neo-Byzantine architecture with polychrome brick facades houses modern facilities treating rheumatism and respiratory conditions. The springs rich in sulfur and minerals have attracted curistes for over 2000 years.

The Saint-Georges church (12th-13th centuries) displays Romanesque architecture with fortified elements. The interior shelters frescoes and carved capitals illustrating medieval art. The massive bell tower dominates old Bourbon testifying to the church's strategic and spiritual role.

Old Bourbon reveals its paved streets lined with stone houses (15th-18th centuries) and half-timbered facades. The town preserves authentic medieval character with ancient ramparts still visible. Stroll discovering artisan shops and café terraces in preserved historical setting.

activities.text: The thermal park extends 15 hectares of landscaped gardens around thermal baths. Marked paths wind through century-old trees, flowerbeds and ponds. The peaceful setting invites relaxation walks away from urban bustle. Benches and pavilions offer rest spots.

The Tronçais Forest surrounds Bourbon offering hiking and biking opportunities. Marked trails explore this exceptional oak forest planted by Colbert in the 17th century. The forest roads lead to remarkable trees, ponds and glades perfect for picnics and nature observation.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: Bourbonne's thermal springs have drawn visitors for 2,000 years. Mineral-rich water surges naturally from deep underground at 66°C, prized since Roman times for its healing properties.
The spa center specializes in two therapeutic areas: rheumatology for treating arthritis and joint pain, and respiratory treatments for asthma and chronic sinusitis.
The Parc des Sources provides shaded refuge in the town center. The 18th-century former military hospital stands as testament to the spa's storied past as a healing destination for soldiers.
The medieval château park overlooks the town from elevated ground. A 16th-century archway opens onto tree-lined paths shaded by centuries-old specimens.
The municipal museum displays Gallo-Roman archaeological finds, fine art collections, and ethnographic curiosities chronicling Bourbonne's thermal heritage across the ages.

activities.text: Treat yourself to a spa package at the thermal center. Hydromassage baths, steam hammam, and relaxation massages complement the therapeutic treatments.
Wander the historic quarter between the thermal park and Notre-Dame church. 18th-century architecture defines the spa town's character.
Explore marked hiking trails through the surrounding forest. The rolling Champagne countryside offers peaceful landscapes ideal for leisurely walks.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: The Royal Monastery of Brou stands like a Bressan Taj Mahal, built out of love between 1506 and 1512. A masterpiece of Flamboyant Gothic architecture, it captivates with its stone lacework, three princely tombs, and poignant history: Margaret of Austria had this mausoleum built for her husband Philibert the Fair, who died too soon. The three cloisters and the Fine Arts Museum complete the visit to this listed monument.

Notre-Dame Church reveals Flamboyant Gothic architecture typical of the Savoy Bresse region. Built with carrons, those characteristic Savoy bricks, it bears witness to the town's medieval past. Its bell tower has watched over the city center for centuries, offering a visible landmark from the surrounding cobblestone streets.

Stroll through the historic center's narrow streets where half-timbered houses tell the story of this former capital of Bresse. Place Carriat and its terraces invite you to observe the daily ballet of the Burgiens. Colorful facades and arcades shelter artisan shops that perpetuate local craftsmanship.

The Ferme du Sougey, a listed historic monument, is one of the oldest half-timbered farms in Bresse, dating from the 15th century. Transformed into a local heritage museum, it showcases traditional Bressan habitat and houses a breeding farm for AOC Bresse poultry. The surrounding 35 hectares of bocage landscape bear witness to ancestral local agriculture.
Discovery of the historic center of Bourg-en-Bresse and its half-timbered houses.
Visit to the Royal Monastery of Brou, a 16th-century flamboyant Gothic masterpiece.
The Royal Monastery of Brou is a jewel of Flamboyant Gothic built in the early 16th century. Margaret of Austria had this complex constructed to house the tomb of her husband Philibert the Fair.
The church displays its glazed roof with multicolored tiles and three cloisters of exceptional delicacy. The sculpted tombs rank among the masterpieces of European funerary statuary.
The 1496 Hugon house illustrates medieval architecture with its stone shop on the ground floor and half-timbered upper floors where the master and his workers lived.
Notre-Dame Co-Cathedral impresses with its 190 years of construction. Its 23-bell carillon rings through the town while its Flamboyant Gothic style rivals Brou.
Stroll through Place de la Grenette dominated by the former neoclassical grain hall and the theater adorned with columns, masks, and music muses.
The 18th-century Town Hall displays a sundial inspired by astronomer Lalande, a local son. Fountains flank the entrance classified as a Historic Monument.
The Fountain of the Four Crossroads, nicknamed Vizirette by locals, symbolizes the world and its four cardinal points in the heart of the pedestrian quarter.

activities.text: Discover Bresse poultry AOC, the only poultry in the world to benefit from a protected designation of origin since 1957. In local farms and restaurants, taste this fine, marbled meat from chickens raised free-range in the Bressan bocage. Local gastronomy highlights this blue-legged chicken, the region's crown jewel.

Get lost in the cobblestone streets of the Brou district. Old houses, secret passages, and small interior courtyards create a preserved medieval atmosphere. Every facade tells a story, every stone bears witness to the passage of centuries in this city of weavers and merchants.

The market halls buzz every Saturday morning with the activity of local producers. Bresse poultry, mountain cheeses, sausages, thick fresh cream: the stalls overflow with local products. The friendly atmosphere and discussions with producers keep the Bressan agricultural tradition alive.

Visit the apothecary of the former Brou hospital, arranged in the early 18th century. This old pharmacy preserves an exceptional collection of Meillonnas earthenware jars and period medical instruments. Carved woodwork and secret drawers testify to medicine of yesteryear.
Tasting of the famous Bresse poultry in a local restaurant.
Walk in Tête d'Or park to enjoy the green spaces and the local market.
Pick up the discovery booklet at the tourist office for a self-guided tour of Bourg-en-Bresse's heritage.
The Bouvent leisure center offers 56 hectares of relaxation three kilometers from the center: swimming, paddle boats, climbing, bike park, and golf course.
Sit down to savor PDO Bresse chicken, the only poultry in the world to hold a protected designation of origin.
Continue to the pottery village of Meillonnas in the Revermont to discover faience workshops perpetuating the tradition of the famous blue decorations.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains
The Alpine Monasteries Route: A Sacred Journey Through Thermal Waters & Mountain Heights
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: Bourges Cathedral surprises from the entrance: no transept, five naves stretching in one line for 120 meters. This extremely rare feature for a Gothic cathedral creates a dizzying perspective found nowhere else in France. Built between 1195 and 1230, it rivals Notre-Dame de Paris. The central portal of the Last Judgment deserves a closer look: smiling resurrected souls, grimacing damned, carved with striking realism.

The 13th-century stained glass windows are among the finest preserved medieval collections. In the ambulatory, the Last Supper and Saint John's vision haven't moved in 800 years. The crypt houses the marble effigy of Duke Jean de Berry (1422) and remnants of the rood screen destroyed during the Revolution. Guided tour required, departures every hour.

396 spiral steps in the Butter Tower lead to the panoramic terrace. The climb is steep but the 360° view over Bourges, medieval rooftops and the Berry countryside rewards the effort. You can make out the marshes to the north and the first hills of Sancerre to the east. Access limited to July-August, fixed hours, limited capacity.

The Palais Jacques-Cœur is one of France's finest Gothic civil buildings. Built between 1443 and 1451 by Charles VII's treasurer, it has 43 rooms over 4000 m². Jacques Cœur only slept there 8 nights before his disgrace. The street facade shows two sculpted figures leaning on false windows — they seem to have been watching passersby for 600 years. Inside, the upturned boat-hull roof frame and monumental fireplaces testify to the splendor of the era.

Jacques Cœur's motto — "To a valiant heart, nothing is impossible" — is carved throughout the palace, accompanied by sculpted shells and hearts. The chapel preserves a stained glass window depicting one of his merchant ships. The banquet hall, with its musicians' gallery and fireplace bearing royal arms, gives an idea of the lavish receptions he never got to host.

activities.text: The Archbishop's Garden, attributed to Le Nôtre, offers an open view of the cathedral's chevet. French-style lawns, geometric flowerbeds and shaded benches: the ideal spot for a break after visits. Free access year-round.

Bourges' historic center is easily walkable. Half-timbered houses on rue Bourbonnoux, Hôtel Lallemant (Renaissance), Notre-Dame church with its contemporary stained glass. The cobbled streets around the cathedral have kept their medieval layout.

Les Nuits Lumière de Bourges (mid-June to mid-September): free nighttime route with projections on historic facades. The cathedral, Palais Jacques-Cœur and several private mansions light up at nightfall. Allow 2 hours for the complete circuit.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: The castle of Boussac stands on a cliff overlooking the Petite Creuse. Built in the 15th century by Jean de Brosse, companion-in-arms of Joan of Arc, it was the site of a major discovery: it was here that George Sand identified the Lady and the Unicorn tapestries during her stays between 1840 and 1870. The writer convinced her friend Prosper Mérimée, Inspector of Historic Monuments, to classify them. The six panels joined the Cluny Museum in 1882.

George Sand's bedroom in the castle has been reconstructed with touching attention to detail: open book on the table, slippers at the foot of the bed, hair tongs on the nightstand. The writer drafted her pastoral novel Jeanne here. A reproduction of the 'À mon seul désir' (To my only desire) tapestry recalls the medieval masterpiece discovered within these walls.

The castle now houses a remarkable collection of more than 40 tapestries, from the 15th century to contemporary times. An entire room is devoted to Dom Robert, a Benedictine monk whose colorful cartoons depict joyful fauna. The works of Jean Lurçat, including the 'Liberté' (Freedom) tapestry inspired by Paul Éluard's poem, testify to the renewal of textile art in the 20th century.

activities.text: The Pierres Jaumâtres, a natural granite chaos on Mont Barlot, offers a fantastic landscape of strangely shaped rocks. George Sand set a scene from her novel Jeanne here. The blocks stacked by erosion evoke petrified creatures. A developed trail winds between the rock formations, with panoramic views over the Marche mountains.

The town of Boussac preserves some old houses and a 12th-century church. A stroll through the alleys allows appreciation of the atmosphere of this small Creuse town. The weekly market animates the central square.

Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: Erbalunga spreads its fishermen's houses tightly across a rocky peninsula. The ruined 16th-century Genoese tower dominates the small harbor while salt-weathered facades reveal authentic charm. The baroque-fronted Church of Saint-Érasme protects the processional crosses used during Holy Week.

The hamlets of Brando climb in tiers through the valley: Castello with its feudal castle ruins, Pozzo and its flagstone quarries, Mausoleu and its cipolin marble quarries. The Chapel of Notre-Dame-des-Neiges preserves 14th-century frescoes. A journey back in time among fountains and dry-stone washhouses.

The Lavasina sanctuary has drawn pilgrims for centuries. The ex-voto museum can be visited by reservation and tells the story of the miracle. The former Franciscan convent overlooks a small pebble beach facing the sea.

activities.text: The coastal path from Erbalunga winds along coves between maquis and black rocks. Kayak rentals available at the harbor for exploring hidden caves and wild inlets. Diving clubs offer trips to the protected waters of the Cap Corse Marine Natural Park.
Erbalunga beach and Campinca cove offer swimming in a pristine setting. Fine sand and transparent waters bordered by rocks. Family-friendly atmosphere far from the crowds of beach resorts.

days_plan.itin_title: Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Benedictine abbey on the island and Romanesque bell tower.
Pont Coudé and quays on the Dronne.

Legend credits Charlemagne with founding Brantôme's Benedictine abbey in 769 AD. Whether or not the emperor passed through, the 11th-century Romanesque bell tower—among France's oldest—still stands on the rock outcrop above the abbey church. Monks carved living spaces directly into the limestone cliff: a dovecote, Saint Sicaire's miraculous fountain, and austere monastic cells that speak to centuries of devotion.

The Cave of the Last Judgment, hewn into the cliff face during the 15th century, harbors two monumental bas-reliefs: Christ in glory surrounded by apocalyptic scenes. The atmosphere inside is haunting and profound. Nearby, the remnants of troglodyte dwellings reveal where monks lived as early as the 9th century—before the abbey was even built.

Brantôme earned the nickname 'the Venice of Périgord' for good reason: the Dronne River winds through the town, crossed by arched bridges and lined with riverside terraces. The angled medieval bridge, the Renaissance pavilion, and the abbey mill create postcard-perfect reflections in the water. It's a place made for strolling and lingering.

activities.text: Peaceful canoe trip on the Dronne around the old town.

The Dronne River offers gentle canoeing and kayaking—Class I water suitable for beginners and families. Routes range from one to five hours, paddling beneath Brantôme's bridges and alongside limestone cliffs. Local outfitters provide gear and shuttle service back to town.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Dordogne Road Trip: Cave Art, Medieval Fortresses & Périgord Delights

visits.text: The 11th-century castle of the Lords of Beaumont unfolds 700 meters of walls punctuated by 38 towers on a rocky promontory.
Follow the restored ramparts and admire the romantic ruins of the 15th-century manor house.
The 19th-century neo-Gothic mansion hosts temporary exhibitions and sculpture symposiums.
The Church of Notre-Dame, founded by Thibault de Beaumont in the 11th century, features 12th-century Angevin domed vaults.
The 56-meter Renaissance bell tower inspired by Italy dominates the city. 19th-century frescoes adorn the choir.

activities.text: From the castle esplanade, enjoy the view over the Chapel of Saint-Cyprien and the 19th-century former slaughterhouses.
Participate in the Terra Aventura treasure hunt within the castle grounds to help Dame Jeanne.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Alpes Majesty: High Mountain Passes, Ski Resorts & Alpine Valleys

visits.text: The Briare Canal Bridge carries barges across the Loire for 2,172 feet—one of the longest navigable aqueducts in the world. Built by Gustave Eiffel's workshops in 1896, this marvel of steel and cast iron suspends the canal 36 feet above the royal river.

The Musée des Deux Marines traces river navigation and Loire boatmanship through the ages. Scale models, vintage photographs, and authentic equipment evoke the life of the mariniers who guided flat-bottomed boats along the treacherous currents.
The Église Saint-Étienne raises its neo-Gothic bell tower above the town center. The 19th-century interior glows with colorful stained glass.

activities.text: Cruise the Canal latéral à la Loire in an electric boat—no license required. Discover the canal bridge from the water, gliding through its graceful arches.
Watch the barges navigate the locks. The canal links the Loire and Seine rivers, cutting through the Loiret on its journey between France's two great waterways.

days_plan.itin_title: Loiret Road Trip: Orléans & Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: Brienne-le-Château earned its fame as Napoleon Bonaparte's military school city. From 1779 to 1784, the young Corsican studied at the Royal Military School, now the Museum of Napoleon and the Revolution. Period collections, imperial souvenirs, weapons, documents retrace the emperor's youth. The castle, rebuilt after WWI bombings, houses temporary exhibitions. Allow 1h30 for the complete visit.

The Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul church houses an exceptional treasure: the Girardon Altarpiece, 17th-century sculpted masterpiece by François Girardon, Louis XIV's official sculptor. White marble composition depicting the Assumption, remarkable for its movement and expressiveness. One of France's most beautiful baroque altarpieces. Free admission but irregular opening hours — check before visiting.

activities.text: Walk around Lac de la Forêt d'Orient: this artificial lake created in 1966 extends over 2,500 hectares. Marked trails allow walking or cycling the shores. Water activities: swimming from supervised beaches, sailing, kayaking, stand-up paddle. Nautical base rents equipment. Popular in summer, bring picnic and swimwear.

Every Wednesday and Saturday, Brienne-le-Château holds its market under the covered hall. Local products: vegetables, cheeses, charcuterie, honey. Then explore the town's shops and cafés. Lunch at a restaurant offering Champagne regional cuisine: andouillette, pig's trotters, chaource, Champagne-braised meat dishes. Authentic local flavors.

days_plan.itin_title: Aube Circuit: Champagne, Medieval Heritage and Orient Forest Lakes

visits.text: Le Corbusier's Cité Radieuse rises from the forest since 1961. This vertical village measures 110 meters long and 56 high, containing 339 duplex apartments across 17 floors.
Rough concrete frames the colorful loggias. André Wogenscky led the construction following Le Corbusier's Modulor principles.
Six interior streets traverse the building constructed on stilts. The association La Première Rue opens model apartments furnished in 1960s style.
The 13th-century Église Saint-Gengoult testifies to Briey's medieval past. This Gothic gem, a listed monument, dominates the old town.
Briey-Haut's historic center preserves ramparts and remains of the county castle. Cobbled lanes wind between old houses.

activities.text: Lac de la Sangsue offers swimming and water activities. The 2.6-kilometer trail circles the lake.
The forest trails of Mance and Mancieulles offer loops from 5 to 15 kilometers. The forest surrounds the Cité Radieuse.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: The Basilica of Saint-Julien is the largest Romanesque church in Auvergne, built between the 11th and 12th centuries over a 4th-century martyr's tomb. Its polychromy of red sandstone, basalt, granulite, and gray marbles is utterly unique.
Look up: roughly 300 Romanesque capitals populated with foliage, symbolic animals, and knights follow one another down the nave. The sculpted cycle in the choir evokes the Passion and Resurrection.
Look down at the pavement of basalt and quartz pebbles, rediscovered in 1963. Arranged in flowers, rosettes, and waves, these river stones form a two-tone mineral carpet.

The 37 contemporary stained-glass windows by Father Kim En Joong, created by the Loire Workshops of Chartres in 2008, flood the nave with colored light. The dialogue between Romanesque and contemporary art is striking.
Take rue du 4-Septembre to admire the Maison de Mandrin (12th–20th c.), its half-timbered brick façade with corbelling, and its vaulted room with painted coats of arms.
The Saint-Julien Fountain, on Avenue d'Auvergne, marks according to legend the site of the saint's beheading. Its capitals reportedly date back to the 10th century.

activities.text: Brioude sits on the Via Arverna linking Clermont-Ferrand to Santiago de Compostela. Walk a stretch of this thousand-year-old pilgrimage route in the surrounding area.
Wander the lanes of this "Petite Cité de Caractère" (Small Heritage Town): mansions, turrets, half-timbered houses, and shaded squares punctuate your stroll.
Need some fresh air? Head down to the banks of the Allier. The river, one of the last wild rivers in Europe, flows at the town's doorstep at the entrance to its gorges.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Château de Brissac — "Green Lady".
Plessis-Bourré — Rumors & curses.
Château de Brissac — "Green Lady" (Charlotte) in the towers; moaning at night.
Brissac — "Green Lady".

Access: public (Plessis)
Access: public — Exact coordinates (47.356, -0.448).
Access: public (Maillezais)

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine's Haunted History: Cursed Castles & Prehistoric Cave Legends
Haunted Loire Valley: Forgotten Castles and Spectral Legends
Loire Valley Phantoms: Tragic Histories and Haunted Castles of France

visits.text: The Château de Brissac is France's tallest, soaring 7 stories and 204 rooms high—earning it the nickname 'Giant of the Loire Valley.' At 50 meters, it dominates the Aubance valley with unmistakable vertical drama.

Two medieval towers stand alongside the Renaissance façade—evidence of an unfinished transformation. Charles II de Cossé commissioned a new palace in 1606, but his death in 1621 permanently halted construction, freezing this architectural paradox in time.

The Belle Époque theater was built in 1890 by Jeanne Say, Marquise de Brissac and renowned opera singer. This intimate opera house welcomed the artistic elite of Paris to performances in the Loire countryside.

Gold-leaf ceilings, precious tapestries, and period furnishings create sumptuous interiors. The Louis XIII chamber preserves the memory of the 1620 reconciliation between the king and Marie de Médicis—a moment when royal family drama played out in these very rooms.
The 16th-century chapel features frescoes painted by Coppin Delf. Sixteen musical angels glorify the Virgin Mary and Christ in celestial harmony.

A 250-meter underground channel diverts the Aubance beneath the park. Its schist vault reflects in the water, creating an illuminated subterranean spectacle where stone and water mirror each other in darkness.

activities.text: The 70-hectare romantic park invites leisurely exploration. Century-old cedars, the mausoleum avenue, Jeanne Say's cascade, and vineyards compose a bucolic landscape that changes with each season.
The village of Brissac-Quincé nestles within vineyards bordered by the Aubance. The 16th-century church and wine-growers' houses testify to generations of local viticultural tradition.
The Montgolfiade hot air balloon festival gathers thousands of visitors each late August to the château park, where dozens of balloons rise into the sunset sky in a magical display.

days_plan.itin_title: Maine-et-Loire Road Trip: Anjou and Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: Labenche Museum. Located in a 16th-century Renaissance mansion listed as Historic Monument, this art and history museum presents 17 rooms. Unique collection in France of 10 tapestries from the English Royal Mortlake Manufactory (17th century). Also features Claude Debussy's piano, prehistoric and Gallo-Roman archaeological collections, and sections on local traditions.
Saint-Martin Collegiate Church. 12th-century Romanesque church in the heart of the old town. The 6th-century baptistery, discovered during excavations, testifies to the site's antiquity.
Saint-Libéral Chapel. 15th-century Gothic building converted into a contemporary art space, programmed by the Labenche Museum.

activities.text: Brive Market. On Saturday morning, it's one of the most renowned in the region. Under the Georges Brassens hall and on the surrounding squares, local producers and market gardeners offer regional specialties. Don't miss the violet mustard of Brive, a specialty made with grape must.

Tasting of Corrèze specialties. The region offers generous gastronomy: farcidures (grated potato dumplings with bacon), mique (poached dough ball served with salted pork), millassou (potato pancake), tourtous (buckwheat crepes), potato pie, flognarde (apple flan).

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley

visits.text: Place des Halles in Brou, the beating heart of this town between Beauce and Perche. The current market hall from 1846 replaces the former 16th-century wooden structure that housed one of the region's most important calf markets. 15th-century half-timbered houses frame this lively square.

Church of Saint-Lubin in Brou, built in the 12th century and expanded in the 15th and 16th centuries. Its 18th-century furnishings and religious art statues testify to this trading town's past prosperity. The bell tower dominates the historic center's rooftops.

Classified half-timbered houses of Brou, notably the 15th-century one on Place des Halles and the houses on rue des Changes with their carved figurative beams. These last witnesses of the medieval town have miraculously survived through the centuries.

activities.text: Weekly market in Brou on Wednesday mornings, one of the region's most important. Place des Halles, rue des Changes, and rue de la Chevalerie come alive with local producers offering cheeses, charcuterie, and vegetables from Beauce and Perche.

Mill race walk along the banks of the Ozanne, where wash houses from the late 19th century follow one another in a bucolic setting. This river that crosses Brou from west to east joins the nearby Loir, offering peaceful rural perspectives.

Explore the Perche-Gouët terroir around Brou, a transitional land between the cereal plains of Beauce and the bocage hills of Perche. Traditional farms and Percheron horse breeding operations dot this authentic landscape.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure-et-Loir Circuit: Chartres, Châteaux & Proust

visits.text: Noirlac Abbey is one of the best-preserved Cistercian abbeys in Europe. Founded in 1136, it escaped revolutionary destruction because it was used as a porcelain factory until 1950. The church, cloister, chapter house, dormitory, refectory: everything is intact or faithfully restored. The stained glass windows by Jean-Pierre Raynaud (1976-2011) — blue, white, gray — respect the Cistercian spirit while bringing contemporary light.

The cloister is the abbey's heart. Four galleries surrounding a square garden. Romanesque columns, sculpted capitals, ribbed vaults. The monks walked here in silence, hands in sleeves, eight times a day between prayers. The chapter house, where daily decisions were made, has kept its acoustics: a whisper at one end is heard at the other.

Noirlac hosts classical music concerts year-round, taking advantage of the church's exceptional acoustics. The Rencontres Musicales de Noirlac (June-September) feature baroque, sacred music, contemporary. Check the program: attending mass or vespers sung by a vocal ensemble in this Cistercian setting is an unforgettable experience.

activities.text: The Borne de l'Empire (Empire Milestone) stands 500 meters from the abbey. Erected in 1757, it marks the geographic center of France under the Ancien Régime — equidistant from Dunkirk, Perpignan, Brest and Strasbourg. A Roman milestone, it's become a pilgrimage site for lovers of symbolic geography.

The abbey shop sells products made by monks from other communities: honey, jams, herbal teas, candles. Also books on Cistercian spirituality, sacred music CDs, local crafts. Part of the proceeds supports abbey restoration.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: The Old Castle, built in the 13th century on a Roman castrum, dominates a 90-meter cliff. Its Renaissance gallery opens sheer above the Aveyron Gorges with vertiginous panoramas.
The Young Castle was erected between 1485 and 1510 by Maffre de Comminges. Its restored rooms host an exhibition on prehistory and the filming of Le Vieux Fusil with Romy Schneider.
Climb Queen Brunehaut's tower from the 12th century. Legend attributes the village's founding to this Merovingian queen.
Walk cobbled lanes where limestone dwellings from the 15th, 16th, and 17th centuries follow one another. Climbing roses and lilacs adorn the facades.
Discover the exhibition dedicated to Bruniquel Cave. Arranged structures dating to 176,500 years ago make this site the oldest human construction in an underground environment.

activities.text: Explore the terraced gardens spreading across 6 hectares around the castles. Views embrace the Aveyron and Vère valleys.
Reach the panoramic belvedere from the Corniche road. The Bône cirque reveals the Aveyron's meanders embedded in limestone cliffs.
Visit artisan workshops installed in the village. Painters, sculptors, and ceramicists animate this bastide classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages since 1994.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: Walk along the Planches de Cabourg, the iconic 4 km promenade stretching along the sandy beach. The Belle Époque atmosphere permeates this seaside resort with its unique fan-shaped layout. The villas with their bow windows, loggias and colourful ceramics showcase the architectural refinement of the 1900s.

The Grand Hôtel de Cabourg stretches its 300-metre façade facing the sea. Opened in 1907, this Belle Époque palace welcomed Marcel Proust, who stayed each summer in room 414 from 1907 to 1914. The writer composed passages of In Search of Lost Time here, renaming Cabourg 'Balbec'.

activities.text: Explore the Villa du Temps retrouvé, a museum evoking the Belle Époque, housed in the former Villa Bon-Abri. Exhibitions, collections and recreations transport you to the art of living in 1900.
Follow the Marcel Proust promenade named after the writer. The Méridien de l'Amour, a giant sundial on the sand, marks this romantic spot cherished by couples.
Try your luck at the Cabourg casino, next to the Grand Hôtel. Rebuilt in 1911 in a neoclassical style, it carries on the tradition of elegant entertainment at the resort.

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy

visits.text: Pech Merle — Paintings & echoes.
Cénevières — Apparitions & chains.

activities.text: Access: public (Pech Merle)
