days_plan.itin_title: Occitanie Mysteries Road Trip: Cathar Legends & Hidden Secrets of Southern France

visits.text: The Abbaye aux Dames, founded around 1060 by Matilda of Flanders, houses the queen's tomb beneath a black marble slab in the Trinity Abbey Church. A masterpiece of Norman Romanesque art, its capitals carved with fantastical animals and its crypt with its forest of columns transport you to the Middle Ages. The 18th-century conventual buildings, now the seat of the Normandy Region, can be visited with enthusiastic guides.

The Caen Memorial, the leading museum on World War II, presents a gripping journey from the D-Day landings to the Cold War. Period films, reconstructions and testimonies plunge you into 20th-century history with immersive staging. Temporary exhibitions enrich this essential place of remembrance.

William the Conqueror's Castle, one of the largest medieval fortified enclosures in Europe, commands the city centre from its thousand-year-old ramparts. Inside, the Normandy Museum and the Museum of Fine Arts house remarkable collections. The ruins of the ducal palace evoke the power of the conqueror of England.

Explore the Abbaye aux Hommes, where William the Conqueror has rested since 1087. The Saint-Étienne abbey church masterfully combines Romanesque and Gothic architecture. The 18th-century cloister, now the town hall, can be discovered during daily guided tours.
Caen — walk the walls of William the Conqueror's castle and visit its museums time permitting
Caen — pay respects in the Abbaye aux Dames where Queen Matilda lies beneath elegant Romanesque arches
Caen — spot the half-timbered Maison des Quatrans and wander the restored old center
Caen — step inside the Gothic Notre-Dame de la Gloriette church

activities.text: Wander through the Vaugueux quarter, the medieval heart of Caen. Its narrow lanes lined with half-timbered houses are home to traditional restaurants and lively terraces.
Visit the marina right in the city centre. Accessible from Ouistreham via the Orne Canal, it offers an unexpected maritime atmosphere just steps from the castle.
Savour Caen's specialities in a traditional cider house. Tripes à la mode de Caen, andouille de Vire and teurgoule are enjoyed with a farmhouse cider from the Pays d'Auge.
Pedestrian circuit — explore the lively shopping streets and historic quarter on foot

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy
Complete Normandy Road Trip: Dramatic Cliffs, D-Day Beaches & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Haut-de-Cagnes — medieval town, small squares and viewpoints.
Grimaldi Castle-Museum (ext.) — keep and esplanade.
Seaside district — Plage promenade (walking/cycling stroll).

activities.text: Renoir Museum (Domaine des Collettes) — studio and olive grove (according to opening hours).
Côte d'Azur Racecourse — tour of the stands and esplanade (according to schedule).

days_plan.itin_title: French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary

visits.text: The Pont Valentré has spanned the Lot River since 1308. Three defensive towers rise 40 meters above the water, linked by eight stone arches stretching 172 meters. Look for the carved devil perched atop the central tower—a reminder of the legend about the architect's pact with Satan. The bridge is UNESCO-listed as part of the Way of Saint James pilgrimage routes.

Step inside the Cathedral of Saint-Étienne, consecrated in 1119. Two massive domes on pendentives cover the nave—the largest medieval domes in southwest France, soaring over 30 meters high. The western dome preserves 14th-century murals depicting the stoning of Saint Stephen and eight prophets. The northern portal, carved between 1140 and 1160, illustrates Christ's Ascension in intricate detail.

Behind the cathedral, the Flamboyant Gothic cloister was built between 1493 and 1553. Its galleries feature delicately carved arches sheltering sculptures and coats of arms of successive bishops. The Chapel of Saint-Gausbert, in the former chapter house, contains the Holy Coif—a relic believed to have wrapped Christ's head.

Wander the narrow streets of old Cahors: half-timbered medieval houses, Renaissance twin windows, and soleilhos—those distinctive open-air attics typical of Quercy. Rue Nationale, Place Saint-Urcisse, and the Badernes quarter showcase the finest facades. Beneath the underground parking, you can glimpse the remains of a 1st-century Gallo-Roman amphitheater.

Climb Mont Saint-Cyr for the most breathtaking panorama of Cahors. From 260 meters elevation, your gaze sweeps across the entire meander of the Lot, the cathedral domes, and the Pont Valentré far below. The walk takes 45 minutes with 120 meters of elevation gain.

activities.text: Follow the towpath along the Lot River at the foot of Pont Valentré. The trail passes the Chartreux Fountain—a natural spring—and the Maison de l'Eau, a converted 19th-century pumping station. Stunning views of the bridge's arches from the riverbank.

Visit Cahors market on Wednesday and Saturday mornings. Stalls fill the area around the cathedral and market hall—ranked among France's exceptional markets. Find Rocamadour cheese, Périgord walnuts, Quercy lamb, melons, saffron, local pastries, and Cahors wines.

The Cahors AOC vineyards spread across the hillsides surrounding the town. Malbec, the region's signature grape, produces deep, full-bodied wines nicknamed "black wine." Several estates offer tastings by appointment.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot Itinerary: Cahors, Rocamadour & the Lot Valley

visits.text: The 75-meter UNESCO belfry has dominated the town since 1925. Climb for 360° panoramas over Calais and surroundings. The colorful clock faces recall communal mastery of time.
The Burghers of Calais, Rodin's monumental sculpture inaugurated in 1895, commemorates six notables' sacrifice in 1347. Six draped figures, ropes around their necks, immortalize heroism.
The town hall, built 1911–25, blends Flemish Renaissance and Art Nouveau styles. Jules Desbois's sculptures symbolize lace and fishing, the economic pillars.
The Museum of Fine Arts holds works from the 16th to 20th centuries. In 2025, a new Rodin gallery dedicated to the Burghers presents sketches, models, and archives.
The International City of Lace and Fashion occupies a former lace factory. Nineteenth-century machines, craft history, and haute couture collections.

activities.text: Stroll the sandy beach. An ideal space to relax, watch ferries come and go, and contemplate the English coastline.
Visit the lighthouse at the end of Jetée Carnot, classified as a sea lighthouse. Cylindrical white and green tower, accessible at low tide.
Discover the Saint-Pierre-lès-Calais quarter and its lace heritage. Former factories testify to the industry that made the town world-famous.

days_plan.itin_title: Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: Old town of Calvi - cobblestone streets and shops
Citadel of Calvi
Calvi Beach
Bonifatu Forest - river and natural pools
Notre-Dame de la Serra - chapel with view over the bay
Revellata Peninsula - wild coves and beaches

The Citadel of Calvi towers over the gulf from its rocky spur. A 15th-century Genoese fortress, it preserves ramparts, bastions, and cobbled lanes. The Palais des Gouverneurs and the baroque Church of Saint-Jean-Baptiste dominate Terra Nova. Exceptional panorama over the bay, Balagne, and all the way to Monte Cinto on clear days.

Legend claims that Christopher Columbus was born in Calvi in a house within the citadel. Though controversial, this tradition endures through commemorative plaques and local names. The town proudly maintains this link to the famous navigator.

The marina animates the lower town with its quays lined with bars and restaurants. A modern harbor welcoming sailboats and yachts facing the citadel. Cosmopolitan atmosphere reminiscent of Saint-Tropez. Colorful facades reflected in the calm basin waters.

activities.text: Water activities in Calvi
Hiking on the Revellata

Calvi beach stretches 4.5 kilometers of fine sand bordered by maritime pines. Shallow turquoise waters ideal for families. Water sports clubs offer sailing, kayaking, and paddleboarding. The pedestrian promenade extends to the Pointe de la Revellata, accessible on foot or by bike.

The Calvi on the Rocks Festival takes over the citadel each summer. Electronic stages and concerts facing the sea attract international artists. Festive atmosphere within the historic rampart setting. Varied programming from June through September.

Maritime excursions to the Scandola Reserve depart from Calvi harbor. A UNESCO site with red porphyry cliffs plunging into crystalline seas. Marine caves, natural arches, and protected wildlife. Full-day trip with a swimming stop at Girolata.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Corsica Road Trip: Granite Cliffs, Mountain Passes & Island Beaches
Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Tristan Island.
Sables Blancs Beach.
Saint-Corentin Cathedral.

activities.text: Locronan Mountain (panoramic view).
Weaving.
Cornouaille Festival (July).

days_plan.itin_title: Finistère, Brittany Road Trip: Breton Headlands, Ponant Islands & Coastal Heritage

visits.text: Cambrai's belfry, a UNESCO World Heritage site, towers 62 meters above the city. The former bell tower of Saint-Martin Church dates from 1447-1474 and served as a watchtower until 1934—lookouts were still posted to signal fires.

Step inside Notre-Dame-de-Grâce Cathedral, a vast 18th-century edifice housing Fénelon's tomb. This funerary monument, sculpted by David d'Angers, depicts the archbishop kneeling, draped in his chasuble.

Saint-Géry Church preserves a Rubens Entombment in a sumptuous baroque altarpiece. Built between 1698 and 1745, it features richly ornamented interiors with a monumental rood screen and 18th-century carved woodwork.

The Porte de Paris, built between 1685 and 1692, was the fortified city's main entrance. A remnant of Spanish fortifications, this imposing stone and brick arch attests to the defensive role of Cambrai, an episcopal seat since the 6th century.

What remains of old Cambrai? The Spanish House, dated 1595, is the city's last half-timbered house. Its timber framing and overhanging stories contrast with surrounding brick façades. It now houses the tourism office.

CambraiScope, an interpretation center in the former Jesuit college, unveils the city's history through relief maps and immersive displays. The models visualize how the city appeared within its ramparts.

The Museum of Fine Arts occupies a 1720 private mansion. Its rooms present a collection of 17th-century Dutch and Flemish paintings, sculptures and archaeological objects found in the Cambrésis region.

activities.text: Descend into the catiches, underground passages carved in white chalk beneath downtown. Quarried since the Middle Ages then used as civilian shelters until 1944, these cool galleries maintain a constant temperature year-round.

The Bêtise de Cambrai, born around 1830 from a manufacturing error, is a caramelized sugar candy striped with mint. Watch confectioners work the paste into long ribbons—artisan know-how passed down for nearly two centuries in the city.

Circle the ramparts along the tree-lined boulevards encircling the historic center. The route follows the former moats, passes the Porte de Paris and offers clear views of the city's steeples—Cambrai is labeled a City of Art and History.
Taste Cambrai specialties in a downtown estaminet. Local cuisine blends Flemish and Picard influences: maroilles flamiche, potjevleesch, carbonnade—generous dishes suited to the northern climate.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

visits.text: Oyster farming port.
Pointe du Grouin.
Saint-Méen Church.
Abbey (UNESCO).
Medieval village.
Ramparts.
Bay.

The Port de la Houle is the beating heart of Cancale. Fishermen's houses, pressed tightly together, cling to the cliff. The 'back streets,' closest to the rock face, date from the 18th and 19th centuries.
The oyster market operates year-round at the foot of Pointe des Crolles. Oyster farmers open the oysters in front of you. Local tradition: throw the shells into the sea, it brings good luck.
The oyster beds form a geometric grid visible at low tide, covering 366 hectares along the coast. Oyster farming in Cancale is classified as part of France's Intangible Heritage.
From Pointe des Crolles, the view extends over Mont-Saint-Michel bay. This is the official 'Kilometer 0' of the GR34, the customs officers' path that covers 2,000 km of Brittany coast.
On Place de la République, a bronze sculpture pays homage to the oyster washers - women who sorted and cleaned shellfish by hand while their husbands fished off Newfoundland.
Walk to the Houle lighthouse at the end of the jetty. The panorama embraces the oyster beds, boats, and the harbor below.

Conclude your journey in Cancale, the celebrated oyster capital of Brittany, where the bay's pristine waters have nurtured shellfish cultivation for centuries. This picturesque fishing port charms visitors with its colorful boats, waterfront market stalls, and spectacular views across the bay toward Mont-Saint-Michel. The town's authentic Breton character offers a perfect finale to your exploration of this remarkable coastal region.

activities.text: Dol Marshes.
Cathedraloscope (sound and light show).
Lake (walk).
Guided bay crossing.
Spring tides.
La Mère Poulard Inn.

Take the customs officers' path (GR34) from Pointe des Crolles to Pointe du Grouin. The trail alternates between coves, secret anchorages, and panoramas over Mont-Saint-Michel bay. Facing Grouin, the Îles des Landes shelters more than 1,000 pairs of gulls.
Head to Pointe du Grouin for sunrise or sunset. This promontory is the most advanced point of Ille-et-Vilaine - you can see both spectacles from the same rock.
Explore the 'back streets' of the upper town, less touristy, with their gray stone houses and quiet lanes. The upper town was the domain of shipowners, the lower town that of fishermen.

Savor the renowned oysters of Cancale directly at the harborside, where local producers sell their freshly harvested shellfish. The unique mineral-rich waters of the bay impart a distinctive flavor to these prized mollusks, considered among the finest in France. Watch fishing boats return with their catch while enjoying the maritime atmosphere of this working port.

days_plan.itin_title: Ille-et-Vilaine, Brittany: Saint-Malo and Medieval Walled Towns
Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage
Normandy's Bay of Mont-Saint-Michel: Coastal Drives & the Sacred Abbey

visits.text: The Oniria Aquarium spans 3,500 m² with 83 tanks. Inaugurated in 2021, this immersive journey follows the water cycle from Canigou's summit to the ocean abyss. Over 3,500 animals from 660 species populate ten ecosystems.
The marina counts 2,200 berths, Europe's third largest. Protected by two jetties, it features three basins, a modern harbor master's office, and facilities for sailing and motorboating.
The fine sandy beach stretches for six kilometers. Blue Flag certified for over 25 years, it guarantees water quality and environmental standards.
The Canet lagoon forms a 4,019 km² marine nature park. This protected wetland shelters remarkable Mediterranean fauna and flora.

activities.text: Practice water sports at the marina. Diving and sailing schools, jet-ski base, sailboat and catamaran rentals to explore the coast.
Watch the fish auction at the fishing port. The comings and goings of boats returning from sea offer a traditional spectacle from dawn.
Enjoy the beach clubs along the shoreline. Beach volleyball, lounging, and entertainment enliven the six kilometers of sand.
Walk the seafront promenade. Restaurants, bars, and terraces animate the boulevard facing the Mediterranean.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: La Croisette stretches its legendary two kilometers between fine sand beaches, Belle Époque palaces, and luxury boutiques.
Climb to Le Suquet, the medieval quarter perched on its hill: authentic alleyways, breathtaking views over Cannes Bay.
The Palais des Festivals raises its modern architecture facing the sea: climb the famous red carpet-covered steps.
Cannes' painted walls pay tribute to cinema: giant murals celebrating legends of the seventh art throughout the city.
Stroll along the Old Port quays: colorful fishing boats, lively terraces, the spectacle of sailboats dancing at their moorings.

activities.text: Head for the Lérins Islands: Sainte-Marguerite Island houses Fort Royal and the mystery of the Man in the Iron Mask, Saint-Honorat Island welcomes Cistercian monks.
Swim on the fine sand beaches of La Croisette, facing the turquoise waters of the Mediterranean.
Shopping on La Croisette: haute couture window displays, sparkling jewelry stores, coffee break on a palace terrace.
Forville market, the belly of Cannes, overflows with Provençal products: flowers, fruits, cheeses, fish from the auction.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure

visits.text: Estacade: 189m wooden pier built under Napoleon III and completed in 1860, rebuilt and modified several times throughout its history. Built with 600 pine trees, it marks the port entrance and faces the Gouf de Capbreton. The lighthouse added in 1950 has a range of 14 miles. The walk on the planks offers a striking view of the ocean and the underwater canyon.

Port of Capbreton: The Landes department's only fishing and pleasure port with 1,000 moorings. Heir to the former prosperous Port d'Albret until the Adour was diverted in 1578 to Bayonne. The port's 19 boats sell their catch directly at the fish market without auction. Sea bass, sea bream, squid according to seasons.

Gouf de Capbreton: Underwater canyon opening right in front of the pier, comparable to the Grand Canyon and carved by tectonics over 270km. It progressively reaches nearly 4,000m depth offshore. This unique geological phenomenon shapes the waves and local marine life. The Gouf Day during Heritage Days features conferences and activities.

Historic center: Pedestrian street lined with medieval half-timbered houses testifying to Capbreton's maritime past. The Maison de l'Oralité et du Patrimoine tells the story of the port and local traditions. The Boudigau, former bed of the Adour, now winds as a developed canal.

activities.text: Fish market: Daily direct sales by fishermen according to arrivals from 9am to 12pm and 3pm to 7pm. Ultra-fresh line-caught fish, langoustines, sole. Authentic atmosphere on the docks. Fishermen advise on preparation. Prices vary by season and weather.

Dune trail: Starting from the Coastal Ecosystem Research Center (CERS). Discovery of the dune and its specific flora through an educational route. Explanatory panels on the Landes dune ecosystem. Panoramic view from the summit over ocean and forest.

Fish restaurants on the port: Lunch facing the boats with freshly caught specialties. Ttoro (Basque fish soup), grilled squid, grilled sea bream. Lively terraces in season. Reservation recommended on weekends and July-August.
Bike paths to Hossegor and Labenne: Flat connected network allowing coastal exploration. Routes through forest and beaches. Loop possibilities by combining several itineraries. Bike rental downtown.

days_plan.itin_title: Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: Medieval Citadel of Carcassonne — The largest medieval fortress in Europe with 52 towers and 3 km of ramparts. UNESCO World Heritage listed, double walls spanning from the 3rd to the 13th century. Free access day and night.
Château Comtal — Built in the 12th century by the Trencavel viscounts, Cathar sympathizers. Walkways along 1.3 km of ramparts and 35 towers, panoramic views over the Pyrenees and the Montagne Noire.
Basilica of Saint-Nazaire — Former cathedral blending Romanesque and Gothic art. Stained glass windows among the finest in southern France. Free entry.
Bastide Saint-Louis — The lower town of Carcassonne, founded in the 13th century. Shopping lanes, covered market hall, Saint-Michel Cathedral. Local atmosphere, markets and terraces.
Canal du Midi — UNESCO-listed, the canal runs through Carcassonne with its locks and centuries-old plane trees. Boat trips or cycling along the towpaths.
Pont Vieux — Medieval bridge from the 14th century spanning the Aude River. The finest view of the illuminated Citadel at nightfall.
City of Carcassonne: ramparts, Saint-Nazaire basilica and comtal castle.
Châteaux de Lastours (or Peyrepertuse/Quéribus depending on weather): "citadels of vertigo".
Cité de Carcassonne — Shadows on the ramparts.
Montségur — Perfect ones (1244) & glimmers.

activities.text: Tour of the Lists — Walk between the two curtain walls to discover the military architecture. The lower lists connect the Château Comtal to the Trésau Tower.
Canal du Midi cruise — Guided cruises lasting 1 to 2.5 hours departing from the port. Lock passages and canal history.
Twilight stroll on the lists of the city (without crowds).
Discovery of the Corbières landscapes from a Cathar belvedere.
Access: public (Cité)
Access: public (Montségur)

visits.text: Carnac Alignments — Korrigans & myths.
Brocéliande (Paimpont) — Merlin & Barenton.
The Ménec alignments stretch for more than half a mile. Over 1,000 standing stones march in 11 nearly parallel rows. The site begins with a partially preserved megalithic enclosure.

At Kermario, more than 1,000 menhirs arranged in 10 lines cover three-quarters of a mile. The most imposing stones reach 13 feet in height. Climb to the old Kermaux windmill for a panoramic view of the alignment.
The Giant of Manio stands 21 feet tall in the woodland. It's Carnac's tallest standing stone. Nearby, the Manio quadrilateral once enclosed a burial mound restored in the 20th century.
The Saint-Michel tumulus measures 410 feet long by 33 feet high. Built in the Neolithic period, it contains a burial chamber where precious objects were discovered.
Climb to the chapel atop the Saint-Michel tumulus. The panorama sweeps across Quiberon Bay, Belle-Île-en-Mer, and the stone alignments.
The Kerlescan alignments comprise over 500 menhirs in 13 rows. It's the smallest but best-preserved site, extended by the Petit Ménec at La Trinité-sur-Mer.

activities.text: Access: public (Carnac)
Access: public (Brocéliande)
The Megalith House facing the Ménec site offers exhibitions and scale models. It's the starting point for guided tours that allow access inside the enclosures.
Explore the alignment circuit by bike. Nine miles of cycling paths connect the three main sites, passing through heathland and pine forests.
The Carnac Museum of Prehistory holds one of Europe's richest collections. 450,000 years of history from the Paleolithic to the Gallo-Roman period.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany's Mystical Coast: Ancient Megaliths, Abbey Ruins & Celtic Legends
Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

days_plan.itin_title: Mystical Provence: Haunted Villages and Paranormal History of Southern France

visits.text: The Synagogue of Carpentras, founded in 1367, is the oldest in France still in use. Remodeled in the 18th century with luminous rococo decor, it preserves in its basement a 14th-century mikvé, a ritual bath carved into rock.

The 15th-century southern Gothic Cathédrale Saint-Siffrein contains twelve side chapels with baroque decoration. The flamboyant Gothic Porte Juive recalls forced conversions. Inside, the treasury holds the Saint Mors, a relic attributed to Emperor Constantine.
The 1st-century Roman arch, embedded in the cathedral walls, bears bas-reliefs of chained captives. It's the only monumental vestige of ancient Carpentorate.

The 18th-century Hôtel-Dieu houses the Bibliothèque-Musée Inguimbertine. Its pharmacy preserves Moustiers faience jars aligned in period woodwork, and the museum displays paintings, manuscripts, and natural history collections.
The Passage Boyer, a 19th-century covered gallery, cuts through a block of buildings beneath an elegant glass roof. A few shops and cafés animate this Haussmann-style passage in the Provençal heart.

activities.text: Friday morning's market spreads across several squares with over 350 vendors. Candied fruits from Apt, Carpentras berlingots candies, goat cheeses, and vegetables from the Comtat Venaissin.
From mid-November to March, the truffle market convenes every Friday morning. Brokers negotiate Ventoux black truffles in hushed voices, following an unchanging ritual.
Sample Carpentras berlingots, artisanal candies in mint, anise, or violet flavors. Confectioners continue a craft documented since the 14th century.
Bike the Voie Verte du Comtat greenway linking Carpentras to Bédoin at the foot of Mont Ventoux. The path follows the old railway through vineyards and orchards.

Take the scenic Gorges de la Nesque road between Villes-sur-Auzon and Monieux. Over fourteen miles, tunnels carved through rock and overlooks succeed one another above the canyon. Stop at the Belvédère du Castellaras facing the Rocher du Cire, a dizzying 985-foot cliff classified as a Biosphere Reserve.

days_plan.itin_title: Vaucluse: Avignon, Luberon Villages & Ventoux Routes

visits.text: Carrouges Castle — Shadows & voices.
Lyons Forest — Mists & silhouettes.

The Château de Carrouges, a listed historic monument, unfolds seven centuries of architecture—from the 14th-century keep to the Renaissance entrance pavilion, Normandy's first. Encircled by water-filled moats, it houses a state bedroom, a unique hunting collection in Europe, and the chamber where Louis XI stayed in 1473.

The château park spans 25 acres. Wrought-iron gates from the 17th century, groves, an orchard, and medieval-inspired gardens invite exploration. The ground-floor hunting rooms and the keep are freely accessible.

The Collégiale du Chapitre, founded around 1480 by Jean Blosset, Seneschal of Normandy, served as the burial place of the lords of Carrouges for three centuries before becoming the seat of the Regional Natural Park.

activities.text: Access: public (Carrouges)
Access: public (Lyons)

The Maison du Parc et du Géoparc Normandie-Maine offers an interactive museum space on the region's geology and landscapes. A local products shop, cultural programming, and trailheads round out the offerings.
From Carrouges, marked trails plunge into the Écouves and Andaines forests. The Regional Natural Park covers 635,000 acres of bocage, forests, and ridges of the Armorican Massif.

visits.text: Les Bains de Casteljaloux features indoor and outdoor thermal pools. Massage jets, jacuzzis, saunas, and hammams utilize healing thermal waters.
The 15th-century Église Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption rebuilt in the 17th century displays lovely stained glass. This classified Historic Monument dominates the old center.
The 16th-century Maison du Roy houses the tourist office. Louis XIII and Louis XIV both stayed here, hence its prestigious name.
The municipal park and château hosted Jeanne d'Albret and Henri IV. Vestiges of 14th-century ramparts encircle old Casteljaloux.
Admire the 15th- and 16th-century half-timbered houses with overhanging upper floors. One is classified as a Historic Monument.

activities.text: Head to Lac de Clarens for swimming on the sandy beach. The water sports center, treetop adventure course, and fitness trail animate this 130-hectare site.
Rent a canoe or pedal boat to explore the lake. The AquaFun Park offers giant inflatable structures on the water.
Treat yourself to a spa treatment or thermal cure. The chloro-sulfated waters relieve rheumatism and neuralgia.
Explore hiking trails at the edge of the Landes forest. Maritime pines offer striking panoramic views.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: Climb the 262 steps leading to Notre-Dame-du-Roc chapel. The sanctuary stands atop a 184-meter limestone rock dominating Castellane. The panorama embraces village rooftops, the Verdon and the first buttresses of the gorges.

The Verdon gorges display their vertiginous canyon with emerald waters. Cliffs 700 meters high frame Europe's largest canyon. The river has sculpted this geological masterpiece in white Jurassic limestone over millennia.

The Route des Crêtes winds along the edge of the void. Viewpoints follow one another, offering vertiginous plunges into the canyon. Each bend reveals a new perspective on the turquoise meanders of the Verdon and sheer walls.

The old village of Castellane preserves its medieval gates and 14th-century ramparts. Walk through cobbled streets where Provençal houses line up. Place Marcel-Sauvaire brings the town center to life with its market and shaded terraces.

Saint-Victor church blends Romanesque and Baroque architecture. 5th-century baptismal fonts testify to the site's early Christian origins. Restored frescoes illuminate the nave with their vivid colors.
Castellane — lively Provençal town, remains of fortifications, posterns and towers.
Notre-Dame du Roc (ext.) — promontory overlooking the Verdon.
Chapel of Notre-Dame-du-Roc.
Old town.

activities.text: Canyoning plunges you into the heart of Verdon's secondary gorges. Natural slides, jumps into pools and rappels punctuate the descent. Rocky walls enclose crystalline streams in a mineral cathedral atmosphere.

The Martel trail crosses the canyon floor for 16 kilometers. The legendary route follows the traces of 1905 explorers between Chalet de la Maline and Point Sublime. Tunnels carved into rock, metal ladders and aerial passages punctuate this exceptional hike.
Rafting on the Verdon offers thrills in the rapids. Boats glide between canyon walls in a grandiose setting. Calm passages allow admiring cliff fauna and vertiginous cliffs.
Whitewater sports on the Verdon (rafting/canoeing depending on conditions).
Heritage walk in the old town and along the river.
Starting point for the Verdon gorges.
Canyoning.

activities.text: Right bank path to panorama over the valley of châteaux.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

Locks and engineering works (Saint-Roch lock): observation of barges passing through.

activities.text: Shaded stroll along the plane trees of the canal; reading break.
Local tastings (e.g. lingot beans/Limoux AOP at local produce shop).

days_plan.itin_title: Languedoc-Roussillon, France: Medieval Carcassonne, Vineyards and Mediterranean Coast

visits.text: Castelnou crowns an Aspres hill, dominated by its 10th-century viscounty castle whose plan forms an irregular pentagon adapted to the rock. The village hasn't changed silhouette since the Middle Ages: schist houses with canal-tiled roofs, steep lanes, ramparts three meters thick.

The viscounty castle served as residence to the Vallespir viscounts from the 10th to 14th centuries. Classified as a Historic Monument, it's open to visitors: discover a collection of medieval weapons, recreated furniture, and a plunging view over the Roussillon plain to the Mediterranean.

From the battlements, the view reaches Mount Canigou (2,784 m), the Catalans' sacred mountain. In clear weather, snowy foothills stand out to the southwest. To the northeast, the plain of Thuir and Aspres vineyards stretch to Perpignan.
The church of Santa Maria del Mercadal, 12th-century Romanesque, stands outside the ramparts. Its name recalls the market (mercadal in Catalan) once held at the village foot.

Two main lanes structure the village: the carrer d'avall (lower street) and carrer del mig (middle street). Brown schist façades, sometimes enhanced with pink marble lintels, testify to Catalan builders' expertise.
Artist galleries and potter workshops occupy old shops. The village counts a dozen permanent creators whose productions draw inspiration from local materials: terracotta, schist, olive wood.

activities.text: Marked trails around Castelnou cross the Aspres maquis, covered with holm oaks, rockroses, and strawberry trees. The castle loop offers an aerial view of the fortified village.
The Aspres terroir produces AOC Côtes du Roussillon wines. Several estates around Castelnou and Thuir offer tastings of grenache, syrah, and mourvèdre grown at Canigou's foot.
The priory of Serrabona, about thirty kilometers into the Aspres, preserves a carved pink marble tribune from the 12th century, considered a masterpiece of Catalan Romanesque art.

days_plan.itin_title: Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Saint-Sauveur Church has stood on Place de la Raison since 961. Rebuilt in 1254, it served as a priory of Moissac Abbey until 1626. Its hexagonal bell tower and 19th-century stained glass illustrate southern Gothic architecture.
Cross the Eiffel Footbridge spanning the Canal de Garonne. This metal structure built by the Eiffel company connects the train station to the marina.
Port Jacques-Yves Cousteau has welcomed barges since 1998. A steel sculpture honors the commander, while flowering banks invite leisurely walks.
The Town Hall occupies the former Carmelite convent since 1791. Rebuilt between 1824 and 1827 after a fire, it gained a clock and two statues during the 19th century.
The grain market preserves its traditional architecture where markets have been held since the town's medieval founding.

activities.text: Climb to the belvedere overlooking the Garonne. Views sweep across the valley to surrounding hillsides dotted with farms and orchards.
Walk along the Canal des Deux Mers beneath towering plane trees. Cyclists and walkers share the shaded towpath alongside gliding barges.
From November to March, visit the gras market held every Thursday morning. Foie gras, confit, and Southwest specialties fill the covered hall with rich aromas.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: The Goya Museum occupies the former episcopal palace, built in 1675 to designs by Versailles' architect. It's France's only museum entirely devoted to Hispanic art: Goya, Velázquez, Murillo, Picasso, Dalí, and Miró share 23 rooms.

The houses on the Agout River are Castres' emblem. From Quai des Jacobins, admire their pastel façades—white, green, blue, orange—plunging directly into the water. Former homes of tanners, dyers, and weavers, they evoke a little Venice of Languedoc.

At the foot of the Goya Museum, the Bishop's Gardens were designed by Le Nôtre, Louis XIV's gardener. This classified French formal garden offers meticulous geometric perspective, best viewed from the palace's first floor.

Place Jean Jaurès, bordered by handsome granite façades and arcades, is the city's beating heart. The market sets up here four days a week with local products, in the singing atmosphere of southwestern France.

The national center and museum dedicated to the tribune born in Castres in 1859 traces his political career and pacifist struggle. Documents, photographs, and personal objects illuminate this major figure in French history.
Explore the old town's narrow streets: mullioned windows, corner turrets, Renaissance mansions like Hôtel de Viviès or Hôtel Nayrac reveal the past wealth of this City of Art and History.

activities.text: Board a water coach, a faithful reproduction of 17th-century river stagecoaches. The wooden vessel ascends the Agout to Parc de Gourjade, the city's green lung.
Taste nougatine castraise, the city's emblematic crunchy confection, in one of the downtown pastry shops. It's a local terroir classic.
Take the route to Sidobre, a granite plateau east of Castres. Improbably shaped rocks—the Peyro Clabado (780 tons balanced precariously), the Trembling Rock of Sept Faux—dot forests and rivers.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn Road Trip: Albi & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: Notre-Dame Church of Caudebec — Described by Henry IV as "the most beautiful chapel in the kingdom," this 15th-16th century flamboyant Gothic church displays a lace stone facade with 333 statues. Its Renaissance organ and stained glass windows are among the treasures of Norman art.

Maison des Templiers — This 13th-century half-timbered medieval house, one of the oldest in Normandy, houses a local history museum. Its carved beams and low rooms testify to medieval civil architecture.

activities.text: MuséoSeine — This modern museum inaugurated in 2015 retraces the history of the river, navigation and the tidal bore that swept over Caudebec until 1963. Models of Viking ships, barges and river boats evoke 2,000 years of river history.

Caudebec-Villequier Seine Ferry — This free crossing allows you to cross the Seine in a few minutes to reach the north bank. An authentic river experience offering views of the cliffs and meanders of the river.

Boucles de la Seine Normande Regional Nature Park — This 89,000-hectare park protects the Seine meanders, the Brotonne and Roumare forests, marshes and orchards. Hiking, bird watching and discovery of Norman rural heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Maritime Road Trip: Cliffs of Étretat, Rouen and Jumièges Abbey

visits.text: Notre-Dame Church from the 13th century displays southern Gothic architecture. Its brick bell tower dominates the bastide.
Place de la Mairie preserves the arcades where merchants once traded. The town hall occupies an 18th-century bourgeois mansion.
The grain market hosts the traditional market. Caussade was the hat-making capital in the 19th century, producing straw hats exported worldwide.

activities.text: Browse the Saturday morning market animating the bastide. Farmers and artisans display Quercy specialties beneath the market hall.
Learn the history of Caussade hat-making. Workshops produced up to 3 million hats annually in the early 20th century.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: The Pont d'Espagne, at 1,500 meters altitude and seven kilometers south of Cauterets, is a stone bridge from 1886 spanning the confluence of the Gave de Gaube and the Gave du Marcadau. A former pastoral route linking France to Spain via mountain passes, it marks the entrance to the heart of the Pyrenees National Park. The waterfall beside it is accessible in a few minutes' walk from the parking lot.

Lac de Gaube, nestled at 1,725 meters altitude, offers its turquoise waters facing the north wall of Vignemale, the highest peak of the French Pyrenees at 3,298 meters. Accessible on foot in 1h15 from Pont d'Espagne via the GR10, or by chairlift then twenty minutes' walk, it is one of the most photographed sites in the Hautes-Pyrénées.

The Chemin des Cascades connects La Raillère to Pont d'Espagne over approximately four kilometers through the forest. Six waterfalls succeed one another along the Gave de Jéret: the Lutour waterfall, the Mauhourat waterfall above the old sulfur thermal baths, the Escane-Gat waterfall (literally "cat strangler" in Gascon), the Ceriset waterfall with its enormous balanced rock, the Pouey Bacou waterfall which can be approached closely, and the Boussès waterfall.

The thermal village of Cauterets preserves 19th-century spa architecture, from the era when aristocracy came to take the waters. Victor Hugo, George Sand, and Chateaubriand stayed here. The thermal center offers treatments and a balneotherapy space.

The Marcadau Valley opens beyond Pont d'Espagne toward the Clot plateau and the Wallon refuge. This sector of the National Park shelters numerous high-altitude lakes - Aratille, Nère, Pourtet, Cambalès - in a preserved high-mountain setting where chamois and marmots are regularly encountered.

The Lutour valley, south of Cauterets, leads toward La Fruitière and Lac d'Estom in a wild setting of waterfalls, forests, and high-altitude meadows. The shaded route from Cauterets takes about four hours round trip.
Exploration of the Pont d'Espagne and surrounding waterfalls in the Pyrénées National Park.
Stroll through the village of Cauterets, a thermal resort with Belle Époque charm.

Cauterets, a thermal resort at 3,117 feet elevation, preserves remarkable Belle Époque architecture. Grand 19th-century hotels, monumental façades, and ornate balconies testify to the golden age of spa culture. Wander the lanes to soak in the atmosphere of this village labeled "Land of Mountaineering."

The Pont d'Espagne, at 4,908 feet and 4 miles from the village, spans the thundering confluence of the Cauterets and Marcadau mountain streams. Once a mule trail to Spain, it opens the gateway to Pyrenees National Park. Five minutes from the parking lot, waterfalls stage a permanent spectacle.

Lake Gaube rests at 5,659 feet, dominated by Vignemale (10,820 feet), the highest summit of the French Pyrenees. Its turquoise waters mirror the eternal snows. Reach it in 1 hour 15 minutes on foot from Pont d'Espagne or by cable car then chairlift.

The Griffons Thermal Baths at La Raillère, upstream from the village, have exploited naturally sulfurous waters since the 16th century. The buildings are listed as Historic Monuments. Across the way, the Lutour waterfall cascades down from Lake Estom.

activities.text: Hike the Chemin des Cascades from La Raillère: allow 1h30 of shaded forest ascent with 550 meters elevation gain to reach Pont d'Espagne, discovering each waterfall along the trail.
From Pont d'Espagne, climb to Lac de Gaube on foot (1h15 via the GR10) or by chairlift, then picnic by the lake facing Vignemale.
For a longer day, continue beyond Lac de Gaube toward the Oulettes refuge via the trail that follows the torrent - Vignemale draws closer with each step.
End the day with a relaxation session at the Cauterets baths, in a renovated thermal setting that combines indoor and outdoor hot pools facing the mountains.
Relaxation at the Bains du Rocher: outdoor pools, hammams, mother-of-pearl mosaics and refined atmosphere.

Follow the Waterfalls Trail between La Raillère and Pont d'Espagne. Six cascades succeed one another through the forest: Mauhourat, Escane-Gat, Ceriset, Pouey, Bousses, Cerisey. A shaded path ideal for families.
Relax at Bains du Rocher, a thermal spa in the heart of the village. Indoor and outdoor pools heated with natural sulfur water, hammams, saunas, and tropical showers—no reservation needed.

From Pont d'Espagne, hike into the Marcadau valley: the Cayan plateau offers exceptional viewpoints. The most motivated can continue to the Wallon refuge and high-altitude lakes (Aratille, Nère, Pourtet, Cambalès).

On Fridays, Cauterets market gathers local producers and artisans in the village center. Berlingots—traditional candies born in the 16th century to mask the sulfurous taste of thermal waters—are the signature specialty.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: From Tarbes to Cirques and Valleys
The Pyrenees Spa Trail: Thermal Baths from Ax-les-Thermes to Bagnères-de-Luchon
Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: Lourdes, Gavarnie & Pic du Midi

visits.text: The Royal Abbey of Celles-sur-Belle was rebuilt in the 15th century by order of Louis XI, then restored in the 17th century by architect François Le Duc, known as Toscane.
The Romanesque portal with six polylobed arches and sculpted capitals are remains of the first 12th-century construction.
The off-center monumental staircase leads to the nave. The north wing was never completed, hence the imbalance of the façade.
The ribbed-vaulted refectory extends over six bays. The cloister gallery with groined vaults dates from the 17th century.
The museum recreates the abbot's chamber and a monastic cell. Touchscreen tablets facilitate the discovery of liturgical objects.

activities.text: Stroll through the formal French gardens, the insect garden, and the herb garden.
Discover the vintage motorcycle museum which presents models from 1903 to the present day.

days_plan.itin_title: Deux-Sèvres Circuit: Marais Poitevin and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Picasso Museum

activities.text: Visit to the national Museum of Modern Art housed in the Centre Pompidou, as well as its temporary exhibitions.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Museum Pass Itinerary: Masterpieces & Artistic Revolution Guide

visits.text: The harbor of Centuri nestles in a cove lined with colorful houses. France's premier lobster fishing port, multicolored nets dry on the quays. Slate roofs and ochre facades compose a picturesque tableau. The round Genoese tower has stood watch since the 16th century near the Chapel of Saint-Antoine.

The seven hamlets of Centuri stretch in an arc between 110 and 130 meters elevation. Camera reveals the Church of Saint-Sylvestre from the 6th century with its separate square bell tower and the Chapel of Sainte-Croix. Ortinola houses the blue Mattei house, an "American's home" built by Corsicans who returned from Puerto Rico.

The Mattei Mill dominates the western point of the Cape from the D80. Restored in the early 20th century, it symbolizes the Cap Corse aperitif created by Louis-Napoléon Mattei in 1872. Exceptional panorama over the sea on both sides of the Cape and the village of Centuri below.

activities.text: The harbor restaurants serve freshly caught lobster, simply grilled or tossed with pasta. A culinary tradition perpetuated for centuries by fishing families. Reservations recommended in high season.

The Roman road connects Centuri to Macinaggio via the Col de Cataro at 192 meters. An old mule track crossing abandoned sheepfolds and fragrant maquis. A 12-kilometer section lined with dry-stone walls bearing witness to past agricultural activity.

days_plan.itin_title: Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Cerdon clings to steep hillsides where vines produce a sparkling rosé wine with the ancestral method. The village developed around viticulture and copper craftsmanship that made its reputation in the 19th century. Narrow streets climb between golden stone houses to the heights dominating the valley. The Cerdon caves, spectacular reculée where a river emerges from rock, offer breathtaking landscapes.

The Cerdon caves form an impressive limestone cirque where the river Cuisance springs from the mountain. The 80-meter-high cliffs shelter numerous cavities explored by speleologists. A marked trail allows discovery of this geological site while remaining safe. Educational panels explain the formation of this reculée and prehistory of occupation. The refreshing setting and spectacular views attract hikers and climbers.

The Cerdon Wine Museum, housed in an old cellar, recounts the history of this unique sparkling wine. Traditional tools, old bottles, and period documents illustrate evolution of production methods. Videos explain the ancestral method giving Cerdon its characteristic pearls. Guided tastings allow appreciation of subtle aromas of this light rosé wine. The museum also recalls the importance of viticulture in local economy.

Walk through the old village where copper craftsmen workshops can still be seen. This ancestral know-how, transmitted for generations, produced renowned pieces: alembics, kettles, decorative objects. Some craftsmen perpetuate the tradition and open their doors for demonstrations. The hammering sound and copper shine fascinate visitors. Shops offer quality artisanal creations.
The Cerdon Caves open in the Bugey's limestone cliff. The underground tour reveals stalactites and stalagmites before emerging mid-cliff to a vertiginous panorama.
Explore on foot the network of galleries carved by an underground river. The cool temperature offers welcome refuge during summer days.
The prehistoric park offers workshops introducing ancestral techniques: flint knapping, fire starting, spear-thrower shooting.
The Cerdon Copperworks perpetuates artisanal copper object-making techniques. Craftsmen hammer the metal before visitors' eyes.
The Bonnet Silk Works bear witness to the valley's industrial past. The former factory traces the silk epic in Bugey.
Île Chambod spreads its pebble beaches along the Ain River. The turquoise waters invite swimming amid a setting of cliffs.

activities.text: Taste the Cerdon ancestral method at independent winegrowers who cultivate steep hillsides. Each producer offers their version of this characteristic sparkling rosé, fruit of unique clay-limestone terroir. Small family estates, often 3-5 hectares, perpetuate know-how transmitted for generations. The legendary conviviality of Bugey winegrowers makes each visit a moment of authentic sharing.

Practice speleology in the numerous cavities piercing the limestone massif. Avens, chasms, and underground networks offer all difficulty levels for underground exploration enthusiasts. Local clubs organize beginner outings and expeditions to discover concretions, underground rivers, and majestic galleries. Provided equipment and guidance by certified instructors ensure safety and enjoyment.

Hike the caves and vines circuit crossing hillsides and forests. The marked trail traverses vineyard parcels clinging to steep slopes, climbs to Notre-Dame de Carmier, protective virgin perched on the heights, and descends by Fouge and Malpasset waterfalls. These refreshing waterfalls offer a welcome break during hot summer days.

Discover the industrial history of copper craftsmanship that radiated worldwide in the 19th century. Cerdon exported hotel silverware pieces, alembics, and trays around the world. Some workshops still perpetuate this ancestral know-how of hammered copper work. Demonstrations of repoussé and chasing fascinate with gesture precision and beauty of crafted objects.
Set off hiking on the vineyard circuit winding through hillsides where Bugey-Cerdon grapes ripen.
Winemakers open their cellars for tastings of the famous sparkling rosé wine, made using an ancestral method without added sugar or yeast.
Paddle down the Ain River by canoe-kayak from Île Chambod. Calm waters suit families while a few rapids add spice to the route.
The Cerdon viewpoint offers a panoramic view of the village nestled in its setting of vineyards and forests.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: Expanded in 2022, the Museum of Modern Art houses 53 works by Picasso, 14 drawings by Matisse, and canvases by Chagall, Miró, and Soutine. Nicknamed the Mecca of Cubism, Céret drew all the great names of the 20th century.
The Devil's Bridge has spanned the Tech River since the 14th century. Legend has it that a cat was sacrificed to the Devil for its construction.
The Nine Jets Fountain dates from 1313. Its nine spouts supplied water to the different quarters of the medieval town.
Pass through the Porte d'Espagne, remnant of the medieval fortifications. Its arch marks the southern entrance to the old town.
The Church of Saints Peter and Paul houses a baroque altarpiece and works by Catalan sculptors.

activities.text: Experience the Saturday morning market. Local produce, crafts, and Catalan atmosphere fill the main square.
In May and June, taste Céret's cherries. The first fruits are traditionally sent to the French President during the cherry festival.
Take the Sublime Paths route. Reproductions of paintings are placed in situ where the artists worked.
Explore the art galleries in the town center. Céret perpetuates its artistic tradition with a vibrant contemporary scene.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: Cergy — Stroll the Axe Majeur by Dani Karavan, a monumental 3‑km urban artwork aligned on the Oise with belvederes and a red footbridge; late‑20th‑century land art and urbanism.
Cergy-Pontoise — Discover the historic port of Cergy on the Oise, a trading hub revived with quays, cafés and towpath walks.
Pontoise — Old town ramparts and Saint‑Maclou Cathedral, a Flamboyant‑Gothic church (13th–16th c.) with fine carved portals.
Vexin villages loop — Wy‑dit‑Joli‑Village and Marines stone farms; rural Romanesque churches with sculpted portals.
Pontoise quarries (guided) — Underground limestone heritage (book official tours only).

activities.text: Sunset walk along the Oise towpath from Port Cergy; go at golden hour for reflections and quiet birdlife.
Taste local craft beer in Pontoise’s historic center; evening opening times vary, arrive after 18:00.
Farewell dinner on the Oise in Port Cergy; book riverside tables.

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau
Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: Historic center of Chablis: alleyways, winemakers' houses and old washhouses along the Serein.
Saint-Martin Collegiate Church and its Romanesque portal, entry point to the old town.
Obedientiary and monastic traces linked to the first vineyards.
Local wine museum (Vinéa Passion) in Chablis: discovery of terroirs
Tour through the Chablis vineyards: viewpoints over the hillsides

The Collegiate Church of Saint-Martin, built in the 12th and 13th centuries, displays a south portal adorned with 111 horseshoes nailed there by passing pilgrims. Gothic vaults shelter finely carved capitals.
Push open the door to the Obédiencerie, a 9th-century monastery where Chablis wines were born. The 12th-century cellars house an intact 13th-century lever press.
Porte Noël, flanked by two round towers, is the last remnant of the 15th-century ramparts. Chablis once counted 29 square towers and 3 gates protecting the 'lower town.'

The Cité des Climats et des Vins de Bourgogne offers an immersive journey through the history of Chablis vineyards. The visit concludes in the former monks' cellar from Pontigny with a tasting introduction.
Along the Serein River, the Tour Mirau d'Aval recalls the old eastern defenses of Chablis. Just opposite, a nine-arched washhouse reflects in the calm waters.
The Vinéa Passion museum presents a collection of antique winemaking tools gathered over twenty years of flea market finds. The space traces the evolution of Chablis viticultural practices.

activities.text: Walking loop to the Grands Crus belvedere for a panorama over the hillsides.
Path along the Serein between footbridges and small bridges.
Introduction to wine tasting (Chablis appellations) without brand names mentioned
Climb to the Aire des Clos viewing table. The panorama embraces the entire vineyard: the seven Grands Crus on the right bank of the Serein, the Premiers Crus on the opposite hillsides.

Take the 'Seven Grands Crus' hiking trail winding through Chablis vineyards. The short route (4 km, ~45 min) borders the most prestigious plots: Blanchot, Bougros, Les Clos, Grenouilles, Preuses, Valmur, and Vaudésir.
Visit Chablis's Sunday market. Stalls overflow with Burgundian terroir products: Chablis andouillettes, Duché biscuits, and local cheeses.

End the day with a tasting in a village cellar. The four appellations—Petit-Chablis, Chablis, Premier Cru, and Grand Cru—each reveal a distinct mineral character from limestone soil 150 million years old.

Views over the Alps, Vercors and Ardèche high plateaus.
Traces of enclosure and old gate opening onto the ledge.

activities.text: Loop on the ridges and return via the lower village (4–6 km).
Short route through the alleyways to read the built fabric.

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: Puy du Fou unfolds its historical spectacles within a centuries-old forest. The Birds of Prey Phantom Show releases falcons, vultures, and owls above a medieval ruin.
At Mont des Alouettes, two windmills crown the ridge overlooking the Vendée bocage. During the Wars of the Vendée, the position of their sails served as signals to royalist armies.
Visit Challans market on Tuesday morning, one of the region's largest. Stalls overflow with live poultry, prized Challans ducks, and produce from the marshland terroir.

activities.text: Attend the Cinéscénie at Puy du Fou, a nighttime open-air spectacular. Since 1978, thousands of volunteers have brought Vendée history to life on an illuminated lake stage.
Explore the reconstructed villages at Puy du Fou: medieval citadel, 18th-century hamlet, and 1900s town. Artisans demonstrate period crafts before visitors' eyes.
Explore the Marais Breton by canoe from Sallertaine. Tidal channels wind through 110,000 acres of wetland prairies where storks, herons, and egrets nest.
Visit the Moulin de Rairé in Sallertaine, the only windmill in France never to have stopped turning since its construction in 1555. The miller demonstrates flour milling firsthand.

days_plan.itin_title: Vendée Road Trip: Noirmoutier Island, Puy du Fou & Atlantic Coast

visits.text: Four towers of the Collégiale Notre-Dame-en-Vaux pierce the skyline. This UNESCO-listed church has blended Romanesque and Gothic architecture since the 12th century.
A carillon of 56 bells chimes every quarter hour. Built in 1858, it ranks among Europe's most impressive bell sets.
The Cloister Museum displays 50 statue-columns from the 12th century. These remarkable Romanesque sculptures once graced the medieval cloister demolished in the 1700s.
Step into the Cathédrale Saint-Étienne, where 13th-century stained glass ranks among Champagne's finest.

activities.text: Glide along the Canal du Mau in a traditional boat. The collegiate church reflects in the water beside you.
Stroll through the gardens lining the Marne. These green spaces earned Châlons its nickname of "Little Venice of Champagne."

days_plan.itin_title: Marne Road Trip: Reims, Épernay and the Champagne Route

visits.text: Discovery of the old center of Chambéry and its picturesque streets lined with covered passages.
Visit to the Castle of the Dukes of Savoy and the Cathedral of Saint-François-de-Sales.
Lake Aiguebelette – Lake House (Nances) & viewpoints
Chambéry – Old Town & Castle of the Dukes of Savoy (exteriors)
Saint-François-de-Sales Cathedral & Elephants Fountain

The Fontaine des Éléphants, voted France's most beautiful fountain in 2023, towers 17 meters high. Four cast-iron elephants arranged in a Savoy cross support the statue of Count de Boigne, the town's benefactor who made his fortune in India. Locals call it "les quatre sans cul" (the four without butts).

Walk up Rue de Boigne, a 19th-century avenue with Turin-style arcades, to the Château des Ducs de Savoie. Residence of the Counts of Savoy since 1232, the castle houses the Sainte-Chapelle, which sheltered the Holy Shroud before its transfer to Turin. The Grand Carillon—70 bells totaling 41 tons—ranks among Europe's largest.

The Cathédrale Saint-François-de-Sales, a former 13th-century Franciscan chapel, conceals a surprise: Europe's largest surface of trompe-l'oeil paintings covers its vaults. The treasury includes a 12th-century Byzantine diptych.

Lose yourself in the maze of old-town alleys: traboules, covered passages, inner courtyards of mansions with bare molasse-stone facades. Rue Basse du Château, the oldest street, preserves a wooden footbridge spanning the lane.
Place Saint-Léger, the city's original heart, lines up colorful facades with Italian influences. Café terraces nestle under arcades, between shops and 15th-18th-century townhouses.

The Musée des Beaux-Arts de Chambéry, near the old town, presents a collection spanning the Middle Ages to contemporary art: paintings, sculptures, and temporary exhibitions in a setting that reflects Savoyard identity.

activities.text: Tasting of chocolate truffles, invented in Chambéry, in an artisanal chocolate shop.
One-hour hike on the trails of the Bauges massif with panoramic view over the valley.
Kayaking or bike path ride along Lake Aiguebelette (seasonal)
Guided tour "Castle, Alleyways and Secrets": a heritage guide opens the doors to inner courtyards, reveals hidden spiral staircases, and recounts the histories of noble Savoyard families.
Savoie wine tasting in downtown cellars. Apremont, Roussette, Mondeuse: local grape varieties are discovered alongside Tomme des Bauges cheese and diots (Savoyard sausages).

Bike ride on the Voie Verte linking Chambéry to Le Bourget-du-Lac. The flat route follows the shoreline and passes the Prieuré du Bourget-du-Lac, an 11th-century Cluniac priory with a Gothic church and French formal gardens.

visits.text: Discovery of Lake Chambon, volcanic lake located at the foot of the Sancy massif.

activities.text: Swimming, canoeing or pedal boating on Lake Chambon.
Walk on the beaches and trails around the lake.

days_plan.itin_title: Auvergne Volcanoes, France: Ancient Peaks, Crater Lakes and Lava Flows

visits.text: The Abbey Church of Sainte-Valérie in Chambon-sur-Voueize surprises with its imposing dimensions in this small village. This 11th-century Romanesque church, one of the largest in Limousin, houses the reliquary bust of Sainte-Valérie, a young Christian beheaded according to legend for refusing marriage. Tradition tells that she carried her head to Saint-Martial who placed it back on her shoulders.

The village of Chambon-sur-Voueize merits a stroll through its old alleys. Ancient shops, the Romanesque bridge spanning the Voueize, and character houses compose a picturesque tableau. Climb the Grande Rue du Puy for an overall view of the village and its majestic abbey church.

activities.text: The Voueize gorges offer a preserved natural setting for hiking. Marked trails follow the river through dense vegetation. The coolness of the undergrowth and the murmur of water create a soothing atmosphere, conducive to observing local wildlife.

days_plan.itin_title: Creuse Circuit: Valley of the Painters and Aubusson Tapestries

visits.text: Château de Chambord rises at the heart of Europe's largest walled park. This architectural masterpiece commissioned by François I after his victory at Marignano impresses with colossal dimensions: 440 rooms, 282 chimneys, and 77 staircases. The double-helix staircase attributed to Leonardo da Vinci forms the centerpiece of the keep, allowing two people to ascend and descend without ever meeting. The terraces offer 360-degree views over the 5,440-hectare park encircled by 32 kilometers of walls. The restored French gardens deploy 600 trees, 800 shrubs, and 15,000 plants before the north façade.

Chambord Forest Park extends across 5,440 hectares entirely enclosed by a 32-kilometer wall. The 800 hectares open to the public offer hiking trails and cycling paths through centuries-old oak forests and wild meadows. Abundant wildlife includes deer, wild boar, roe deer, and numerous forest birds. Purpose-built observation points let you admire animals without disturbing them, creating privileged moments deep in preserved wilderness. The estate constitutes a national hunting and wildlife reserve.

French Gardens of Chambord recreated from Louis XIV's historical plans. The 6.5 hectares of geometric parterres unfold boxwood embroidery, topiaries, and immaculate lawns before the château's north façade. The grand axis stretching 4.5 kilometers extends the perspective from the double-helix staircase to the canal. Quincunxes of trees and riding paths structure the space harmoniously. Flowerbeds and sculpted shrubs evolve through the seasons, creating ever-renewed botanical tableaux.

activities.text: Bicycle rental to explore Chambord estate and surrounding forests. Rental shops offer classic and electric bikes for covering forest trails and the canal loop. Dedicated cycling paths enable wildlife observation and château views from changing angles. The 4-kilometer circuit around the château offers shifting perspectives on Renaissance architecture. Surrounding villages like Maslives reveal themselves by bike in a preserved countryside atmosphere.

Deer watching during rutting season in Chambord forest from mid-September to mid-October. The estate shelters approximately 700 deer whose powerful bellowing echoes at dawn and dusk throughout the forest. Purpose-built observation points let you witness this impressive natural spectacle while respecting wildlife. Males clash in spectacular combat to win females. Booking is highly recommended for guided outings organized by the estate with specialized naturalist guides.

Electric boat ride on Chambord canal running alongside the château. This peaceful activity offers a unique perspective rarely accessible—viewing the north façade from the water. The 1.8-kilometer canal dug in the 18th century reflects the monumental architecture and French gardens. Silent boats favor observation of aquatic birds nesting in the reeds. Boats rent by the hour for contemplative family outings in an exceptional setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Chamonix-Mont-Blanc nestles at the foot of Western Europe's roof. This world capital of mountaineering has attracted travelers fascinated by glaciers and granite needles since 1741.
The Aiguille du Midi peaks at 3,842 meters, accessible by the Alps' most vertiginous cable car. The panoramic terrace offers a breathtaking view of Mont Blanc and surrounding peaks.
Step into the Void suspends visitors above 1,000 meters of emptiness in a glass cage. The experience guarantees thrills.
The Panoramic Mont-Blanc gondola links the Aiguille du Midi to Pointe Helbronner in Italy. This aerial journey flies over the Vallée Blanche and its seracs.
Chamonix town center blends traditional chalets with mountaineering shops. The statue of Jacques Balmat points to the summit he first conquered in 1786.
Saint-Michel Church raises its steeple facing the peaks. The neighboring cemetery holds the graves of mountaineers who died in the mountains.
The Montenvers Train has climbed the mountainside since 1908 to the Mer de Glace. This rack railway offers spectacular views of Chamonix's needles.
The Mer de Glace spreads its 7-kilometer glacier, France's longest. The Drus, Grandes Jorasses, and Grépon dominate this river of ice with their vertiginous walls.
The Ice Grotto is visited inside the glacier itself. Carved each summer as the glacier advances 70 meters per year, it reveals ephemeral ice sculptures.
The Glaciorium explains glacier formation and retreat due to climate change. This interpretation center raises awareness about environmental issues.
The Alpine Wildlife Museum presents animals inhabiting the high mountains. Mounted chamois, ibex, and eagles alongside a crystal collection.
430 steps now separate the station from the glacier, eloquent testimony to ice retreat over the decades.

activities.text: Treat yourself to the Aiguille du Midi ascent at day's end to watch the sunset over the Mont Blanc range.
Glaciers can also be discovered on guided hikes with mountain guides who share their passion for the massif.
The QC Terme spa offers hot baths facing the Alpine panorama. Steam from outdoor pools creates a magical atmosphere in winter.
The pedestrian street abounds with mountaineering gear shops and souvenirs. Café terraces offer constant spectacle of the peaks.
The Montenvers station panoramic restaurant offers unbeatable views of the Drus and Grandes Jorasses during lunch.
Experienced hikers can descend on foot to Chamonix via the Montenvers trail through the forest.
In winter, the 20-kilometer Vallée Blanche ski descent is a legendary adventure on the glacier.
The Mont-Blanc Tramway from Saint-Gervais climbs to Nid d'Aigle at 2,372 meters, starting point for climbers.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: Board the cable car holding the world record for the highest vertical ascent: 2,807 meters in just 20 minutes. The summit reaches 3,842 meters with a 360° panorama over the Mont Blanc massif. Don't miss the Step Into the Void—a glass box suspended more than 1,000 meters above the abyss that tests your nerves and your Instagram game.

Wander the lively streets of Chamonix, the world capital of mountaineering. Visit the Saint-Michel church and admire the Belle Époque villas that recall the town's pioneering days. The Alpine museum traces the dramatic history of summit conquests that made this valley legendary.

The cable car's intermediate station at 2,310 meters, Plan de l'Aiguille serves as the jumping-off point for numerous summer hikes. This plateau offers unobstructed views of Chamonix's needle-sharp granite spires—the peaks that launched modern alpinism.

activities.text: Experience a once-in-a-lifetime journey on this legendary cable car. The ascent unfolds in two stages: Plan de l'Aiguille, then the spectacular section that climbs the sheer north face. At the summit, explore the panoramic terraces and brave the Step Into the Void if you dare.

For experienced hikers, the Grand Balcon Nord trail links Plan de l'Aiguille to Montenvers station. The path traverses high above the valley beneath the razor-sharp granite needles that make Chamonix famous among climbers worldwide.

Explore the historic center, browse world-class mountaineering equipment shops, and soak up the unique atmosphere of a town where alpinists from every corner of the globe converge to test themselves against legendary peaks.

visits.text: The Château de Champs-sur-Marne, an 18th-century gem, illustrates aristocratic living under Louis XV. Its furnished and decorated interiors—painted paneling, chinoiserie, and refined furniture—are among the best preserved in Île-de-France.
The formal garden, attributed to Claude Desgots, nephew of Le Nôtre, unfolds its embroidered parterres facing the château. Geometric perspectives frame pools and sculpted topiaries.
The English-style landscape park, laid out in the 19th century, contrasts with the formal garden's rigor. Large centuries-old trees border rolling lawns and winding paths.
The château has served as a backdrop for numerous historical films and series. Its salons, staircases, and gardens recreate the Enlightenment atmosphere.

activities.text: Picnic in the château park, beside the Marne. The shaded lawns offer a peaceful setting to conclude your Seine-et-Marne circuit.
Walk to the Marne riverbanks from the château. The towpath follows the river, offering a bucolic stroll at the gates of Paris.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: Chanaz nestles along the Savières Canal linking Lake Bourget to the Rhône. This picturesque village is nicknamed the little Venetia of Savoy for its quays lined with flower-bedecked houses.
The navigable canal invites waterside wandering. Pleasure boats pass former salt storehouses converted into artisan workshops.
Steep lanes climb between stone houses with colorful shutters. The village antique shop overflows with treasures collected over decades.
The walnut oil mill still operates the old way. Stone millstones crush the kernels to produce oil with an incomparable taste.
The Romanesque church raises its bell tower above the slate roofs. Interior frescoes date from the 12th century.

activities.text: Rent a canoe-kayak to glide along the Savières Canal to nearby Lake Bourget.
Guided cruises reveal the canal and its wild banks where herons and kingfishers nest.
Push open the doors of artisan workshops housed in former shops: potters, weavers, and wood carvers.
The canalside restaurant serves Savoyard specialties facing the water reflections and colorful facades.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: The Château de Chantilly rises in two parts: a Renaissance Petit Château from the 16th century and a Grand Château rebuilt between 1875 and 1880. Passing from Louis d'Orléans to the Princes of Condé and finally to the Duke of Aumale, it was bequeathed to the Institut de France in 1886.

The Musée Condé holds France's second-largest collection of Old Master paintings after the Louvre. Eight hundred works by Raphael, Fra Angelico, Poussin, Watteau, and Ingres hang in 19th-century galleries arranged exactly as the Duke of Aumale specified in his will.

The Cabinet des Livres houses 19,000 volumes and 1,500 illuminated manuscripts. Among these bibliophilic treasures bequeathed by the Duke of Aumale shines the Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry, one of medieval art's supreme masterpieces.

The Grandes Écuries stand as a monument to equestrian grandeur, designed by Jean Aubert between 1719 and 1735. Two 70-meter naves crowned by a 28-meter dome once sheltered 240 horses and 500 hunting dogs.

The Living Museum of the Horse fills fifteen rooms of the Grandes Écuries with two hundred objects tracing equestrian history. The harnesses from Charles X's 1825 coronation and rare hippological collections bring centuries of horsemanship to life.

The Park spreads across 115 hectares designed by Le Nôtre, Louis XIV's legendary landscape architect. A 2.5-kilometer Grand Canal flows through formal French gardens, an Anglo-Chinese garden, and an English landscape garden.

activities.text: Wander through the Hameau among five rustic thatched cottages built in 1773. These Norman-style cottages directly inspired Marie-Antoinette's hamlet at the Petit Trianon.

days_plan.itin_title: Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: 30 km south of Troyes, Chaource sits in the bocage landscape with limestone houses and damp meadows typical of the Champagne countryside. The town gave its name to the famous soft cheese with bloomy rind, created in the Middle Ages by Cistercian monks from Pontigny. The Cheese Museum tells this dairy story through period objects, documentary film and final tasting that showcase this gastronomic heritage recognized as AOC in 1970.

The church of Saint-Jean-Baptiste is worth the visit alone. This Gothic building constructed from the 12th to 17th century houses a dazzling Renaissance sculpture collection. In the crypt rests the Entombment of 1515, created by the mysterious Master of Chaource — a polychrome sculpted group that attracts art pilgrims from around the world. 16th-century gilded wood nativity scene, majestic organ, sculptures blending Champagne art with Italian touches form an exceptional museum collection housed within a parish church.

activities.text: Cheese artisans perpetuate ancestral methods: 2 to 4 liters of whole milk from local cows for a single chaource. Slow coagulation of minimum 12 hours, delicate hand-ladling (never mechanized), dry salt curing then minimum 14-day aging in cool humid cellars produce this creamy cylinder with flowing heart. On the palate: notes of fresh hazelnut and double cream. Chaource delighted royal courts even at François I's table. Visits possible with reservation.

The Pays d'Othe region around Chaource offers a network of marked trails through state forest, preserved bocage and secret valleys. Family circuits or experienced hikers explore this territory alternating deciduous woods, grazed meadows and viewpoints over the Champagne countryside. GPS tracks and paper maps available at the Othe Armance Tourist Office to independently explore these rolling landscapes between Champagne and Burgundy.
