days_plan.itin_title: Val-de-Marne, France: A Road Trip to Pleasure Gardens & Historic Lakeside Châteaux

visits.text: Benedictine Abbey. Founded around 875 and attached to Cluny Abbey in 932, this classified monastic ensemble distinguishes itself through exceptional architectural quality. The 12th-century great portal, its decoration inspired by the Book of Revelation, constitutes a masterpiece of Romanesque art. The late 15th-century cloister opens onto the chapter house through a Romanesque colonnade. The prior's chapel and courtyard date from the early 16th century. The Philippe Auguste tower, a defensive donjon over 21 meters tall and 11 meters in diameter, dominates the complex. Excavations have revealed foundations of three successive churches built in the 9th, 10th, and 11th centuries. The abbey celebrates 1,150 years since its founding in 2025.

Silk Museum. Installed in a former weaving workshop, the museum recounts Charlieu's textile history as once a premier silk production center. From 1827 onward, the silk-weaving industry flourished here. Functioning looms, sumptuous fabrics, and live demonstrations reveal artisan expertise. Temporary exhibitions complement the permanent collection. This living museum illuminates the international reputation Charlieu achieved through its textile creations.

Medieval Old Town. Certified as a Village of Character and one of France's Most Beautiful Detours, Charlieu preserves its 13th-century stone houses and picturesque 14th- and 15th-century timber-framed dwellings with overhanging upper stories. Renaissance and classical residences line the medieval streets. The town's first mention dates to 994. Created under abbey protection at the Duchy of Burgundy's edge, its strategic position prompted French kings to fortify it, as Philippe Auguste did in 1180. A prosperous town populated by merchants and artisans, particularly weavers.

activities.text: Charlieu Andouille Tasting. This local gastronomic pride is crafted according to traditional expertise passed down through generations. Smoked over beechwood and lightly spiced, it's enjoyed hot or cold. Downtown restaurants feature it as a specialty. Local charcutiers perpetuate the tradition.

Véloire Greenway Ride. The greenway connects Roanne to Paray-le-Monial in Saône-et-Loire. From Briennon, a gentle 1.2 km stretch on shared roadway crosses the Loire to reach Pouilly-sous-Charlieu, then 4.9 km of greenway leads to Charlieu. Family-friendly cycling or walking route along the canal and through the countryside.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Tower of Charles the Bold.
Convent of the Visitation.
Priory.

activities.text: Charolais Country (livestock farming).
Arconce.
Villages of character.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: Charroux, the only Most Beautiful Village of France in Allier, crowns a hill at 413m altitude. Its cobblestone streets wind between carved stone facades (15th-18th centuries) and half-timbered houses from the 14th century. The Orient and Occident gates mark the location of the old fortifications of this medieval city once a stronghold and commercial crossroads of Bourbonnais.

The 12th-century Saint-Jean-Baptiste church intrigues with its truncated bell tower, a mystery finally solved: lightning beheaded it over the centuries. In the village heart, the Cour des Dames reveals its unique circular architecture, a grassy inner courtyard where facades seem to curve creating a mysterious space. An astonishing place accessible through narrow passages.

The Charroux and Canton Museum occupies 14 rooms spread across two buildings of the old fortification. Collections of objects, documents, sculptures and furniture trace Charroux's history from Gallo-Roman times to the 20th century. A monetary treasure of 600 silver coins from the 12th century testifies to the right to mint currency granted to monks.

Walk through rue de l'Horloge and rue de la Poulaillerie discovering houses with carved stones and hidden courtyards. Maison à la Salamandre, with its François I emblem, and Maison du Prince de Condé with Renaissance decoration illustrate the medieval village's prestige. Panoramic viewpoints over Bourbonnais bocage reveal a patchwork of meadows and hedges.

activities.text: The Charroux mustard house perpetuates artisanal mustard-making since 1988, reviving a tradition dating back to monks. Local mustard seed, white wine from Allier and local honey compose this condiment with subtle flavor. The shop offers tastings and sales of several mustard varieties, sweet to strong.

The Sunday morning market brings life to the village with local producers offering farm products, Charroux mustard, Bourbonnais cheeses and fruits from family orchards. The convivial atmosphere invites tasting and exchanges with artisans perpetuating regional know-how.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: Notre-Dame de Chartres Cathedral, a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1979 and an absolute masterpiece of French Gothic architecture. Its 176 stained glass windows from the 12th and 13th centuries represent 2,600 square meters of exceptionally preserved glass work, including the famous Chartres blue. The two asymmetrical spires dominate the Beauce plain and can be seen from nearly thirty kilometers away.

Cathedral labyrinth, a geometric pattern inlaid in the nave's paving stones since the 13th century. This symbol of the tortuous path to salvation is one of Europe's largest at 261 meters long. Pilgrims still walk it on their knees during special occasions.

Cathedral crypt, the world's third-largest crypt. It forms the lower cathedral and houses the Well of the Saints-Forts along with the Veil of the Virgin, a relic given by Charles the Bald in 876. One of medieval Western Christianity's most popular Marian pilgrimage sites.

Royal Portal of the cathedral, a marvel of 12th-century Romanesque sculpture. The column statues frozen in eternity represent a transitional art between Romanesque and Gothic, unique in the world. The 13th-century north and south portals showcase the era's elegant craftsmanship.

Ascent of the cathedral's north tower to access the immense metal framework and discover a breathtaking view over the city and the Beauce plain. A dizzying experience revealing the construction secrets of medieval master builders.

Saint-Piat Chapel, reopened in 2024 after 24 years of restoration. It now houses the cathedral treasury with nearly 150 precious liturgical objects and contemporary stained glass by Korean artist Bang Hai Ja. An architectural jewel bridging medieval heritage and contemporary creation.

activities.text: Chartres in Light, the world's largest heritage illumination event. From April to January, 21 heritage sites light up every evening from dusk until 1 AM. A magical free walking tour through the historic center with video mapping projections on the cathedral.

Stroll through old Chartres, between the upper town around the cathedral and the lower town along the Eure River. Discover half-timbered houses like the Maison de la Truite qui File and the Maison du Saumon, witnesses to the medieval merchant tradition. The cobblestone streets reveal remarkably preserved heritage.

Walk along the banks of the Eure in the lower town, where stone bridges, medieval wash houses, and timber-framed houses follow one another in a bucolic setting. The cathedral's silhouette in the background offers romantic perspectives at every turn.

Visit the Bishop's gardens behind the cathedral, laid out in the former episcopal palace. The beautifully maintained French-style garden offers panoramic views over the old town, the Eure riverbanks, and Chartres' outskirts. An ideal relaxation spot after visiting the cathedral.

Valbonne state forest, Mediterranean relic with varied tree species.

days_plan.itin_title: Nièvre, France: Morvan Hills and Ducal Castle Heritage Routes
Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: Chambord emerges from the marshy Sologne lands. 128 meters of façade, 282 chimneys, 440 rooms, and 83 staircases. François I ordered its construction in 1519 to engrave his power into white tufa stone.

At the center of the keep, the double-helix staircase remains the marvel of the place. Two helical ramps coil around an open core: two people climb simultaneously without ever meeting. The design is attributed to Leonardo da Vinci's inspiration.

On the second floor, the coffered vaults bear the emblems of François I: the salamander and the letter F repeat several hundred times on walls and ceilings. Some monograms are traced upside-down to be readable by God from heaven.

Climb to the terraces for a 360-degree view. This "celestial village" bristling with turrets, sculpted dormers, and monumental chimneys forms a striking contrast with the sober façades. The lantern tower rises to 56 meters.
The royal apartments house a collection of 4,500 art objects in refurnished rooms. The 18th-century kitchens and the state apartments complete the more than 70 rooms open to visitors.
Château de Chambord, the largest and most extravagant of all Loire châteaux—a royal hunting lodge turned architectural marvel
The double-helix staircase of Château de Chambord, rumored to be inspired by Leonardo da Vinci himself
The rooftop terraces and chimneys of Château de Chambord, a skyline of carved stone turrets and lanterns
The carriage hall at Château de Chambord, displaying historic vehicles and royal splendor

activities.text: The formal French gardens, recreated in 2017 across 6.5 hectares at the château's foot, recover their Louis XIV-era design. The 19th-century English garden unfurls its curved paths among cedars and sequoias.
The 5,500-hectare estate is Europe's largest enclosed forest park, surrounded by a 32-kilometer wall. Nature outings in all-terrain vehicles allow observation of deer, wild boar, and raptors.
Walk through the formal gardens and vast estate of Chambord, enclosed by Europe's longest wall
Experience the year-end illuminations at Chambord, when the château glows like a winter dream

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château de Champchevrier, surrounded by moats and woods, is one of the rare stag-hunting estates still active in Touraine. Its long 17th-century classical façade overlooks a preserved forest park.
The reception salons preserve 17th and 18th-century furniture: Flemish tapestries, Louis XV commodes, family portraits, and hunting trophies compose an authentic aristocratic décor.
The hunting room traces several centuries of venery. Antlers, hunting horns, whips, and period attire testify to a tradition transmitted from generation to generation by the owning family.
The château's old kitchens and outbuildings open their doors. Copper batteries, serving utensils, and larders recreate the domestic organization of an aristocratic estate.
Château de Champchevrier, a royal hunting lodge where kings once pursued game through surrounding forests
Tour the reception salons of Château de Champchevrier, still furnished as they were in centuries past
Discover the history of hunting at Champchevrier, through displays of antique weapons, trophies, and hunting prints

activities.text: The pack of hunting hounds, fed daily in the château's kennel, can be observed during the visit. Ask at reception for the feeding schedule to witness this centuries-old tradition.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Chenonceau spans the Cher on five arches. Nicknamed the "Ladies' Château," it was shaped by Katherine Briçonnet, Diane de Poitiers, Catherine de Medici, and Louise of Lorraine, each leaving her architectural mark.
The two-story gallery built by Catherine de Medici over the Cher extends 60 meters. During World War I, it served as a military hospital. During World War II, the south bank opened to the Free Zone.

Pass through the richly decorated rooms: Catherine de Medici's green study, Diane de Poitiers' chamber with its monumental fireplace by Jean Goujon, François I's chamber with its Renaissance furniture.

The Louis XIV salon preserves a portrait of the king painted by Rigaud, offered during his visit in 1650. The neighboring chapel holds stained glass windows by Max Ingrand installed after World War II.
The painting collection assembles works by Primaticcio, Rubens, Tintoretto, and Murillo. The Gallery of Domes exhibits paintings by European old masters.
The kitchens occupy the château's foundations, at water level. Butler's pantry, staff dining room, larder, and butchery testify to the domestic organization of a great Renaissance estate.
Château de Chenonceau, the château of the great ladies of history—built, embellished, and protected by women across the centuries
The two-story gallery of Château de Chenonceau spanning the River Cher, a corridor of light and reflection
The richly decorated rooms of Château de Chenonceau, each bearing the mark of its remarkable female patrons
The main gardens of Château de Chenonceau—Diane de Poitiers' garden and Catherine de Medici's garden, rivals in beauty
The plant labyrinth at Chenonceau, where pathways wind through carefully sculpted greenery
The collection of Old Master paintings at Chenonceau, including works by Rubens, Tintoretto, and Van Loo

activities.text: Diane de Poitiers' gardens unfold their geometric beds bordered with lavender along the Cher. Facing them, Catherine de Medici's more intimate gardens organize around a central basin.
Get lost in the 1-hectare plant labyrinth, planted with 2,000 yews. At the center, a raised pavilion offers a plunging view onto the winding paths.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Cheverny dazzles with the perfect symmetry of its Bourré stone façades, a tufa that whitens with time. Built in a single campaign between 1620 and 1640, it pioneered the French classical style that would dominate under Louis XIV.

Seventeen richly furnished rooms are open. 17th-century Gobelins tapestries, Louis XIV and Louis XV furniture, old master paintings, and gilding compose an interior so well preserved it seems still inhabited. The Hurault de Vibraye family has resided here for six centuries.
The arms room houses a collection of armor, crossbows, and arquebuses. Heavy swords and shields recall the era of medieval tournaments.

Hergé drew inspiration from Cheverny's façade to create Marlinspike Hall for Tintin. He simply removed the two side pavilions. The permanent exhibition "The Secrets of Moulinsart" occupies 700 m² in the outbuildings.

Crypt, Marlinspike drawing room, Tintin's bedroom, Professor Calculus's laboratory: the life-size recreations from the exhibition plunge young and old into the comic book universe with sound and light.
Château de Cheverny, the real-life inspiration for Marlinspike Hall in the Tintin comics—still owned by the same family for six centuries
The lavishly furnished interiors of Château de Cheverny, a living museum of French decorative arts
The formal gardens of Cheverny, where symmetry and color create a tapestry across the seasons

activities.text: Board an electric boat to glide along the park's canal. The avenue of 157 Atlas cedars and the Louisiana bald cypresses reflect in the calm water.
Six themed gardens unfold through the seasons: bouquet vegetable garden, tulip garden in spring, laurel labyrinth. Electric carts tour the 100-hectare estate.
Craving a sweet break? The Orangery behind the château offers artisanal ice creams and cold drinks beneath the park's canopy.
Explore The Secrets of Marlinspike Hall exhibition at Château de Cheverny, a tribute to Hergé's beloved comic series
Glide across the park in an electric boat, drifting along the château's tranquil waterways
Enjoy a picnic in the park of Château de Cheverny, under the shade of ancient trees

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château de Gizeux unfurls 250 meters of façades, making it the longest residence in Touraine Angevine. Property of the du Bellay family for 350 years (including the poet Joachim du Bellay), it's now inhabited by the de Laffon family.

The François I Gallery, on the first floor, was entirely painted by Italian artists around 1585. One can distinguish Marie d'Yvetot's monogram, mythological scenes inspired by Ovid's Metamorphoses, and flower bouquets.

During the Revolution, the villagers helped cover the paintings with a mud wall to hide royal symbols from vandals. The formwork, intended as temporary, was only rediscovered in the 20th century by a child playing in the château.

The Gallery of the King's Châteaux, restored between 2013 and 2019, unfurls 400 m² of 17th-century murals representing the great royal châteaux: Chambord, Versailles, Fontainebleau, and Gizeux itself.

On the ground floor, the small salons with 18th-century woodwork illustrate the comfort of Renaissance life. The dining room, kitchen, and vaulted cellars complete the circuit through this still-inhabited residence.
Château de Gizeux and its magnificent painted galleries, adorned with frescoes depicting mythological scenes
The collections of furniture and objets d'art at Gizeux, accumulated by generations of the same family

activities.text: In summer, the owners dress in costume on Tuesdays at 9 PM for a candlelit tour. By flickering light, the painted galleries, Cordovan leathers, and gilding take on a theatrical dimension.
The château's vaulted cellars host tastings of Bourgueil wines, an appellation produced on neighboring hillsides. The estate once owned its own vines, lost to phylloxera in the early 20th century.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

places.name: Chateau De La Ferte Saint Aubin

visits.text: At the edge of Sologne, the château de La Ferté-Saint-Aubin aligns its 17th-century brick-and-stone façades above moats that once controlled the Cosson River before Chambord. A porch flanked by two pavilions opens onto the courtyard of honor.

A private residence inhabited for over 350 years, the château opens more than 15 furnished rooms. From vaulted cellars to attics, the route crosses the guards' hall, the dining room, the salons, and the granaries.

The grand kitchens in the basement are the star attraction. The 19th-century stove still functions: a cook in period costume prepares Sologne honey madeleines baked over wood fire and offers tastings.
On either side of the courtyard, the Great Stables (riding horses) and the Small Stables (service horses) built by Henri II de la Ferté Sennecterre are open to visitors.
Behind the château, on a small island in the moats, stands a 19th-century chapel. Its reflection in the still water composes one of the estate's most photogenic views.
Château de La Ferté-Saint-Aubin, nestled in a wooded park where nature and history intertwine
Tour the historic rooms of Château de La Ferté-Saint-Aubin, filled with family heirlooms and period charm
Explore the 50-hectare park of La Ferté-Saint-Aubin, with forest trails and peaceful ponds

activities.text: Explore the 40-hectare park in Sologne. Mini-golf, life-size wooden games, and a puzzle trail through the vegetation occupy a half-day for families.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château de Langeais juxtaposes two edifices: the ruins of Foulques Nerra's keep (994), one of France's oldest stone keeps, and Louis XI's residence built from 1465, a severe fortress facing the town, an elegant manor facing the gardens.
The Langeais drawbridge is one of the rare still in working condition in France. Its mechanism of chains and counterweights operates just as it did in the 15th century.

Fifteen richly furnished rooms recreate late-15th-century seigneurial life. Millefleurs tapestries, carved chests, canopy beds, and monumental fireplaces furnish the rooms from ground floor to upper story.

The scene of the marriage of Charles VIII and Anne of Brittany, celebrated here on December 6, 1491, is recreated with life-size wax figures in period costumes. This event sealed Brittany's attachment to the kingdom of France.
The covered rampart walks offer an elevated promenade with views of the Loire and the town rooftops. The machicolations and crenellations recall the edifice's defensive vocation.
Château de Langeais, a medieval treasure combining a fortress keep with an elegant Renaissance residence
The keep of Château de Langeais, built by the legendary Foulques Nerra in the year 994
The décor of the seigneurial residence at Langeais, filled with tapestries, carved furniture, and historical atmosphere
The medieval-inspired gardens of Château de Langeais, planted with period herbs and flowers

activities.text: The medieval-inspired gardens occupy the terrace between the château and the keep ruins. Dye plants, herbs, and medicinal essences are cultivated in boxwood squares according to medieval horticultural treatises.
Cross through the ruins of Foulques Nerra's keep. This 10th-century vestige, attached to the main tower, overlooks a panorama of the Loire and Langeais' medieval bridge.
Experience the recreation of the marriage of Charles VIII and Anne of Brittany, staged with life-size figures in period costume

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château de Talcy appears as a country house in the heart of the Beauce plain. Behind the square gate-tower flanked by turrets and crenellations, the cobbled courtyard reveals a four-arch Renaissance gallery inspired by the one at Château de Blois.

Here the poet Ronsard met Cassandre Salviati, daughter of the Florentine banker who owned the estate, at a ball in Blois. He dedicated his famous verses to her: "Darling, let us go see if the rose..." His niece later inspired the poet Agrippa d'Aubigné.

About fifteen rooms are open to visitors. The 18th-century furniture remains in place: the chamber known as Charles IX's preserves its Hungarian point tapestries, while painted calico decorations adorn the salon paneling.
The late-15th-century circular dovecote holds 1,400 nesting holes. Its original rotating ladder still allows circulation between the nests. It's one of the largest in the region.
In the 17th-century barn, an impressive 6.7-meter-high wine press testifies to the estate's viticultural past, when it produced up to 25,000 liters of wine annually.
Château de Talcy, a perfectly preserved Renaissance manor where poets once courted muses
Explore the Renaissance rooms of Château de Talcy, still echoing with 16th-century elegance
Stroll through the tranquil gardens of Château de Talcy, framed by fruit trees and flowerbeds

activities.text: Visit the conservatory orchard labeled Jardin Remarquable. Across 6 hectares, hundreds of heritage apple and pear varieties are trained into artistic forms: palmettes, tridents, lattices, and cordons.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château de Valençay blends Renaissance and Classicism in an imposing façade dominated by a round keep crowned with an Italian-style dome. It's the former residence of Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord, Napoleon's diplomat.

The state salons preserve the Empire furniture commissioned by Talleyrand. The Grand Salon, the Chamber of the King of Spain Ferdinand VII (detained here from 1808 to 1814), and the gallery testify to diplomatic splendor.
The small theater with First Empire décor could accommodate 150 spectators. Talleyrand had plays performed there to entertain his illustrious guests and the captive Spanish princes.
The château kitchens display the copper batteries and utensils necessary for lavish receptions. Talleyrand, a renowned gastronome, employed the celebrated chef Carême.
The museum presents Talleyrand memorabilia: diplomatic documents, personal objects, and portraits trace the career of the man who served every regime from Louis XVI to Louis-Philippe.
Château de Valençay, the former residence of Talleyrand—diplomat, statesman, and master of political survival
The collections of furniture and objets d'art at Château de Valençay, reflecting the refined taste of the Empire period
The small theater with First Empire décor at Valençay, a private stage for aristocratic entertainment
The gardens and 53-hectare park of Château de Valençay, home to peacocks and roaming deer

activities.text: The terraced formal French gardens descend toward a vast 53-hectare park populated with fallow deer, peacocks, and black swans. The Duchess's garden and the Spanish garden offer contrasting atmospheres.
The Napoleon labyrinth, planted in the park, invites children to find their way through trimmed hedges, among historical references and orientation games.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Villandry is the last of the great châteaux built on the Loire's banks in the Renaissance. But its fame rests above all on its gardens, recreated in the early 20th century across six levels of terraces descending toward the Cher.

The ornamental vegetable garden comprises nine geometric squares planted with vegetables, flowers, and aromatic plants. The colors change twice yearly: spring then summer plantings entirely renew the tableau.

The ornamental gardens unfold four squares symbolizing the forms of love: tender love, passionate love, fickle love, and tragic love. Trimmed boxwood designs illustrate each theme through their motifs.
Inside, the furnished rooms present an oriental salon adorned with a 13th-century Mudéjar ceiling from Toledo, collections of Spanish paintings, and 17th and 18th-century furniture.
The water garden, at the top of the terraces, surrounds a large basin shaped like a Louis XV mirror. Trimmed lindens and hornbeams create a space of coolness and serenity above the ensemble.
Château de Villandry, world-renowned for its gardens—the finest example of Renaissance horticulture in France
The ornamental vegetable garden of Villandry, composed of nine symmetrical squares where beauty meets bounty
The terraced gardens of Château de Villandry, rising level by level from water garden to sun garden
The furnished and decorated rooms of Château de Villandry, showcasing Spanish and French period styles

activities.text: Reach the belvedere at the top of the terraces for an overview of the gardens, château, and confluence of the Cher and Loire. The viewpoint is the best spot to photograph the whole.
The hornbeam labyrinth, at the heart of the gardens, invites a plant-based orientation game. The shaded paths lead to a raised central platform.
Guided garden tours by the estate's gardeners explain the techniques of pruning, planting, and maintaining this horticultural masterpiece labeled Jardin Remarquable.
Relax in the oriental salon of Château de Villandry, an intimate space with exotic décor

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château de Villesavin was Chambord's "work shed." Jean Le Breton, secretary of finances to François I, had it built between 1527 and 1537 to oversee the royal construction site a few kilometers away.

Designed in the model of an Italian villa with a U-shaped plan and square pavilions, the château preserves in its courtyard of honor a Florentine Carrara marble basin, a gift from Italian craftsmen to Jean Le Breton.

The chapel holds murals from the second half of the 16th century depicting the Passion cycle. Chubby infants bearing the instruments of the Passion compose an iconographic detail as surprising as it is fascinating.

The 16th-century white stone dovecote holds 1,500 nesting holes and preserves its original rotating ladder and chestnut timber framework. A symbol of judicial power, it's one of the best preserved in the Loire Valley.

The marriage museum recreates the stages of a wedding day between 1840 and 1950. More than 1,500 original objects: costumes, trousseau, bridal chamber. This collection is considered the world's largest on this theme.
The collection of horse-drawn carriages and 19th-century children's vehicles completes the visit in the château's outbuildings.
Château de Villesavin in the heart of the Sologne, a hidden Renaissance gem surrounded by countryside calm
Visit Château de Villesavin and its outbuildings, including a charming dovecote and historic stables
Stroll through the park surrounding Château de Villesavin, where manicured lawns meet wildflower meadows

activities.text: Wander through the 27-hectare English-style park. A melliferous garden welcomes beehives, while a mini-farm presents donkeys and draft horses from Easter to All Saints' Day.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The Clos Lucé was Leonardo da Vinci's final home. Invited by François I in 1516, the Florentine master lived here his last three years. His reconstructed bedroom overlooks the garden he walked daily.
Leonardo's workshop has been recreated with its easels, brushes, and sketches. In this room he allegedly completed some of his last paintings and continued his scientific research.
The chapel adorned with frescoes attributed to Leonardo's disciples preserves a contemplative atmosphere. Pictorial details recall the master's style, particularly in the treatment of light.
Forty scale models of machines built from Leonardo's drawings punctuate the route: pivoting bridge, assault chariot, flying machine, aerial screw. Visitors can manipulate some mechanisms.
The Renaissance kitchen, with its period dishes and monumental fireplace, evokes the meals prepared for the master and his guests. Italian recipes mingled with Touraine fare of the era.
Château du Clos Lucé, the final residence of Leonardo da Vinci—where genius found its last refuge
Walk through the gallery of Leonardo da Vinci's machines at Clos Lucé, from flying contraptions to war engines
The Renaissance kitchen at the Priory Inn in Clos Lucé, preserved as it was in Leonardo's time
The Leonardo da Vinci Park and Garden, where life-size models of his inventions stand among the trees

activities.text: Descend into the Parc Leonardo da Vinci across 7 hectares. Full-scale machines are installed outdoors: the pivot bridge, the paddle boat, Archimedes' screw. Sound and visual animations bring the circuit alive.
A tunnel connected the Clos Lucé to the royal château of Amboise, allowing François I to visit his friend Leonardo. The passage is visible from the estate's gardens.
Enjoy family-friendly activities at Château du Clos Lucé, including interactive workshops and treasure hunts

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The château du Rivau rises in the Touraine countryside, between medieval fortress and Renaissance manor. Its fairytale silhouette, with crenellated keep and drawbridge, was mentioned by Rabelais in Gargantua.

The 15th-century royal stables are classified as Historic Monument. Joan of Arc came here to collect horses before the Battle of Chinon. Their impressive dimensions testify to the site's military prestige.

The interior mixes classical décor and contemporary art. Artists' installations dialogue with tapestries and antique furniture in the vaulted halls and towers. The contrast is striking and intentional.
The Potager de Gargantua takes up the château's Rabelaisian theme. Giant vegetables and heritage varieties compose a kitchen garden of Pantagruelian proportions.
The château rose garden assembles more than 450 varieties of roses. Labeled "National Collection" by the Conservatoire of Specialized Plant Collections, it perfumes the air from May to October.
Château du Rivau, a fairy-tale castle where towers and turrets rise from gardens straight out of storybooks
The royal stables of Château du Rivau, once home to the warhorses of kings
The décor blending classical elegance with contemporary art at Le Rivau, creating unexpected visual dialogues
Gargantua's vegetable garden at Château du Rivau, a whimsical potager inspired by Rabelais
The rose garden of Château du Rivau, fragrant with hundreds of varieties in bloom

activities.text: Explore the 14 fairytale gardens labeled Jardin Remarquable. Each tells a tale: the enchanted forest, Melusine's garden, Sleeping Beauty's path. Artistic installations blend into the vegetation.
Wander through the enchanted gardens of Château du Rivau, where each space tells a different fairy tale

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Château-Gontier-sur-Mayenne, classified among France's Most Beautiful Detours, was born around the year 1000 from Count of Anjou Foulque Nerra's strategic decision to establish a fortress facing the Bretons. The castle, entrusted to officer Gontier, has disappeared, but the town has preserved abundant heritage on both sides of the river, with 18 protected historic monuments and a 58-hectare Remarkable Heritage Site.

Saint-Jean-Baptiste church, built in the 11th century in flint and roussard stone by Benedictines from Saint-Aubin Abbey in Angers, is the town's oldest church. Its Romanesque interior strikes with its purity: wooden-vaulted nave, rare dome on pendentives above the choir, ten-column crypt and fine ensemble of 12th-13th century mural paintings.

Hôtel Fouquet, an elegant 17th-century townhouse at the intersection of Grande Rue and Rue Jean Bourré, houses the Museum of Art and Archaeology. Nearby, spot the Hôtel de Lantivy (17th c., classified MH), Hôtel du Tertre de Sancé (15th c., listed MH) and half-timbered houses in medieval lanes.

Cross the Mayenne to discover the Ursuline convent in the Azé suburb. Founded in 1634 in a 15th-century manor house, expanded by Laval architects Pierre and Gilles Corbineau from 1642, it boasts a majestic cloister, a Jesuit-style church and convent cells. Since 1999, it has housed the National Stage Le Carré in a 530-seat theater integrated into the cloister.

Push open the gate to the Garden of the End of the World, perched on a rocky spur above the Mayenne. This flower-filled park with century-old trees shelters a 17th-century ice house and mischievous goats. The view over the river and town rooftops is worth the visit.

The Garden of Scents, on the Mayenne's banks, displays 80 varieties of fragrant and medicinal plants: lavender, mint, oregano, thyme. The Medieval Garden of the Spring, at the foot of old ramparts, completes this plant journey. Château-Gontier has earned four flowers in the Flowered Towns and Villages competition.

activities.text: Walk down the Mayenne quays along the river from the river stop. In summer, ephemeral riverside cafés set up on the banks with concerts and dining.
The Perrettes circuit (marked) winds between the Mayenne quays, the Ursuline convent, old quarters and the Garden of the End of the World—an ideal loop to embrace all the town's faces.
Thursday mornings, Château-Gontier's traditional market invades the town center squares. It's also the continent's largest calf fair—a vibrant tradition of this livestock-raising land.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: The royal château of Amboise overlooks the Loire from atop its promontory. Favorite residence of Charles VIII then François I, it was the cradle of the French Renaissance. The terrace offers a 360-degree view of the river and town.

The Chapel of Saint-Hubert, a flamboyant Gothic masterpiece, houses Leonardo da Vinci's presumed tomb. Its sculpted lintel depicts the legend of Saint Hubert facing the stag bearing a cross between its antlers.

The Tour des Minimes, with its five-meter-wide helical ramp, allowed riders and carriages to climb directly from the Loire's edge to the château terrace. Its counterpart, the Tour Hurtault, offers the same ascent on the opposite side.

The royal apartments present period-furnished rooms: the Council Hall adorned with Gothic pillars, Henri II's chamber with its Renaissance furniture, and the States Hall where royal audiences were held.
From the ramparts, spot the traces of the immense medieval palace that once occupied the entire promontory. Only one-tenth of the original edifice remains, the rest demolished under Napoleon.
Château Royal d'Amboise, a former residence of French kings where the Renaissance first flowered in France
The 360-degree view over the Loire from the ramparts of Amboise, sweeping across river, town, and valley
The Chapel of Saint-Hubert where Leonardo da Vinci is entombed, a delicate Gothic jewel overlooking the gardens
The panoramic garden of Château Royal d'Amboise, offering breathtaking vistas and peaceful paths

activities.text: The château's panoramic gardens, redesigned in the 19th century, blend flowerbeds, Lebanon cedars, and trimmed boxwoods. The linden avenue plunges toward the Loire below.
In summer, the château offers themed guided tours, children's workshops, and illuminated evening visits that highlight the Gothic and Renaissance architecture under enchanting lighting.
Join a guided tour of Château Royal d'Amboise to uncover hidden history and royal anecdotes

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The royal château of Blois unites four wings from four eras in one monument: the 13th-century Gothic of the States Hall, the flamboyant Gothic of Louis XII, François I's Renaissance, and Gaston d'Orléans' 17th-century Classicism.

The monumental staircase of the François I wing is a feat: an octagonal newel housed in a three-sided open tower facing the courtyard. Sculptures of salamanders, pilasters, and medallions ornament each floor.

The royal apartments recreate daily court life in the 16th century. The chamber of King Henri III is marked by the assassination of the Duke of Guise on December 23, 1588, an event narrated by the scenography.
Catherine de Medici's study preserves its 237 carved wood panels. Four panels conceal secret compartments, long presented as her "poison cabinets."

The Museum of Fine Arts, installed in the Louis XII wing, exhibits paintings, sculptures, and tapestries from the 16th to 19th centuries. The queen's gallery offers perspectives onto the Façade des Loges.
The Façade des Loges, facing the Loire, displays its Italian-style stacked galleries. From the garden below, the view embraces the full height of this Renaissance façade.
Château Royal de Blois, the favorite residence of French kings during the Renaissance—where history was made and unmade
The royal apartments of Château de Blois, scene of intrigue, assassination, and royal births
The exterior architecture and François I's spiral staircase at Blois, a masterpiece of ornamental stonework
The Fine Arts Museum in Château de Blois, housing paintings, sculptures, and decorative objects
View of the Loges façade from the nearby park at Château de Blois, revealing Renaissance elegance from across the gardens

activities.text: The château de Blois sound and light show projects onto the courtyard façades the great episodes of the site's history. The walls come alive with colors and stories for 45 minutes.
Attend the sound and light show at Château Royal de Blois, projecting the château's dramatic history onto its façade

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The International City of the French Language occupies the former royal château built by Francis I between 1532 and 1540. This Renaissance monument houses a contemporary museum celebrating French language worldwide. Interactive exhibitions explore linguistic evolution, Francophonie and French literary heritage. The restored château reveals sculpted ceilings and period architectural elements.

The Jean de La Fontaine birthplace museum occupies the 16th-century house where the famous fabulist was born in 1621. Period rooms evoke 17th-century daily life. Original editions, manuscripts and illustrations of the Fables present the poet's work. The museum garden recreates a French-style garden from the era.

The Retz Forest unfolds over 13,000 hectares of preserved nature surrounding the town. Ancient oak, beech and chestnut stands create a remarkable woodland landscape. This royal forest where kings once hunted shelters rich fauna and flora.

The medieval castle ruins crown the hilltop dominating the Marne valley. Remains of fortifications, towers and curtain walls testify to this feudal fortress's strategic importance. Panoramic viewpoints over town and valley reward the climb. Interpretation panels recount castle and region history.

Alexandre Dumas Museum pays tribute to the famous writer born in Villers-Cotterêts in 1802. The birth house presents manuscripts, editions and objects belonging to the Three Musketeers and Count of Monte-Cristo author. Temporary exhibitions explore various aspects of his prolific work.
Old Château Gate is the only remaining vestige of medieval enclosure. This fortified gate defended town access. Massive stonework and defensive elements illustrate medieval military architecture.
Walk through the historic center discovering old houses and remarkable facades. The town preserves architectural heritage testifying to its royal past. Saint-Nicolas Church dominates the main square.
Walk along the Marne River banks offering pleasant waterside strolls. The quays invite strolls between town and nature. Pleasure boats and fishing spots enliven this fluvial landscape.
Jean de La Fontaine was born in this 1559 townhouse. The fabulist spent his childhood here before selling the property in 1676 to seek his fortune in Paris.
The museum displays illustrated editions of the Fables from the 18th and 19th centuries. Upstairs, a reconstructed study evokes the writer's creative world.
Climb to the ramparts of the old château. Medieval ruins stand sentinel over the Marne Valley below.

activities.text: Hike marked Retz Forest trails offering loops from 5 to 20 kilometers. Paths wind through century-old stands to remarkable trees including giant oaks. The peaceful forest invites walking and nature observation.
The Château-Thierry slopes produce Champagne under the appellation. Several houses offer cellar visits and tastings. The Champagne Route winds between vineyards and wine villages of the Marne valley.

Discover local products at the Wednesday and Saturday morning market. Producers offer cheeses, cured meats, vegetables and regional specialties. The convivial atmosphere invites strolling and tasting.
Stroll through downtown streets dotted with private mansions from the 17th and 18th centuries. La Fontaine's statue stands on the renovated square. Facades tell the history of this literary city.

Visit craft workshops perpetuating traditional skills. Local artisans work wood, leather and textiles according to ancestral methods. Demonstrations reveal technical gestures transmitted through generations.
The Jean de La Fontaine Festival brings the town to life each year in May. Music, theater and dance celebrate Château-Thierry's cultural heritage during this artistic event.
Cycle the paths linking Villers-Cotterêts to surrounding villages through forest and countryside. Several circuits cross the Retz massif offering varied landscapes and heritage discovery.
Wander through the museum's garden, where a rustic well and remnants of ancient ramparts create a peaceful retreat.
Explore the cobblestoned streets of the historic center. Renaissance facades recall the town's prosperous past.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature
Marne Road Trip: Reims, Épernay and the Champagne Route

visits.text: Château de Châteaubriant — Apparitions of Françoise de Foix on October 16; rumors of spectral processions.
Châteaubriant — Françoise de Foix (16/10).

activities.text: Access: public — Exact coordinates (47.718, -1.376).
Access: public

days_plan.itin_title: Haunted Loire Valley: Forgotten Castles and Spectral Legends
Loire Valley Phantoms: Tragic Histories and Haunted Castles of France

visits.text: Châteaudouble — medieval village suspended above the Nartuby, with steep streets and old stones.
Belvedere over the river and panorama of the surrounding cliffs.

activities.text: Hiking on the trails around the Nartuby canyon.
Bird of prey observation from the village heights.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages

visits.text: Château de Châteaudun, first of the Loire châteaux for those arriving from Paris. Overlooking the Loir from more than 60 meters, this fortress was the home of Jean de Dunois, companion-in-arms of Joan of Arc. The building spans eight centuries of architecture, from the medieval keep to Renaissance staircases.

Circular keep from the 12th century, one of the best preserved in the world at 31 meters high with walls 4 meters thick. The magnificent 15th-century timber framework crowns this defensive tower where the Counts of Blois resisted Norman assaults.

Gothic Sainte-Chapelle of the château, founded by Jean de Dunois in the 15th century. It preserves fifteen polychrome statues of saints and a mural painting of the Last Judgment. This private sanctuary testifies to the piety of Joan of Arc's companion.

Longueville wing from the 16th century, where the first signs of the Renaissance emerge. The grand state rooms house an exceptional collection of 17th-century tapestries. The monumental staircase already heralds the wonders of the Loire châteaux.

activities.text: Medieval-inspired garden at the foot of the keep, laid out in the former moats. Fourteen themed beds present 150 varieties of medieval plants: aromatic, medicinal, edible, and dye plants. An immersion into the art of medieval gardens.

Promenade du Mail offering exceptional panoramas over the Loir valley and the château perched on its rocky spur. The hanging gardens, the first of their kind in France inspired by the Italian model, complete this exploration of the exteriors.

Wander through Châteaudun's old town with its 15th and 16th-century houses preserved from the 1723 fire. Rue Saint-Lubin and its half-timbered facades lead to the Foulon caves, a fascinating geological site with concretions and marine fossils.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure-et-Loir Circuit: Chartres, Châteaux & Proust

visits.text: Medieval castle and castle complex overlooking the Burgundy canal.
Cobbled streets and Burgundian facades of the hilltop village.
Viewpoint over the Auxois valley and the line of hills.
Lake Kir (Dijon beach): lakeside walk
Snail farm in Vernot: discovery of snail farming (exterior/explanations)
Hilltop village of Châteauneuf-en-Auxois: keep and narrow streets
Lake Grosbois-en-Montagne: beach and shoreline trail

activities.text: Descent to the Burgundy canal: walk along the reach and locks.
Hamlet loop on agricultural paths (short hike).
Viewpoint over the Burgundy Canal from the heights

days_plan.itin_title: Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: The medieval castle of Châteauneuf has vanished. Only the name and presumed site near the current fairground remain. However, the Logis de Barqueville (15th century) facing the church forms a handsome ensemble with the square. Pleasant walk along the shaded riverbanks.

The church of Saint-Pierre (12th century) boasts one of the finest façades in the Charente: three sculpted tiers, a horseman representing Constantine crushing paganism. Inside, carved Romanesque capitals and a little snail hidden in high relief.
The river port brings the town to life. A stop on the Charente for pleasure boaters and canoeists. Café terraces, shaded picnic area. Watersports centre in summer.

activities.text: Canoeing on the Charente. The watersports centre hires kayaks and canoes with return shuttle. Routes from 2 hours to a full day. Calm water, swimming possible at designated stops.
Swimming at the Bain des Dames. The leisure area, labelled Station Sport Nature, has the only supervised beach on the Charente in the Cognac area. Lawn, toilets, snack bar. Free.
Fishing on the Charente. Quiet spots upstream and downstream of town. Zander, pike, carp. Daily fishing licence available at the tobacconist.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: Châteaurenard — castle hill and lively town, between Avignon and Alpilles.
Top of the village — views over the Durance and market garden plains.

activities.text: Urban loop (Provençal market depending on day) and chapel circuit.
Walk on the Durance dikes (section).

Convent of the Cordeliers.

Market (Saturday).
Belle Époque (Art Deco facilities).

days_plan.itin_title: Indre, France: Secret Berry Region and Vallée Noire Rural Villages

visits.text: The Pont Henri IV, in Renaissance style, has spanned the Vienne since 1611. An emblem of Châtellerault, it offers picturesque views of the river and quays. It's one of only two bridges in France classified as historic monuments.

The Auto Moto Vélo Museum occupies La Manu, a former arms factory that employed up to 8,000 workers in the early 20th century. Across 4,000 square meters, over 200 vehicles are on display: Bugatti, Delage, Ferrari, Terrot, and rare prototypes like the 1953 Longchamps-Decouçy.
The Théâtre Blossac, a 19th-century Italian-style theater, was fully restored to its original state in 2013. Its intimate auditorium with gilded balconies hosts a regular program of performances.
Saint-Jacques Church, a stop on the route to Compostela, houses a classified carillon of 52 bells. Its neo-Romanesque façade overlooks the town.
The Maison Descartes, 16th-century residence of René Descartes' grandparents, speaks to the city's intellectual past. The visit sheds light on the philosopher's life and his connection to Poitou.

activities.text: Board the river boat for a narrated cruise on the Vienne, from Châtellerault to the Chitré mill. Offered in summer only.
Cycle the Ligne Verte, a 40 km bike path laid along a former railway line beside the Vienne. Informational panels on the region's history line the route.
Stroll along Châtellerault's quays at twilight. The reflection of the Pont Henri IV in the Vienne is a photographic classic.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Châtenois's fortified cemetery, rare in Alsace, preserves its medieval enclosure pierced with loopholes. At the center, the 12th-century Saint-Georges church presents a squat Romanesque bell tower and a porch with sculpted décor.
The Tour des Sorcières (13th century), former rampart keep, owes its name to the witchcraft trials held in the region. Its massive silhouette dominates the old town.
The partially preserved ramparts and medieval gates frame an ancient core of half-timbered houses. The village is a southern gateway to the Alsace Wine Route.
A few kilometers away, Sélestat houses the Humanist Library, registered in UNESCO's Memory of the World registry, and the Romanesque Sainte-Foy church (12th century).

activities.text: Châtenois's wine trail winds between plots of Riesling and Pinot Noir. Educational panels and viewpoints over the plain line the route.
Climb to Château du Haut-Koenigsbourg (10 km), a medieval fortress restored in the early 20th century, perched at 757 meters with views over the Alsace plain, Black Forest and Vosges.
Châtenois cellars produce excellent Rieslings. The clay-limestone terroir yields mineral and chiseled wines.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: Canal du Nivernais: locks, bridges and view of the village.
Village center and silhouettes of the former seigneurial residence.
Nautical stopover and tree-lined towpath.

activities.text: Leisurely cycling on the towpath (family round trip).
Wildlife/flora observation along the reaches and wetland meadows.

days_plan.itin_title: Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: Châtillon-sur-Chalaronne charms with its flowered canals and Burgundian-style half-timbered houses reflected in the clear waters of the Chalaronne. The medieval town, former border of the Duchy of Savoy, has preserved its defensive character with fortified gates and watchtowers. The eleven bridges that span the river create a romantic landscape worthy of the most beautiful Venetian canals.

The covered market, built on wooden pillars in 1440, stands as one of the finest examples of Bresse civil architecture. Under its impressive oak framework, merchants have set up stalls for six centuries. Local producers still offer Bresse specialties there every Saturday: poultry, cheeses, vegetables from the market gardens.

The former Hôtel-Dieu hospital, founded in 1442, houses a remarkable apothecary with 120 ceramic jars from Meillonnas. The painted woodwork, period medical instruments, and herb drying room plunge visitors into 18th-century medicine. The nuns' chapel and patients' rooms complete this fascinating journey through time.

Follow the Heritage Trail that winds through narrow streets and along canals. Informative panels reveal the history of brick houses, stone bridges, and wash houses where Bressan women came to do their laundry. The Saint-André gate and the Clock Tower punctuate this walk through medieval history.
Châtillon-sur-Chalaronne displays its red bricks and half-timbering in the heart of the Dombes. France's first bee-friendly town, it proudly wears its four flowers and labels as a blooming city.
The 15th-century Market Hall hosts every Saturday morning the local produce market voted Most Beautiful Market in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region. Stalls overflow with Bresse terroir products.
The apothecary of the former hospital preserves a unique collection of 120 Meillonnas faience jars with blue and white decorations. 18th-century woodwork frames this pharmaceutical treasure.
Pass through the Villars Gate, vestige of the fortified town, to reach the ramparts of the old castle that have dominated the town since the 12th century.
Flower-decked bridges span the Chalaronne as it winds between half-timbered houses. The 14th-century salt storehouse testifies to the town's commercial importance in the Middle Ages.
The Saint Vincent de Paul House recalls that it was here the saint conceived the idea of creating the Ladies of Charity. An exhibition traces his humanitarian work.
Discover the history of botanist Philibert Commerson, a local son who accompanied Bougainville and discovered, among other things, the hydrangea.

activities.text: Rent a canoe to explore the Chalaronne from the water and discover hidden perspectives of the town. The calm current makes navigation accessible to everyone, even beginners. Passing under arched bridges and along flowered gardens offers a bucolic experience. Swans and ducks accompany paddlers along this aquatic walk.

Stroll through the exceptional flower gardens that earned Châtillon the title of 4-flower town. Terraced gardens descend to the water, geraniums cascade from windows, and roses climb ancient facades. The municipal park and its century-old trees invite contemplation and rest.

Visit the Dream Train Museum, unique in Europe, which brings together an exceptional collection of old toy trains. Miniature landscapes recreate various French and European regions. Animated dioramas fascinate young and old with their precision and realism. Rare pieces and collector trains complete this nostalgic journey.

Attend the Saturday morning market that transforms the town center into a vibrant agora. Stalls overflow with local products: Bresse chickens, Dombes fish, seasonal vegetables, mountain cheeses. The festive atmosphere and exchanges with producers perpetuate an ancestral market tradition.
The municipal Arboretum gathers 342 exceptional tree varieties. The educational apiary welcomes thousands of children each year to explain the essential role of bees.
Push open the doors of art workshops where stained glass makers, bookbinders, and ceramicists perpetuate traditional crafts. The town is labeled a City of Arts and Crafts.
Sit down at one of the restaurants to savor fresh frogs' legs, PDO Bresse chicken, and carp from the Dombes ponds.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: The Source du Par gushes out at 82°C, the European natural record temperature for a hot spring. This exceptional geothermal curiosity, used since Roman antiquity, still supplies the town's district heating today. The steaming water bubbles in the fitted basin where visitors try the traditional experience: cooking an egg in 15 minutes in this naturally scalding water.

The Caleden thermal centre makes the most of Chaudes-Aigues' 32 hot springs in a modern complex combining spa therapy and wellness. The mineral waters with pain-relieving and relaxing properties treat rheumatic conditions. The leisure thermal area, open from 9 months of age, offers pools at 32-37°C, jacuzzi, waterfalls and massage jets in a family-friendly relaxation setting.

The Musée Géothermia tells the exceptional story of this spa town, the first city in Europe to use a geothermal district heating network as early as the Middle Ages. Models, historical documents and interactive displays explain how residents exploited these springs for heating, healthcare and daily life since antiquity.

activities.text: The thermal walk through the town reveals Auvergne architecture of stone and lauze (schist slate) roofs. Touch the warm water in the restored fountains, discover the hot-water wash house fed by the Lestande spring (62°C), and warm up in winter in the Saint-Martin-Saint-Blaise church heated through the floor by geothermal springs. The "De Par en Par" trail guides you through this unique thermal heritage.

Hiking on the Aubrac plateau is a must at the gates of Chaudes-Aigues. These vast wild highland spaces reveal lush pastures, traditional burons and herds of Aubrac cattle in a preserved mid-mountain landscape. Waymarked trails offer panoramas stretching to the Truyère gorges and the Cantal mountains.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions

visits.text: Chaumont's viaduct stretches 600 meters at a height of 52 meters. Built in just 15 months between 1855 and 1856, its 50 arches required 2,500 workers and 300 horses—an engineering marvel of the railway age.
Saint-Jean-Baptiste Basilica retains its 13th-century nave and façade. The transept and choir, rebuilt from 1517 to 1543, blend Flamboyant Gothic exuberance with early Renaissance refinement.
Admire the late-15th-century Entombment sculpture. Works by sculptor Jean-Baptiste Bouchardon adorn the pulpit, pew bench, and altarpiece.
The carved Tree of Jesse from the 1530s rises 4.5 meters high. The romantic Cavaillé-Coll organ dates to 1872.
The medieval keep crowns the promontory—the town's original nucleus that gave Chaumont its name ("bald mountain").

activities.text: Walk to the viaduct from town center. The structure appears most dramatic at sunrise or sunset when low light sculpts its arches.
Explore old Chaumont's lanes between basilica and château. Grand townhouses recall the era when the city reigned as France's glove-making capital.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: Perched on a promontory overlooking the Loire, the domaine de Chaumont-sur-Loire offers one of the valley's finest panoramas. The medieval fortress was transformed into a Renaissance residence, then into a 19th-century pleasure estate.

Catherine de Medici acquired the château in 1550, then ceded it to her rival Diane de Poitiers in exchange for Chenonceau. Terra cotta medallions adorned with intertwined C's and D's still mark the towers from this turbulent history.

The decorated apartments testify to 19th-century splendor, when the Princess of Broglie transformed the interiors. Refined furniture, tapestries, and historiated tiles compose a coherent and warm ensemble.
The stables, considered among France's most luxurious, were built in 1877 to house the princess's horses. Teak stalls, elaborate tack room, and period harnesses are preserved intact.
Chaumont hosts an annual center for arts and nature. Contemporary artists' installations dialogue with historic architecture in the château's halls and estate buildings.

International Garden Festival of Chaumont-sur-Loire running from April to November since 1992. A globally recognized laboratory of contemporary landscape creation, it presents thirty ephemeral gardens annually created by landscape architects, designers, and architects worldwide around a theme. Bold plant creations blend rare plants, unusual flowers, and singular associations in a multi-hectare green setting. Six permanent gardens complete the experience: the English-inspired woodland garden, the extraordinary greenhouse, and playful children's gardens. The immersive sensory journey evolves through the seasons.

Château de Chaumont-sur-Loire dominating the Loire from its promontory 40 meters high. Built between the 15th and 16th centuries, it combines Gothic defensive aspects with Renaissance comfort. Catherine de Medici acquired it in 1550 before exchanging it with Diane de Poitiers for Chenonceau. Richly furnished interiors testify to splendor restored in the 19th century by the Prince de Broglie. Apartments reveal tapestries, period furniture, and refined art objects. Temporary exhibitions in historical rooms present internationally renowned contemporary artists.

Stables and historic park of Chaumont created by landscape architect Henri Duchêne between 1884 and 1888. The stables—among the most remarkable of their era—now house contemporary art exhibitions in vast vaulted halls. The 32-hectare park unfolds shaded paths dotted with sculptures and artistic installations. Centuries-old cedars, giant sequoias, and carefully calculated perspectives create a remarkable green setting. Viewpoints over the Loire and château offer exceptional contemplative pauses.
Domaine de Chaumont-sur-Loire, a regional estate perched on a bluff overlooking the Loire like a sentinel over the valley
The prestigious stables of Chaumont-sur-Loire, showcasing equestrian luxury fit for royalty
The richly decorated apartments of Château de Chaumont-sur-Loire, displaying centuries of refined taste

activities.text: The International Garden Festival, from late April to early November, presents some thirty ephemeral gardens created by landscape designers from around the world around an annual theme.
Walk through the 32-hectare English-style park designed in the 19th century. Centuries-old cedars, giant sequoias, and winding paths descend in terraces toward the Loire.

Strolling through the Festival's creative gardens exploring current trends in international landscape architecture. Each ephemeral creation offers an original vision blending plant, mineral, and artworks in bold compositions. Installations invite reflection on our relationship with nature and the contemporary environment. Light effects, perspectives, and plant compositions reveal designers' talent. A children's activity booklet transforms the visit into a playful botanical adventure with riddles to solve in each garden.

Viewpoints offering breathtaking vistas over the Loire, Europe's last wild river. The château's terraces reveal 180-degree panoramas over the valley dotted with wooded islands and shifting sandbars. Silver meanders snake between meadows and forests to the distant horizon. The historic park arranges carefully calculated visual openings framing the landscape like living paintings. Sunsets setting the river ablaze create unforgettable atmospheres from the heights of the estate dominating the valley.

Discovering contemporary art exhibitions in the stables, outbuildings, and estate park. The Art Season presents monumental sculptures, photographs, and artistic installations by leading international artists. Works scattered throughout the park create an open-air museum where nature and creation engage in continuous dialogue. Temporary exhibition rooms in historic buildings showcase paintings, videos, and digital creations. The estate combines architectural heritage and contemporary creation in unprecedented stimulating dialogue.
Wander through the 32-hectare English-style park at Chaumont-sur-Loire, home to the renowned International Garden Festival

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The Saint-Martin Church mixes Romanesque and Gothic styles. The bell tower stands watch over the town with its 15th-century chime. Stained glass windows from various periods illuminate the nave.
Wander along the Oise and canal banks. The river meanders through the town offering walks along the water. Locks and boats punctuate this fluvial landscape.
The covered market built in Art Deco style shelters merchant stalls. The metal structure and geometric decorations reflect post-war reconstruction.
The Chauny countryside unfolds between fields and canals. Villages preserve rural heritage with old farms and churches. Country roads invite exploration of this preserved agricultural territory.

activities.text: Cycle along the Oise greenway following the river's meanders. The converted towpath offers a flat route suitable for all levels. Locks, villages and nature follow one another along this bucolic route.
Fish for pike, zander and bream in the Oise and canals. Anglers find well-equipped spots along the banks. Fishing permit required.
Explore the surrounding forests offering marked hiking trails. Paths wind through beech and oak groves in preserved massifs. Several loops allow 2 to 4 hour walks.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature

visits.text: Five fortified castles stand on the same rocky spur in Chauvigny—a rare concentration in Europe. The Bishops' baronial castle, built in the 11th century, dominates the Vienne Valley from the promontory's edge.

The Saint-Pierre Collegiate Church, a 12th-century jewel of Romanesque art, is world-renowned for its polychrome capitals. Signed by master sculptor Gofridus, they depict scenes from Christ's life, monsters, and fantastical beasts.
The Château d'Harcourt, best preserved of the five fortresses, dates from the 13th century. Its curtain walls and towers provide a clear glimpse into medieval military architecture.

Enter the Gouzon Keep, topped by a modern glass watchtower. Inside you'll find the Industrial Archaeology Center and a folk traditions museum showcasing a reconstructed Poitevin interior, traditional headdresses, and craftsmen's tools.

Hidden in a Merovingian cemetery, Saint-Pierre-les-Églises Church contains some of Western Europe's oldest frescoes, dating between 780 and 980. The Nativity theme is treated in a remarkably original way.

activities.text: Watch the Giants of the Sky show in the setting of the Bishops' Castle. Eagles, vultures, and falcons fly free above the medieval ruins.
Hop on a VéloRail along the old railway line for 17 km of scenic riding through woods, over viaducts, and along the river—with breathtaking views of the medieval city.
Head down to the lower town to walk along the Vienne riverbanks. The trail offers a striking perspective on the fortress-crowned rocky spur.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Colleville-sur-Mer — American Cemetery (promenade overlooking Omaha, memorial, chapel)
Omaha Beach — "Les Braves" sculpture (beach, esplanade)
Overlord Museum (around Omaha) — June 6th operations and staged equipment
Barfleur — port, Saint-Nicolas church, granite alleyways
Gatteville-le-Phare — lighthouse (exterior) and coastal spit
Saint-Vaast-la-Hougue — port and Vauban tower (UNESCO, from the coast)
Tatihou Island — maritime museum (by amphibious shuttle and schedules)
Nez de Jobourg — coastal path (cliff and cape panoramas)
Goury — la Hague lighthouse (view from the coast) and shelter port
Biville Dunes — walk on dune ridge and wild beach
Cap de Carteret — promontory, semaphore and customs officers' path
Carteret Lighthouse — belvedere over dunes and haven
Barneville-Carteret — large beach and haven (tides)

Cité de la Mer occupies the former 1933 transatlantic terminal, France's largest Art Deco monument. Inside, 17 aquariums include an abyssal tank plunging 35 feet deep, populated by 3,000 tropical fish swirling in the artificial current.

Step aboard Le Redoutable, France's first nuclear-powered submarine launched in 1967. At 420 feet long, it's the world's largest visitable submarine. The audio guide immerses you in the daily life of its 135 submariners: engine room, command post, cramped sleeping quarters.

In the Baggage Hall, the 'Titanic, Return to Cherbourg' exhibit traces the liner's sole continental stop on April 10, 1912, at 6:35 PM. Forty-two artifacts recovered from the wreck are displayed here, silent witnesses to tragedy.

Climb to Fort du Roule, perched 384 feet above the city. The Liberation Museum traces the role of Cherbourg's port in the D-Day logistics. The terrace offers sweeping views over the harbor, the ports, and the city center below.

Push open the door of the Umbrella Factory, installed in the former Bank of France building on quai Alexandre III. Craftsmen still handcraft the famous umbrellas immortalized in Demy's 1964 film, each one unique.

The Thomas Henry Museum houses nearly 400 paintings and sculptures, including a major collection of works by Jean-François Millet, a native of the region. It's Normandy's third-richest museum by holdings.

activities.text: Bessin region — guided tour of an artisanal cider house (orchard, press, cellar)
Saint-Vaast — dike promenade & observation of oyster parks at low tide
Cap de la Hague — successive viewpoints (photo stops)
Hattainville Dunes — free walk (sand and marram grass loop)

Embark on a cruise around Cherbourg's harbor, the world's second-largest artificial roadstead. Two and a half miles of jetties thrust into the sea protect four ports: military, commercial, marina, and fishing fleet.

Get lost in the boëls, narrow alleys lined with blue schist facades typical of the Cotentin. They reveal the pre-war Cherbourg forgotten by tourist guides, where fishermen once mended nets and smoked their catches.

Cherbourg's markets run Thursday and Saturday mornings on place De Gaulle, and Sunday mornings on avenue de Normandie. Seafood glistens on ice, Norman farm products pile high, and farmhouse cider flows freely for tastings.

visits.text: Château de Cheverny has remained in the same family for over six centuries—the Hurault de Vibraye, who still live here today. Built between 1624 and 1630 in homogeneous classical style using Bourré stone, it's considered the most magnificently furnished château of the Loire with its Gobelins and Flemish tapestries, Louis XIV and XV commodes, and intact period furniture. The visit reveals sumptuous rooms including the arms room with carved woodwork, the king's chamber, and the grand salon with master portraits. The château inspired Hergé's drawings of Marlinspike Hall in Tintin.

Cheverny Kennels house a pack of approximately 120 tricolor French-English hounds, descendants of English fox-hounds and French poitevins. These magnificent dogs participate in stag hunts during the season. The afternoon feeding ritual provides a fascinating spectacle where animals are fed in the former stables following a tradition perpetuated for generations. Visitors discover aristocratic hunting traditions. In spring, the puppy baptism festival invites the public to propose names for new residents according to the annual letter.

Gardens of Cheverny deploy six themed spaces across nearly 100 hectares. The English garden unfolds sinuous paths lined with majestic centuries-old lime trees. The botanical garden presents a rich collection of labeled varied species. The flower-and-vegetable garden designed by the Marquise combines vegetables and flowers in harmonious innovative compositions. The plant maze challenges visitors to reach its heart. In spring, 120,000 multicolored tulips form a spectacular floral ribbon. Contemporary artworks punctuate the landscaped walks.

activities.text: Permanent exhibition 'The Secrets of Moulinsart' spanning 700 square meters recreating life-size Tintin's universe. The crypt, underground passage, living room, Tintin's bedroom, and Professor Calculus's laboratory immerse young and old in the famous reporter's adventures. Interactive sets with sound animations and models literally transport you inside the comic panels. The dedicated 100-square-meter shop delights collectors with figurines, plush toys, and exclusive collectibles. This playful visit enchants families and awakens adult nostalgia.

Electric boat rides and golf carts on the canal and through Cheverny park. The 115-meter canal dug in the 18th century allows peaceful gliding between shaded banks. Electric golf carts traverse the estate's pathways offering comfortable exploration of the 100-hectare park without fatigue. Changing perspectives on the château reveal classical architectural harmony. The 2-hectare vineyard producing white wine reveals itself along the route through the outbuildings.

Discovering the surrounding Sologne with its characteristic landscapes of heaths, ponds, and pine forests. Winding roads cross villages with typical red-brick houses and châteaux hidden behind foliage. Shimmering ponds attract varied bird life with herons, egrets, and wild ducks. This game-rich region has always been the privileged hunting ground of kings and nobles. Sologne farms testify to preserved vernacular architecture. These landscapes inspired writer Maurice Genevoix.

days_plan.itin_title: Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Chiroubles, the highest cru of Beaujolais perched at 400 meters altitude, produces elegant and delicate wines nicknamed the 'flowers of Beaujolais.' The village clings to granite hillsides overlooking valleys dotted with vineyards and forests. This elevated position creates a unique microclimate that gives wines their distinctive finesse and floral character.

The Terrasse de Chiroubles offers a breathtaking 360-degree panorama over the entire Beaujolais region. On clear days, the view extends to Mont Blanc and the Alps in the east, the Monts du Forez in the west. Information panels identify the different Beaujolais crus visible from this exceptional belvedere.

The Church of Saint-Étienne, with its Romanesque bell tower, watches over the village from its elevated position. The interior houses a remarkable collection of religious furniture and ex-votos testifying to popular devotion. The stained glass windows filtered by the sun create a mystical atmosphere conducive to meditation.

The Victor Pulliat Museum, housed in a former wine storehouse, pays tribute to this ampelographer who revolutionized viticulture in the 19th century. Pulliat studied grafting to save French vines from phylloxera. Tools, documents, and explanatory panels retrace his essential work for world viticulture.

activities.text: Discover Chiroubles wines through tastings at independent winegrowers who cultivate steep hillsides. This lightest and most aromatic cru of Beaujolais reveals notes of violet, peony, and red fruits. Producers explain the influence of altitude on ripeness and the delicate balance they seek. Small family estates, often spanning 5-10 hectares, welcome visitors with legendary Beaujolais conviviality.

Hike the Sentier des Crus trail that crosses vineyards while offering spectacular views of the Alps. The 8 km marked loop passes through different climats and explains the geological particularities of granite terroir. Resting areas allow you to contemplate the landscape while enjoying a snack. The gentle slopes make this walk accessible to families.

Visit during the Fête des Crus in April, when the entire village celebrates the new vintage. Producers open their cellars for free tastings, street entertainment animates the streets, and regional specialties are served on every corner. The festive and authentic atmosphere showcases Beaujolais conviviality.

Take a mountain bike ride on trails winding through vineyards and forests. Local circuits offer all difficulty levels, from beginner to expert. The varied terrain alternates between forest paths and vineyard roads. Bike rental shops in the village provide quality equipment and detailed maps.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: The Museum of Art and History devotes its history gallery to the Choletais region's defining moments from Gallo-Roman times forward. Extensive focus on the Vendée Wars that profoundly marked the city in blood and memory.

The Textile and Fashion Museum occupies the former linen bleaching factory built in 1881. Demonstrations on century-old looms reveal the manufacturing stages that made Cholet's textile industry famous.
The museum workshop still weaves Cholet's famous red handkerchief. Red for the blood spilled during the Vendée Wars, white for the monarchy—this local symbol has been sung about since 1900.
Notre-Dame Church rises in the city center. Its architecture testifies to Cholet's reconstruction after the Revolutionary Wars' devastation.
The Oriental Park of Maulévrier, just kilometers from Cholet, is Europe's largest Japanese garden at 29 hectares—a landscape of contemplation where Eastern philosophy meets French countryside.

activities.text: Puy du Fou lies 25 km from Cholet. Voted Best Theme Park in the World, it presents grandiose historical spectacles and enchanting settings. The nighttime Cinéscénie gathers 2,400 volunteer actors in an unforgettable epic performance.
Cholet's Saturday market ranks among Anjou's most important. Local terroir products and regional specialties fill the stalls with authentic flavors.
Parc de Moine and Lac de Ribou offer natural spaces for restoration and recreation. Hiking trails and water activities provide outdoor escape.
