visits.text: Saint-Nicolas Church in Civray boasts one of the most ornate Romanesque façades in Poitou, rivaling Notre-Dame-la-Grande. Built in the 12th century, it displays the Wise and Foolish Virgins, the Assumption, the Labors of the Months, and the signs of the Zodiac across two tiers.

Step inside to see the 13th-century fresco recounting the legend of Saint Giles in the south transept. The rest of the interior was painted in the 19th century by Amédée Brouillet, creating a highly colorful atmosphere beneath the octagonal lantern tower.
The Hôtel de la Prévôté, built in the late 15th century, hosted King Louis XIII and his young bride in 1616. Several other private mansions line the town's streets.

Fifteen minutes from Civray, the village of Charroux preserves a tall octagonal tower—a remnant of the 11th-century Saint-Sauveur Abbey—plus a cloister and chapter house. The village is labeled a Small Town of Character.

activities.text: Walk along the Charente River in Civray. A path leads to the leisure area and Île Foin, a 10-minute walk from the center. The town is designated a Green Resort.
Visit local producers in the Civray region: farmhouse cheeses, artisanal apple juice, and Poitevin charcuterie can be found within a few kilometers.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Clairvaux Abbey, founded June 25, 1115 by Saint Bernard, embodied Cistercian spiritual power for centuries. The mother abbey spawned 80 daughter abbeys across Europe. Transformed into prison in 1808, it held up to 2,000 inmates and closed definitively in 2023. Guided tours reveal this dual history: 12th-century Lay Brothers' Building (74m long, exceptional), 18th-century refectory-chapel, 19th-century disciplinary quarter. Heavy atmosphere marked by centuries of confinement.

The Clairvaux Historical Circuit extends around the abbey: Bernard of Clairvaux Museum in Ville-sous-la-Ferté (childhood house), medieval hospice, Val des Choues where Bernard experienced his mystical visions. Interpretation trail connecting key sites of Cistercian history. Allow a full day to complete the circuit including abbey visit.

activities.text: The Clairvaux forest surrounds the abbey with marked hiking trails. Peaceful paths through oak and beech woods, clearings, streams. Easy to moderate circuits from 5 to 15 km. Maps available at Clairvaux tourist office. Meditative walking in the footsteps of Cistercian monks who found solitude and prayer here.

Clairvaux celebrates its Cistercian heritage through cultural events: medieval market in summer, classical music concerts in the abbey, temporary exhibitions on monastic history. Check the calendar before your visit. Special atmosphere in these centuries-old walls. Book tickets in advance for concerts — limited seating.

visits.text: Saint-Samson Church raises its Rayonnant Gothic façade from the 13th and 14th centuries. Sculpted portal and rose window dominate the Place d'Armes from the hilltop overlooking the Brèche valley.
The communal belfry has stood since the 12th century as a symbol of urban freedoms. Rebuilt in the 16th century, it marks the town's independence from the Counts of Clermont.
The Town Hall occupies a 16th-century Renaissance building. Its stone and brick façades testify to communal prosperity during the Wars of Religion.

activities.text: Follow the vestiges of medieval ramparts around the historic center. The 12th-century fortifications protected the city perched on its limestone spur.

days_plan.itin_title: Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: Discovery of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption cathedral on place de la Victoire, a Gothic building made of black lava stone.
Stroll through the medieval streets to place de Jaude and the statue of Vercingetorix.

Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Cathedral crowns the historic center's hilltop with its striking black lava silhouette. Construction began in 1248 under master builder Jean Deschamps, making it the first major edifice built entirely from Volvic stone, whose exceptional strength allowed remarkably slender pillars to soar skyward. Inside, a unique collection of stained glass from the 12th to 19th centuries floods the nave with colored light. The twin 315-foot spires, added by Viollet-le-Duc in the 19th century, signal the monument from every quarter of the city.

In the old merchant quarter of Portus, Notre-Dame-du-Port Basilica radiates the warm glow of blonde arkose stone—a striking contrast to the dark volcanic tones that dominate elsewhere. Built in the first third of the 12th century and inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site on the Santiago de Compostela pilgrimage routes, it ranks among the five great Romanesque churches of Auvergne. Its pyramidal apse adorned with lava stone mosaics, 250 narrative capitals, and sculpted portal stand as some of the finest examples of Romanesque art in France. In the crypt, the Black Madonna has drawn pilgrims since 1614.

The Bargoin Museum houses one of Auvergne's richest archaeological collections. The archaeology department spans from prehistory to the Gallo-Roman era with remarkable pieces including the Bronze Age Manson Treasure, a monumental bronze foot, and a unique collection of Gaulish ex-votos from the Roches spring at Chamalières—unmatched anywhere in Europe. The second department showcases non-European textiles from the 18th to 21st centuries, with pieces from Asia, Africa, and Central America.

Across 21,500 square feet of scenographic space, L'Aventure Michelin traces more than a century of industrial history born in Clermont-Ferrand. From the Michelin brothers' first pneumatic tires to contemporary innovations, the journey mingles spectacular vehicles, interactive screens, cinema experiences, and exploration notebooks. The saga of Bibendum, the company's planetary mascot, unfolds through archival documents and unexpected objects. The museum offers bilingual French-English signage with audio guides in multiple languages.

Place de Jaude, Clermont-Ferrand's grandest esplanade, concentrates the city's energy around its fountains and magnolia trees. Bartholdi's equestrian statue of Vercingetorix—created by the sculptor of the Statue of Liberty—dominates the square with its triumphant posture. The 19th-century theater, Saint-Pierre-des-Minimes church, and Galeries de Jaude shopping arcades frame this plaza where strollers, café terraces, and seasonal markets converge.

Vulcania plunges visitors into the heart of the telluric forces that shaped Auvergne. This European volcano park, nestled in the Chaîne des Puys, combines immersive experiences, shows, and educational workshops around volcanoes, geology, and natural phenomena. Highlights include The Chaîne des Puys Story, Awakening of the Giants, and First Flight—a spectacular aerial journey over the volcanoes. The park is accessible by shuttle from Clermont-Ferrand's train station.

Puy de Dôme rises to 4,806 feet, the highest point in the Chaîne des Puys UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Panoramique des Dômes electric rack railway climbs 1,640 feet of elevation in fifteen minutes with departures every 20 to 40 minutes depending on season. At the summit, 360-degree panoramas embrace 80 dormant volcanoes, the Limagne plain, and on clear days, the Alps themselves. Three themed trails traverse the site: the Pilgrims' Path, the Conquerors' Path, and the Curious Path.

The Temple of Mercury ruins atop Puy de Dôme constitute the largest mountain sanctuary in Roman Gaul. Built in the 2nd century, this monumental temple testifies to the site's religious importance since antiquity. An interactive museum space presents the sanctuary's history and archaeological discoveries. A three-level treasure hunt game, The Temple Relics, offers a playful way to discover the site.

Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Cathedral crowns the historic center with its dramatic black lava silhouette. Construction began in 1248 under architect Jean Deschamps, making it the first major building constructed entirely from Volvic stone, whose exceptional strength enabled impossibly slender pillars to soar skyward. Inside, an extraordinary collection of stained glass from the 12th to 19th centuries floods the nave with kaleidoscopic light. The twin 96-meter spires, added by Viollet-le-Duc in the 19th century, mark the city's skyline from every neighborhood.

In the old merchant quarter of Portus, the Basilica of Notre-Dame-du-Port radiates warm honey tones from its golden arkose stone—a striking contrast to the dark volcanic rock that dominates Clermont. Built in the early 12th century and listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site along the pilgrimage routes to Santiago de Compostela, it stands as one of the five great Romanesque churches of Auvergne. The pyramidal chevet adorned with lava stone mosaics, 250 narrative capitals, and sculpted portal rank among France's finest Romanesque treasures. In the crypt, the Black Virgin has drawn pilgrims since 1614.

The Bargoin Museum houses one of Auvergne's richest archaeological collections. The archaeology wing spans from prehistory through the Gallo-Roman period with remarkable pieces including the Bronze Age Manson Treasure, a monumental bronze foot, and a unique collection of Gallic votive offerings from the sacred spring of Roches in Chamalières—the only such ensemble in Europe. The second wing showcases non-European textiles from the 18th to 21st centuries, with pieces from Asia, Africa, and Central America.

L'Aventure Michelin traces over a century of industrial history born in Clermont-Ferrand across 2,000 square meters of immersive exhibits. From the Michelin brothers' first pneumatic tires to cutting-edge innovations, the experience blends spectacular vehicles, interactive screens, cinema rooms, and explorer journals. The saga of Bibendum, the world-famous tire mascot, unfolds through archival materials and quirky artifacts. The museum offers bilingual French-English exhibits with audio guides in multiple languages.

Place de Jaude, Clermont-Ferrand's grandest square, pulses with city life around its fountains and magnolia trees. Bartholdi's equestrian statue of Vercingetorix—created by the sculptor of the Statue of Liberty—dominates the space in triumphant pose. The 19th-century theater, Saint-Pierre-des-Minimes church, and Galeries de Jaude arcade frame this square where locals gather at café terraces and seasonal markets.

Vulcania plunges visitors into the telluric forces that shaped Auvergne. This European volcano park, nestled in the Chaîne des Puys, combines immersive experiences, shows, and educational workshops exploring volcanoes, geology, and natural phenomena. Highlights include The Chain of Puys Revealed, Awakening of the Giants, and First Flight—a spectacular aerial journey over the volcanoes. The park is accessible by shuttle from Clermont-Ferrand train station.

Puy de Dôme rises to 1,465 meters—the highest point in the UNESCO-listed Chaîne des Puys. The Panoramique des Dômes, an electric rack railway, climbs 500 vertical meters in fifteen minutes with departures every 20-40 minutes depending on season. From the summit, the 360-degree panorama sweeps across 80 dormant volcanoes, the Limagne plain, and on clear days, the Massif du Sancy. Three themed trails circle the site: the Pilgrims' Path, the Conquerors' Path, and the Curious Path.

The Temple of Mercury ruins atop Puy de Dôme constitute the largest mountain sanctuary in Roman Gaul. Built in the 2nd century, this monumental temple testifies to the site's religious importance since antiquity. An interactive museum space presents the sanctuary's history and archaeological discoveries. A three-level treasure hunt game, The Temple Relics, offers a playful way to explore the site.

activities.text: Free walk in the historic center of Clermont-Ferrand and its artisan shops.

Wander through the twin historic centers of Clermont and Montferrand, united from two rival cities in 1630. In Clermont, medieval lanes spiral around the cathedral past Renaissance townhouses, sculpted fountains, and volcanic stone facades. Montferrand's protected quarter preserves its bastide grid plan and exceptional private mansions including the celebrated Maison de l'Apothicaire.

Discover Clermont's street art on an urban trail that leads from mural to mural through downtown streets. Five major works coexist with more discreet interventions scattered along the lanes, like the one on rue des Bohêmes evoking Lascaux's cave paintings. The Such'Art route, designed by the Sommet Urbain Clermontois association, guides the curious among art galleries, antique dealers, and wall creations.

Taste Auvergne's signature dishes in the historic center's restaurants. Truffade, Auvergne potée, stuffed cabbage, tripoux, and potato pâté form the local culinary repertoire. Protected designation of origin cheeses—Saint-Nectaire, Bleu d'Auvergne, Cantal, Fourme d'Ambert—accompany meals or stand alone as worthy tastings.

Hike the Muletiers Trail to reach Puy de Dôme's summit on foot. This historic 3-mile path offers a sporty but accessible climb with 1,378 feet of elevation gain. The route crosses moorland and alpine meadow landscapes before opening onto the summit panorama.

Witness the Brocken spectre phenomenon from Puy de Dôme's summit when conditions align. This optical illusion projects the observer's shadow onto the sea of clouds, surrounded by a circular rainbow. Free seasonal activities include guided walks with interpreters, summit concerts, and yoga sessions with volcano views.

Paraglide from Puy de Dôme's summit for thrill-seekers. The site ranks among France's most renowned for free flight thanks to regular updrafts and exceptional panoramas over the volcanic chain. Tandem discovery flights supervised by certified instructors.

Wander through the twin historic hearts of Clermont and Montferrand, rival cities united in 1630. In Clermont, medieval lanes spiral around the cathedral past Renaissance mansions, sculpted fountains, and volcanic stone facades. The preserved quarter of Montferrand retains its grid-pattern bastide layout and exceptional private mansions, including the celebrated Maison de l'Apothicaire.

Discover Clermont's street art scene through an urban trail connecting murals across the city center. Five major works coexist with more discreet interventions scattered through the alleys, like the one on rue des Bohêmes evoking Lascaux's cave paintings. The Such'Art route, designed by the Sommet Urbain Clermontois association, guides visitors between art galleries, antique shops, and wall murals.

Sample authentic Auvergnat cuisine in restaurants throughout the historic center. Truffade, potée auvergnate, stuffed cabbage, tripoux, and potato pie represent the local gastronomic repertoire. Protected-origin cheeses—Saint-Nectaire, Bleu d'Auvergne, Cantal, Fourme d'Ambert—accompany meals or stand beautifully on their own.

Hike the Muletiers trail to reach Puy de Dôme's summit on foot. This historic 5-kilometer path offers a challenging but accessible climb with 420 meters of elevation gain. The route traverses moorland and high-altitude meadows before emerging onto the summit panorama.

Watch for the Brocken spectre phenomenon from Puy de Dôme's summit when conditions align. This optical illusion projects the observer's shadow onto the sea of clouds, ringed by a circular rainbow. Free seasonal activities include guided walks with mediators, summit concerts, and yoga sessions with volcano views.

Paraglide from Puy de Dôme's summit for thrill-seekers. The site ranks among France's most renowned for free flight thanks to consistent updrafts and the exceptional panorama across the volcanic chain. Tandem flights supervised by certified instructors available.

visits.text: The Château de Clisson has guarded the Sèvre Nantaise since the 12th century. Sprawling across ten acres, this frontier fortress of the Duchy of Brittany bristles with arrow slits and cannon ports carved into weathered stone.

The Church of Notre-Dame crowns its bell tower with a Tuscan campanile—a surprising touch added in the 1800s. After the Vendée Wars razed the town, Clisson was rebuilt in an Italianate style inspired by Tuscany's sun-washed villages.
The medieval wooden market halls rank among France's oldest. Their massive oak beams once sheltered bustling trade, a window into Clisson's prosperous medieval past.
Cross the ancient stone bridge and wander cobbled lanes lined with ochre houses and terracotta roofs. Clisson weaves together medieval bones and Italian soul in an unlikely but enchanting mix.

On the far bank, the Domaine de la Garenne Lemot invites rambling exploration. Temples, follies, and carefully framed views of Clisson evoke the Roman countryside, a romantic fantasy frozen in stone and greenery.

activities.text: The Nantes wine country grows Muscadet on granite slopes. Visit local cellars to taste Clisson cru, an age-worthy Muscadet with smoky notes and candied citrus that defies the grape's simple reputation.
Follow the Sèvre Nantaise on foot or by canoe. The river carves through vineyards, slipping between granite cliffs and past watermills that once powered the valley's industries.

Each June, Hellfest transforms Clisson into the world capital of heavy metal. The legendary festival draws hundreds of thousands of metalheads from across the globe to this unlikely medieval-Italian town.

visits.text: Cluny Abbey (largest medieval church).

visits.text: The Hennessy house offers the most spectacular tour: solar-powered boat crossing of the Charente, ageing cellars where the 'angel's share' floats in the air, guided tasting. Booking essential.

Martell, the oldest of the great houses (1715), has renovated its historic site with its Art Deco tower. Tour of the centuries-old cellars and the founder's house. A more intimate atmosphere than Hennessy.
The Château de Cognac, birthplace of Francis I, houses Baron Otard cognacs. Renaissance vaulted cellars, rooftop view over the Charente. French history entwined with the story of cognac.
Old Cognac is best explored on foot: medieval houses with walls blackened by the cognac fungus (the famous Torula), merchants' townhouses, quays where gabares loaded barrels.
The Musée des Arts du Cognac traces the history of this spirit: stills, cooperage, vintage labels, retro advertisements. A good complement to cellar tours. Housed in two townhouses.

activities.text: Tour of a major cognac house. Hennessy for the immersive experience, Martell for intimacy, Rémy Martin for connoisseurs (expert tours available). Allow 1h30 to 2h including tasting.
Cruise on the Charente. Traditional gabares with commentary (1h30) or licence-free electric boat hire. The river at the pace of the barrels of old.
Cycling along the Charente. The Flow Vélo (national route) passes through Cognac. Bike hire available in town. Flat route to Jarnac (15 km) or Saint-Brice (8 km).

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: Perched on the cliff overlooking Omaha Beach, the American Cemetery at Colleville-sur-Mer spreads its 9,387 white crosses in perfect rows across an emerald lawn. The headstones face westward toward the homeland, while at the center, the bronze statue 'The Spirit of American Youth Rising from the Waves' watches over this haven of peace. The chapel, the Garden of the Missing and the Visitor Center movingly recount Operation Overlord and the sacrifice of an entire generation.

Walk down to Omaha Beach, the scene of 'Bloody Omaha' on June 6, 1944. The fine sand stretches peacefully today, but the remains of blockhouses and memorials recall the 2,500 American soldiers who fell in a single day. The calm sea contrasts with the memory of waves laden with men and equipment, creating a uniquely contemplative atmosphere.

At Pointe du Hoc, the 30-metre cliffs bear the indelible marks of bombardment. Moon-like craters, shattered bunkers and gaping casemates bear witness to the heroic assault by Colonel Rudder's 225 Rangers, who scaled these walls at dawn on D-Day. The site, managed by the American administration, offers a striking panorama over the English Channel and illustrates the ferocity of the fighting.

activities.text: Walk the coastal path between Omaha Beach and Pointe du Hoc. Orientation tables line this historic route offering spectacular views of the cliffs and the sea.
Attend the flag-lowering ceremony at the American Cemetery. Every day at 4 pm, the American flag is retired to the sound of Taps in reverent silence.

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy

visits.text: Yellow train of the Pyrenees: emblematic journey Villefranche-de-Conflent → Latour-de-Carol (recommended section).
Villefranche-de-Conflent: Vauban ramparts and medieval alleyways.
Côte Vermeille: Collioure, Port-Vendres, Banyuls and coastal path.
Cerbère-Banyuls marine reserve: seabed observation (snorkeling depending on conditions).

The Royal Château plunges its stones into the Mediterranean, standing since the 13th century. Built by the Kings of Majorca then remodeled by Vauban, it offers a circular view over the bay and the Albères mountains.

The Church of Our Lady of the Angels rises from the waves with its 17th-century lighthouse-bell tower. Its baroque altarpiece by Joseph Sunyer, covered in gold leaf, features 97 figurines and statues.
Fort Saint-Elme dominates the bay with 360° views. This 1538 fortress controlled the passage between Collioure and Port-Vendres.
The Fauvism Showcase displays reproductions and documents about Matisse and Derain. It's the starting point for the Fauvism Trail.
Step inside the Chapel of Saint Vincent, perched on its rocky outcrop. It houses the patron saint's relics brought back from Rome in 1700.

activities.text: Return to the sea: late afternoon stroll on the seafront of Collioure.
Sunset at the foot of the royal castle and bell tower.
Artistic walk following the Fauvist trail (viewpoints and reproductions).
Beach or cove at midday (swimming depending on season).
Follow the Fauvism Trail. Reproductions mark the exact spots where Matisse and Derain set up their easels in 1905.
Get lost in the narrow streets of Mouré and Port d'Avall. The ochre-pink facades capture the light that seduced the painters.
Admire the colorful Catalan fishing boats on the pebble beach. Fishermen still haul in their nets from 5 a.m. onward.
Taste Collioure's AOC anchovies. The 16th-century cellars preserve Banyuls and Collioure wines, fortified on site.

visits.text: Saint-Pierre Church and its sculpted tympanum. Romanesque building from the 11th century with a rare detail: the tympanum representing Christ's Ascension is made of white Turenne limestone, which contrasts with the surrounding red sandstone. The octagonal gabled bell tower exceeds 20 meters. The church was divided in two during the Wars of Religion to accommodate both religious services simultaneously.

Penitents' Chapel (Saint-Maximin). 14th-century Gothic chapel, it served as a burial place for noble families including the Maussacs (coat of arms visible on a vault keystone). From the mid-17th to the late 19th century, the Black Penitents brotherhood met here. Saved from ruin in 1927 by the Friends of Collonges, it houses a stained glass window by Francis Chigot (1937) depicting the Resurrection, and two contemporary stained glass windows by Didier Mencoboni and Olivier Juteau (2016).

Vassinhac Castle. Built in 1583, this manor belonged to the lords of Collonges who were also governors of the Viscounty of Turenne. The facade features typical Renaissance mullioned windows, and two round towers frame the structure. Not open for interior visits.

Mermaid House. 16th-century residence that owes its name to the mermaid sculpted to the right of the entrance door. It houses a small museum of folk arts and traditions with a reconstruction of a traditional Corrèze interior.

16th-century grain hall. Under this covered hall, the wine and walnut oil market was held. The floor is paved with red sandstone. It was here that Charles Ceyrac, former mayor, launched the association of Most Beautiful Villages of France in 1982. Collonges was the first village to receive the label.
City of red sandstone, towers and noble lodgings.

activities.text: Walk through the streets with 25 towers. Allow 2 hours for the complete tour. The noble houses with blue schist or slate roofs were built by officers of the Viscounty of Turenne between the 15th and 16th centuries. Vines climb the red facades - the green/red contrast is striking. The red sandstone comes from a geological fault between Brive and Meyssac, rich in iron oxide.
Tasting of Corrèze straw wine. This sweet wine is produced from grapes dried on straw racks. A few local producers offer tastings in the village or around Meyssac.
Meyssac Market. 1.5 km from Collonges, the neighboring village holds a market on Tuesdays and Fridays year-round, and on Sundays in July-August.
Walking loop at sunset (red stones).

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley
Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: Little Venice follows the Lauch River where half-timbered houses in ochre, pink, and sky blue lean toward the water. Flat-bottomed boats glide beneath ancient bridges, their reflections rippling across the surface.

The Unterlinden Museum occupies a 13th-century Dominican convent. Matthias Grünewald's Isenheim Altarpiece—painted between 1512 and 1516—commands the former chapel with its haunting Crucifixion scene.
Saint Martin's Collegiate Church raises its Gothic spires above the old town. Gargoyles peer down from the 13th-century carved portal, presiding over the square below.
Look up at the Pfister House, built in 1537 by a wealthy merchant. Its octagonal turret, Renaissance frescoes, and carved wooden gallery showcase the opulence of Colmar's trading heyday.
The Tanners' Quarter lines narrow half-timbered houses along the Fishmonger's Quay. Their upper floors once served for drying animal hides, stretched between the timber beams.
Colmar Christmas Market
Decorations across the historic centre and timber-framed houses
Koïfhus indoor artisan market

activities.text: Step into a flat-bottomed boat for a gentle glide through Little Venice's canals. Painted facades dance in the water as you drift past flower boxes spilling geraniums.
The covered market at Place du Marché-aux-Fruits brims with local treasures. Munster cheese, golden mirabelle plums, bottles of Gewurztraminer chilling in ice.
Wander the cobbled lanes of old Colmar where every corner reveals another half-timbered house painted in jewel tones. Carved wooden signs swing above doorways, and window boxes overflow with blooms.
Explore the six Christmas market squares
Visit the children’s area in Little Venice

visits.text: The Charles de Gaulle Memorial nestles at the foot of the Cross of Lorraine. Across 1,600 square meters, exhibitions trace 20th-century history through the General's extraordinary life.
Giant-screen films, immersive environments, and archival footage recreate the atmosphere of each era. A panoramic elevator connects the memorial to the cross above.
The pink granite Cross of Lorraine soars 44 meters high. Visible from 30 kilometers away, it was inaugurated on June 18, 1972—the anniversary of de Gaulle's historic 1940 appeal.
La Boisserie, purchased in 1934, preserves the salon, library, and study where the General penned his War Memoirs. The tower offers views across the Haute-Marne plains he loved.
The de Gaulle family tomb rests in the village cemetery. Its stark simplicity contrasts powerfully with the monumental cross on the hillside.

activities.text: Visit the Memorial in early afternoon. Allow two hours to explore the chronological sequences and thematic spaces documenting France's turbulent century.
Stroll through La Boisserie's grounds. The General cherished these landscapes he described in his memoirs as embodying France's essence.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: Chateaubriand Castle.
Tranquil Lake.
Old town.

The Château de Combourg has stood since 1016 on a natural hill, flanked by four large pepper-pot towers. The writer's family bought it in 1761. The child lived there from age 8 through adolescence - a period that marked him deeply.

Inside, the tour passes through the writer's bedroom in the Cat Tower. According to his Memoirs, a peg-legged ghost accompanied by a black cat haunted the grand staircase. During renovations, a mummified cat was found behind a 16th-century beam.

The 25-hectare park, designed in English style in the 19th century by the Bühler brothers, contains a 250-year-old false cypress labeled 'Remarkable Tree' and the cross of Lucile, the writer's sister.
The Notre-Dame church, nicknamed 'cathedral church' for its imposing size, rivals the cathedral of Dol-de-Bretagne. Its stained glass windows are remarkable.

In the streets of this Small City of Character, spot the Maison de la Lanterne (lit by torches until the Revolution), the Templars' courtyard, and the Relais des Princes. Half-timbered facades testify to the medieval past.
Château de Combourg — Wooden leg.
Bay of the Dead — Ghost ships.

activities.text: Lake (walk).
Fishing).
Literary heritage.

Walk around Lac Tranquille - the writer gave it this name. A literary trail marked with panels retraces his youth in Combourg. Water lilies and castle reflections on the water create the perfect setting for a walk.

Three walking circuits start from the town: the heritage circuit (medieval architecture), the literary circuit (along the lake), and the historical circuit (in the writer's footsteps). Choose according to your mood.
The trail leads to the Ménage de la Vierge, a rocky chaos hidden under the canopy. Granite blocks form narrow passages that you pass through by squeezing between moss-covered walls.
Access: public (Combourg)
Access: public (Bay)

visits.text: Château Stanislas de Commercy, classified as a Historic Monument, was embellished by the Prince of Vaudémont then by Stanislas Leszczynski, former King of Poland and Louis XV's father-in-law. Architects Boffrand and Dorbay gave it its current appearance. Partly destroyed in 1944, it was identically rebuilt from 1957 to 1977.

Cross the semicircular Place du Fer à Cheval, bordered by two symmetrical buildings extending the castle. The stables redesigned by architect Héré recall the pavilions of Place Stanislas in Nancy: continuous rustication, semicircular bays, and balustrades adorned with trophies.
Saint-Pantaléon church blends a 17th-century nave with a 19th-century choir in Champagne Gothic style. Its sober interior contrasts with the richness of liturgical furnishings.

The Museum of Ceramics and Ivory is housed in the former municipal bathhouses in Art Deco style (1930), inspired by Stanislas's royal pavilion. It holds one of France's most important ivory collections, from the 17th to 19th centuries, complemented by porcelains and earthenware.
Place Charles de Gaulle houses the former Town Hall built under Stanislas. Nearby, a 1903 pharmacy with Art Nouveau decor testifies to the town's elegance at the turn of the century.

activities.text: Step into an artisanal madeleine factory to watch the making of these small shell-shaped cakes, born in the kitchens of Stanislas's castle in the 18th century. Tasting on site.

Walk along the Meuse following the Promenade Stanislas, which crosses the town's different districts within 18th-century boundaries. The river draws meanders bordered by willows and classical architecture.
Visit the Priory of Breuil, founded in the 11th century, which occupies an important place in Commercy's religious history. Guided tours trace its successive transformations.

days_plan.itin_title: Meuse Circuit: Verdun and the Citadels

visits.text: The Château de Compiègne unfolds its neoclassical façades built between 1751 and 1788 by Ange-Jacques Gabriel. Louis XV, Louis XVI, then Napoleon I and Napoleon III made it a major residence alongside Versailles and Fontainebleau.

The Imperial Apartments showcase the unified First Empire décor of 1808-1810. Architect Louis-Martin Berthault completely remodeled the interior with Jacob-Desmalter furnishing and Girodet creating painted decorations.

The Ballroom Gallery was built in 1810 for Marie-Louise of Austria's arrival. Napoleon welcomed his future empress here on March 27, 1810, exactly as Marie-Antoinette had been received forty years earlier.

The Second Empire Museum evokes Napoleon III's famous Séries de Compiègne. Each autumn, one hundred guests succeeded each other for four to six weeks of hunting, concerts, and theatrical performances in quasi-imperial intimacy.

The Armistice Clearing preserves the railway car where the 1918 and 1940 armistices were signed. On November 11, 1918 at 5:15 AM, Marshal Foch received Germany's capitulation in dining car 2419D of the Wagons-Lits Company.

The Armistice Memorial displays car 2439D, fitted out identically after the original was destroyed in 1945. Hitler had demanded that the June 1940 armistice be signed in the same place to avenge the 1918 humiliation.

activities.text: Wander through the Forest of Compiègne among beech groves and centuries-old oaks. Fourteen thousand hectares of forest unfold just steps from the château.

days_plan.itin_title: Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: Fortified walled town.
Fishing port.
Fishing Museum.

The Ville Close of Concarneau, surrounded by 14th-century ramparts, occupies a granite islet connected to land by a fortified footbridge. It's one of Brittany's last inhabited walled towns - about 100 people live there year-round.

The ramparts offer an almost complete walkway, punctuated with towers and watchtowers. From the south bastion, the view plunges over the fishing port - France's third largest - and its blue-hulled trawlers.

The Fishing Museum, installed in the Ville Close's former arsenal, traces three centuries of Breton fishing: tuna boat models, nets, navigation instruments. A floating trawler, the Hémérica, can be visited at the port.
Concarneau's fish auction comes alive each morning at dawn. Crates of tuna, sardines, and langoustines parade on conveyor belts while fish merchants bid. It's the town's economic pulse.
The Clock Tower belfry, entrance gate to the Ville Close, dates from the 15th century. Its sundial and mechanical clock have marked the hours for 500 years.
The covered halls of Quai Pénéroff, built in 1880 for fish sales, preserve their iron and glass structure. The market is held there daily.

activities.text: Blue Nets Festival (August).
Beaches.
Fish auction.
Walk the complete circuit of the Ville Close ramparts. The walkway alternates views of the fishing port, pleasure harbor, and Concarneau bay.
Follow the coastal path toward Sables Blancs and Cornouaille beaches. The path passes the seafront, old fish tanks, and Pointe du Cabellou.
If you're there in August, the Blue Nets - Brittany's oldest festival, created in 1905 to support striking sardine workers - animates the quays for four days: fest-noz, costume parades, and concerts.

days_plan.itin_title: Finistère, Brittany Road Trip: Breton Headlands, Ponant Islands & Coastal Heritage
Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Pierre Cathedral dominates Condom like a vessel of golden stone. Built in the 16th century on the ruins of a Benedictine abbey from 1011, it blends Flamboyant Gothic with Renaissance influences. The 19th-century choir takes inspiration from Albi. The choir sculptures and 19th-century stained glass deserve attention. The organ resonates magnificently during concerts.
The 16th-century Gothic cloister adjoins the cathedral. Its large walkways and numerous bays create a peaceful atmosphere. It occasionally hosts exhibitions and cultural events.
The Armagnac Museum explains the making of this emblematic Gers brandy. You'll discover traditional distillation methods and the history of this spirit produced here since the Middle Ages.

activities.text: The medieval streets of the town center have real charm. Rue Charron, one of the oldest, leads from the cathedral to Place du Lion d'Or where 13th-century houses stand. The 18th and 19th-century mansions testify to prosperity from the Armagnac trade.
The port on the Baïse River was an important commercial center in the 18th century. Now a marina, the river is navigable and boat trips are offered. Hiking trails also follow the Baïse.
Wednesday morning market takes place in the square beside the cathedral. You'll find local products: foie gras, Armagnac, cheeses, and local vegetables.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: The Pont-Vieux in Confolens has spanned the Vienne since the 11th century (on ancient foundations). Postcard view of half-timbered houses reflected in the water. This is where the Goire meets the Vienne — hence the name 'confluent'.
The old town climbs the hill in winding lanes. Medieval half-timbered houses, craft shops, small shaded squares. The Saint-Barthélemy quarter keeps its old-world atmosphere.
The church of Saint-Maxime overlooks the upper town. Sculpted Romanesque doorway, square bell tower typical of Poitou. Inside, carved historiated capitals and contemporary stained glass. Free entry.

activities.text: Walk along the Vienne. The towpath leads from the Old Bridge towards the countryside. Anglers, grey herons, abandoned locks. Peaceful atmosphere guaranteed.
Canoeing on the Vienne. The watersports centre offers routes from 2 hours to a full day. Calm water, no technical difficulty. Hire includes life jackets and dry bags.

Confolens Festival (mid-August). Since 1958, France's biggest folklore festival. Troupes from around the world, costumed parades, free concerts. If you're passing through at this time, it's unmissable.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: The Sainte-Foy Abbey Church was built from 1041 by Abbot Odolric. The Last Judgement tympanum features 124 sculpted figures on 24 blocks of yellow limestone. The interior contains 250 Romanesque capitals spread over two levels.

The Treasury houses the reliquary statue of Saint Foy, a unique piece of Carolingian goldsmith work set with gold and precious stones. This collection bears witness to nine centuries of pilgrimage on the Way of Saint James.

Pierre Soulages worked from 1987 to 1994 to create 104 stained glass windows for the abbey church. He carried out nearly 700 trials with master glassmaker Jean-Dominique Fleury to achieve a unique translucent glass. The light changes throughout the day thanks to variations in grain size.

activities.text: The Conques Nocturnes take place from May to October to illuminate the polychrome tympanum. The reimagined polychromy reveals the restored medieval colours.

Visit the abbey church galleries to get up close to the Soulages stained glass windows. The guided tour lasts 45 minutes and explores the painter's creative approach. Booking recommended, open to visitors aged 12 and above.

visits.text: Route Autoire → Conques — countryside crossing and valleys of Aveyron, photo stops.
Conques — medieval town on the Dourdou, half-timbered houses and sloping alleyways.
Sainte-Foy Abbey Church — Last Judgment tympanum, stained glass windows by Pierre Soulages.

activities.text: Treasure of Conques — medieval goldsmithery (reliquary of Saint Foy).

visits.text: The 19th-century Grands Moulins dominate the Essonne River with their metallic industrial architecture. Saint Louis built his château here before departing for the Crusades.
Founded in 957 to house the relics of Saint Exuperius, the Cathedral of Saint-Spire blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its bell tower dominates the river valley.
The marble effigy of Count Haymon rests in the choir. This 14th-century sculpture rivals those at Saint-Denis for its exquisite craftsmanship.
The 17th-century organ was restored after its destruction by Prussian forces. The stained glass windows trace the history of the relics preserved in the primitive church.
The former Church of Saint-Jean-en-L'Isle housed a commandery of the Knights of Malta. Though deconsecrated, it has been a classified historic monument since the 12th century.

activities.text: The Juine and Louette rivers flow through town, creating peaceful small canals. Follow the paths along the right bank past the old mills.
Corbeil-Essonnes Jazz Festival takes place between June and July with several days of open-air concerts throughout the town.
La Nacelle Park and Chantemerle Park offer over 200 hectares of green spaces. The town has earned three flowers in the Flowered Towns competition.

days_plan.itin_title: Nièvre, France: Morvan Hills and Ducal Castle Heritage Routes

visits.text: Cordes-sur-Ciel reveals itself on foot as you climb its cobbled lanes through five fortified walls. Founded in 1222 as a bastide by Count Raymond VII of Toulouse, it's one of Occitanie's oldest hilltop towns.

Stop before the Maison du Grand Fauconnier: its 13th-century Gothic façade is carved with fantastical creatures and mythological scenes. Next door, the Maison du Grand Veneur displays hunting bas-reliefs of remarkable precision.
The church of Saint-Michel dates from 1269. Its southern Gothic architecture with a single nave was expanded twice in the 14th and 15th centuries. The side chapels deserve careful attention.

Step inside the Charles-Portal Museum, housed in the Porte des Ormeaux, a classified medieval military structure. Here you'll find carved falcons, an old 16th-century town hall door, and films about the market hall's well, which plunges more than 100 meters deep.

Under the 14th-century market hall—Cordes' commercial heart for seven hundred years—locate the vertiginous well that drops more than 100 meters beneath your feet. The surrounding terraces remain the townspeople's gathering place.

The Jardin des Paradis, classified as a Remarkable Garden, occupies the summit of the citadel behind a white stone wall. Botanical squares, forgotten species, and refreshing pools compose a timeless retreat.

Forty minutes by road, Bruniquel perches atop a cliff overlooking the Aveyron gorges. Two castles face each other: the Old (13th century) and the Young (15th century), separated by a wall born of family feuds lasting three centuries.

In the Old Castle, the Renaissance gallery overlooks the Aveyron 90 meters below. The knights' hall preserves 13th-century paired windows and sculpted capitals. One room recounts the discovery of Bruniquel Cave, whose structures date back 176,500 years.

Climb the cobbled streets to the upper town. The Grand Fauconnier House, classified as a Historical Monument, displays carved falcons on its 14th-century façade. Today it houses the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art.
The Grand Veneur House stands out with its four stories and façade decorated with carved hunting scenes in sandstone. On the white stones, dragons, fantastic beasts, and enigmatic figures come alive.

Beneath the 14th-century covered market hall, built for fabric and leather trading, discover the well of Cordes. More than 100 meters deep, it plunges vertically into the rock. The wrought-iron cross stands to its left.
Enter the Gothic-style Saint-Michel church, whose interior frescoes deserve attention. Stained glass windows filter light onto period furnishings and carved wooden altars.
Hidden behind white stone walls, the Jardin des Paradis reveals its botanical squares, forgotten species, and refreshing pools. A timeless retreat at the summit of the citadel.

The Charles Portal Museum traces Cordes's history from prehistory to the 19th century. Objects, videos, and panels tell the story of the bastide's founding in 1222 by Raymond VII, Count of Toulouse, during the Albigensian Crusade against the Cathars.

activities.text: Follow Cordes' heritage trail (roughly 2-hour loop). The route offers views of the citadel from surrounding hills and passes through the five remaining fortified gates out of the original fifteen.

Rise early to admire Cordes from the Cérou valley: on certain mornings, mist envelops the hill and only the citadel emerges from the clouds. This spectacle inspired its name 'sur-Ciel' (in the sky) in 1993.
Artisan workshops—ceramicists, jewelers, wood sculptors, leather craftspeople—line the upper town's lanes. Push open their doors and discuss their craftsmanship.
The AOC Gaillac vineyard spreads at Cordes' foot, with over 2,000 years of winemaking history. Nearby estates offer tastings of reds, dry whites, sparkling wines, and rosés.
Wander among artisan workshops: ceramicists, jewelry makers, painters, and leather craftspeople occupy medieval shops along Rue Droite. About thirty of them work year-round in the citadel.
Taste the croquants de Cordes, a local specialty inherited from the Middle Ages. This crunchy biscuit combines sugar, egg whites, and roasted almonds.

Rise early to admire Cordes from the Cérou valley below. On certain mornings, pink mist envelops the valley and only the citadel emerges from the clouds, fully justifying its name 'sur-Ciel' (in the sky).
Reach the ramparts' belvedere for a 360° panorama over the Cérou valley and the hills of Gaillac vineyards. On clear days, the view extends to the Montagne Noire.

visits.text: Alpine village south of the plateau; chalets, small squares and stone walls.
Clearings and trail starts toward the high valleys.

activities.text: Panoramic loop at the edge of the Hauts-Plateaux (6–8 km).
Heritage trail in the village: roofs with stone slabs and wooden shingles.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

Old town — vaulted passages and golden stone facades.

activities.text: Walk in the Gorges de Bagarèdes and Vallon Sourn (shaded trails).
Monthly organic market in May (agricultural products and plants).

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages

visits.text: Old town of Corte
Cours Paoli - main shopping street
Citadel of Corte and regional anthropology museum
Sainte-Croix Chapel
Restonica Gorges
Lake Melo at 1711m altitude

The Citadel of Corte rises from its rocky pinnacle 100 meters above the town. An eagle's nest built in the 15th century, it houses the Museum of Corsica tracing island history and traditions. From the Belvedere terrace, plunging views of the confluence of the Tavignano and Restonica rivers between mountains.

The old town climbs in cobbled lanes up to the citadel. Capital of Pasquale Paoli from 1755 to 1769 during independent Corsica, Corte preserves the soul of island resistance. The University of Corsica, founded by Paoli and reopened in 1981, brings life to this mountain city.

The Chapel of Sainte-Croix and the Four Cannons fountain mark the old town. Genoese and Corsican architecture intermingle in the stone facades. Place Paoli at the center, shaded squares, and student bars give life to this mountain town.

activities.text: Exploration of the university town
Hike to the Grotelle sheepfold
Swimming in natural pools and basins

The Restonica Gorges climb 15 kilometers from Corte toward the mountain lakes. A spectacular road serpentining between rock walls and Laricio pine forests. The Grotelle sheepfolds at 1,370 meters mark the starting point for hikes to Lakes Melo and Capitello.

The hike to Lake Melo then Capitello starts from the Grotelle sheepfolds. 1.5 hours climbing to Lake Melo nestled at 1,711 meters in a granite cirque. An additional 45 minutes to Lake Capitello at 1,930 meters. Rocky passages with chains. Glacial waters reflecting the summits.

The natural pools of the Restonica invite swimming in basins of rushing water. Several spots accessible from the road before the sheepfolds. Cool waters and rocks polished by the torrent. Heavy summer crowds, prefer mornings or late afternoons.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Corsica Road Trip: Granite Cliffs, Mountain Passes & Island Beaches
Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

Gate of Burgundy.
Cistercian abbey.

activities.text: Earthenware route.

days_plan.itin_title: Nièvre, France: Morvan Hills and Ducal Castle Heritage Routes

visits.text: Cotignac — village labeled 'Most Beautiful Village of France', nestled at the foot of a tufa cliff pierced with troglodyte dwellings.
Discovery of the two Saracen towers and medieval streets lined with stone houses.

Cotignac's tuff cliff rises 80 meters high and 400 meters wide, sculpted by the ancient Cassole waterfall. Troglodyte dwellings carved into the rock served as refuge in the Middle Ages. Climb the 90 steps to discover the old caves and a panoramic view over the village.

At the cliff's summit, two watchtowers known as 'Saracen' once surveyed the horizon against invasions. An orientation table allows you to embrace the rooftops of Cotignac, the terraced hills planted with olive trees and cypress—a view of timeless Provence.

Cours Gambetta, the main artery shaded by century-old plane trees, is the hub of social life. The Fountain of the Four Seasons marks its center. Café terraces come alive especially on market days—the pulse of village life.

The sanctuary of Notre-Dame de Grâces, built in 1519 following apparitions of the Virgin Mary, nestles in the hills 1 km south of the village. King Louis XIV and his mother Anne of Austria made a pilgrimage here in 1660 to give thanks for the king's birth.

Some semi-troglodyte houses, embedded at the foot of the cliff, are still inhabited. The 12th-century medieval lanes reveal ochre and pastel facades, painted shutters, and 17 fountains with clear water—living history in stone and color.

activities.text: Walk to the troglodyte cliff and exploration of the rock site.
Provençal market on Tuesday morning — local products and local atmosphere.
Wine estates around Cotignac produce AOC Côtes de Provence wines. The cooperative cellar in the village center and several estates offer tastings and visits to the cellars—the terroir in a glass.
On Tuesday mornings, the Provençal market takes over the Cours. In summer, a farmers' market gathers local producers: wine, oil, honey, truffles, and artisan crafts—the bounty of the land on display.

Six kilometers north, the Sillans-la-Cascade waterfall plunges 42 meters into a verdant setting. The access trail crosses an oak forest. Swimming is forbidden at the waterfall's base but possible downstream—nature's refreshment.

Push open the doors of artisan workshops and galleries dotting the lanes. Cotignac attracts numerous artists, painters, and photographers from across Europe—creative energy flows through these ancient stones.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages
Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: Coucy Castle raises its spectacular ruins on a wooded spur. Built in the 13th century by Enguerrand III, this medieval fortress dominated the region with its 54-meter keep before German troops dynamited it in 1917. The massive ramparts and imposing towers still testify to the grandeur of this feudal palace. The site offers one of the finest examples of medieval military architecture.

The medieval town surrounds the castle with its ramparts and fortified gates. The Porte de Laon and Soissons Gate open the enclosure protecting the upper town. Cobblestone streets lead to Saint-Sauveur church and half-timbered houses.
The underground cellars dug beneath the castle served as storage and refuge. Vaulted galleries carved into rock reveal medieval construction techniques. These spaces now host cultural events.
The Saint-Aubin Park surrounds the castle over several hectares. Wooded paths wind through greenery offering viewpoints over ruins and surrounding countryside. Picnic areas invite outdoor breaks.

activities.text: The castle historical show brings the medieval era to life with jousts, falconry and knight combats. This spectacle recreates 13th-century atmosphere with period costumes and authentic weapons. Performances occur during summer and certain weekends.
Walk the marked forest trails surrounding Coucy. Several loops cross the massif through beech and oak groves. Paths lead to panoramic viewpoints over the valley.
Visit the museum evoking castle and town history. Collections include medieval objects, weapons, period models and documents. Interactive displays explain fortress construction and strategic role.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature

visits.text: The Commanderie des Templiers de Coulommiers, built between the 12th and 15th centuries, is the best preserved north of the Loire. The rectangular courtyard serves the Tithe Barn, dovecote, commander's lodging, and Sainte-Anne Chapel.
Enter the Sainte-Anne Chapel: its 13th-century wall paintings are among the rare preserved medieval decorations in the region. A permanent exhibition traces the history of the Knights Templar.

The Parc des Capucins, considered one of the most beautiful parks in Île-de-France, occupies the site of the former château of the Duchess of Longueville, who inspired "La Princesse de Clèves". The château remnants and Notre-Dame-des-Anges Church are classified Historic Monuments.
The Capucins Municipal Museum, housed in the former convent chapel, preserves the last vestiges of the tannery industry that made Coulommiers prosper for 800 years.

The Halle aux Fromages (Cheese Market Hall), labeled Heritage of Regional Interest, was built in 1887 in cast iron modeled after Paris's Les Halles. It was the trading and sales place for Brie cheeses.

activities.text: Walk along the Grand Morin's brassets, small canals created in the Middle Ages by Champagne tanners. Thirty-six bridges and footbridges span these waterways that earn Coulommiers the nickname "Little Venice".
The Commanderie's medieval garden recreates a vegetable patch, medicinal plants, and cut flowers cultivated in the Middle Ages. A 4,000-square-meter space to explore at your own pace.
Taste Coulommiers cheese at one of the local fromageries. Smaller and creamier than Brie de Meaux, this soft cheese is best enjoyed when aged on-site.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: The Maison du Marais Poitevin occupies the former Maison de la Coutume on the square of the same name. The illuminated maraiscope traces the draining of the marsh.
The Church of the Holy Trinity dates from 830. Its watchtower on the side and its 18th-century funeral frieze testify to a turbulent history.
The narrow streets reveal low houses with whitewashed walls and blue or green shutters.

activities.text: Board a traditional flat-bottomed boat from the Quai Louis Tardy. The boatmen tell stories of the marsh, its wildlife, and the mystery of fire on water.
Rent a boat or canoe to navigate independently through the maze of canals bordered by centuries-old pollarded ash trees.

days_plan.itin_title: Deux-Sèvres Circuit: Marais Poitevin and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Acquired in 1552 by Cosme Clausse, the Château de Courances was rebuilt between 1622 and 1630. Baron de Haber restored it in the 19th century, adding the horseshoe staircase inspired by Fontainebleau.
Step into the Monkey Gallery adorned with tapestries where playful primates perform antics. The guided tour reveals six rooms still inhabited by the de Ganay family.
Fourteen springs feed the park. The 600-meter Grand Canal predates Fontainebleau's by a century. King Louis XIII came here to paddle his canoe.
Cascading water features, the Mirror reflecting the château, the decagonal Gerbe fountain, and sculpted gargoyles dramatize the Renaissance hydraulic network.
The Japanese garden created in 1930 by the Marquise de Ganay sits beside the 3-hectare vegetable garden. Organic fruits and vegetables are grown for sale throughout Île-de-France.

activities.text: Wander the 75-hectare park along grass-lined alleys. The great gardener de Noailles described it as France's only garden that is both classical and romantic.
Visit the Foulerie tea room, housed in the former hemp mill. The building reflects beautifully in the canal of the same name.
Landscape architects Achille Duchêne redesigned the park in the early 20th century to restore its classical layout. Each generation of owners has left their mark.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral of Coutances is a masterpiece of 13th-century Norman Gothic, built over an 11th-century Romanesque structure still visible beneath the stone facing. Its vertiginous lantern tower floods the transept crossing with ethereal light. The facade's twin spires soar to 246 and 253 feet.

Take the guided tour of the cathedral's upper reaches. The route winds through the Romanesque tower interiors, the galleries, medieval timber frames, and the nave's upper walkways. Up here, 13th-century stained glass reveals itself at eye level, its jeweled colors blazing.

The Jardin des Plantes, a Historic Monument since 1992, blends French, English, and Italian garden styles on a single terraced hillside. Italian-style terraces, English-style groves, and a living labyrinth succeed one another. The 16-foot-circumference purple beech and the tulip tree rank among its notable specimens.

The Quesnel-Morinière Museum occupies a 17th-century mansion bequeathed to the city in 1850. Its seven permanent galleries present paintings from the 17th to 20th centuries, Norman ceramics, and works by 'Le Pou qui grimpe' ('The Climbing Flea'), an early 20th-century local art movement. Admission is free.

Saint-Pierre Church, rebuilt after the Hundred Years' War in the 15th century, illustrates the transition from Flamboyant Gothic to Renaissance. Its tracery windows and sculpted portal deserve a stop.
Founded before 1238 by Hugues de Morville, Saint-Nicolas Church stands outside the old city walls. The 13th-century chapel was expanded in the 14th century to become the parish church of the suburb.

activities.text: The Jazz sous les Pommiers (Jazz Under the Apple Trees) festival takes over Coutances each Ascension week since 1982. More than 50 concerts unfold in the cathedral, theater, halls, and schoolyards. Jazz, soul, world music, and street performances pulse through the town for five days.
Wander the medieval lanes around the cathedral. Interior courtyards, vaulted passages, and half-timbered houses sketch an old center that survived the 1944 bombardments remarkably intact.
Coutances market runs every Thursday morning, on place Saint-Nicolas and around the cathedral. Cotentin cheeses, teurgoule rice pudding, Isigny butter, and coastal fish crowd the stalls.
The Jardin des Plantes' tradition of mosaic culture, practiced since the late 19th century, unfolds across the flower beds. Geometric compositions change with each season, a living art form.

days_plan.itin_title: Manche Road Trip: Cotentin Peninsula & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Craon Castle, nicknamed 'little Versailles of Mayenne,' stands on Guinefol hill overlooking the town. This elegant late 18th-century tuffeau edifice, built by the Marquis d'Armaillé on the ruins of a feudal lodge destroyed by the Wars of Religion then by Henri IV, is still inhabited by the same family.

The guided tour opens salons with finely carved woodwork and furnishings that belonged to Marie-Antoinette. The architecture, inspired by Versailles' Petit Trianon, illustrates the art of living in the Age of Enlightenment.

The French formal garden surrounds the castle with perfect symmetry. Water mirrors reflect the façade and light. The English-style park, planted in 1830, unfolds 47 hectares of greenery and over 150 plant species along 6 km of tree-lined alleys with century-old specimens.
Don't miss the large walled kitchen garden (over a hectare), the 19th-century greenhouses, the ice house, the wash-laundry and the dovecote—all preserved in their original state.

In town, Saint-Nicolas church and the market halls merit a detour. Craon was also a major center for Mayenne horse racing, a tradition rooted in this horse-breeding land symbolized by Pegasus, the red winged horse, emblem of the department.

activities.text: Walk the castle park following the 6 km of alleys. A treasure hunt is offered to children. Along the paths, encounter horses, goats, swans, geese and perhaps deer or squirrels that populate the estate.
Follow the Oudon river that borders the park. Its two bridges offer romantic viewpoints of the castle through the grove.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul

visits.text: The Gallé-Juillet Museum showcases fine earthenware from Creil and Montereau produced between 1797 and 1895. Black stencil-printed and polychrome services illustrate the golden age of Creil manufacturing.
The former earthenware factories lined the banks of the Oise from the late 18th century. The ceramic industry made Creil's reputation with patterns inspired by Antiquity and the Orient.
Saint-Médard Church raises its Flamboyant Gothic bell tower from the 16th century. Rebuilt after the Hundred Years' War, it preserves Renaissance stained glass and furnishings.

activities.text: Stroll along the banks of the Oise where 19th-century industry once thrived.
Discover the town's industrial heritage through its ceramic-era architecture.

days_plan.itin_title: Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: Small town of character: monumental halls, Augustinian convent and medieval alleys.
Climb to the castle and panorama over the Dauphiné plain.

activities.text: Intra-muros circuit of gates and ramparts (3 km).
Ridge walk around the castle (short loop).

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Climb the 257 steps leading to the summit of France's tallest keep. Standing 52 meters high, the Tower of Crest is an architectural masterpiece comprising three nested towers. Transformed into a state prison from the 17th to 19th centuries, it held Protestants, libertines, and insurgents. From the top, enjoy exceptional 360° panoramas over the Drôme valley, Saou forest, and Vercors mountains.

Wander the narrow, winding alleys of the medieval old town that snake beneath the tower. Discover calades paved with river stones, covered passages, and remnants of ancient ramparts. The Saint-Sauveur church with its Romanesque bell tower stands as a remarkable edifice.

activities.text: Experience something unique with the immersive audio system. A 19th-century guard guides you through nine centuries of history. Discover prisoners' living conditions, escape attempts, and hundreds of poignant graffiti covering the walls.
For the truly daring, attempt the 44-meter rappel down the east wall, reliving Philippe Rivoire's 1789 escape attempt. Supervised by certified instructors, you'll enjoy an incredible view over Crest.
Take the Ramparts Path that climbs from downtown to the Tower. This steep ascent offers beautiful valley views. Below, stroll along the emerald-watered Drôme riverbanks.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir

Loops of the Marne.

activities.text: MAC VAL (contemporary art museum).
Leisure island.
Vincennes Zoo.

days_plan.itin_title: Val-de-Marne, France: A Road Trip to Pleasure Gardens & Historic Lakeside Châteaux

visits.text: The fortress of Crozant rises on a rocky spur at the confluence of the Creuse and Sédelle, a strategic site that fascinated George Sand from 1827. The romantic ruins of the Lusignan castle, built in the 12th-13th centuries, stretch over a kilometer of ramparts punctuated by ten towers. The Colin tower, figurehead above the precipice, offers a striking silhouette. Listed as a Historic Monument and a stop on the path to Santiago de Compostela.

The Hôtel Lépinat, former meeting place for Impressionist painters from 1880, has become the Museum of the Valley of the Painters. In this legendary inn where Guillaumin, Picabia, and many others stayed, an immersive 90-minute journey plunges visitors into the universe of the Crozant School through new technologies, atmospheric settings, and more than 100 original works. Discover how 500 painters followed one another here from 1850 to 1950.

The Moulin de la Folie (Mill of Madness), on the banks of the Sédelle, was one of the most painted motifs in the valley. Paul Madeline depicted it realistically, Francis Picabia drew abstract-edged works from it. The mill and its stone bridge remain, even if vegetation has replaced the rocky debris that fascinated the artists. A trail follows the watercourse to the mill.

activities.text: The Painters' Trail of Crozant offers a circuit punctuated by interpretation posts presenting the paintings created at each viewpoint. Enameled stoneware medallions reproduce details of works, engraved plaques tell the valley's history, and glass windows invite visual games with the landscape. A discovery booklet extends the experience with practical exercises.

A narrated boat ride allows discovery of the Creuse gorges from the water. From Crozant to the Éguzon dam, the 90-minute route offers a unique perspective on the cliffs and lush vegetation that replaced the mineral landscapes painted by the Impressionists before the waters rose in 1926.
