days_plan.itin_title: Forcalquier & the Lure Valley: Lavender Fields, Gorges & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: Discovery of downtown Dax and its arena.
Visit to the Borda museum and Gallo-Roman remains.

Fontaine Chaude: Gushing at 64°C since Roman times, this spring feeds the thermal establishments of Dax, France's premier spa town and one of Europe's most important. The neoclassical building erected between 1814 and 1818 houses the Nèhe spring. The péloïde, mud derived from Adour River silt, has been used for rheumatological treatments for 2,000 years.

Archaeological crypt: Remains of a 1st-century basilica bearing witness to ancient Aquae Tarbellicae (waters of the Tarbelli). The mosaics and Roman foundations reveal the importance of this ancient thermal city. Guided tours organized by the Borda Museum on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday at 3pm from February to December.

Notre-Dame Cathedral: Built between 1662 and 1894 in an imposing neoclassical style. The Apostles Portal, a 13th-century Gothic remnant, contrasts with the overall architecture. The Gallo-Roman ramparts are still visible nearby, recalling the ancient city's fortifications.

Art Deco heritage: The Atrium and Hotel Le Splendid testify to the golden age of the 1930s. These buildings designed by Parisian architects Granet and Expert illustrate the splendor of grand spa resorts. The Parc du Sarrat, a remarkable 3.5-hectare garden, shelters over 1,000 trees and 130 species.

activities.text: Discovery of the thermal culture of Dax, the largest thermal resort in France.

Heritage circuit: 2-hour urban route between Fontaine Chaude, Gallo-Roman ramparts and cathedral. The tourist office offers themed guided tours (Art Deco, thermal heritage, arenas). Dax has been labeled a City of Art and History since 2019.

Dax markets: The renovated halls (2021) offer local products Saturday and Sunday mornings. Fattened duck, Landes asparagus, Tursan wines and Bayonne ham. The friendly atmosphere and local producers make these markets essential stops.

Banks of the Adour: Walk along the river at Parc Théodore-Denis. The landscaped banks offer a peaceful setting for walking or running. Fishing possible with permit. Sunsets over the water create a special atmosphere.

Feria de Dax in August: 5 days of entertainment with course landaise, bandas, concerts and parades. The city transforms completely during this festive period. Accommodation booking essential several months beforehand. The arenas host corridas and bullfighting shows.

days_plan.itin_title: Southwest France Journey: Atlantic Coast to Pyrenees Mountain Peaks
Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: The Planches de Deauville, a legendary 643-metre boardwalk of azobé wood, line the beach with multicoloured parasols. The 450 bathing cabins bear the names of stars who attended the American Film Festival. The Art Deco Bains Pompéiens complex completes this postcard setting immortalised by Claude Lelouch.

Admire the Hôtel Normandy Barrière with its green half-timbered Anglo-Norman style. This five-star palace built in 1912 embodies the elegance of the Côte Fleurie. Just steps away, the Casino Barrière has been glowing with golden lights for over a century.

Visit Les Franciscaines, an innovative cultural hub set in a former convent. Museum, temporary exhibitions, media library and documentation spaces explore horses, cinema, photography and the Norman art of living.

activities.text: Attend horse racing at the Deauville-La Touques racecourse. Inaugurated in 1864 by the Duc de Morny, this temple of racing hosts the most prestigious Group 1 events during the August meeting.
Enjoy the beach and its water sports. Land sailing, swimming and sunbathing set the rhythm of summer days on Deauville's fine sand.
Browse the luxury boutiques in the town centre. Deauville cultivates the art of elegant shopping, with fashion houses and designers side by side.
Unwind at the spa or thalassotherapy centre. Deauville's wellness establishments offer marine treatments and massages overlooking the sea.

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy

visits.text: Saint-Aré Church.
Medieval Loire bridge.
Priory.

activities.text: Loire-Aron confluence.
River heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Nièvre, France: Morvan Hills and Ducal Castle Heritage Routes

visits.text: The international station at Delle, reopened in 2018, serves the Belfort-Bienne line via Delémont. Just 1,600 meters from Boncourt in Switzerland, it marks the terminus for CFF trains and provides connections to TGV services from Belfort-Montbéliard.

The railway heritage testifies to Delle's strategic role since 1868. After the annexation of Alsace in 1870, the line was rerouted around German territories to maintain the Franco-Swiss connection without passing through Mulhouse.

activities.text: Cross the border on foot or by bike to Boncourt. Explore the Swiss canton of Jura: Porrentruy lies 15 km away with its medieval old town and castle.

The Malsaucy leisure base (30 minutes from Delle) offers sailing, kayaking, and stand-up paddleboarding from April to October. A free 6,000 m² supervised beach opens from June to August. The Eurockéennes festival draws 100,000 spectators in early July.

days_plan.itin_title: Territoire de Belfort Road Trip: The Citadel and the Lion

visits.text: Admire these exceptional 3rd-century ramparts, witnesses to the grandeur of Dea Augusta Vocontiorum. These fortifications extend nearly 2 kilometers with a thickness of 3.6 meters and rise up to 14 meters high. The Saint-Marcel Gate, the only Roman monument still standing in the department, ranks among France's best-preserved.

Visit this listed cathedral built between the 12th and 13th centuries atop the vestiges of an ancient Roman temple. The building blends Romanesque and Gothic architecture. The remarkable 12th-century Romanesque portal ranks among the finest in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region.

Discover an exceptional treasure in this chapel of the former episcopal palace: the 12th-century Romanesque mosaic of the Four Rivers. This unique altar carpet in France offers a symbolic representation of the universe according to medieval cosmogony.

Housed in an 18th-century mansion, the municipal museum designated a Museum of France holds archaeological collections dating back to the Neolithic. The Gallo-Roman period shines through tauroboic altars listed as Historical Monuments.

activities.text: Head to the cellars to taste the famous Clairette de Die, France's first sparkling wine to receive PDO status in 1942. This naturally effervescent wine is crafted using the ancestral Diois method dating back to Gallo-Roman times. The Jaillance Cooperative Cellar, founded in 1950, brings together over 240 winemakers.

Wander through the medieval cobbled streets of the historic center with its colorful old houses. Admire the Protestant temple housed in a former 18th-century Jesuit chapel. Enjoy the Wednesday and Saturday morning markets to discover Clairette, Picodon PDO, and local products.

A few kilometers from Die, visit the Notre-Dame de Valcroissant Abbey, a listed monument founded in the late 12th century. Though partially ruined, it still presents a cloister surrounded by an abbey church in a preserved natural setting testifying to over 800 years of history.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir

visits.text: Dieppe Castle — This 15th-century fortress perched on a cliff houses a museum exhibiting one of France's finest collections of carved ivories. Dieppe was Europe's main ivory working center in the 17th and 18th centuries.

Saint-Jacques Church — This 13th-16th century church mixes Gothic and Renaissance styles. Its sculpted frieze representing a procession of Brazilian Indians commemorates the 1520 expedition that brought exotic wood from Brazil to Dieppe.

Puits Salé Square — This central square lined with cafes hosts Saturday morning's famous fish market where fishermen sell their catch directly. An authentic and lively place appreciated by Dieppe residents and visitors.

activities.text: Dieppe Beach — This kilometer-long pebble beach is France's oldest seaside resort. The 1930s seafront promenade, Belle Époque villas and beach cabins bear witness to 400 years of bathing history. Kite flying is a local tradition.

Pollet District — This former fishermen's district clinging to the cliff preserves narrow cobbled alleys and sailors' houses. The stairs climbing to the castle offer changing perspectives on the port and the English Channel.

August 19, 1942 Memorial — This museum commemorates the Dieppe Raid when 6,000 Allied soldiers, mainly Canadians, attempted a landing. Photographs, testimonies and objects evoke this tragic episode that cost 3,600 lives.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Maritime Road Trip: Cliffs of Étretat, Rouen and Jumièges Abbey

visits.text: Stroll down the pedestrian shopping street running from the Protestant temple to the clock tower. Designated a City of Art and Crafts, Dieulefit concentrates workshops, boutiques, museums, and galleries. The village sits beside the Jabron River. The riverside house façades have been repainted in pastel tones creating a colorful, joyful atmosphere.

Discover the 40 pottery and ceramics workshops, heirs to a 2,000-year tradition. Dieulefit's pottery history begins in Gallo-Roman times thanks to clay renowned for its qualities. Today, the Dieulefit region perpetuates this tradition with a revival of contemporary production. Enter galleries to admire original creations bearing the Dieulefit Original label.

Visit this cultural center created in 1995 in Baume Park that presents the region's pottery history. The museum space displays over 200 pieces illustrating local production evolution, particularly the great 19th-century era. Discover pottery's various uses through the ages and manufacturing techniques employed.

Spend the morning completing your artisan souvenir shopping in village boutiques. Utilitarian or decorative pottery, unique pieces created by local ceramists stamped with the Dieulefit Original label, local products like Picodon PDO, lavender honey, and essential oils.

activities.text: Get hands-on during a pottery initiation workshop offered by the House of Ceramics or a local potter. Discover coiling, slab building, modeling, and throwing. You can create your own unique piece guided by passionate artisans.

Tour the workshop circuit open to the public in downtown and surroundings. Engage with artisans in their workspaces, observe shaping techniques, discover kilns and various firing methods. Each artisan has developed their own style and specialty.

Enjoy the orienteering sport space set up by the department to discover the old village in a fun family way. The goal is to find wooden markers shown on the map. Three routes of varying difficulty exist. Cool off along the Jabron's banks, whose source lies in neighboring Comps.

Savor one last stroll through Dieulefit's colorful alleys, enjoy a café terrace along the Jabron's banks, soak in the peaceful atmosphere of this artists' village nestled in Drôme Provençale. If departing on Sunday, enjoy the small local market.

Hit the road home carrying memories of this magnificent journey through Drôme Provençale. From Roman ramparts to lavender fields, from medieval villages to sun-drenched olive groves, you've discovered this region's exceptional terroir and heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir
Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir

visits.text: The Geological Reserve of Haute-Provence reveals its fossil treasures. Marine imprints emerge from limestone rock, witnesses of a vanished ocean 300 million years ago. The geological trail leads you through ammonite slabs and fossilized ichthyosaurs.

The Gassendi Museum combines contemporary art and natural sciences in an unexpected dialogue. Naturalist collections sit alongside installations by resident artists. Zenith light floods the main gallery where Andy Goldsworthy's works and geological specimens interact.

Discover the limestone rock that rises above Digne-les-Bains like a stone ship. Steep trails lead to the summit where views embrace the spa town and surrounding valleys. The perched chapel has watched over the city since the Middle Ages.

The Digne Thermes have been exploiting sulfurous waters gushing at 42°C since 1930. The spa offers treatments and balneotherapy in a preserved Art Deco setting. The thermal gardens provide a relaxing haven in the shade of century-old plane trees.

The old town displays its ochre facades and shaded squares. Stroll through medieval alleys where fountains murmur their freshness. Boulevard Gassendi brings the city center to life with its Provençal craft shops and welcoming terraces.

activities.text: The Train des Pignes winds from Digne to Nice through the pre-Alps. The historic route uses vertiginous tunnels and viaducts. Landscapes shift from olive trees to fir trees, offering a unique railway spectacle in Provence.
Digne-les-Bains is the ideal starting point to explore the Verdon gorges. Scenic roads lead toward Castellane and the canyon entrances. Plan a full day for this memorable excursion.
Hiking trails crisscross the surrounding hills. Mont Saint-Pancrace offers a moderate ascent rewarded by a 360-degree panorama. Oaks and Aleppo pines punctuate the routes with their welcome shade.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages

visits.text: Route des Grands Crus between Beaune and Dijon: panoramic stops
Heritage stop at Château de Pommard (exteriors and vineyard)
Cassisium (Nuits-Saint-Georges): blackcurrant museum space
Dijon: Palace of the Dukes and Place de la Libération
Historic center tour of Dijon: half-timbered houses and churches

activities.text: Owl Trail (self-guided) in Dijon

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul

visits.text: The ramparts of Dinan stretch 2,650 m - the longest in Brittany. Ten towers punctuate the wall: Beaumanoir, Vaucouleurs, Saint-Julien, Beaufort, du Connétable, de Coëtquen, Penthièvre, Longue, Sainte-Catherine, and the Jerzual gate.

The Clock Tower rises 43 m high. Erected in the 15th century by Dinan's bourgeoisie to rival the clergy, it houses a 1498 clockwork mechanism, one of the oldest in Europe. Count 158 steps for the panorama.
Walk down Rue du Jerzual, steep at 35% in places, lined with 15th-17th century half-timbered houses. Glassblowers, wood gilders, and painters occupy workshop-boutiques.

The Saint-Sauveur basilica blends Romanesque, Gothic, Classical, and Baroque styles. Its Romanesque portal deserves a stop. Inside rests the heart of Bertrand du Guesclin, Constable of France who died in 1380.
Place des Merciers and Place des Cordeliers display the most beautiful half-timbered facades in the city. Wooden pillars support overhanging upper floors, typical of the 15th century.
The 14th-century castle, built by Duke John IV upon his return from exile in 1368, has a 34 m keep. It now houses a local history museum.

activities.text: Descend Rue du Jerzual then Rue du Petit Fort to the port of Dinan on the Rance. The climb back is steep but the port is worth the detour: pleasure boats, waterside terraces, and an old arched bridge.
From the port, the bike path follows the Rance southward. On foot, the riverbanks offer a peaceful walk away from the medieval center's crowds.

The English Garden, laid out in 1852 on the former parish cemetery, adjoins the Saint-Sauveur basilica. Continue to the Sainte-Catherine tower for a plunging view over the Rance and the port, 75 m below.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Disneyland Park, opened in 1992, centers around Sleeping Beauty Castle. Five themed lands recreate worlds ranging from the Victorian Wild West to science fiction, with attractions for all ages.
Walt Disney Studios Park plunges into the backstage of cinema and animation. Immersive attractions recreate large-scale movie sets.

activities.text: Disney Village, a free-access zone between the two parks, offers restaurants, shops, and evening shows. The atmosphere comes alive especially after the parks close.
The nighttime spectaculars project onto Sleeping Beauty Castle a show blending fireworks, fountains, lasers, and video projections.

days_plan.itin_title: Jura Mountains Road Trip, France: Comtois Traditions & Emerald Lakes

visits.text: The ruins of Domfront Castle rise on a sandstone spur at 692 feet. The 12th-century keep, 82 feet tall, the shell keep, and the curtain walls testify to a stronghold that controlled routes to Mont-Saint-Michel, Maine, and Brittany. Dismantled in 1610 by order of Sully.

At the fortress's foot, the Church of Notre-Dame-sur-l'Eau is a jewel of Norman Romanesque art, dating to the late 11th century. Its choir welcomed illustrious guests: Louis IX and Louis XI on pilgrimage, Thomas Becket, and Henri II Plantagenet, who baptized his daughter here in 1162.

The Church of Saint-Julien, built in 1924–1926, is a unique structure: reinforced concrete, square plan, and neo-Byzantine decoration. Its mosaics in geometric gold-and-blue forms, by Gaudin, create a striking atmosphere. Listed as a historic monument in 1993.

Roam the cobbled lanes of the medieval town, one of the few in Orne to preserve its medieval urban plan. Covered passageways, interior courtyards, half-timbered houses, and townhouses follow one after another.
The 11 towers and gates of the old town punctuate the Rue des Fossés Pusson. These remnants of the ramparts frame a preserved medieval urban fabric.

activities.text: From the Place du Panorama and the castle's orientation table, views extend from the Maine landscapes to the borders of Brittany. The Domfront bocage spreads below, dotted with centuries-old pear trees.
Domfront is the capital of poiré, a fermented pear drink with AOP status. Visit a producer to discover Domfront calvados as well, which blends pears and apples—a unique particularity.
Domfront sits at the crossroads of the Vélo Francette (Ouistreham–La Rochelle) and the Véloscénie (Paris–Mont-Saint-Michel). Ride a section through Norman bocage.
The Medieval Festival of Domfront, held every two years, plunges the town into the fervor of the 12th century: shows, activities, and historical reenactments.

days_plan.itin_title: Orne Road Trip: Norman Bocage and Prestigious Stud Farms

visits.text: Domme is a royal bastide founded in 1281 by Philip III the Bold, perched 150 meters above the Dordogne on a rocky promontory. Unlike the checkerboard layout typical of bastides, Domme's trapezoidal plan adapts ingeniously to the clifftop terrain. The Porte des Tours—a gateway flanked by two massive towers—preserves enigmatic graffiti carved between 1307 and 1318.

The graffiti inside the Porte des Tours have long been attributed to Knights Templar imprisoned here after Philip the Fair dissolved the order in 1307. Crosses, human figures, and mysterious symbols cover the stone walls. Historians continue to debate whether these carvings are truly Templar—or the work of other prisoners—but the mystery endures.

Domme Cave, accessible directly from the central market square, is the largest developed cave in Périgord Noir. Its 450 meters of galleries are adorned with stalactites, stalagmites, and flowing draperies. The exit is through a panoramic elevator carved into the cliff, emerging at the belvedere with stunning views across the valley.

activities.text: The Belvedere de la Barre offers one of the finest panoramas in all of Périgord: a sweeping 180-degree view over the Dordogne Valley, the villages of La Roque-Gageac and Beynac, and the castles of Castelnaud and Marqueyssac. The esplanade sits right at the cliff edge—bring your camera.

Domme's market convenes Thursday morning at Place de la Halle, where local producers sell foie gras, walnuts, seasonal truffles, and Domme wine. The vineyard, replanted in 1990 after phylloxera devastated it a century earlier, now produces wine again—a small triumph of agricultural revival.

days_plan.itin_title: Dordogne Road Trip: Cave Art, Medieval Fortresses & Périgord Delights

visits.text: Visit to the Basilica of Bois-Chenu, dedicated to Joan of Arc

Joan of Arc's birthplace, a listed Historic Monument and Maison des Illustres, presents four rooms including the girl's bedroom. On the façade, a sculpted tympanum with 15th-century coat of arms remains.

The "Visages de Jehanne" center extends the visit: permanent exhibition, audiovisual scenography, "Chamber of Kings" reconstructing the small theater of the Hundred Years' War. A film traces Joan's childhood, her epic and her trials.

Climb the Bois-Chenu hillside. The Basilica of Sainte-Jeanne d'Arc (1881-1926) stands where Joan is said to have heard her voices. Stained glass from Chartres workshops, gilded mosaics and a cycle of paintings trace her life.
Begin with the crypt Notre-Dame des Armées, opened in 1891. The Stairway of Peace, adorned with coats of arms from cities marked by the epic, leads to the upper church.
The parish church of Saint-Rémy, Joan's baptismal site, preserves baptismal fonts and a 15th-century statue of Saint Margaret. Modern stained glass completes the Johannine narrative.

activities.text: Walk on the heights overlooking the Meuse valley
Follow the "In Joan's Footsteps" themed trail between the village and the basilica. The path crosses meadows and woods above the Meuse valley.
From the basilica forecourt, the panorama embraces the Meuse valley and wooded hills. Statues of Joan and her parents punctuate the esplanade.

The second Sunday in May, the Joan of Arc festival animates the village: procession, wreath-laying and historical performance. In June-July, a sound and light show takes place on the basilica forecourt.

days_plan.itin_title: Finistère, Brittany Road Trip: Breton Headlands, Ponant Islands & Coastal Heritage

visits.text: Completed in 1222 by King Philip Augustus, Dourdan Castle stands as one of the rare 13th-century fortresses in Île-de-France that has retained its original structures: keep, towers, and dry moats.
Climb the 36-meter circular keep for a sweeping 360° view over the town and surrounding forest. The ramparts offer a fascinating perspective on this Capetian defensive masterpiece.
The municipal museum occupies the former salt storehouse. Interactive models, digital tablets, and films trace the castle's evolution from royal residence to prison.
The Church of Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois dates from the 12th and 13th centuries. Its Gothic architecture reflects Dourdan's importance as a royal residence.
Houses built from sandstone cobbles and decorative rockwork surround the castle. The historic center has preserved its medieval character remarkably well.

activities.text: The Dourdan State Forest stretches across thousands of hectares. Once a royal hunting preserve, it now offers countless marked hiking trails through ancient woodlands.
Follow the Fontaines Bouillantes circuit along the Orge River. These three ponds, created in the 1950s, form a bucolic landscape between town and forest.
The Haute Vallée de Chevreuse Regional Nature Park begins at Dourdan's doorstep. Perfect for cycling and nature walks through protected countryside.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: Saint-Benoît d'En Calcat Abbey, founded in 1890, gathers some forty Benedictine monks. The abbey church, open to all, bathes in light filtered through colored stained glass reflecting on stone columns.

1,200 meters away, Sainte-Scholastique Abbey has welcomed a community of Benedictine nuns since 1890. Fraternal life, prayer, and work form the pillars of their daily routine, shared with passing visitors.

Head to Sorèze, a few kilometers away. The Abbey-school, a former royal college founded in the 8th century, now houses the museum devoted to contemporary tapestries by the monk-artist, a major figure in 20th-century textile art.
In Dourgne village, a small church shelters the only mural painting created by this same artist-monk, along with seven stained-glass windows dated 1957. A discreet but touching detour.
Explore downtown Dourgne, a small nature town at the foot of Montagne Noire. Its stone and brick houses, fountains, and preserved atmosphere make it a peaceful stop between two abbeys.

activities.text: Attend a sung service at En Calcat Abbey. The liturgy, celebrated in French with Gregorian passages, is open to the public. Chants resonate beneath the abbey church's vaults.
Browse the Siloë-Saint Benoît bookstore at the abbey. You'll find religious works, tapestry reproductions, art cards, balms, and craft products made by the monks.
Hike the Montagne Noire trails starting from Dourgne. Paths cross beech and oak forests, with open views over the Lauragais hills and Toulouse plain.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn Road Trip: Albi & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: The Clock Tower, rebuilt in 1662 and classified as a historic monument, rises on the town's central rock. Its 79 steps lead to a campanile offering a panoramic view over the Dracénie landscape. The monument stands 24 meters tall.

The Dolmen de la Pierre de la Fée, dating from 2,500 BCE, is one of Provence's most imposing: 60 tons, three slabs over 2 meters supporting a 6-meter-long table. Classified as a historic monument since 1889, it leans against a centuries-old oak—prehistoric monumentality.

The Museum of Popular Arts and Traditions of Middle Provence, labeled Musée de France, holds one of the country's finest ethnographic collections. Exhibitions are built in partnership with the world's greatest museums—local heritage meets international scholarship.

The Museum of Fine Arts, located in the heart of the historic center, displays a collection of artworks and historical artifacts, including the ceremonial armor of François de Montmorency, restored by the Research Center of the Museums of France.
The Rhône American Cemetery and Memorial, established in August 1944, gathers the graves of 861 soldiers who died during the reconquest of southern France. A sober and moving place of remembrance.

activities.text: In Trans-en-Provence, 12 km north, cross the 70-meter footbridge spanning the Nartuby gorges. In summer, swimming is possible in the natural pools—a local secret of cool waters and canyon beauty.
Climb to the Malmont orientation table for a 360° panorama over the region. The trail starts from downtown and winds between garrigue and pine forest—a walk that rewards with sweeping vistas.

Wander the medieval lanes of the old town, between the ancient houses of the Maison de la Reine Jeanne and Saint-Hermentaire chapel. Parc Chabran, with its century-old trees, invites relaxation in the shade.

days_plan.itin_title: Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: The Drancy Shoah Memorial, opened in 2012, faces the Cité de la Muette. Video testimonies, archival documents, and period photographs trace the history of France's main internment and transit camp for Jews between 1941 and 1944.

The Cité de la Muette, built in the 1930s by Beaudoin, Lods, and Bodianski, represented the avant-garde of collective housing with its fourteen-story towers, France's tallest at the time. Requisitioned by the Nazis, it became a gathering camp from which 63,000 people departed for the extermination camps. It has been a protected historic site since 2001.

In front of the housing project, Shelomo Selinger's deportees' monument consists of three 3-meter blocks of pink granite forming the Hebrew letter Shin. The central block depicts ten figures gripped by flames.

The witness wagon, inaugurated in 1988 and protected as a historic monument, is connected to the memorial by rails. It is identical to those that transported thousands of deportees to the camps in Poland.

activities.text: Every Sunday at 3 PM, a free guided tour of the Memorial is offered. It includes the permanent exhibition and an outdoor route facing the Cité de la Muette.
Take a break at Parc de Ladoumègue, a 7-hectare green space with playgrounds, sports fields, and shaded paths.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: Royal Chapel of Saint-Louis in Dreux, necropolis of the Orléans family since the 19th century. This masterpiece of neo-Gothic architecture houses about fifty burials including that of Louis-Philippe, the last King of the French. The stained glass windows from the Sèvres Manufactory, signed by Ingres and Delacroix, are exceptionally beautiful.

Sculpted tomb effigies of the royal chapel, a veritable museum of 19th-century sculpture. Admire particularly the tomb of Sophie-Charlotte of Bavaria, sister of Empress Sissi, who died tragically in the Bazar de la Charité fire in 1897. Her effigy by Walhain depicts burning pieces of wood.

Remains of Dreux's medieval castle on the former domain of the counts. The defensive wall flanked by towers and the 13th-century Grey Tower bear witness to over a thousand years of history at the borders of Normandy and the Loire Valley.

Dreux belfry, symbol of medieval communal power. This 15th-century square tower, topped with a Renaissance campanile, offers a panorama over the city and the royal estate parks. A testament to the city's commercial importance in the Middle Ages.

activities.text: Stroll through the parks of Dreux's royal estate, laid out in the 19th century in the English landscape garden style. These 6-hectare spaces feature remarkable tree species and offer panoramic views over the city from the heights of the former fortress.

Tour of Dreux's historic center with its half-timbered houses and the 16th-century Saint-Pierre church. The Art and History Museum presents archaeological and artistic collections tracing the history of this royal city.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure-et-Loir Circuit: Chartres, Châteaux & Proust

visits.text: Dun-sur-Auron's belfry is the town's pride. Built in the 15th century, 32 meters high, it dominates the valley. Climb the 120 steps to the top for a panorama of the bocage and Berry Canal. The belfry also houses a small museum on the town's history and the role of belfries in the Middle Ages.

The Saint-Étienne Church (12th-15th centuries) mixes Romanesque and Gothic. Beautifully sculpted portal, nave with broken-barrel vault, 16th-century stained glass. Inside, a remarkable Tree of Jesse and a 14th-century fresco depicting Saint Christopher.

The Berry Canal runs through Dun. Dug between 1830 and 1841, it connected the Cher to the Allier over 261 km with 52 locks. Commercial navigation ceased in 1955; today the canal is used for pleasure boating. Towpath maintained, locks restored. A peaceful walk along the water.

activities.text: Dun-sur-Auron sits at the edge of Tronçais Forest, one of Europe's most beautiful oak forests. 11,000 hectares of centuries-old oaks, some over 300 years old. The Stebbing, Sentinelle and Carré Renard oaks are local celebrities. Numerous marked trails, picnic areas. The forest supplied timber for the Navy under Colbert; today it's managed for quality cabinetmaking wood.
The Auron meanders through the town. Pleasant banks, washhouses, old mills. A 3 km loop follows the river and returns via the old town. You might spot ducks, moorhens, sometimes a heron.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: Climb Dun-Haut hill (81 m above the town), an ancient Gallic oppidum then Roman castrum. Notre-Dame de Bonne Garde church, built in 1346 by the lords of Apremont, is the only surviving monument from the old fortress. This Gothic jewel possesses a sumptuous 18th-century organ case and furnishings.

Inside the church, two monumental sculptures by contemporary artist Ipoustéguy, native of Dun-sur-Meuse, surprise with their expressionism: Death of Bishop Neumann (1976) and a tormented Christ. The church is part of the European "Open Churches" network.

Walk through remnants of ramparts built from the 10th century. A round tower and a square tower survive, along with the 1402 Porte des Chevaux. From the church square, the view plunges over the Meuse valley, the river's meanders, and surrounding fields.

In the lower town at Doulcon, the Ipoustéguy cultural center exhibits marbles and bronzes by this sculptor who won the Bright Award at the Venice Biennale in 1964 and installed a monumental bronze on the Berlin Congress Palace forecourt in 1978.
Five kilometers away, Mont-devant-Sassey's 12th-century Romanesque church stands beside the Meuse in a majestic setting. Its young heritage ambassadors offer passionate summer tours.

activities.text: Follow the Dun-le-Chastel ramparts circuit, a one-hour pedestrian walk punctuated with explanatory panels between archaeology, heritage, and gardens. Medieval remains blend with valley panoramas.
The "Old Meuse and Green Lake" green circuit winds along ponds and the old Meuse. The Natura 2000 classified zone shelters remarkable fauna and flora, between gray herons and water lilies.
Lake Dun offers supervised summer swimming and daily boat rentals. The marina allows peaceful navigation on the water body.

days_plan.itin_title: Meuse Circuit: Verdun and the Citadels

visits.text: The Château des Ducs de Duras commands the Dropt valley. This 12th-century fortress remodeled in the 18th century unfolds 35 rooms, with terraces offering exceptional panoramas.
Discover the Hall of the Three Marshals, the kitchen with its hundred faggots, and the bakery. The Durfort family—illustrious musketeers—held court here until the 19th century.
The Maison des Vins offers an educational journey through the vineyard. The vine garden designed by Cap Sciences explains local viticulture.
Explore the old town's cobbled lanes. Stone houses testify to the town's rich winemaking heritage.

activities.text: Taste Côtes de Duras wines at the Maison des Vins. Reds, dry whites, rosés, and sweet wines reveal a 1,230-hectare terroir.
Visit surrounding wine cellars. Winemakers welcome visitors for guided tastings and cellar tours.
Browse the Monday morning market. Local producers and Duras wines animate the stalls.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: Écouen — Musée national de la Renaissance in Château d’Écouen, a 16th‑century palace with tapestries (including the famous David & Bathsheba) and decorative arts.
Parc du Château — Formal terraces and hunting forest perspectives typical of the French Renaissance.

activities.text: Guided focus on enamels and maiolica rooms (check museum schedules; closed Tuesdays).
Sunset viewpoint over the Plaine de France from the château steps.

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

High esplanades — views over the Berre lagoon and the Trévaresse chain.

activities.text: Heritage walk in the old center (cobbled streets, passages).
Scrubland paths on the edge of olive groves.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Concentric rings of ramparts around the central square and fountain.
Half-timbered houses clustered along circular streets.
Remains of towers and access gates.
Eguisheim's octagonal castle stands at the heart of Place Saint-Léon. Founded in 720 by Count Eberhard, it witnessed the birth of the future Pope Leo IX in 1002.
The octagonal fountain in Place Saint-Léon is Alsace's largest in this shape. Pope Leo IX's statue rises above the Renaissance basin, presiding over the village center.
Saint Peter and Saint Paul Church blends Romanesque transept with Gothic nave. Its square bell tower in yellow sandstone marks the village entrance.
Follow Rue du Rempart Sud as it traces the medieval moat. A hexagonal stone dovecote marks where the fortification circuit begins its loop around the village.
Half-timbered winegrowers' houses spiral outward in concentric circles. Their ochre, rose, and butter-yellow facades jut forward in overhangs above the cobblestones.
Eguisheim Christmas Market
Decorated medieval streets and village squares

Eguisheim nestles in concentric rings around its 13th-century octagonal castle. The circular plan, unique in Alsace, reveals itself with every step: curved alleys draw perfect circles around the central keep.
On the central square, the Renaissance fountain bears the statue of Pope Leo IX, born here in 1002. This son of Eguisheim became one of the most important reforming popes of the 11th century.
The chapel of Saint-Léon IX, inside the castle, preserves a 12th-century Romanesque portal and ancient frescoes. 14th-century opening Virgin in the treasury.
The half-timbered façades of the circular streets vie for floral displays: geraniums, petunias and Virginia creeper cover the walls. Eguisheim was voted "France's Favorite Village" in 2013.
Saints-Pierre-et-Paul church houses a polychrome Romanesque tympanum depicting Christ between Saint Peter and Saint Paul, and a Virgin and Child called the Opening Virgin.

activities.text: Complete circular route of the inner ramparts (2–3 km).
Vineyard path towards the sandstone hills (3–4 km).
The Eichberg Grand Cru wine trail climbs through south-facing limestone slopes. Riesling and Gewurztraminer vines have thrived on these renowned hillsides since Roman times.
The Stork Park at the village edge shelters several nests. Every spring, storks return to nest on rooftops and specially prepared platforms.
Push open a winemaker's cellar door to taste all seven Alsatian grape varieties. More than 30 winegrowers carry on Eguisheim's centuries-old viticultural tradition.
Attend seasonal performances and traditional displays
Walk around the village through the concentric alleys: each ring reveals interior courtyards, fountains and vaulted passages. A camera is essential.
Eguisheim is surrounded by three Grand Crus: Eichberg, Pfersigberg and Florimont. Winemakers offer tastings of Gewurztraminer, Riesling and Pinot Gris in the main street cellars.
Climb to the Three Castles of Eguisheim (Weckmund, Wahlenbourg, Dagsbourg) perched on the hill above the village. The panorama embraces the Alsace plain to the Black Forest.
In December, Eguisheim's Christmas market dresses the medieval alleys with lights and spice scents. Chalets set up around the Castle Square.

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages
Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route
The Ultimate Guide to Alsace Christmas Markets: Enchanted Winter Villages Itinerary
Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: The Cathedral of Saint Eulalia and Saint Julia has dominated the town since the 11th century. A major monument of Catalan Romanesque art, it served as the bishopric seat from the 6th to 17th century. Blue marble portal and barrel-vaulted nave.

The white marble cloister veined with blue was built from the 12th to 14th century. Listed as a historical monument in 1840, it displays the evolution of medieval Roussillon sculpture between Romanesque and Gothic.
The Terrus Museum celebrates Étienne Terrus, a painter born in Elne in 1857. Friend of Matisse, Maillol, and Derain, he captured Roussillon landscapes in watercolor. Over 100 works on display.
The archaeology museum in the Saint-Laurent chapel presents artifacts from the Neolithic to the Middle Ages. Three 6th-century Visigothic marble sarcophagi adorn the east gallery.
The Swiss Maternity Hospital, built in 1901, sheltered children of all nationalities between 1939 and 1944. A historical monument bearing witness to solidarity and hope.

activities.text: Stroll from the Porte Balaguer. Panoramas embrace the surrounding mountains and Canigou, the Catalans' sacred peak.
Wander through the old town's maze. Glassblowers, art restorers, and galleries perpetuate the artistic tradition.
Visit the Garden of Arts and Crafts. Catalan artists and local artisans open their workshops: ceramics, chocolate making, rousquilles pastries.
Enjoy the market three times a week. Produce from vineyards and orchards recall Elne's agricultural heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: Highest commune in Europe.
Traditional village.

activities.text: Hike in one of the most beautiful valleys of the Alps.
Water sports.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Alpes Majesty: High Mountain Passes, Ski Resorts & Alpine Valleys

visits.text: Enghien‑les‑Bains — Lakeside spa architecture; casino façade and Belle‑Époque bandstand on the boardwalk.
Spa heritage museum (if open) and lakeshore villas; eclectic styles from 1850–1930.

activities.text: Pedal a lakeside boat (spring–summer rentals until 18:00); quiet morning waters are best.

visits.text: Entraygues comes from the Occitan entraigas meaning between the waters. The Lot and the Truyère rivers meet here at an altitude of 219 metres. Two 13th-century Gothic bridges connect the banks near the medieval castle.

The historic centre retains half-timbered houses from the 15th and 16th centuries. The cantous are small covered passageways running beneath the houses. Some façades still shelter craftsmen's workshops.

The Entraygues-Le Fel vineyard covers 20 hectares of terraces between schist and granite. Five winemakers carry on a winemaking tradition dating back to the Roman occupation. The AOC was granted in 2011, following the VDQS classification of 1965.

activities.text: The Espace EDF Truyère occupies the former control room of the Couesques dam power station. This 600 m² educational trail explains how hydroelectricity works and the industrial adventure built around water.

The Calvaire viewpoint offers a panorama of the confluence of the Lot and the Truyère. Head towards Aurillac, cross the Cambeyrac dam and stop after a hairpin bend. A 5-minute path leads to the viewpoint marked by a large cross.

visits.text: The Avenue de Champagne unfolds like a grand procession of 19th-century mansions. This UNESCO-listed street conceals 110 kilometers of cellars beneath your feet.
The Moët & Chandon cellars stretch for 28 kilometers underground. In the courtyard above, a bronze Dom Pérignon keeps eternal watch.
Board a miniature train to explore the Mercier cellars 30 meters below ground. The giant oak barrel built for the 1889 World's Fair holds the equivalent of 200,000 bottles.
The De Castellane tower has dominated Épernay's skyline since 1905. Climb its 237 steps for sweeping views across the champagne vineyards.

activities.text: Stroll the Avenue de Champagne at your leisure. Each mansion facade tells stories of the champagne trade's golden age.
Drive through the UNESCO-listed slopes above the Marne Valley. Vines cascade down the chalky hillsides in geometric precision.

visits.text: The Jean-Jacques Rousseau Park unfolds across 62 hectares created between 1763 and 1775 by the Marquis de Girardin. As continental Europe's first landscape garden, it drew inspiration from Rousseau's novel La Nouvelle Héloïse.

The Isle of Poplars holds Jean-Jacques Rousseau's cenotaph, who died here in 1778. Before his remains were transferred to the Panthéon in 1794, this tomb became a pilgrimage site for Romantic souls across Europe.

The Temple of Philosophy raises its deliberately unfinished columns dedicated to Newton, Descartes, Voltaire, Rousseau, Montesquieu, and William Penn. This rotunda symbolizes the perpetual progress of human thought.
The Royal Abbey of Chaalis preserves its 13th-century Cistercian ruins and 16th-century frescoes. The Jacquemart-André collections and Rousseau's autograph manuscripts enrich the visit.
The Forest of Ermenonville spreads across 3,300 hectares of Scots pine and sandstone chaos. The Witch's Stone and Bruyères du Frais Vent emerge mysteriously among the trees.

activities.text: Follow the Writers' Path for three kilometers between the Rousseau Park and Chaalis Abbey. This trail crosses the Launette valley in the footsteps of Rousseau, Senancour, and Nerval.

days_plan.itin_title: Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: The Château of the Barons of Ezpeleta has dominated the village since the year 1000. Now serving as the town hall, it houses an exhibition about Espelette pepper, which earned its AOC status in 2000.
The Église Saint-Étienne features a 16th-century portal considered among the finest in the Basque Country. Its fortified bell tower-keep and baroque altarpiece are architectural treasures.
Visit the ETXEA interpretation center that traces the pepper's history since the 16th century. Originally from South America, it replaced costly black pepper in Basque cuisine.
Wander through whitewashed lanes with red shutters. From September to November, scarlet pepper strings dry on house facades in brilliant cascades of color.

activities.text: The Tuesday morning market buzzes from 8am with Ossau-Iraty sheep cheese, Basque cake, and charcuterie filling the stalls around the main square.
Hike to Mondarrain summit at 750 meters. From the top, views sweep from the Atlantic coast to the Pyrenean chain, with vultures wheeling overhead.

days_plan.itin_title: Haunted Flanders Tour: Northern France's Castles, Legends & Dark History

visits.text: Nestled in the Côte des Bar vineyards, Essoyes lives in the memory of Pierre-Auguste Renoir. The Centre Culturel Du Côté des Renoir — housed in the former castle stables overlooking the Ource river — begins the story: 20-minute film, permanent exhibition on the family saga (Pierre the actor, Jean the filmmaker, Claude the ceramist), temporary exhibition hall. For thirty summers (1888-1919), the Impressionist master found here incomparable light, generous models and peaceful life far from Parisian turmoil.

The family home acquired in 1896 reveals the Renoirs' intimacy: period furniture, wallpaper restored to match the originals, everyday objects frozen as if the family just stepped out. The garden path leads to the 1906 Studio — built at the back of the property to not disturb the children's games. Under the exposed beams bathed in skylight: easel, brushes, wheelchair (Renoir painted despite hands deformed by gout), transport trunk for Paris trips. Labeled Maison des Illustres, the house still breathes the painter's soul.

The Renoir Walking Trail connects the cultural center to the family cemetery passing by key locations. Aline Charigot's parents' house (who became Madame Renoir), the washhouse immortalized in Les Laveuses (The Washerwomen), the forge, the church where Renoir was married and buried, the Renoirs' graves in the municipal cemetery. Interpretation panels with reproductions guide visitors through the landscapes that inspired the master. Allow 1h30 for this immersive walk in the Renoir family's footsteps.

The Centre Culturel Renoir, on the town hall square, opens the tour. The permanent exhibition traces the life of the painter and his three sons: an actor, a filmmaker and a ceramist. A film completes the visit.
On rue de l'Extra, step through the door of the painter's studio. Easels, brushes and the wheelchair he used late in life remain in place. Upstairs, a rare film shows the artist at work.
The family house, acquired in 1896, was the painter's first property. Rooms restored in period style and a garden promenade planted with fruit trees extend the immersion into family intimacy.
The Saint-Rémi church, 19th-century neo-Gothic, presents a Latin cross nave, stained glass and an organ donated by a family of local philanthropists.
In the village cemetery rest the painter, his wife and their three sons. The choice of this final resting place speaks volumes about the family's attachment to Essoyes.

activities.text: Essoyes holds its Renoir Festival each year in early August: art exhibitions, classical music concerts, painting workshops, guided tours, literary meetings around the impressionist's work. The whole village becomes an open-air museum. Book accommodation early as hotels fill quickly. Special atmosphere blending art, local traditions and Champagne conviviality.

Champagne houses in Essoyes open their cellars to visitors: guided tour of vaults, explanation of winemaking methods, tasting of Côte des Bar champagnes. This southern Champagne region produces rounder, more full-bodied champagnes than those from Reims or Épernay. More Pinot Noir, less acidity, longer aging. Discovery appointment and wine purchase possible.
Follow the Renoir trail through the village: reproductions of famous paintings are displayed on façades, where the painter had set up his easel.
Descend to the quai de l'Ource, recently redeveloped. The river flows peacefully through the village between shaded banks—the very setting of several of the master's canvases.
The village lies at the heart of the Côte des Bar vineyard. Local cellars offer champagne tastings paired with the painter's universe.

days_plan.itin_title: Aube Circuit: Champagne, Medieval Heritage and Orient Forest Lakes
Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: Estaing Castle dates back to the 13th century with its octagonal keep surrounded by turrets. The d'Estaing family owned it for eight centuries before it was acquired by Valéry Giscard d'Estaing in 2005. The exhibition retraces the presidential term and the advances of his mandate.

François d'Estaing had the Gothic bridge built in the early 16th century. This UNESCO-listed structure is crossed each year by pilgrims heading to Santiago de Compostela. The wrought-iron cross in the middle is a symbol of Aveyron craftsmanship.

The 15th-century Church of Saint-Fleuret holds the relics of the Bishop of Clermont who died here in the 5th century. The saint is known for his miraculous healings. Grey-blue schist houses with lauze stone roofs line the narrow streets.

activities.text: The Maison de la Vigne, du Vin et des Paysages tells the story of the vineyard. The Vignerons d'Olt cultivate 20 hectares that earned the AOC Estaing designation in 2011. The wine was once shipped throughout Europe via the Lot river.

The Saint-Fleuret procession takes place on the first Sunday of July. Locals wear costumes representing saints, angels, and members of the d'Estaing family. This historical and religious re-enactment brings the whole village to life.

days_plan.itin_title: Aveyron Road Trip: Causses, Tarn Gorges and Villages

visits.text: The Church of Saint-Basile dates from the 12th century. Its imposing bell tower and stained glass windows make it a jewel of Étampes Gothic architecture.
The Guinette Tower rises 27 meters from its plateau. This unique quatrefoil keep from the 12th century, built by Louis VII, served as Queen Ingeburge's prison from 1201 to 1213.
Climb to the tower's summit for panoramic views over Étampes and its four Gothic churches. The valleys of the Juine, Louette, and Chalouette rivers stretch out below.
The Church of Notre-Dame du Fort features a twisted spire that leans like the Tower of Pisa. A fascinating example of medieval Gothic architecture gone slightly askew.
The Chapel of Saint-Blaise, decorated by Cocteau in Milly-la-Forêt, lies 20 km away. His frescoes of medicinal plants adorn the walls of this former leprosarium.

activities.text: The Dourdan Forest extends to the west. Once a royal hunting ground for French kings, it now offers well-marked hiking trails through centuries-old woodlands.
Follow the Orge Valley on the GR11 trail. Old washhouses and watermills dot this pastoral route through meadows and woods.
Fontainebleau Forest begins just 15 km to the east. Its climbing boulders and hiking paths attract outdoor enthusiasts year-round.

visits.text: Aval Cliff — This 80-meter-high chalk cliff carved by erosion forms a natural arch nicknamed "Elephant" for the shape of its pillar dipping into the sea. The Needle rising 70 meters inspired Arsène Lupin's hidden treasure in Maurice Leblanc's adventure novel.

Amont Cliff — This arch east of the beach is topped by the Notre-Dame-de-la-Garde chapel and a monument to aviators Nungesser and Coli who disappeared in 1927 attempting the first transatlantic crossing. The path offers dizzying views of the Manneporte.

Manneporte — This third monumental arch 30 meters high pierces the cliff west of the Aval. Accessible only at low tide via the beach, it reveals caves carved by the sea. Monet painted it several times between 1883 and 1886.

Étretat Gardens — These contemporary gardens perched on the cliff combine contemporary sculptures and plants from five continents. The walking path leads to a belvedere offering a 180° panorama from Le Havre to Fécamp.

Yport — This authentic fishing village nestled in a cliff valley preserves its traditional character with its thatched-roof fishermen's huts called "calets." The beach offers a view of Étretat's arches 4 kilometers away.

Fécamp Abbey Church — This 12th-century Benedictine abbey houses a relic of the Holy Blood brought back from the Crusades. Its 127-meter length makes it one of the longest churches in France. The Lady Chapel preserves Renaissance sculptures.

Bénédictine Palace — This neo-Gothic palace built in 1888 houses the distillery of the famous liqueur created by a Fécamp monk in 1510. The museum displays a collection of liturgical art and the recipe room reveals some of the 27 plants used.
Yport — valleuse, boats and white cabins.
Étretat — cliffs, arches & village (market hall, Belle Époque villas).
Jumièges Abbey — wander through the hauntingly beautiful ruins where Romanesque arches frame the sky
Étretat — stand beneath the soaring Aval and Amont chalk arches carved by endless waves
Étretat — photograph the needle-sharp Aiguille rising from the pebble beach at low tide

activities.text: Étretat Beach — This pebble beach framed by cliffs attracted Parisian high society in the 19th century. Beach cabins and Belle Époque villas lining the seafront perpetuate this bathing heritage. Swimming depends on tides and currents.

Clos Arsène Lupin — This villa where Maurice Leblanc lived from 1918 to 1939 has been transformed into a museum dedicated to the gentleman burglar. Period rooms, secret passages and scenographic installations bring the adventures to life.

GR21 Hiking Trail — This coastal path connecting Le Havre to Le Tréport runs along the cliff tops. The Étretat section offers spectacular views of the arches and the English Channel. Count 3 hours to reach Yport.

Cap Fagnet — This cliff rising 110 meters north of Fécamp offers a panorama of the Alabaster Coast. The sailors' chapel and the orientation table help identify Étretat, Saint-Valéry and the Normandy Bridge on clear days.

Fisheries Museum — Housed in a former cod-drying plant, this museum retraces Fécamp's great era when 80 trawlers sailed to Newfoundland banks. Models, tools and testimonies evoke the harsh life of cod fishermen.

Port of Fécamp — This fishing port, France's 4th largest, welcomes trawlers daily. The fish market in the early morning and the restaurants of the quays offer the day's catch: scallops, sole, turbot according to the season.
Cliff path (depending on weather & tide).
Clifftop hike — follow the GR® coastal trail toward the Aval Arch for breathtaking perspectives

Seine-Maritime Road Trip: Cliffs of Étretat, Rouen and Jumièges Abbey

Complete Normandy Road Trip: Dramatic Cliffs, D-Day Beaches & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Évaux-les-Bains, Limousin's only thermal spa town, traces its history to Antiquity. Around 50 BC, Caesar's legions were already exploiting the hot springs of Ivaonum, a name derived from Ivaos, Gallic divinity of waters. The remains of Gallo-Roman baths, classified as Historic Monuments as early as 1840, testify to this ancient occupation. The ancient capture system is still in use.

The Abbey Church of Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul, a masterpiece of Romanesque art, was built in the 11th century on the relics of Saint-Marien, hermit protector of the town. Its five-story bell tower-porch, covered with chestnut shingles, dominates the town. The interior surprises with its grandeur and sobriety. Partially destroyed by fire in 1942, it remains the pride of Evahoniens.

The modern thermal establishment, completely renovated in 2001, occupies an Art Deco building with red and white bricks in geometric patterns. The waters spring forth at 60°C and treat rheumatism and venous conditions. The 'Les Bains d'Evahona' spa, recently inaugurated, offers a hammam, sauna, jacuzzi, and outdoor thermal pool, the gentlest in France.

activities.text: The Rochers de Bord circuit, 6 kilometers from the tourist office, crosses a remarkable natural site. Allow two hours to discover the rock formations and enjoy an impressive view of the Tardes Viaduct, a metal structure built between 1882 and 1885 under the direction of Gustave Eiffel.

The thermal park, a green setting in the heart of the town, invites strolling. The century-old trees of the former convent and shaded alleys offer a restful setting between treatments or after a visit. The Grand Hôtel, a characteristic building of spa towns, overlooks the park.

days_plan.itin_title: Creuse Circuit: Valley of the Painters and Aubusson Tapestries

visits.text: Évian-les-Bains displays its spa resort elegance on Lake Geneva's shores. Mineral waters have sprung from the sources for centuries, attracting spa-goers and celebrities from around the world.
The Palais Lumière, former thermal baths converted to an exhibition center, sports its Belle Époque facade adorned with ceramics and Art Nouveau ironwork.
The Cachat spring flows freely in a kiosk where anyone can fill their bottle with this world-famous water.
The historic funicular has climbed Évian's heights since 1907. This rack railway links the lower town to residential neighborhoods overlooking the lake.
The Lumière Villa, former property of the cinema-inventing brothers, now houses the town hall. The gardens offer panoramic views of Lake Geneva.
Thonon-les-Bains lines up its viewpoints above the lake. The Chablais Museum at Sonnaz Castle dominates this exceptional panorama.
Ripaille Castle spreads its medieval towers in a 53-hectare park. Amédée VIII, first Duke of Savoy, retired here before becoming Pope Felix V.

Explore this spectacular natural amphitheater in the Sixt-Fer-à-Cheval nature reserve. The cirque forms a 4-5 kilometer horseshoe with 500-700 meter vertical walls. More than thirty waterfalls cascade from its cliffs—particularly dramatic in spring when snowmelt sends torrents plunging down the rock faces.

Visit the legendary spring discovered in 1789 that launched Évian's worldwide fame. The magnificent Art Nouveau Cachat Pavilion, built in 1905, crowns the site with its glazed tile dome. The water flows continuously at a constant 52.9°F (11.6°C)—the pure Alpine water that became an international icon.

Marvel at this sumptuous building constructed in 1902 as a thermal spa. The former spa transformed into a cultural center in 2007 still impresses with its Belle Époque architecture—especially the immense glass dome soaring more than 30 meters high, flooding the interior with Alpine light.

Discover the former summer residence of the Lumière family, inventors of cinema, which became Évian's Town Hall in 1927. Rich in woodwork, bronze, and marquetry, the building can be visited freely during office hours—a glimpse into Belle Époque elegance.

activities.text: The Évian market enlivens the quays on Tuesday and Friday mornings. Local producers sell cheeses, charcuterie, and Chablais vegetables.
The thermal baths offer wellness cures and relaxing treatments in heated pools facing the lake.
The Saint-François de Sales Basilica in Thonon houses monumental frescoes by painter Maurice Denis. Vibrant colors illuminate the neo-Byzantine interior.
Taste Ripaille wines produced in the castle vineyard, one of the northernmost in France.

Follow the family-friendly trail that climbs the valley floor from the parking area to the Bout du Monde (End of the World). This virtually flat walk traverses grandiose scenery beneath vertiginous walls and multiple cascading waterfalls—nature's drama on an epic scale.

Stroll the flower-lined lakefront promenade stretching nearly 3 kilometers along Lake Geneva's shores. Manicured gardens, fountains, and a music kiosk dot the route. The sunsets paint the lake and mountains in impossible colors—pure Alpine magic.

Ride the historic funicular, free to use and in service since 1907. This gem of railway heritage links the town center to the heights over 750 meters of track. At the upper station, you can visit the historic engine room—Victorian engineering still working perfectly.

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral of Évreux. A jewel of Gothic art, this vast sanctuary brings together styles from the 11th to 16th centuries. Its 70 stained glass windows constitute a masterpiece of glass art, including the famous 'Évreux Yellow'—a 14th-century silver-salt color whose golden brilliance has never been equaled. The flamboyant north portal by Jehan Cossart and the lantern tower with its 'silver steeple' complete this treasure. The contemporary organ by Pascal Quoirin sports a futuristic case designed by Bruno Decaris.

Évreux Belfry (Clock Tower). The sole vestige of medieval fortifications, this 44-meter flamboyant Gothic belfry built between 1490 and 1497 houses the 'Louyse' bell cast in 1406. Unique in Normandy, it symbolizes the communal freedoms of the Middle Ages and offers a panorama over the city.

Saint-Taurin Abbey Church. Founded in the 10th century by Richard the Fearless, this former Benedictine abbey preserves a priceless treasure: the shrine of Saint Taurin, a masterpiece of 13th-century medieval goldsmithing, considered one of France's most precious.

Museum of Art, History, and Archaeology. Housed in the former 15th-century episcopal palace flanking the cathedral, this museum traces Évreux's history from Gallo-Roman times (when it was called Mediolanum Aulercorum) to modern Reconstruction.

Iton riverbank promenade. This developed path along the river crosses Évreux's historic heart. Old washhouses, rampart remains, stone bridges, and a reflecting pool offer a romantic perspective on the cathedral and episcopal palace.

activities.text: Gisacum Archaeological Site. A few kilometers from Évreux, this Gallo-Roman site reveals the vestiges of an exceptional 2,000-year-old city. The interpretation center offers guided tours, children's workshops, and themed events.

Évreux–Le Bec-Hellouin Greenway. This 42 km pastoral route follows an old railway line through woods, bocage, and villages. Accessible on foot, by bike, or on rollerblades, it passes near Château du Champ de Bataille.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure Road Trip: From Giverny to Normandy's Finest Medieval Villages

visits.text: The Basilica of Notre-Dame de l'Épine in Évron is Mayenne's most significant medieval religious building. According to legend, a 7th-century pilgrim returning from Jerusalem deposited a relic of the Virgin's milk in a hawthorn bush; its miraculous overnight flowering led Saint Hadouin to found a monastery here in 642.

The architecture offers a complete panorama of medieval religious art: a 10th-century crypt, an 11th-century Romanesque nave, a 12th-century fortified tower-porch, and a 13th-century Gothic choir with soaring proportions. Listed as a Historic Monument since 1840.

Don't miss the 12th-century Saint-Crépin chapel, a stunning Arabo-Byzantine jewel inspired by Spanish Moorish architecture—unique décor in western France. Also admire the mural paintings, stained glass and ornate reliquary containing the Virgin's milk.

The basilica's history is turbulent: destroyed by Bretons and Vikings in the 9th century, rebuilt in the 10th, pillaged during the Wars of Religion in 1562. A Festival of Sacred Arts brings the naves to life each summer in July.

activities.text: Hike in the Charnie Forest, southeast of Évron. This forest massif is one of Mayenne's most extensive, offering numerous marked trails through oak and beech groves.
The Coëvrons territory around Évron offers over 500 km of marked trails for hiking, mountain biking or horseback riding through hedgerow countryside and green hills.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: The only cathedral built in France during the 20th century. Its 38-meter brick cylinder is crowned by 24 silver lime trees symbolizing the hours of the day and resurrection.
Ascend into the keep to discover the 12 stained glass windows in different colors, the work of Father Kim En Joong. Each evokes one of the twelve apostles.
The white Carrara marble altar stands at the center of the choir beneath a modern stained glass window depicting a tree. The cylindrical baptistery allows for baptism by immersion.
Place des Droits de l'Homme brings together three modern brick buildings: cathedral, town hall, and chamber of commerce. Pools and water fountains animate the esplanade.

activities.text: Walk along the confluence of the Seine and Essonne rivers at Coquibus Park. The two rivers meet in a wooded setting accessible on foot.
The Évry 2 shopping center and Agora border the cathedral district. Perfect for a shopping break in this new town development.
