visits.text: Falaise Castle, birthplace of William the Conqueror born in 1027, raises its three imposing keeps above the town. The medieval fortress combines Caen stone and Norman architecture with majesty. The virtual tour recreating the castle in the time of the dukes offers a spectacular plunge into the 11th century.
Explore the historic centre of Falaise and its medieval remains. The ramparts, Saint-Gervais Church and half-timbered houses recount the history of this strategic ducal city.

activities.text: Visit the Civilians in Wartime Memorial, the only one of its kind in France. Set in the castle's underground passages, it tells the story of everyday life under the Occupation and during the Liberation.
Discover the Automates Avenue museum, home to an astonishing collection of Belle Époque automata and antique toys. The magic of these mechanisms delights visitors of all ages.

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy

visits.text: Felletin shares with Aubusson the tapestry tradition since the 15th century. This small working-class town has preserved some workshops where weavers perpetuate ancestral gestures. The Church of Moutier, in Romanesque style, merits a visit for its sculpted capitals. The Creuse river crosses the town, offering charming perspectives on old weavers' houses.

The Felletin diamond is the largest rough diamond ever found in France. Discovered in the Creuse in 1477, it weighed 21 carats before being cut. A replica is displayed in the local museum, testimony to a little-known geological richness of the Massif Central.

activities.text: The tapestry workshops of Felletin sometimes open their doors to visitors. Observing a weaver working on their low-warp loom, choosing threads from thousands of shades, interpreting an artist's cartoon, is to understand why this know-how is inscribed on UNESCO's intangible heritage list. Inquire at the tourist office for possible visits.

The Millevaches plateau, of which Felletin is one of the gateways, offers landscapes of moors, peat bogs, and forests. Hiking trails allow discovery of this 'water tower' of France where several rivers are born. The altitude (up to 1000 meters) guarantees coolness and pure air.

days_plan.itin_title: Creuse Circuit: Valley of the Painters and Aubusson Tapestries

visits.text: Fère-en-Tardenois Castle raises its Renaissance ruins on a wooded height. The 16th-century vestiges testify to refined architecture commissioned by princes. Towers and curtain walls emerge from vegetation in a romantic atmosphere.

The fortified Saint-Macre church displays its defensive keep and loopholes characteristic of Thiérache. Though located further south, it shares the religious military architecture of the border region.
The nearby Templar Chapel recalls the military order's presence in the region. This small medieval building merits a visit for its history.
The picturesque village preserves rural charm with its old houses and quiet streets. The verdant setting invites leisurely strolls.

activities.text: Fère Forest unfolds its hiking trails around the village. Forest paths follow streams and clearings in a preserved massif. Several marked loops allow 2 to 4 hour walks.
Surrounding ponds welcome anglers in peaceful settings. Predator fish and coarse fish populate these developed waters. Fishing permit required.
Country roads link Tardenois villages through rolling landscapes and grain fields. Rural heritage reveals itself at the slow pace of cycling.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature

visits.text: Borough at the foot of the castle ruins of the counts; stairs and narrow passages.
Church and Town Hall at the center of the small valley of the Alsatian Jura.
Belvedere beneath the walls offering a reading of the Sundgau relief.

activities.text: Access path to the castle and viewpoint loop (3–4 km, elevation change).
Route through the lower streets and former moats of the town.

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: The Champollion Museum—Writings of the World occupies the birthplace of the man who deciphered hieroglyphics. Its contemporary facade is inlaid with a thousand writing symbols in copper and glass. Inside, 5,300 years of writing history unfolds: Sumerian cuneiform, Egyptian hieroglyphics, Chinese ideograms, Mayan glyphs. The oldest piece, a Sumerian pictographic tablet, dates back to 3200 BCE.

Just beside the museum, Place des Écritures features a giant reproduction of the Rosetta Stone cast in black granite by American artist Joseph Kosuth in 1991. In the adjacent courtyard, the French translation is engraved on a glass plate suspended above a map of the Nile Delta.

On Place Champollion, the Maison du Griffon dates from the mid-12th century—the town's oldest dwelling. All around, half-timbered medieval houses and typical Quercy soleilhos compose an intact historic setting. The 14th-century former hospice completes the ensemble.
The Hôtel du Viguier du Roy, a 14th-century palace, served as the royal representative's residence. Its interior courtyard, cloister, formal French gardens, and royal tower are open to visitors.
The Church of Saint-Sauveur grew from a 9th-century Benedictine abbey. Romanesque and Gothic styles blend through successive renovations. The carved capitals and austere atmosphere merit a stop.

Wander Figeac's historic center, designated a Town of Art and History. Merchants' houses from the 12th–15th centuries with ogival arcades, open soleilhos beneath the roofs, Renaissance mansions, and 18th-century bourgeois facades form a remarkably preserved ensemble.

activities.text: Follow the Clés de Figeac circuit, a marked route through the old town. An illustrated booklet guides you from one monument to the next in a coherent loop.
Figeac's market fills Place Carnot every Saturday morning beneath the 19th-century metal hall. Find cabécous, Rocamadour cheeses, walnuts, Quercy saffron, and fouace—a local orange-blossom brioche.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot Itinerary: Cahors, Rocamadour & the Lot Valley

visits.text: Le Corbusier UNESCO World Heritage Site. Europe's largest Le Corbusier architectural ensemble brings together five groundbreaking buildings in the Firminy-Vert district. The Maison de la Culture, the only structure completed during the architect's lifetime (1961-1965), features a façade tilted at 53 degrees with undulating panels designed by composer Xenakis. The curved roof floats on unstressed cables—a technical marvel. Inside, a 5,000-square-meter complex houses auditoriums and art spaces that still pulse with cultural life.

Saint-Pierre Church. This truncated concrete cone soars 33 meters skyward, completed between 1973 and 2006 to realize Le Corbusier's vision posthumously. Inside, an 11-second echo creates otherworldly acoustics. The constellation of Orion, pierced through the eastern wall, floods the interior with golden light at sunrise—a celestial clock that transforms throughout the day. The lower level, originally designed for parish activities, now hosts exhibitions featuring Le Corbusier's original maquettes and sculptures.

Unité d'Habitation. The fifth and final Unité worldwide, completed in 1967 by André Wogenscky after Le Corbusier's death. This residential ship stretches 130 meters long and rises 56 meters high on massive pilotis. Its 414 apartments (ranging from 25 to 113 square meters) house roughly 600 residents affectionately known as 'the Corbus.' Seven color-coded interior streets serve the dwellings—yellow, red, blue corridors that bring joy to daily life. The entire design follows the Modulor system, proportions based on a 1.83-meter human figure. Guided tours only.

Stadium and Swimming Pool. The stadium, finished in 1968, is France's only sports facility classified as a historic monument. Its 4,000 seats cascade down from the rim like a Greco-Roman arena—spectators enter from above and descend toward the field. The municipal pool, built 1969-1971 by Wogenscky and restored in 2006, completes Le Corbusier's vision of harmonizing physical culture with intellectual and spiritual life—a modernist ideal made concrete.

activities.text: Firminy-Vert District Discovery. Created in the 1950s to address the housing crisis in this former mining town, the district embodies modernist urban planning at its most ambitious. Social housing, schools, shops, and garages form a self-contained 'city within a city'—more spacious, healthier, and functional than the cramped 19th-century workers' quarters. The site draws 20,000 architecture pilgrims annually from around the globe.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Ramparts, fortified gates and sloping streets of the perched town.
Saint-Pierre Abbey and monastic layouts visible in the village.
Stone houses and shaded squares around the market hall.

activities.text: Circuit of the ramparts and viewpoints over the Ozerain valleys.
Rural path to the plateau and return through the orchards.

days_plan.itin_title: Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: Fleurance is a bastide town founded in 1274. Its central market hall with Gothic arcades dates from the 14th century and still hosts the market today. The Notre-Dame church features beautiful contemporary stained glass windows created by Arnaud Moles, the same artist who worked on Auch cathedral.
The archaeological museum displays Gallo-Roman discoveries from the region. You'll see mosaics, ceramics, and everyday objects that bring Roman-era life to vivid reality.

activities.text: Tuesday morning market is one of the liveliest in the Gers. Local producers sell foie gras, duck, cheeses, and vegetables. It's the perfect time to discover regional products and chat with the Gersois.
Stroll through the arcaded streets surrounding the central square. The typical bastide architecture is clear here with the grid layout and central plaza. Half-timbered houses add charm to the scene.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Fleurie, the 'Queen of Beaujolais,' produces arguably the most elegant and refined wines of the region. The 880 hectares of vines unfold on pink granite hillsides that give the wine its characteristic finesse. The village itself charms with its golden stone houses and Romanesque chapel overlooking the vineyards. Fleurie embodies the perfect balance between viticultural excellence and preserved architectural heritage.

The Madonna Chapel, perched on the hill overlooking Fleurie, offers a breathtaking panorama of the vineyards stretching to the horizon. Built in the 19th century, it became a place of pilgrimage for winegrowers seeking protection for their harvests. The stained glass windows depict wine-related scenes, celebrating the sacred bond between faith and viticulture. The walk to reach it crosses the most beautiful parcels of the appellation.

The village center preserves remarkable wine architecture with vaulted cellars, sculpted doorways, and period wineries. Golden stone facades reflect warm light at dusk, creating a romantic atmosphere. The central square and its century-old plane trees provide a shaded meeting place where producers and visitors exchange impressions on the latest vintage.

The Caveau des Producteurs du Cru Fleurie groups together sixty independent winegrowers under one roof. This cooperative tasting room allows discovery of wine diversity despite the common appellation. Each parcel, each climat brings subtle nuances that passionate producers decipher. Modern architecture contrasts with ancient cellars while respecting the site.

activities.text: Taste Fleurie wines at renowned estates like Clos de la Roilette or Domaine de la Grand'Cour. These elegant wines, with silky tannins and aromas of iris and violet, represent the quintessence of Beaujolais. Producers explain the influence of pink granite on finesse and the winemaking techniques that preserve aromatic delicacy. Some estates offer vertical tastings of several vintages to understand evolution over years.

Walk the Wine Trail that crosses the most beautiful climats of the appellation: La Roilette, Grille-Midi, Les Moriers. Information panels explain the influence of exposure, slope, and soil composition on wine character. The 5 km loop offers spectacular views of Mont Blanc on clear days and passes through century-old vines.

Attend a wine and cheese pairing workshop organized by local sommeliers. Young Beaujolais cheeses, goat cheeses from nearby mountains, and aged Comté accompany different cuvées of Fleurie. Professionals explain harmony principles between wine tannins and cheese textures. The convivial format encourages exchanges between participants.

Cycle through vineyards on the Beaujolais Wine Route. The gentle slopes make cycling accessible while offering exceptional panoramas. The route connects Fleurie to neighboring villages, passing through varied landscapes of vineyards, forests, and small valleys. Electric bike rental makes climbs effortless.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: Florac's château, beside the Vibron stream, houses the headquarters of Cévennes National Park. Its courtyard, shaded by centuries-old plane trees, provides a peaceful setting. The building hosts exhibitions on Cévenol heritage.

In a quiet park, the Pêcher spring gushes from a rocky scree through several outlets. It channels water from the Méjean causse toward the Tarnon. Its name derives from the Occitan "pesquièr" (fish pond), inherited from the old mills that once lined the watercourse.

Cross the stone Pont du Tarn, Florac's architectural emblem. It offers unobstructed views of the river and surrounding cliffs. Downstream, the metal bridge of the old station, built in 1890 following Eiffel's design, recalls when trains opened up the Cévennes.

The Tourism and National Park Information Center occupies the renovated old train station building. An interactive exhibition presents the Park, its ecosystems, and conservation challenges. Nature shop and bookstore on-site.

Florac-Trois-Rivières lives up to its name: the Tarn, Tarnon, and Mimente converge here. Stroll the Vibron's banks between schist houses, the 1833 neoclassical temple on the Esplanade, and Parc Paul Arnal.

activities.text: Paddle down the Tarn by canoe from Florac to Sainte-Énimie. The gorges gradually tighten, cliffs rise higher, pebble beaches invite breaks. Rental companies provide shuttle service back.
The Rochefort via ferrata offers two intertwining routes along the river, with an optional 50-meter zipline. Swimming breaks possible between passages.

The GR70, Robert Louis Stevenson's trail, passes through Florac. Follow a section to reach Col de Jalcreste or Barre-des-Cévennes, a hilltop village with history-laden facades and panoramic views over the National Park.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes

visits.text: Place des Couverts.
Half-timbered houses.
Cathedral (UNESCO).

activities.text: Stroll through the narrow streets.
Discovery of Couserans.

days_plan.itin_title: Ariège Pyrenees Road Trip, France: Cathar Castles & Prehistoric Cave Art

visits.text: Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie

activities.text: Visit to the building designed by Frank Gehry and the modern and contemporary art exhibitions presented by the foundation.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Museum Pass Itinerary: Masterpieces & Artistic Revolution Guide

visits.text: The Odeillo Solar Furnace stands 50 meters tall. Built in 1969 with 1,000 adjustable mirrors, it concentrates solar energy to reach 3,500°C at the focal point. Research center for high-temperature materials.
The Hermitage of Notre-Dame de Font-Romeu dates from 1693. This baroque chapel on the Camino de Santiago houses a 13th-century statue of the Virgin. The sacred fountain gives it its name.
The 20th-century Church of Saint Louis dominates the center. Built in concrete in 1733 on the model of the citadel chapel, it features a monumental statue of Christ the King.
The National High-Altitude Training Center has welcomed Olympic athletes since 1967. Its facilities are open to the public: swimming pool, ice rink, weight room.
The Grand Hotel, built between 1910 and 1914, dominates the resort. Listed as a historical monument, this Belle Époque establishment symbolizes the rise of climate therapy.

activities.text: Ski on the Font-Romeu Pyrénées 2000 domain. France's sunniest resort with 43 slopes between 1,600 and 2,213 meters altitude, 500 snow cannons, and 110 km of cross-country skiing.
Take the Yellow Train from Font-Romeu station. Century-old line connecting Villefranche to Latour-de-Carol through Cerdagne landscapes.
Hike on the Cerdagne plateau. Hundreds of kilometers of marked trails traverse pine forests, lakes, and clearings at 1,800 meters altitude.
Relax in the sulfurous hot spring baths. Llo, Dorres, and Saint-Thomas offer havens of peace in pristine nature.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: Fontaine-de-Vaucluse — spectacular resurgence at the foot of a limestone cliff.
Emerald water body under plane trees and banks of Sorgue.

The Sorgue springs from the base of a 755-foot cliff. France's most powerful resurgence and the world's fifth, it discharges an average 165–185 billion gallons annually. The chasm has been explored to 1,010 feet without reaching the bottom. In spring, the churning waters offer a striking spectacle.

Ruins of the Château des Évêques de Cavaillon dominate the village from a rocky spur. A steep path leads to the 12th-century vestiges, where the panorama plunges over the Sorgue Valley and Vaucluse cliffs.

The 11th-century Romanesque Église Saint-Véran-Sainte-Marie, a classified Historic Monument, houses a sarcophagus attributed to Saint Véran, Bishop of Cavaillon who supposedly slew the spring's dragon.

The Vallis Clausa paper mill perpetuates artisanal rag paper production. The paddle wheel drives the hammers in a building that served as a mill since the 15th century. Demonstrations of vat papermaking.

The Musée-Bibliothèque Pétrarque occupies the house where the Italian poet stayed in the 14th century. Collections of rare books, antique editions, and contemporary works illustrating the site's influence on literature and art.
The Colonne Pétrarque, erected in 1804 for the poet's five-hundredth birthday, marks the path to the spring. It recalls that Petrarch composed his Canzoniere dedicated to Laura here.

activities.text: Round trip to the chasm (depending on water level).
Left bank path of the Sorgue (shaded portion).
Follow the path along the Sorgue from the village to the chasm. The shaded half-mile walk traces the emerald water between plane trees and rock faces.
Kayak down the Sorgue from Fontaine-de-Vaucluse. The clear waters cross a corridor of greenery before reaching L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue.
Visit the Musée Jean Garcin dedicated to the Resistance in Vaucluse during World War II. Documents, objects, and testimonies trace the history of the Ventoux maquis.

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour
Vaucluse: Avignon, Luberon Villages & Ventoux Routes

visits.text: The Château de Fontainebleau commands 130 hectares of parks and gardens. Eight centuries of monarchs lived here continuously, from the 12th to the 19th century. With 1,500 rooms, it's the most furnished royal palace in France.
Walk through the François I Gallery, 60 meters long. The frescoes and stuccowork by Rosso Fiorentino depict mythological scenes commissioned by the king to transform Fontainebleau into a "new Rome".

The Napoleon I Museum occupies the Louis XV wing. Uniforms, weapons, imperial jewels, and personal items trace the emperor's life—he called the château "the true home of kings, the house of centuries".
Step into Empress Eugénie's Chinese Museum. Cloisonné vases, jade, and porcelain form an Asian cabinet of curiosities installed during the Second Empire.

The Imperial Theatre, commissioned by Napoleon III and inaugurated in 1857, was rediscovered after 150 years of neglect. Its refinement echoes that of the Versailles opera house. Accessible by guided tour only.

Descend to the Court of Honor, known as the "Farewell Court". The horseshoe staircase marks the exact spot where Napoleon bid farewell to the Imperial Guard on April 20, 1814, before his exile to Elba.

activities.text: Stroll through the English Garden, landscaped under Napoleon I, then follow the Grand Canal dug under Henri IV. Rowboats let you glide across the water facing the château.

The Fontainebleau Forest stretches across 22,000 hectares. Its sandstone boulders are the world reference for bouldering, drawing climbers from across the globe. Over 30,000 problems across 270 sectors are mapped, from beginner to expert.
Follow the marked forest trails: the GR 1, 2, 11, and 13 cross the massif. Landscapes alternate between sandstone chaos, oak groves, and sandy plateaus.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: Château du Plessis-Bourré (Écuillé) — Rumors of curses; phenomena in certain rooms.
Plessis-Bourré — Rumors & rooms.

The Renaissance old town of Fontenay-le-Comte, Vendée's only Town of Art and History, unfurls its grand townhouses along cobbled lanes. The Billaud House, Hôtel de la Sénéchaussée, and Hôtel Grimouard bear witness to 16th-century splendor.

Château de Terre-Neuve, built in the late 16th century for the poet Nicolas Rapin, is a Renaissance jewel. Its grand salon houses gilded sun motifs that once adorned Louis XIV's bedchamber at Chambord.

Notre-Dame Church, a 15th-century Gothic edifice, conceals an 11th-century Romanesque crypt. Its bell tower soars over 260 feet. Renaissance chapels, a classical altarpiece, and an 18th-century pulpit punctuate the nave.
Descend a few steps to discover the Fontaine des Quatre Tias, built in 1542. This listed monument in the form of an ancient temple, with pediment and Doric columns, bears the town's Latin motto.
Around Place Belliard, arcaded 17th-century houses recall the commercial prosperity of Vendée's former capital. Look closely at the facades to spot hidden caryatids.
The Musée de Fontenay, housed in the former Notre-Dame presbytery, holds one of France's richest collections of Gallo-Roman glassware.

activities.text: Access: public — Exact coordinates (47.583, -0.610).
Access: public (Prieuré)
Follow the circuit of 42 heritage interpretation panels, from the Illustrious Quarter to the Loges suburb. Two loops departing from the Tourist Office cover medieval and Renaissance treasures.
Climb to Parc Baron, site of the medieval fortress. Remnants of the Romanesque keep, Guinefolle bastion, and Tour de la Boulaye offer the finest views over Fontenay's rooftops.
Embark on a flat-bottomed boat ride in the Marais Poitevin from landing stages near Fontenay. Shaded canals lined with ash and poplar crisscross the Green Venice.

days_plan.itin_title: Haunted Loire Valley: Forgotten Castles and Spectral Legends
Loire Valley Phantoms: Tragic Histories and Haunted Castles of France
Vendée Road Trip: Noirmoutier Island, Puy du Fou & Atlantic Coast

visits.text: The Royal Abbey of Fontevraud, founded in 1101, ranks among Europe's largest monastic cities, sprawling across 13 hectares. UNESCO-listed and remarkable for its history, it was governed for 700 years by 36 abbesses—an extraordinary matriarchy in medieval Christendom.

In the abbey church lie the polychrome effigies of Eleanor of Aquitaine, Henry II Plantagenet, Richard the Lionheart, and Isabelle of Angoulême. This royal necropolis bears witness to the Plantagenet empire that once stretched from Scotland to the Pyrenees.
The 12th-century Romanesque kitchens are architecturally unique. Twenty stone chimneys rise beneath an octagonal structure crowned with slate scales—a medieval engineering marvel.
The Grand-Moûtier cloister invites contemplation. Its 16th-century galleries frame a garden where silence reigns, much as it has for centuries of monastic life.
The chapter house served as the nuns' daily meeting place. Converted into a prison in the 19th century, it has been restored to reveal its Gothic beauty once more.

activities.text: The abbey welcomes artists in residence, contemporary art exhibitions, and concerts within its history-laden spaces where ancient stones meet modern creativity.
The village of Fontevraud-l'Abbaye, classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages, reveals itself on foot. White tuffeau stone houses line flower-filled lanes that seem untouched by time.
Saumur vineyards surround the abbey. Several estates within a few kilometers offer tastings where you can sample the terroir that has been cultivated here for centuries.

days_plan.itin_title: Maine-et-Loire Road Trip: Anjou and Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: Fontvieille — village of quarries and mills, living traditions.
Stone quarries (ext.) and buildings in blonde limestone.

activities.text: Mills loop (stony paths).
Discovery of capitelles and oratories (according to circuit).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: The citadel crowns the hill above Forcalquier. Medieval ruins dominate the town and plain with their austere walls. Notre-Dame-de-Provence chapel watches from the summit, offering a circular panorama over the Alps, Luberon and Montagne de Lure.

The Cordeliers convent displays its 13th-century Franciscan monastic architecture. The Gothic cloister with vaulted galleries surrounds a simple garden. Temporary exhibitions and concerts regularly animate this carefully restored historic place.

Notre-Dame-du-Bourguet cathedral blends Romanesque and Provençal Gothic. The 13th-century sculpted portal opens onto a harmoniously proportioned nave. Side chapels house richly decorated Baroque altarpieces.

Walk through old town streets where mansions and Renaissance residences line up. Medieval gates punctuate the former ramparts' layout. Restored fountains and washhouses mark shaded squares where Provençal gentleness reigns.
Saint-Michel cemetery offers a peaceful haven away from town. Terraced tombs follow the hillside slope. Cypresses stand like sentinels in this serene place.

activities.text: Forcalquier market brings the town to life every Monday morning. Considered one of Provence's most beautiful markets, it spreads its colorful stalls across several squares. Local producers, artisans and market gardeners offer goat cheeses, lavender honey, olives and local specialties.

Montagne de Lure rises north of Forcalquier. Forest roads wind through beech groves and alpine meadows to the 1826-meter summit. The astronomical observatory benefits from clear skies for its observations.
Hiking trails radiate around Forcalquier. The Montagne des Mourres tour offers a moderate route through garrigue and oaks. Medieval ruins and Alpine panoramas punctuate the itineraries.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages

visits.text: The fortress of Montbazon raises its 11th-century keep on a rocky spur overlooking the Indre. Erected by Foulques Nerra, the formidable Count of Anjou, this 28-meter square tower is one of France's oldest stone keeps.
Climb to the top of the keep to embrace with your gaze the Indre valley, the village rooftops, and the Touraine countryside. The panorama extends several kilometers on clear days.
The fortified enclosure shelters the remains of a seigneurial residence and a chapel. Explanatory panels retrace the history of Foulques Nerra, fortress builder and major figure of medieval Anjou.
Forteresse de Montbazon and its towering keep, one of the oldest stone donjons in France
Explore the keep of Montbazon fortress, climbing its ancient stairs for panoramic views over the valley

activities.text: Medieval animations and demonstrations regularly take place within the enclosure: crossbow shooting, blacksmithing, calligraphy, and knightly combat bring the fortress alive during school holidays.
Medieval demonstrations and entertainment at Montbazon, featuring sword fighting, falconry, and period crafts

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: The royal fortress of Chinon stretches 500 meters along the top of a rocky spur dominating the Vienne. Three fortified enclosures succeed one another: Fort Saint-Georges, the Middle Castle, and Fort du Coudray.
In the great hall of the royal apartments, Joan of Arc recognized Charles VII among his courtiers in March 1429. Interactive scenography retraces this founding episode of French history.
The Tour du Coudray preserves graffiti carved by Templars imprisoned here in 1308 on the order of Philippe le Bel. Crosses, inscriptions, and mysterious symbols cover the tufa walls.

The royal apartments have been recreated through a digital device that projects furniture, hangings, and characters onto the walls. The contrast between the ruins and the virtual reconstruction is striking.
From the ramparts, the view plunges onto the Vienne, the slate roofs of old Chinon, and the hillsides planted with vines that produce the famous Chinon red wine.
Forteresse Royale de Chinon, a mighty fortress looming over the Vienne River where Joan of Arc met her king
The interactive scenography of Chinon fortress, immersing visitors in the world of medieval power and intrigue
The great defensive tower of Chinon, rising above the valley with commanding views
The Tour du Coudray and the Templar graffiti at Chinon, carved into stone by imprisoned knights

activities.text: Descend into old Chinon via the cobbled lanes. Half-timbered houses from the 15th and 16th centuries, troglodyte caves dug into the tufa, and shaded squares compose a preserved historic center.
The troglodyte caves in Chinon's hillsides house wine producers who offer tastings of the local cabernet franc, the appellation's emblematic grape.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Half-timbered houses.
Écluse Beach.

activities.text: Fougères Forest.
Marches de Bretagne region.
Ramparts Walk.

visits.text: Nicéphore Niépce Museum (photography).
Saint-Vincent Cathedral.

activities.text: Comtois heritage.
Battle Museum (1871).
Ognon.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: Fourcès is one of France's rare circular bastides, listed among the Most Beautiful Villages. Founded in the 13th century, it's organized around a round square bordered by arcades. Half-timbered houses and flower-laden façades create a picturesque atmosphere. The 15th-century château overlooks the village.
The church of Saint-Laurent has a fortified bell tower typical of the region. Inside, 15th-century frescoes are still visible.

activities.text: In late April, the flower market transforms the circular square into an ephemeral garden. It's one of the Southwest's most beautiful flower markets with hundreds of exhibitors. The atmosphere is festive and vibrant.
Wander beneath the arcades of the round square. The galleries shelter small shops and restaurants. Sit at a terrace to admire this unique architecture.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Fox-Amphoux — twin village: Fox in the plain and Amphoux perched, connected by a panoramic road.
12th-century feudal castle (exteriors) and panorama over the hills of Haut-Var.

activities.text: Walk among olive groves and lavender fields around Fox.
Sunset viewing from Amphoux.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages

visits.text: The Roman amphitheater, built in the 1st century, could hold 10,000 spectators who came to watch gladiatorial combat. Its tiers, corridors, and vomitoria can be visited freely. The venue still hosts concerts and shows—ancient stones echoing with modern music.

Saint-Léonce Cathedral forms, along with the 5th-century Paleo-Christian baptistery, one of France's oldest episcopal complexes. The octagonal baptistery, supported by recycled ancient columns, preserves its original baptismal font—a tangible link to early Christianity.

The 13th-century Romanesque cloister is a medieval jewel. Its 14th-century carved larch wood ceiling presents 300 painted panels of fantastic creatures, saints, and daily life scenes. A bestiary unique in France—look up and lose yourself.

The Roman aqueduct stretched 42 kilometers with a 481-meter drop and 36 aqueduct bridges. At La Roche Taillée, a 50-meter canal was carved directly into the rock. Classified as a historic monument since 1886, its vestiges can be visited on foot from downtown.

The Porte des Gaules, one of the four main entrances to the Roman city, preserves its monumental pillars overgrown with wild capers. Just beside it, a section of Roman paved road testifies to the past of Forum Julii.

The archaeological museum, behind the cloister, displays the results of local excavations. The Hermès Bicéphale, a two-faced bust that has become Fréjus's emblem, is the centerpiece—ancient mystery in marble.

activities.text: Stroll through the pedestrian lanes of the historic center, between Place Formigé with its terraces, Rue Sieyès with its good addresses. The Provençal market animates the squares every morning with local flavor.
Villa Aurélienne and its 24-hectare park offer a green break in town. This Palladian-style residence, surrounded by umbrella pines, hosts temporary exhibitions in a setting of aristocratic elegance.
Visit the Roman theater, more modest than the amphitheater but fascinating. Its restored tiers allow you to imagine the performances of comedies and poetry from Antiquity—sit where Romans once sat.

days_plan.itin_title: Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: The 12th-century Notre-Dame church boasts a remarkable carved oak door from 1528. The Tree of Jesse stands alongside the twelve apostles on this masterpiece.
Climb to the castle park to admire the panorama over the Sarthe and the river's meanders. The keep ruins dominate the site.
The 14th-century castle gate consists of two circular towers. This defensive element also served as a prison.
The market hall, now a performance venue, once hosted sales of the famous Fresnay hemp cloth.
The Coiffe Museum displays 180 19th-century Sarthe bonnets worn by local women. Meticulous restoration by traditional seamstresses.
Wander the narrow lanes lined with weavers' cottages. The local roussard stone gives the town its distinctive character.

activities.text: Walk along the Rue du Bourgneuf beside the Sarthe. This cobbled street offers calm and tranquility along the water.
Hike through the Perche Sarthois and the Bonnétable Forest. Walking trails depart from Fresnay.
The twice-weekly markets at the foot of the church offer local produce and everyday goods.

visits.text: Fresselines preserves the imprint of Claude Monet's stay from March to May 1889. The Impressionist master created 23 canvases here, including ten representing the confluence of the two Creuse rivers nicknamed 'Les Eaux Semblantes' (The Similar Waters). This series is considered his first true exploration of the same motif under different lights, a technique he would perfect with the Haystacks and then the Cathedrals.

The Monet-Rollinat Space, an art center inaugurated in 2018, pays tribute to the two personalities who marked the village. A memorial room is dedicated to Monet and presents reproductions of his Creuse canvases. The other evokes Maurice Rollinat, poet of Névroses who lived here for twenty years and received artists and writers. Temporary contemporary art exhibitions animate this creative space.

On the wall of the Fresselines church, a bas-relief by Rodin entitled 'The Poet and His Muse' pays homage to Maurice Rollinat. The sculptor, a friend of the poet, offered this work to the town after Rollinat's death in 1903. Inside, contemporary stained glass windows created by a local glass artist add a modern artistic touch to the building.

activities.text: The 'In Monet's Footsteps' trail starts from the village and winds 3 kilometers along the Petite Creuse. A suspended footbridge crosses the river to reach the painter's favorite viewpoints. Interpretation panels present the paintings created at each location, allowing comparison of the current landscape with the Impressionist vision of 1889.

The Rocher de la Fileuse (Spinner's Rock), in the neighboring commune of Saint-Plantaire, offers the most beautiful panorama of the valley and the confluence of the Creuse and Sédelle. It was here that Monet created his series of 24 canvases. A 3-kilometer hiking trail leads through the woods. The late afternoon light magnifies the colors the master sought to capture.

days_plan.itin_title: Creuse Circuit: Valley of the Painters and Aubusson Tapestries

visits.text: Saint-Michel Abbey, founded in 972, dominates the Tarn riverbanks. In its vaulted cellars, the museum traces Gaillac's history through a Gallo-Roman mosaic discovered on site, sacred art, and guild craftsmanship.
Head to the Quai Saint-Jacques quarter, the oldest part of town. From here, gabarres loaded with pastel and wine once departed, sailing down the Tarn to the Gironde and European ports.
Continue to the Portanelle quarter. Its corbelled houses, half-timbered structures, and walls of raw or fired brick mixed with river pebbles illustrate typical Tarn riverside architecture.
Château de Foucaud houses the Fine Arts Museum. Its classified Italian-style garden descends in terraces to the Tarn's banks, with small pools and open views.
Saint-Pierre Church, built in the 10th century, features a 14th-century stone portal and sober façade. Inside, marble altars and the nave's proportions warrant a visit.

activities.text: Visit a wine estate for a tasting introduction. Gaillac's vineyard, one of France's oldest with over 2,000 years of history, produces powerful reds, dry whites, sweet wines, and sparkling varieties.
Follow a wine-hiking trail through the Gaillac AOC vineyards. These marked walks cross rolling landscapes nicknamed 'Occitan Tuscany.'
Stop at Gaillac's weekly market to discover regional products: foie gras, duck confit, local saffron, and sheep's milk cheeses from the Lacaune Mountains.

visits.text: The Cirque de Gavarnie, inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List since 1997 as part of the cross-border ensemble "Pyrénées-Mont Perdu," is a natural amphitheater 6.5 km in circumference whose limestone walls rise to 1,700 meters high. Sculpted by glacial erosion approximately 50 million years ago, its concentric tiers of striking symmetry are surrounded by peaks exceeding 3,000 meters. Victor Hugo called it an "impossible and extraordinary object."

The Grande Cascade de Gavarnie, with its 423-meter drop, is the highest waterfall in mainland France. Fed by snow and the Marboré glacier, it unfolds in long white veils on the cirque wall. Its flow varies considerably by season, with the spring melt months offering the most powerful spectacle.

The Brèche de Roland, at 2,804 meters altitude, is a natural notch 40 meters wide and 100 meters high in the rock wall separating France from Spain. According to legend, the knight Roland, Charlemagne's nephew, opened it with a blow of his sword Durandal to destroy it so it wouldn't fall into enemy hands.

The village of Gavarnie, starting point toward the cirque, preserves traditional Pyrenean architecture of stone houses and slate roofs. A historic stop on the paths to Santiago de Compostela, it also constitutes the birthplace of Pyreneanism, that current of Pyrenean exploration and ascent born in the 18th century.

The Refuge des Sarradets, at 2,587 meters altitude below the Brèche de Roland, dates from 1955-1956. Its terrace offers one of the most striking panoramas of the Pyrenees, with the Cirque de Gavarnie and the Grande Cascade as a backdrop. It serves as a stop for hikers climbing toward the Brèche.

The Cirque de Gavarnie is part of a set of three glacial cirques with Estaubé and Troumouse, forming the "Pyrénées-Mont Perdu" site recognized by UNESCO. This sector shelters remarkable fauna: chamois on the slopes, marmots in high-altitude meadows, bearded vulture (Europe's largest raptor with 2.80 m wingspan) and golden eagle in the updrafts.

The Cirque de Gavarnie, inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List ("Pyrénées-Mont Perdu" ensemble, 1997), unfolds its 5,577-foot-high wall stretching 8.7 miles around. Its concentric limestone tiers, sculpted by glacial erosion over 50 million years, are crowned with summits exceeding 10,000 feet: Marboré (10,656 feet), Taillon (10,315 feet), Astazou.

The Grande Cascade de Gavarnie plunges 1,388 feet—the highest waterfall in metropolitan France. Fed by the Marboré glaciers, it's visible from the hotel at the foot of the cirque. In spring, snowmelt gives it its most spectacular flow.

The village of Gavarnie, home to fewer than 200 souls, is a historic stop on the Way of St. James. Its parish church is among the properties inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List. Stone houses huddle along narrow lanes at the foot of the natural amphitheatre.

The Brèche de Roland, a natural notch 131 feet wide and 230 feet high at 9,209 feet elevation, opens the border between France and Spain at the foot of the Casque de Marboré. Legend has it that Roland, Charlemagne's nephew, cleaved it with a stroke of his sword Durandal after the Battle of Roncevaux.

From the Bellevue viewpoint or the Saugué plateau (above Gèdre), the panorama embraces the entire cirque and three neighboring cirques: Estaubé, more pastoral and wild, and Troumouse, the vastest with its 6.8-mile circumference and alpine meadows accessible by road.

activities.text: From the village, walk about 1h30 on the main trail to the foot of the cirque to see the Grande Cascade up close. The path, without technical difficulty, crosses meadows and follows the gave - it can also be done on horseback with village outfitters.

For seasoned hikers, reach the Brèche de Roland from the Col des Tentes (2,208 m) via the Sarradets refuge. Allow 5 to 6 hours round trip for this demanding hike (approximately 1,000 m elevation gain, possible passages on snowfields even in summer).
Tour the medieval village of Gavarnie observing the stone architecture of Pyrenean houses and barns, and stop at one of the small restaurants to taste garbure or valley sheep cheese.
Stay until evening if you can: the sunset light on the cirque walls transforms the rock into gradients of ochre and pink, a spectacle that photography struggles to reproduce.

Hike from the village to the foot of the cirque along the path following the Gave de Gavarnie. Verdant terrain, autumn crocuses, and streams accompany this easy 1.5-hour walk. At arrival, the immensity of the vertical walls is dizzying.

Reach the Brèche de Roland from the Col des Tentes (7,244 feet, accessible by road). The trail passes through the Port de Boucharo (7,451 feet), crosses the Taillon stream below the glacier, then climbs to the Sarradets refuge (8,488 feet) before the final ascent to the breach. Cross-border panorama over the Gavarnie cirque and Spain's Ordesa canyon.
A horseback ride to the foot of the cirque lets you experience the landscape differently. Local outfitters offer mounts suited to all skill levels.

The Cirque de Troumouse, accessible via a scenic road from Gèdre, offers an amphitheatre stretching 6.8 miles around—even vaster than Gavarnie. Alpine meadows, marmots, and griffon vultures populate this grandiose setting that sees far fewer crowds.

visits.text: Discover the Ecomusée de la Baie, an enlightening interpretation center dedicated to the natural wonders of the Mont-Saint-Michel bay and its protected ecosystems. Spread across 400 square meters, this engaging museum features films, detailed scale models, and interactive terminals that explain the unique environment of Europe's greatest tidal bay. The museum offers unobstructed views toward the iconic silhouette of the mount.

Explore the charming coastal village of Genêts, a quintessentially Norman settlement that serves as the traditional starting point for guided bay crossings. This picturesque harbor community retains its authentic maritime character with stone cottages, fishing boats, and a peaceful atmosphere that contrasts beautifully with the drama of the surrounding tidal flats.

activities.text: Embark on the legendary barefoot crossing of the Mont-Saint-Michel bay, an unforgettable adventure through one of the world's most dramatic tidal landscapes. Accompanied by an expert guide, wade through shallow channels, discover the phenomenon of quicksand safely, and experience the vast scale of this UNESCO-listed natural site. The bay witnesses Europe's highest tidal variations, creating an ever-changing seascape of extraordinary beauty.

Observe the remarkable wildlife that thrives in the bay's unique ecosystem, including elegant egrets, graceful seals, and the famous pré-salé sheep that graze the salt marshes. The herbus-coastal meadows regularly covered by tides-support an extraordinary biodiversity and create the distinctive flavored lamb that is a regional culinary treasure.

visits.text: Gerberoy (Oise): "village of a thousand rose bushes", ramparts & mixed brick/half-timbered houses.
Gerberoy clings to its hilltop as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages. Classified in 1928, this Picard village of 90 inhabitants unfurls climbing roses among half-timbered houses.

Three thousand rose bushes cascade down façades and overflow gardens from June through September. Post-Impressionist painter Henri Le Sidaner planted the first in 1901, transforming the village into a hanging garden.
The Saint-Pierre collegiate church raises its bell tower from the 11th century. Remodeled in the 15th and 16th centuries, it dominates the tiled rooftops of the fortified village.
Henri Le Sidaner's garden surrounds his painter's house. Flower beds and rose gardens evoke the intimate atmosphere of his canvases painted here between 1901 and 1939.
Half-timbered houses from the 15th and 16th centuries line cobbled lanes and small squares. Rose-pink bricks and sculpted timber framing compose this preserved medieval setting.

activities.text: Le Sidaner Gardens & floral stroll (seasonal).
Wander the flower-filled lanes between ramparts and secret gardens. The rose circuit winds through the village for an hour from the church to the old moats.

visits.text: The Château de Gien commands the Loire from its red-brick heights. Inside, the International Hunting Museum displays trophies, antique firearms, and animal paintings spanning five centuries—from 15th-century tapestries to 19th-century oils.
The stone bridge has arched across the Loire since the 18th century. Sixteen elegant spans connect both riverbanks directly beneath the château.

The Gien Faïencerie perpetuates centuries of pottery craftsmanship dating back to 1821. The factory outlet and museum unveil historic collections and offer glimpses into the working studios where artisans still paint by hand.

activities.text: The Saturday market animates the Loire quays with local flavor. Farmers' stalls and Gien pottery stands line the riverfront opposite the château.
Follow the Faïence Route connecting Gien, Briare, and surrounding villages. Workshops, studios, and outlet stores dot the scenic circuit.

visits.text: Saint-Pardoux Church. Church from the late 15th century housing an exceptional treasure: the reliquary shrine of Saint Stephen, a masterpiece of 12th-century Limoges enamel. Also several ancient statues and liturgical objects.
Notre-Dame du Rosaire Chapel. White Penitents' chapel located on the village's main street.
Ruins of Roche Haute Castle. Medieval ruins overlooking the village, visible from the main street.

activities.text: Gimel Waterfalls - Vuillier Park. The Montane river plunges in three spectacular falls totaling 143 meters: the Grand Saut (45 m), the Redole (38 m) and the Queue de Cheval (60 m) which dives into the "Inferno abyss". Painter Gaston Vuillier developed this park between 1893 and 1899 with staircases and observation points. Abel Hugo, Victor's brother, was the first to describe the site's beauty in "Picturesque France" (1883). Listed site since 1912.

Hike to the 4th waterfall and Pont du Péage. Free circuit of about 1h30 one way to discover an additional waterfall outside the paid park. The "cascadelles" are also accessible via the Short Circuit in the forest.

visits.text: At the summit of the Ballon d'Alsace (1,247 m), the statue of Jeanne d'Arc erected in 1909 marks the border between three departments. The orientation table built in 1888 by the Alpine Club offers views stretching to the Alps on clear days.
Fort Dorsner was built in 1875 as part of the Séré de Rivières system to guard the Savoureuse valley. This pink sandstone fortress towers over Giromagny and the Ballon d'Alsace road.
The Église Saint-Jean-Baptiste in Giromagny houses a remarkable Verschneider organ. Its 19th-century neoclassical architecture is worth a visit.

activities.text: Hike the GR5 from the Ballon d'Alsace down to Giromagny. This 13-km stage with 224 m descent follows the red rectangle blazes of the Club Vosgien. Pass through the mountain farmhouse inns of La Chaumière and Wissgrut.
The mining trail winds through former lead-silver extraction sites. Discover the industrial history of the Upper Savoureuse valley from the Middle Ages to the 20th century.

Gordes rises amphitheater-like on a rocky spur of the Vaucluse plateau. Ranked among France's Most Beautiful Villages, it aligns white stone houses, cobbled lanes, and lauze-stone roofs facing the Luberon Valley.

The Renaissance Château de Gordes, with medieval elements, dominates the central square. Its vaulted halls host contemporary art exhibitions. The great hall's monumental fireplace is one of France's largest.

The Village des Bories groups around thirty dry-stone huts, classified Historic Monuments. Sheepfolds, bread ovens, wine vats, and dwellings document an agropastoral way of life from the 17th to 19th centuries.

The Abbaye Notre-Dame de Sénanque, founded in 1148 by Cistercian monks, remains home to a monastic community. The Romanesque church, vaulted dormitory, and scriptorium are open to visitors. Lavandin fields surrounding it bloom from mid-June to mid-July.
The Caves du Palais Saint-Firmin descend beneath the church into a medieval underground network. Vats carved into rock, an olive oil mill, and presses reveal the village's medieval craft activity.
Reach the Rocher de Bel-Air via the Cavaillon road. This viewpoint offers Gordes's most photographed vista: the entire village etched against the sky, clinging to its rock.

activities.text: Upper loop of the ramparts and castle esplanades (ext.).
Path towards viewpoints south of the village (panoramic shots).

Strolling through the narrow streets of Gordes, shops and terraces
Hike from Gordes to Sénanque Abbey along the ridge trail. The path descends through garrigue and holm oaks to the valley sheltering the abbey.
In season, the lavandin fields around Sénanque offer one of Provence's most iconic landscapes. Arrive early morning for the light and to avoid crowds.
Browse art galleries and artisan workshops scattered through Gordes's cobbled lanes. Ceramicists, painters, and sculptors work in studios open to visitors.

visits.text: Gorron is a small character town set on the granite foundations of the Armorican Massif, at the historic crossroads of the Breton and Norman marches. The Colmont river flows through it, creating a green setting bordered by old wash houses.

Saint-Martin church, rebuilt from 1868 to 1874 in neo-Romanesque style, dominates the town from its tall square bell tower that forms the entrance porch. Inside, an altarpiece depicting the stoning of Saint Stephen deserves attention.

Rue des Chauvinettes, quite steep, runs within the outline of the old fortress built around 1162 by Henry II Plantagenet, King of England. The granite flanks of the Colmont riverbanks served as natural fortification. The castle, contested between the lords of Mayenne and the English crown, was destroyed during the Hundred Years' War.

Stroll the lanes to spot the town hall housed in the old market halls, 19th-century bourgeois houses and the metal footbridge above the street—remnant of the former furniture factory that brought industrial fame to Gorron after the clog makers.

activities.text: The Colmont trail (n°11, yellow markers, FFRandonnée certified) starts from the church and circles the town between sunken lanes, hedgerows and Colmont riverbanks. Along the way, the Roche menhir has stood since approximately 4,000 BC beside a stream: 4.40 meters tall, classified Historic Monument. Legend says that on Christmas night, at the twelve strokes of midnight, the stone turns twelve times on itself.
The Colmont Leisure Park offers in season treetop adventure courses, kayaking, swin-golf, outdoor laser tag and paintball in a preserved natural setting.

visits.text: Goumois is a Franco-Swiss village split in two by the Treaty of Vienna in 1815, with the Doubs serving as the border. Nestled in the valley hollow, it is surrounded by the Corniche road, the Rocher du Singe, and the ruins of the medieval castle of Franquemont. Jean-Jacques Rousseau came to botanize here as early as 1748 with botanist Gagnebin. The bridge over the Doubs connects the two namesake communes.

The Corniche de Goumois viewpoint offers an exceptional panorama over the Doubs gorges and the Swiss Jura. The very picturesque road that leads there dominates the gorges and offers a series of varied viewpoints. It is the meeting place for lovers of wild and authentic nature.

The Maîche plateau extends between 800 and 1,000 meters altitude, bounded by the deep valleys of the Doubs and Dessoubre. This characteristic area of the Haut-Doubs offers vast expanses dotted with old Comtoise farms. Maîche, the canton's chief town near the Swiss border, is integrated into the Doubs Horloger regional natural park.

activities.text: Goumois is an internationally renowned fishing spot for trout and grayling. The Franco-Swiss Doubs offers 150 km of marked hiking trails. The most daring will take the Échelles de la Mort, installed in a wild and spectacular site near Charquemont.

Le Russey, at nearly 1,000 meters altitude on the Maîche plateau, offers panoramas over the surrounding plateaus. The 19th-century town hall is listed as a Historic Monument. Saint-Nicolas church and Saint-Roch chapel testify to the local religious heritage. It is the birthplace of the Almanach Vermot, founded by Joseph Féréol Vermot born here in 1828.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs Circuit: Watchmaking and Swiss Border

visits.text: Gourdon — classified perched village, monumental viewpoint over the Pre-Alps.
Château de Gourdon (exterior) and gardens inspired by Le Nôtre.
Stroll through the perched village of Gourdon, classified among the most beautiful in France.
Hiking on the Paradise circuit connecting Gourdon to Bar-sur-Loup.

The Church of Saint-Pierre sits atop Gourdon's hilltop. Its southern Gothic facade, flanked by two defensive towers, conceals a richly decorated interior: an 18th–19th-century tribune organ, altarpiece, and bas-reliefs. The 14th-century rose window on the main portal and the large apse window play with light throughout the day.

Reach the château esplanade at the hilltop's highest point, 286 meters elevation. From the site of the former castle and its ramparts, panoramic views extend across Gourdon's rooftops, the Bouriane countryside, and the distant plateaus.

The Maison du Sénéchal, built in the 13th century, was the residence of the royal official responsible for justice and local administration. Now converted into a Center for Architecture and Heritage Interpretation, it presents the history of the citadel and Bouriane region.

The Gardens of the Hilltop nestle in Gourdon's medieval heart. The Zig-Zag Gardens recreate the medieval atmosphere; the Sénéchal Gardens shelter a performance courtyard adorned with a topiary butterfly; the Fairy Tale Garden blends wicker structures, wooden characters, and ornamental grasses. All maintained by passionate volunteers.

The Cougnac Caves, 3 kilometers from Gourdon, comprise two cavities discovered in 1949 and 1952. The first cave displays a mineral forest of rare density: stalactites, translucent tubular formations, delicate draperies. The second contains Paleolithic paintings about 30,000 years old—ibex, mammoths, giant deer, and rare human figures called "wounded men." Listed as Historic Monuments.

activities.text: Gorges du Loup — stops at Saut du Loup and photo points (whitewater).
Paragliding sites in the vicinity (depending on aerology/club).
Observation of the panorama over the Côte d'Azur and the Esterel massif.
Original sensory tours invite you to discover Gourdon blindfolded, guided by touch, hearing, and smell. An unconventional approach to heritage that engages all the senses.

Walk the medieval lanes of the historic center: golden stone houses, pointed arches, covered passages. The marked pedestrian circuit leads from one building to the next in a village founded in the 11th century.
Gourdon's market gathers local producers and artisans. Black truffles in winter, porcini mushrooms in autumn, goat cheeses, walnuts, and honey year-round.

Villedieu-les-Poêles — Bell foundry (museum route)
Mortain-Bocage — Grande Cascade and Petite Cascade (short loop)
Granville — fortified Upper Town (ramparts, gate, narrow streets)
Granville — Pointe du Roc (semaphore, panorama Chausey islands in the distance)
Granville — Richard-Anacréon Modern Art Museum (collection and exhibition)
Granville — Christian Dior Museum (Les Rhumbs villa, gardens) — depending on opening

Begin your journey in Granville, a captivating fortified town perched dramatically on a rocky promontory that marks the northern boundary of the Mont-Saint-Michel bay. This historic corsair city enchants visitors with its impressive ramparts encircling a charming old town of granite houses and narrow cobblestone streets. Stroll along the defensive walls for breathtaking panoramic views over the English Channel and the distant silhouette of the Chausey archipelago.

Discover the beautiful sandy beaches of Granville that stretch beneath the imposing cliffs of the upper town. These pristine shores offer a perfect blend of seaside relaxation and dramatic coastal scenery, with the tides revealing fascinating rock formations and tide pools teeming with marine life.

Granville occupies a rocky promontory closing off Mont-Saint-Michel Bay. Cross through the Grand'Porte—once a drawbridge—to enter the fortified Upper Town, walled by the English in the 15th century. Cobbled streets, 16th- and 18th-century granite houses, and ramparts with 360-degree views await.

Villa 'Les Rhumbs,' the couturier's childhood home, perches on a cliff ridge facing the Chausey Islands. The English-style garden, laid out by his mother Madeleine, features a rose garden, a fragrance garden, and a reflecting pool designed by the couturier himself.

Head down to the fishing port, France's leading shellfish harbor. Trawlers and trap boats bring back whelks, scallops, and lobsters. The ballet of boats moving with the tides animates the quay year-round.
Notre-Dame du Cap Lihou Church, in the Upper Town, houses remarkable furnishings and an imposing organ. The couturier was baptized here in 1908, beginning a lifelong connection to this granite town.
The Richard Anacréon Museum of Modern Art, installed in the former Paul Bert school in the Upper Town, presents paintings, graphic works, and rare books from the first half of the 20th century.
The Maison du Guet, set on the rampart with its twin turrets, once kept watch over the sea. From the wall-walk, the panorama stretches from the ports to the Chausey Islands scattered on the horizon.
Pointe d'Agon — discover the lighthouse keeper's view over the Sienne River estuary reserve
Coutances — lift your eyes to the heaven-piercing Gothic spires of Notre-Dame Cathedral
Coutances — find tranquility in the terraced Bishop's Park and public gardens
Granville — explore the fortified Upper Town and walk the granite ramparts to Pointe du Roc
Granville — feel the power of the waves at Cap Lihou Lighthouse
Granville — wander the clifftop gardens where Christian Dior found his love of flowers
Chausey Islands — step ashore in Europe's largest archipelago at the tiny Blainvillais village
Chausey Islands — circle the historic Fort and Lambert Tower guarding the harbor
Chausey Islands — discover hidden coves and watch for seals basking on the rocks

activities.text: Shuttles/on foot — footbridge crossing and photo session (tide rises/falls)
Mortain — viewpoint over the bocage (photo stop)
Granville — walk on the dike and Plat Gousset beach

Embark on an unforgettable boat excursion to the Chausey Islands, a stunning archipelago featuring 365 islets at low tide and 52 at high tide. This maritime adventure reveals one of Europe's most remarkable tidal environments, where crystal-clear waters, white sand beaches, and abundant wildlife create a pristine natural sanctuary just offshore from the mainland.

Board a boat from the maritime station to the Chausey archipelago: 350 islets at low tide, about fifty at high tide. Only the Grande Île is inhabited. Its former granite quarries provided stone for Mont-Saint-Michel's construction.

Stroll the Plat Gousset promenade, a waterfront lined with bathing cabins and Belle Époque villas. The sandy beach stretches below the Upper Town's granite walls, a striking juxtaposition of nature and fortification.
Walk around the Pointe du Roc headland on the coastal path. At the lighthouse's base, rehabilitated World War II bunkers offer a vantage point over Mont-Saint-Michel Bay.

Granville's Carnival, inscribed on UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage list, brings the town alive for five days with floats, confetti battles, and balls. It's a spectacular event if you're passing through in late February.
Harbor walk — watch the fishing boats unload their catch at the working fish market
Narrated boat tour — navigate between 52 islands at high tide, 365 at low tide

visits.text: Grasse, world capital of perfume since the Middle Ages, exhales its secrets through the old town's ochre and yellow facades.
The International Perfume Museum traces 4,000 years of perfume, soap, makeup, and cosmetics history across 3,500 m².
Visit historic perfumeries: copper stills, secret laboratories, packaging rooms where legendary fragrances are born.
The MIP Gardens spread their 2.5 hectares of May roses, jasmine, orange trees, and violets at the foot of olive-covered hills.
Notre-Dame du Puy Cathedral raises its medieval walls at the heart of the historic center, housing masterpiece paintings.
Climb to Gourdon village, one of France's most beautiful: vertiginous peak at 760 meters, castle with gardens designed by Le Nôtre, panorama over the Mediterranean.
Visit to Fragonard perfumery and perfume creation workshop.
Discovery of the International Perfume Museum.

days_plan.itin_title: Europe's Volcanic Landscapes: Auvergne, Eifel & Lake Como Comparison

visits.text: Visit the largest Renaissance château in southeastern France, perched on a 33-meter rocky promontory. Mentioned as early as the 11th century as a fortress, it was transformed during the Renaissance into a sumptuous residence. The Marquise de Sévigné stayed here during three long visits and died here in 1696. Admire the Adhémar Gallery, the Tinel hall, the Prelates' wing, and Madame de Grignan's chamber in the former medieval keep.

Stroll the famous terraces built atop the Saint-Sauveur collegiate church that offer unforgettable 360° panoramas of Provence. The view extends to La Lance mountain, Mont Ventoux, and the Dentelles de Montmirail. Madame de Sévigné wrote: 'It is even pleasant not to be tempted to leave your beautiful terraces.'

Explore this charming medieval village ranked among France's Most Beautiful Villages that hugs the contours of the rocky promontory. Reach the village via steep alleys where you can admire the 14th-century belfry and superb 15th-century houses. The village cultivates both its literary heritage and its terroir: PDO vineyards, truffle grounds, lavender fields.

Visit this collegiate church built in the 16th century, one of the first buildings listed as a Historical Monument in 1840. The Renaissance façade features two symmetrical square towers. Madame de Sévigné was interred in this collegiate church on April 18, 1696. She still rests in this history-laden place.

activities.text: Discover Madame de Sévigné's apartments, the painting collection from the 16th to 20th centuries, and the interpretation space tracing the château's architectural evolution. Guided tours illuminate daily life of Provençal nobility in the 17th century. Possibly attend one of the many concerts held in the Adhémar Gallery.

Walk through the surrounding landscapes where vineyards, lavender, and truffle grounds create a typically Provençal mosaic of colors. In June-July, blooming lavender fields offer an unforgettable spectacle with the château as backdrop.

Visit producers directly and the village's fine restaurants to discover local gastronomy. Taste Grignan-les-Adhémar PDO wines, Côtes-du-Rhône, Tricastin black truffles, Nyons olive oil, and goat cheeses.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir

visits.text: Grimaud Castle, built in the 11th century, preserves its three enclosures, two massive round towers, and a medieval keep. Pillaged during the Revolution, its ruins still offer a panorama over the Gulf of Saint-Tropez and the Maures massif. In summer, the ramparts host the Grimaldines festival.

Saint-Michel church, a 12th-century Romanesque structure, is a classified historic monument. Its typically Provençal architecture contrasts with the Penitents' chapels and Saint-Roch, whose restored mural paintings illuminate medieval devotion.

Get lost in the village's cobbled lanes: Rue des Arcades houses the Templars' house, a fine 16th-century Renaissance building adorned with three Gothic arches. Mullioned windows and doorways framed with serpentinite punctuate the stroll.

The Saint-Roch mill, a 17th-century windmill restored in 1990 by the Companions of the Tour de France, crowns the village on its hill. On the ground, a large slab was used for threshing wheat; beside it, an old press produced olive oil.

Reach the Pont des Fées via a 3 km loop from the mill. This 15th-century arched bridge spans the Garde and served as an aqueduct to supply the village with water. The trail follows the river through a cool, shaded valley.

activities.text: Port-Grimaud, a lakeside town created in the 1960s by architect François Spoerry, can be explored by boat on its canals. Each house has direct water access and a mooring ring. The 'Provençal Venice' can also be discovered on foot from the village.
The Provençal markets of Grimaud and Port-Grimaud alternate throughout the week. Local producers and artisans offer fruits, cheeses, olive oil, and art objects in a lively atmosphere.
Several wine estates around the village offer tastings of AOC Côtes de Provence wines. The Grimaud wine cooperative allows you to sample local vintages straight from the source.

days_plan.itin_title: Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: Circular village and Barberousse Tower — Former fishing village built in a spiral around the Barberousse Tower, remnant of a 10th-century castle reinforced in 1247. Site at 35 m altitude, panoramic views over lagoons and the Clape massif.

Stilted beach chalets — 1,330 colorful chalets lined up in 11 rows facing the sea. First appeared around 1850, destroyed in 1943, rebuilt on stilts in the 1950s. Made famous by the film "Betty Blue" (37°2 le matin).
Île Saint-Martin salt pans — 400 hectares of salt marshes worked since Antiquity. Pink salt tables in summer, flamingos, stilts, avocets. Guided tours available.

activities.text: Beach and Clape massif — 15 km of beaches including the Chalets beach. 15,000-hectare Natura 2000 massif, views from the Pech Redon (214 m).
Oyster tasting — Oyster farms around the lagoon. Tasting at the producer, views over the lagoon.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean

visits.text: Saint Leger Church raises its twin Romanesque towers from the 12th century. Its carved portal and Gothic choir exemplify Rhineland art.
The Dominican Convent transformed into a cultural center preserves its Gothic cloister and 13th-century vaults. Carved capitals narrate medieval monastic life.
Notre-Dame Church built in the 18th century expresses neoclassical restraint. Its Callinet organ resonates beneath the central dome.
The Théodore Deck Museum traces the work of Guebwiller's celebrated ceramicist who became director of the Sèvres Manufactory. Enameled faience and Art Nouveau creations gleam in the cases.
The Florival Valley opens toward Grand Ballon. The Lauch River descends from the Vosges through meadows and beech forests.

activities.text: Guebwiller's vineyards cling to vertiginous terraced slopes. The only commune in Alsace producing four Grands Crus: Kessler, Kitterlé, Saering, and Spiegel.
Domaines Schlumberger cultivates 130 hectares—more than half in Grand Cru vineyards. Take a 4x4 tour through slopes reaching 50 degrees, followed by a commented tasting.
The wine trail climbs between vine rows facing due south. Gewurztraminer and Riesling thrive on this limestone terroir between 250 and 390 meters elevation.

days_plan.itin_title: Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route

visits.text: Guérande's medieval walls stretch for 1,400 meters in an unbroken ring. Walk the rampart path from the Porte Saint-Michel for panoramic views over the salt marshes and the slate-roofed old town clustered within.

The Collégiale Saint-Aubin dominates the skyline with its bell tower-porch. Romanesque carved capitals and Gothic vaulting reflect five centuries of construction, each era leaving its architectural mark.
Step into the Terre de Sel visitor center amid the working marshes. Modern exhibits and live demonstrations reveal how white gold is still harvested entirely by hand.
Wander cobbled lanes lined with half-timbered houses. Saturday's market fills the Place du Marché-au-Bois beneath 15th-century timber halls, just as it has for centuries.
The Château de Careil preserves Renaissance furniture and 15th-century timber framing. Its water-filled moat mirrors the fortified manor's storybook silhouette.

activities.text: Join the paludiers in the crystallizing ponds to watch salt harvesting in action. From June through September, they rake coarse salt and hand-gather delicate fleur de sel with traditional wooden tools.
Cycle the paths between basins and dikes. Five thousand acres of salt marshes form a silver checkerboard that reflects the sky, crisscrossed by paths perfect for exploring by bike.
Sample oysters and pink shrimp at the oyster shacks in Trescalan. The clay-rich tidal flats give the oysters their distinctive briny intensity.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire-Atlantique Road Trip: Nantes and the Jade Coast

visits.text: The Museum of Art and Archaeology of Guéret, housed in the Hôtel des Moneyroux, a 15th-century mansion, shelters eclectic collections: paintings of the Creuse valley by Guillaumin, Madeline and Alluaud, Limousin enamels, regional archaeology, Asian arts. The collection of Chinese and Japanese porcelains is among the finest in the provinces.

The Hôtel des Moneyroux itself deserves attention: this Renaissance residence with mullioned windows and sculpted staircase tower testifies to the prosperity of the Creuse bourgeoisie in the 15th century. The inner courtyard and rooms with French-style ceilings compose a refined setting for the collections.

The town center of Guéret, prefecture of Creuse, preserves some mansions and Place Bonnyaud bordered by old houses. The Saint-Pierre church, remodeled over the centuries, presents a Romanesque portal. The town remains human-scale, conducive to strolling between shops and café terraces.

activities.text: The Animal Park of the Monts de Guéret, in the heart of Chabrières forest, offers an immersion in wolf territory. Created in 2001, it welcomes about fifty wolves in semi-freedom across six enclosures, the largest reaching 19,000 m². European gray wolves, Canadian white wolves, black wolves: from observation points and the watchtower, observe their natural pack behaviors.

The Giant Labyrinth of the Monts de Guéret, near the wolf park, unfolds its hedges over more than 6 hectares. Thematic questionnaires guide visitors through the plant maze. Mini-farm, skill course, educational space on sustainable development, and aquagliss complete this fun site ideal for families.

The Chabrières forest envelops the tourist sites of the Monts de Guéret. Hiking and mountain biking trails crisscross this forest massif where oaks, beeches, and conifers alternate. The sylvan atmosphere contributes to the spirit of the animal park, placing wolves in an almost natural environment.
