visits.text: Château d'Haroué displays 365 windows, 52 chimneys, 12 towers, and 4 bridges. Between 1720 and 1729, Germain Boffrand integrated the medieval castle's towers and moats into his baroque masterpiece.
Marc de Beauvau-Craon commissioned this residence from the same architect who designed Lunéville château. The princely family still lives here after eight generations.
The grand staircase features ironwork by Jean Lamour, who also created the gates of Place Stanislas. The Beauvau family tree covers the wall.
The Pillement salon reveals Chinese paintings in a round tower. This boudoir also served as a music room.

activities.text: The French-style gardens spread before the château. Emilio Terry designed them in 1957 with perspectives over the Saintois region.
The château moats are still fed by the Madon river. The walk around the moats offers different perspectives on the baroque architecture.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: Hartmannswillerkopf—nicknamed Vieil Armand—dominates the Alsatian plain from 956 meters. This strategic spur contested throughout the Great War claimed 30,000 French and German soldiers.
The National Monument carved into bedrock shelters a crypt where 12,000 unknown soldiers rest. Two winged bronze Victories sculpted by Antoine Bourdelle guard the entrance.

The Altar of the Fatherland overlooks the Silberloch necropolis. Inspired by the 1790 Federation altar, it bears the coats of arms of twelve donor cities. President Albert Lebrun inaugurated it in 1932.

The Franco-German Historial inaugurated in 2017 by Presidents Macron and Steinmeier traces the battles and the building of Franco-German friendship. Modern scenography and war archives tell the story.
The battlefield preserves kilometers of trenches carved into sandstone. Underground shelters, barbed wire networks, and shell craters testify to the 1915 fighting.

activities.text: Walk the historical trail through French and German trenches. Interpretive panels explain strategic positions and the murderous offensives that swept back and forth.
From Rocher panorama, climb to the Aussichtsfelsen viewpoint. Clear views extend across the southern Alsatian plain, Mulhouse, Basel, and in good weather the Bernese Alps.
Pay respects in the necropolis that gathers 1,640 bodies including 384 unknowns interred in six ossuaries. Each cross bears a name, a regiment, a date.

days_plan.itin_title: Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route

visits.text: Perched on a rocky spur of the Meuse Heights, Hattonchâtel village overlooks the Woëvre plain by 80 meters. Fortified in the 9th century by Hatton, Bishop of Verdun, it preserves the 12th-14th century vaulted house, the 14th-century arcaded house, and a 1921 washhouse inspired by medieval and Japanese design.

The Saint-Maur collegiate church houses the Hattonchâtel altarpiece (1523), attributed to sculptor Ligier Richier. This polychrome stone triptych depicts three Passion of Christ scenes in a setting borrowed from the Italian Renaissance: scroll pilasters, interlaced motifs, and basket-handle arches.

The 14th-century cloister, of which only one gallery remains, adjoins the church. Stained glass windows by Jacques Grüber, Nancy master glassmaker, illuminate the nave with colored reflections. The 16th-century calvary outside completes this ensemble classified as Historic Monuments.

The castle, rebuilt in the 1920s thanks to American patron Belle Skinner, blends medieval fantasy with Norman checkerboard stonework. A private property housing a hotel, it can be visited by appointment. From the esplanade, the panorama extends over the Meuse Heights, mirabelle orchards, and Lake Madine.

Climb to the Montsec Butte (375 m) to discover the American memorial erected in honor of troops who reduced the Saint-Mihiel salient in September 1918. The bronze orientation table and circular colonnade offer a 360° panorama over the Woëvre plain and Lake Madine.

activities.text: Cycle around Lake Madine: a 20-kilometer bike path circles this large body of water ideal for water sports, swimming, and observing migratory birds.
Wander through Hattonchâtel's lanes following the arcaded street. Bucolic gardens border village houses and viewpoints offer views over the vineyards and orchards of the northern Meuse Heights.
Want to taste the terroir? Producers of the Meuse Heights offer gray, white, and red wines from Lorraine grape varieties with tangy and fruity aromas.

days_plan.itin_title: Meuse Circuit: Verdun and the Citadels

visits.text: Step through the great gate of the castle. 900 years of history await. Kaiser Wilhelm II had it restored by architect Bodo Ebhardt between 1900 and 1908.
The lower courtyard houses a forge, mill, and inn. The ramparts stretch over 270 metres. Two artillery towers flank the great bastion.
The lord's apartments retain their furniture and décor. The banqueting hall carries political weight: the imperial eagle towers over the Alsatian coats of arms.
The medieval garden grows aromatic and medicinal plants. The beds with woven borders are called plessis and protect against wild animals.

activities.text: From the great bastion, the panorama stretches to the Swiss Alps on a clear day. The Alsace plain, the Black Forest, and the Vosges spread out before you.
Theatrical tours bring the castle to life. Costumed actors recount medieval life. Children and adults alike travel back in time.

days_plan.itin_title: Alsace and the Wine Route: Strasbourg to the Vosges

visits.text: Hauteville-Lompnes unfolds on a plateau at 800 meters altitude, benefiting from an exceptional climate that earned it the nickname 'Little Switzerland.' The town developed in the 19th century thanks to tuberculosis sanatoria that attracted thousands of patients. Period architecture, large parks, and tree-lined avenues testify to this past. Today, medical institutions have been converted while preserving their heritage character.

The Church of Saint-Pierre, rebuilt in the 19th century, stands out with its imposing neo-Gothic facade. The interior houses remarkable stained glass windows and period religious furniture. The bell tower serves as a landmark visible from the entire plateau. The peaceful square invites contemplation while enjoying pure mountain air.

Walk through the Vallon park, a green oasis in the heart of town. Century-old trees, flowerbeds, and winding paths create a romantic atmosphere inherited from the sanatorium era. The arboretum presents rare species adapted to mountain climate. Children's play areas and picnic tables attract families. The park hosts outdoor concerts in summer.

The Plateau de Retord, accessible by small mountain roads, offers spectacular wild landscapes. Vast expanses of meadows alternate with dense forests. The plateau, at 1200 meters altitude, serves as a Nordic skiing area in winter. In summer, hikers discover intact nature and exceptional panoramas extending to Mont Blanc. Marmots and chamois can be observed with binoculars.

activities.text: Cross-country ski on the Plateau de Retord, one of the finest Nordic domains in the region. Fifty kilometers of groomed trails wind through forests and clearings. All difficulty levels are represented, from gentle beginner loops to demanding courses for experts. Equipment rental and ski lessons are offered on site. The snowy landscapes and pure air create a magical atmosphere.

Hike the marked trails crossing Bugey mountains. The Crêt du Nu trail climbs to a belvedere offering 360-degree views of the Alps and Jura. The route passes through spruce forests, mountain pastures, and rocky passages. Diverse flora includes gentians, edelweiss, and rare orchids. The approximately 3-hour round trip is accessible to regular hikers.

Discover local gastronomy featuring mountain products. Restaurants serve comté cheese, smoked meats, blueberry tart, and Bugey wines. Some establishments perpetuate recipes from the sanatorium era when refined cuisine aided patient recovery. The warm atmosphere and hearty portions embody mountain conviviality.

Visit the Wednesday morning market that brings together local producers. Mountain cheese makers, vegetable gardeners, beekeepers offer quality products. Direct sales and advice from producers make shopping a moment of authentic exchange. Regional specialties - honey, jams, liqueurs - reflect mountain terroir wealth.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: Inside the Église Saint-Sindulphe lies Dom Pérignon's tomb. The Benedictine monk perfected the art of champagne-making here from 1668 to 1715.
Look up to discover nearly 140 wrought-iron signs adorning the village facades. Each one tells a story of local crafts and village life.
In the Parc Pierre Cheval stands a bronze statue of Dom Pérignon. A striking mural traces the village's winemaking heritage across the centuries.

activities.text: Follow marked trails through the vineyard slopes. The panoramas across the Marne Valley reveal the same landscape that inspired Dom Pérignon's genius.
Visit the village's independent winemakers. Taste champagnes produced from these historic UNESCO-listed slopes.

days_plan.itin_title: Marne Road Trip: Reims, Épernay and the Champagne Route

visits.text: Espelette: traditional streets and facades, old castle, Saint-Étienne church, covered market.
Basque Corniche – Domaine d'Abbadia (Hendaye): coastal path and sculpted cliffs.

activities.text: Summit of Mondarrain (from Espelette/Itxassou): panoramic hike (moderate level).
Scenic road climb to Artzamendi: photo stops and short walk on the ridges.

days_plan.itin_title: Béarn & Basque Country: Pyrenean Passes to Atlantic Coast Soul

visits.text: The Broërec'h Gate frames two massive towers with pepper-pot roofs. Restored after the 1944 bombardments, it houses the museum of art and traditions of Lower Brittany.
Walk along the restored rampart walkway. The view plunges down over the town and the Blavet River. The fortifications bear witness to the walled town's medieval past.
The Basilica of Notre-Dame-du-Paradis soars in flamboyant Gothic style. Its spire reaches 213 feet. The Max Ingrand stained glass from the 1950s retraces Hennebont's history.
The National Stud has occupied the former Cistercian abbey of La Joie since 1857. Inaugurated by Napoleon III, it's the birthplace of the Breton draft horse breed. Classified as a historic monument.
Visit the Napoleonic stables of the Haras. The museum space recounts horse-related trades: farrier, saddler, blacksmith. The ceremonial tack room preserves its original tools.
The port of Hennebont extends at the foot of the railway viaduct. Once a commercial route on the Blavet, it now offers a peaceful stroll away from the bustle.

activities.text: Thursday's market is the largest in the Lorient area. Breton products, crêpes, and kouign-amann on the stalls.
Watch an equestrian show under the Haras big top. Mounted performers present Breton draft horses and acrobatic acts.
The Kerbihan Botanical Park covers 25 acres. 400 tree and flower species from around the world. The refreshing bamboo grove evokes Asia.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: Henrichemont is a 17th-century utopian city. Founded in 1609 by the Duke of Sully, Henri IV's minister, it was meant to be the capital of the Principality of Boisbelle — an independent micro-state where no taxes were paid. The planned layout: a perfect 500-meter square, eight streets radiating from a central square to the city gates. Inspired by Italian ideal cities and Charleville, its contemporary.

Henri IV's assassination in 1610 and Sully's disgrace froze the project. Only the pavilions around the central square were completed. You can recognize Salomon de Brosse's style — the architect of the Luxembourg Palace in Paris — in the pediment facades and ornate dormers. The Hôtel du Bœuf, Hôtel des Monnaies and Maison du Procureur fiscal testify to what should have been.

The Principality of Boisbelle, of which Henrichemont was the capital, remained independent until 1779. No royal taxes, its own justice system, currency minted on site. Louis XV eventually bought back these privileges, ending four centuries of autonomy. A small museum tells this unique story.

activities.text: The "Balade de Sully" is a 4h50 circuit around Henrichemont. You cross oak and beech forests, sleepy hamlets, fish ponds. Cher Pas-à-Pas waymarking. Bring water and a picnic.

From Henrichemont, the Menetou-Salon and Sancerre vineyards are less than 20 minutes away. Menetou-Salon produces whites (Sauvignon) and reds (Pinot noir) in the same style as its neighbor, often at gentler prices. The Château de Menetou-Salon, property of Prince d'Arenberg, can be visited in season.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: Convent of the Visitation.
Cluny Abbey (largest medieval church).
Ursulines Museum.

activities.text: Schneider industrial heritage.
Pilgrimage.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: Hérisson, medieval city labeled Petite Cité de Caractère, sits perched above Aumance gorges. The picturesque site reveals rampart remains, fortified gates and old houses (15th-17th centuries). The Porte de Varenne and Porte de la Bade mark former medieval enclosure entrances. Views over valley and surrounding forests are spectacular.

The fortress ruins dominate the village from their rocky promontory. Towers, curtain walls and keep vestiges testify to this strategic stronghold's medieval power. The Bourbon coat of arms carved in stone recalls lords who controlled this border territory. Climb the ramparts for panoramic views over Combrailles.

The Saint-Pierre church (12th-15th centuries) mixes Romanesque and Gothic styles. The carved portal and interior capitals display medieval stonemason art. Stained glass windows from various periods illuminate the modest nave testifying to village religious life through the ages.

Walk along Aumance discovering old wash houses and mills lining the river. The green banks invite peaceful strolls in nature. Footbridges and footpaths allow exploring gorges where water carved a picturesque path through rock.

activities.text: Hiking trails depart from Hérisson village exploring surrounding forests and valleys. Marked paths wind through woods, meadows and along Aumance. Several loops allow 2 to 4 hour walks discovering preserved natural and built heritage.

The artisan market in summer brings village to life with regional product stalls. Local producers offer cheeses, cured meats, jams and crafts. The friendly atmosphere invites tasting and conversation with artisans.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: Hesdin: medieval town of the 7 Valleys, belfry & Notre-Dame.

activities.text: Nature loop in the forest of the 7 Valleys.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-France: Opal Coast Cliffs, Medieval History & Great War Sites

visits.text: Honfleur's Vieux Bassin sparkles with colourful façades reflected in the calm harbour waters. The tall shipowners' houses from the 16th to 18th centuries frame this picturesque port that inspired Boudin, Monet and the Impressionist painters. The Lieutenance, the former governor's residence, has guarded the harbour entrance since 1600.

The Church of Sainte-Catherine, the largest wooden church in France, unfolds its twin naves in the shape of an upturned ship's hull. Built in the 15th century by naval carpenters after the Hundred Years' War, it astonishes with its unique architecture. Its separate bell tower, an oak structure atop the bell-ringer's house, now houses an annex of the Eugène Boudin Museum.
Discover the Eugène Boudin Museum dedicated to Norman Impressionism. Works by Boudin, Monet, Courbet and Dubourg trace the artistic adventure born on these shores of light.
Honfleur — Old Basin, half-timbered streets, art galleries.
Pont de Normandie — viewpoint over the estuary (quick).
Saint-Aubin-sur-Mer (Calvados) — seafront & villas.
Route to Honfleur through the Norman countryside.
Discovery of Honfleur harbor and Sainte-Catherine church.
Walk along the Old Basin and visit to art galleries.
Honfleur — frame the perfect postcard shot of slate-roofed houses reflected in the Old Harbor
Honfleur — find bronze busts of artists and writers hidden throughout the Garden of Personalities
Honfleur — choose your cultural treasure: the Boudin Museum, Maritime Museum, or whimsical Satie House
Deauville — stroll the legendary Boardwalk past beach cabins named for film stars

activities.text: Stroll through the Sainte-Catherine quarter with its cobbled medieval lanes. Art galleries, designer boutiques and artists' studios enliven this maze of half-timbered houses.
Savour Honfleur's gastronomy in one of the restaurants overlooking the Vieux Bassin. Fresh fish, moules marinières and Norman andouille are enjoyed facing the dance of sailboats.
Cross the Pont de Normandie, a technical marvel linking Honfleur to Le Havre. The panorama from this 2,141-metre cable-stayed bridge encompasses the Seine estuary and the Côte Fleurie.
Twilight walk around the port + sunset.
Relaxing return to Honfleur (galleries/cafés).
Architecture tour — trace Belle Époque timbered villas between Deauville and Trouville

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy
Normandy's Classic Coast: Étretat Cliffs and Bocage Countryside Villages
Normandy's Classic Coast: Étretat Cliffs and Bocage Countryside Villages
Paris to Bordeaux Heritage Route: Castles, Vineyards & French Flavors
Complete Normandy Road Trip: Dramatic Cliffs, D-Day Beaches & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Discovery of the surf beaches of Hossegor and Capbreton.
Walk around Lake Hossegor and the typical Landes villas.

La Gravière and La Nord surf spots: Hossegor's legendary waves are influenced by the Gouf de Capbreton, an underwater canyon extending to nearly 4,000m depth offshore. The canyon begins at shallow depth near the coast and deepens progressively. These beach breaks, among the most powerful on the planet, attract the world's best surfers during World Surf League competitions each autumn.

Basque-Landes villas: Explore the seafront and its interwar architecture designed by renowned architects (Godbarge, Lagrange, Pomade, Prunetti). The Sporting Casino, a classified historic monument, dominates the beach. These elegant residences with characteristic half-timbering and steep roofs embody the Basque-Landes style of the 1920s-1930s.

Lake Hossegor marine lagoon: This reshaped natural lagoon offers 6km of promenade lined with traditional oyster cabins and elegant villas. The lake's calm waters contrast with the power of the nearby ocean. The complete loop on foot or by bike showcases this unique landscape between fresh and salt water.

Place des Landais: Hossegor's beating heart with its cafes, restaurants and designer boutiques. The laid-back atmosphere mixes surfers, families and vacationers. The mural of La Vague celebrates the town's surf identity. Evening markets in summer with local products and crafts.

activities.text: Surf initiation on one of the legendary beaches of the Atlantic coast.

Surf lessons: Schools offer beginner courses and advanced coaching on spots suited to each level. South Beach suits beginners with more accessible waves. Equipment provided, maximum groups of 8. Booking advised in high season.

Lake loop by bike: 6km of flat bike path around the marine lake. The route offers beautiful views of oyster cabins and allows for tasting stops. Bike rental downtown and near the lake. Allow 45min to 1h depending on stops.

Oyster tasting on the lake: Oyster cabins offer tastings facing the water. Marennes-Oléron oysters accompanied by local white wine. Authentic atmosphere lakeside, feet in the sand. Open year-round, arrive before 12:30pm in season.

Bike paths through the forest: 40km of greenways connecting Hossegor to neighboring towns through the Landes pine forest. Shaded and flat routes, perfect for exploring the region. Connection to the Vélodyssée, the European Atlantic bike route. Electric bike rental available.

days_plan.itin_title: Southwest France Journey: Atlantic Coast to Pyrenees Mountain Peaks
Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: Houdan's keep, a 25-meter cylindrical tower flanked by four corner turrets, was erected between 1125 and 1132 by Amaury III de Montfort. Restored between 2014 and 2016, its 250 steps lead to panoramic views over the Yvelines countryside.

The Church of Saint-Jacques-Saint-Christophe blends Flamboyant Gothic and Renaissance styles. It preserves a 1734 Clicquot organ, a rare classical instrument kept intact, and a 1582 fresco depicting the Montserrat pilgrimage.
Houdan's market hall recalls the commercial past of this rural town. 17th- and 18th-century half-timbered houses line neighboring streets, forming a preserved setting.

activities.text: The traditional Houdan market brings the town center to life each week. Free-range poultry, cheeses, and seasonal vegetables: local producers hold their stalls in the shadow of the keep.
Walk through the old town to spot half-timbered façades, interior courtyards, and carved details on door lintels.
Take country paths around Houdan for a pastoral walk between grain fields and groves. The rolling landscape evokes nearby Normandy.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

visits.text: Fortified church on its hillock, surrounded by vineyards in an amphitheater.
Narrow streets and half-timbered houses of the lower village.
Views of Ribeauvillé and Riquewihr.

The fortified church of Saint-Jacques-le-Majeur (15th-16th century) stands in the middle of the vines, surrounded by its cemetery encircled by a hexagonal crenellated wall. This enclosure served as refuge for villagers in times of danger. The building, simultaneously Catholic and Protestant, is a rare case of simultaneum.

Half-timbered winemakers' houses line the main street, adorned with dated carriage gates and sculpted signs. The village, classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages, has barely 600 inhabitants.
The village backs onto Grand Cru Rosacker, a terroir of muscats and rieslings renowned for their minerality. The vines descend in gentle slopes toward the plain.
The 18th-century washhouse, fed by a spring, and Renaissance fountains punctuate the stroll through flower-filled alleys.

activities.text: Loop of vineyard stone walls and wayside crosses (3–4 km).
Climb to the walled cemetery for landscape reading.
The Stork and Otter Reintroduction Center presents these two emblematic Alsatian species. Free-roaming storks, otter feeding show and birds of prey aviary compose the visit.
The Exotic Butterfly Gardens, under tropical greenhouse, shelter hundreds of species in free flight among orchids and tropical plants.
Reach Riquewihr on foot via the wine trail (2 km). The path crosses the plots of Rosacker and Schoenenbourg, two Grand Crus facing each other.

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages
Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: Half-timbered village lined along the main street and typical white farms.
Church and grassy squares, covered wells and washhouse.
Open landscapes of the Outre-Forêt and historic agricultural paths.

activities.text: Traditional building interpretation trail (2 km).
Country walk towards forest edges (4–6 km).

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Walk on the port of Hyères and discovery of the beaches of the Giens peninsula.

Built in the 1920s by architect Robert Mallet-Stevens, Villa Noailles is a classified modernist masterpiece. Gabriel Guévrékian's cubist garden offers panoramic views of the Golden Islands. The villa hosts year-round exhibitions and festivals celebrating fashion, design, and avant-garde art.

Below the villa, Parc Saint-Bernard unfolds its narrow terraces linked by stone staircases. The botanical garden gathers Mediterranean and exotic species: rosemary, wisteria, and rare plants that thrive in this microclimate.

Jardins Olbius-Riquier spreads across seven hectares of greenery. An exotic greenhouse shelters palms, bamboo, banana trees, and cacti. The pond and its cascade offer refreshing coolness in summer. Free admission year-round.

Climb up to the Collégiale Saint-Paul, adorned with ex-votos, then wind back down through the steep alleys of the old town. The Templars' Tower, a medieval vestige of the order, can be visited with a treasure hunt for children.

The ruins of the medieval castle crown a rocky peak at the town's summit. Dating from the 11th century, it offers a panorama over Hyères Bay, the Golden Islands, and the Maures massif. Free access via the ruin trail from Villa Noailles.

Visit the archaeological site of Olbia, a Greek trading post founded in the 4th century BCE. Excavations reveal ramparts, dwellings, and Roman baths by the sea—a tangible link to ancient Mediterranean commerce.

activities.text: Relaxation on the beaches and swimming in the Mediterranean Sea.
On Saturday mornings, the Îles d'Or market takes over the old town. Seasonal fruits, tapenade, soaps, and local crafts fill the stalls under the plane trees in a scene of timeless Provençal charm.

Follow the coastal trail around the Giens peninsula. Between salt marshes, pine groves, and coves, the route traces the salt road and its marshes where flamingos and grey herons pause—a walker's paradise of biodiversity.
Craving the beach? L'Almanarre beach, a long ribbon of sand between sea and salt pans, is renowned for windsurfing and kitesurfing thanks to steady winds that make it a mecca for wave riders.

days_plan.itin_title: Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages
Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: Old town of Île Rousse
Place Paoli
Pietra peninsula and its lighthouse

Place Paoli spreads its century-old plane trees through the heart of L'Île-Rousse. Founded in 1758 by Pasquale Paoli to compete with Genoese Calvi, the town retains its orthogonal layout. The covered market with its 21 columns in antique style, built between 1844 and 1846 and classified as a Historic Monument, hosts stalls of charcuterie, cheese, and honey every morning.

The island of La Pietra is reached by a causeway from the marina. Red porphyry rocks give the town its name (Isola Rossa in Italian). The white lighthouse built in 1875, fully automated and solar-powered, offers panoramic views of the coast and the islets of Roccio, Roccetto, and Piano. The 15th-century Genoese tower stands watch over the waves.

The Church of the Immaculate Conception overlooks Place Paoli. Inaugurated in 1893, partially destroyed by fire in 1914, then rebuilt in 1935. Architecture blending baroque and neoclassical styles. Two 17th-century paintings from the Fesch collection adorn the interior.

activities.text: Bodri beach - wild beach

The Marinella promenade runs along Napoléon beach on the waterfront. A pedestrian path beneath palms with views of the island of La Pietra. The bronze Siren statue (A Sirenella di l'Isula Rossa) has perched on a granite rock since 2016. Best at sunset when the rocks turn crimson.

The beach train connects L'Île-Rousse to Calvi along the coast. U trinichellu stops at all the Balagne beaches: Bodri, Ghjunchitu, Algajola. A scenic journey at leisurely pace discovering coves and maquis. A relaxing alternative to driving for exploring the coastline.

The beaches of Bodri and Ghjunchitu stretch to the southwest 3-5 kilometers away. The finest sand in Corsica, translucent waters. Naturist zone at the northern end of Bodri. Access via coastal path from L'Île-Rousse or paid parking in season.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Corsica Road Trip: Granite Cliffs, Mountain Passes & Island Beaches
Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Tante Léonie's House - Marcel Proust Museum, a world literary pilgrimage site. In this 19th-century bourgeois home, young Marcel spent his holidays between 1877 and 1880. The quaint kitchen, Marcel's and Tante Léonie's bedrooms inspired the immortal pages of 'Swann's Way.'

Pré Catelan of Illiers-Combray, exotic garden created by Proust's uncle that became 'Swann's park' in In Search of Lost Time. From this haven of greenery, the Beauce plains stretch as far as the eye can see, inspiring the writer's contemplative descriptions. A place for literary meditation.

Church of Saint-Jacques in Illiers-Combray, whose painted framework in bright colors and boat-shaped vault captivated young Marcel. This is where he would place Combray's church in his novel, with its stained glass windows filtering light like 'a historical sun.'

Proustian circuit through Illiers-Combray, renamed in 1971 for the writer's birth centenary. The streets, squares, and houses correspond to locations in In Search of Lost Time: discover the 'Méséglise way' and the 'Guermantes way' that the narrator walked as a child.

activities.text: Tasting of artisanal madeleines at La Madeleine de Proust, those little scallop-shell-shaped cakes that made Illiers world-famous. The flavor of this madeleine dipped in tea triggered in Proust the flood of memories that became the most celebrated in French literature.

Hike along the paths of the surrounding Beauce countryside, where wheat fields undulate to the horizon as in Proust's time. The landscape has hardly changed in a century, offering total immersion in the world of In Search of Lost Time.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure-et-Loir Circuit: Chartres, Châteaux & Proust

visits.text: Saint-Austremoine Abbey Church in Issoire, classified as a Historic Monument since 1840, is Lower Auvergne's largest Romanesque church at 213 feet long and 56 feet high under the vault. Its apse is a masterpiece of tiered volumes, adorned with small columns, capitals, sculpted modillions, geometric mosaics, and medallions depicting zodiac signs. Inside, polychromy restored by Anatole Dauvergne between 1857 and 1860 bursts in vivid hues that transform the edifice into a jewel box of unexpected color within the blonde arkose's austerity.

The choir's historiated capitals develop a complete cycle of Christ's Passion and Resurrection with exceptional narrative quality. The celebrated Last Supper, carved with remarkable expressiveness, ranks among Auvergne's finest Romanesque capitals. In the crypt, Saint-Austremoine's 12th-century reliquary and a 15th-century Last Judgment painting complete this major heritage ensemble.

Issoire's historic center, established in the Val d'Allier, reveals itself through colorful facades and red roofs contrasting with monuments' volcanic stone. The Georges-Duby Romanesque Art Center, housed in a classified chapter house, exhibits collections on Auvergne Romanesque art and hosts temporary exhibitions.

Saint-Austremoine Abbey Church in Issoire, classified as a Historic Monument since 1840, stands as Lower Auvergne's largest Romanesque church at 65 meters long and 17 meters high beneath the vault. Its chevet is a masterpiece of tiered volumes, adorned with colonnettes, capitals, sculpted modillons, geometric mosaics, and medallions depicting zodiac signs. Inside, the polychromy restored by Anatole Dauvergne between 1857 and 1860 explodes in vivid hues that transform the building into an unexpected jewel box within the golden arkose stone's austerity.

Issoire's historic center, established in the Val d'Allier, unfolds through colorful facades and red roofs contrasting with the volcanic stone monuments. The Georges-Duby Romanesque Art Center, installed in a classified chapter house, exhibits collections devoted to Auvergnat Romanesque art and hosts temporary exhibitions.

activities.text: Join guided abbey church tours organized in July-August and by reservation for groups year-round. A free activity booklet for 6-12 year olds, available at the Tourist Office, transforms church discovery into an architectural treasure hunt. The abbey opens daily 8:30 AM to 6:30 PM.

Experience the Issoire Romanesque Art Festival, a major cultural event running late July to early August. Concerts, lectures, performances, and themed visits celebrate the town and region's Romanesque heritage in programming that attracts specialists and curious visitors alike.
Walk along the Allier River near Issoire. The Val d'Allier offers wild river landscapes with pebble beaches, riparian forests, and volcanic cliffs—ideal for walking, cycling, or simply contemplation.

Join guided abbey tours organized July-August and by reservation for groups year-round. A free activity booklet for children ages 6-12, available at the Tourist Office, transforms church discovery into an architectural treasure hunt. The abbey is open daily 8:30 AM–6:30 PM.

Experience the Issoire Romanesque Art Festival, a major cultural event from late July to early August. Concerts, conferences, shows, and thematic tours celebrate the town's and region's Romanesque heritage in a program attracting specialists and curious visitors alike.

Walk along the Allier River around Issoire. The Val d'Allier offers wild river landscapes with gravel banks, riparian forests, and volcanic cliffs, ideal for walking, cycling, or simple contemplation.

VOLCANOES, ROMANESQUE STONE AND TRADITIONS OF AUVERGNE

visits.text: White Tower.
Saint-Roch Hospice Museum.
Basilica.

activities.text: Market (Saturday).
Festivals.

days_plan.itin_title: Indre, France: Secret Berry Region and Vallée Noire Rural Villages

visits.text: The Courvoisier house stands in its château on the banks of the Charente. Tour of the cellars including the famous 'Paradis' where the oldest eaux-de-vie age. Tasting overlooking the river.
The church of Saint-Pierre blends eras: 11th-century Romanesque foundations, a 12th-century crypt where the former Counts of Jarnac rest, later alterations. Tombs of the local lords in the crypt.

The Musée Donation François-Mitterrand occupies a former warehouse. State gifts received during his terms: paintings, sculptures, ceramics from around the world. The former president was born here and rests here.
The Jarnac quays line up trading houses and bourgeois residences. The Charente flows peacefully, white façades reflected in the water. Starting point for river cruises.

activities.text: Tour of the Courvoisier house. More low-key than the Cognac giants, with a family feel. The 'Paradis' cellar holds century-old eaux-de-vie. Tasting included.
River cruise Jarnac–Cognac. Licence-free barge for the day or guided gabare. The river winds between vineyards and villages. Manual locks, contemplative pace.
Visit to François Mitterrand's birthplace. The house where the former president was born in 1916. Guided tour by appointment, intimate atmosphere.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: Scenic route between Saint-Florentin and Migennes: landscapes of Yonne
Old town of Joigny: half-timbered houses and churches
Banks of the Yonne in Joigny: walk

Saint-Thibault Church, built between 1490 and 1529, blends flamboyant Gothic with early Renaissance influences. Its choir leans curiously to the left. Inside, admire the hanging vault keystones and Renaissance pulpit.
Château des Gondi, a Renaissance edifice, overlooks Joigny from the heights of the Saint-Jean quarter. The panorama embraces the entire town and Yonne valley.
At Place du Pilori, the Tree of Jesse House displays half-timbered carvings of Christ's genealogical tree, enhanced with polychrome ceramics. It's one of Burgundy's finest half-timbered houses.
The Bailli House, at 36 rue Montant-du-Palais, is a 16th-century tower house. Its façades bear Latin and Greek inscriptions dated 1573; its half-timbers are carved with scales and lozenges.
Saint-Jean Church, a castle chapel turned parish church in the 11th century, contains the tomb of Countess Aélis de Joigny (early 13th century) and a Renaissance Entombment of great refinement.
Cross the Pont Saint-Nicolas, long the only passage on the Paris-Lyon route. From the Baltard market halls, the view of half-timbered houses tiered in an amphitheater is striking.

activities.text: Self-guided heritage tour in Joigny
Climb into the vineyards of Côte Saint-Jacques, an AOC Bourgogne appellation. The trail offers an open view over the Yonne valley, between forests and grain fields.
Wander through Joigny's three historic quarters—Saint-Thibault, Saint-Jean, and Saint-André—linked by steep lanes, stairs, and narrow passages. Each quarter has its own personality and church.
The river port of Les Maillotins, at the foot of the old town, welcomes boaters between the Seine, the Canal de Bourgogne, and the Yonne. Landscaped banks invite strolling.
The Museum of the Resistance traces the action of Groupe Bayard, created in Joigny in 1940. Documents, photos, and period objects testify to the fight against the occupier.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul
Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: The Château du Grand Jardin is a pleasure pavilion built between 1533 and 1546 by the first Duke of Guise. The Renaissance façades rank among the most finely sculpted in the region. The Saint-Claude chapel preserves two caryatids rescued from the Guise tomb.
Enter the Renaissance-style garden classified as a Remarkable Garden: geometric parterres, verdant labyrinth, large orchard and a national collection of 500 boxwood specimens.
Notre-Dame church presents a remarkable Renaissance portal. Around it, half-timbered houses and private mansions recall that the Guise made Joinville the capital of their principality.
The Sainte-Croix chapel, in the cemetery, offers flamboyant Gothic style and magnificent stained glass from the early Troyes school.
The Auditoire de Justice testifies to the Renaissance momentum brought by the Guise. Its architecture expresses the judicial and political power of the lords of Joinville.
The Château du Grand Jardin was built between 1533 and 1546 by Claude de Lorraine, first Duke of Guise. This pleasure pavilion showcases Renaissance architecture imported from Italy.
The Saint-Claude chapel features a coffered vault adorned with high-relief motifs. Two caryatids representing Temperance and Justice survive from Claude de Lorraine's tomb.

The Renaissance garden extends across 4.5 hectares with compartmented parterres, boxwood topiaries, a verdant labyrinth, and orchards. The collection includes 139 boxwood and 56 yew topiaries—a National Collection.
The 19th-century romantic park unfolds its winding paths, rare plant groves, and centuries-old trees in picturesque arrangements.
The Renaissance Auditoire de Justice displays architectural style influenced by Italian campaigns. Notre-Dame church's portal also dates from this transformative period.

activities.text: Take the "Joinville, medieval city" circuit: from the site of the château d'en Haut, vanished stronghold of the Guise on the heights, down to the quai des Peceaux where the Marne flows.
Walk along the banks of the Marne and the canal locks. The calm of the towpath contrasts with the bustle of the Renaissance town.
The 19th-century romantic park, laid out as a continuation of the Grand Jardin, offers winding paths, groves of rare species and artificial streams.
Wander through this Petite Cité de Caractère's lanes. Follow the medieval town circuit from the upper château down to the Quai des Peceaux along the Marne.
Visit the Mon Moulin gardens in nearby Thonnance-lès-Joinville. Three National Collections of peonies flourish across 6,000 square meters.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests
Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: Gustave-Roussy Institute.
Bois de Vincennes nearby.
Seine-Marne confluence.

activities.text: Perfumes.
Ancient varieties.

days_plan.itin_title: Val-de-Marne, France: A Road Trip to Pleasure Gardens & Historic Lakeside Châteaux

visits.text: Josselin Château overlooks the Oust River. Three medieval towers on the river side. On the courtyard side, the Renaissance façade in carved granite unfolds like stone lacework. Home to the Rohan family since the 15th century.
The Doll and Toy Museum occupies the former stables. The Rohan collection includes over 3,000 dolls from the 19th century. Temporary exhibitions complement the visit.

The château gardens are arranged on three levels. The formal French garden designed by Achille Duchêne, who also worked at Vaux-le-Vicomte. The rose garden contains over 150 rose bushes. English-style park at the foot of the ramparts.

The Basilica of Notre-Dame-du-Roncier blends Romanesque and Flamboyant Gothic styles. The recumbent effigies of Olivier de Clisson and Marguerite de Rohan rest in the nave. The wrought-iron pulpit is the work of Eustache Roussin.
Climb the 138 steps of the basilica's bell tower. Panorama over the Oust, the château, and the medieval town. Legend tells that in 808 a peasant discovered a statue of the Virgin in a thornbush.

The Sainte-Croix quarter climbs the hillside. Restored in 2006, it's among Josselin's oldest neighborhoods. The 11th-century Sainte-Croix chapel overlooks the valley. Half-timbered houses and cobbled lanes.
The House of the Caryatids dates from 1538. Its carved half-timbered façades are classified as historic monuments. One of Josselin's oldest dwellings.

activities.text: From the riverside quay at the château's foot, embark by paddleboard, canoe, or electric boat on the Nantes-Brest Canal.
Cycle along the canal toward Rohan. 15 miles through the countryside. Possible stop at Timadeuc Abbey, which makes Timanoix cheese aged in walnut liqueur.
Every two years on July 14th, the medieval festival takes over the streets. Knights in armor, jugglers, musicians, and a medieval market recreate the era of the Dukes of Brittany.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: Ancient Noviodunum, now the commune of Jublains, is western France's most important Gallo-Roman site. Capital of the Gallic Diablintes people and founded in the 1st century AD, the city counted 3,000 to 4,000 inhabitants at its peak and served as a road junction connected to a dozen cities.
The Gallo-Roman temple on the road to Mayenne marks the town's origin. Rebuilt in stone after 65 AD, it testifies to the acceleration of Romanization in the mid-1st century.

The fortress is the site's most spectacular element and a monument unique in the Roman Empire. This fortified trapezoid measuring 117.50 × 104.25 meters wasn't a military camp as long believed, but probably a warehouse where taxes in kind and precious metals transited to Rome.

The theater, built around 80 AD and gifted to the city by merchant Orgétorix, sits on the plateau slope facing the Coëvrons hills. Initially fully circular in the 1st century, it was rebuilt as a semicircle in the 2nd. It still hosts cultural events today.

Beneath the current church hide the Roman baths, transformed into a place of worship as early as the 5th century. They occupied a square urban block 60 meters on each side with porticos, bathing rooms and shops—the heart of Roman social life.

The departmental archaeological museum, labeled Tourism and Disability, presents collections from the Bronze Age to the early Middle Ages: pottery, jewelry, coins, game pieces, terracotta Venus statuettes and fragments of the 'pillar with masks' evoking a theater scene.

activities.text: Follow the archaeological trail by spotting the 12 bronze discs set into the ground. They mark a pedestrian circuit between the temple, baths, theater and fortress, crossing the ancient Roman town's layout.
Continue to the Crafts Forum, a venue dedicated to artisanship built after the discovery of an ancient artisan quarter whose activity continues today.

Excavations have been ongoing since 2010 at Jublains: archaeologists and student volunteers are uncovering a vast Gallo-Roman complex—domus or macellum—along the Grazay road. A temporary exhibition accompanies each year's excavation season closing.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: Village of thirteen castles: defensive dwellings and 19th century industrial châteaux.

activities.text: "Castles and belvederes" loop (3–4 km).

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Juliénas, the northernmost cru of Beaujolais, unfolds its vineyards on granite hillsides that give character to its powerful and structured wines. Legend attributes the village's name to Julius Caesar, who supposedly planted the first vines here. The Château du Bois de la Salle, a former commandery, dominates the appellation and houses a renowned tasting cellar.

The Church of Saint-Just-et-Saint-Pasteur stands atop the hill, offering a panoramic view of the vineyards stretching to the horizon. Its Romanesque bell tower watches over the vines that have made the village's reputation for centuries. The stained glass windows depict wine-related scenes, celebrating the inseparable bond between faith and viticulture.

The former church of Juliénas, now a wine cooperative, represents a unique architectural conversion. The sacred building, deconsecrated in the 1950s, was transformed into a cathedral dedicated to wine. Frescoes by artists Victor Charreton and Paul Borel adorn the walls, celebrating wine and work in the vineyards.

Walk through the old village where golden stone houses bear witness to the prosperity brought by wine. The vaulted cellars, dug directly into granite, maintain constant temperature ideal for wine aging. Some cellars open their doors to reveal bottles dating back several decades.

activities.text: Taste Juliénas wines in one of the many estate cellars. This cru, produced on only 600 hectares, reveals rich aromas of red fruits and spices. Independent winegrowers passionately explain the influence of granite terroir on character. The convivial tasting includes several vintages to understand the evolution over the years.

Hike the Cru Trail that winds through vineyards and offers spectacular views of Mont Blanc on clear days. The marked path passes through the different climats that make up the appellation: Juliénas, Les Mouilles, Les Capitans. Information panels explain viticultural practices and the influence of terroir.

Visit the Cellier de la Vieille Église, a former cooperative transformed into a tasting temple. The frescoes depicting vineyard work and winemaking techniques create a unique atmosphere. Tastings are accompanied by explanations of specific characteristics of Juliénas wines compared to other Beaujolais crus.

Participate in a traditional cooking workshop pairing Juliénas wines with Beaujolais terroir dishes. Local chefs teach how to prepare coq au vin, beef à la Juliénas, and Beaujolais tart. Each dish is carefully paired with an appropriate vintage to enhance flavors.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: Jumièges Abbey — Victor Hugo called these ruins "the most beautiful in France." Founded in 654, this Benedictine abbey preserves its twin Romanesque towers 46 meters high dating from 1067. The roofless nave open to the sky and the cloister evoke the grandeur of medieval monasticism.

Saint-Pierre Church of Jumièges — This 10th-century Carolingian church next to the abbey displays pre-Romanesque architecture with its irregular pillars and rough stone walls. One of the rare testimonies to Norman architecture before the year 1000.

Seine Viewpoint from Jumièges — The abbey's elevated position offers panoramic views of the Seine loop and surrounding forests. The sunset illuminating the ruins creates a romantic atmosphere that inspired 19th-century writers.

Saint-Martin-de-Boscherville Abbey — This 12th-century Romanesque abbey, remarkably preserved, displays a purity of lines characteristic of Norman architecture. Its chapter house and 17th-century French-style gardens with their yew topiaries create a meditative setting.

Ruins of Château Robert le Diable — This fortress perched on a rocky outcrop overlooking the Seine dates from the 12th century. Legend attributes its construction to Robert the Magnificent, father of William the Conqueror. The panorama spans the valley.

activities.text: Abbey Gardens — These 15-hectare landscaped gardens surrounding the ruins include century-old yew trees, rose gardens and medicinal plant beds evoking monastic gardens. The paths offer constantly changing perspectives on the ruins.

Fruit Route — The Seine loop between Jumièges and Duclair crosses orchards producing Norman apples. Cider producers welcome visitors for tastings. The blossoming in April transforms the landscape into a white and pink sea.
Seine Loop Hike — A 15-kilometer circuit around the Jumièges peninsula offers panoramas of the abbey, forests and the river. The GR2 follows the banks through orchards and Norman villages.

Brotonne Forest — This 7,000-hectare state forest covering the Seine loop offers 250 kilometers of hiking and mountain biking trails. Centuries-old beeches and oaks create a canopy sheltering fallow deer and roe deer.

Brotonne Bridge — This cable-stayed bridge inaugurated in 1977 spans the Seine with a central span of 320 meters. Its height allows the passage of cargo ships sailing upriver to Rouen. An emblematic structure of Norman engineering.

Vieux-Port Viewpoint — This high point in the Brotonne Forest offers a panorama of the Seine meandering through forests and meadows. Picnic tables allow you to appreciate the peacefulness of the river valley.

visits.text: Kaysersberg, voted France's favourite village in 2017, unfolds its half-timbered houses along the Weiss river. The Emperor's Mountain truly lives up to its prestigious name.
The fortified bridge spans the Weiss. Built in the early 16th century in pink sandstone, it offers a picturesque view of the half-timbered houses.
The Church of Sainte-Croix holds a carved altarpiece from the 16th century. This masterwork depicts the Passion of Christ with extraordinary finesse.
The birthplace of Albert Schweitzer houses a museum. Winner of the 1952 Nobel Peace Prize, he founded the Lambaréné hospital in Gabon. An exhibition on his life and work.
Fortified bridge over the Weiss and row of half-timbered houses.
Castle on the heights and views over the vineyard.
Central square and radiating alleys.
Kaysersberg Christmas Market
Historic town centre and fortified bridge
Kaysersberg's fortified bridge, spanning the Weiss, is one of the rare defensive bridges surviving in Alsace. Its central chapel and crenellated parapets compose an emblematic image of the village.

Sainte-Croix church (12th-15th century) houses a sculpted and polychrome wooden altarpiece from 1518, representing the Passion of Christ. The Romanesque tympanum of the portal depicts the coronation of the Virgin.

Voted "France's Favorite Village" in 2017, Kaysersberg aligns polychrome half-timbered houses, sculpted oriels and galleried courtyards along rue du Général-de-Gaulle. Wrought-iron signs signal former guilds.
The communal museum, in a Renaissance house, presents medieval religious art objects and a 15th-century polychrome wood Christ of Pity.
The village is linked to a historical figure born here in 1875, who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1952 for his humanitarian work in Africa.

activities.text: Climb to the medieval castle. The 13th-century circular keep towers 50 metres above the town. Walls 4.42 metres thick. Panoramic views over the valley.
Explore the Wine Route. Seven Grand Cru vineyards surround Kaysersberg. Domaines Louis Sipp, Agapé, and Bott Geyl open their cellars.
In December, the Christmas market transforms the village. Chalets, artisans, and lights. A warm and magical atmosphere over the four Advent weekends.
Ascent to the castle via the forest path (2 km round trip).
Urban loop along the Weiss and small squares.
Explore artisan stalls in the old town
Visit the festive exhibitions organized during Advent weekends
Climb to Kaysersberg castle (13th century) via the winding trail. The cylindrical keep, rare in Alsace, offers a 360° panorama over the vines, the Weiss valley and the Vosges crests.
Kaysersberg winemakers cultivate the Grand Crus Schlossberg (first Grand Cru classified in 1975) and Kaefferkopf. Taste the chiseled Rieslings in town center cellars.
In December, Kaysersberg's authentic Christmas market is held around the fortified bridge: local crafts, bredele and mulled wine in an intimate atmosphere.

visits.text: The Château de L'Aigle, completed in 1730 to plans by Hardouin-Mansart, stands where an 11th-century fortress once rose—reputedly named for an eagle's nest. Its rubble and brick walls now house the town hall.

In the château's outbuildings, the June 1944 Museum, inaugurated in 1953, was France's first 'talking museum.' Life-size reconstructions, authentic BBC broadcasts, and a 390-square-foot animated strategic map recount the Battle of Normandy.
The Church of Saint-Martin, Gothic in style, survived the 1944 bombings that destroyed 80% of the town. Its ancient stained glass filters soft light.

On April 26, 1803, a shower of meteorites fell on L'Aigle. The permanent exhibition in the town hall displays fragments and recounts scientist Jean-Baptiste Biot's investigation, which proved the stones' extraterrestrial origin.
In the Square Eugène Pasquis, two 300-year-old plane trees—designated 'remarkable trees'—take root between two arms of the Risle. Botanists believe they could become thousand-year-old specimens.

activities.text: L'Aigle's market is one of France's largest. Miles of stalls spread Norman regional products, cheeses, poultry, and crafts every Tuesday.
In Saint-Sulpice-sur-Risle, an active factory produces needles and pins using techniques refined over 190 years. The tour reveals period machinery still in operation.
Trails along the Risle reveal the bocage landscape of Pays d'Ouche, the former domain of Countess de Ségur, who wrote many of her novels at the nearby Château des Nouettes.

visits.text: The Basilique Notre-Dame rises dramatically from the Champagne plain. This flamboyant Gothic masterpiece took 121 years to complete (1406-1527), built to house a miraculous statue.
Carved gargoyles adorn the east end. Each fantastical creature tells a medieval tale frozen in stone.
A 15th-century rood screen closes off the choir. Behind its right arch stands the Virgin statue discovered, according to legend, in a burning thorn bush.

activities.text: Look up at the two mismatched spires. The left spire was leveled in 1798, then rebuilt in 1868.
Drive across the chalky plain. For centuries, the basilica has guided pilgrims walking the route to Santiago de Compostela.

days_plan.itin_title: Finistère, Brittany Road Trip: Breton Headlands, Ponant Islands & Coastal Heritage

visits.text: Port-Joinville welcomes ferries and trawlers alike. Colorful shuttered facades line the quays where sea bass, monkfish, and crustaceans are landed each morning.

The Vieux Château, a listed historic monument since 1890, crowns a rocky promontory encircled by the sea. Built in the 14th century at the outbreak of the Hundred Years' War, it evokes Hergé's castle in The Black Island.
Climb the steps of the Grand Phare, rebuilt after its 1944 destruction. From the top of its 184-foot tower, panoramic views sweep across the entire island and reach 30 nautical miles out to sea.
Port de la Meule, a tiny fishing haven on the wild coast, is hemmed by brightly painted huts. The chapel of Notre-Dame-de-Bonne-Nouvelle overlooks the cove from the cliff path.
Saint-Sauveur Church, classified as a historic monument in 1906, is one of the island's oldest structures. 12th-century frescoes were uncovered during restoration work.

The Citadelle de Pierre Levée, erected between 1858 and 1866 on the heights above Port-Joinville, served as both state prison and barracks. A permanent exhibition traces the island's defensive history.

activities.text: Rent a bike for the island loop: 17 miles of trails and lanes traverse wild coastline, windswept heathland, hedgerow bocage, and golden sand coves.
Explore the island's prehistoric dolmens: the Dolmen des Petits Fradets and Dolmen de la Planche à Puare, both protected monuments, date to around 4,000 BCE.
Spread your towel at Plage des Vieilles, the island's most celebrated beach. Bordered by traditional island houses, this crescent of fine sand remains a pocket of unspoiled nature.

days_plan.itin_title: Vendée Road Trip: Noirmoutier Island, Puy du Fou & Atlantic Coast

Forêt de L’Isle‑Adam — Oak and beech forest with signed hiking loops and bridleways.

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: L'Isle-Jourdain developed around the Save River. The church of Saint-Martin dates from the 14th century with its characteristic octagonal bell tower. The town center preserves some half-timbered houses.
Lac de L'Isle-Jourdain is a leisure base with a developed beach. In summer, it's a swimming and water sports spot popular with families.

activities.text: Walk along the Save River that flows through town. The banks are landscaped and offer a pleasant setting for walking.
Saturday morning market offers local products from the Toulouse region. You'll find vegetables, cheeses, and charcuterie.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Nicknamed the "Venetian Comtat," L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue is crossed by willow-lined canals. About fifteen paddle wheels still turn, remnants of the textile and paper industries that once enriched the town.

The Collégiale Notre-Dame des Anges surprises with its 17th-century baroque interior: 222 sculpted and gilded angels populate the nave, chapels, and choir. The ensemble is a classified Historic Monument.
Over 300 permanent antique dealers occupy seven antique villages, making L'Isle Europe's third-largest art and antiques marketplace.

Visit the Partage des Eaux, a natural site where the Sorgue divides into two branches according to historic distribution: five-twelfths toward Velleron, seven-twelfths toward Entraigues. A small shaded path follows the river.
The medieval Tour d'Argent and Renaissance mansions on Rue Ledru-Rollin testify to the city's past prosperity, enriched by silk and paper trade.

activities.text: Sunday and Thursday markets animate the Sorgue quays. In summer, the floating market parades boats loaded with goods along the canals, following the nego-chin ("wet bottom") tradition.
Rent a canoe or kayak to descend the Sorgue from Fontaine-de-Vaucluse to L'Isle. Transparent water flows between white cliffs and foliage.
Sunday browsers or serious collectors: move from stall to stall during the major antique fairs held at Easter and around August 15, attracting hundreds of vendors.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: The Grande Plage unfurls nine kilometers of fine golden sand along the bay. An upscale resort since the Belle Époque, La Baule lines the shore with turn-of-the-century villas and Art Deco grand hotels.
Stroll the beachfront promenade shaded by umbrella pines. Luxury boutiques and ice cream parlors line up beside white-fronted palace hotels facing the eternal Atlantic.

The covered market brings together local market gardeners and producers under its metal-frame roof. Pénestin oysters, fleur de sel, and regional specialties change hands in the buzz of morning commerce.

activities.text: Rent a sand yacht or try kitesurfing on the vast beach. Westerly winds blow steadily across the bay, making La Baule a prime spot for wind-powered thrills on sand and water.
The Escoublac quarter preserves the Romanesque church of Saint-Guénolé. This old village core stands in quiet contrast to the seaside resort's Belle Époque splendor.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire-Atlantique Road Trip: Nantes and the Jade Coast

visits.text: La Borne is a unique village: 100 potters for 300 inhabitants. Pottery has been practiced here for 600 years, thanks to clay and wood from surrounding forests. In the 1950s, artist-potters arrived, attracted by cheap workshops and creative freedom. Today La Borne is one of France's main contemporary ceramics centers.

La Borne's studios are scattered throughout the village. Most display the "Open Studio" sign; you can enter, chat with the potter, see works in progress. Styles vary: utilitarian pottery, contemporary sculpture, installation art. Every piece is unique. Prices range from €10 (small bowl) to several thousand euros (large sculpture).

The Centre Céramique Contemporaine occupies old barns. Permanent exhibition on La Borne's history and techniques, temporary exhibitions of French and international ceramists. Workshop, kiln, archival photographs. Free entry. The shop offers a good selection if you haven't found anything in the studios.

activities.text: La Borne en Fête, the first weekend of June, is the major event. All studios open, demonstrations, wood-fired kiln, concerts, outdoor pottery market. Over 10,000 visitors. If you're in the area in early June, it's worth the trip.

The forest surrounding La Borne is crisscrossed with marked trails. The "Sentier des Potiers" (3h, 12 km) passes kilns, clay quarries, old workshops. Explanatory panels on the history of local pottery. Moderate, forest shade. Start from the village parking lot.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: La Bourboule preserves its Belle Époque elegance along the upper Dordogne River at 2,790 feet in the Massif du Sancy. The spa town owes its renown to 136°F waters rich in bicarbonate, sodium chloride, and arsenic—celebrated for treating respiratory, dermatological, and mucous membrane conditions. The Grand Thermes, palace hotels, former casino, and Parc Fenestre compose a coherent architectural ensemble from the turn of the 20th century. Illustrious guests have included the Queen of Romania, Sacha Guitry, and Buster Keaton.

The Funiculaire du Capucin at Mont-Dore is France's oldest electric funicular, built in 1898 and classified as a Historic Monument. Its Art Deco departure station, expanded in 1930, accesses a cabin that climbs at one meter per second to the Salon du Capucin at 4,085 feet. From there, trails lead to hiking paths, a Sylvatorium for forest bathing, a treetop adventure park, and a via ferrata.

Parc Fenestre offers greenery and freshness in La Bourboule's heart. This spa garden bordering the Dordogne gathers rare species and Belle Époque features in a mountain resort atmosphere. The pure mid-mountain air, naturally low in allergens, makes the resort popular with families—La Bourboule holds the Famille Plus label.

La Bourboule preserves its Belle Époque elegance along the upper Dordogne River at 850 meters altitude in the Massif du Sancy. The spa town owes its renown to thermal waters at 58°C rich in bicarbonate, sodium chloride, and arsenic, renowned for treating respiratory and dermatological conditions. The Grands Thermes, palace hotels, the former casino, and Fenestre Park compose a coherent architectural ensemble from the turn of the 20th century. Illustrious guests have included the Queen of Romania, Sacha Guitry, and Buster Keaton.

The Capucin funicular in Mont-Dore is France's oldest electric funicular, built in 1898 and classified as a Historic Monument. Its Art Deco departure station, enlarged in 1930, gives access to a cabin that climbs at one meter per second to the Salon du Capucin at 1,245 meters altitude. From there, hiking trails, a Sylvatorium for forest therapy, a treetop adventure park, and a via ferrata fan out into the mountains.

Fenestre Park offers a verdant, refreshing space in La Bourboule's heart. This spa garden bordering the Dordogne gathers rare species and Belle Époque features in an atmosphere of mountain resort elegance. The pure mid-mountain air, naturally low in allergens, makes the resort popular with families—La Bourboule carries the Family Plus label.

activities.text: Hike to Puy de Sancy, the Massif Central's highest point at 6,188 feet. From Le Mont-Dore, the resort cable car provides summit access after a short ridge walk. Panoramas embrace the entire volcanic massif, the Limagne plain, and on clear days, the Alps.

Discover the Grande Cascade du Mont-Dore, one of Auvergne's highest waterfalls. Accessible by a shaded forest trail from Mont-Dore, the cascade offers refreshing spectacle in a green volcanic setting.

Stroll the spa districts of Mont-Dore and La Bourboule to admire Belle Époque villa and hotel architecture. Ornate facades, wrought-iron canopies, and sculpted pediments testify to Auvergne spa culture's golden age.

Hike to Puy de Sancy, the Massif Central's highest peak at 1,886 meters. From Mont-Dore, the resort's cable car provides access to the summit after a short walk along the ridges. The panorama embraces the entire volcanic massif, the Limagne plain, and on clear days, the Alps.

Discover the Grande Cascade du Mont-Dore, one of Auvergne's highest waterfalls. Reached by a shaded forest path from Mont-Dore, the cascade offers a refreshing spectacle in a verdant volcanic setting.

Stroll through Mont-Dore and La Bourboule's streets to admire the Belle Époque villa and hotel architecture. Elaborate facades, wrought-iron canopies, and sculpted pediments testify to the golden age of Auvergnat thermalism.

days_plan.itin_title: Vosges Mountains, France: Alpine Lakes, Spa Towns and Forest Heritage

visits.text: The Abbey of La Chaise-Dieu (Casa Dei, "House of God") was founded in 1043 by Robert de Turlande. The 14th-century Gothic abbey church shelters the white marble tomb of Pope Clement VI, surrounded by 55 sculpted figures.
The famous Danse Macabre, a 15th-century fresco painted on the north aisle, is one of the few surviving in France. Three dead and three living dance together: "Death spares neither small nor great."
Admire the 14 Flemish tapestries from the early 16th century, totaling 213 feet in length. Commissioned by Abbot Jacques de Saint-Nectaire, they illustrate biblical scenes from the Poor Man's Bible.
The 144 carved oak choir stalls surround the choir. Chimeras, monks in grotesque poses, grimacing faces: Flemish sculptors let their imaginations run wild here.
Visit the Echo Room, a genuine acoustic curiosity. Stand in one corner and whisper: your companion, in the opposite corner, hears you perfectly.
The flamboyant Gothic rood screen separates the nave from the monks' choir. Above the main entrance, the 17th-century Baroque organ case adorns the interior façade with sculpted musical angels.
The Clémentine Tower, an imposing 14th-century fortified keep at the church's chevet, once housed the abbey's treasures. The neighboring stables have been converted into an auditorium.

activities.text: Wander through the medieval town built below the abbey. The rue des Casernes, narrow and paved with pebbles, is the oldest. Some façades preserve bartizans, mascarons, and coats of arms.
Each August, the La Chaise-Dieu Music Festival, founded in 1966, hosts classical music concerts beneath the abbey's vaults. Check the program.
Step inside the Chapelle des Pénitents, the former monks' refectory transformed into a chapel after the Revolution. Free access year-round.
