days_plan.itin_title: Marseille to Cassis: A Coastal Drive to the Best Calanques & Villages

visits.text: The Fier Gorges form a spectacular canyon carved by the river of the same name. A walkway suspended 25 meters above the torrent follows walls sculpted by erosion.
Faces in the rock naturally appear in the limestone walls. Visitors' imagination discerns human profiles and animal silhouettes.
Montrottier Castle dominates the valley from its rocky promontory. This medieval fortress houses collections of antique weapons, faiences, and art objects from around the world.
The castle's circular keep offers a panoramic view of the gorges and surrounding mountains. Vaulted rooms preserve monumental fireplaces.
Menthon-Saint-Bernard Castle stands on a spur overlooking the lake. This fairy-tale residence allegedly inspired Walt Disney's Sleeping Beauty Castle.
Still inhabited by the same family for a thousand years, the castle opens its furnished rooms to visitors. The library holds over 12,000 antique volumes.
La Clusaz displays its authentic Savoyard village at the foot of the Aravis range. Wooden chalets and a pointed church steeple compose a postcard setting.
The Aravis Pass peaks at 1,486 meters offering a grandiose panorama of Mont Blanc on clear days. The winding road crosses pastures and fir forests.
The Balme, Torchère, and Fernuy cirques carve into the massif with their hanging valleys. These natural amphitheaters shelter remarkable alpine flora.
The Burgeat Waterfall tumbles down rocks in the Manigod Valley. A short forest trail leads to this refreshing curtain of water.
The Sulens chalet perched in the alpine meadow welcomes hikers with its farmhouse cheeses. Cows graze the rich grass that gives Reblochon its incomparable taste.

A renowned ski resort that's retained its authentic mountain village soul, La Clusaz charms with its cluster of traditional carved-wood chalets and excellent gastronomic restaurants. This is Alpine living at its most genuine.

This 18th-century baroque church dominates the village center with its imposing onion-domed bell tower covered in wooden shingles. Inside, discover a gilded altarpiece and intricately carved woodwork that showcase Savoyard craftsmanship.

activities.text: Packrafting allows descending the Fier Gorges by water in May and June. This inflatable craft weaves between rocks and rapids.
The 430 steps leading to the gorges' ice cave offer an athletic challenge rewarded by underground coolness.
Visit Menthon Castle during summer evening tours when candles and torches recreate the medieval atmosphere.
Menthon Castle's Christmas market transforms the courtyard into an enchanted village with chalets, ice rink, and mulled wine.
Taste PDO farmhouse Reblochon made in the Aravis alpine pastures. This raw-milk cheese is enjoyed aged or melted in tartiflette.
The Thônes via ferrata offers an aerial route on the cliffs. Ladders, monkey bridges, and footbridges provide vertiginous sensations.
Hiking trails crisscross alpine meadows where herds graze. The climb to the Aravis Pass rewards walkers with an unforgettable panorama.
In summer, ski lifts transport mountain bikers to the summits for descents through flowering alpine meadows.

Ride the Beauregard cable car up to 1,800 meters. Multiple trails unfold from the summit, offering exceptional panoramas of the Aravis chain and Mont Blanc visible to the north—the Alps spread before you in all their glory.

Settle into one of the village restaurants for farm-fresh Reblochon fondue, authentic tartiflette, or diots sausages in white wine. Mountain farms produce Reblochon AOP right up in the high pastures—cheese that truly tastes of the Alps.

Ascend to the top of the Aiguille cable car to reach the highest point at 2,400 meters. The view sweeps across the entire Aravis chain and the Mont Blanc massif—a perspective that captures the full majesty of the French Alps.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc
Haute-Savoie Road Trip: Alpine Lakes & Mont Blanc

visits.text: Parc Georges-Valbon spans 417 hectares: it's the Paris region's third-largest park after the Bois de Vincennes and Bois de Boulogne. Over 310 hectares are classified Natura 2000, harboring more than 140 bird species.
The park's rose garden gathers 15,000 rose bushes. In spring, the paths are fragrant and colors burst between carefully tended beds.
The Victoria Montou park house, by the Grand Lake, hosts free exhibitions and events year-round. Nearby, artist Rachid Koraïchi's sculpture Le Vigilant overlooks the water.
The Terrain des Essences, 13 hectares renaturalized after the Paris Games, has joined the park. An observatory lets you contemplate this still-young ecological reserve, a refuge for local wildlife.

activities.text: Take the 10 km hiking loop offered by the Hiking Federation. The trail winds between seven lakes, woodlands, clearings, and viewpoints.
In fine weather, pedal boats and rowboats are available on the Grand Lake. Families enjoy playgrounds, the carousel, and orienteering courses.
The park's equestrian center offers pony introductions for children. Horse-drawn carriage rides are organized from April to September.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: La Couvertoirade rises from the Larzac plateau like a mirage. Its intact ramparts, built by the Hospitallers in the 15th century, encircle a village of 25 permanent residents. Two monumental gates topped by square towers and round towers at corners form the defensive system.

The Templar castle, erected in the late 12th century, is the only castle built by the Templars in France. Classified as a Historic Monument, it houses a space dedicated to the history of the Order of the Temple: armor, iconographic documents, plans. The keep is carved into rock.

The church of Saint-Christol, built by the Hospitallers in the late 13th century in flamboyant Gothic style, replaced a Templar chapel that had become too small. Its position on a rocky spur dominates the entire village.

From the rampart walk, the view embraces lauze roofs, the castle, paved lanes, and beyond the walls, the Larzac causse expanses to the Cévennes. Arrow slits and loopholes testify to the medieval defensive system.

The lavogne, an artificial pond lined with slabs, served as a watering trough for flocks on this limestone plateau where water is scarce. Along with houses' roof cisterns, it illustrates the ingenuity of causse architecture for capturing every drop.

The Maison de la Scipione, starting point of the visit, recounts the village's history through films and exhibitions. The communal oven, Redounel mill (17th century), and 16th-17th century mansion houses complete the architectural panorama.

activities.text: The hiking loop around La Couvertoirade crosses Larzac's agropastoral landscape: dry-stone walls, lavognes, sheepfolds, and expanses of limestone grasslands. Ideal for understanding inhabitants' daily life in the Templars' era.

The network of five Templar and Hospitaller sites of Larzac (La Couvertoirade, Sainte-Eulalie de Cernon, La Cavalerie, Viala-du-Pas-de-Jaux, and Saint-Jean-d'Alcas) can be visited with a combined pass. The commandery of Sainte-Eulalie, the network's mother house, particularly deserves a detour.

The Larzac plateau, inscribed as World Heritage for the agropastoral landscapes of the Causses and Cévennes, is crossed by marked trails. Shepherds still lead flocks of sheep whose milk produces Roquefort cheese.

days_plan.itin_title: Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: The Grande Arche, inaugurated in 1989, anchors Paris's historic axis. Danish architect Johan Otto von Spreckelsen conceived this 110-meter hollowed cube as a modern echo to the Arc de Triomphe.
The CNIT, built between 1955 and 1958, displays a triangular concrete vault spanning 220 meters per side. This spectacular shell rests on just three support points.
La Défense towers embody glass-and-steel architecture at its boldest. Tour First, Tour Total, and Tour EDF compose Europe's premier business district.

activities.text: The La Défense esplanade spreads across 3 hectares punctuated by modern sculptures: César's enormous Thumb, Barrias's La Défense statue, and Takis's kinetic fountains.
The Quatre Temps shopping center features 220 boutiques. When it opened in 1981, it was Europe's largest shopping mall.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: Founded in 1603 by King Henry IV, the Prytanée National Militaire impresses with its classical architecture. The Saint-Louis church holds the heart ashes of both the king and Queen Marie de Medici.
The formal French gardens of the Prytanée extend into a centuries-old park. You'll discover the courtyards of Austerlitz and Sebastopol, witnesses to a prestigious military heritage.
Established in 1946, the La Flèche Zoo is home to 1,600 animals representing 150 species. White lions, elephants, and lemurs roam through carefully designed habitats.
The ruins of Château des Carmes line the banks of the Loir River. This protected natural site offers a verdant riverside walk.
The 14th-century Bruère mill produced natural ice using water from the Loir. A unique testament to pre-industrial ingenuity.

activities.text: Stroll along the Loir River from Parc des Carmes. The landscaped riverbanks invite leisurely exploration.
The Monnerie Lakes offer swimming, a cycling path, and a beach. A fishing lake completes the offerings.
The Cré-sur-Loir marsh, a regional nature reserve, features several trails for discovering local wildlife.

days_plan.itin_title: Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Port of La Flotte, flower-lined streets and medieval market.

activities.text: Bike loop along the salt marshes (easy section).

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: 1970s architecture of La Grande-Motte, visionary seaside resort created from scratch by Jean Balladur. Residential pyramids with staggered white facades draw inspiration from pre-Columbian and modern architecture. The Grande Pyramide, iconic 14-story building, dominates the seafront. Seaside residences with bold geometric forms—Point Zéro, Grande Motte, Acapulco—illustrate the seaside utopia of the post-war boom years. The 20th-century architectural heritage classified with Heritage of the 20th Century label attracts modern architecture enthusiasts. Green spaces integrated into buildings create a unique garden city on the coast.

Port de plaisance of La Grande-Motte, modern marina with 1,600 berths nestled between dunes and pyramids. Pontoons welcome yachts, sailboats, and pleasure boats in a protected basin. Lively quays border restaurants, ice cream shops, and nautical boutiques in relaxed seaside atmosphere. Sailing school offers introductions and courses for all levels. Developed promenades invite strolling between boats and brutalist architecture. Sunsets set ablaze white pyramid facades reflecting in calm waters.

Beaches of La Grande-Motte, three miles of supervised fine sand bordered by protected dunes. Grande Plage facing the pyramids offers lifeguard stations, nautical clubs, and deckchair rental. Themed beaches—Plage du Couchant, de l'Esplanade—adapt to different practices: family swimming, water sports, sunbathing. Breakwaters create calm swimming zones for children. Handicapped access with tiralos allows swimming for all. Beaches with Blue Flag label guarantee water quality and preserved environment.

activities.text: Water sports at La Grande-Motte, premier destination for aquatic activities. Schools offer lessons in optimist sailing, catamaran, dinghy, or windsurfing. Kitesurfing practiced on windy spots with professional supervision. Paddleboarding and kayaking allow discovering coast and lagoons at peaceful pace. Scuba diving reveals Mediterranean seabeds, posidonia meadows, and local fauna. Nautical centers rent equipment and organize supervised outings. The tramontane wind guarantees optimal conditions for gliding sports.

Thalassotherapy and wellness at the resort's specialized centers. Marine cures use seawater, algae, and mud for restorative treatments. Heated seawater pools, massaging jets, and whirlpool baths relax after an active day. Facial and body treatments with marine products regenerate skin. Relaxing massages, wraps, and scrubs complete wellness offerings. Half-day or full-day packages include access to facilities and personalized treatments. The zen atmosphere invites a relaxing break facing the Mediterranean.

Evening at La Grande-Motte casino, gaming and entertainment establishment by the sea. Air-conditioned rooms offer slot machines, roulette, blackjack, and Texas Hold'em poker. Weekly tournaments gather skilled players in competitive atmosphere. The panoramic restaurant offers gourmet cuisine with sea views. Shows, concerts, and stand-up comedy animate cultural programming. The lounge terrace allows cocktails facing the waves. The building's brutalist architecture integrates into the resort's pyramidal style.

days_plan.itin_title: Gard Road Trip: Roman Nîmes, Pont du Gard & Camargue Wilderness

visits.text: La Malène occupies a Tarn meander at the gorge floor. The Montesquieu barons' château, rebuilt in the 16th century, dominates the slate rooftops. Narrow lanes descend to the boatmen's landing.
Drive up to Roc des Hourtous or Roc du Serre. These two viewpoints, accessible by causse road, deliver a 600-meter vertical drop into the gorges. Griffon vultures often soar below.
Aven Armand, on the Méjean causse, shelters a forest of over 400 stalagmites. The tallest reaches 30 meters—a world record. A funicular descent leads to an underground chamber of 60,000 m².

The Vulture Observatory, above the Jonte gorges, is a museum space dedicated to raptors reintroduced since the 1970s. Telescopes and live cameras let you track griffon vultures, monk vultures, and Egyptian vultures on the cliffs.

The Méjean causse stretches between the Tarn and Jonte gorges. An almost lunar landscape of sparse grasslands, dolines, and dry-stone walls. Isolated farms perpetuate a UNESCO-recognized agropastoral tradition.

activities.text: Embark from La Malène for the flat-bottomed boat descent to the Baumes cirque. Boatmen navigate through Les Détroits, where cliffs plunge vertically into the Tarn.
Hike down the Jonte gorges from the Méjean causse. The trail winds between cliffs where vultures nest. Simply look up to spot raptors with nearly 3-meter wingspans.
Swim in the Tarn at pebble beaches upstream or downstream from La Malène. The turquoise water is brisk but invigorating. Cliffs frame natural spots sheltered from wind.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes

visits.text: La Palud-sur-Verdon is the characteristic village nestled at the foot of the gorges. Stone houses tier around the Romanesque church. Flowered squares offer refreshing stops in the shade of lime trees.

Point Sublime offers a vertiginous viewpoint over the gorge entrance. The panorama plunges onto the Verdon 180 meters below. It's the starting or arrival point of the Martel trail, depending on the chosen direction.

Viewpoints along the Route des Crêtes follow one another on the clifftop. La Carelle, Tilleul, l'Escalès... each promontory reveals a different facet of the canyon. The setting sun sets the cliffs ablaze in golden and pink hues.

The Maison des Gorges du Verdon presents the canyon's exceptional ecosystem. Interactive exhibitions and documentaries reveal the geology, fauna and flora of this classified natural site. Griffon vultures and golden eagles reign over these walls.
Verdon Gorges.
Route des Crêtes.

activities.text: Descend the Verdon by kayak from Lac de Sainte-Croix. The boat glides on turquoise waters between canyon walls. Limestone cliffs rise on each side, creating an open-air natural cathedral atmosphere.

Aquatic hikes combine walking and swimming in Verdon tributaries. Jumps into pools, passages under waterfalls and whitewater swimming punctuate the route. Secondary gorges offer an intimate and preserved setting.

Climbing in the gorges attracts climbers from around the world. Over 1500 equipped routes trace their lines on the limestone. Sectors range from 3 to 9, offering challenges for all levels in a spectacular setting.
Sentier Martel hiking trail.
Kayak.
Rock climbing.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages
Verdon Gorge Road Trip: Moustiers-Sainte-Marie, Castellane & Turquoise Waters

visits.text: La Petite-Pierre Castle has stood here since the 13th century. Vauban modernised the fortifications in 1684. Today it serves as the headquarters of the Northern Vosges Regional Natural Park.
The castle courtyard is open to visitors. Information panels trace the history of the fortress. The Design & Savoir-faire shop showcases local artisans and designers.
The Staedtel, the old fortified town, rises in tiers along the rocky spur. Ramparts, underground cisterns carved in sandstone, and 15th-century frescoes.
The church retains 15th-century frescoes. The murals reveal medieval faith. Remarkably well-preserved religious art.

activities.text: The rampart trail runs along the fortifications. 250 metres long and 80 metres wide: the sandstone spur is impressive. Remarkable underground cisterns.
Explore the Northern Vosges Regional Natural Park. A UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 1989. Pine forests, sandstone rocks, and ruined castles.
The Alsatian Seal Museum displays coats of arms and seals. The Museum of Folk Art and Traditions presents Springerle, traditional small biscuits.

days_plan.itin_title: Alsace and the Wine Route: Strasbourg to the Vosges

visits.text: La Réole is a medieval city founded in 977, one of Gironde's oldest urban centers. Classified as a City of Art and History, it's France's smallest commune to carry this label. The town clings to a rocky promontory overlooking the Garonne. It was protected by three successive walls, of which vestiges remain. Wander cobbled lanes to discover half-timbered houses, vaulted passages, and small squares. The atmosphere is authentic and peaceful.

The Benedictine Priory of Saint-Pierre majestically dominates the Garonne. Founded in the 10th century, it's at the origin of the town's development. The 18th-century classical façade hides older buildings. The priory now houses the town hall, municipal services, and library. The 18th-century wrought iron entrance gate is an ironwork masterpiece. The forecourt offers beautiful river and hillside views.

La Réole's Town Hall is one of France's oldest civic buildings, dating from the 12th century. This remarkable Gothic edifice originally served as market halls and common house. The architecture testifies to La Réole's political and economic importance in the Middle Ages. The square-facing façade preserves its Gothic arcades. The interior houses municipal services. The building can be visited on guided tours organized by the tourist office.

Château des Quat'Sos is an imposing 13th-century medieval fortress. Built to protect the town, it had four corner towers (hence its name of Four Sous). The château was dismantled on Richelieu's orders in 1629. Two imposing round towers and part of the curtain walls survive. Transformed into a bourgeois residence in the 18th century, it's now private. Visible from outside, it can be visited exceptionally during Heritage Days or on reserved guided tours.

Saint-Pierre Church in La Réole combines several architectural styles from the 12th to 15th centuries. The Gothic building presents Romanesque and Flamboyant elements. The sculpted capitals and stained glass merit attention. The church preserves interesting furnishings including a Baroque altarpiece. It's part of the Vézelay Way stage on the Santiago de Compostela pilgrimage routes. Remarkable acoustics host classical music concerts.

activities.text: Guided tour of La Réole. The tourist office and City of Art and History service offer themed guided tours: medieval heritage, town history, architecture. The classic tour lasts 1.5 hours and covers main monuments and neighborhoods. You'll discover the fascinating history of this city that alternated between French and English control during the Hundred Years' War. Passionate guides bring La Réole's past to life. Reservations recommended.

Stroll along the Garonne banks. The quays developed in the 19th century offer a pleasant riverside walk. You'll enjoy views of vineyard-covered hillsides on the opposite bank and the Rouergue suspension bridge. A towpath follows the river upstream and downstream. It's a peaceful spot for walking or picnicking. Some benches let you settle in facing the river. Sunset here is particularly beautiful.

La Réole Market is held every Saturday morning on the Garonne quays. This traditional market gathers local producers and artisans. You'll find seasonal fruits and vegetables, cheeses, charcuterie, honey, Entre-deux-Mers wines. The atmosphere is friendly and authentic. It's an opportunity to chat with producers and discover regional specialties. Some stalls offer on-site dining for breakfast.

Discovering La Réole's gastronomy. Several restaurants highlight Gironde terroir products: duck, foie gras, porcini mushrooms, asparagus, nearby Agen prunes, regional cheeses. Entre-deux-Mers wines perfectly accompany these dishes. The town also preserves pastry specialties. For an authentic experience, choose an old town restaurant with summer terrace overlooking the quays.

Walk in Charros Park, developed at the foot of medieval ramparts. This peaceful landscaped garden follows the path of the former Charros stream that served as château moats. Interpretation panels and benches invite relaxation and heritage discovery. The park offers lovely views of fortifications and third wall vestiges. It's a green haven appreciated by locals. Children's playground.

days_plan.itin_title: Gironde Road Trip: Bordeaux, Vineyards & Arcachon Bay

visits.text: La Roche-Bernard, a Small City of Character, clings to a rocky spur overlooking the Vilaine. The 'Promenade du Ruicard' follows the cliff and offers a vertiginous view over the river, 30 meters below.
The old quarter preserves 16th-17th century captains' and shipowners' houses. Rue du Ruicard displays granite facades with arched doorways and exterior staircases typical of maritime Vilaine.
The port, at the foot of the cliff, once housed shipyards that built Vilaine barges. A museum recounts this fluvial maritime history - the Vilaine was navigable as far as Redon.
The current suspension bridge succeeds that of 1839 - Brittany's first suspension bridge, swept away by a storm in 1852. From its deck, the view embraces both banks and the Vilaine meanders.
The Notre-Dame chapel, perched atop the rock, dates from the 16th century. During the Revolution, the town mayor took refuge there before being executed - a tragic episode of local royalist uprising.

activities.text: Descend to the port via the staircase carved into the rock, then follow the Vilaine on the towpath. Old warehouses and launching ramps dot the route.
Cross the bridge and reach the Arzal dam on foot or by bike. This maritime lock, the largest in France, separates fresh water from salt water and regulates tides on the Vilaine.
Thursday morning market on Place du Bouffay is a gathering of local producers. Pénestin oysters, buckwheat pancakes, and farmhouse cider compose a complete Breton breakfast.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: La Roche‑Guyon — Cliff‑side château with medieval keep, troglodyte stair and 18th‑century salons; site on the Seine loop.
Seine valley viewpoints in Parc naturel régional du Vexin français; chalk hills and orchard landscapes.

activities.text: Walk the “sentier des crêtes” above the village for sweeping Seine panoramas; avoid after rain (slippery chalk).
Local cider tasting at a Vexin farm (pre‑book).

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: Place Napoléon sprawls across 6.4 acres at the heart of a pentagonal city plan drawn up in 1804. Thirteen colossal mechanical animals in steel inhabit its fountains—turn the cranks to bring them roaring to life.

Step through the gates of Haras de la Vendée, a national stud farm founded in 1843 within an 11-acre park. The stables house rare horse breeds, and equestrian arts demonstrations punctuate guided tours.
Saint-Louis Church, begun in 1809, is the largest religious building in Vendée. Its neoclassical facade and soaring interior columns reflect the imperial ambition behind the city's founding.
Enter the Italian-style Theatre, a listed historic monument. Golden balconies and a painted ceiling make this one of three historic playhouses that anchor the city's cultural life.
Walk up rue du Vieux-Marché to the Renaissance House, a 1566 townhouse built in Italian architectural style. Inside, exhibitions trace the city's evolution from imperial creation to modern capital.

The Extraordinary Vegetable Garden gathers over 1,000 varieties of produce across 17 acres. Giant squash, heirloom tomatoes in every hue, and tasting workshops bring the vegetable kingdom to vivid life.

activities.text: Visit the Historial de la Vendée to journey through the department's past via immersive reconstructions, from prehistoric settlements to the bloody Wars of the Vendée.
Wander the city's gardens: Square Bayard, Jardin des Compagnons, and Parc de la Vallée de l'Yon offer 100 acres of green space threading between the river and rocky outcrops.
Follow the audio-guided Napoleonic circuit departing from the Tourist Office: three marked routes reveal imperial architecture, the railway district, and the old town quarter.
Rent a bike and pedal along the Vallée de l'Yon to the Chaos de Piquet, a romantic spot where boulders surge from the river amid wild vegetation.

days_plan.itin_title: Vendée Road Trip: Noirmoutier Island, Puy du Fou & Atlantic Coast

visits.text: The Château de La Rochefoucauld has belonged to the same family since 1019 — a French record. The three-storey Renaissance galleries recall Italian palaces. Legend has it the spiral staircase was designed by Leonardo da Vinci.
The castle's four libraries hold 21,000 volumes. The guided tour (compulsory for this section) includes the Treasury room where the guide handles eight-century-old archives. Impressive.

The town at the foot of the castle is worth a stroll: half-timbered houses, cobbled lanes along the Tardoire. This is where the charentaise slipper was born — the shoe, not the resident. Specialist shop on Rue des Halles.

activities.text: Full castle visit. Self-guided section (salons, kitchens, galleries) + guided tour of the libraries and archives. Allow 2 hours total. Children can dress up as knights or princesses — costumes provided.
Chocolaterie d'Antan at the foot of the castle. Watch artisans at work from the shop. Local speciality: the pichotte, a chocolate-almond-icing sugar sweet. Open even on Sundays.
Hike along the Tardoire. Waymarked trails from the castle into the rolling countryside. Landscapes that hint at the neighbouring Périgord. Several loops from 5 to 15 km.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: The three towers of the Old Port are remnants of La Rochelle's medieval fortifications. The Saint-Nicolas Tower (14th century), slightly tilted like Pisa, rises to 37 meters. A chain once linked it to the Chain Tower to close the harbor each evening – the original chain is visible at the tower's base.

The Lantern Tower, with its 55-meter octagonal Gothic spire, served as both lighthouse and prison. Some 600 graffiti carved by English, Spanish and Dutch corsairs adorn its walls – ships, figures, and even a locomotive. Rabelais mentions it in his Fifth Book.

La Rochelle's Old Port was the largest port on the Atlantic coast in the 15th century. Stroll along Cours des Dames and Quai Duperré, lined with café terraces. In the evening, the illuminated towers reflect in the basin – one of the most beautiful scenes on the French coast.

The arcades of the city center have sheltered passersby since the Middle Ages. Over 3 km of covered galleries line the shopping streets. Under stone and wooden vaults, half-timbered houses and Renaissance mansions tell the story of the wealthy Rochelais shipowners.

La Rochelle Aquarium is one of the largest private aquariums in Europe. Over 12,000 marine animals in 3 million liters of water. The shark tank and jellyfish gallery are spectacular. Allow 2 to 3 hours for the visit.

The New World Museum occupies Hôtel Fleuriau, an 18th-century shipowner's mansion. Collections on the triangular trade, the French West Indies and the slave trade. An unflinching look at La Rochelle's wealth built on slavery.

The Gabut district, a former bastion converted into a colorful village. Brightly painted wooden houses, artists' studios, terraces facing the marina. An unexpected Scandinavian atmosphere on the Atlantic shore.

activities.text: Visit of La Rochelle's three towers. A single ticket grants access to all three monuments. Climbing to the top of Saint-Nicolas Tower offers a complete panorama over the port and roadstead. Allow 2 hours for the full visit.

Walk along the rampart walkway between the Chain Tower and Lantern Tower. This section of rampart, called 'Rue sur les Murs', overlooks the Saint-Jean-d'Acre esplanade and offers stunning views of the port.

La Rochelle central market. Under the wrought iron and wooden halls, producers sell Marennes-Oléron oysters, Pineau des Charentes, mogettes (white beans) and tourteau fromager. Lively atmosphere every morning.
The Sea Bus and the Ferry connect both sides of the port. A 5-minute crossing, a pleasant alternative to walking around. The electric ferry operates year-round.

Concurrence Beach, the closest to the city center. Fine sand, calm water, view of the towers. Lifeguarded in summer. The Mail promenade lined with tamarisk trees runs along the coast toward Les Minimes.
Yellow bike rental (Yélo) self-service. La Rochelle pioneered bike-sharing in France. Cycle paths lead to Les Minimes beaches and the marina.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge
Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: Village of La Rochepot and silhouettes of the castle on its spur.
Ancient polychrome tiles visible from public observation points.
Path to Evelle and views of the wine coast.

activities.text: Walking loop on wine paths at the edge of the plateau.
Landscape reading: stone walls, enclosed vineyards and strip parcels.

days_plan.itin_title: Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: Houses backed against the cliff and exotic gardens.

La Roque-Gageac clings to a 120-meter limestone cliff above the Dordogne River, its golden stone houses and slate roofs reflected in the water below. Classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages since 1982, it's the third most visited site in the country after Mont Saint-Michel and Rocamadour. The village's dramatic setting and medieval architecture make it instantly unforgettable.

A 12th-century fort is carved directly into the cliff face 40 meters above the village. Climb 140 steps hewn from living rock to reach the summit, where panoramic views sweep across the Dordogne Valley and the rival castles of Beynac and Castelnaud. The fort was never conquered—its position made it impregnable.

An exotic garden thrives at the cliff base, nurtured by a south-facing microclimate that shields it from northern winds. Palm trees, banana plants, orange trees, cacti, and towering bamboo grow together in improbable abundance. Admission is free—a botanical surprise tucked into medieval Périgord.

activities.text: Cruise or kayak on the Dordogne at the foot of the village.

Traditional flat-bottomed gabarres—the cargo boats that once carried wine, timber, and salt along the Dordogne—now offer one-hour river cruises. Two companies operate from La Roque-Gageac. Guides recount the history of river commerce and point out the castles of Castelnaud, Beynac, Fayrac, and Marqueyssac rising from the valley cliffs.

The Gardens of Marqueyssac, just 3 km away, feature 6 km of pathways bordered by 150,000 hand-trimmed boxwood shrubs—some over a century old. The belvedere perched 130 meters above the Dordogne offers one of the most breathtaking viewpoints in all of Périgord. Come for sunset if you can.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Dordogne Road Trip: Cave Art, Medieval Fortresses & Périgord Delights

Classified Charles-Martel bridge, crossing the Cèze at the foot of the village.
Sautadet waterfalls downstream, landscape of potholes and limestone slabs.

activities.text: Secure pedestrian route to the waterfall viewpoints (respect prohibited areas).
Heritage trail through the upper village and the Romanesque chapel.

Quays and views of mills and riverside gardens.

activities.text: Loop of quays and nearby hamlets (2–3 km).
Path to riverside viewpoints for reading the river.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: The Church of Notre-Dame de La Souterraine stands out with its 60-meter bell tower, the tallest in Creuse. A masterpiece of Romanesque-Gothic transition built from the 11th to 13th centuries by the monks of Saint-Martial de Limoges, this austere granite edifice reveals a façade with a polylobed portal of Mozarabic influence, testimony to the passage of pilgrims to Compostela on the Via Lemovicensis. Inside, the vast proportions of the nave invite contemplation.

Descend into the thousand-year-old crypt via Place d'Armes. This underground church, which gave the town its name (Subterranea in 1268), was built around 1020 on a Gallo-Roman necropolis. Under the Romanesque vaults reinforced with ribbed arches, three chapels follow one another: the main one under the choir, Sainte-Anne to the north, and Saint-Martial to the south. The Heritage Space presents archaeological finds from the ancient site of Bridiers. Open in summer, free admission.

The Saint-Jean Gate, a remnant of medieval ramparts, stands near the church with its two corbelled turrets, crenellations, and machicolations. Built in the 13th and 15th centuries, it preserves the notches that supported the drawbridge chains. Ask for the key at the Café du Marché to access the top: the view over the town and surrounding countryside rewards the ascent.

At the cemetery of La Souterraine, a 12th-century lantern of the dead intrigues with its silhouette of a hollow tower topped by an openwork pavilion. According to tradition, the lamp lit there guided the souls of the deceased toward eternal rest. This funerary construction typical of Limousin testifies to medieval beliefs about death.

Four kilometers to the east, the site of Bridiers reveals the remains of a Gallo-Roman settlement of the Lemovices. The Tower of Bridiers, a 12th-century keep of an ancient fortress, overlooks reconstructed medieval gardens. In August, the site hosts the Historical Fresco: a nocturnal spectacle mixing sound, light, and pyrotechnics with more than 300 costumed actors.

activities.text: Lake Sagnat, a few kilometers from La Souterraine, offers a complete leisure base in the heart of Creuse nature. Supervised beach in summer for swimming, shaded paths for walks, pontoons for fishing: the ideal spot for a refreshing break after heritage visits.

The Cheix pond, two kilometers from the center, offers a peaceful setting for fishing or a simple walk by the water. The developed banks allow observation of local wildlife in a preserved environment.

days_plan.itin_title: Creuse Circuit: Valley of the Painters and Aubusson Tapestries

visits.text: Village on the Beaume; pebble houses and vaulted passages.
Stone bridge and esplanades along the riverbank.
Church and high points on the Beaume loop.

activities.text: Labeaume belvedere trail (3–5 km, stairs and developed ledges).
Waterside walk along the bank, observation of pebbles and riparian forest.

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: Walk around Lake Saint-Point, the third largest natural lake in France.
Discovery of the House of the Reserve in Labergement-Sainte-Marie.
Visit to the Obertino foundry and demonstration of bell casting.
Discovery of the Rucher des 2 Lacs and explanation of the work of bees.
Visit to the aging cellars of Fort Saint-Antoine and Comté cheese tasting.

activities.text: Pedal boat or sailing trip on Lake Saint-Point.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs, France Natural Tour: Gorges, Waterfalls & Craft Heritage

visits.text: The Pisseurs Fountain stands on Place du Griffoul. Classified as a Historical Monument in 1913, this 15th-century fountain depicts four figures—Lacaune's former consuls—and symbolizes the diuretic virtues of the town's thermal waters.

The Old Lacaune Museum occupies the 16th-century consular house facing the fountain. Fifteen themed rooms recreate Lacaune daily life from the 18th to 20th centuries: costumes, tools, vanished trades.

Push open the door of the Charcuterie House to understand how the harsh mountain climate—800 meters altitude, north winds—favored the art of curing. The exhibit traces this craft's evolution since the 18th century.

The Ramond Spinning Mill, founded in 1841, preserves carding machines and spinning looms in working order, listed on the Historical Monuments inventory. The visit plunges into Haut-Languedoc's textile heritage.
At the town's edge, the Peyro Levado is Europe's largest statue-menhir. These carved and sculpted stones, scattered across the Lacaune Mountains, testify to a still-mysterious Neolithic past.

activities.text: Visit an artisanal curing house to discover production stages: salting, drying in northern winds, aging. The end-of-tour tasting lets you sample award-winning hams, dry sausages, and cured meats.
Take the Roc du Montalet trail for a hike in the Lacaune Mountains. Beech forests, heather moorlands, and valley panoramas unfold along the route.
Head to the Lakes Plateau near Lacaune: four lakes within a small area offer swimming, first-category fishing, and water sports in the heart of Haut-Languedoc Regional Natural Park.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn Road Trip: Albi & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: Lacoste — hilltop village dominated by the Marquis de Sade's castle (restored in the 20th century).
Paved streets and medieval staircases leading to ramparts and viewpoints.
Art galleries and workshops scattered throughout the village.

activities.text: Climb to the castle plateau (panorama over Luberon and Calavon valley).
Walking on the stone-paved paths between terraces and retaining walls.

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour

visits.text: Abbey of Sainte-Marie d'Orbieu — Founded in 778 under Charlemagne. Medieval cloister, monks' dormitory, Romanesque bell tower. Canons regular still in residence. Sculptures by the Master of Cabestany.
Village of Lagrasse — Listed as one of the Most Beautiful Villages of France. Cobbled lanes, medieval half-timbered houses, 14th-century market hall. An artisan village, straddling the Orbieu River.
Pont Vieux de Lagrasse — Medieval three-arched bridge from the 14th century over the Orbieu. Links the village to the abbey. Swimming possible in summer.

From the road coming from Lézignan-Corbières, Lagrasse reveals itself at a bend: the medieval village nestled in the valley, the winding Orbieu River, and the massive abbey on the other side. Fifteen buildings in the town are protected as Historic Monuments.

The abbey of Sainte-Marie-d'Orbieu was founded in 779 under Charlemagne's protection. For over a thousand years, Benedictine monks lived here. The Revolution split it in two: the public part (abbatial palace, cellar, dormitory, chapels) and the private part, administered since 2004 by a community of canons.

The humpback Old Bridge connects the town to the abbey. It appears on a seal from 1303, and its three unequal arches were once topped by two 18-meter crenellated gate-towers. They were demolished because their weight was causing the bridge to sag.

The medieval hall, arranged in 1315, marks the market's transfer from outside the walls. One can easily imagine the bustle of merchants from that era. Saturday morning's market perpetuates this tradition under the same vaults.

The Heritage House occupies the former 15th-century presbytery. Three rooms display 131 painted medieval ceiling panels, classified as Historic Monuments. The permanent exhibition 'Forgotten Images of the Middle Ages' offers a fresh look at medieval daily life in Languedoc.
The parish church of Saint-Michel, built between 1359 and 1398, is a typical example of the region's single-nave Gothic. Since the Revolution, it contains furnishings mainly from the abbey.

activities.text: Corbières wine tasting — Lagrasse sits at the heart of the appellation. Estates offering full-bodied reds and crisp whites.
In summer, a swimming area is set up in the Orbieu, facing the abbey. Clear water, 'beach space,' and shaded spots under trees. Supervised swimming in July-August.
Lagrasse is classified 'Towns and Crafts of Art.' Ceramics, leatherwork, luthiery, jewelry, sewing, stained glass: push open the doors of workshops lining the village lanes.
The Corbières hills around the village are ideal for hiking. The view from the D212 toward Lézignan offers a remarkable panorama of Lagrasse and its bridges.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Visit the cutlery workshops in the heart of Laguiole village. The cutlers handcraft each piece with the forged bee, chiselled spring, and guillochage patterns. Several manufacturers offer tours and assembly demonstrations.

The Forge de Laguiole lets you watch the complete making of a knife. The artisans hot-forge the blades, sculpt the bee with a file and punch, then assemble the different parts. Handles are made from precious wood, Aubrac horn, or stag antler.

Laguiole village is also the birthplace of the Aubrac cattle breed and the Laguiole AOC cheese. Burons dot the plateau where the cows graze. Aligot is the local speciality made from fresh tome cheese and potatoes.

activities.text: Explore the Aubrac plateau between 1,000 and 1,400 metres altitude. The landscapes alternate between summer pastures and peatlands. The traditional burons were used to make cheese during the transhumance.
Taste the aligot in the village restaurants. This mashed potato dish mixed with fresh tome cheese is beaten at length until it forms long ribbons. Each inn has its own recipe and technique.

days_plan.itin_title: Aveyron Road Trip: Causses, Tarn Gorges and Villages

visits.text: Lambesc — historic town of the Aix region: private mansions and religious heritage (ext.).
Courtyards and fountains, memory of the États de Provence.

activities.text: Vine-olive loop on the Trévaresse hillsides.
Provençal market (depending on day) on the central avenue.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Gervais-Saint-Protais Church, founded in 998, preserves a 12th-century Romanesque nave flanked by two side aisles. Fifteenth-century Gothic chapels house a 17th-century Virgin statue. The flamboyant Gothic portal opens to a sober, light-filled interior.

The 18th-century grain hall is one of France's largest preserved market halls. Its Tuscan-order granite columns support an imposing timber frame covered with Tournel slate. The market still meets here every Saturday.

The Filature des Calquières, a historic monument, is France's oldest mill still in operation. Its 19th-century machinery, powered by a larch water wheel on the Langouyrou stream, transforms fleece into yarn before your eyes. A living witness to when Lozère had three times more sheep than people.

Langogne is a thousand-year-old town with a circular layout unique in Lozère. Remnants of ramparts and six medieval towers—one housing the town hall—still trace the fortified perimeter. The 15-monument heritage walk comes with a brochure from the Tourist Office.

The ruins of Château de Luc, 12 km southeast, overlook the Allier valley. Built between the 10th and 12th centuries on the Voie Régordane, it displays remarkable "opus spicatum" (herringbone) masonry. Dismantled by order of Richelieu in 1630, it was converted to a chapel in the 19th century.

activities.text: Lake Naussac, 1,050 hectares at 950 meters elevation, is France's fifth-largest reservoir. Sailing, paddleboarding, kayaking, kitesurfing, and electric boats operate from two water sports centers. Lifeguarded beach in summer.

Langogne sits at the crossroads of major trails: the GR70 (Stevenson Trail), GR700 (Voie Régordane), GR4, and GR470 (Sources et Gorges de l'Allier). Follow a section toward the Mercoire forest, 11,000 hectares where the Allier and Chassezac rivers rise.
Langogne's market runs Saturday mornings under the grain hall and in adjacent streets. A second market operates Tuesdays in summer. Cheeses, charcuterie, mountain honey, and Margeride lentils.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes

visits.text: Saint-Mammès Cathedral (1150-1196) combines the last Burgundian Romanesque influences with the first Gothic practices. Measuring 94 meters long, it rises 23 meters under the vault. Two Renaissance tapestries illustrate the legend of Saint Mammès.
Climb the 227 steps of the cathedral's south tower. At the summit, the view embraces the rooftops of the old town, the Langres plateau and distant forests.
Enter the Sainte-Croix chapel (1549), a Renaissance masterpiece: sculpted coffered vault, altar and floor in polychrome Rouen faïence.
The Maison des Lumières traces the universe of the 18th century and displays an original copy of the Encyclopédie. The philosopher Diderot was born here in 1713.
The Art and History Museum occupies the former Jesuit convent. Gallo-Roman collections, paintings and art objects cover twenty centuries of local history.
Admire the Porte des Moulins, a monumental entrance pierced in the ramparts in 1647. Its two round towers frame a vaulted passage adorned with rustication.
Langres' ramparts extend for 3.5 kilometers around the hilltop town. This defensive circuit features 12 towers and 7 gates spanning from Gallo-Roman times through the 19th century.
The Gallo-Roman arch dates to 20 BC, making it the town's oldest monument. Integrated into the walls near the Porte du Marché, it stands as silent witness to two millennia of history.
Saint-Mammès Cathedral was built between 1150 and 1196. Its design marries Burgundian Romanesque volumes with early Gothic ribbed vaulting—a transitional masterpiece.
The apse displays a hemicycle of monolithic columns and a frieze of carved foliage scrollwork. The west façade, rebuilt from 1761 to 1768, exemplifies classical restraint.
Two Renaissance tapestries from the 16th century illustrate the life of Saint Mammès. The Sainte-Croix chapel, constructed 1547-1549, boasts an ornately carved coffered vault.

activities.text: Walk the sentry path along the ramparts: 3.5 km of curtain walls punctuated by 12 towers and 7 gates. Viewpoints open onto the plateau, Lake Liez and distant mountain ranges.
Follow the golden studs of the "Pas à Pas" circuit on the ground: they guide through medieval and Renaissance alleys of the old town to the main monuments.
Visit the Tour de Navarre, a 16th-century cannon tower with a unique helical ramp inside France, designed to raise artillery pieces.
Walk the sentry path atop the ramparts. This promenade offers sweeping views across the surrounding countryside from over 130 meters above sea level.
Climb the 227 steps of the cathedral's south tower for spectacular panoramas over the town and rolling farmland beyond.
Sample Langres AOC cheese at local shops. This washed-rind cheese features a distinctive crater at its summit—traditionally filled with champagne or marc brandy.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests
Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: Gateway village to the plateau; shopping streets and mountain architecture.
Panoramas of the eastern ridges and valleys.

activities.text: Balcony path above the town (3–4 km).
Walk to a viewpoint over the Grenoble cluse.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral stands atop the hill like stone lacework. Built between 1150 and 1235, it represents one of the first major examples of French Gothic architecture. Sixteen sculpted oxen adorn its towers, recalling the legend of a miraculous ox descended from heaven to transport the stones. The interior displays stunning brightness thanks to tall windows and white limestone.

Climb the 209 steps of the tower to reach the lapidary museum installed in the galleries. This unique deposit in France displays about a hundred carved stones dating from the construction and 19th-century restoration. Gargoyles, capitals and medieval sculptures reveal themselves up close. The panorama over the upper town and surrounding plains rewards the ascent.

Explore the medieval underground passages with audio guide for a one-hour visit through the network of galleries dug beneath the city. These former quarries transformed into cellars tell the geological and political history of Laon. The new scenography recently inaugurated transforms the discovery into a true time journey under the crowned city.

The medieval ramparts encircle the upper town for several kilometers. Discover the fortified gates, notably the Ardon gate, and admire the sweeping view over the Axonais countryside. The walls punctuated with towers testify to Laon's strategic past.

activities.text: Wander through the cobblestone streets of the medieval upper town. Half-timbered houses line the narrow streets, including the oldest house in Laon with its round chimneys in the Pourrier alley. Private mansions and inner courtyards reveal themselves as you stroll.

The Euromédiévales bring the ramparts to life each year with shows, period craftsmen and activities for the whole family. The festival plunges the city into a medieval atmosphere during a festive weekend.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature

visits.text: Larressingle is France's smallest fortified village, nicknamed the little Carcassonne of the Gers. This 13th-century fortress is surrounded by 270 meters of ramparts with eight towers. The bridge replaced the original drawbridge. Inside, a few medieval houses nestle against the walls. The bishops' castle of Condom (private) and the Romanesque church of Saint-Sigismond complete this remarkably preserved village.

The fortified Romanesque church dates from the 12th century. It has a peculiarity: it houses a statue representing Saint Sigismund that is actually a reduced copy of the Vercingetorix statue from Alise-Sainte-Reine. An ordering mistake by the 19th-century priest that makes the story amusing.

Larressingle is France's smallest fortified village. Nicknamed 'little Carcassonne of Gers,' it preserves intact its 13th-century ramparts, crenellated towers, dry moat, and recently restored old drawbridge.

Cross through the vaulted gateway with broken barrel arch, topped by a bretèche. Inside, a handful of medieval houses lean against the curtain walls. The entire village can be toured in twenty minutes, yet the atmosphere suspends time.

At the heart of the enclosure, ruins of the castle of the abbots then bishops of Condom occupy the entire center. The building is private but its massive 13th-century walls dominate the village at full height.

The fortified Romanesque church of Saint-Sigismond, from the 12th and 13th centuries, combines architectural purity with modern stained glass. The atmosphere holds absolute calm, far from tourist bustle.
The Medieval Siege Engines Park, installed around the ramparts, recreates a medieval siege camp. Trebuchets, bricoles, and full-scale assault engines are presented with demonstrations.
A few minutes' walk away, the Lartigue Bridge spans the Osse River. Inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage as part of the Ways of St. James, it sits exactly 1,000 km from Santiago de Compostela.

activities.text: The medieval siege camp sits just outside the fortified town. From April to October, you can see and operate medieval war machines: catapults, trebuchets, and ballistas. Guides explain how they work and let you fire them. It's fun and educational for all ages.
Walk around the ramparts. The dry moats, crenellated towers, and arrow slits are clearly visible from outside. The village is quickly explored but the medieval atmosphere is genuinely preserved.
Larressingle sits on the Via Podiensis (GR 65). Walk a portion of the Way of St. James toward Condom or Montréal-du-Gers through the Gers wine country.
Estates producing Armagnac and Floc de Gascogne surround the village. Visit one to understand distillation and taste these two local specialties.

For families, try the treasure hunt 'Conquering the fortified citadel of Larressingle,' available at tourist offices in Condom, Larressingle, and Montréal-du-Gers. Two versions depending on children's ages.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Col d'Aubisque (1709 m): 360° panorama and orientation table at the summit.
Gourette: discovery of the resort and Bézou plateau (access by cable car in summer).
Lac de Bious-Artigues: easy loop along the lake with views of Pic du Midi d'Ossau.

activities.text: Aubisque → trail towards the ridge (Grum ridge type route) for extended viewpoints.
Gourette: mountain biking on dedicated trails (summer).
Bious-Artigues: family hike and supervised water activities (canoe/horseback riding depending on season).

days_plan.itin_title: Béarn & Basque Country: Pyrenean Passes to Atlantic Coast Soul

visits.text: Lassay-les-Châteaux, a Small Town of Character, boasts three castles. Victor Hugo, passing through in 1836, wrote to his wife that he'd seen 'Lassay, a charming half-wild little town with three castles, two of them admirable, which I sketched.'

The fortress, rebuilt in one campaign in 1458-1459 by Jean II de Vendôme after the Hundred Years' War, is a remarkable example of 15th-century military architecture. Its eight massive towers linked by curtain walls and ramparts, its barbican and drawbridge form an irregular octagon that has survived intact to this day—an exceptional occurrence in France.

The guided tour opens furnished rooms: bedroom, armory, kitchen with its granite cooking range and collection of antique copper. Arrive at the first tour to witness the drawbridge opening, or at the last to see it close.

A kilometer from the center, the ruins of Bois-Thibault castle raise their century-gilded towers amid the ivy. Built on a castle mound, it was home to the Du Bellay family—that of poet Joachim. Classified as a Historic Monument in 1925, it's maintained by a volunteer association.
Saint-Fraimbault church is dedicated to the 6th-century evangelizing hermit buried at Lassay, who allegedly inspired Chrétien de Troyes to create the character of Lancelot of the Lake.

The historic center in local granite can be explored on foot: picturesque lanes, houses from the 14th-18th centuries, colorful storefronts and preserved period signs. Spot the lintel carvings and turrets at street corners.

activities.text: Wander through Lassay's rose garden, near the old convent, where some 300 rose varieties offer an olfactory experience in season.
The medieval garden, connected to the castle, presents plants and herbs cultivated according to Middle Ages practices—aromatic, dye, medicinal.
Follow the Lassay river to discover the numerous old wash houses lining the waterway, witnesses to daily life of yesteryear.
The King Arthur legend interpretation trail connects the town's three castles (Lassay, Bois-Thibault and the Bois-Frou vestiges) through verdant landscapes and built heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: The Four Castles of Lastours — Cabaret, Tour Régine, Surdespine and Quertinheux perched at 300 m altitude. A major Cathar site, besieged by Simon de Montfort in 1211. Visiting trail 1h30.
Cabrespine Giant Chasm — One of the largest chasms in Europe, 250 m deep, 80 m wide. Suspended balconies at 200 m, glass walkway, aragonite crystals. Constant 14°C.
Montolieu, Book Village — Hilltop village with around fifteen bookshops and second-hand booksellers. Museum of Book Arts and Crafts. Views over the Montagne Noire.

activities.text: Castle hike — Full circuit through the 4 castles and the castrum of Cabaret. 250 m elevation gain, sturdy footwear essential.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean

places.name: Laudun L Ardoise Camp De Cesar

visits.text: Oppidum of Camp de César (Laudun plateau) with walls and circular towers.
Remains of roads, ancient habitats and places of worship (oratory and chapel).
Panorama over the Rhône corridor, the Cèze and the Tave.

activities.text: Archaeological loop on the plateau (3–5 km) with interpretation of defensive features.
Simple orientation workshop on map and identification of former access points.

days_plan.itin_title: Cèze Valley Road Trip, France: Ancient Gorges & Perched Medieval Villages in Provence

visits.text: The windmill of La Salette, dating from 1688, dominates the village from its hilltop. It's one of the last mills in Occitania that still grinds flour. Its sails open to visitors in season for a demonstration of traditional milling craft.

The Collégiale Saint-Rémy, classified as a Historical Monument since 1996, stretches 40 meters long in the village heart. Its marble retable is remarkable, and the pastel-blue interior tones recall that you're in the Pays de Cocagne.

Pass through the Porte de la Caussade, remnant of medieval fortifications. Behind it, the quarter contains underground silos carved into rock beneath homes: these round-bottomed 2 m³ vessels stored grain during wartime.
Stroll around the central square bordered by arcades and covered houses. 14th-century corbelled houses and half-timbered façades testify to prosperity from the pastel trade.
Climb to the Calvary of La Salette for the finest panorama of the Lautrec region. The view embraces the Agout valley, Montagne Noire, and on clear days, the Pyrenees chain.

activities.text: Walk the 'garlic trail,' an 8 km loop through Lautrec countryside. The path passes farms equipped with traditional drying rooms where pink garlic hangs in bunches called 'manouilles.'

Want to taste Label Rouge pink garlic from Lautrec? Friday mornings from mid-July through December, the garlic market sets up in the village. Its sweet, subtle flavor works equally well raw or roasted.
Visit a clog-maker's workshop reconstructed identically, with tools and machinery restored to working order. This nearly vanished craft genuinely existed in Lautrec until the early 1960s.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn Road Trip: Albi & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: Place des Cornières forms a medieval bastide founded in 1241 by the Count of Toulouse. Its semicircular arcades frame Gothic and Renaissance houses from the 15th to 18th centuries.
Saint-Barthélemy Church houses a 17th-century gilded Baroque altarpiece. The building testifies to the enrichment of this medieval trading town.
The defensive barbican offers panoramic views over the Quercy Blanc's limestone plateaus and valleys. Vistas extend across the Barguelonne and Lendou rivers.
The Pilgrim's Garden, classified as a remarkable garden, features a life-size game of goose. Each square retraces the history of the Compostela pilgrimage.
Wander lanes where half-timbered houses and stone dwellings follow one another. Carved facades recall the prosperity of medieval merchants.

activities.text: Walk the Via Podiensis passing through the bastide. Lauzerte is a major stop on the Way of Saint James between Le Puy-en-Velay and Spain.
Reach the Éveillé promenade to embrace the valleys. Hillsides wear orchards of Moissac Chasselas and Quercy melons.
Visit art galleries and artists' workshops installed in old dwellings. Lauzerte cultivates cultural vitality with exhibitions and summer concerts.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: Laval, prefecture of Mayenne and a Town of Art and History, has sprawled for a millennium along the riverside. Dominated by its medieval castle, the historic city overflows with half-timbered houses, steep lanes and townhouses.

The Old Castle, founded around 1020 by Guy de Dénéré on a hill overlooking a ford, is the town's emblematic monument. Its 34-meter cylindrical keep, crowned with a defensive hoarding, houses an exceptional 13th-century timber frame. The 12th-century Romanesque chapel boasts beautiful carved capitals.

The MANAS (Museum of Naïve Art and Singular Arts), installed in the castle since 1967, is France's first naïve art museum. It displays major collections across 1,100 m² including three canvases by Le Douanier Rousseau, a Laval native born in 1844, and works by Séraphine de Senlis. Free admission to permanent collections.

Pass through the Beucheresse Gate, one of the old fortified gates: it was in this tower that Le Douanier Rousseau was born. From the other side of the Old Bridge, the panorama of the castle and quays is Laval's most photographed view.

The Basilica of Notre-Dame d'Avesnières, on the right bank, is a fine Romanesque building from the 11th-12th centuries. Its chevet with radiating chapels is one of the most harmonious in western France.

The municipal Public Baths, labeled '20th-century Heritage,' are a jewel of Laval Art Deco. Their mosaics by Isidore Odorico play with blue and yellow contrasts in each cabin, following a pattern inspired by Viennese art.
The Saint-Julien wash-boat, last survivor of the fleet that animated the Mayenne riverbanks, recalls the time when washerwomen beat their laundry along the water.

activities.text: Climb up to the Perrine Garden, a haven of peace in the heart of town. This park overlooking the Mayenne shelters century-old trees, a rose garden and panoramic views of the river. At Le Douanier Rousseau's grave, read the verses engraved by his friend Guillaume Apollinaire.

Descend to Laval's port for an electric boat ride on the Mayenne. Southward, the river leads to the Abbey of Notre-Dame du Port-du-Salut (birthplace of the famous cheese) and the Gallo-Roman baths of Entrammes.
The towpath along the Mayenne is part of the Vélo Francette (from Caen to La Rochelle). Rent a bike to pedal along the river between manual locks and hedgerow landscapes.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: Lavaudieu's Romanesque cloister is the only one in Auvergne to have survived destruction intact. Its single or paired columns, crowned with sculpted capitals, support rounded arches beneath a 12th-century wooden gallery.

Enter the refectory adjoining the cloister. A monumental Byzantine-influenced fresco depicts Christ in Majesty above the Virgin surrounded by the Apostles. Classified as a Historic Monument as early as 1862.

The Abbey Church of Saint-André, crowned by its octagonal Romanesque bell tower, conceals a collection of 14th-century murals from the Italian School: Passion scenes and a curious allegory of the plague, the "Black Death."
The Benedictine abbey was founded in 1057 by Robert de Turlande, also founder of La Chaise-Dieu. Nuns lived here until the Revolution, in this place baptized Lavaudieu—"Valley of God."
Visit the Museum of Folk Arts and Traditions, housed in the former baker's home. Over a thousand objects recreate an Auvergnat interior from days past.
Notice the abbey's bell tower, truncated during the Revolution: a pike and Phrygian cap still ornament its summit, an unusual republican vestige.

activities.text: Stroll along the Senouire River and cross the Romanesque bridge. From both sides, the view of the golden stone wine-growers' houses and terra-cotta tiles is exceptional.
Meander through the cobbled lanes of the village, classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages. Kitchen gardens nestled around the abbey and an 18th-century iron cross punctuate the walk.
In summer, the village hosts its traditional wine festival, a custom born during the Revolution when locals seized barrels destined for the monks of La Chaise-Dieu.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Saint-Alain Cathedral, a masterpiece of southern French Gothic, was built from 1255 onward. Its single nave rises 23 meters high. The carved polychrome wooden organ case from 1523 is a jewel of Midi Renaissance art.

Look up at the tower: the Jacquemart, a 17th-century wooden automaton, still strikes the hours. It's the only working example in southwestern France. Legend has it that a Protestant prisoner built it to escape.
The Bishop's Gardens, north of the cathedral, form a carefully flowered French formal garden from May to October. The subtly colored beds descend in terraces with views over the Agout.
Follow the path to the Tour des Rondes, remnant of medieval fortifications. Here in 1211, during the Albigensian Crusade, 400 Cathars perished in the crusade's largest mass burning.

Place du Plô overlooks the Agout. The paved streets of the medieval quarter are lined with half-timbered houses and brick mansions, witnesses to the era when Lavaur was capital of the Pays de Cocagne.
Saint-François Church, built in the 17th century by Franciscans, offers a contrast of simplicity and intimacy after the cathedral's grandeur. Its modest nave invites contemplative pause.

activities.text: The Saturday morning market invades Lavaur's avenues. It's one of the region's largest: farm products, poultry, foie gras, cheeses, and local crafts spread across the stalls.

Follow the Roman road between Lavaur and Puylaurens, which runs along the hilltops of Pays de Cocagne. The landscape of pastel fields, dovecotes, and white stone houses recreates the atmosphere of a flamboyant era.
Attend an organ concert at the cathedral when programming permits. The grand 1876 Cavaillé-Coll organ attracts international organists for regular recitals.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn Road Trip: Albi & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: The Cluniac Priory of Sainte-Croix was founded in 1025 by Odilon de Mercoeur, 5th Abbot of Cluny. The buildings visible today date mainly from the 15th and 18th centuries, their hemicycle form hugging the Allier's meander.
Step inside the Priory Church of Sainte-Croix, in Gothic style (15th c.). It preserves a Romanesque door called Saint Odilon's Door (12th c.) and a polychrome wooden Christ from the mid-12th century.
Look for the statuette of Notre-Dame-Trouvée: in 1496, two girls playing by the Allier discovered this 0.6-inch Virgin inside a broken pebble. She is preserved in a silver reliquary.
Cross the humpbacked medieval bridge linking the village's two quarters. One of its arches dates back to the 11th century—it has resisted centuries of violent Allier floods.
The Maison des Oiseaux et de la Nature, in the priory courtyard, presents around fifty bird species from the Allier gorges, sculpted life-size in wood against a fresco backdrop.
Explore the Barrys quarter, the village's oldest, with its traboules—narrow characteristic passageways allowing quick descent to the river.

activities.text: Descend the Allier gorges by canoe or kayak. Outfitters offer trips suited to all levels departing from the village.
Take the belvedere loop (PR001, 2 km / 1.2 mi) for a unique view of the Allier's perfect loop around the priory. Family-friendly.
In summer, swim in the Allier from the beach near the bridge. This river, one of the last wild rivers in Europe, is also ideal for family fishing.
The GR 470 "Source et Gorges de l'Allier" crosses the village. The Lavoûte-Chilhac–Langeac stage (19 km / 12 mi) offers gorge landscapes hemmed between volcanoes and forests.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Village of Le Bec-Hellouin. Eure's second village labeled among France's Most Beautiful Villages, this Norman gem enchants with its colorful half-timbered houses, flower-filled cobbled streets, and preserved atmosphere. Nestled in the Bec valley hollow, it offers a condensed essence of authentic charm that echoes its neighbor Lyons-la-Forêt.

Notre-Dame Abbey of Le Bec. Founded in 1034 by knight Herluin, this Benedictine abbey became one of Europe's greatest spiritual and intellectual centers. Two of its abbots, Lanfranc and Anselm, became Archbishops of Canterbury. The 15th-century Saint-Nicolas tower, the site's symbol, dominates the cloister and Maurist buildings with their elegant facades. Monks perpetuate monastic life and sell their delicate handcrafted ceramics in the shop.
Saint-André Church of Le Bec-Hellouin. Erected in 1039 and dependent on the abbey until the Revolution, this neo-Gothic parish church houses the tomb of Blessed Herluin, the abbey's founder.

Sainte-Françoise Romaine Monastery. Two kilometers from the abbey, 26 Benedictine nuns live according to the Rule of Saint Benedict in buildings constructed since 1950. You can buy handcrafted candles there and enjoy absolute calm for a spiritual retreat.

activities.text: Le Bec-Hellouin Organic Farm. This permaculture farm, located 500 meters from the abbey, is a global reference in agroecology. Training sessions and tours reveal this productive agriculture without tractors or pesticides, where ecosystems interact harmoniously.

Château d'Harcourt and arboretum. Eight kilometers from Le Bec-Hellouin, this 12th-century medieval castle is surrounded by one of France's oldest arboretums (1802). Nearly 500 species of century-old trees compose this remarkable park.

Château du Champ de Bataille. Twelve kilometers away, this 17th-century château restored by decorator Jacques Garcia presents sumptuous interiors and exceptional French formal gardens. A journey into the French art de vivre.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure Road Trip: From Giverny to Normandy's Finest Medieval Villages

Château square of Le Castellet and viewpoint of "Trou de Madame" over the Sainte-Baume massif
Village of La Cadière-d'Azur and orientation table with panorama over the Var countryside

Xtrem Park at the Paul Ricard Circuit: recreational activities like quad biking, zip line, trampoline and driving simulators

days_plan.itin_title: Marseille to Cassis: A Coastal Drive to the Best Calanques & Villages

visits.text: The Matisse Departmental Museum occupies the Palais Fénelon, the former palace of the archbishops of Cambrai. Founded by Matisse himself in 1952 in his hometown, it gathers 783 works by the master: 26 paintings, 21 sculptures, 479 drawings and cut-outs, including Window in Tahiti and the Oceania series.

The Auguste Herbin collection, another Le Cateau-Cambrésis native, presents 92 works by this pioneering artist of geometric abstraction. His stained glass Joie, with vivid colors and pure forms, encapsulates his quest for a universal plastic language.

What treasures filled publisher Tériade's dining room? The museum displays this entire room, decorated by Matisse and Giacometti. The Tériade donation counts 590 works signed by Picasso, Chagall, Miró, Giacometti and Léger—a panorama of 20th-century art assembled by one man.
The Palais Fénelon itself merits attention. This 18th-century edifice, former residence of Cambrai's archbishops, presents an orderly classical façade overlooking Place du Commandant-Richez.

The French formal garden, laid out in the late 17th century in Le Nôtre's style, extends behind the palace. One hundred seventy-five trees, including three-hundred-year-old lindens, border its rectilinear paths traced in classical perspective.

activities.text: Take time to sketch in the museum's galleries. Drawing workshops are regularly offered before Matisse's works—a way to grasp the line simplification characteristic of his late work, between purity and color.

Walk through Le Cateau-Cambrésis center, from the market square to Saint-Martin Church. The small town has preserved a coherent urban fabric, with 19th-century brick houses aligned along narrow streets leading to the Selle.

Le Cateau-Cambrésis holds France's third-largest Matisse collection, after Nice and Paris. Compare the cut-outs exhibited here with those you may have seen elsewhere: the installation illuminates the master's creative process, from sketch to finished work.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

visits.text: Le Chambon-sur-Lignon Memorial Site. Opened in 2013, this profoundly moving museum chronicles how this mountain village saved thousands of persecuted Jews during World War II. The exhibits explore the unique character of the Vivarais-Lignon plateau and what motivated ordinary villagers to risk everything in spiritual, civil, and armed resistance. The memorial room presents testimonies from rescuers, refugees, and resistance fighters. Nearly 90 people have been proclaimed Righteous Among the Nations. The Memory Garden, designed by renowned landscape architect Louis Benech, offers a place for contemplation and remembrance.

Le Chambon Temple. Built around 1821 on land donated by Valla Chomier, this Protestant temple replaced its predecessor destroyed in 1679 during the Wars of Religion. Above the granite stone porch, the inscription 'Love one another' embodies the village's tradition of welcome. Here on June 23, 1940, pastors André Trocmé and Edouard Theis called their congregation to resist with 'the weapons of the spirit'—a sermon that transformed this community into a sanctuary for thousands. The building itself witnesses to the plateau's deep Protestant roots.

Le Chambon Historic Center. Place de la Fontaine forms the village heart with its shops and cafés. All around, pine forests, groves, and footpaths create a peaceful atmosphere even in the center of town. The 2,400 residents live surrounded by nature interwoven with built heritage. Historic houses, old hotels, and public buildings tell the story of the village's tourist development, which began in the early 20th century when the railway arrived from Saint-Étienne.

activities.text: Vivarais-Lignon Plateau Hike. The Plateau of the Righteous circuit offers stunning panoramas of the volcanic peaks, the Lizieux summit, and Mont Mézenc. Approximately 16 km. Marked trails wind through pine forests, groves, and meadows between 874 and 1,139 meters elevation. The village's natural lake provides summer swimming and water sports. The 18-hole golf course spreads across a beautifully wooded, rolling site.

Memory Trail through the Village. Guided tours offered year-round for groups and on Tuesday evenings in summer for individuals. The circuit begins at the station with historical context, continues through the 'Welcome and Words from our Villages' exhibition, then winds on foot through the village discovering Aunt Soly's shelter, the presbytery, the old village, and the school. The tour concludes with a reflective moment in the temple. Reservations at the Tourist Office.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Le Croisic's harbor springs to life at dawn when the trawlers return. The modernized fish auction hall sells sea bass, sole, and langoustines while the catch is still glistening.

The Océarium showcases 4,000 marine creatures in tanks recreating tropical and Atlantic ecosystems. Sharks, rays, and clownfish glide through immersive tunnels that put you at the heart of underwater worlds.
Climb Mont Esprit for a 360-degree view of the peninsula. The panorama sweeps from salt marshes to open ocean, tracing the coastline all the way to La Baule's famous beach.
The Côte Sauvage lives up to its name with wave-battered rocks and dramatic cliffs. A coastal path runs between windswept heathland and the Atlantic, reaching the tip of Pen Bron peninsula.

activities.text: Cycle around the Guérande peninsula between ocean and marshland. Bike paths connecting Le Croisic, La Baule, and Guérande weave through some of Brittany's most distinctive landscapes.
