visits.text: The Vauban Citadel has dominated Le Palais harbor since 1549. Expanded by Fouquet then fortified by Vauban in 1683, it served as a state prison - political detainees were imprisoned there until the 20th century. The rampart walk offers a complete panorama over the harbor.
The Aiguilles de Port-Coton, rocky pyramids battered by waves, fascinated a famous Impressionist who painted them 39 times in 1886. Colors change with each hour depending on light and tide.
Pointe des Poulains, at the island's northern tip, takes its name from the 'poulains' - rock debris extending it. A 19th-century military fort is accessible at low tide via a submersible causeway.
The Grand Phare, commissioned in 1836, rises 52 meters. Its 247 steps lead to a circular panorama embracing the Wild Coast, the mainland, and on clear days, Noirmoutier island.
Le Palais harbor, protected by two jetties, displays colorful houses facing the boats. Pastel facades - pink, yellow, blue - date from the 19th century when shipowners competed in elegance.
Donnant Beach: wedged between two black schist cliffs, this wild beach receives Atlantic swells head-on. Surfers frequent it; swimmers remain cautious of currents.

activities.text: Ride the Wild Coast by bike (rental at the port). The road follows 30 to 60-meter cliffs, interspersed with inaccessible coves and sea caves.
The coastal path from Port-Coton to Port-Goulphar winds along cliff edges between heather and gorse moors. Views of the needles and sea caves are spectacular.
Reach Pointe des Poulains at low tide to access the small fort. Absolutely check tide times: the causeway covers in 20 minutes at rising tide.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Le Paradou — medieval village between Baux and Maussane, narrow streets and fountains.
Heritage trail: wash houses, oratories and stone houses.

activities.text: Shaded walk along the irrigation canals.
Walking loop towards Maussane (one way possible).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: The 12th-century keep towers over the village, its pale yellow stone walls glowing in the sunlight. The Knights Hospitaller of Saint John of Jerusalem established a commandery here—one of the most significant in all of Provence.

Step through the gates of the Château des Hospitaliers, meticulously restored by the French Historic Monuments Commission in 1996. The Renaissance wing adjoining the keep now hosts permanent and rotating exhibitions showcasing regional art and history.

The Chapelle Saint-Jean-des-Commandeurs dates from the early 13th century. From rue Neuve, the view of its standing nave and choir is striking—a testament to medieval craftsmanship weathering the centuries.

Wind through the covered rue de la Chalanque, then descend the lower rampart street. Vaulted passages, uneven stone steps, and sun-drenched terraces form a labyrinth blissfully free of cars and modern intrusions.

The former 17th-century Protestant temple—one of the rare survivors in France—now houses the Museum of Dauphiné Protestantism. Its exhibits trace the Reformation's rise, the bloody Wars of Religion, and the exile of Huguenot families who fled persecution.

The Yvon Morin Art Center occupies beautifully restored rooms built from materials salvaged throughout the village. Each summer it hosts major exhibitions alongside intimate evening concerts in the stone halls.

activities.text: Make your way to the Grand Portail, the village's ancient entrance framed by a vaulted chicane passage, then climb to the benches overlooking the Jabron Valley. The panorama sweeps across forested hills and lavender fields that shimmer purple in summer.

Le Poët-Laval marks the starting point of the "Huguenot Trail," a 1,800-km European footpath retracing the exile route of Dauphiné Protestants who fled to Germany. The first few kilometers wind through the surrounding hills and offer a taste of this historic journey.

Curious about local pottery? The nearby town of Dieulefit has kept alive an ancient ceramic tradition spanning centuries. Studios open their doors to visitors, offering a glimpse into the artisan's world.

days_plan.itin_title: Rhône-Alpes Circuit: Perched Villages and Mountain Peaks

visits.text: The Church of Notre-Dame du Raincy, the world's first church built entirely in reinforced concrete, was erected in just thirteen months in 1922-1923. Its bell tower rises 43 meters. Le Corbusier called it "the Sainte-Chapelle of reinforced concrete."
Inside, 32 slender columns support barrel vaults. Load-bearing walls are replaced by openwork concrete claustra where stained glass is set, transforming the walls into walls of light.

The stained glass, designed by a Nabis painter and created by a pioneering female master glassmaker, adorns all the walls. Ten large figurative windows illustrate the life of the Virgin and the departure of the Marne taxis toward the Battle of the Ourcq in September 1914.
Le Raincy preserves beautiful turn-of-the-century villas along its tree-lined avenues. Walk down Allée des Tilleuls to admire millstone facades and enclosed gardens.
Le Raincy high school occupies a historic property surrounded by a vast park. Its gates and courtyard of honor deserve a glance in passing.

activities.text: Walk to the Allée de Montfermeil, a straight forest clearing that crosses the wooded heights between Le Raincy and Montfermeil. A verdant stroll far from urban tumult.
Look up at Le Raincy's modern architecture: the town served as an urban planning laboratory with its early-20th-century subdivisions conceived as garden cities.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: Eu Castle — This 16th-century brick and stone castle was the summer residence of King Louis-Philippe from 1830 to 1848. Its apartments preserve Second Empire furniture and decor. The park of 22 hectares includes a French garden and an English garden.

Saint-Laurent Collegiate Church of Eu — This 12th-16th century Gothic church shelters the crypt where the counts of Eu rest, including the Guise princes. Its flamboyant portal and Renaissance statues testify to four centuries of construction.

Le Tréport Funicular — This 1908 funicular climbs the 100-meter cliff in 3 minutes. The upper station offers a breathtaking panorama of the Bresle estuary, Mers-les-Bains and its Belle Époque villas. An emblematic experience of the resort.

Port of Le Tréport — This fishing port welcomes a fleet of about thirty trawlers. The daily fish auction and the port restaurants offer freshly caught scallops, sole and herring. The quays provide a close view of fishing boats.

activities.text: Mers-les-Bains — Neighboring seaside resort on the Picardy coast, Mers-les-Bains displays 300 Belle Époque villas with polychrome facades classified as historical monuments. Their carved wooden balconies, bay windows and ceramics form a unique architectural ensemble.
Le Tréport Beach — This pebble beach bordered by cliffs has welcomed Parisians since the arrival of the train in 1873. Colorful beach cabins and seafood restaurants perpetuate the bathing tradition.

Saint-Jacques Church of Le Tréport — This 15th-16th century flamboyant Gothic church dominates the port with its massive silhouette. Its pendant keystones and Renaissance porch testify to the port's prosperity in the Middle Ages.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Maritime Road Trip: Cliffs of Étretat, Rouen and Jumièges Abbey

visits.text: Lectoure commands the Gers valley from its rocky promontory. The Cathedral of Saint-Gervais-Saint-Protais blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its fortified bell tower bears witness to its defensive past.

The archaeological museum holds a unique collection of Roman taurobolic altars. These 20 sacrificial altars from the 2nd and 3rd centuries were discovered in Lectoure. It's an exceptional collection found nowhere else.

The Gallo-Roman villa of Séviac lies 5 km away. This archaeological site showcases superb mosaics that once covered the floors of a wealthy Roman residence. Geometric patterns and mythological scenes remain beautifully preserved. The villa extended over more than 6,500 square meters.

activities.text: In summer, Lectoure is famous for its melon. This local specialty has its own protected designation of origin. You'll find them at markets, and producers offer tastings.
Wander the medieval lanes descending from the cathedral. Honey-colored stone houses, vaulted passageways, and small squares give the upper town tremendous character.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: The Louvre-Lens, inaugurated in 2012 on a former mining site, is all glass and light—a SANAA-designed symbol of the coalfield's UNESCO-listed rebirth.
The Time Gallery unfolds 200 Louvre masterpieces across 3,000 square meters of open space. A chronological journey from Mesopotamia to the 19th century flows uninterrupted, without walls or barriers.
Visit the miners' housing estate adjacent to the museum. These 19th-century corons (row houses)—UNESCO protected—reveal workers' life with their gardens, narrow alleys, and communal wells.
Base 11-19 at Loos-en-Gohelle preserves the pithead and its industrial buildings. This UNESCO site chronicles coal extraction from 1891 to 1960.
Stade Bollaert-Delelis, opened in 1932, is a cathedral of French football. Lens supporters, crowned best fans in France, create an electric atmosphere unmatched anywhere.

activities.text: Climb the twin slag heaps of Loos-en-Gohelle, Europe's highest at 186 meters. From the summit, 360° views sweep across the mining basin with glimpses of Vimy and Lorette.
Stroll through the Louvre-Lens landscaped park. The main axes follow former railway tracks, and grass mounds evoke the slag heaps that shaped this landscape.
Discover downtown Lens and its Art Deco treasures. Elegant facades and shops fill a neighborhood rebuilt after 1918 with distinctive style.

days_plan.itin_title: Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: Château Gaillard. Richard the Lionheart's proud fortress has dominated one of the Seine's most beautiful loops for 800 years. Built in just two years (1196–1198), this feat of military architecture prompted the King of England to exclaim: 'How beautiful she is, my one-year-old daughter!' The keep offers breathtaking panoramas over the valley and Petit-Andely below. Guided tours available April through November.

Petit-Andely. This medieval village born in the castle's shadow retains its picturesque charm. The 12th-century Saint-Sauveur church and narrow streets lined with old houses invite wandering. Facing the Seine, the quays offer the finest view of the perched fortress.

Notre-Dame Collegiate Church of Grand-Andely. Founded in the 6th century by Queen Clotilde, wife of Clovis, this church blends styles from the 13th to 17th centuries. Its 16th-century Renaissance stained glass windows rank among Normandy's finest. The Sainte-Clotilde fountain, a miraculous spring that appeared during construction, still draws pilgrims.

Nicolas Poussin Museum. Housed in a 17th-century mansion, this museum honors the classical painter born in Les Andelys in 1594. Local history collections, paintings, and art objects trace this strategic city's past.
Gisors — climb the feudal motte to explore the castle ramparts and towers
Gisors — admire the Renaissance flourishes inside Saint-Gervais-Saint-Protais Church
Les Andelys — hike up to Richard the Lionheart's ruined Château Gaillard for commanding Seine valley views
Les Andelys — visit Notre-Dame church and the Nicolas Poussin Museum celebrating the baroque master

activities.text: Richard the Lionheart Loop hike. This 8 km walking trail starts from the Seine riverbanks, crosses Petit-Andely, and climbs to the castle via limestone hillsides. The viewpoints over the river's meanders are spectacular, especially at sunset.
Seine river cruise. Cruise ships dock at Les Andelys to admire Château Gaillard from the river. Boat tours reveal this majestic loop from a unique perspective.
Seine riverside walk — connect Petit and Grand Andely along the peaceful waterfront

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage
The Most Beautiful Villages of Provence: Luberon, Alpilles & Verdon

visits.text: Padirac — Myth of the "devil's step".
Puymartin — "White Lady".
Commarque — Knight & mount.

The National Museum of Prehistory in Les Eyzies houses over 18,000 artifacts spanning 400,000 years of human history. With nearly 7 million pieces in its collections, it's the world's largest repository of prehistoric materials. Paul Dardé's imposing statue of Primitive Man looms above the entrance—a fitting welcome to the birthplace of paleoanthropology.

Font-de-Gaume Cave is one of the last painted sanctuaries of the Ice Age still open to the public. Discovered in 1901, its galleries shelter approximately 230 polychrome images—bison, horses, mammoths, and reindeer—painted 14,000 years ago. To preserve these fragile masterpieces, visits are strictly limited to 13 people at a time. Book weeks in advance.

Combarelles Cave contains 800 engraved figures etched along 300 meters of narrow galleries. Discovered just three days before Font-de-Gaume in September 1901, it stands out for its 48 human representations—an unusual subject in Ice Age art. The engravings are subtle, rendered in fine lines that emerge slowly from the rock as your eyes adjust.

activities.text: Access: public (Padirac)
Access: public (Puymartin)
Access: public (Commarque)

The Vézère Valley concentrates about fifteen UNESCO-listed prehistoric sites within a few kilometers. Beyond the painted caves, you can explore the Pataud Shelter (14 distinct occupation levels), the Cro-Magnon Shelter (where the first anatomically modern humans in Europe were discovered in 1868), and the Cap-Blanc Shelter, famous for its sculpted frieze of life-sized horses.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine's Haunted History: Cursed Castles & Prehistoric Cave Legends
Dordogne Road Trip: Cave Art, Medieval Fortresses & Périgord Delights

visits.text: Les Riceys holds the unique distinction in France of having three wine AOCs: Champagne, Coteaux Champenois and the legendary Rosé des Riceys. This pink wine, recognized AOC since 1947, was King Louis XIV's favorite. Produced only in exceptional years from 100% Pinot Noir, it develops aromas of red fruits and almonds. Only 50 to 100,000 bottles produced per year. Several estates offer tastings — book ahead as production is limited.

Largest wine commune in Champagne with 866 hectares of vines, Les Riceys actually groups three villages: Ricey-Bas, Ricey-Haut and Ricey-Haute-Rive, each with its own Renaissance church. The Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens churches in Ricey-Bas and Ricey-Haute-Rive showcase remarkable 16th-century stained glass. Walk through the three hamlets discovering half-timbered winegrowers' houses, wine cellars, communal washhouses. Authentic wine village atmosphere.

activities.text: The Riceys vineyard trail: 8 km marked circuit through vines. Interpretation panels explain viticulture, terroir, Rosé des Riceys specificity. Panoramic viewpoints over the three villages and surrounding hills. Moderate difficulty with elevation changes. Allow 2h30 walking. Download the map from the tourist office before departure.

Visit champagne estates: many Riceys producers welcome visitors to their cellars. Family estates explain their work from vine to bottle. Tasting of their three AOCs: champagne, Coteaux Champenois red and the famous rosé. Meet passionate winegrowers attached to their terroir. Direct purchase possible at estate prices.

Discovery of the bell tower, fountain, old washhouses and war memorial, remnants of the vanished village.
Stroll through the new village with its flower-lined streets and revisited Provençal architecture.

Provençal market on Thursday morning and local products on the main square.

activities.text: Belvedere hike (round trip ~2 h, ~300 m elevation gain), vulture observation depending on conditions.

days_plan.itin_title: Béarn & Basque Country: Pyrenean Passes to Atlantic Coast Soul

visits.text: Cap Leucate — 40-meter limestone cliffs overlooking the Mediterranean. Sentier du Guetteur trail (4.3 km) between lighthouse, semaphore and panoramic viewpoints. Views of Mount Canigou on clear days.
La Franqui — The oldest seaside resort on the Aude coast, nestled in a pine grove. Plage des Coussoules: 8 km of fine sand classified Natura 2000. A world-class kitesurfing spot.
Leucate Lagoon — A 5,400-hectare lagoon. 280 bird species, pink flamingos. Kitesurfing and windsurfing spots. Oyster farms on the channel.
Village of Leucate — A Mediterranean village perched on its rock, with castle ruins. Lively square, colorful lanes. Sunsets over the lagoon from the belvedere.

activities.text: Kitesurfing or windsurfing — France's top spot, 300 days of wind per year (tramontane). Schools for beginners, sea or lagoon spots depending on level.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean

visits.text: Lose yourself in the cobbled streets of Old Lille. The brick and white stone façades blend Flemish and French styles, with 17th-century crow-stepped gables lining rue de la Monnaie and rue Esquermoise.

The Grand'Place (Place du Général-de-Gaulle) opens onto the Column of the Goddess, erected to commemorate the Austrian siege of 1792. All around, the façades of La Voix du Nord and the New Exchange create a striking Flemish backdrop.

Push through one of the four wooden portals of the Old Exchange, crowned with the lions of Flanders. This Renaissance Flemish jewel (1652-1653) aligns 24 identical houses around a courtyard where booksellers and chess players gather beneath the arcades.

The Town Hall belfry soars 104 meters high—the tallest in the world. This UNESCO-listed tower offers sweeping views of the entire metropolis from its summit. At its base, two sculpted giants recount the legend of Lydéric and Phinaert, mythical founders of the city.

The Palais des Beaux-Arts on Place de la République is France's second-largest museum by number of works after the Louvre. Its galleries house canvases by Rubens, Van Dyck, Goya and Delacroix, 40 sheets by Raphael, and fifteen relief maps of Vauban's fortified towns.

Notre-Dame de la Treille Cathedral surprises with its contemporary translucent marble façade, completed in 1999, which contrasts with its 19th-century neo-Gothic nave. The crypt houses a collection of contemporary sacred art.

The Hospice Comtesse, founded in 1237 by Countess Jeanne de Flandre, houses Lille's museum of art and history. The patients' ward, covered with a vaulted timber ceiling, recalls the Hôtel-Dieu of Beaune. In the kitchen, walls are tiled with Lille faience inspired by Delft.

The Porte de Paris, a triumphal arch erected between 1685 and 1692, celebrates Louis XIV's conquest of Lille. Its allegorical sculptures represent Victory, Hercules and Mars. It marks the historic entrance to the city.

The Palais Rihour, last remnant of the Dukes of Burgundy's residence in Lille (15th century), preserves a Gothic guard room and a chapel with ribbed vaults. The monumental white stone staircase is worth the visit alone.
Head to rue de la Monnaie, one of Lille's oldest streets. Its 17th-century Flemish gabled houses, in brick and limestone, are among the best-preserved in the city.

Charles de Gaulle's birthplace on rue Princesse recreates the bourgeois Lille interior of the late 19th century. It was here, in his maternal grandparents' home, that the future president was born in 1890.

activities.text: Stroll the shaded paths of Citadel Park, designed by Vauban in 1667. This pentagonal fortress, nicknamed the "Queen of Citadels," is surrounded by moats and woods where locals come to jog and picnic.

Sample Flemish specialties in an Old Lille estaminet: Welsh rarebit (cheddar melted with beer on toast), carbonnade flamande, and potjevleesch (terrine of meats in aspic). Local beer accompanies each dish.
Browse along rue de la Monnaie and rue Esquermoise to admire the finest shop windows in Old Lille. Boutiques occupy Flemish townhouses with sculpted façades.
The Wazemmes market comes alive every Sunday morning. Spices, fresh vegetables, colorful fabrics and roasted poultry spread across Place de la Nouvelle Aventure in a warm, cosmopolitan atmosphere.
Ready for shopping? Euralille, designed by Rem Koolhaas, is one of northern France's largest shopping centers. Its futuristic architecture contrasts sharply with the Flemish heritage of downtown.
In September, the Grande Braderie transforms Lille into a gigantic flea market for an entire weekend. Mussels and fries flow freely and piles of empty shells accumulate outside the estaminets.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage
Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: Visit to Château de Rochechouart, housing the Museum of Contemporary Art of Haute-Vienne.
Walk through the old town of Rochechouart and discovery of the Rochechouart-Chassenon meteorite impact crater.
Route to Oradour-sur-Glane to visit the martyred village preserved in memory of the events of 1944.

The Musée national Adrien Dubouché showcases 5,000 ceramic pieces from a reserve collection of 18,000. The circular route spans antiquity to contemporary porcelain, centered around the world's richest Limoges collection.

Step through the doors of Gare des Bénédictins, a classified Historic Monument. Built between 1924 and 1929, it blends Art Nouveau, Art Deco, and Neoclassical styles. Its campanile rises 61 meters high, while the copper dome crowns a hall bathed in light from Francis Chigot's stained glass depicting Limousin chestnut trees and foliage.

The Four des Casseaux, a classified Historic Monument, is a former porcelain kiln built in 1900. It bears witness to the titanic work of porcelain workers during 19th-century firings and hosts temporary exhibitions of contemporary ceramics.

Walk down to Cathédrale Saint-Étienne, the only monument in Limousin built in pure Gothic style. Construction stretched from 1273 to 1888. Admire the Flamboyant Gothic Saint-Jean portal, the Renaissance rood screen commissioned in 1533, and three sculpted tombs in the ambulatory.

The Jardins de l'Évêché cascade in terraces below the cathedral, offering sweeping views over the Vienne River. The botanical garden assembles medicinal plants and toxic species. The Musée des Beaux-Arts, housed in the former 18th-century episcopal palace, holds a remarkable collection of medieval enamels.
Cross the Pont Saint-Étienne, built around 1210 over the Vienne. Its medieval arches link the Cité quarter to the left bank and offer one of the finest views of the cathedral.

Visit a porcelain manufacture for an immersive guided tour. From raw material to finished product, you'll follow every manufacturing stage: modeling, slip casting, glazing, and high-fire kiln firing. Artisans work before your eyes.

The Église Saint-Michel-des-Lions, built between the 14th and 16th centuries, takes its name from two granite lions flanking its portal. It preserves the relics of Saint Martial and Saint Valérie, displayed during the septennial Ostensions.
The Église Saint-Pierre-du-Queyroix features a typically Limousin bell tower and beautiful stained glass. Its late Gothic atmosphere contrasts with the dark granite facade.

Discover the Cour du Temple, an elegant 17th-century Renaissance courtyard tucked between Rue du Temple and Rue du Consulat. Its arcades and terraces form an unexpected jewel in the heart of downtown.
The Pavillon du Verdurier, an octagonal Art Deco building designed by the railway station's architect, is adorned with porcelain and enamel tiles. It regularly hosts exhibitions.

activities.text: Reflective walk through the ruins of Oradour-sur-Glane, classified as a historic site.
Return to Limoges through the Limousin countryside and end of the circuit.

Wander through the Quartier de la Boucherie, Limoges' most picturesque neighborhood: half-timbered houses, narrow lanes, and the 15th-century Chapelle Saint-Aurélien, owned by the butchers' guild. The Maison traditionnelle de la Boucherie traces the techniques and tools of this corporation active since the Middle Ages.

Beneath Place de la République, the Crypte Saint-Martial preserves vestiges of the Benedictine abbey founded in the 9th century. This medieval scriptorium spread the art of illumination and polyphonic music — the word 'troubadour' was born here, from the 'tropes' composed by monks.
Head up to Place de la Motte in late afternoon to enjoy the terraces and illuminated half-timbered facades. The atmosphere buzzes with life in the evenings.
The Halles centrales de Limoges are a food lover's rendezvous. Fine-grained Limousin beef, farmhouse cheeses, chestnuts, and clafoutis: taste the spirit of Limousin among the market stalls.
Try your hand at modeling or painting on porcelain in a workshop. Beginners welcome — you'll leave with your own creation.
Stroll along the Vienne riverbanks in late afternoon for a peaceful walk between medieval bridges. Limoges boasts 52 m² of green space per inhabitant: nature is never far away.

days_plan.itin_title: A Road Trip Through the Heart of Limousin: Historic Castles, Porcelain & Countryside
Haute-Vienne Circuit: Limoges, Porcelain & Historic Villages
Haute-Vienne Circuit: Limoges, Porcelain & Historic Villages

visits.text: Historic center of Limoux — Capital of Blanquette, home to the world's longest carnival (3 months). Place de la République lined with arcades, half-timbered houses, medieval Pont Vieux.
Blanquette cellars — The world's oldest sparkling wine, discovered in 1531 at the Abbey of Saint-Hilaire. The ancestral method predates champagne. Tours and tastings.
Notre-Dame de Marceille — Pilgrimage sanctuary 3 km from Limoux. 14th-century Gothic church, miraculous Black Virgin, sacred spring. Views of the Pyrenees.

activities.text: Cellar visit and tasting — Century-old cellars, traditional method: hand riddling, disgorgement. Blanquette, Crémant and still wines.
Limoux Carnival — The world's longest carnival, January to March. Masked Fécos every weekend on the main square. Each band represents a neighborhood.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean

visits.text: Porte Haute, flanked by two towers, guards the medieval town entrance. It ranks among the finest examples of fortified gates in Meurthe-et-Moselle.
The 12th-century Collégiale Saint-Pierre features a Romanesque tower topped with a modern bell tower. The organ, restored in 1999, dates from 1847.
Château Corbin was built on the ramparts between two towers. Its park offers views over the Moselle loop and now houses a media library.
Place de la Fontaine reveals 16th-century arcades. The Renaissance facades testify to the architectural wealth of this summer residence of the Bishops of Toul.
The 18th-century presbytery houses the tourist office. From its windows, views extend over the Moselle loop.

activities.text: Head to the viewpoints over the Moselle loop from Porte Haute or Château Corbin park. The Moselle draws a spectacular meander around the promontory.
Explore the medieval town's cobbled lanes. Corner statuettes served as landmarks for visitors.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: The Forest Park of the Poudrerie spans 137 hectares, the last witness to the immense Bondy forest. Created by decree of Napoleon III in 1865, the national gunpowder factory produced civilian and military powders for a century. Some thirty brick and stone buildings survive among the century-old oaks.

The Technical Museum of Gunpowder and Armament traces the history of this pioneering factory. The first steam-powered gunpowder plant, it employed up to 3,300 workers during World War I, producing 28 tons of powder daily.
The entrance pavilions of the Cour d'Honneur, built in 1884, mark the threshold of the estate. Their brick architecture with stone corners is characteristic of 19th-century state factories.

The Ourcq canal crosses the park and divides it into two worlds: the forest side with the Bois des Sablons and Bois de la Tussion, and the leisure side with ponds, the educational farm, and playgrounds.

The forest ponds of the Bois de la Tussion harbor palmate newts, crested newts, and spotted salamanders. These protected amphibians find refuge in this network of old ponds, habitat extremely rare in urban environments.

activities.text: Take the park's marked trails for a hike among giant sequoias, sessile oaks, and century-old chestnuts. Clearings left by demolished buildings welcome rare butterflies and insects.
In fine weather, a water sports center offers canoe introductions on the Ourcq canal in a wooded, quiet setting. Paddle in the shade of century-old trees.
Join free events organized year-round by the park's eco-rangers: birdwatching, nocturnal outings in search of amphibians, nature workshops for families.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: The Broken Great Menhir lies in four pieces on the ground. At 21 meters long and 280 tons, it was the largest monolith ever erected in Europe. Transported 10 km from a gneiss quarry, it was raised around 4500 BC.

The Table des Marchands, a 30-meter-long cairn, houses a dolmen whose capstone bears a spectacular carving: a crook or hafted axe symbol. This fragment fits with another found at Gavrinis, 4 km away by sea.

The Er Grah tumulus, 140 meters long, is one of the largest funeral monuments of European Neolithic. Built in several phases between 4600 and 3900 BC, it contained chest burials accompanied by polished axes.

The Dolmen des Pierres Plates stretches 24 meters along the seaside. Its L-shaped angled corridor is covered with Neolithic carvings: axes, crooks, shield-shaped idols. One wall bears a stylized face nicknamed the 'Mother Goddess.'
The port of Locmariaquer faces the entrance to the Gulf of Morbihan. The tidal current reaches 9 knots - one of the strongest in Europe. Oyster beds grid the foreshore as far as the eye can see.
The Notre-Dame-de-Kerdro church, from the 11th century, preserves Romanesque elements. On the square, a 16th-century cemetery cross bears sculptures of the Virgin and Christ.

activities.text: Visit the megalithic complex (Great Menhir, Table des Marchands, Er Grah) in one go. The interpretation center at the site entrance explains megalith transport and erection techniques with models and films.
Follow the coastal path (GR34) to Pointe de Kerpenhir, facing Port-Navalo. The view embraces the entrance to the Gulf of Morbihan, Gavrinis island, and the Rhuys peninsula.

Embark on the crossing to Gavrinis island (15 min). The Neolithic cairn houses the most beautiful known megalithic carvings: 23 of 29 slabs are entirely sculpted with spiral motifs, chevrons, and arches.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Village of painters (Gauguin).
Windmills.
Church.

Locronan, classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages and a Small City of Character, has served as a film set for numerous movies. Its central square, entirely paved with granite, is surrounded by Renaissance residences built by sail cloth merchants.

Saint-Ronan church (15th century) houses the Pénity chapel, attached to the south side. Inside, the recumbent effigy of Saint Ronan, in polychrome kersanton stone, dates from the 15th century. Stained glass windows recount the life of the Irish hermit saint who came to evangelize Cornouaille.
The square's houses are built of Locronan granite - a fine-grained gray stone. Sculpted dormers, dated lintels, and monumental chimneys testify to weavers' wealth in the 16th and 17th centuries.

The royal sail cloth manufactory, created by Colbert, supplied the French navy. Hemp grown in the region was spun and woven here - an industry that made the city's fortune before declining in the 19th century.
The square's calvary, from the 16th century, is among Brittany's simplest and most expressive. Its stocky, weathered figures convey raw emotion.

activities.text: Hike along the Aven.
Galettes.
Weaving.
Climb to the summit of Locronan mountain (289 m) via the Grande Troménie trail. This 12 km pilgrimage, one of Brittany's oldest, occurs only every six years - but the trail is accessible year-round.
Wander the cobbled streets beyond the main square. Rue Moal, Rue du Prieuré, and Venelle du Four contain less-known but equally remarkable facades.
Continue to the Névet woods, former sacred druid forest converted to a park. Centuries-old chestnut trees and fern undergrowth offer a cool walk even in summer.

visits.text: Vauban's fortifications form a star on the plateau since 1679. Longwy ranks among the nine new towns built ex nihilo by King Louis XIV's engineer.
Porte de France resembles a triumphal arch. Vauban gave this monumental entrance the prestige worthy of the Sun King.
The Siege Well and cross-shaped casemate complete the stronghold's equipment. The military bakery and powder magazine served the garrison's needs.
The Musée des Émaux et Faïences occupies the former military bakery. Faience produced since 1798 and cloisonné enamels appearing in the 1870s illustrate this unique craft.
The enamels with their distinctive blue acquired worldwide renown. The collections present tableware, vases, and sculptures from the 19th and 20th centuries.

activities.text: Walk the UNESCO ramparts to discover Église Saint-Dagobert and the town hall. The promenade offers views over bastions and curtain walls.
Manufacturers perpetuate the craft of cloisonné enamels. Some workshops open by reservation to discover the production stages.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: The Keroman submarine base covers 64 acres. Three reinforced concrete blocks (K1, K2, K3) were built between 1941 and 1943. It could shelter up to 30 submarines.
The Flore-S645 submarine is moored at the quay on Lorient La Base. Step inside the passageways, engine room, and command post. The museum space recounts the Battle of the Atlantic.
La Cité de la Voile Éric Tabarly celebrates offshore racing. Navigation simulator, 4D cinema, interactive exhibits. Éric Tabarly's Pen Duick yachts are on display. Dynamic and engaging visit.
Stroll along the offshore racing pontoons. The 105-foot Ultim trimarans and IMOCA 60s from the Vendée Globe are moored here. Skippers like Franck Cammas and Armel Le Cléac'h prepare their races.

The Museum of the French East India Company in Port-Louis displays Oriental porcelain, spices, and objects brought back by ships in the 17th and 18th centuries. The collection testifies to Lorient's maritime influence.

activities.text: Take a guided tour of the K3 block of the submarine base. The pens, slipway, and military installations are revealed with a guide.
Settle onto a terrace at La Base. Views of racing boats, bunkers, and maritime activity. Crêpes, seafood, and cocktails overlooking the pontoons.
The Keroman fishing port is one of France's largest. Visit the fish auction in the morning to see the journey from sea to plate.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: The Square Tower dominates Loudun from its 156 steps. Built between 1162 and 1185 under Henry II Plantagenet, it's the sole remnant of the fortress dismantled by Louis XIII to suppress the Protestants. The panorama sweeps across the city and the crossroads of Anjou, Touraine, and Poitou.

Sainte-Croix Collegiate Church, an 11th-century Romanesque edifice, was the theater of exorcism sessions during the trial of Urbain Grandier in 1634. Accused of witchcraft by the Ursuline nuns, the priest was tortured and burned at the stake. The interior preserves painted decorations from the 12th and 14th centuries, restored in 1995.
The Porte du Martray, sole survivor of the four gates in the fortified enclosure designed by Philip Augustus in the 14th century, opens onto one of Loudun's oldest quarters.

The Renaudot Museum occupies the birthplace of Théophraste Renaudot, physician to Louis XIII and founder of La Gazette de France in 1631. You'll discover a reconstructed print shop, a period herbalist's, and the library with original issues of the Gazette.
The Charbonneau-Lassay Museum houses eclectic collections bequeathed by the local scholar: archaeological objects, antique books, swords, and artifacts from the Loudun area.

activities.text: At the foot of the Square Tower, the medieval-inspired garden features medicinal plants in woven chestnut beds, including those in Renaudot's "Polychreston" remedy from 1619.
Walk the Philippe-Auguste and Foulques Nerra promenades that follow the old ramparts. Views of slate rooftops and bell towers compose a well-preserved tableau.

Join the guided tour "The Affair of the Possessed" offered by the tourist office. Various stops in Loudun illuminate this famous 17th-century witchcraft case, orchestrated by Richelieu against the priest Urbain Grandier.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: The Grotte de Massabielle, on the banks of the Gave de Pau, is the site where Bernadette Soubirous reported eighteen apparitions of the Virgin Mary in 1858. This rock cavity (3.80 m high, 9.50 m deep) houses a Carrara marble statue sculpted by Fabisch, placed in the niche of the apparitions. The spring discovered by Bernadette still flows, captured and channeled to fountains accessible to visitors. The site is protected as a Historic Monument.

The Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, built from 1866 to 1871 atop the Massabielle rock, is in neo-Gothic style. Its single nave of five bays is adorned with ex-votos, and the arches bear the words that the Virgin addressed to Bernadette. The bell tower rises to 70 meters.

The Basilica of Our Lady of the Rosary, constructed between 1883 and 1889 below the previous one, adopts a Greek cross plan and Romano-Byzantine style. Its interior walls are covered with mosaics over more than 2,000 m² depicting the mysteries of the Rosary. It can accommodate 1,500 worshippers.

The Underground Basilica of Saint Pius X, inaugurated in 1958 for the centenary of the apparitions, is one of the world's largest churches with a capacity of 25,000 people. Its gemmail stained-glass windows diffuse a particular light in this elliptical concrete space buried beneath the esplanade.

The Château Fort, erected in the 11th century on a rocky outcrop, dominates the town and surrounding valleys. Classified as a Historic Monument, it houses the Pyrenean Museum (labeled Museum of France) dedicated to Pyrenean cultures, traditions, and crafts from the 18th to the 20th century. A botanical garden enhances the visit.

The Pic du Jer, accessible by a funicular inaugurated in 1900, rises to 1,000 meters altitude. At the summit, a 360° panorama embraces the Pyrenees chain, the Tarbes plain, and the town of Lourdes below. Developed caves can be visited on site.

The Grotto of Massabielle, site of the 18 apparitions of 1858, carves into the rock 12 feet high and 31 feet deep. The Carrara marble statue occupies the apparition niche 6 feet above ground. Pilgrims touch the wall polished smooth by millions of hands. Access is free around the clock.

Above the grotto, the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception (1866-1871) raises its tall spire. Its stained glass windows narrate the events of Lourdes. Below, the Rosary Basilica (1883-1889) unfolds 21,500 square feet of polychrome Byzantine-Romanesque mosaics beneath a dome of gold and indigo.

Descend beneath the esplanade: the underground St. Pius X Basilica (1958), stretching 627 feet long, can welcome over 20,000 people. Its architecture evokes an overturned ship's hull. Gemmail stained-glass windows create a multicolored pathway of light.

Climb up to the fortress perched on a rocky outcrop since the 11th century. Keep, drawbridge, and arrow slits tell a thousand years of military history. The Pyrenean Museum, founded in 1921 and labeled "Museum of France," presents costumes, furniture, and pastoral traditions from both French and Spanish Pyrenees.

From the castle ramparts, the panorama sweeps across the town, the sanctuaries, and the Pyrenean range. The botanical garden offers a quiet moment among miniature models of traditional mountain dwellings and sculptures.

The monumental Way of the Cross winds through the wooded hillside above the sanctuaries. Its 15 life-size stations in gilded cast iron mark a path offering plunging views of the Gave de Pau river and the mountains.

activities.text: Cross the sanctuary esplanade to the grotto, then climb back toward the superimposed basilicas using the ramps that follow the Gave de Pau.
Climb to the Château Fort by the steep paths and enjoy the plunging view over the sanctuaries and rooftops of Lourdes before touring the Pyrenean Museum collections.
Take the Pic du Jer funicular for a fifteen-minute ascent, then explore the caves at the summit before descending on foot via the wooded trail.
In the evening, from Easter to late October, attend the torchlight procession that takes place every evening within the sanctuary grounds - a moment that touches believers and visitors alike.

Devote an excursion to the Bétharram Caves, located between Pau and Lourdes. The approximately 1h20 visit combines walking through five levels of underground galleries, a descent of 250 steps, a boat crossing on the underground river, and a return by small train over 700 meters.
Attend the torchlight procession, one of Lourdes' most moving moments. Thousands of candles ripple through the night from the esplanade to the basilica, accompanied by the singing of Ave Maria.

Take the century-old Pic du Jer funicular, inaugurated in 1900. In 10 minutes it climbs 1,550 feet to the summit at 3,110 feet. Enjoy a 360° panorama over Lourdes, Tarbes, Pau, and the Pyrenean peaks. A large illuminated cross crowns the summit.

Nine miles from Lourdes, the Bétharram Caves offer a 1.7-mile underground journey across five levels: stalactites, stalagmites, and limestone draperies follow one another. You descend 250 steps to the underground river, travel by boat, then a little train brings you back to the surface. Constant temperature of 57°F—bring a warm layer.
Lake Lourdes, nestled in greenery five minutes from the center, invites an easy stroll along its shoreline path. Picnic tables and birdwatching complete the peaceful stop.

visits.text: Germain Boffrand built Lunéville château between 1703 and 1723 for Duke Leopold I. Mansart's student created this 'Lorraine Versailles' after Louis XIV occupied Nancy.
Stanislas Leszczynski settled in Lunéville in 1737. He embellished the gardens with fabriques—exotic pavilions designed by Emmanuel Héré.
The ducal chapel, restored after the 2003 fire, now welcomes visitors. The Livery Room and Guards Room pay tribute to the reconstruction workers.
The château museum displays 18th-century paintings and decorative arts. Three rooms recount the château's history from the year 1000.
Église Saint-Jacques was built between 1730 and 1747 under Francis III and Stanislas. Its organ, designed by Emmanuel Héré, is entirely concealed by magnificent decoration.

activities.text: Parc des Bosquets spreads 21 hectares of French-style gardens laid out by Yves des Hours. Visitors roam freely between classical perspectives and wild groves.
The Lunéville Embroidery Conservatory perpetuates this recognized and transmitted Lorraine craft. Introductory workshops are offered regularly.

visits.text: The perched village of Lurs clings to its rocky spur dominating the Durance valley. Medieval streets wind between carefully restored stone houses. The former episcopal city has preserved its medieval character and peaceful atmosphere.

The Bishops' Promenade follows the clifftop ridge. The shaded path offers plunging views over the Durance plain and Pre-Alps. Fifteen oratories mark this spiritual route laid out by Sisteron bishops in the 18th century.

Notre-Dame-de-Vie chapel stands at the village entrance. The 12th-century Romanesque building dominates the landscape with its austere silhouette. The sculpted portal and decorated modillions testify to Provençal builders' craftsmanship.

Discover artists' and artisans' workshops installed in the village. Sculptors, ceramists and painters have occupied former residences. Their creations reflect inspiration drawn from this preserved and luminous setting.
The Lurs seminary occupies a vast monastic complex. 19th-century buildings now house a cultural and training center. Terraced gardens offer a panoramic view over the valley.
Lurs — village on a balcony above a vast olive grove (AOC Aglandau).
Promenade des Évêques and viewpoints over the Durance.

activities.text: Hiking trails crisscross hills around Lurs. The route loops through Aleppo pines and pubescent oaks. Viewpoints follow one another over the Durance, Valensole plateau and distant Alpine summits.
The Bishops' Promenade extends through the botanical trail. Educational panels present Mediterranean flora. Thyme, rosemary, wild lavender and cistus perfume the path overlooking the valley.

Admire the panorama from the village's multiple viewpoints. The view embraces the Durance valley, Haute-Provence plateaus and first Alpine foothills. Sunsets set the landscape ablaze with exceptional light.
"Characters and typography" trail (Rencontres de Lure, graphic heritage).
Tasting of local olive oils (neighboring estates).

visits.text: Lusigny-sur-Barse sits at the gates of Orient Forest Regional Natural Park. This protected area covers 70,000 hectares around three major lakes: Orient, Temple and Amance. The park headquarters houses an information center: interactive exhibitions on forest ecosystems, wetlands, migratory birds. Maps and brochures for planning your nature explorations. Free admission.

Lusigny beaches hold Blue Flag certification: fine sand, clear water, supervised swimming. Water sports base offers sailing lessons, catamaran rentals, windsurfing, stand-up paddle. Shallow calm waters perfect for families with young children. Picnic areas, children's playgrounds, snack bars. Lively atmosphere in summer, peaceful in low season.

activities.text: Discover the Voie Verte trail: 42 km of paved path around the Orient Forest lakes reserved for cyclists and pedestrians. Flat easy route suitable for all. Rent bikes in Lusigny or Mesnil-Saint-Père. Stops at observation points, picnic areas, beaches. Allow a full day for the complete loop with breaks. Electric bikes available for less athletic riders.

Bird observation in Orient Forest: 265 species recorded including cranes, herons, osprey, harriers. Spring and fall migrations bring thousands of birds. The park offers guided walks with ornithologists. Bring binoculars. Observation hides placed along shores. Respectful quiet observation of nature. Magical moments guaranteed for bird lovers.

visits.text: The Church of Saint-André, called "of the Templars," is actually the work of the Hospitallers of Saint John of Jerusalem, who fortified it in the 14th century to protect pilgrims on the Way of Saint James from miquelets, Aragonese bandits. Its battlements, arrow slits, and defense towers give it a fortress-like appearance. Classified as a Historic Monument in 1840 - one of the very first Pyrenean monuments to receive this distinction - it contains a painted 16th-century vault depicting Christ surrounded by the four evangelists in tetramorphic form, and an 18th-century Baroque high altar.

The Pont Napoléon spans the Gave de Gavarnie at 63 meters height with an arch of 68 meters span. Constructed between 1859 and 1861 under Napoleon III, it was erected in gratitude to the valley inhabitants after Empress Eugénie stayed at the Saint-Sauveur thermal baths. The site has become a bungee jumping spot.

The Solférino Chapel, built in 1859 at Napoleon III's request to commemorate the victory at the Battle of Solferino in Italy, stands on a promontory overlooking the valley. Its Byzantine-inspired tower and surrounding benches make it a peaceful viewpoint over Luz and the surrounding mountains.

The Gorges de Luz carve a narrow passage through rock walls downstream from the village. The road that crosses them offers a striking view of the erosive power of the gave, with geological strata visible on the cliff faces.
The Château Sainte-Marie, in ruins on the heights at 630 meters altitude, preserves two medieval defense towers. The remains offer a viewpoint over the confluence of the Barèges and Gavarnie valleys.

Luz-Saint-Sauveur itself comprises two united towns: Luz, a commercial center animated by its Monday morning market at the foot of the fortified church, and Saint-Sauveur, a thermal spa where Second Empire elites stayed. Victor Hugo described the light of this valley by comparing its name - Luz - to the word "light."
Discovery of the Pays Toy and its authentic villages with stone houses.
Stroll through the center of Luz-Saint-Sauveur, a lively thermal village.

The Church of St. Andrew, called the "Templars' Church," was actually built by the Knights Hospitaller of St. John of Jerusalem who fortified it in the 14th century. Its 14-sided crenellated enclosure, arrow slits, and two towers (Arsenal and clock keep) make it a unique fortress. It was classified as a Historic Monument as early as 1840.

Inside, look up at the 16th-century painted vault: Christ surrounded by the four evangelists forms a colorful tetramorph. The 18th-century baroque main altar in gilded wood and a 17th-century polychrome Pietà complete the décor. The Chapel of Our Lady of Pity (1650), attached to the ramparts, was erected to ward off a plague epidemic.

The Pont Napoléon spans the mountain stream from 207 feet up on a single stone arch 138 feet in diameter. Built between 1859 and 1861 under Napoleon III by engineer Bruniquel, it links the districts of Luz and Saint-Sauveur. Vertigo is guaranteed at the center of the 223-foot deck.

On a hilltop overlooking the town, the Solférino Chapel raises its Byzantine tower. Rebuilt in 1859 on Napoleon III's orders, it occupies the site of the ancient Chapel of St. Peter. Traditionally, its priest blessed flocks departing for high mountain pastures.

The thermal quarter of Saint-Sauveur stretches along a promontory above the stream. Its baths, exploited since the 16th century and listed as Historic Monuments, welcomed Empress Eugénie and Napoleon III. The wellness center continues the tradition of water therapy.

Wander the lanes of old Luz: stone wash-houses, marble window frames, and wrought-iron balconies sketch a preserved mountain heritage. The Maison Gradet (current town hall), built in 1828, hosted a cabinet meeting of Napoleon III.

activities.text: Visit the fortified church, paying attention to the sculpted Romanesque tympanum on the north facade, the polychrome painted vault, and the sacred art treasury displayed in the Notre-Dame-de-la-Pitié chapel.

Cross the Pont Napoléon on foot, then descend the small trail on the right that leads to the gave's edge, at the foot of the bridge - a cool spot for a break, with a view looking up at the monumental arch.
Climb to the Solférino Chapel for a peaceful panorama over the valley. On market days (Monday morning), first stock up on local products below before climbing to picnic.
Explore the town of Saint-Sauveur, its thermal facades and alleys, climbing toward the Château Sainte-Marie ruins for an overview of the Pays Toy.
Moment of relaxation at Luzéa: Roman baths, oriental hammam and suspended jacuzzi.

The Napoleon-Eugénie Walk forms an easy 1.9-mile loop between the Town Hall and the Thermal Baths, passing by the Pont Napoléon and Solférino Chapel. Interpretive panels and valley landscapes punctuate this 2-hour historical stroll.
From the Pont Napoléon, a via ferrata is installed on the rock of the left pillar. Vertical thrills guaranteed 207 feet above the stream, supervised by mountain professionals.
Luz-Saint-Sauveur is the starting point for the ascent of Col du Tourmalet, a legendary Tour de France climb. Bike rental shops offer equipment suitable for tackling the switchbacks.
The Bastan Trail follows the torrent along the valley floor. An easy, peaceful path accessible to all, offering direct contact with the natural landscape of Pays Toy.

visits.text: Old Lyon unfolds between the Saône and Fourvière hill, forming the largest Renaissance quarter in Europe after Venice. The traboules, these covered passages crossing buildings, allowed silk workers to transport fabrics sheltered from bad weather. The Renaissance facades, inner courtyards, and spiral staircases create a unique architectural ensemble listed as UNESCO World Heritage. Rue Saint-Jean and its shops, Place du Change and its old bank, testify to past commercial prosperity.

Fourvière Basilica, perched on its hill, dominates Lyon like a wedding cake. Built in the late 19th century in Romano-Byzantine style, it fascinates with golden mosaics, marble columns, and exceptional stained glass windows. The crypt, as richly decorated as the upper church, houses remarkable ex-votos. The esplanade offers breathtaking panoramic views of the entire city, from Croix-Rousse to Confluence.

The Gallo-Roman theaters of Fourvière, built in the 1st century BC, rank among the oldest in France. The great theater could accommodate 10,000 spectators, while the odeon served more intimate performances. Excavations revealed sophisticated stage sets and audience organization. Summer evening performances recreate ancient magic. The attached Lugdunum Museum presents exceptional collections of objects found on site.

The Croix-Rousse district, former stronghold of canuts (silk workers), climbs steep slopes north of the city center. Tall buildings with huge windows once housed weaving looms. Traboules allowed workers to go from workshop to market without climbing stairs. Today, the neighborhood vibrates with artists, craftsmen, and designers who perpetuate creative spirit. The Gros Caillou belvedere offers spectacular views of the city.
Saint-Jean Cathedral (Vieux Lyon)
Traboules of Vieux Lyon (selected route)
Lugdunum – museum & Roman theaters (exteriors included)
Fourvière Hill & Basilica (panoramic esplanade)
Vieux Lyon & Saône quays (UNESCO area)
Parc de la Tête d'Or (greenhouses & lake, stroll)
Musée des Confluences (architecture + exhibitions)
Medieval village of Pérouges (fortified city, Grand'Rue & Place du Tilleul)
Lyon: Old Lyon (UNESCO), Saint-Jean Cathedral and Renaissance districts.
Lyon: Notre-Dame de Fourvière basilica and belvedere.
Lyon: Presqu'île, Place Bellecour and the Rhône/Saône quays.

activities.text: Discover Lyon's famous bouchons, these traditional restaurants serving Lyonnais gastronomy. Quenelles, pike perch, sausage with pistachios, tablier de sapeur accompany Beaujolais and Côtes du Rhône wines. Authentic bouchons, recognizable by their checkered tablecloths and regional dishes, perpetuate ancestral recipes. The warm atmosphere and hearty portions embody Lyonnais conviviality.

Visit Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse, temple of local gastronomy where the greatest chefs source supplies. Fifty artisan vendors offer exceptional products: Bresse chickens, mountain cheeses, regional charcuterie, artisanal chocolates. The festive atmosphere and quality products make this visit an immersion into French culinary art. Tastings allow discovery of unique flavors.

Cruise the Rhône or Saône to discover Lyon from the water. The perspective on quays, bridges, and monuments completely changes the city's perception. Commentary reveals river history and evolution of neighborhoods. Lunch or dinner cruises offer a romantic experience combining gastronomy and sightseeing. Night cruises showcase illuminated buildings.

Explore the Confluence district, this futuristic neighborhood where the Rhône and Saône meet. Contemporary architecture contrasts with historic city: Confluence Museum by architects Coop Himmelb(l)au, the Orange Cube, Nuage towers. The renovated docks, green spaces, and aquatic promenade create a pleasant living environment. The transformation of this former industrial port illustrates Lyon's urban renewal.
Bike ride along the Rhône (urban greenway)
Hiking loops around Pérouges (40–150 min depending on trail)
Lyon: self-guided tour through the traboules (historic passages).

visits.text: Village of Lyons-la-Forêt. Ranked among France's Most Beautiful Villages and a Green Resort, this Norman jewel served as the backdrop for both adaptations of Madame Bovary (Jean Renoir 1933, Claude Chabrol 1991). Its 17th and 18th-century half-timbered houses, flower-filled streets, and 18th-century wooden market hall classified as a Historic Monument compose a portrait of preserved authenticity.

Lyons-la-Forêt Market Hall. Beneath their oak framework, these 18th-century halls have punctuated village life for three centuries. They still host the market (Thursday, Saturday, and Sunday mornings) and cultural events.

Mortemer Abbey. Normandy's first Cistercian abbey, founded in 1134 by Henry Beauclerc, William the Conqueror's son. Nicknamed 'France's most haunted abbey,' it houses the Museum of Legends and Ghosts in its 12th-century cellars. The White Lady of Matilda the Empress, Saint Catherine's fountain for singles, and the 18th-century dovecote fuel fantastic tales.
Saint-Denis Church of Lyons-la-Forêt. This 12th-century parish church houses an eagle-shaped lectern from Mortemer Abbey. Its peaceful cemetery invites meditation.
Lyons-la-Forêt — market halls, half-timbered houses, beech forest edge.
Les Andelys — Château Gaillard & meanders of the Seine.

activities.text: Hiking in Lyons Forest. At 10,695 hectares, this beech cathedral is Normandy's largest forest and one of Europe's most beautiful. Century-old beeches soar up to 45 meters high. Over 200 km of marked trails traverse this massif dotted with clearings and valleys.

Les Bordins Arboretum. In the forest's heart, this woodland garden presents a hundred tree species from around the world. A playful orienteering course allows families to discover botanical diversity while having fun.

Saint Catherine's Fountain. This Fouillebroc spring, nestled in the forest, is linked to Mortemer Abbey. Young women came here to pray for a husband within the year. A place steeped in mystery and romance.
View of the Seine from the ruins of Gaillard.

visits.text: The ruins of Maillezais Abbey dominate the marsh from a former island. It was a fortress, Romanesque abbey, then Gothic cathedral from the 11th to 17th centuries.
The cathedral measured 105 meters long and reached 60 meters high. Only 25 meters of the north wall's height and the two bell towers remain.
Climb the tower to contemplate the surrounding marsh excavated by monks as early as the 11th century.
The refectory and salt cellar testify to monastic life. François Rabelais stayed here for five years during the Renaissance.
An immersive film on three walls traces the history of the abbey in the former refectory.

activities.text: Picnic in the shaded area with a view of the majestic ruins.
Board from the abbey's embarkation point to navigate the canals of the wet marsh.

days_plan.itin_title: Deux-Sèvres Circuit: Marais Poitevin and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Château de Maintenon, home of Françoise d'Aubigné, Louis XIV's secret wife. This architectural jewel blends medieval remains with Renaissance and classical elements. The 17th-century apartments reveal Madame de Maintenon's intimate world with period portraits, furniture, and the Noailles gallery adorned with master paintings.

Vauban's unfinished aqueduct, a monumental testament to Louis XIV's ambition. Commissioned in 1685 to channel Eure waters to Versailles' fountains, this colossal project was abandoned in 1688 for lack of funds. Its romantic ruins majestically cross the park for nearly 4 kilometers.

French gardens designed by Le Nôtre, restored in 2013 according to the original 1686 plans. The flower parterres of blue sage, roses, and impatiens surround a canal bordered by two paths named after Racine and Le Nôtre. Facing the aqueduct, deck chairs invite contemplation of this grandiose setting.

activities.text: Walk along the Eure through the château park, where the river has been transformed into a canal passing beneath the aqueduct's majestic arches. White swans glide on the water while century-old lime trees create an atmosphere of aristocratic serenity.

Explore the village of Maintenon with its old houses and Saint-Nicolas church, connected to the château by a wing built under Louis XIV. A peaceful village that has preserved its old-world charm in the shadow of the royal estate.

visits.text: Lake Saint-Point is the 3rd largest natural lake in France at 7.2 km long, 950 m wide, and 40 m deep at an altitude of 849 m. Crossed by the Doubs, it is separated from Lake Remoray by a protected wetland. It frequently freezes in winter and becomes a natural ice rink. Five villages border its shores: Saint-Point-Lac, Les Grangettes, Labergement-Sainte-Marie, Montperreux, and Malbuisson.

Malbuisson has been a Station Verte since 2009, recognized for its hotel and gastronomic tradition. The village overlooks the lake and serves as the starting point for the lake loop trail (23 km, pedestrians only). The Aqua2lacs water complex offers pools overlooking with panoramic lake views, jacuzzi, and relaxation area.

Mont d'Or rises to 1,463 meters, the highest point in the Doubs department. From its summit, accessible by the Morond chairlift or on foot via the GR5, you discover an exceptional panorama of more than 300 Alpine peaks including Mont Blanc, as well as the Haut-Doubs, Haut-Jura, and neighboring Switzerland. The site is classified as a Sensitive Natural Area for its remarkable flora including some protected species.

activities.text: Four water sports centers offer sailing, catamaran, stand-up paddle, canoe-kayak, and pedal boats on Lake Saint-Point. The beaches at Les Grangettes and Oye-et-Pallet are supervised in July-August. The water remains cool even in summer (18-22°C in August).

The Mont d'Or ridge hike (approximately 2h round trip, 6 km) connects the Morond summit to the Mont d'Or summit via a panoramic trail. A museum space in the snow factory presents the history and biodiversity of the massif. Free trail guides are available at the station ticket offices.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs Circuit: Watchmaking and Swiss Border

visits.text: Established in 1747, the Bourg-Joly Pottery carries on the time-honored craft of master potters. The openwork baskets are Malicorne's signature piece.
The Faïence and Ceramics Museum, designated a Museum of France, showcases antique ceramics and contemporary creations. Tour the interior of the firing kilns.
The 11th-century Saint-Sylvestre church houses a magnificent Gothic-style recumbent statue. Stained glass windows illuminate the Romanesque nave.
The Château de Malicorne, listed as a Historic Monument, once hosted Madame de Sévigné. The gardens overlook the Sarthe River.
The mills bear witness to a past when the river provided energy. The former color mill ground pigments for pottery painters.

activities.text: Cruise the Sarthe in an electric boat. A unique perspective on the village and its riverbanks.
Paddle down the Sarthe by canoe-kayak from Malicorne. Locks punctuate the navigation route.
Join slip-casting pottery workshops at the museum. A professional leads these sessions for all ages.

days_plan.itin_title: Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

visits.text: The 13th and 14th-century Saint-Nicolas church towers over the town. Its remarkable bell tower and Renaissance portal are emblematic.
The Grain Hall, built in 1818, still hosts weekly markets. Its stone columns and wooden framework provide an authentic setting.
The Italian-style theater, on the ground floor of the festival hall, forms with the market hall and church the Place Carnot 'triptych.'
The Flamboyant Gothic Notre-Dame church possesses a remarkable porch and rare triforium. Its stained glass illuminates the nave.
The Convent of the Visitation, founded in 1630, houses a former state prison in its chapel. Prisoners' graffiti remain visible.
Stroll through the 'coulées,' narrow alleyways typical of Mamers. The weavers' houses on Rue de Cinq-Ans testify to the hemp industry.

activities.text: Visit Place de la République to see Mamers' Eiffel Tower, a 19th-century 1/100th scale replica.
Taste the authentic Sarthe rillettes. Mamers is the rillettes capital and headquarters of the Brotherhood of Sarthe Rillettes Knights.
Weekly markets (Monday, Friday, and Saturday) under the halls offer local produce and Perche specialties.
The Maine Saosnois Greenway, a former 12 km railway line, invites family-friendly bicycle or walking outings.

days_plan.itin_title: Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

Citadel (ext.), priory, gardens and pointed huts around.

activities.text: Route of the calades and fountains in the town.

days_plan.itin_title: Forcalquier & the Lure Valley: Lavender Fields, Gorges & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: The historic center displays its winding streets between two medieval gates. Porte Saunerie and Porte Soubeyran guard the fortified old town entrance. Renaissance mansions reveal their inner courtyards and spiral staircases behind heavy wooden doors.

The Jean Giono Center celebrates the local-born writer. The birthplace and urban trail trace the life and work of the author. Manuscripts, original editions and personal objects evoke the universe of the one who sang of Provence and its inhabitants.

Saint-Sauveur church blends Provençal Romanesque and southern Gothic. The 14th-century sculpted portal precedes a nave with soaring vaults. Side chapels house Baroque altarpieces and Renaissance baptismal fonts.
The Présentation convent occupies a vast monastic complex. Terraced gardens offer a green break in the city center. The Baroque chapel displays its gilded stuccoes and restored frescoes.

Discover shaded squares where fountains and washhouses murmur. Place de l'Hôtel de Ville brings Manosque's heart to life. Café terraces invite observing the daily animation of this authentic Provençal town.

activities.text: The Route Napoléon crosses Manosque on the Emperor's historic route. The itinerary follows Bonaparte's footsteps during his return from the island of Elba in 1815. Commemorative markers and panels mark this mythical route between Golfe-Juan and Grenoble.

The Valensole plateau extends at Manosque's gates. Lavender fields draw their fragrant geometry from June to July. Perched villages and distilleries punctuate country roads through this iconic landscape.
Hiking trails crisscross wooded hills around Manosque. Mont d'Or offers a moderate ascent rewarded by a panorama over the Durance and Luberon. Aleppo pines and kermes oaks punctuate the routes.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages

visits.text: The Collégiale Notre-Dame de Mantes-la-Jolie, built between 1140 and 1240, bears striking resemblance to Notre-Dame de Paris. Its Last Judgment rose window, dated 1210-1220, and Burgundian glazed tile roof set it apart.
The Saint-Maclou Tower, remnant of a 14th-century Gothic parish church, stands sentinel above the old town rooftops. It serves as a landmark visible from the Seine quays.
The Hôtel-Dieu Museum holds the largest collection of works by Maximilien Luce, a neo-Impressionist painter native to the town. A lapidary deposit displays carved fragments from the collégiale.

activities.text: Stroll along the Seine quays to Île aux Dames, accessible via a pedestrian footbridge. The island offers lawns, playgrounds, and views of the collégiale from the opposite bank.
Wander through Mantes-la-Jolie's old town: medieval alleyways, fountains, and half-timbered façades surround the collégiale.
Listen to the 1897 Merklin organ during concerts regularly held beneath the collégiale's vaults.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

visits.text: Marché des Enfants Rouges

activities.text: Discovery of the oldest covered market in Paris, known for its stalls and variety of products offered.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Museum Pass Itinerary: Masterpieces & Artistic Revolution Guide

visits.text: Brouage, a citadel asleep in the marshes. Founded in 1555, it was Europe's leading salt port before silting up. Richelieu made it an impregnable stronghold between 1628 and 1633 under Pierre d'Argencourt, then Vauban reinforced the fortifications in 1685. Samuel de Champlain, founder of Quebec, was born here around 1570. Today, 500 inhabitants and an uncanny silence.

The Brouage rampart walk (2 km) offers views over former salt marshes turned bird reserve. Black-winged stilts, egrets and spoonbills nest here. The powder magazines, forge and restored church can be visited.

Marennes, oyster capital. The Marennes-Oléron basin produces 45% of French oysters. The Saint-Pierre church bell tower (85 m) is the tallest in Charente-Maritime. The Oyster City explains aging in 'claires', those brackish water pools that green and refine the oysters.

activities.text: Visit an oyster shack. Producers open their establishments to explain farming and aging. Tasting on site with views of the claires – a glass of local white accompanies the oysters.
Walk in the Brouage marshes. Marked trails through former salt marshes. Binoculars recommended for watching migratory birds. The sunset over the pools is memorable.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: The Margaux appellation is one of six communal Médoc appellations, renowned for elegant and aromatic wines. The vineyard extends over 1,500 hectares across four communes: Margaux-Cantenac, Soussans, Arsac, and Labarde. The appellation counts 21 grands crus classés from 1855, including the celebrated Château Margaux. The gravelly terroir (pebbles) brings finesse and complexity to the wines. Margaux village itself is small but charming.

The Margaux Wine and Tourism Center welcomes you to discover the appellation. The museum space explains the terroir, vineyard history, and the 1855 classification. A wine selection is available for tasting and purchase. Staff can advise you on châteaux to visit and help with reservations. It's the ideal starting point for organizing your vineyard discovery.

The Margaux-Cantenac Châteaux loop is a 15 km route to walk or cycle. This marked itinerary crosses the vineyard passing 18 of the 21 classified grands crus in the appellation. You'll pass prestigious properties like Château Margaux, Château Palmer, Château Lascombes. The path offers beautiful estuary and Île Margaux views. Allow 2 hours by bike, 4 hours on foot without visit stops.

Saint-Michel Church in Margaux, built in the 19th century in neo-Romanesque style, stands in the village center. Its square bell tower is visible from afar across the flat Médoc landscape. The sober interior houses some interesting stained glass. The forecourt opens onto the main village square where the market is held. It's a useful landmark for orientation in Margaux.

activities.text: Visit and tasting at a Margaux château. The appellation offers a wide diversity of wine tourism experiences, from classified grands crus to more accessible family properties. Guided tours help you understand vineyard work, vinification, and barrel aging. Tastings reveal the elegance characteristic of Margaux wines. Reservations essential, sometimes several weeks in advance for the most prestigious estates.

Cycling through Margaux vineyards. The Médoc's flat topography and quiet small roads make cycling very pleasant. Several rental shops offer classic or electric bikes. You can follow the château loop or create your own itinerary. Landscapes of vines aligned as far as the eye can see are magnificent. Plan breaks to admire châteaux and take photos.

Margaux Golf offers an 18-hole, 6,000-meter course spread over 45 hectares. Designed in a natural setting amid vineyards, it's renowned for its beauty and impeccable maintenance. Greens are bordered by century-old elms and ash trees. The clubhouse offers views over the course and surrounding vineyards. On-site restaurant. Green fees accessible with reservations recommended.

Margaux Saveurs is an annual event held the third weekend of November. Many appellation châteaux open their doors for tastings, entertainment, concerts, and gourmet meals. It's a festive and convivial opportunity to discover the Margaux appellation differently. The program blends wine discoveries with musical ambiance. Tickets and reservations on the event website.

visits.text: Discovery of Lake Chalain, largest natural lake in Jura, and walk around the turquoise waters

visits.text: The 13th-century Église Notre-Dame blends Gothic architecture with 19th-century restoration. Inside, admire the Baroque altarpiece and the Entombment sculpture.
The Renaissance Cloister built in 1540 preserves two elegant galleries. Its varied decoration showcases the refinement of the era.
The Jardin du Cloître landscaped in 1950 follows French formal garden principles. Boxwood parterres, sculpted yews, and a central basin create perfect harmony.
Stroll along Rue Labat lined with 16th-century half-timbered houses. These dwellings testify to Marmande's medieval prosperity.
The statue of Ferline with her pomme d'amour on Place Clemenceau reminds visitors that Marmande is the capital of heirloom tomatoes.

activities.text: Browse the market to taste the famous Marmande tomatoes. Growers and market gardeners display their bountiful harvests.
Walk the Garonne riverbanks at the Plaine de la Filhole. This green meander offers a peaceful stroll along the river.
Explore the Chemin de Ronde du Caillou behind the church. These medieval fortification remnants include the Tour du Passeur.

days_plan.itin_title: Mystical Provence: Haunted Villages and Paranormal History of Southern France

visits.text: Martel, the "Town of Seven Towers," is listed among France's Most Beautiful Villages. A merchant city founded in the 11th–12th centuries by the viscounts of Turenne, it has preserved its intact medieval layout encircled by 12th–14th-century ramparts.
Place des Consuls forms Martel's beating heart. An 18th-century market hall shelters stalls beneath stone pillars. All around, half-timbered houses and arcaded dwellings compose a preserved setting.

The Palais de la Raymondie, built between 1280 and 1330, raises its square tower above the square. The former seigneurial residence houses the Uxellodunum Museum—Gallo-Roman collections and Quercy history. Designated a Museum of France.

The fortified Church of Saint-Maur impresses with its 40-meter bell tower-keep built for defense. A carved 12th-century tympanum adorns the portal. Inside, entirely painted decoration, surprisingly colorful, contrasts with the facade's austerity.

Spot the seven towers that gave the town its nickname. The 13th-century Tour Tournemire, a former prison, offers panoramic views from its summit. The Tour des Cordeliers is the sole remnant of a Franciscan monastery founded in 1230. The Maison Fabri recalls a dark episode: here a young Anglo-Norman king allegedly breathed his last after pillaging Rocamadour.

activities.text: The Truffadou tourist train follows the former Bordeaux-Aurillac line carved into the cliff 80 meters above the Dordogne. The 13-kilometer route between Martel and Saint-Denis offers plunging views of the valley from open wagons.
Browse Martel's market on Wednesday and Saturday mornings beneath the 18th-century hall. Seasonal truffles, walnuts, Quercy terroir products, and local specialties.
Visit a traditional walnut oil mill near Martel. Périgord walnuts, with AOC designation, are pressed using artisanal methods. Tastings and on-site sales.
