days_plan.itin_title: Ariège Pyrenees Road Trip, France: Cathar Castles & Prehistoric Cave Art

visits.text: Vauban's fortifications still encircle Maubeuge along two-thirds of their original layout. Erected in record time from 1679 to 1685 on Louis XIV's orders, they transformed the city into a sentinel of the Pré Carré, that line of strongholds protecting the kingdom's northern frontier.

The Porte de Mons, classified as a Historic Monument since 1924, is the rampart's last intact gate. Built in 1682, this monumental gate preserves its complete defensive complex: drawbridge, guardhouse and ravelin.

The Corps de Garde Museum occupies an 1683 building erected following Vauban's directives. Beneath its ancient timber frame, it traces Maubeuge's military history. On the ground floor, a 19th-century relief map clarifies the fortifications' geometry.

Saint-Pierre-Saint-Paul Church, erected between 1955 and 1958, is built entirely of reinforced concrete. Its 43-meter bell tower, pierced with glass bricks, houses a 28-bell carillon. The tympanum is adorned with a mosaic designed by Jean Lurçat, brother of architect André Lurçat.

The Sthrau Hall, listed as a Historic Monument since 1958, is a unique Art Deco ensemble inserted into a former baroque chapel of the Jesuit college. Rebuilt between 1923 and 1927, it comprises a two-level music hall with characteristic geometric decoration.

Maubeuge was 80% destroyed in 1940. André Lurçat, charged with reconstruction, designed a downtown of remarkable modernist homogeneity: concrete and brick buildings, airy perspectives, green spaces integrated into ramparts. Architecture that still divides opinion but leaves no one indifferent.

activities.text: Maubeuge Zoo occupies 7 hectares within Vauban's very ramparts. Tour the bastions while observing over 300 animals of 60 species, in a setting where the fortifications' moats and embankments serve as natural enclosures.

Walk along the Monier ponds southeast of the fortifications. Backed against the rampart, these former defensive basins bordered by willows now form a peaceful haven popular with strollers and fishermen, steps from downtown.

Follow the fortifications' covered way from Porte de Mons to the Oratoire bastion. Artillery access ramps, embrasures and casemates punctuate the route—you can imagine horses pulling cannons to firing platforms.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

visits.text: The Basilique Notre-Dame-des-Miracles rises at the heart of Mauriac, a sanctuary founded in the 6th century by Théodechilde, daughter of Clovis. The sculpted Romanesque portal of the 12th century announces the majesty of the building. Inside, the Gothic choir and the relics of Saint Marius (an evangelizing disciple whose name is said to have inspired "Puy Mary") bear witness to the age-old religious influence of this town between the Dordogne and the Cantal mountains.

The old town retains the charm of Auvergne market towns with its bourgeois houses, shaded small squares and volcanic stone façades. Stroll through the lanes climbing towards the basilica, discover the local shops and the peaceful atmosphere of this Cantal sub-prefecture with its preserved character.

activities.text: The weekly market brings the central square to life in a bustle of colours and flavours. Farm producers, market gardeners and artisans offer aged cheeses, local cured meats, sourdough breads and seasonal vegetables. The perfect opportunity to meet passionate farmers and taste Cantal's authenticity.

The walk to the Château d'Anjony reveals one of the finest castles in Cantal, a 15th-century medieval fortress overlooking the Doire valley. Its four corner towers frame a remarkable square keep. The Renaissance frescoes in the chapel and the wall paintings in the apartments are exceptional artistic treasures within this austere military setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Mayenne Castle overlooks the river of the same name. Over 1,100 years old, it houses Europe's best-preserved Carolingian palace, classified as an archaeological site of national interest. The reception hall, cellar and residential tower are still legible in the masonry.

The museum, labeled Museum of France and starred in the Michelin Green Guide, traces 2,000 years of history through an interactive journey. The collections from excavations are exceptional: chess and backgammon pieces from the 10th-12th centuries, ceramics, coins, arrowheads and funerary furnishings testifying to the life of Mayenne's lords.

In the upper courtyard, a medieval-inspired garden has been recreated from period documents. Plants and shrubs are classified as in the Middle Ages: medicinal herbs, aromatics, edibles, medicinals or 'magical' plants.

The Basilica of Notre-Dame-des-Miracles, on the right bank, is a composite edifice from the 12th, 16th and 19th centuries. The west façade is original Romanesque (circa 1110). The 19th-century choir draws inspiration from Le Mans Cathedral's chevet. A chapel houses the 15th-century polychrome wooden statuette of Our Lady of Miracles.

The basilica's current stained glass windows, designed by Maurice Rocher and installed between 1952 and 1962, replaced those destroyed during the June 1944 bombings that devastated the town. The basilica remained closed for thirteen years for restoration.

Stroll through Place de Hercé with its octagonal fountain, then reach Place Cheverus surrounded by 17th-18th century townhouses. On the left bank, the 11th-century Saint-Martin church stands out with its russet granite.
The Calvary Sisters Chapel, last vestige of a vast 17th-century convent, now houses an art center devoted to contemporary creation.

activities.text: Walk along the Mayenne quays for a riverside stroll. The castle park, right in the town center, offers a bandstand, towering trees and a stunning view from the ramparts.

Drive 5 km to Fontaine-Daniel, a village of character nestled in a clearing in the Salair woods. Founded around a Cistercian abbey in 1205, it became the birthplace of Toiles de Mayenne in 1806 when the abandoned abbey was transformed into a spinning mill. The factory, labeled Living Heritage Company, still weaves on site.
In season, board the pleasure boat departing from the river stop for a narrated cruise on the Mayenne River. Wildlife, flora, local history and manual lock operation on the program.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: Hautpoul clings to its rocky outcrop, 300 meters above Mazamet. According to legend, this village was founded in 413 by a Visigoth king. A Cathar refuge then Protestant stronghold, its steep streets preserve remnants of medieval fortifications.

Climb to the Rocher de la Vierge and the old castle terraces for an exceptional panorama over the Arnette valley and Mazamet below. The neighboring medieval garden presents medicinal and dyeing plants from the period.
The Wood and Toy House unfolds over 1,500 m² of exhibitions on the journey from forest to tree, tree to wood, and wood to toy. Children and adults alike linger here.
Descending toward Mazamet, the mid-19th-century Cormouls Houlès Gardens offer a spectacular botanical trail overlooking the valley, punctuated by viewpoints over Montagne Noire.

Follow Mazamet's self-guided heritage circuits, labeled '100 Most Beautiful Detours of France.' The architecture tells of the era when the city was the world center for processing wool imported from Australia and Argentina.

activities.text: Cross the Mazamet footbridge, suspended 70 meters above the Arnette valley. 140 meters long, it sways gently underfoot and connects the town to Hautpoul village. Free and open daily.
Take the Jamarié path, the old salt road and Roman way, to reach the footbridge via a history-laden route. The return can follow a different trail in a loop.
In the evening, return to admire the illuminated footbridge: each night it lights up in changing colors until 2 a.m., creating a luminous spectacle above the gorges.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: The Saint-Étienne Cathedral of Meaux, begun around 1175, displays four centuries of Gothic styles layered: classical, rayonnant, and flamboyant. Five richly sculpted portals frame a central tympanum depicting the Last Judgment. The vaults reach 33 meters.

Inside, look for the 14th-century Crucifixion stained glass window above the choir, the great 15th-century rose window, and Bossuet's tomb—the famous 17th-century bishop and orator nicknamed "the Eagle of Meaux".

The Bossuet Museum occupies the former episcopal palace, built from the 12th to 17th centuries. Its vaulted rooms house a collection of 17th and 18th-century paintings. Wood paneling, paved ramp, and garden views make the site remarkable.

The Bossuet Garden, attributed to Le Nôtre, extends over 8,500 square meters in the shape of an episcopal mitre. Boxwood parterres, a pool, centuries-old linden trees, and views of the Gallo-Roman ramparts make it one of the finest formal gardens in Île-de-France.

The Museum of the Great War of the Pays de Meaux, inaugurated in 2011, is one of the largest museums dedicated to World War I in Europe. It stands on the very spot where the German advance was halted in September 1914.

The Gallo-Roman ramparts, erected in the late 3rd century, line the Boulevard Jean Rose for 250 meters. Their brick chains alternating with small stone courses are characteristic of late Roman architecture.

activities.text: Visit the Maison du Brie de Meaux for a discovery tour: from milk collection to a recreated 19th-century aging cellar. The visit concludes with a tasting of the "king of cheeses".
Walk along the Marne and Ourcq Canal. The Parc naturel du Pâtis, one of the largest urban parks in Île-de-France, offers hiking trails, waterways, and birdwatching.
In summer, the Grand Spectacle historique de Meaux brings together over 500 costumed actors to retrace the town's history outdoors.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: Accessible by gondola, this calvary stands at 1,840 meters on Mont d'Arbois. It offers an exceptional 360° viewpoint over the Mont Blanc massif, where you can clearly distinguish the summit soaring to 4,809 meters—Western Europe's rooftop spread before your eyes.

The chicest resort in the French Alps, Megève has preserved its authentic Savoyard village character. The center clusters with superb wooden chalets sporting flower-laden balconies, while excellent gastronomic restaurants serve Alpine cuisine elevated to an art form.

activities.text: Explore the flower-studded Alpine pastures surrounding Megève. Gentle trails wind through meadows and forests up to working mountain farms. Stop at the farmsteads to taste Beaufort, Tomme de Savoie, and Reblochon where they're made—cheese with a view.

Stroll the cobbled lanes lined with elegant boutiques and discover Savoyard specialties in the gourmet food shops: mountain charcuterie, aged Alpine cheeses, and artisan honey that captures the flavor of wildflower meadows.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Savoie Road Trip: Alpine Lakes & Mont Blanc

visits.text: The Château de Mehun-sur-Yèvre was Charles VII's favorite residence — the king who owed his crown to Joan of Arc and died here in 1461, perhaps from starvation following an abscess. Only the north tower and part of the curtain wall remain standing. The tower houses a museum on Charles VII, the Hundred Years' War and the château's construction site, illustrated by the Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry, where the castle appears in all its splendor.

The château once rivaled Chambord in magnificence. Three wings, watchtowers, chapel, gardens descending to the Yèvre. Charles VII brought his court, artists, scholars here. Agnes Sorel, his favorite, lived here. The Duke of Berry's miniaturists painted the castle around 1410: blue roofs, gilded weathervanes, sculpted galleries. Comparison with the ruins shows the extent of revolutionary destruction.

Mehun is known for its porcelain since 1854. Several workshops still operate, some open for visits. Pillivuyt, the most famous, supplied the Élysée Palace. The Pôle de la Porcelaine (closed Mondays) traces two centuries of manufacturing, displays historic pieces and contemporary creations. You can see potters at work and purchase in the shop.

activities.text: The Saint-Martin Collegiate Church (12th-13th centuries) towers over the Yèvre. Romanesque portal, Gothic nave, 16th-century stained glass. Inside, a beautiful polychrome Entombment and the tomb of Charles VII (the king's remains were transferred to Saint-Denis in the 19th century).

Walk along the Yèvre to see old tanneries, mills, washhouses. The river formed the town's economy: tanneries, fulling mills, paper mills. Mehun once housed up to 500 workers. The banks are pleasant, shaded, with views of the castle ruins.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: Gévaudan Wolf Park (Sainte-Lucie, near Marvejols): observation trail.
Segment of the Stevenson Trail (GR70) around Florac/Barre-des-Cévennes: ridge walking.

Mende's Notre-Dame-et-Saint-Privat Cathedral dominates the skyline with its mismatched twin towers. Built in 1368 at the request of Pope Urban V—a native son of Gévaudan—it once housed the Non-Pareille, the largest bell in Christendom when cast in 1516. Only its clapper survives, now displayed at the organ's base.

Step into the Gévaudan Museum, spread across 1,200 m² and three floors. Twelve galleries showcase over 500 artifacts spanning prehistory to the present day, organized around two themes: Nature and Culture. The legend of the Beast of Gévaudan is documented here with scholarly rigor.
The medieval Pont Notre-Dame spans the Lot River upstream from the center. Riverside houses sport distinctive upturned boat-hull roofs, a hallmark of Mende's architectural heritage.
The Tour des Pénitents stands as the last remnant of the medieval ramparts. From its summit, views sweep across the old town's slate-topped roofs and frame both cathedral spires.

Visit the old hospital pharmacy, constructed between the 17th and 19th centuries. Its walnut woodwork and apothecary instruments rank it among France's ten finest historic pharmacies. Accessible by guided tour only.

The old town's cobbled lanes reveal themselves along a heritage trail marked by 28 posts. Ancient doorways, fountains on small squares, an 18th-century town hall with a slate roof—pick up a free map at the Tourist Office.

activities.text: Reading the Cévennes landscapes: schist, chestnut groves, drailles.
Evening stroll in Mende: cathedral and Notre-Dame bridge.

Climb Mont Mimat to the summit cross. The orientation table offers a complete panorama: Mende at your feet, the Margeride mountains to the north, the Mende causse plateau to the south. Best at sunset.
Craving thrills? Mende's via ferrata features routes for all levels on cliffs above town. Suspension bridges, ladders, and a zipline punctuate the course.

visits.text: Saint Michael Archangel Basilica dominates the old town with its ochre and yellow facade, a Baroque masterpiece with glittering gold.
Lose yourself in Old Menton: cobbled lanes, pastel facades, turquoise shutters, a postcard setting with Italian accents.
Discover the Jean Cocteau Museum - Séverin Wunderman Collection: modern, luminous architecture celebrating the artist who loved this border town.
The Bastion, a 17th-century fortress perched at the water's edge, was the first place dedicated to the artist's work.
Climb to the Old Château Cemetery: terraced levels offer spectacular views over ochre rooftops and the glittering Mediterranean.
The market stalls of Les Halles overflow with flavors: creamy cheeses, fragrant tapenades, golden olive oil, and the famous Menton lemon in all its forms.
Menton — colorful old town (alleyways, stairs) up to Saint-Michel basilica and panoramic terrace over the bay.
Jean Cocteau Museum (Séverin Wunderman collection) — works inspired by the Mediterranean.
Val Rahmeh Garden — subtropical garden with rare species and pools.
Monaco — old rock, Prince's Palace, Oceanographic Museum and Port Hercule.
Roquebrune-Cap-Martin — medieval castle, Le Corbusier promenade and Cap Martin coves.
Sainte-Agnès — perched village at 800 m, Maginot fort and panorama over the sea.
Menton — old town, Saint-Michel basilica, Jean Cocteau museum and Val Rahmeh garden.
Marine Cemetery of Menton — Nocturnal voices.
Castle Hill (Nice) — Glimmers/murmurs.

activities.text: Stroll through Biovès Gardens: flower-lined paths, giant citrus sculptures, stage of the famous Lemon Festival each winter.
The Promenade du Soleil stretches its palm-lined ribbon between pebble beach and restaurants facing the azure.
Bring back a lemon souvenir: tangy jams, amber limoncello, fragrant soaps from specialty shops.
The coastal path to Cap Martin winds between umbrella pines and secret coves, the turquoise sea below.
Succumb to Menton's lemon tart, concentrated sunshine on shortbread crust, accompanied by a limoncello spritz on the terrace.
Promenade du Soleil — coastal walk shaded by palm trees.
Discovery of Jardin Biovès installations (depending on season).
Harbor stroll and view of yachts from Monte-Carlo.
Botanical break in the Biovès Gardens of Menton.

visits.text: Acquired in 1784 by the Marquis de Laborde, this estate was transformed into a picturesque garden by Hubert Robert. The Juine River was diverted to create islands, meanders, and lakes.
The neoclassical château from the 13th and 15th centuries overlooks artificial rock formations. It occupies pride of place in the composition of this Anglo-Chinese park.
The Golden Ball Bridge by Jean-Michel Othoniel has spanned the Juine since 2023. Four large gilded spheres and three thousand mirror beads reinterpret the 18th-century original.
Picturesque ruins dot the park: artificial grottos, remnants of bridges, and spectacular rock formations. Chateaubriand called this place a romantic oasis.
The Trajan Tower, standing 33 meters tall, was built between 1790 and 1792 by stonemasons from Limousin. It served for terrestrial meridian measurements as early as 1793.

activities.text: Explore the 90-hectare park, designated a historic monument. Seven hundred artisans worked for ten years to create this landscape of open prairie encircled by trees.
Follow the diverted Juine that flows through the estate. The rehabilitated hydraulic network was just inaugurated after extensive restoration work.
The estate reopened in 2018 and received the Remarkable Garden label in 2019. Guided tours offered by the tourism office on Sunday afternoons.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: Saint-Étienne Cathedral displays its 6,500 m² of stained glass windows, an absolute record in France ahead of Chartres' 2,600 m². Nicknamed the 'Good Lord's Lantern', it bathes in changing light where Marc Chagall's mystical blues dialogue with Hermann de Münster's medieval windows. Its naves rise 42 meters under vault, France's third highest. Between 1958 and 1970, Chagall created stained glass windows inspired by the Old Testament for the ambulatory and north transept, featuring the Sacrifice of Isaac and Jacob's Dream in tones of supernatural blue, cosmic green, and mystical red.

Centre Pompidou-Metz emerges like a spaceship set down on the landscape, with its hexagonal roof of 8,500 m² in woven wood inspired by a Chinese hat. Designed by Japanese architect Shigeru Ban and Jean de Gastines, inaugurated in 2010, it deploys 5,000 m² of exhibition spaces under a structure of 18 km of glued laminated beams. Its spire rises to 77 meters, a nod to the year 1977 when the Paris Centre Pompidou was created. The 15-meter-wide galleries frame views of the cathedral, the train station, and the Seille park.

Place Saint-Louis, the 13th-century medieval arcades draw a setting of blond stone where the footsteps of money changers and Lombard merchants still echo. Half-timbered facades and wrought-iron signs tell eight centuries of international trade. Take time for a coffee under the vaults, where the city of Metz has been beating since the Middle Ages.

The Temple Neuf, a neo-Romanesque Protestant church built between 1901 and 1904 on a small island in the Moselle, is reflected in the waters with its twin 58-meter spires. Erected during the German annexation, it illustrates the Wilhelminian will to mark the urban landscape. Gray sandstone facades, copper roofs turned green, and stained glass windows by Wilhelm Pfeffer create a romantic decor. The interior, restored after World War II, displays Rhine Romanesque architecture.

The Saint-Pierre-aux-Nonnains church, built in the 4th century, is one of the oldest religious buildings in France. Originally a Gallo-Roman basilica then a Benedictine church, it preserves walls 1,600 years old. The nave, austere with exposed stones, evokes late Antiquity. Archaeological excavations revealed Roman mosaics and Merovingian foundations. The building now houses exhibitions and concerts, its millennial acoustics attracting musicians.

activities.text: Stroll through the German Imperial Quarter, an architectural laboratory built between 1902 and 1918 under Wilhelm II. Avenue Foch lines up its neo-Romanesque and Art Nouveau villas with polychrome facades, while the monumental 1908 train station in gray sandstone evokes Rhine castles with its 40-meter central tower. This kaleidoscope of Wilhelminian styles offers a unique immersion in Prussian urbanism of the Belle Époque, with over 800 listed buildings.

The Musée de la Cour d'Or unveils 2,000 years of Metz history in the former Petits Carmes convent. 1st-century Gallo-Roman baths, Roman mosaics, and Romanesque sculptures dialogue under centuries-old vaults. The Merovingian collections are among the richest in France, with the treasure from the Metz-Sablon necropolis. Don't miss the medieval Greniers de Chèvremont integrated into the route.

Take a boat cruise on the Moselle to admire Metz's architecture from the water. The 1-hour routes pass under medieval bridges (Moyen Pont, Pont des Roches), along the cathedral and the Temple Neuf, and the imperial port district. Commentary explains the city's 3,000-year history. Evening cruises at sunset offer a romantic atmosphere. Departures from the port quays April to October.

Explore the covered market of Metz, a metallic structure from 1831 renovated in 2007. The 40 stalls offer regional products: Lorraine mirabelle plums, Munster cheese, Metz sausages, and local wines. Butchers, fishmongers, bakers, and produce sellers perpetuate artisanal traditions. The central square hosts a market on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings. The wrought iron and glass architecture evokes 19th-century Les Halles.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass
Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: The château de Meung-sur-Loire earns its nickname "the château with two faces." Facing the town, an imposing 13th-century medieval façade. Facing the garden, an 18th-century classical façade painted ox-blood red, once called the "red château."

Residence of the Bishops of Orléans until the Revolution, the château opens from attics to cellars. More than 25 furnished rooms display 2,000 period objects: liquor salon, smoking room, herbarium, library with 18th-century Versailles parquet.

Descend into the dungeons that served as prison. The poet François Villon was locked up here. The torture chamber bears witness to punitive methods of old, while a video show animates the dark galleries.

The neoclassical chapel from the late 18th century, designed by architect Trouard, is one of the rare examples of this style in France. The early-13th-century cellar and the 16th-century spiral staircase complete the architectural circuit.
The remarkable bishops' bathroom traces the evolution of hygiene across the centuries. Antique bathtubs, toiletry objects, and accessories compose a collection as instructive as it is surprising.
An odorama pathway awakens the senses while the "boitakois"—display cases of unusual everyday objects—invite you to guess their use through quizzes.

The Château de Meung spans a thousand years of architectural history. From the feudal keep to the elegant 18th-century apartments, discover the underground chapel and chilling medieval dungeons that once held prisoners of the bishops of Orléans.
The Collégiale Saint-Liphard raises its Romanesque bell tower above the town. The 6th-century crypt and Romanesque nave shelter the tomb of Saint Liphard, who founded the monastery here in 520.
Water mills dot the channels of the Mauves River as it splits through town. These medieval mills, still powered by the rushing water, preserve the memory of centuries of grain grinding.
Château de Meung-sur-Loire, one of the most expansive châteaux in the Loiret with a rich medieval past
Tour the grand halls and chambers of Château de Meung-sur-Loire, from dungeons to state rooms
Wander through the landscaped park of Château de Meung-sur-Loire along the riverside paths

activities.text: Walk through the 7-hectare park right in the town center. Vestiges of an English-style garden created on the eve of the Revolution, it preserves centuries-old trees and a sound-enhanced rose garden.
Wander through the château's terraced gardens. A fragrant rose garden, medieval kitchen garden, and English-style park cascade down toward the Mauves.
The Sunday market fills the Place du Martroi with local color. Loire Valley farmers and market gardeners sell fresh produce, fruit, and tangy local goat cheeses.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
Loiret Road Trip: Orléans & Loire Valley Châteaux
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Beaune — historic center, ramparts and Hospices de Beaune (Hôtel-Dieu)
Veuve Ambal (Montagny-lès-Beaune) — tour of the Crémant de Bourgogne production site
Savigny-lès-Beaune — castle and parks, discovery of unusual collections
Aloxe-Corton — village stop and viewpoint over the Corton hillsides
Pommard — tour of the vineyard and wine village
Château de Pommard — vineyard route & cellar visit (without commercial mention)
Town Hall square and Saint-Nicolas church at the heart of the village.
Wine-growing quarters and historic enclosed vineyards in the immediate surroundings.
Climats of the Côte de Beaune visible from the vineyard paths.

activities.text: Guided tasting in Côte de Beaune (focus on pinot noir and chardonnay)
Wine trail to Volnay or Auxey-Duresses (round trip).
Twilight walk among low walls, stone huts and rows of vines.

days_plan.itin_title: Burgundy's Grand Crus Route: Prestige Vineyards & Historic Wine Cellars
Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes

visits.text: Meyrueis, at the confluence of the Jonte, Béthuzon, and Brèze, is ringed by mountains. Its narrow streets weave between Renaissance houses and covered passages. The Tour de l'Horloge, a remnant of medieval fortifications, marks the town's heart.
The Château de Roquedols, 2 km from the center, is a restored 16th-century manor house. It hosts the Cévennes National Park information center for the Méjean causse's southern slope.

The Dargilan cave, known as the "pink cave" for its formations' hue, opens onto the Causse Noir. Immense chambers—including the 142-meter-long Grand Hall—display draperies, columns, and stalactites with orange reflections. Discovered in 1880 by a shepherd.

The Mont Aigoual Observatory, at 1,567 meters elevation, is France's last inhabited mountain weather station. On clear days, panoramas extend from the Alps to the Pyrénées and out to the Mediterranean. The exhibition traces meteorology's history.
Drive back up the Jonte gorges from Meyrueis. Dolomite cliffs frame a narrow road carved into rock. Natural balconies offer views of griffon vulture colonies in flight.

activities.text: Hike on the Méjean causse starting from Meyrueis. The trail crosses dry grasslands, skirts lavognes (pastoral ponds), and passes causse farmsteads built of stone. A landscape of magnificent solitude.
Canyoning in the Tapoul or Jonte gorges. Jumps, natural slides, and rappels in crystalline water between limestone walls. Outfitters provide full equipment.
Meyrueis market runs Wednesday and Friday mornings beneath the plane trees. Causse sheep cheeses, chestnut honey, country charcuterie, and seasonal porcini mushrooms.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes

visits.text: The Millau Viaduct reaches 343 metres in height, taller than the Eiffel Tower. Spanning 2,460 metres, it links the Causse Rouge to the Causse du Larzac. The visitor area features a 220 m² interactive exhibition and a viewing platform with free 24/7 access.

The glove-making workshops have been Millau's claim to fame since the 19th century. Maison Fabre has been making gloves in the same family since 1924. Visit the workshops to see the artisanal crafting of a pair of Made in Millau gloves.

The La Graufesenque site was one of the most important pottery centres of the Roman world. The Millau museum displays pieces that were exported across all Roman lands. The Belfry and the Baltard-style metal hall complete the town's heritage.
Panoramic view of the Millau Viaduct from the Peyre belvedere.
Discovery of the troglodyte village of Peyre and its church on the banks of the Tarn.

activities.text: The Explorers' Trail takes you under the viaduct deck with an Eiffage guide. The tour reveals the construction secrets of this steel giant. Booking required, the trail is suitable for all ages.

Millau is the capital of outdoor sports. Paragliding, rock climbing, via ferrata, canyoning, and mountain biking are all available on the surrounding causses and gorges. Certified instructors offer introductory sessions and courses.
Walking under the Millau Viaduct and break at the bistrot des Amis.

days_plan.itin_title: Aveyron Road Trip: Causses, Tarn Gorges and Villages
Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages

visits.text: The 15th-century timber-framed market hall has miraculously survived the centuries. Its massive beams shelter a traditional Thursday market where Milly mint is still sold.
The Chapel of Saint-Blaise des Simples was a 12th-century leprosarium. In 1959, Cocteau decorated it with frescoes depicting medicinal plants and Christ's resurrection.
The herb garden surrounding the chapel cultivates mint, valerian, and belladonna. These medicinal plants recall Milly's tradition dating back to the Middle Ages.
Step inside Jean Cocteau's House. His office, bedroom, studio, and grand salon immerse visitors in the mythological universe of the poet who lived here from 1947 to 1963.
The National Conservatory of Plants gathers more than 1,500 medicinal and aromatic species. The museum space explains the history of healing herbs and their traditional uses.
The Château de la Bonde from the 13th and 15th centuries raises its two crenellated towers near the stone bridge. Cocteau lived in a former outbuilding here.

activities.text: Venture into the forest to discover Tinguely's Cyclops. This giant head, 22 meters tall and weighing 300 tons of steel, surveys the forest with its single golden eye.
Enter the Cyclops's interior through stairs and walkways. Works by Niki de Saint Phalle, Spoerri, Arman, and César fill this mechanical labyrinth.
The Trois-Pignons massif extends south of Milly. Its boulder fields attract climbers while its forest trails draw hikers seeking solitude.
Reach nearby Fontainebleau Forest. The sandstone plateaus and maritime pine groves create surprising landscapes just a few kilometers from Milly.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: Sainte-Marie bell tower-porch: Remnant of a 12th-century Benedictine priory inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage as part of the Santiago de Compostela Routes. The sculpted 13th-century portal ranks among the finest in southwestern France. Remarkably preserved 15th-century murals. The Priory Museum completes the visit with archaeological collections.

Courant de Mimizan: 7km sinuous coastal river connecting Lake Aureilhan to the ocean. This natural boundary separates Mimizan-Nord from Mimizan-Sud. Landscaped walks along the banks with views of fishing and pleasure boats. Renowned spot for sea bass and sea trout fishing.

Lake Aureilhan and Promenade Fleurie: Over 400 plant species line the lake loop. Open-air botanical garden with remarkable trees and exotic plants. The 350-hectare lake offers calm waters for swimming and water activities. View over the Landes forest and dunes in the distance.

Wings Monument: Commemorates the first North Atlantic crossing by the French team of the Oiseau Canari (Assolant, Lefèvre, Lotti) who landed on Remember Beach in June 1929. Stele erected facing the ocean. The Woolsack castle, Tudor architecture from 1910, testifies to the resort's aristocratic past.

activities.text: Hiking on marked trails: 40km of routes through forest, dunes and lakes. Loops from 2h to 5h depending on itineraries. The coastal trail offers ocean panoramas and passage by blockhouses. Maps available at the tourist office. Welcome shade in summer.

Ocean beach swimming: 10km of beaches including 4 lifeguarded in season (Nord, Sud, Lespecier, Courant). Beware of baïnes (dangerous currents). Swimming flags must be strictly respected. PMR mats for disabled access on certain beaches. Lifeguard stations June to September.

Canoe on the Courant: Peaceful 7km descent between lake and ocean. Rental from the lake departure with shuttle return or one-way to the sea. Wildlife observation (herons, cormorants) and riparian flora. Easy outing accessible from age 6 with accompaniment.

Landes Aventure treetop course: 120 workshops distributed over 9 courses in the pines. Heights from 1m to 15m depending on levels. 160m zipline. Open April to November with evening sessions in summer. Equipment provided, mandatory safety briefing. Online booking advised.

days_plan.itin_title: Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: Mourèze Cirque.
Lodève Museum.
Cesse Gorges.

Minerve stands on a rocky spur between the gorges of the Cesse and Brian rivers. Classified as a Grand Site of France, the village is accessible only by a single bridge. Below, the Cesse has carved two spectacular natural bridges: the Grand Pont (228 m long) and the Petit Pont (126 m).

In 1210, Simon de Montfort besieged Minerve for seven weeks during the Albigensian Crusade. A trebuchet named 'la Malvoisine' destroyed the village's only well. One hundred forty Cathars refused to recant and were burned alive—the crusade's first collective pyre.
The Dove of Peace, a carved stone stele, commemorates the massacred Cathars. It stands at the presumed location of the pyre, at the village entrance.

The church of Saint-Étienne preserves a white marble altar dated 456, one of France's oldest. This Visigothic vestige, set in sober Romanesque architecture, testifies to the site's ancient occupation.

Descend by the path leading to the Cesse riverbed to walk through the Grand Natural Bridge on foot. In summer, when the river runs dry, you walk under the stone vault—a tunnel carved by millennia of karst erosion.

The Saint-Rustique well, whose destruction during the 1210 siege sealed the citadel's surrender, can be visited in the village's lower part. A museum recounts Cathar history and crusade episodes in the region.

activities.text: Lunar landscapes.
Geopark.
Salagou Lake.
The Cesse gorges trail offers a shaded hike along limestone cliffs. In summer, natural pools allow swimming in translucent water.
The AOC Minervois vineyard surrounds the village. Nearby wine estates produce powerful reds based on syrah, grenache, and carignan, grown on limestone and schist soils.
The Canal du Midi, a World Heritage site, passes about twenty kilometers away. The Ognon lock and Malpas tunnel, the world's first canal tunnel, are easily visited from Minerve.

days_plan.itin_title: Hérault, France: Mediterranean Beaches and Languedoc Wine Country
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Mirande is a 13th-century bastide organized in a grid pattern around its central square. The covered wooden market hall has sheltered the market for centuries. The church of Sainte-Marie has a characteristic octagonal bell tower.
The Museum of Fine Arts displays paintings and sculptures from the 17th to 20th centuries. The collection includes works by regional and national artists.

activities.text: Monday morning market is renowned throughout the Gers. Producers sell poultry, foie gras, and Gascon specialties. It's an authentic market where locals do their shopping.
Taste the gastronomy of the Gers at restaurants in the center. Duck confit, seared foie gras, and garbure (peasant soup) are specialties. Regional wines accompany these hearty dishes perfectly.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Traditional market (Saturday).
Col de Port.
Half-timbered houses.

Mirepoix was rebuilt in a grid pattern on the left bank of the Hers after the devastating flood of 1289. This regular layout, typical of Occitan bastides, organizes around a central square whose architecture has barely changed.

The 15th-century arcades stretch for 140 meters—the longest of all bastides in southern France. Supported by massive oak pillars, they shelter shops, cafés, and restaurants beneath pastel-colored half-timbered façades.
Look up at the Maison des Consuls: 103 sculptures adorn the ends of its beams. Grimacing heads, fantastic monsters, improbable animals—a complete bestiary carved in wood in the 15th century.

The former cathedral of Saint-Maurice is distinguished by the widest single nave in Europe: 22 meters without an intermediate pillar. Its construction spans six centuries, from 1297 to the 19th. The floor labyrinth, installed between 1520 and 1537, reproduces a model from the Toulouse provostship.

The Porte d'Aval is the last vestige of medieval fortifications. Cross it in the other direction to understand the effect on travelers entering the citadel: perspective closes on half-timbered houses, time slows.

The seven-arch bridge, 206 meters long, was built between 1776 and 1789. Its architect is the same who designed the Pont de la Concorde in Paris. The stones come from quarries in Bastide de Bousignac.
The Baltard-style hall, inaugurated in 1885, replaces the old wooden hall. It hosts markets on Mondays and Thursdays, as well as medieval festivals, puppet festivals, and the apple fair.

activities.text: Monday market.
Crafts.
Gastronomy.

Monday morning's grand market is an institution: stalls invade the Place des Couverts and adjacent streets. Products from the Ariège terroir, cheeses, charcuterie, and seasonal fruits under medieval arcades.

The village of Camon, about ten kilometers away, is nicknamed 'the village of roses.' Its fortified Benedictine abbey and flower-lined lanes are worth a detour, especially in May during the rose festival.
The petrifying waterfalls of Roquefort-les-Cascades offer an unusual family hike: limestone deposited by water transforms moss into stone over centuries, creating staircase formations.

days_plan.itin_title: Ariège Pyrenees Road Trip, France: Cathar Castles & Prehistoric Cave Art
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Climb to the summit of the village to reach the Église Sainte-Foy, a jewel of 12th-century Romanesque architecture. Now deconsecrated, it hosts rotating exhibitions from April through September that breathe new life into the ancient stone.

From the orientation table near Sainte-Foy, the view embraces the Rhône Valley, the Vivarais mountains, and the foothills of the Vercors. On clear days, the panorama stretches for dozens of kilometers in every direction.
Sloping lanes lead past superb stone facades. The Adhémar de Monteil family built the first fortifications in the 12th century, and the ramparts still define the silhouette of this clifftop village.

The Église Saint-Pierre, in the heart of the village, dates from the mid-19th century. Inside hangs a 17th-century painting depicting Saint Ursula and Saint Augustine contemplating the mystery of the Trinity.

Artisan workshops dot the narrow streets: ceramics, jewelry, sculptures. A cubist painter settled here in the 1920s and founded a summer academy, igniting an artistic tradition that thrives to this day.
Mirmande once flourished through sericulture—silkworm farming. Panels throughout the village recount that era when magnaneries (silkworm nurseries) provided livelihoods for local families.

activities.text: Follow the Sainte-Foy trail winding through orchards and olive groves below the village. You'll be rewarded with panoramic views of Mirmande's rooftops against the backdrop of the Drôme hills.
The region is renowned for its orchards. In season, farmers open their properties to visitors: cherries, apricots, peaches, nectarines, and kiwis available for pick-your-own or direct purchase.

The village of Cliousclat, just a few kilometers away, preserves its pottery-making heritage. A historical trail traces the story of the kilns and artisans who have worked the clay here for generations.

days_plan.itin_title: Rhône-Alpes Circuit: Perched Villages and Mountain Peaks

visits.text: Sandstone village and Renaissance houses around courtyards and wine presses.
Cobbled alleys leading to the wine terraces of Zellberg.
Civil and religious buildings soberly decorated.

Mittelbergheim, classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages, aligns Renaissance winemakers' houses in pink sandstone along its main street, dating from the 16th and 17th centuries. Sculpted carriage gates display construction dates and family names.
The former communal press, on the main street, testifies to the village's ancestral wine activity. Engraved lintels and mullioned windows recall the Renaissance prosperity of the winemakers.
The Renaissance town hall, with its overhanging oriel and sculptures, is one of the village's most photographed buildings.
The village backs onto Grand Cru Zotzenberg, the only Grand Cru in Alsace to authorize the Sylvaner grape in addition to Riesling and Gewurztraminer.

activities.text: Wine trail loop and hillside viewpoint (3–4 km).
Architectural identification of dated lintels and cart porches.
Climb the wine trails to the viewpoint over Andlau and the Alsace plain. Zotzenberg vines descend in terraces facing east.
Village winemakers open their cellars for tastings of Sylvaner Grand Cru Zotzenberg, Riesling and Gewurztraminer. Ask for the cellars route.
Push on to Andlau Abbey (2 km), whose Romanesque portal sculpted with hunting and combat scenes is one of the richest in Alsace.

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages
Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: The Forts de l'Esseillon form an ensemble of five fortifications built between 1819 and 1834 by the Kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia on a natural glacial lock. Listed Historic Monuments, they bear the names of the royal family: Victor-Emmanuel, Marie-Thérèse, Marie-Christine, Charles-Albert, and Charles-Félix.

Fort Victor-Emmanuel, the most imposing of the complex, could house 1,500 soldiers. You wander through casemates, vaulted corridors, and guard posts. A scenario-based treasure hunt invites families to slip into the role of a 19th-century French spy.

Redoute Marie-Thérèse, horseshoe-shaped, houses a fortified heritage interpretation center. Scale models, panels, and artifacts trace the history of the military lock, from its construction to Savoy's annexation in 1860.
Walk down to the Pont du Diable, a suspension bridge above the Arc gorges, linking Fort Victor-Emmanuel to Redoute Marie-Thérèse. The plunging view into gorges more than 100 meters deep is dizzying.

At Modane's outskirts, on the Valfréjus road, spot the "maison penchée." This former 1939 blockhouse, an observation post at the railway tunnel entrance, was hurled dozens of meters by the explosion of two explosives wagons in 1944. It replanted itself in the ground, nearly intact but tilted.

The monumental entrance to the Fréjus railway tunnel (the Alps' first boring, 1857-1871) stands on the Modane-Valfréjus road. The cut-stone portal marks the beginning of one of the 19th century's great engineering projects.

activities.text: Via Ferrata du Diable. Seven routes of increasing difficulty spread across the Esseillon site, between rock walls, monkey bridges, and metal ladders overhanging the Arc gorges.

Hike on the old Esseillon road, starting from Modane. The trail winds between Le Bourget and Aussois via the Saint-Benoît waterfall and chapel, then passes the forts one by one. Drinking water points all along the route.
Treetop adventure course in the Parc du Diable, near Redoute Marie-Thérèse. Walkways between the trees and zip lines above the gorges, in a spectacular setting blending forest and military heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Savoie from Lakes to Glaciers: Yenne to Haute-Maurienne

visits.text: Visit to the Toy Museum in Moirans-en-Montagne, tracing the playful history of Jura
Discovery of Lake Vouglans and the Pont de la Pyle, one of France's largest artificial lakes

activities.text: Cruise or kayak trip on the emerald green waters of Lake Vouglans
Panoramic walk to the Garde belvedere

days_plan.itin_title: Jura Lakes & Mountains: Turquoise Waters, Waterfalls & Alpine Cheese Routes

visits.text: The cloister of Saint-Pierre Abbey, completed in 1100, displays 76 carved capitals—46 with narrative scenes. Galleries with round arches frame a peaceful garden where each capital tells a biblical or medieval story in stone.

The south portal tympanum measures 6.5 by 4.5 meters. Carved between 1110 and 1130, it depicts Christ in Majesty surrounded by the 24 Elders of the Apocalypse according to Saint John—one of Romanesque art's supreme masterpieces.
The abbey church combines Romanesque stone and Gothic brick. Its upper sections were rebuilt in the 15th century after destruction during the Albigensian Crusade.
The Marcel Durliat Center for Romanesque Art exhibits reproductions of illuminated manuscripts created by monks in the 11th and 12th centuries. A specialized library completes the collection.
Climb to the cloister gallery for views over the town and Tarn valley. Terracotta rooftops spread toward the Moissagais hillsides.

activities.text: Walk the Way of Saint James through Moissac. This major stop on the Via Podiensis welcomes thousands of pilgrims each year on their journey to Santiago de Compostela.
Follow the Canal des Deux Mers cycling path. From Toulouse to Bordeaux, the route hugs calm waters perfect for contemplative pauses beneath ancient trees.
Sample Moissac Chasselas grapes harvested from September to October. These golden-white grapes have held AOC protection since 1971.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: Mollégès — plain town between Alpilles and Durance, bright facades and shaded squares.
Village heritage: church and old alleyways.

activities.text: Agricultural paths between hedges and orchards towards Saint-Andiol.
Gentle bike loop (flat terrain).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: The village of Eze clings to its rocky peak at 429 meters altitude: pass through the medieval gate and lose yourself in alleys where time has stopped.
The Exotic Garden of Eze crowns the castle ruins: century-old cacti, rare aloes, contemporary sculptures, and vertiginous views over the Mediterranean.
Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Church raises its 19th-century bell tower at the heart of the village, with a luminous Baroque interior.
Monaco Rock displays its 16th to 18th-century alleyways: ramparts, the Visitation Chapel, and the cathedral where the Grimaldi princes rest.
The Prince's Palace has dominated the Mediterranean since 1297: witness the changing of the carabinieri, a ceremony run like clockwork.
The Oceanographic Museum plunges into the abyss: 6,000 marine species, the Lagoon recreates a living coral reef at the museum's heart.
The Monte Carlo Casino sparkles with Belle Époque splendor: Charles Garnier signed this masterpiece in 1879, a sumptuous theater-opera inside.

activities.text: Descend the Nietzsche Path: 2 kilometers of steep trail connect the perched village to Eze-sur-Mer, where the philosopher used to meditate.
Eze perfumeries open their workshops: copper stills, manufacturing secrets, fragrant boutiques.
Stroll through Monte-Carlo: sumptuous villas, towering buildings, the Hermitage Hotel, giant yachts in the port.
The Princess Grace Rose Garden blooms with thousands of roses: a peaceful haven dedicated to the memory of the actress who became princess.
Swim at Larvotto beach, fine sand and crystal-clear waters at the foot of Monte-Carlo's buildings.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure

visits.text: Moncontour, classified as a Small City of Character, preserves its medieval ramparts almost intact. Six towers and two fortified gates encircle the upper town, perched on its rocky spur since the 11th century.

The Saint-Mathurin church contains six 16th-century stained glass windows classified as Historic Monuments. The windows tell the lives of Breton saints with a palette of blues and reds of rare intensity.
Overhanging 15th and 16th-century houses line the narrow streets. Half-timbered facades, sometimes leaning to the point of almost touching, testify to the prosperity of linen cloth merchants.
On Place Penthièvre, granite mansions align their sculpted porches. The central fountain dates from the 18th century. This is where the cloth fair that made the city wealthy was held.
From the walkway, the panorama embraces the Penthièvre countryside and the Côtes-d'Armor hills. The crenellations and machicolations are remarkably preserved for a wall of this size.

activities.text: Follow the ramparts circuit (marked in yellow) that makes the complete tour of the medieval wall. Six towers punctuate the route, each offering a different angle on the valley.
Descend to the medieval washhouse below the ramparts. Water still flows there. The trail joins the terraced gardens built on the former moats.
Stroll through the artisan workshops installed in old medieval shops. Potters, weavers, and painters occupy the vaulted ground floors of Rue des Dames.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Bastide on a spur, arcaded square and checkerboard streets.
The Place des Arcades forms the heart of this bastide founded in 1256. Its covered walkways supported by broad pillars frame six remarkably similar half-timbered houses.
The Maison du Prince Noir on the square displays beautiful mullioned windows. Edward of Woodstock stayed here during the Hundred Years' War.
The Gothic Église Saint-André was rebuilt in the 18th century. Its stone portal and 20th-century bell tower dominate the bastide's skyline.
Explore the carrerots—narrow pedestrian lanes topped by pontets (overhead passages) connecting upper floors. The medieval grid plan remains perfectly intact.
The Musée des Bastides explains the creation of these medieval new towns. Scale models and interactive projections bring their history vividly to life.
Climb to Cap del Pech for panoramic views from 181 meters elevation. The rolling countryside evokes Tuscany, with the Château de Biron visible in the distance.

activities.text: Museum of Bastides or free tour of the ramparts (depending on opening).
Browse the Thursday morning market that has animated the Place des Arcades since 1256.
Join a theatrical guided tour with Janouille la Fripouille, a jester-guide who brings the bastide's story to life with humor and insight.
In August, the Journées Médiévales transform the village with troubadours, fire performances, and a grand period banquet.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: Monpazier, founded in 1284 by Edward I of England, is considered the model bastide among the 300 scattered across southwestern France. Its rectangular checkerboard plan remains perfectly intact. With 32 classified monuments, Monpazier ranks among France's Most Beautiful Villages—a medieval town that seems to have resisted time itself.

Place des Cornières is bordered by 23 arcaded houses in golden limestone, built between the 13th and 17th centuries. The central chestnut market hall still contains the old grain measures (bushels) used for centuries. This is one of the best-preserved medieval squares in France—architecture textbooks cite it as the definitive bastide plaza.

Le Bastideum is an interpretation center dedicated to bastide history, offering a playful approach to medieval life through interactive exhibits, an escape game, and a reconstructed period garden. It's engaging for families and provides context for understanding these planned medieval towns.

activities.text: Monpazier's market has convened every Thursday morning for 700 years—since the 13th century. Stalls spread under the market hall and around Place des Cornières, selling regional products and local crafts. It's a living tradition that connects the present directly to the Middle Ages.

Monpazier's narrow streets shelter artisan workshops and shops selling regional specialties. Despite enduring the Wars of Religion and the bloody Croquants peasant revolts (1594, 1637), the village has preserved its medieval character—a testament to the durability of stone and civic memory.

days_plan.itin_title: Dordogne Road Trip: Cave Art, Medieval Fortresses & Périgord Delights

visits.text: Musée Despiau-Wlérick: France's largest collection of 20th-century figurative sculpture housed in the 13th-century Donjon Lacataye medieval tower. The 2,400 works honor local sculptors Charles Despiau and Robert Wlérick. Sculpture gardens offer an outdoor trail that extends throughout the city via the Museum in the Street initiative, a pioneering project launched in 1988.

Plumaçon Arena: Built in 1889 and expanded in 1933, classified as 20th-century heritage. These arenas come alive with tradition during the famous Madeleine Feria every July. The course landaise (a regional form of bullfighting) has been passionately practiced here for over a century.

Historic center: Stroll along the Midou and Douze rivers that converge at the city's heart. The shaded quays and bridges offer beautiful perspectives on local architecture. The Parc Jean-Rameau stretches peacefully along the water's edge.

activities.text: Museum in the Street trail: Discover monumental sculptures scattered throughout the city. This free outdoor urban art trail showcases major works in public spaces. Allow 1h30 for the complete walking circuit.

Saturday morning food market: Local producers offer foie gras, Tursan wines, and Landes asparagus. The convivial atmosphere and Gascon specialties make this market unmissable. Vendors set up from 8am around the central halls.

Fêtes de la Madeleine in July: 5 days of Landes tradition with course landaise in the arenas, bandas in the streets, and concerts. Over 500,000 festayres gather annually for this major southwestern feria. Accommodation must be booked several months in advance.

days_plan.itin_title: Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: The UNESCO-listed Citadel of Mont-Louis is France's highest fortified town at 1,600 meters. Created from scratch by Vauban in 1679, it forms a square flanked by four bastions. It has housed the National Commando Training Center since 1964.
The Convicts' Well houses a 17th-century squirrel-cage wheel. At 28 meters deep, the well was operated by two men. Only three original wheels survive in France.
The Mont-Louis solar furnace was the world's first in 1949. Installed by Félix Trombe, it enabled the experimentation that led to the large Odeillo furnace. Power output of 50 kW.
The Church of Saint Louis from 1733 was built on the model of the citadel's chapel. Architectural gem dedicated to Louis XIV's ancestor.
The star-shaped ramparts follow Vauban's plan. Three fortified gates controlled access: Royal Gate, France Gate, and northern emergency gate.

activities.text: Walk the bird trail at the foot of the ramparts. Observe various bird and insect species of the territory with views of Vauban's genius.
Explore the citadel's parade ground. This esplanade bustles with military activities and testifies to the regiment's current life.
Wander through the streets of the department's smallest commune. Saint-Louis fountain, historic town hall, and Catalan architecture await discovery.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: Mont Saint-Michel — Monks & mists.
Mortemer Abbey — White lady.
Mont-Saint-Michel — Gothic abbey & medieval village.

Ascend to the magnificent Abbey of Mont-Saint-Michel, one of medieval Europe's most extraordinary architectural achievements and a UNESCO World Heritage masterpiece. This Benedictine abbey represents a stunning fusion of religious and military architecture, with its soaring Gothic spires, Romanesque crypts, and the ethereal cloister known as La Merveille suspended between heaven and earth. The abbey remains an active spiritual site where monastic communities continue daily prayers.

Lose yourself in the enchanting medieval streets that wind their way up the rocky mount toward the abbey summit. These atmospheric lanes, flanked by historic timber-framed houses and ancient stone buildings, create an authentic journey through centuries of pilgrimage history. Each turn reveals architectural treasures, from weathered doorways to tiny chapels tucked into rocky alcoves.

Walk the ancient ramparts encircling Mont-Saint-Michel for unforgettable views of the ever-changing bay. The Terrasse de l'Ouest offers particularly spectacular vistas where you can witness the dramatic interplay of light, tide, and sky that has captivated visitors for over a millennium. These defensive walls tell stories of the mount's military past when it successfully resisted English sieges during the Hundred Years' War.
Mont-Saint-Michel — climb the medieval ramparts and cobbled Grand'Rue to the summit
Mont-Saint-Michel — ascend through the Abbey's soaring Gothic halls where monks have prayed for a millennium
Mont-Saint-Michel — explore the museums and drink in the sweeping bay panoramas

activities.text: Access: public (MSM)
Access: public (Mortemer)
Guided crossing of the bay (according to tide schedules).

Explore the fascinating museums within the mount that reveal different facets of its rich history through carefully curated collections of religious artifacts, historical maquettes, and archaeological discoveries. These intimate exhibitions provide deeper understanding of the spiritual, architectural, and cultural significance of this extraordinary site.

Discover the Couesnon Dam, an innovative hydraulic engineering marvel that has restored the maritime character of Mont-Saint-Michel. This elegant contemporary structure harnesses tidal forces to flush accumulated sediments from around the mount, while also serving as a dramatic architectural gateway and public viewpoint on the approach to the island.

Experience the magical evening atmosphere during summer nocturnal visits to the abbey, when subtle lighting transforms the ancient stones into a dreamscape of shadows and illumination. These special after-dark explorations, accompanied by classical music concerts throughout the year, reveal the monument's mystical essence in an entirely new dimension.
Le Passeur shuttle — ride the causeway bridge as the island rises from the sea
Sunset vigil — watch the abbey silhouette against fire-colored skies over the bay

visits.text: Montargis—the Venice of the Gâtinais—spreads across 131 bridges and footbridges. Canals, channels of the Loing, and branches of the Vernisson wind through the old town past half-timbered houses that seem to lean in to share secrets.
The Musée Girodet showcases paintings, sculptures, and drawings by the neoclassical master who was born here. The rich collection spans 6,000 works from the 16th to the 21st century.
The château ruins crown the hilltop above town. Medieval vestiges and landscaped parkland offer sweeping panoramic views over Montargis and its lacing network of canals.

activities.text: Taste the pralines de Montargis, a local specialty created in 1636. These caramelized almonds coated in crunchy burnt sugar were invented by the Duke of Plessis-Praslin's cook—giving the world the word "praline."
The Saturday market takes over the town center. Gâtinais farmers and local artisans set up stalls along the quays and squares.
Rent an electric boat to navigate the canals. Drift along the water-level circuit between stone bridges and colorful house façades reflected in the still water.

days_plan.itin_title: Loiret Road Trip: Orléans & Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: Place Nationale forms a perfect quadrangle surrounded by double arcades in rose brick. Founded in 1144 and rebuilt after fires in 1614 and 1649, its covered galleries once sheltered medieval merchants beneath their vaulted ceilings.

The Ingres-Bourdelle Museum occupies a 17th-century bishop's palace overlooking the Tarn. Reopened in 2019 after extensive renovation, its five floors showcase 4,500 Ingres drawings including La Belle Jardinière, alongside a major collection of Bourdelle sculptures.
Pont Vieux has spanned the Tarn since 1335. Seven rose-brick arches stretch 205 meters across the river, once crowned by a triumphal arch celebrating the 1697 Peace of Ryswick.
Saint-Jacques Church exemplifies southern Gothic with its single nave and massive buttresses. An octagonal bell tower rises above the old town's terracotta rooftops.
The Canal latéral à la Garonne has flowed through town since 1856. Landscaped towpaths lead to Port-Canal, where barges moor beneath century-old plane trees.

activities.text: Stroll beneath Place Nationale's arcades where red brick and white stone create a classical harmony unchanged since the 17th century.
Follow the Canal des Deux Mers greenway. This cycling route connects Bordeaux to the Mediterranean along tranquil waters lined with lock-keepers' cottages.
Taste golden Moissac Chasselas grapes at the market stalls. These crisp, honey-sweet grapes have held AOC protection since 1971.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: Fontenay Abbey (UNESCO): cloister, church and gardens

activities.text: Landscape trail around Fontenay Abbey

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul

visits.text: The Château de Montbéliard has dominated the city since the 10th century. Its two hectares include 250 rooms divided between the Henriette and Frédéric towers. The museum presents 15 renovated rooms (875 m²) with history collections (furniture, silverware, weapons from the 15th to 18th centuries), archaeology, natural sciences linked to naturalist Georges Cuvier native to the city, and contemporary art.

The Saint-Martin temple, built between 1601 and 1607 by architect Heinrich Schickhardt, is the oldest French building assigned to Reformed worship. Montbéliard was the only French-speaking Lutheran territory, attached to the Duchy of Württemberg for four centuries. The temple is currently closed for restoration.

The Musée de l'Aventure Peugeot traces the history of the Lion brand from its 19th-century origins. The collections present not only iconic automobiles but also the coffee, pepper, and electric mills that made the company's reputation before the automobile. An immersion into the region's industrial history.

activities.text: Stroll through the historic center of Montbéliard, a City of Art and History. Les Halles (former governmental center of the Principality), the Hôtel du Lion Rouge, the Hôtel Forstner, and the colorful facades testify to the Germanic influence inherited from four centuries of attachment to Württemberg. Saint-Maimboeuf church (1850) completes the architectural panorama.

The Lumières de Noël in Montbéliard is one of the most beautiful Christmas markets in Europe. For four weeks at year-end, 160 artisans set up around the Saint-Martin temple. Shows, entertainment, ice rink, and children's village animate the city. The castle lights up and the streets are adorned with magical decorations.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs Circuit: Watchmaking and Swiss Border

visits.text: Diana Heraldic Hall. Commissioned around 1300 by Count Jean I of Forez, this extraordinary hall measures 19 meters long by 8 meters high and wide. Its vaulted pine wood ceiling displays 48 parallel bands, each adorned with 36 repeated coats of arms—1,728 compartments in all—representing feudal families allied with the Counts of Forez. A frieze of 242 interlaced shields and fantastical creatures encircles the room. François I was received here in 1536. France possesses no comparable heraldic chamber of such antiquity. The Diana houses a library of over 50,000 volumes.

Allard Museum. Set beside a public garden, this is one of the department's oldest museums. Two centuries of continuously enriched collections present archaeology, fine arts, natural history, and regional ethnography. Exhibitions reveal Forez history and its people through objects, paintings, sculptures, and archival documents. The museum occupies a handsome 19th-century building in Montbrison's heart.

Notre-Dame d'Espérance Collegiate Church. This Gothic church has towered over Montbrison for more than eight centuries, an emblematic monument of the Forez region. Unique architecture and millennial history make it unmissable. A soaring nave, luminous choir, and colorful stained glass characterize the building. Still an active place of worship, the collegiate has traversed centuries while maintaining its spiritual and heritage significance for the region.

Montbrison Historic Center. Former capital of Forez, Montbrison preserves abundant testimony to its prestigious past. Aristocratic townhouses, medieval dwellings, and Renaissance buildings line the streets of the center. Place Grenette, Rue Martin Bernard, and Ruelle du Palais offer glimpses of Forez architecture across the centuries. Free walking brochure 'Let Montbrison Tell Its Story' available at the Tourist Office.

activities.text: Allard Garden Stroll. This public park adjoining the museum offers a peaceful retreat in the town center. Centuries-old trees, shaded paths, and lawns invite leisurely walks. An ideal starting point for exploring Montbrison's historic center and shops.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Perched village dominated by castle ruins; narrow white stone streets clustered around the central square.
Bridge over the Cèze and shaded banks with ancient fords, offering viewpoints on the meander.

activities.text: Walking loop along the Cèze (3–5 km) to observe mills, fords and riverside fauna.

days_plan.itin_title: Cèze Valley Road Trip, France: Ancient Gorges & Perched Medieval Villages in Provence

visits.text: Perched on Montélimar's heights and accessible within minutes on foot from downtown, this château testifies to the Adhémar family's power. Built in the 12th century, it comprises a seigneurial residence, the 11th-century Saint-Pierre chapel, a square tower, and a fortified enclosure. From the keep, access the sentry path offering 360° panoramic views over the Drôme Pre-Alps and Rhône valley.

Stroll through the entirely pedestrian historic center with alleys lined by Provençal-colored houses. Admire the rehabilitated ramparts and private mansions. Discover Diane de Poitiers' House, a beautiful 16th-century Renaissance building. If you're there Saturday morning, the highly reputed weekly market takes over the market square.

Enter the delicious world of Montélimar nougat at artisanal factories perpetuating tradition since the 19th century. The Arnaud Soubeyran Nougat Museum, the oldest factory founded in 1837, traces this confection's history and offers live viewing of artisanal production. Nougat consists of honey, sugar, egg whites, almonds, and sometimes pistachios.

activities.text: Explore the château through multiple playful visit routes enriched with models, treasure hunts, sound atmospheres, tactile experiences, and augmented reality. This family-friendly discovery imagined by children and Drôme professionals teaches the château's history, lords' lives, and medieval practices.

Visit traditional factories like Le Chaudron d'Or or Arnaud Soubeyran where local expertise unfolds during regular demonstrations. Taste different nougat varieties: white, black, soft, hard, with pistachios, with candied fruits. Learn to distinguish quality genuine Montélimar nougat.

Complete your visit with the Montélimar Museum presenting local history, the European Museum of Fighter Aviation with combat aircraft still in flying condition, or the Miniature Museum displaying incredibly meticulous miniatures.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir

visits.text: The ruins of the Counts of Montfort's château overlook the village from a hilltop at 185 meters altitude. The Anne de Bretagne Tower, a 15th-century Flamboyant Gothic remnant, offers panoramic views over Yvelines and Rambouillet forest.

The Church of Saint-Pierre, from the 15th and 16th centuries, houses 37 Renaissance stained-glass windows considered unique in Île-de-France. Each window tells a biblical scene in blues, reds, and golds.

The Maurice Ravel House-Museum, called "Le Belvédère," preserves intact the piano, scores, and unusual object collections of the composer, who lived here from 1921 to 1937. This is where he composed Boléro.
The old cemetery, classified as a Historic Monument, surprises with its 15th- and 16th-century galleries evoking a cloister, and its Gothic portal. The Aznavour family vault is located here.

activities.text: Walk the cobbled streets of the medieval village: half-timbered houses, mansions, and the Porte Bardoul trace a circuit through a thousand years of history.
Hike along the edge of Rambouillet forest from Montfort-l'Amaury. Marked trails wind between ponds and clearings.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Alpes Majesty: High Mountain Passes, Ski Resorts & Alpine Valleys

visits.text: The 13th-century Tower of Montlhéry dominates the plain from its rocky spur. This medieval keep was the seat of a strategic county between Paris and Orléans.
The Linas-Montlhéry racing circuit was built in 1924 by industrialist Alexandre Lamblin. Its 2.5 km speed ring with parabolic curves created a sensation.
Between 1925 and 1939, the circuit recorded 86% of world speed records. The track received the 20th Century Heritage label.
Since 1973, UTAC has managed the facilities. The site now hosts automotive testing and about ten public events per year.

activities.text: The Coupes Auto Légende takes place in October with six grids dedicated to classic cars. From youngtimers to pre-war vehicles, they bring the circuit to life.
The US Motor Show celebrates American cars while the Autodrome Italian Meeting welcomes 400 Italian vehicles. Track sessions, exhibitions, and parades fill the day.
The 3.4 km road circuit lets you relive the atmosphere of grand prix racing. The 51% gradient of the Lapize curve still impresses modern drivers.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: The MuPop (Museum of Popular Music) occupies a 15th-century castle offering unique museography dedicated to music from 1750 to today. Interactive exhibits present instruments, sound recordings and music evolution through eras. Collections illustrate mechanical music, accordions, vielles à roue and popular instruments. Multimedia stations invite experimenting with sounds and rhythms.

The Dukes of Bourbon castle (end 13th-beginning 14th centuries) dominates old city with its massive keep and fortified walls. This medieval fortress converted into residential palace illustrates Bourbon power evolution. The courtyard reveals Gothic architecture while some rooms still display period murals. The castle houses the MuPop.

The Saint-Pierre church (12th-15th centuries) combines Romanesque and Gothic in imposing architecture. The carved portal displays remarkable medieval stonework. Interior shelters stained glass windows and carved capitals testifying to religious art development over the centuries. The massive bell tower marks the city skyline.

Old Montluçon unfolds its paved streets and medieval alleys around the castle. Stone and half-timbered houses from 15th to 18th centuries line picturesque streets. Place Notre-Dame and Rue Grande concentrate merchant facades and artisan shops. The medieval city preserves authentic character.

activities.text: The Wilson esplanade and jardins extends in the city center offering green spaces and playgrounds. Paths wind among flowerbeds, century-old trees and fountains. The bandstand hosts concerts during summer. A pleasant place for walks and family breaks.

The Tronçais Forest 25km from Montluçon offers hiking, biking and nature discovery. Marked trails explore exceptional oak forests planted in 17th century. The forest includes ponds, glades and remarkable trees like the Stebbing Oak 300 years old. Perfect for outdoor activities and tranquility.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: The citadel of Montmédy dominates the town from a rocky promontory. Erected in 1545 under Charles V to defend the Spanish Netherlands, it was conquered by French troops in 1657 then remodeled by Vauban. More than 1.5 km of walls encircle the upper town.
The Jules Bastien-Lepage museum, in the citadel's former school, presents drawings, paintings and objects of this naturalist painter from Meuse, internationally recognized for his rural life scenes.
The Fortification Museum traces the evolution of Meuse defensive systems, from Prehistory to the 18th century. Models and plans explain the successive works of Charles V, Vauban and Séré de Rivières.
Saint-Martin church, at the heart of the citadel, blends Romanesque and Gothic influences. Renovated, it occasionally hosts concerts and exhibitions under its restored vaults.
Montmédy was the destination chosen by the king during his flight from Paris in 1791: the garrison had remained loyal to him. A piece of history to ponder while walking through the casemates.

Montmédy citadel, erected in 1545 by Charles V to defend the Spanish Netherlands, is one of northeastern France's vastest fortresses with over 1.5 kilometers of walls. Conquered by Louis XIV's troops in 1657, it was remodeled by Vauban who added bastions, demi-lunes, and a second ring of fortifications.

At the upper town's heart, the Fortification Museum presents the evolution of Meuse defense systems from prehistory: scale models of works, ancient weapons, aerial views of fortified sites. Maps and reconstructions help understand attack and defense strategies through the centuries.

The Jules Bastien-Lepage Museum, housed in the citadel's former school, exhibits drawings, prints, and paintings by this 19th-century Meuse artist from Damvillers, who painted rural life scenes with realism influenced by the Impressionists.

Upper town lanes twist around small squares where artists' workshops animate the citadel's cultural life. The upper town church houses a remarkable organ and temporary exhibitions in certain casemates transformed into galleries.

Fifteen kilometers away, Avioth basilica is a Gothic marvel rising in the middle of a small village. A highly visited pilgrimage site, it surprises with its dimensions and sculpture finesse. Don't miss the "Recevresse," a structure unique in France designed to receive offerings.

activities.text: Follow the marked circuit of the ramparts. Bastions, underground passages, covered way and casemates succeed one another. The viewpoints offer a panorama over the Meuse countryside and the Chiers valley.
The Upper Town houses artists' studios installed in former casemates. Wander between small squares and winding alleys that thread through the heart of the stronghold.
Push on to the basilica of Avioth, 15 km away: a Gothic masterpiece nestled in a tiny village, it surprises with its dimensions and its "Recevresse," a unique outdoor baldachin.

Follow the ramparts circuit, a marked route of about 1 kilometer circling the fortifications. Explanatory panels, videos, and quizzes trace the citadel's history. The 360° panorama embraces the Meuse countryside to the Belgian border.
In summer, torchlight visits transform the citadel at nightfall. Underground galleries, artillery casemates, and caponnières take on a striking atmosphere by torchlight.
Make a detour to Marville, 10 kilometers away, a village known for its Renaissance architecture and Spanish-style houses. The cemetery and church merit a stop for old stone enthusiasts.

visits.text: Montmorency — Basilica of Saint‑Denys (12th–18th c.) and streets once frequented by Jean‑Jacques Rousseau.
Valmorency forest trails — Chestnut groves and classic viewpoints towards Paris.
