days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: Cross the 14th-century Gothic bridge over the Gartempe to enter the City of Writing and Book Crafts. Since 2000, some thirty booksellers, antiquarian dealers, bookbinders, and illuminators have occupied this restored medieval quarter.
Notre-Dame Church houses 12th-century murals in its Sainte-Catherine crypt. Outside, a statue of the Virgin, considered miraculous since 1789, is still venerated today.

The Octagon is a 12th-century funerary chapel, almost unique in Europe for its octagonal shape. It's part of the classified Maison-Dieu complex, founded in the 11th–12th centuries to shelter pilgrims and the sick.

Climb up to Saint-Laurent Chapel, whose façade and bell tower date from the 12th century. It preserves frescoes and the tomb of Étienne de Vignolles, known as "La Hire," Joan of Arc's companion and lord of Montmorillon.

The Montmorillon Art and History Museum (free admission) presents varied collections from prehistoric archaeology to fine arts. A permanent exhibit showcases over 200 antique typewriters and calculating machines.

activities.text: Taste Montmorillon's macarons, a local specialty since the 17th century. The Macaron Museum traces the history of this confection in the lower town.
Stroll along the banks of the Gartempe, the river that separates upper and lower town. From the quays, the view of the medieval city and Notre-Dame Church is especially photogenic.
Visit the open-air theater set in the gardens of the Maison-Dieu, overlooking the town. The magnificent 17th-century monastic buildings dominate the panorama.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Gilles Chapel of Montoire-sur-le-Loir sheltering exceptional 12th-century Romanesque frescoes. These remarkably preserved murals depict biblical scenes and saints in colors still vivid after nine centuries. Christ in Majesty enthroned in the apse dominates the ensemble with monumental presence. Apostles and angels unfold their wings in harmonious compositions. This small chapel constitutes an overlooked gem of Romanesque art absolutely deserving a detour. Specialists consider it one of the region's most important painted ensembles.

Medieval bridge of Montoire spanning the Loir with its centuries-old stone arches. This fortified bridge from the Middle Ages connected both banks of the walled town. Massive piers have resisted floods for centuries without failing. The view from the bridge embraces old façades reflecting in tranquil water. Restored washhouses testify to past activity of laundresses. Landscaped banks invite strolling along the river lined with willows. The riverside heritage reveals itself along the water in a peaceful atmosphere.

Old Town of Montoire-sur-le-Loir unfolding its ancient lanes and half-timbered houses. The ruined château dominates the town from its rocky promontory. Saint-Laurent church presents sober Gothic architecture. Old bourgeois residences testify to past prosperity. Flower-filled interior courtyards reveal themselves during wandering walks. The preserved architectural heritage invites leisurely exploration of this characterful small town. The lively central square concentrates shops and cafés.

activities.text: Discovering the Loir valley winding between limestone hillsides and green meadows. The river's peaceful meanders lined with poplars invite cycling or walking along towpaths. Wine-growing villages dot the waterside offering picturesque stops. Restored mills testify to flourishing past economic activity. Bucolic landscapes inspired writers and Impressionist painters. The Angevin gentleness resonates in this valley preserved from mass tourism.

Exploring troglodyte dwellings carved into tuffeau cliffs lining the Loir. Former quarries transformed into cellars and mushroom farms sometimes open for tours during special events. Underground galleries maintain constant temperatures ideal for wine storage. Some caves converted into dwellings reveal the ingenuity of vernacular architecture. Caforts dug as wartime refuges dot the hillsides. This fascinating underground heritage deserves discovery with passionate local guides.

Vineyards of the Vendômois hillsides producing AOC wines overlooked by the general public. Chenin, Pineau d'Aunis, and Gamay grape varieties flourish on sunny slopes overlooking the Loir. Winemakers open their cellars to introduce crisp whites and light reds. The Coteaux du Vendômois and Cheverny appellations testify to the region's wine revival. Tastings let you appreciate these characterful wines accompanying local goat cheeses. Panoramas from the vines embrace the entire verdant valley.

visits.text: Saint-Martin Collegiate Church has dominated the village since the 14th century. Its 16th-century Flemish tapestries, classified as Historic Monuments, depict the life of Saint Martin in vivid colors and intricate detail.
Explore the bastide center with its white stone houses. Arcades and covered passages testify to Quercy's medieval architecture.
Discover the collegiate church's side chapels adorned with murals. Liturgical furnishings include carved choir stalls and gilded altarpieces.

activities.text: Stroll cobbled lanes lined with half-timbered houses and dovecotes. The tranquil atmosphere reflects rural Quercy life.
From November to March, visit the truffle market animating the bastide. The Quercy black diamond changes hands beneath the market hall.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: Medieval village on Tanargue foothills; keep and church overlooking the valley.
Network of alleys and stone-paved paths connecting the upper town to the terraces.
Viewpoints over the southern ridgelines.

activities.text: Round trip to the high point for panorama and survey of the terrace network.
Short heritage loop within the enclosure and suburbs (2 km).

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: Montréal-du-Gers is a 13th-century hilltop bastide, listed among France's Most Beautiful Villages. Its central square is bordered by Gothic arcades. The fortified church dominates the village with its square bell tower that served as a keep.

The Gallo-Roman villa of Séviac lies a few kilometers away. This archaeological site presents exceptional mosaics dating from the 4th century. The private baths with their polychrome mosaics are particularly well preserved.

activities.text: Stroll through the cobbled lanes descending from the central square. Houses of honey-colored stone and half-timbering, vaulted passages, and small squares give the village tremendous charm.
The panorama from the church terrace embraces the Gers countryside and Armagnac hills. On clear days, you can glimpse the Pyrenees to the south.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Montréjeau is a hilltop bastide dominating the confluence of the Garonne and Neste rivers. Its 19th-century market hall marks the town center. The architecture follows the grid pattern typical of bastides.
The panorama from the terrace embraces the entire Pyrenees chain. On clear days, the view extends from Pic du Midi to the peaks of Spain. It's one of the finest viewpoints over the central Pyrenees.

activities.text: Saturday morning market draws people from across the region. You'll find mountain products and Pyrenean specialties.
From Montréjeau, Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges is visible in the distance on its rocky outcrop. The road leading there crosses landscapes of hills with the Pyrenees as backdrop.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Montreuil-sur-Mer: 13th century citadel, ramparts and medieval streets.

The Château de Montreuil-Bellay raises 15 towers and 600 meters of ramparts above the Thouet valley. Founded in 1025 by Foulques Nerra, the fortress blends medieval military architecture with Renaissance elegance.

The 15th-century medieval kitchen with its central hearth is exceptionally well-preserved. Dry moats and vaulted underground passages testify to the fortress's defensive past when it guarded this strategic river crossing.
The collegiate church and canons' lodge, built in the 15th century, showcase the ornate beauty of Flamboyant Gothic architecture at its finest.
The château's 15th-century vaulted cellars house its wine estate. Sixteen hectares of organic vineyards produce Saumur reds, whites, and sparkling wines beneath these ancient stones.
The Duchess of Longueville's chamber preserves its period furnishings. This cousin of Louis XIV was exiled here after the Fronde rebellion—royal punishment in gilded surroundings.
Three kilometers of perfectly preserved ramparts encircle the upper town. This tree-lined promenade offers magnificent views across the Canche Valley.
The star-shaped citadel, built in the 16th century atop a Philippe Auguste castle, commands the valley from 40 meters up. It houses the Roger-Rodière Museum: sacred art and medieval sculptures.
Saint-Saulve Abbey Church dates from the 12th century and holds one of northern France's finest sacred art treasures. Europe's oldest crosier, from the 7th century, is displayed here.
Wander cobbled medieval lanes: Rue du Clape-en-Bas, Cavée Saint-Firmin. Half-timbered houses, blonde stone, and red brick tell a thousand-year story.
The Boulogne Gate, rebuilt in 1828, is a majestic vestige of military architecture. It marks the northern entrance to the fortified town.

The Murs à Pêches (Peach Walls) span 34 hectares of undeveloped orchards. From the 17th to the early 20th century, these three-meter-high walls of plaster and flint made it possible to grow exceptional peaches served at the tables of Louis XIV and the Russian Tsar.
Within the school garden, the horticultural museum is France's only museum devoted to the tools and techniques of espalier peach cultivation from the 16th to 19th centuries.
The Maison Populaire de Montreuil, a contemporary art center, programs exhibitions, seminars, and events in a brutalist building at the heart of the town.
Climb up to Parc des Beaumonts for an open view over the capital. This 24-hectare natural park harbors limestone meadows rare in the Paris region and a bird observatory.
Bas-Montreuil blends workers' buildings in brick and millstone, former workshops converted into lofts and cultural third places. The alleyways hold surprises at every turn.

activities.text: Bistronomic break (land of restaurant La Grenouillère & fine local establishments).

The village of Montreuil-Bellay, a medieval walled town, unfolds as you wander on foot. Cobbled lanes climb toward the château, passing between white tuffeau stone houses that glow in the afternoon sun.
The Saumur vineyards embrace Montreuil-Bellay. Clay and flint slopes produce powerful Cabernet Francs and elegant Chenins that express the unique character of this terroir.
The Thouet cycling route follows the river through pastoral landscapes. This cycle path connects Montreuil-Bellay to neighboring châteaux via bucolic trails.
Descend via the Poterne Tower for an 8-kilometer rampart-base walk. Cross countryside and discover the lower town.
Victor Hugo stayed in Montreuil in 1837 and set part of Les Misérables here. The town still inspires with its timeless medieval atmosphere.
Explore 18th-century townhouses. Nearly 40 exceptional residences testify to the economic prosperity that transformed the urban landscape.
Wander the paths of the Murs à Pêches between plots maintained by local associations: gardening, beekeeping, theater, and land art coexist here.
The Croix-de-Chavaux neighborhood concentrates shops, cafés, and restaurants with flavors from around the world. Craving escape just steps from Paris?
Spot the murals and collages scattered throughout downtown streets. Montreuil hosts one of the most vibrant street art scenes in the eastern suburbs.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-France: Opal Coast Cliffs, Medieval History & Great War Sites
Maine-et-Loire Road Trip: Anjou and Loire Valley Châteaux
Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries
Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: Cloister.
Bishops' Palace.

activities.text: Cascades d'Ars.
Cathar history.

days_plan.itin_title: Ariège Pyrenees Road Trip, France: Cathar Castles & Prehistoric Cave Art

visits.text: Pass through the Porte de Bourgogne, remnant of the 1,400 meters of fortifications erected by Philippe Auguste in the 12th century. Its defensive systems—portcullis, murder hole, and machicolations—remain visible.

The bridge over the Loing, immortalized by the Impressionist painter who lived here his last twenty years, offers one of the most photographed views in town. Enameled lava plaques mark the exact spots where he set up his easel.
Notre-Dame Church, Gothic from the 13th to 15th centuries, was painted fourteen times by the same artist. Its two-tower facade frames a richly sculpted portal.
The keep, remnant of the royal castle, has dominated the town since the 12th century. The ramparts still preserve several turrets and the Porte de Samois, the town's second fortified entrance.
Step into the Maison du Sucre d'Orge (Barley Sugar House). This confection, created in 1638 by Benedictine nuns, has been made here for nearly four centuries using a closely guarded secret recipe.
The so-called François I Gallery, dating from 1527, features a Renaissance facade adorned with detailed sculptures. Ancient facades line the town's cobbled streets.

activities.text: Follow the "In Sisley's Footsteps" trail: a route marked by enameled plaques at the locations where the artist set up his easel. Reproductions of his paintings are visible on-site.
Cycle along the banks of the Loing. A bike path connects Moret-sur-Loing to Souppes-sur-Loing following the Loing Canal towpath.
Visit the Halle de Moret-sur-Loing on market days to taste local Brie specialties: valley cheeses, forest honey, and barley sugar drops.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: The Saint-André Crypt is all that remains of the old Toussaint collegiate church, founded by Countess Mahaut of Bavaria around 1200. Its low vaults and carved capitals evoke the medieval Perche.
The Church of Notre-Dame, in Flamboyant Gothic style, was built with support from Marguerite of Lorraine in the late 15th century. Its 18th-century woodwork frames a luminous interior.
Climb to the Porte Saint-Denis, remnant of the old fortifications. It houses local history collections: Percheron costumes, Gallo-Roman mosaics, and commemorative medals.
The Saint-François Cloister and Chapel, built by Marguerite of Lorraine in the 16th century, form a well-preserved monastic ensemble at the heart of the town.

The Alain Museum, housed in the former residence of the Counts of Perche, pays tribute to philosopher Émile-Auguste Chartier, known as Alain, a native of Mortagne. Manuscripts, photographs, and personal items trace his life.
Stroll the formal gardens of the town hall, planted in the French style. The surrounding cobbled lanes reveal handsome limestone houses in shades of rose and ochre.

activities.text: Mortagne-au-Perche is the capital of black pudding. Visit an artisan butcher to discover variations: farm-style, with apples, with walnuts, with chili. The Brotherhood of Knights of the Black Pudding has upheld the tradition since 1963.
The Saturday morning market sets up in the square. Percheron regional products, cheeses, and farmhouse cider fill the stalls.
Want fresh air? Trails around Mortagne wind through the Percheron bocage. Gentle hills, hedgerows, and stone manors punctuate the route.
A few miles away, stud farms offer encounters with the Percheron, the region's iconic draft horse breed. Visits, rides, or introductory sessions are available.

days_plan.itin_title: Orne Road Trip: Norman Bocage and Prestigious Stud Farms

visits.text: The Saut du Doubs is a 27-meter waterfall on the Franco-Swiss border, classified as a Grand National Site. Created 12,000 to 14,000 years ago by a landslide, it marks the end of Lake Brenets (or Lake Chaillexon). The Basins of the Doubs that precede it form a 3.5 km long canyon, 100-200 m wide and 30-40 m deep, bordered by high limestone cliffs with sometimes strange shapes. The level varies by nearly 20 meters between floods and low waters. The site attracts 200,000 visitors per year.

Morteau is the birthplace of the eponymous sausage, protected by PGI since 2010 and Label Rouge since 2006. Its cylindrical shape with wooden peg is recognizable among all. Smoking with coniferous wood (fir, spruce, juniper) in traditional tuyés is inscribed on UNESCO's intangible heritage. Production reaches approximately 5,000 tons per year. The town, labeled Cité de Caractère, preserves beautiful monuments including the Town Hall (1590) and the Renaissance-facade Château Pertusier.

The Pays Horloger saw the birth of the French watchmaking industry in the mid-18th century. This know-how is inscribed on UNESCO's intangible cultural heritage. The watchmaking museum, installed in Château Pertusier, is currently closed for renovation and will reopen in 2026 under the name Cité des Horlogers with new exhibition spaces.

activities.text: Two boat companies offer commented one-hour cruises to the Saut du Doubs from Villers-le-Lac. You can also access it on foot (2.5 km from Vions parking), by carriage from La Courpée, or by car to the viewpoint. The sporty hike to the Châtelot dam offers superb views of the gorges.

Visit a tuyé farm to discover traditional Comtoise architecture and the meat smoking process. These buildings with large roofs house a central room with a chimney that can reach 15 meters where coniferous smoke slowly perfumes sausages, bresi, and hams for several weeks. The Ferme-musée du Beugnon in Grand'Combe-Châteleu presents this heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs Circuit: Watchmaking and Swiss Border

visits.text: Exploration of the village of Mougins and its spiral streets.
Discovery of art galleries and the André Villers photography museum.

activities.text: Participation in the gastronomic festival 'Les Étoiles de Mougins' (if September period).

days_plan.itin_title: Côte d'Azur Secrets: Perched Villages and Mountain Escapes

visits.text: The CNCS (National Center for Stage Costume and Scenography) displays over 10,000 costumes in an exceptional collection illustrating three centuries of performing arts. Former 18th-century barracks transformed into a modern museum present costumes worn by Nureyev, Pavlova or Caruso. Temporary exhibitions unveil backstage secrets and creations by major designers like Christian Lacroix and Yves Saint Laurent.

The Notre-Dame Cathedral, built between 15th and 19th centuries, shelters a masterpiece: the Moulins Master Triptych (circa 1498-1499). This flamboyant Gothic painting depicting the Virgin in Glory with donors Pierre II of Bourbon and Anne of France ranks among French Gothic art masterpieces. The central panel dazzles with colors and refined details characteristic of Franco-Flemish style.

The Anne de Beaujeu Museum occupies a ducal pavilion (late 15th century), testimony to the Dukes of Bourbon's power. Archaeological collections trace the region from prehistory to Middle Ages. The fine arts section displays paintings from 15th to 20th centuries including works by the Moulins Masters. Decorative arts reveal ceramic, sculpture and furniture treasures.

The Jacquemart belfry (15th century) stands out with its 46-meter-high square tower topped by a wrought-iron campanile. Since 1651, three jacks strike the hours: Jacquemart the father, his wife Jacquette added in 1655, and their children in 1774. Climb the 106 steps to enjoy a panorama over the city and Allier valley.

The old Moulins unfolds its cobblestone streets between half-timbered houses and Renaissance mansions. Rue d'Allier and Place d'Allier concentrate bourgeois facades from the 15th to 18th centuries. The Mal Coiffée tower, remnant of the ducal castle razed by Richelieu, overlooks the city from its 38 meters.

activities.text: Stroll along Allier quays converted into a promenade with playgrounds and green spaces. Pedestrian paths invite riverside walks with views of the river and surrounding nature. The proximity to city center allows combining urban visits and outdoor relaxation.

The Saturday morning market fills Place d'Allier with stalls offering regional products, Bourbonnais cheeses, farm poultry and seasonal vegetables. Local producers present their specialties while craftsmen exhibit traditional know-how. The atmosphere is lively and authentic.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: Mouriès — France's leading olive-growing commune: Provençal town at the foot of the hills.
Center — small squares and rows of olive trees.

activities.text: Eastern Alpilles ridge trails (section).
Mills and oratories route (village).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Climb up to Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir chapel watching over the village. The 262 steps wind through oratories adorned with earthenware tiles. The 12th-century Romanesque sanctuary dominates Moustiers rooftops and offers a plunging view over Lac de Sainte-Croix.

The golden star suspended between two cliffs has intrigued since the 10th century. The 135-meter chain carries this mystical symbol above the village. According to legend, knight de Blacas had it suspended in gratitude to the Virgin Mary after his release from the crusades.

The Earthenware Museum traces the history of this craft renowned throughout Europe. Over 300 exceptional pieces from the 17th and 18th centuries reveal the evolution of designs and techniques. The pharmacy goat signed by Clérissy in 1687 is the collection's jewel.

Earthenware workshops perpetuate centuries-old know-how. Seven workshops open their doors to visitors. Throwing, glazing and painting traditional bird motifs unfold before your eyes respecting ancestral methods.

The Notre-Dame de l'Assomption church displays its 12th-century Lombard bell tower. The Romanesque interior houses an altar carved from a 5th-century sarcophagus. 18th-century organs and gilded altarpieces enrich this historic monument.
Stroll through cobbled streets where the Riou torrent cascades. Fountains murmur at the corners of flowered squares. Ochre facades and vaulted passages compose a Provençal postcard scene.
Moustiers-Sainte-Marie — classified village, built between two cliffs, suspended star and tiered narrow streets.
Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Church and earthenware museum (centuries-old craftsmanship).
Moustiers-Sainte-Marie — village perched between two cliffs, famous for its suspended star and traditional earthenware.
Church of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption and stepped streets with fountains.
Moustiers-Sainte-Marie — village classified among the most beautiful in France, famous for its earthenware and its star suspended between two rocky peaks.
Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Church and medieval heritage in the heart of the village.
Earthenware museum — collection tracing five centuries of Provençal ceramic art.
Village of Moustiers-Sainte-Marie clinging to the cliff face, Provençal facades and streets
Climb to Notre-Dame de Beauvoir chapel on the cliff face
Earthenware museum tracing local craftsmanship
Faience workshops.

activities.text: The Valensole plateau unfolds its lavender fields as far as the eye can see from June to July. Purple rows undulate to the horizon in a fragrant ocean. Country roads cross this iconic landscape where lavandin blue contrasts with the Provençal sky.

Visit a traditional distillery where lavender essence is extracted. Copper stills transform freshly cut flowers into essential oil. The aroma fills stone buildings where bouquets once dried. Discover derivative products and natural cosmetics.

The Friday morning Provençal market brings Place Montelupo to life. Local producers offer goat cheeses, lavender honey, olives and olive oil. The colorful and fragrant atmosphere evokes authentic Provençal terroir.

Lac de Sainte-Croix extends its turquoise waters over 2200 hectares. Equipped beaches invite swimming in this artificial lake with lagoon-like appearance. Pedal boats, canoes and electric boats rental to explore the shores and the Verdon gorge entrance.
Ascent to Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir (stairway) and belvedere overlooking Lake Sainte-Croix.
Tour of earthenware workshops/boutiques and walk to the Rion waterfalls.
Visit to an earthenware workshop and artisan demonstration.
Hike to the chapel of Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir (panoramic view of Lake Sainte-Croix).
Hike to the Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir chapel for a view over the lake and the Verdon Gorges.
Discovery of earthenware workshops and shops (14 workshops and 22 stores).
Walk around the Rion waterfall or towards the Sainte-Madeleine cave.
Viewpoint of the star suspended above the village and the landscapes around the Verdon
Crafts.

visits.text: The Cité de l'Automobile houses the Schlumpf collection. Over 450 cars including six of the world's existing Bugatti Royales. Two are here.
The Schlumpf brothers—textile industrialists—secretly amassed these treasures in their Malmerspach factory for years. The gleaming chrome hall displays the dream cars of the 1930s.
The Cité du Train spreads across 60,000 square meters—Europe's largest railway museum. From 19th-century steam locomotives to TGVs, the epic story of French rail unfolds here.
The spectacle circuit recreates the golden age of rail travel. Animated figures, period music, and special effects bring 1900s mountain stations and platforms back to life.
Saint Stephen Temple raises the tallest Protestant spire in France at 97 meters. Its 19th-century stained glass windows illuminate the neo-Gothic nave.
Return to Mulhouse historic area

activities.text: Place de la Réunion concentrates Renaissance facades and the Town Hall with its trompe-l'oeil frescoes. The Reformed Temple dominates the cobbled square.
The Électropolis Museum traces the history of electricity. The 170-ton Sulzer-BBC machine powers up each day—it once supplied the DMC textile mill.
The Zoological and Botanical Park shelters 1,200 animals in 25 hectares of greenery. Madagascar lemurs, polar bears, and arctic wolves roam naturalistic habitats.
Additional exploration of local festive installations

days_plan.itin_title: Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route
The Ultimate Guide to Alsace Christmas Markets: Enchanted Winter Villages Itinerary

visits.text: Vosges valley center, tree-lined squares and major religious buildings.
Banks of the Fecht and landscaped parks.
Remains of the former abbey and historic quarter.
The Munster Valley unfolds at the foot of the Vosges Ballons. High mountain pastures feed Vosgienne cows whose milk produces the pungent, orange-rinded Munster AOP cheese.
The Cheese House traces every step of farmhouse Munster production. Watch the molding demonstration in the barn, then settle in for a commented tasting paired with local wine.

Grand Ballon rises to 1,424 meters—the highest peak in the Vosges massif. From the summit, views sweep across the Alsatian plain, the Black Forest, and on clear days, the Alps gleaming white on the horizon.
The Blue Devils Monument honors the alpine chasseurs who fell during the Great War. A white meteorological radar sphere adds a futuristic note to this somber memorial.
Eguisheim spirals in concentric circles around its octagonal 8th-century castle. Named France's Favorite Village in 2013 and classified among the Most Beautiful Villages in France.
Munster Christmas Market
Decorated town square and seasonal installations

activities.text: Park-to-park walk along the Fecht (3–4 km).
Gentle climb on a hillside path for an overview of the valley.
Mountain farm inns on Petit Ballon serve the traditional marcaire meal. Roïgebrageldi potatoes, fleischnacka meat rolls, warm Munster cheese melting on its plate, blueberry tart to finish.
The Route des Crêtes winds between Col de la Schlucht and Grand Ballon. Every hairpin bend reveals panoramic views over both the Alsatian and Lorraine slopes.
Climb to the ruins of the Three Castles that have watched over Eguisheim since the 11th century. The view plunges down across terraced vineyards to the Alsatian plain spreading below.
Attend choir performances and festive animations

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages
Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route
The Ultimate Guide to Alsace Christmas Markets: Enchanted Winter Villages Itinerary

visits.text: The village of Murat clings to the foot of the Rocher de Bonnevie, a spectacular basaltic spur crowned by a monumental statue of the Virgin. The medieval town preserves fine Renaissance houses and a Gothic church bearing witness to its prosperous past. The steep lanes offer ever-changing perspectives over the Cantal mountains.

The Viaduc de Garabit spans the Truyère gorges with its 565-metre reach, a metallic masterpiece by Gustave Eiffel completed in 1884. This red railway arch soars 122 metres above the reservoir lake in a setting of vertiginous gorges. Arranged viewpoints allow visitors to admire the boldness of this structure, a precursor to the Eiffel Tower.
Basalt town at the foot of the Bredons and Bonnevie rocks; stone slab houses and radiating alleyways.
Saint-Pierre de Bredons church perched, panorama over the Alagnon valley.
Place du Balat and medieval facades.

activities.text: The panoramas from the heights of Murat reveal the Margeride, a vast granitic plateau of rounded, wooded forms. This land of legends, theatre of the infamous Beast of Gévaudan, offers a striking contrast with the volcanic reliefs of the Cantal mountains. Viewpoints follow one another along the basaltic ridges.

The hike to the Puy de Chavaroche, nicknamed "the goat mountain", leads to 1,739 metres at the iconic summit crowned by an impressive "stone man" built from rocks stacked by hikers. The 360° panorama embraces the Mandailles cirque, the Puy Mary and the entire chain of puys in a grandiose setting.
Ascent to Bredons rock via paved path (2 km round trip).
Urban route of portals, shops and mascarons.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions

visits.text: Muret's old town preserves half-timbered houses and some medieval buildings. The 15th-century church of Saint-Jacques has a bell-gable typical of the Southwest.
The Battle of Muret in 1213 was decisive in the Albigensian Crusade. A memorial commemorates this event that marked the region's history. The site lies near the Garonne.

activities.text: The banks of the Garonne in Muret are landscaped for walking. It's a peaceful place to stroll along the river.
Tuesday and Saturday morning markets take place in the town center. You'll find products from the Toulouse region.

Saint-Michel Church of Cordes — southern Gothic nave and sculpted portal.
Najac — stroll through the medieval town among half-timbered houses and artisan shops.

activities.text: Royal Castle of Najac — climb to the keep and panorama over the Aveyron valley.
Saint-Jean Church of Najac — visit of the late Romanesque decoration.

days_plan.itin_title: Bastide Villages of France: Cliffside Abbeys & Medieval Fortified Towns

visits.text: Place Stanislas spans 106 by 124 meters, its UNESCO-listed ensemble framed by Jean Lamour's gilded wrought-iron gates and crowned by Neptune and Amphitrite fountains. Built in 1755, this architectural masterpiece connects the medieval old town to the planned new city.
Arc Héré bridges Place Stanislas and Place de la Carrière, its bas-reliefs celebrating Louis XV beneath the inscription 'Terror of enemies, architect of treaties.'
Place de la Carrière stretches 124 meters between two rows of trees. Emmanuel Héré unified its 18th-century facades to complete the UNESCO architectural ensemble.
The Musée des Beaux-Arts occupies one of the pavilions on Place Stanislas. Its collections showcase Old Masters, Rodin sculptures, and Lorraine artists from the 14th century to today.
The neo-Gothic spire of Basilique Saint-Epvre soars to 87 meters. Prosper Morey built it between 1864 and 1871 using Euville stone, with financial support from Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria.
Saint-Epvre's interior glows with over 70 stained glass windows created by Vienna's Geyling workshops. The windows total approximately 2,300 square meters of richly colored glass.

The Musée de l'École de Nancy occupies patron Eugène Corbin's former property. Its rooms display over 400 glass pieces by Émile Gallé, furniture by Louis Majorelle, and stained glass by Jacques Gruber.
The Masson dining room unites Eugène Vallin's woodwork, Victor Prouvé's painted ceiling, and Daum lighting fixtures in a harmonious Art Nouveau ensemble.
The museum garden cultivates peonies, anemones, and hydrangeas. An Art Nouveau aquarium pavilion houses Gruber's stained glass depicting underwater worlds.
Henri Sauvage designed Villa Majorelle in 1901 for furniture maker Louis Majorelle. Jean Lamour created the ironwork, Jacques Gruber the stained glass, and Alexandre Bigot the stoneware facade.
Villa Majorelle's interior displays nearly 100 pieces of furniture and decorative art. The woodwork, ironwork, and furniture are Louis Majorelle's own creations.

activities.text: Parc de la Pépinière spreads 21 hectares of greenery in Nancy's heart. Shaded walkways wind past a rose garden and a small zoo.
Walk Avenue Foch and Rue de la Commanderie to discover Art Nouveau facades with their organic curves and Majorelle ironwork flowing across the buildings.
Rue Saint-Jean brings together boutiques and cafés in the old town, where Renaissance buildings stand beside contemporary storefronts.
Wander through the Saurupt quarter, a garden city where Art Nouveau and Art Deco residences nestle among greenery.
Nancy's covered market has offered Lorraine products and regional specialties since 1851. Its metal halls host vendors Tuesday through Sunday mornings.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities
Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: Discovery of the Frasne peat bog and educational trail on wooden walkways.
Visit to the source of the Lison and the Sarrazine cave, spectacular natural sites.
Visit to the old taillanderie of Nans-sous-Sainte-Anne, historic hydraulic workshop.

activities.text: Observation of local wildlife: chamois and peregrine falcons around the cliffs.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs, France Natural Tour: Gorges, Waterfalls & Craft Heritage

visits.text: Fort Mont-Valérien, built in 1841, dominates Paris from 161 meters above sea level. Between 1941 and 1944, over 1,000 resistance fighters and hostages were executed here by Nazi firing squads.
The Mémorial de la France combattante, inaugurated by General de Gaulle on June 18, 1960, honors World War II victims. Sixteen bodies symbolize the different forms of French Resistance.
The Parcours du Souvenir retraces the condemned prisoners' final path. In the chapel, scratched graffiti bears witness to their last hours. The clearing preserves the execution posts.

activities.text: The Jacques Baumel departmental park-promenade circles the fort, offering panoramas of Nanterre, Rueil-Malmaison, Suresnes, Paris, and La Défense.
Suresnes American Cemetery gathers the graves of soldiers fallen during both World Wars. A wall of the missing inscribes their names.
Parc des Chenevreux, labeled an eco-garden, offers walking paths and community gardens with predominantly native flora.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: The Château des ducs de Bretagne houses 32 museum rooms chronicling the city's layered past. Walk the 15th-century granite ramparts, then step into the inner courtyard where white tuffeau stone facades glow against the weathered battlements.

The Grand Elephant towers 12 meters high, a mechanical giant that trumpets and sprays water from its articulated trunk. Climb aboard this walking marvel at Les Machines de l'Île and feel the deck sway as it lumbers along the quays.

Inside the Galerie des Machines, machinists bring giant mechanical spiders and caterpillars to life. Ride the Carrousel des Mondes Marins on mechanical jellyfish and octopuses that rise and dive through three spinning levels.

Built in 1843, the Passage Pommeraye cascades down three levels across a 9-meter drop. Monumental stairways, statue-candelabras, and sculpted glass canopies make this covered arcade a neoclassical masterpiece.
Lose yourself in the medieval maze of the Bouffay quarter. Half-timbered houses from the 1400s, cobbled lanes, and Renaissance facades line the Place du Pilori, where Nantes' oldest streets converge.

The Cathedral of Saint Peter and Saint Paul dominates the historic heart with its soaring Gothic nave. Don't miss the flamboyant portal and the intricate tomb of Duke François II carved in white marble.

activities.text: Follow the green line painted on the ground for Le Voyage à Nantes art trail. Contemporary installations, surprising viewpoints, and historic monuments unfold along this urban treasure hunt through the reimagined city.

Wander the Île de Nantes where old shipyards have been reborn as cultural spaces. The Hangar à Bananes stretches along the Loire, its industrial shell now home to galleries, restaurants, and riverside terraces.
Head up the Erdre by boat or bike. Called France's most beautiful river, it winds between châteaux and tree-shaded parks, offering a green escape just minutes from downtown.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire-Atlantique Road Trip: Nantes and the Jade Coast

visits.text: Nantua nestles along the shores of a glacial lake enclosed in a mountain cirque. The town developed around its Benedictine abbey founded in the 8th century. The lake, 2.7 kilometers long and 650 meters wide, offers enchanting landscapes with mountains reflected in calm waters. Nantua also played a crucial role during the Resistance, serving as a refuge for many maquis fighters.

The Abbey Church of Saint-Michel, rebuilt in the 19th century in neo-Romanesque style, stands out with its two asymmetrical bell towers. The interior houses an exceptional collection of religious art including a monumental wooden altarpiece and remarkable stained glass windows. The crypt preserves vestiges of the primitive abbey dating from the 8th century. The building's history intertwines with that of the town over twelve centuries.

The Resistance and Deportation Museum pays tribute to Bugey maquis fighters who fought Nazi occupation. The collections present period documents, weapons, personal objects, and moving testimonies. Reconstituted scenes recreate daily life of clandestine fighters in the mountains. A section is dedicated to local heroes deported to concentration camps. The visit, both educational and emotional, keeps alive the memory of these dark years.

Walk along the lake on the promenade offering spectacular views of surrounding mountains. The tree-lined path connects beaches, picnic areas, and belvederes. Lakeside cafés invite you to enjoy quenelles de Nantua, local specialty with crayfish sauce, while admiring the landscape. Children's play areas and pétanque courts attract families. The peaceful atmosphere and natural beauty make this walk a privileged moment.
Nantua nestles in a spectacular mountain pass, hemmed between vertiginous limestone cliffs and its emerald-green glacial lake.
Saint-Michel Abbey Church is the most important Romanesque building in the Ain department. Elder sister of Cluny, it preserves a Delacroix painting depicting the Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian.
Sculpted marble angels keep watch in the Romanesque and Gothic choir. The classified organ resounds during concerts that enliven the thousand-year-old nave.
The Museum of Resistance and Deportation bears witness to the commitment of the Ain maquis. This memorial honors the freedom fighters.
Stroll through the Pierre quarter where medieval shops line narrow alleyways. The Doye spring gushes forth right in the town center.
The Lâte Tower stands as the last remnant of the ramparts that once encircled the town. From its battlements, the view embraces the lake and cliffs.

activities.text: Taste the famous quenelles de Nantua, this pike dumpling topped with crayfish sauce that made the town's culinary reputation. Local restaurants all offer their version of this emblematic dish. The original recipe, jealously guarded, dates back several centuries. Some establishments open their kitchens to show preparation of this technical dish. The delicate texture and rich sauce delight fine palates.

Swim or practice water sports on the lake. The supervised beaches offer safe swimming in summer. Canoe, kayak, and paddleboard rentals allow exploration of hidden coves. Fishing enthusiasts can catch pike, perch, and trout. Pedalos invite families to gentle cruises while admiring mountain landscapes. The clear, fresh water delights swimmers.

Hike the Tour du Lac trail, an 8 km loop offering varied perspectives on water and mountains. The marked path alternates between lakeside sections and wooded passages. Belvederes reveal panoramic views of the cirque and town. The gentle slopes make this walk accessible to everyone. Picnic areas invite pauses to fully enjoy the landscape.

Visit during Fête du Lac in August, when the town celebrates summer with fireworks reflected in calm waters. The entire lakefront comes alive with stands, entertainment, and concerts. Local restaurants offer outdoor tasting menus. The festive atmosphere and spectacular fireworks attract thousands of visitors. The tradition, perpetuated for decades, marks the high point of the summer season.
The turquoise lake invites swimming, canoeing, and paddleboarding. The limpid waters reflect the limestone cliffs that frame it.
Taste authentic quenelles with Nantua sauce, a specialty born on the lake shores. Pike and red-clawed crayfish once made this recipe famous.
Each autumn, the Quenelle Festival celebrates this local specialty in a gourmet and festive atmosphere.
Pair your meal with a glass of Bugey-Cerdon, the sparkling rosé wine produced just a few kilometers away in neighboring hillsides.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: Cathedral of Saint-Just-et-Saint-Pasteur — 13th-century Gothic, left unfinished. The 4th tallest choir in France (41 m). Only the choir was built; the nave was never completed. Adjoining cloister.
Roman Horreum — Underground galleries from the 1st century BC, unique in France. 5 m below ground across 200 m². Narbonne was the first Roman colony outside Italy (118 BC).
Archbishops' Palace — Between the cathedral and city hall. Three medieval towers, Gothic halls, Passage de l'Ancre. Art and archaeology museums. Views from the Gilles-Aycelin keep.
Canal de la Robine — A branch of the UNESCO-listed Canal du Midi. The inhabited Pont des Marchands, quayside strolls, moored barges.
Narbonne Market Hall — Century-old covered market open every day. Fishmongers, charcutiers, cheesemongers. Tastings on the spot.

activities.text: Robine quayside stroll — From the Pont des Marchands to the Clape canal bridge. Terraces, barges, street artists in summer.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean

Hike to the Cirque de Navacelles and panorama from the Blandas belvedere.

activities.text: Swimming in the Vis waterfall.

days_plan.itin_title: Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages

visits.text: Navarrenx's ramparts form France's first purpose-built bastioned fortification, erected from 1538 onward. Their 1.5-kilometer circuit still protects the historic center in an intact Renaissance star pattern.
The Porte Saint-Antoine, inscribed on UNESCO's heritage list, marks the Compostela pilgrims' entrance. Its fortified bridge has spanned the Gave d'Oloron since the 16th century.
The Église Saint-Germain blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its 19th-century stained glass windows illuminate the restored nave with jewel-like colors.
Walk the chemin de ronde that crowns the ramparts. The corner bastions reveal Renaissance military architecture designed to withstand cannon fire.

activities.text: The Gave d'Oloron flows at the ramparts' foot. Salmon fishing and canoeing are practiced from April to October in these clear mountain waters.
Follow the Camino de Santiago that crosses through the bastide town. Pilgrims have rested at Navarrenx since the Middle Ages before tackling the mountains ahead.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Atlantiques Road Trip: Basque Country & Béarn

visits.text: Village of character at the gates of Cévennes National Park; clustered houses and cobbled streets.
Church and shaded squares, views over the valleys of Chassezac.
Remains of the enclosure and passages under arches.

activities.text: Discovery loop of the old town and nearby viewpoints (2–3 km).
Walk towards the faïsses and traditional terraced crops.

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: The Château-Musée de Nemours rises above the Loing River. Built in the late 12th century by Gauthier I de Villebéon, it's one of the rare medieval urban castles still standing in Île-de-France. Its rectangular keep is flanked by four corner turrets.
Climb the turret to discover the oratory, a Gothic architectural gem on two levels. The château houses 25,000 objects, from 19th-century paintings to antique prints.

The Saint-Jean-Baptiste Church, founded in 1170, was rebuilt after the 1358 fire during the Hundred Years' War. The choir dates from the 15th century. The stained glass windows and high altar were added in the 19th century.

The Prehistory Museum of Île-de-France occupies a building designed by Roland Simounet, classified as 20th-century heritage. The collections span 500,000 years of human history, from early hunters to Gallic metalworkers. A 9th-century Carolingian boat completes the tour.
Head to the banks of the Loing from the château. The picturesque streets of Nemours preserve the charm of an ancient town, with stone bridges and medieval facades.

activities.text: Extend your museum visit with the Nemours communal forest loop. This marked trail crosses a sea of sand, old quarries, and strangely shaped boulders.
Canoe down the Loing from Grez-sur-Loing to Moret-sur-Loing. The river winds between willows, meadows, and artists' villages.
The nearby village of Larchant deserves a detour for its spectacular Saint-Mathurin church ruins and the Dame Jouanne rock, one of the highest bouldering spots in the massif.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: The Château-musée Henri IV preserves the north wing of this Renaissance palace. Its gallery with twisted columns evokes the golden age of the d'Albret court in the 16th century.
Follow the Allée des 3000 Pas through the Parc de la Garenne. This 2.5-kilometer promenade created by Queen Margot winds beneath ancient oaks along the Baïse River.
Discover the park's Renaissance fountains: the Fontaine Saint-Jean, Fleurette's grotto, and the Fontaine du Dauphin erected in 1601.
In the Petit Nérac quarter, stroll Rue Séderie lined with half-timbered houses. The Vieux Pont offers lovely views of the old port and quays.
At Place du Général Leclerc, Henri IV's statue commemorates the future king of France's years here with Marguerite de Valois between 1577 and 1582.

activities.text: Follow in the footsteps of literary figures who frequented the court—Marguerite d'Angoulême welcomed Clément Marot and possibly Calvin himself.
Browse the market along the Allées d'Albret, where farmhouse cheeses, melons, and seasonal porcini mushrooms tempt food lovers.
Walk down to the navigable Baïse where pleasure boats moor in poetic tranquility.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: The thermal baths of Néris perpetuate 2000-year-old Gallo-Roman tradition. Ancient thermal springs called "Aquae Nerii" attracted Romans seeking benefits of mineral waters. Current modern facilities treat rheumatism, osteoarthritis and anxiety disorders. The Belle Époque architecture preserves spa resort charm from early 20th century.

The archaeological site reveals Gallo-Roman thermal baths and ancient sanctuary remains. Educational panels explain Roman bathing practices and daily life in ancient spa resort. Excavated vestiges testify to thermal installation importance in antiquity. Free access allows discovering this historical heritage.

The thermal park extends 50 hectares of English gardens around spa facilities. Paths wind among century-old trees, flowerbeds and ponds. The landscaped setting invites strolling and relaxation in green environment. Bandstand and kiosks host summer concerts and events.

The thermal quarter reveals Belle Époque architecture with hotels and villas from early 20th century. Bourgeois facades, balconies and ornate ironwork testify to spa resort splendor. Rue de la République and surrounding streets concentrate period buildings creating nostalgic atmosphere.

activities.text: The Néris casino offers games, slot machines and evening shows in Belle Époque setting. This leisure establishment perpetuates spa resort festive tradition attracting visitors seeking entertainment. Restaurant and bar complete the offer for convivial evening.

Walk around Néris lake discovering beach, nautical base and picnic areas. Water activities include pedal boats, canoes and swimming in summer. Paths around lake offer family strolls in nature close to town center.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: Fortified town with octagonal plan designed under Louis XIV, bastions and monumental gates.
Orthogonal central street and regular alignments.
Ramparts and glacis offering views over the Rhine and the plain.
Neuf-Brisach draws a perfect eight-pointed star across the Alsatian plain. Built from scratch in 1698 by Vauban after the loss of Alt-Breisach, it embodies his third defensive system.
Place d'Armes occupies the geometric center of the octagon. Louis XIV personally selected this design from three proposals Vauban submitted. The fountain served as a fire reserve.
The Vauban Museum installed in the Belfort Gate traces the fortified town's construction. Scale models, original plans, and period accounts explain the military engineer's genius.
The Royal Church of Saint Louis, built in 1731, expresses the sober classical style of 18th-century France. Its clean lines survived American bombing in 1945.
The fortifications extend 2.4 kilometers of ramparts accessible from four gates. Ravelins, counter-guards, and bastions succeed one another in the moats.

activities.text: Complete tour of the ramparts on developed walkway (5–6 km, flat).
Reading of the star-shaped plan from an exterior viewpoint.
Walk the sentry path that makes a complete circuit of the enceinte. Contemporary art installations punctuate the route between military structures.
A period-costumed guide recounts Neuf-Brisach's history. Vauban, his wife, and other characters resurrect Louis XIV's grand ambitions for this border fortress.
Soar above the citadel in an ultralight to grasp the geometric perfection of the octagonal plan. Forty-eight blocks organize around the central square like a spider's web.

visits.text: The Île de la Jatte stretches two kilometers between Neuilly and Levallois, once home to the Château de Neuilly where King Louis-Philippe resided. Square Jatte preserves a charming Temple of Love pavilion originally from Parc Monceau.

Georges Seurat immortalized this island in his masterpiece A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte. Monet, Sisley, and Van Gogh also painted these bucolic riverbanks dotted with riverside cafés.
The 19th-century Saint-Pierre church towers over the residential quarter, its spire rising above tree-lined avenues bordered by elegant Haussmannian buildings.

activities.text: Parc de l'Île de la Jatte occupies the island's northern tip. Discover the educational apiary, peaceful gardens, and Seine embankments where barges and rowing sculls glide past.
The Bois de Boulogne unfolds across 850 hectares south of Neuilly. Once the royal hunting grounds, it shelters the Parc de Bagatelle and Jardin d'Acclimatation.
The Fondation Louis Vuitton, designed by Frank Gehry, showcases breathtaking architecture. Its glass sails evoke ships catching wind and light.

visits.text: The Promenade des Anglais stretches 7 kilometers along the Bay of Angels, lined with Belle Époque palaces with pink domes and iconic blue chairs.
Lose yourself in Old Nice: laundry hangs from windows, green shutters clatter against ochre and yellow facades, cool alleyways wind toward secret squares.
The Palais Lascaris reveals its 17th-century Baroque treasures: sumptuous frescoes, gilded woodwork, and a rare collection of ancient musical instruments.
Admire the Sainte-Réparate Cathedral on Place Rossetti, a Baroque jewel of Nice where gilding rivals polychrome marbles.
Climb Castle Hill by staircase or free elevator: a wooded park overlooks the city, a waterfall murmurs, and the view embraces the Bay of Angels all the way to the Alps.
Colorful fishing boats dance on the waters of Port Lympia while red and yellow facades reflect in the basin, between luxury yachts and fishermen's nets.
Discover Place Garibaldi, unique in Europe: its four yellow arcaded facades create a Piedmontese trompe-l'oeil theater.
On Cimiez Hill, Roman arenas sleep beneath century-old olive trees. The Matisse Museum watches from its red villa, the Franciscan monastery offers its peaceful gardens.
Place Masséna: esplanade, light sculptures, perspective on avenue Jean-Médecin.
Promenade du Paillon (Green Belt): water mirror, games and sculptures, shade in the city center.
Place Garibaldi: trompe-l'œil facades and historic arcades.
Vieux-Nice: narrow streets, squares, Cours Saleya market, shops and craftsmen.
Sainte-Réparate Cathedral (Vieux-Nice): Nice baroque interior.

Villefranche-sur-Mer: old town, port and churches (Saint-Michel, Jean Cocteau chapel).
Marinières Beach (Villefranche): large sheltered cove, clear water.
Èze-Village: perched medieval village, cobbled streets and stone houses.
Exotic Garden of Èze: cacti, viewpoints over the Mediterranean.

Cap-Ferrat trail: Passable beach → Paloma beach along the coast.
Roquebrune-Cap-Martin: medieval village, narrow streets and castle.
Cap d'Ail: coastal trail and coves (including Mala beach).
Tête de Chien (La Turbie): viewpoint over Monaco and the coast.
Haut-de-Cagnes (Cagnes-sur-Mer): hilltop village, Grimaldi castle and artists' alleyways.
Biot: old center and Verrerie de Biot (contemporary glass).
Saint-Paul-de-Vence: ramparts, galleries and viewpoints over the valley.
Tourrettes-sur-Loup: fortified town, Grand'Rue, squares and fountains.
Gorges du Loup: viewpoints and Cascades du Saut du Loup.
Gilette: Pont de la Cerise and Estéron valley (riverside walk).
Promenade des Anglais and Old Nice (warm-up after flight)

activities.text: Stroll along Cours Saleya where flower market stalls explode with colors every morning, giving way to antique dealers on Mondays.
The Promenade du Paillon crosses the city as a green corridor: children run through the water mirror, palm trees shade benches all the way to the Modern Art Museum.
Cross Place Masséna with its checkered floor, surrounded by bright red buildings, gateway to the shops of Avenue Jean Médecin.
The colorful domes of Saint Nicholas Orthodox Cathedral emerge behind the station: the icon-adorned interior testifies to Nice's Russian community.
Spread your towel on the pebbles of the Promenade des Anglais and dive into the turquoise waters of the Mediterranean.
Taste Niçoise cuisine: golden socca crackles on the plate, pissaladière melts in your mouth, Swiss chard pie plays sweet and savory.
Panorama from Colline du Château (access on foot or by elevator).
Supervised swimming on Nice beach (depending on season and weather).
Sports walk (running/roller/bike) on the Promenade des Anglais.
Swimming at Marinières beach (Villefranche).

Photo stops and short trails along the Gorges du Loup.

visits.text: Arènes de Nîmes and ancient layout of the Roman city.
Maison Carrée and ancient forum reinterpreted by modern squares.
Tour Magne and jardins de la Fontaine at the foot of the sacred spring.

Arènes de Nîmes, one of the world's best-preserved Roman amphitheaters at 433 feet long and 69 feet high. Built in the 1st century AD, it held 24,000 spectators who came to watch gladiatorial combat. The two-tiered exterior arcade in honey-colored Vers-Pont-du-Gard stone demonstrates Roman engineering mastery. The free audioguide in seven languages recreates the atmosphere of ancient games. Today the monument hosts bullfights, concerts, and historical reenactments including the Roman Days of Nîmes each late April.

Maison Carrée, a 1st-century BC Roman temple inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2023. The Corinthian facade with 30 fluted columns illustrates the harmony of classical proportions. It's the only completely preserved ancient temple from the entire Roman world. Innovative museography with immersive projection "Nemausus, the Birth of Nîmes" traces 2,000 years of history on the interior walls. The building successively served as a consular house, church, prefecture, and departmental archives.

Tour Magne, remnant of Roman ramparts dominating Nîmes from atop Mont Cavalier at 105 feet high. Built under Augustus, it marked the northwestern corner of fortified walls that stretched nearly four miles. Climbing the 140 steps leads to a panoramic platform offering 360° views over the city, garrigue scrubland, and on clear days, Mont Ventoux and the Cévennes mountains. The octagonal tower integrated into the most imposing defensive system in Roman Gaul.

Jardins de la Fontaine, an 18th-century public park designed around the sacred spring that gave birth to Nemausus. Majestic tree-lined pathways bordered by balustrades and neoclassical statues follow a monumental perspective inspired by Versailles. The Temple of Diana, a mysterious Roman sanctuary with collapsed arcades, stands at the garden's heart. Terraced pools capture spring waters while staircases climb toward Mont Cavalier and Tour Magne. In summer, the garden becomes a cool refuge beneath centuries-old plane trees.

Musée de la Romanité, contemporary building opened in 2018 facing the Arena. The pleated glass facade reflects the amphitheater, creating dialogue between ancient heritage and modern architecture. The 5,000 pieces displayed across 37,500 square feet trace 25 centuries of history from Nemausus to Nîmes: exceptional mosaics, statues, everyday objects, augmented reality reconstructions. The multimedia immersive experience uses interactive technologies and monumental projections. The panoramic rooftop overlooks the city's roofs and Roman arena.

Nîmes Old Town, medieval historic center with winding streets lined by Renaissance facades and private mansions. Notre-Dame-et-Saint-Castor Cathedral combines Romanesque and Gothic styles with its sculpted frieze depicting the Old Testament. Shaded small squares shelter café terraces and artisan shops. The 19th-century central market halls offer Provençal products: olives, tapenades, Costières de Nîmes wines, brandade. The southern atmosphere comes alive at daily markets in a colorful, fragrant ambiance.
Visit to the Arena of Nîmes, a remarkably well-preserved Roman amphitheater.
Discovery of the Maison Carrée and the Museum of Romanity.
Nîmes Arena: discovery of the Roman amphitheater and panorama over the city.
Maison Carrée and Carré d'Art: Roman temple and contemporary architecture face to face.
Gardens of the Fountain and Tour Magne: historical walk to the belvedere.
Visit to the arenas of Nîmes and the Maison Carrée.
Discovery of Pont du Gard and swimming in the river.

activities.text: Ancient route linking Arènes, Maison Carrée and Jardins (2–3 km).
Ascent to Tour Magne for panorama over the Nîmes plain.

Experience the Nîmes Férias, major bullfighting events in May (Pentecost) and September. For five days, corridas in the arena, lively bodegas, musical peñas, free concerts, and marching bands invade downtown. Aficionados in white outfits stroll from bar to bar in a festive, convivial atmosphere. Abrivados and bandidos see Camargue bulls running through the streets. Goyesque corridas feature bullfighters in period costumes. The electric atmosphere celebrates Camargue and Spanish bullfighting culture.

Taste brandade de Nîmes at a traditional restaurant in the historic center. This specialty made from desalted cod, milk, olive oil, and garlic is served hot with croutons. Family establishments perpetuate ancestral recipes passed down since the 18th century. Brandade houses also offer versions with truffles or gratinéed. This emblematic Nîmes dish pairs with white Costières wine or chilled rosé.

Wander through Nîmes' Provençal markets, particularly the one on Boulevard Jean-Jaurès Monday and Friday mornings. Stalls overflow with Gard fruits and vegetables, Pélardon AOC goat cheese, artisanal charcuterie, honey, seasonal fruits. Local producers sell garrigue honey, homemade jams, aromatic plants. The lively atmosphere resonates with southern accents and spirited haggling. Aromas of rotisseries, socca, and paella float between the aisles.
Stroll through the Jardins de la Fontaine and climb the Tour Magne for the view over the city.
Guided walk in the old center of Nîmes (pedestrian streets, private mansions).
Introduction to Roman archaeology at the Museum of Romanity (permanent exhibition).
Walk in the old town of Aigues-Mortes and on its ramparts.

visits.text: The twin towers of the Keep rise 28 meters above the Sèvre Niortaise River. Listed as a historic monument since 1840, it's one of the finest Romanesque keeps in France.
Climb the spiral staircase to the terrace to contemplate the green expanses of the Marais Poitevin.
The refectory hall displays sculpted capitals and traditional Poitevin furniture with its elevated beds.
The museum presents the ethnographic collection and graffiti of English sailors imprisoned in the 18th century.
Walk along the banks of the Sèvre Niortaise to the Épona space where remains of the ancient sanctuary of Port Boinot are exhibited.

activities.text: Stroll through the historic quarter between market halls and sculpted dragons that animate the city center.
The Bernard d'Agesci Museum brings together fine arts, decorative arts, and natural history collections in a grand cabinet of curiosities.

days_plan.itin_title: Deux-Sèvres Circuit: Marais Poitevin and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: The Cutlery Museum occupies a former blade-making workshop founded in 1725. Over 8,000 pieces chronicle this craft's evolution from the 18th century to present day.

Collections showcase folding knives with intricate mechanisms, Nicolas Pierre Pelletier's embroidery scissors, the Garnier brothers' zeppelin knife inspired by the airship that crashed here in 1917, and surgical instruments of remarkable precision.

The Nogent cutlery basin extends across 20 kilometers. Seven major categories divide production: folding knives, table cutlery, professional tools, shears, specialized implements, surgical instruments, and grooming accessories.
The old town preserves several historic houses and cobbled lanes. The Marne riverbanks invite leisurely strolls along the water's edge.

activities.text: Follow the Route des Vallées Coutelières (Cutlery Valley Route). This circuit introduces you to workshops and artisans perpetuating Nogent's blade-making traditions.
Browse the museum shop's offerings. Handcrafted knives, scissors, and cutlery items manufactured locally make distinctive souvenirs.
Visit the Friday morning market. Haute-Marne regional produce and local specialties bring the town square to life.

Cinematographic heritage.

days_plan.itin_title: Val-de-Marne, France: A Road Trip to Pleasure Gardens & Historic Lakeside Châteaux

visits.text: The Passage du Gois, a 2.6-mile submersible causeway unique in the world, links the mainland to Noirmoutier. Cross it at low tide by car or on foot—check tide tables before you set out.
Noirmoutier Castle, a 12th-century fortress built by the lords of La Garnache, dominates the town center. Climb to the top of the keep for commanding views over the island.

Saint-Philbert Church rests on the foundations of a Benedictine abbey founded around 674 CE. The crypt preserves the empty tomb of the saint, whose relics were moved to Tournus during Norman invasions.

Wander the flower-draped lanes of the Banzeau quarter, one of the island's oldest neighborhoods. Whitewashed houses with bright shutters, hollyhocks, and climbing vines compose a scene quintessentially Noirmoutrin.
Stroll through the Bois de la Chaise: maritime pines, holm oaks, and strawberry trees lead down to Plage des Dames and its iconic white beach huts.
Walk the Jetée Jacobsen at the heritage harbor. To your left, the Müllembourg nature reserve and its salt marshes; to your right, sailboats and a small boat graveyard.

activities.text: Join a salt worker to learn the ancient harvest. Salt marshes cover a third of the island, and centuries-old techniques transform seawater into coarse salt and delicate fleur de sel.
Set off by bike on the island's cycle paths, linking all four communes: Barbâtre, La Guérinière, L'Épine, and Noirmoutier-en-l'Île.
Pull on your wellies for a session of shellfish gathering at spring tides. Periwinkles, cockles, and clams await on the beaches of the Gois and Mardi Gras.
Discover the village of Le Vieil, a former fishing hamlet of whitewashed houses with their feet in the water. Its narrow alleys and quiet coves offer total escape.

visits.text: Tower of Nonza — Guardian & chains.
