days_plan.itin_title: A Road Trip Through the Somme Valley: Cathedrals, History & River Landscapes

visits.text: Pierrefonds: neo-medieval castle & Compiègne forest.

The Château de Pierrefonds rises from a medieval fortress built between 1397 and 1407 for Louis d'Orléans. After Cardinal Richelieu ordered its demolition in 1617, Viollet-le-Duc rebuilt it between 1857 and 1885 for Napoleon III.

Viollet-le-Duc applied his controversial restoration philosophy here: to establish the building in a complete state that may never have existed. This Romantic reinvention of the Middle Ages employed 19th-century construction techniques.
The Hall of the Nine Female Worthies stretches 52 meters long and 12 meters high. This former medieval hall of justice displays Second Empire grandeur through neo-Gothic decoration.
The Keep houses the Caesar and Charlemagne towers. In the lord's chamber, a frieze chronicles a knight's life from childhood to death.
The Chapel conceals modern architecture beneath a sculpted porch. The guards' tribune overlooks the choir, where a pilgrim statue bearing Viollet-le-Duc's features was sculpted by Hiolin in 1884.

activities.text: Loops on the edge, lake & village.
Explore the courtyard of honor among fantastic sculptures and salamander-shaped gargoyles. Medieval bestiary and 19th-century innovations merge in this theatrical setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-France: Opal Coast Cliffs, Medieval History & Great War Sites
Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: Pigna perches at 400 meters elevation overlooking the Balagne valley. The quintessential artisan village, its lanes reveal workshops of potters, glass blowers, luthiers, and sculptors. The Casa Musicale perpetuates the tradition of Corsican polyphonic singing and hosts concerts and workshops.

Sant'Antonino crowns its peak at 500 meters, one of Corsica's oldest villages. Classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages, its granite houses spiral around the rocky pinnacle. Vaulted lanes and covered passages create a medieval labyrinth. 360-degree panorama over Balagne and the sea.

Corbara terraces its ochre houses between olive groves and vineyards. The 19th-century Convent of Saint-Dominique dominates the village. The baroque Church of the Annunciation preserves paintings and sculptures. The terraces offer plunging views of the sea and L'Île-Rousse.

activities.text: The Balagne artisan route winds through Pigna, Corbara, Lumio, and Sant'Antonino. Workshops open to visitors offer demonstrations of ancestral techniques: pottery, ceramics, lutherie, woodworking. A hilltop village atmosphere far from mass tourism.

Polyphonic music concerts are organized at the Casa Musicale in Pigna. Male voices a cappella interpreting traditional Corsican repertoire. Reservations recommended for summer evening performances. Intimate atmosphere beneath stone vaults.

Panoramic hikes depart from the villages toward the Balagne ridges. Marked trails crossing maquis and century-old olive groves. Sea views at every turn. Easy to moderate difficulty depending on chosen routes.

days_plan.itin_title: Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Piriac's harbor shelters working trawlers and pleasure boats in equal measure. White houses with blue shutters frame the basin where lobster traps and fishing nets pile high on the granite quays.
The Church of Notre-Dame raises its square bell tower above the sea. Inside, sailors' ex-votos and suspended ship models bear witness to centuries of fishing tradition and answered prayers.
The Pointe du Castelli offers sweeping views along the wild coast. Jagged rocks, hidden coves, and granite needles compose an authentically Breton seascape untouched by resort development.

activities.text: Follow the coastal path to the Mine d'Or beach. Ochre cliffs, sea caves, and remnants of old mining operations punctuate this dramatic walk along the rugged shoreline.
Sample fish and shellfish right on the docks. Fishermen sell their morning catch directly from their boats—as fresh as it gets, with the Atlantic rolling just meters away.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire-Atlantique Road Trip: Nantes and the Jade Coast

visits.text: Lac au Duc covers 620 acres. One of Brittany's largest bodies of water. Created in the 12th century by Benedictine monks who dammed the Yvel River to power their mills.
The Hydrangea Trail winds 2 miles through woodland. Over 5,000 hydrangeas of numerous varieties. Remarkable botanical collection. Blooming from June through September.
Saint-Armel Church preserves Gothic architecture. The carved portal dates from the 15th century. Colorful stained glass and baroque furnishings.
The astronomical clock of Ploërmel stands in the town hall square. Complex mechanism indicating lunar phases, tides, and planetary positions.
Half-timbered houses line the cobbled streets of the historic center. Place du Roi Arthur and Rue Beaumanoir concentrate the medieval façades.

activities.text: Walk around Lac au Duc. 8.5 miles of developed trail. Watch for otters, roe deer, and gray herons in the wetland areas.
The Ploërmel Brocéliande water sports club rents windsurfers, dinghies, catamarans, canoes, kayaks, and stand-up paddleboards. Water skiing and wakeboarding by reservation.
The Lac au Duc golf course offers 9 holes on the shoreline. Technical course between lake and forest. Equipment rental available.
The V3 greenway connects Mauron to Questembert for 33 miles. Old railway line developed for cyclists, walkers, and horseback riders. Crosses the Ploërmel area and skirts the lake.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: Battle Museum (Czechoslovakia 1918).
Thermal baths.
Imperial park.

The Thermes Napoléon rises with its Second Empire façade at the heart of town. Inside, an 18-meter vaulted ceiling crowns a 65-meter stone corridor bathed in light. The entire ensemble is listed as a Historic Monument.

Descend to the Bains Romains, Gallo-Roman remains from the 1st century. Roman legions captured the hot springs here by diverting the Augronne river and pouring a concrete foundation pierced with chimneys to channel the water upward.
The Pavillon des Princes, a sober 18th-century building, hosted a meeting that changed history: the 1858 interview that decided Italy's fate.
The Saint-Amé church blends flamboyant neo-Gothic with imperial heritage: its spire bears the crown of the Empire. It's listed as a Historic Monument.
Step into the museum dedicated to the landscape painter born here in 1817, a figure of the Barbizon School. Canvases, sketches and views of the Vosges valley compose the collection.

Plombières is nicknamed the "city of a thousand balconies": wrought iron, molded cast iron or wooden balconies adorn 19th-century façades. A marked circuit leads from alley to stairway through these architectural treasures.

activities.text: Vosges Saône.
Princes' Pavilion.
Augronne Valley.
Climb to the Jardins en Terrasses, the town's "1001st balcony." Pools, sculptures and rare species punctuate the ascent to the panorama over the Augronne valley.
Stroll through the Parc Impérial, a green haven laid out during the Second Empire. The Stanislas Fountain, adorned with baroque motifs, marks the park entrance.
Taste the Plombières ice cream, a dessert born during the 1858 Interview: a blend of candied fruit and cream that became a local pride.
Follow the Coteau de la Vierge trail for a viewpoint overlooking the spa town and the rooftops of old Plombières.

days_plan.itin_title: Vosges Mountains, France: Alpine Lakes, Spa Towns and Forest Heritage
Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: The monumental calvary of Plougastel-Daoulas, erected between 1602 and 1604, counts 181 figures sculpted in kersanton stone. Built to celebrate the end of a plague epidemic, it's one of Brittany's three great calvaries with those of Guimiliau and Plougonven.

Scenes of Christ's Passion, arranged in continuous frieze around the base, blend biblical figures and 17th-century Breton costumes. Look for the Roman soldier dressed as a Breton gentleman - a deliberate anachronism.

The Strawberry and Heritage Museum traces the history of this cultivation that made the peninsula's fortune in the 19th century. Strawberry plants were imported from Chile in 1714 by a naval officer, and Plougastel strawberries became an export product.
Sainte-Christine chapel (16th century), set by the sea on Tinduff beach, is accessible only at low tide. Its miniature parish enclosure includes calvary, ossuary, and devotional fountain.
Pointe de l'Armorique, at the peninsula's tip, offers a panorama over Brest harbor, the Albert-Louppe bridge, and military vessels at anchor. An orientation table identifies landmarks.

activities.text: Hike the peninsula's coastal path, between Anse de l'Auberlac'h and Pointe de l'Armorique. The trail alternates coves, pebble beaches, and viewpoints over Brest harbor.
Visit strawberry orchards (in season, May to July). Some farms offer pick-your-own - Plougastel's heritage varieties have an incomparable fragrance.
Visit Daoulas Abbey (5 min drive). Its 12th-century Romanesque cloister, the only one preserved in Brittany, houses a medicinal plant garden from five continents.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Ploumanac'h's granite chaos displays pink granite blocks sculpted by 300 million years of erosion. Some bear nicknames: Napoleon's Hat, the Turtle, the Die, the Upturned Bottle. Each weighs between 50 and 500 tons.
The Mean Ruz lighthouse (1945), in pink granite, replaces a 19th-century semaphore destroyed during World War II. Its color blends with surrounding rocks - you must search the chaos to find it.

Saint-Guirec beach, a fine sand cove framed by pink rocks, shelters an 11th-century oratory on the foreshore. According to tradition, unmarried girls stuck a needle in the saint statue's nose to find a husband within the year.

Costaérès castle, built in 1892 on a rocky islet, is the iconic image of the Pink Granite Coast. Accessible only at low tide, it served as a summer residence for a Polish engineer passionate about literature.
The Coastal House explains pink granite geology: formed 300 million years ago at 6 km depth, it owes its color to iron-rich feldspars. Only three sites worldwide present granite of this hue.

activities.text: Walk the customs officers' path from Ploumanac'h to Perros-Guirec. The trail winds between pink granite blocks, gorse moors, and turquoise coves. It's one of the GR34's most spectacular sections.
Embark for the Sept-Îles, France's largest bird sanctuary. Northern gannets (France's only colony), puffins, guillemots, and gray seals populate this protected archipelago.
At sunset, pink granite turns orange then purple. Best viewpoint: the path between Saint-Guirec beach and Mean Ruz lighthouse.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Villa Savoye, inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2016, embodies Le Corbusier's five points of modern architecture: pilotis, roof terrace, free plan, ribbon windows, and free façade. Built between 1928 and 1931, it appears to float above the lawn.

The Collégiale Notre-Dame de Poissy, built in the 12th century, blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its baptismal font is where Saint Louis was christened in 1214. Two octagonal towers crown the transept.
Step into the Toy Museum, housed in the 14th-century royal priory gatehouse. Over 600 toys and games from 1850 to 1950 tell the story of childhood across the ages.
Parc Meissonier offers a manicured rose garden and a curiosity: the Maison de Fer, a 19th-century prefabricated metal structure witnessing the dawn of industrial architecture.

activities.text: Walk along the Seine riverbanks in Poissy: the towpath connects downtown to Île de la Dérivation, perfect for a picnic or nature break.
Explore Poissy's old town on foot to spot medieval façades and narrow streets surrounding the collégiale.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

visits.text: The façade of Notre-Dame-la-Grande displays one of the richest 12th-century sculptural programs in Poitou. Prophets, apostles, and biblical scenes cover the stone across two tiers. Inside, restored Romanesque frescoes drape the vaults in vibrant colors.

Step into the Saint-Jean Baptistery, one of France's oldest preserved Christian buildings. Built in the 4th century, it houses an octagonal baptismal font, Merovingian sarcophagi, and Romanesque wall paintings.

The Palace of the Counts of Poitou, residence of the Dukes of Aquitaine, preserves a Great Hall in Angevin Gothic style, rebuilt around 1200 by the Plantagenets. The Maubergeon Tower offers sweeping views over the old town.

Saint-Pierre Cathedral, commissioned by Eleanor of Aquitaine from 1160 onward, blends Angevin Gothic with influences from the Île-de-France. Marvel at the 12th-century Crucifixion window—one of Europe's largest Romanesque stained-glass panels—and the 13th-century choir stalls, the oldest in the country.

Listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site on the Routes to Santiago de Compostela, Saint-Hilaire-le-Grand Church is dedicated to Poitiers' first attested bishop, who died around 367. Its Romanesque murals and carved capitals are well worth exploring.
The Sainte-Croix Museum brings together collections spanning from prehistory to the 20th century. You'll find medieval sculptures, Gallo-Roman artifacts, and works by Camille Claudel.

Futuroscope offers over 40 immersive attractions just 10 km north of Poitiers. The Extraordinary Voyage, voted Europe's best attraction, sends you soaring above five continents with your feet dangling in the void. Tornado Hunters features Europe's largest circular LED screen.

activities.text: Wander through the medieval lanes of the historic center. Half-timbered houses, Hôtel Fumé, and Hôtel Berthelot bear witness to the rich past of this city of a hundred bell towers.
Stroll through Parc de Blossac, 10 hectares of greenery designed as a French formal garden, English landscape garden, and rocky garden. Clear views over the Clain Valley.
Catch Futuroscope's nighttime spectacular, "La Clé des Songes," a show combining water projections, flames, and dazzling lights.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Polignac Fortress rises from a 3-hectare basalt platform at 2,644 feet elevation. The 14th-century keep soars 105 feet high, commanding a 360° panorama across the Puy basin and the Meygal and Mézenc massifs.
Follow the 14-stop circuit through the ruins: half a mile of ramparts, 6 fortified gates, the armory hall, a vertiginous 274-foot-deep well, and the medieval-inspired garden.
On the keep's ground floor, the mask of Apollo testifies to an ancient Roman temple. Pilgrims once consulted an oracle here—a priest hidden behind the mask dictating prophecies.
Step inside Saint-Martin Church, a Romanesque jewel classified as a Historic Monument since 1902. The choir shelters 14th-century frescoes depicting the Last Judgment, paradise, and hell.

In the south apsidiole, 15th-century paintings illustrate the Annunciation, the Visitation, and the Nativity. Notice the polychrome statue of Saint Anne from the 13th century, typical of medieval folk art.

The village counts over 100 rural heritage features scattered across twenty hamlets: crosses, fountains, bread ovens, and wash houses. The one at Bilhac preserves a cross inscribed as a Historic Monument since 1930.

activities.text: Climb to the top of the keep to embrace the Velay volcanoes. On clear days, the view reaches all the way to the Chaîne des Puys.
Follow the Pinatelle du Zouave trail winding around the basalt dike. The walk reveals the volcanic geology of this site, over 2.5 million years old.
Wander the lanes of this village labeled one of France's Most Beautiful Villages. Houses built from volcanic breccia and lava stone fountains punctuate your stroll.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Tufa waterfalls.
Grande Saline (UNESCO).
Saline Royale (UNESCO).
Ledoux Museum.

activities.text: Yellow wine tasting.
Panorama over the vineyard.
Hiking in the reculée.

days_plan.itin_title: Jura Mountains Road Trip, France: Comtois Traditions & Emerald Lakes

visits.text: Pompadour Castle. Fortress rebuilt in the 15th century by the Hélie family. In 1745, Louis XV bought the estate and gave it with the title of Marquise to his favorite Jeanne-Antoinette Poisson - who never visited it, deeming the property too far from the Court! She resold it in 1761. The following year, Louis XV bought it back and transformed it into a Royal Stud Farm. Tour of 11 rooms including the library, with furniture, Aubusson tapestries and Limoges porcelain.
Marquise Stables and Orangery. House the National Stud horses. The Orangery hosts equestrian shows in summer.

Chignac Estate Stud Farm. France's only national stud farm, birthplace of the Anglo-Arab breed created in Pompadour in the 19th century. You can see foals being born and growing (present from March to October). Visit to discover breeding and selection methods.

activities.text: Horse racing at the racecourse. Classified 1st category for steeplechase and 2nd category A for flat racing, it's one of the most beautiful racecourses in France with its 2000-meter natural sand track facing the castle. 11 race days per year in summer.

Equestrian shows at the castle. In July-August, equestrian cabarets are organized in the evening on the castle terraces or in the Orangery riding hall. The company "Christophe et Max Hasta Luego" notably offers internationally renowned shows.
Horse Festival - August 15th. Major annual event: Saint Hubert mass at the racecourse, show jumping competition, horse races, demonstrations and equestrian shows.
Limousin Apple Route. Pompadour is also the starting point of this route that crosses the PDO Limousin Apple orchards. Farm visits possible in summer.

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley

visits.text: Abbaye des Prémontrés presents its classical 18th-century facade along the Moselle. Built between 1705 and 1735, it was bombed in 1944 then restored until 1974.
The Sainte-Marie-Majeure abbey church follows a hall church plan. The grand staircase and library rank among the jewels of this listed monument.
The abbey gardens cover 2.5 hectares. The Scent Garden, the French garden, and the Moselle garden offer three distinct atmospheres.
Triangular Place Duroc features Renaissance arcades around its entire perimeter. It's one of the largest arcade ensembles still visible in Lorraine.
Église Saint-Martin, consecrated in 1335, blends 14th and 15th-century styles. The Entombment of Christ required four years of restoration.

activities.text: The Musée Au Fil du Papier traces the town's history since the founding of the University of Lorraine in 1572. Its collection of papier-mâché objects reflects Belle Époque style.
Drive 10 minutes to climb the Mousson hill. The castle ruins offer valley views.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: Pont-Audemer, the Norman Venice. Crisscrossed by Risle canals, this former tanners' city has retained its medieval charm. Classified among France's Most Beautiful Detours and labeled a City of Art and History, it reveals its treasures along the water: 15th and 16th-century half-timbered houses, old skin-drying sheds, private mansions, and small stone bridges.

Saint-Ouen Church of Pont-Audemer. This imposing church blending Romanesque, Gothic, and Renaissance styles impresses with its 15th and 16th-century stained glass windows and remarkable organ case. The building dominates the town from the main street.

Ruisseau des Pâtissiers and Ruisseau des Carmes. These canals crisscrossing the old town bear names evocative of local history. Views from the small bridges strangely recall Venice, with reflections of colorful facades in the water.
Alfred Canel Museum. Housed in the former home of the historian and politician, this cabinet of curiosities presents local history collections, antique library holdings, and temporary exhibitions.
Pont-Audemer — Risle canals, "Norman Venice".
Le Bec-Hellouin — abbey & preserved village.

activities.text: Kayaking on Pont-Audemer's canals. Trade the gondola for a kayak to glide along Risle branches through medieval quarters. The route passes under picturesque stone bridges and along the tanners' old wharves.

Mirliton tasting. This local specialty created in 1340 by Guillaume Tirel, known as Taillevent, cook to the kings of France, this rolled cookie filled with praline cream and sealed with chocolate is the pride of Pont-Audemer pastry makers. This is where Thierry Hermès lived before founding his famous Parisian house.

Marais Vernier. A few kilometers away, this largest peat marsh in France (4,500 hectares) is a paradise for migratory birds. Ramsar-labeled, it offers 44 hiking trails and wild basketry workshops in this preserved setting.
Walking loop along the canals & bridges.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure Road Trip: From Giverny to Normandy's Finest Medieval Villages
Normandy's Classic Coast: Étretat Cliffs and Bocage Countryside Villages

visits.text: Village of painters (Gauguin).
Museum.
Windmills.
Chapels.
Pont-Aven, 'the artists' town,' owes its fame to artists who settled there from 1860, seduced by the light, mills, and washerwomen. There were then 'fourteen mills and fifteen houses' along the Aven.

The Pont-Aven Museum, renovated in 2016, exhibits works from the Pont-Aven school and Synthetism. Permanent collections trace this small town's artistic adventure as it became the capital of post-Impressionist painting.

The Trémalo chapel, 500 m from the center, houses a 17th-century polychrome wooden Christ - the very one that inspired the famous 'Yellow Christ' in 1889. The sculpture remains in place above the altar.
The port ascends the Aven estuary to the town's heart. At high tide, sailboats float among the trees; at low tide, hulls rest on mud among egrets.
Several mills survive along the Aven. The Grand Poulguin mill (15th century) preserves its water wheel. At the time, these tan mills crushed oak bark for sail tanning.

activities.text: Hike along the Aven.
Art galleries.
Galettes.

Stroll through the Bois d'Amour, the stand of beeches and oaks that follows the Aven upstream from the town. Here the Synthetist movement was born in 1888, when a young painter created his 'Talisman.'
Follow the Xavier Grall promenade along the Aven. The path passes old washhouses, wooden footbridges, and mill ruins. Painting reproductions are placed where artists set up their easels.
Descend the Aven by kayak or boat from the port. The estuary winds between woods and mudflats to Port-Manec'h, where the river meets the sea between two white sand beaches.

days_plan.itin_title: Finistère, Brittany Road Trip: Breton Headlands, Ponant Islands & Coastal Heritage
Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Houses suspended above the Bourne; bridge and castle remains.
Medieval heart sloping down to the quays, colorful facades.
Entrance to the Bourne gorges, limestone cliffs.

The abbey church of Saint-Antoine-l'Abbaye, built between the 13th and 15th centuries, ranks among the most remarkable Gothic achievements in Dauphiné. A Historic Monument since 1840, it preserves murals, walnut woodwork, and an organ dating from the 17th and 18th centuries.

The Treasury Room, housed in sacristies paneled with walnut and Hungarian oak, displays the collection of the Antonine Order: a 17th-century ivory crucifix, antiphonaries, medieval surgical instruments, and an exceptional rotating vestment cabinet.

Take the "goulets"—narrow half-covered alleys climbing to the village summit. The houses grow more elaborate as you ascend: mullioned windows, glazed tiles creating "Dauphiné roofs," carved decorative elements.

The Departmental Museum, set in the former novitiate from the 17th and 18th centuries, focuses on the Hospitallers of Saint Anthony—an order of monk-physicians who treated "St. Anthony's Fire." A medieval garden complements the visit.

In Pont-en-Royans, the suspended houses appear to spring from the rock face above the Bourne River. Built in the 16th century to facilitate timber trade from the Vercors, their ochre, yellow, and pink façades have been protected as Historic Monuments since 1944.

Cross the Pont Picard for the village's most iconic view: the colorful houses stand out against the deep green waters. The buildings are constructed directly into the rock spur, with wooden overhangs projecting into empty space.

The Musée de l'Eau occupies a former convent that became a silk mill and then a power plant. It houses a water bar featuring 1,500 bottles from around the world, plus an exhibit on aquatic biodiversity.

activities.text: Belvederes–quays–footbridges loop (3 km).
Exploration trail at the foot of the cliffs (round trip, secured).

Climb to the Belvédère des Trois Châteaux above Pont-en-Royans. The ascent is short but steep, passing through the medieval quarter and its terraced gardens. The panorama takes in the Royans region and the entrance to the Bourne gorges.
The landscaped banks of the Bourne invite relaxation: picnic tables, a waterfall, and swimming areas in summer. The water is crystal-clear and cool, flowing straight down from the Vercors.

The Gorges de la Bourne road connects Pont-en-Royans to Villard-de-Lans over 24 km. Carved into the cliff face in the 19th century, it hangs above the gorge with vertiginous drops and tunnels bored through solid rock.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies
Rhône-Alpes Circuit: Perched Villages and Mountain Peaks

visits.text: Pontarlier was the world capital of absinthe in the 19th century. In 1805, the first distillery opened its doors. In 1900, 25 distilleries employed 3,000 people (38% of the population) and produced 66,000 liters per day. Banned on March 17, 1915, absinthe was rehabilitated in 2001 and has enjoyed PGI status since 2010. The municipal museum recounts this history with a collection of objects, posters, and period documents.

The last historic distillery in Pontarlier, founded in 1890, perpetuates the tradition at 49 rue des Lavaux. Its century-old copper stills and vats produce absinthe using ancestral methods. Labeled Living Heritage Company, it offers free tours with tasting of its products: absinthe, Pontarlier-Anis, and fir liqueur.

The Château de Joux overlooks the Pontarlier cluse since the 11th century, controlling the passage to Switzerland. Its 5 enclosures, 3 moats, and 3 drawbridges extend over 2 hectares with 250 rooms. Classified as a Historic Monument, it was fortified by Vauban at the end of the 17th century then served as a state prison. Toussaint Louverture, hero of Haitian independence, died there on April 7, 1803, after seven months of imprisonment in a freezing cell. The site is inscribed on the Route of the Abolitions of Slavery.
Tasting of Marsotte kirsch in Mouthier-Haute-Pierre.
Observation of the source of the Doubs in Ouhans and visit to the natural site.
Visit to the Armand Guy distillery in Pontarlier to discover the history of absinthe.
Discovery of the Joux castle and its fortifications, wells and weapons collections.

activities.text: Participate in a guided tour of the Château de Joux to discover the evolution of fortification from the Middle Ages to Vauban. Guides also recount the history of famous prisoners: Mirabeau, Toussaint Louverture, and German writer Heinrich von Kleist. Toussaint Louverture's cell is a memorial site for the abolition of slavery with commemorations every April 7 and May 10.

Taste Comtoise specialties in Pontarlier restaurants: Morteau sausage, Comté fondue, mushroom croute, warm Mont d'Or in winter. The city maintains a gastronomic tradition linked to its past as a commercial crossroads between France and Switzerland.
Panoramic walk to Fort Mahler for a view of the castle and the Jura mountains.

days_plan.itin_title: Doubs Circuit: Watchmaking and Swiss Border
Doubs, France Natural Tour: Gorges, Waterfalls & Craft Heritage

visits.text: The Rohan Château has dominated the Blavet since the 15th century. Three massive towers and ramparts testify to the power of the Dukes of Rohan. The interiors preserve Renaissance treasures.
Saint-Joseph Church displays Napoleonic neoclassical style. Built in the early 19th century, it reflects Napoleon's ambition for the town he renamed Napoléonville.
Walk the straight streets of Napoléonville. The neoclassical façades contrast with the medieval quarter. Napoleon wanted to make Pontivy the capital of interior Brittany.
The Nantes-Brest Canal runs through Pontivy. 226 miles between Nantes and Port-Launay. Construction ordered by Napoleon I to bypass Breton ports during the British blockade.
The floating tourist office is moored on a barge. An original information point alongside the canal.

activities.text: Cycle along the canal towpath. Numerous flower-filled locks punctuate the route between Rohan and Pontivy. Greenway developed on the old railway line.
From Pontivy, the Blavet towpath descends toward Hennebont for 36 miles. Bucolic landscapes and flower-filled locks.
Rent an electric boat or license-free canal barge. Navigation between April and October. Lock keepers operate the free locks.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: Musée Pissarro, Pontoise — Impressionist collections in a 19th‑century villa overlooking the Oise; focus on Camille Pissarro and contemporaries.
Vieux Pontoise — Medieval lanes around the Mont Bélien with half‑timbered houses and painterly viewpoints.
Oise river banks — Bridges and islets that inspired 19th‑century plein‑air painters; gentle photography loop.

activities.text: Market tasting in Pontoise (morning hours); pick seasonal cheeses and baguettes for a riverside picnic.
Evening bistro crawl around Place Notre‑Dame; reserve for weekend nights.

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: The Château de Pornic has overlooked the old harbor since the 10th century. Its medieval core hides beneath 19th-century seaside resort architecture—turrets and romantic facades that transformed it into a Belle Époque jewel.
Stroll the old harbor lined with fishermen's cottages. At low tide, boats rest on exposed mudflats while restaurants buzz to life along the stone quays, serving the day's catch.
The Noëveillard beach offers the most family-friendly swimming. Sheltered near the marina, it holds enough water for bathing even when the tide retreats.

activities.text: Walk the Sentier des Douaniers for 14 kilometers of coastal drama. The customs officers' path winds past secret coves, Belle Époque villas, and traditional stilt fishing huts perched above the waves.
Head to Pointe Saint-Gildas and its lighthouse. On clear days, the panorama sweeps across the Bay of Bourgneuf all the way to Noirmoutier Island on the southern horizon.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire-Atlantique Road Trip: Nantes and the Jade Coast

visits.text: Fort Sainte-Agathe, strengthened in 1531 under François I, has dominated the harbor since Antiquity. Managed by Port-Cros National Park, it hosts exhibitions on the island's marine and terrestrial biodiversity. Views from the ramparts sweep over the village and Courtade beach.

Notre-Dame beach, voted Europe's most beautiful beach, stretches in a bay bordered by eucalyptus. Its turquoise, shallow waters make it ideal for swimming. Count on 25 minutes on foot or 10 minutes by bike from the village.
Near the fort, the Moulin du Bonheur—a Provençal windmill restored by the National Park—offers a glimpse of island agricultural life. Free guided tours for visitors under 18, from May to September.

Porquerolles village nestles behind the harbor, around the shaded Place d'Armes. Sainte-Anne church and houses with colorful shutters compose a postcard scene. In the evening, when the ferries have departed, tranquility reigns supreme.

Fort de la Repentance, an 1893 buried battery, offers sweeping views over Notre-Dame Bay and the harbor. The interior can be visited during Heritage Days. The final section is steep by bike but worth the climb.

activities.text: Bike rental shops line the harbor. Four trails marked by the National Park allow you to traverse the island north to south between vineyards, pine forests, and fragrant maquis—cycling heaven on car-free paths.

Follow the forts circuit: 9.5 km of trails linking Forts Lequin, Alycastre, Repentance, and Sainte-Agathe. The route reconstructs the island's military life through four centuries of fortifications—history on foot.

The island's wine estates produce 70% rosé AOC Côtes de Provence. Tastings are by reservation in a unique island setting, between vines and pine groves—sipping pink wine where salt air meets the terroir.

Two dive centers offer explorations of the underwater depths around the island, classified as the heart of Port-Cros National Park. Posidonia seagrass meadows, groupers, and barracudas populate these protected waters.

days_plan.itin_title: Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: The fishing port of Port-en-Bessin brings the small coastal village to life with its ballet of colourful trawlers. The quays echo with the cry of seagulls and the bustle of fishermen unloading their fresh catch. The authentic atmosphere of this working port contrasts with the neighbouring seaside resorts.
Stroll between the nearby D-Day beaches. Gold Beach lies just a stone's throw away, a reminder that Port-en-Bessin served as a fuel port during the Battle of Normandy thanks to the PLUTO pipeline.

activities.text: Savour fresh seafood at one of the port's fish auctions. Scallops, oysters and fresh fish come straight from the boats to the restaurant stalls on the quayside.
Climb up to the Vauban tower overlooking the port. The panorama encompasses the Bessin coast and offers an unbeatable view of Gold Beach.

days_plan.itin_title: Calvados Circuit: D-Day Beaches and Normandy

visits.text: Route Grasse → Gulf of Saint-Tropez
Pampelonne Beach (beach club day)
Boat shuttle to Saint-Tropez (Old Port)
Breakfast at Café Sénéquier (quai Jean-Jaurès)
Place des Lices Market
Saint-Tropez Citadel (museum & ramparts)
Late afternoon beach at Port Grimaud

activities.text: Dinner in Port Grimaud (e.g. Don Peppe)
Lunch in Saint-Tropez (e.g. La Petite Plage)
Seafood dinner (e.g. La Table du Mareyeur)

Provence, France: Lavender Fields, Hilltop Villages and Riviera Towns

visits.text: Museum of Prehistory.
Fortified upper town.

activities.text: Boat excursion to Bonifacio.
Catenacciu Procession (Good Friday).
Megalithic sites (Filitosa).

Panoramic viewpoints over the Gulf of Porto
Scandola Nature Reserve - UNESCO
Girolata - fishing hamlet accessible only by boat

activities.text: Boat excursion in the calanques of Piana
Guided cruise to Scandola and Girolata

Marina.

Palombaggia Beach - one of the most beautiful beaches in the world
Santa Giulia Beach

Santa Giulia).

days_plan.itin_title: Southern Corsica Travel Guide: Corsican Mountains & Gulf Heritage Itinerary
The Ultimate Corsica Road Trip: Granite Cliffs, Mountain Passes & Island Beaches

visits.text: Former stronghold of the Régordane at over 1,000 m; gates, ramparts and notable residences.
Windy small squares and views over the Devès plateau and Lake Naussac.
Medieval layout with narrow alleyways and basalt staircases.

Pradelles, classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages, overlooks the Upper Allier valley from 3,786 feet elevation. Nicknamed the "balcony of the Midi," it offers a panorama over Lake Naussac and the Margeride hills.
Cross the Place de la Halle with its stone arcades. The noble dwellings with tall stone façades, braced against the Cévennes squalls, testify to the town's medieval prosperity.
The Chapel of Notre-Dame de Pradelles, built in the early 17th century, is the village's spiritual heart. Several French kings stopped here, including Saint Louis in 1254.
Spot the vestiges of medieval fortifications: towers, corner turrets, shadowy porches. The cobbled lanes climb in tiers through this ancient town of tawny stone.
Pradelles was a major stop on the Via Régordane (GR 700) linking Le Puy-en-Velay to Saint-Gilles-du-Gard. Merchants and pilgrims passed through for centuries.

activities.text: Heritage walk within the walls and tour of the ramparts (2–3 km).
Panoramic round trip to a viewpoint overlooking the Margeride.
Walk in the footsteps of Robert Louis Stevenson: the GR 70, the famous Stevenson Trail, crosses Pradelles. The Scottish writer stopped here in 1878 with his donkey Modestine.
Try the Pradelles vélorail: pedal along the old Transcévenol railway line that crosses the volcanic Devès plateau toward Langogne.
Lake Naussac, visible from the village heights, offers water activities in season: sailing, paddleboarding, canoeing, and swimming at developed beaches.

days_plan.itin_title: The Volcanoes of Auvergne: A Road Trip Through Medieval Towns & Lunar Landscapes
Haute-Loire Road Trip: Le Puy-en-Velay & Volcanic Peaks

visits.text: Fort Lagarde, built by Vauban between 1677 and 1682, guards the entrance to the Haut-Vallespir. Its star-shaped fortress surrounds a medieval signal tower. Climb via the zigzagging path or the underground passage with 142 steps.
The medieval ramparts encircle the upper town since the 14th century. Vauban remodeled them in the 17th century to create a remarkable defensive ensemble.
The Church of Saints Justus and Rufina imposes its dimensions since the 9th century. Rebuilt in the 13th and 16th centuries, its 1245 portal displays ironwork from Catalan forges.
The Tour de Mir testifies to the medieval defensive system. This watchtower offers a vantage point over the valley.
Visit La Verneda, a museum housed in a former textile factory. Exhibitions on the history, heritage, and Catalan traditions on both sides of the Pyrenees.

activities.text: Wander through the medieval streets of the upper town. The colorful facades contrast with the rigor of Vauban's fortifications.
Drive up to La Preste, a spa town nestled at 1,130 meters altitude. Its sulfurous waters have treated rheumatism and respiratory ailments since the 16th century.
Discover the Col d'Arès leading to Spain. Historic passage between France and Catalonia at 1,513 meters altitude.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: Cliffs.
King of Aragon's Staircase.
Harbor.
Propriano - seaside resort
Portigliolo Beach - wild and uncrowded
Campomoro - natural seaside site

activities.text: Boat to the caves and Lavezzi islands.
Beaches (Palombaggia).
Boat excursions to Scandola or Sanguinaires islands
Parachuting in Propriano

days_plan.itin_title: Southern Corsica Travel Guide: Corsican Mountains & Gulf Heritage Itinerary
The Ultimate Corsica Road Trip: Granite Cliffs, Mountain Passes & Island Beaches

visits.text: The Tour César, a 12th-century keep, is unique in France: an octagon set on a square base, raised on an artificial mound. From the top, the panorama embraces the medieval town and the Brie plain.
The upper town's ramparts, 1,200 meters long with 22 varied towers, were erected from 1226 to 1314 to protect the wealth of the Champagne Fairs. A walkway runs along their length.

Descend into Provins' underground passages. These galleries carved in limestone served as merchant cellars during the fairs. The guided tour crosses vaulted rooms with sculpted capitals, in groups of 25. Constant temperature: 13°C.

The Grange aux Dîmes, a 13th-century merchant house once rented to Toulouse traders, recreates the atmosphere of the Champagne Fairs. An audio-guided exhibition presents the trades and merchants of the era.

The Saint-Quiriace Collegiate Church, begun in the 12th century, was never completed. Its Gothic choir and 17th-century dome create a striking contrast with the unfinished nave. The Place du Châtel, at the church's foot, was the heart of comital power.
The Saint-Ayoul Priory, whose forecourt hosted the first fairs born from pilgrimages, preserves a thousand-year-old architectural ensemble with its crypt and Romanesque sculpted capitals.

activities.text: Watch "Les Aigles des Remparts" (Eagles of the Ramparts): equestrian falconry at the foot of the fortifications. Eagles, falcons, and horses recreate medieval life in 50 minutes.
"The Legend of the Knights," a chivalry show in the ramparts' moats, features sword fights, jousting, and equestrian stunts.

The Provins Rose Garden spreads across three hectares at the foot of the upper town. The Provins rose, reputedly brought from Damascus by a Count of Champagne, appears in jam, crystallized petals, and rosewater.
Wander through the upper town's streets to the half-timbered houses. Artisans offer medieval specialties: honey, hypocras, and Provins rose products.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: Hilltop village, fortified gates and views over the Lot valley.
The 16th-century Église Sainte-Foy houses magnificent classified murals. Its Latin cross floor plan opens onto two side chapels.
The Flamboyant Gothic Église Saint-Nicolas is integrated into a town gate. Its bell tower formed part of the medieval defensive system.
Pass through the Porte des Anglais, a superbly preserved medieval entrance marking the northern access to the fortified village.
Wander the lanes between restored half-timbered houses. Rue de la Citadelle and Rue du Temple preserve their timeless charm.
The 19th-century market hall hosts the Sunday market. Its wooden beams shelter local producers and artisans.

activities.text: Walk from the belvedere to the narrow streets (round trip).
Reach the viewing platform for 180-degree panoramas over the Lot valley. Villeneuve-sur-Lot's rosy bricks sprawl 30 kilometers in the distance.
Browse the Sunday market at the Halle to taste Lot-et-Garonne regional specialties.
Attend summer concerts and exhibitions held in the Église Sainte-Foy.
Take the tourist train from Villeneuve-sur-Lot up to the hilltop village while enjoying the scenic views.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: Ascent of Puy de Dôme by road or the Panoramique des Dômes.
Visit of the Gallo-Roman temple of Mercury at the summit and panorama over the Puys chain.

activities.text: Hiking on the trails around the summit of Puy de Dôme.

days_plan.itin_title: Auvergne Volcanoes, France: Ancient Peaks, Crater Lakes and Lava Flows

visits.text: Puy-l'Évêque rises on a rocky spur 30 meters above the Lot River. Golden-stone medieval dwellings tier in concentric arcs from the seigneurial tower at the summit down to the old port below. From the bridge across the Lot, the overall view of the terraced citadel and its reflection in the water forms the village's iconic image.

The 13th-century episcopal tower rises 23 meters—the last vestige of the bishops' palace of Cahors, who gave the town its name in 1228. Its four levels, connected by a staircase within the wall thickness, served as a watchtower. The top floor preserves a fireplace and latrines carved into the stone.

The Church of Saint-Sauveur, a Historic Monument from the 14th–15th centuries, occupies an unusual position: outside the castrum, on the heights. Its Gothic nave with ribbed vaults and its bell tower—a former watchtower—dominate the valley. A remarkable feature: the church possesses the Lot department's only historic carillon, composed of 15 bells, the oldest dating from 1632.

Descend through the hanging gardens, created in 2016 on the site of ruined medieval houses. This terraced pedestrian pathway connects the upper town to the river, punctuated by rest stops with open views across the Lot Valley and the citadel rooftops.

At the village base, Rue de la Cale leads to the old port where gabarres moored, loaded with wine barrels bound for Bordeaux. Street names preserve the memory of former trades: boatmen, nailsmiths, dyers, washerwomen. On Place Guillaume de Cardaillac, admire medieval houses from the 13th–16th centuries and a beautiful half-timbered dwelling.

activities.text: Board an electric gabare at the foot of the village. This replica of 19th-century boats glides silently on the Lot. The guide recounts river navigation history while vineyards, cliffs, and mills slip past.

Puy-l'Évêque is the capital of the Cahors wine region. Malbec, planted here since Roman times, produces deep-colored, structured AOC wines. Several estates open their cellars to visitors for tastings led by the winemaker.
The Lot Valley cycle route winds between vineyards and river. From Puy-l'Évêque, ride toward Albas and its steep lanes, or toward Luzech and its peninsula, for panoramas of the Lot's meanders.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot Itinerary: Cahors, Rocamadour & the Lot Valley

visits.text: Bonaguil — Ghost of Marguerite.

activities.text: Access: public (Bonaguil)

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine's Haunted History: Cursed Castles & Prehistoric Cave Legends

visits.text: The Wild Coast stretches for 5 miles between Pointe du Percho and Château Turpault. The Atlantic sculpts cliffs and coves beneath pounding waves. The GR 34 coastal path follows the shoreline.
At Pointe du Percho, the guardhouse ruins overlook the cliffs. This military building was once connected to an artillery battery. Spectacular views of Atlantic rollers.
The Port Blanc arch pierces through the coastal rock. This natural formation has become one of the peninsula's most photographed landmarks. At low tide, walk right up to the arch's base.

Château Turpault marks the entrance to the Wild Coast. This Anglo-medieval manor was built in 1904 by a textile manufacturer from Cholet. It's private property but makes a striking photograph from the road.

Pointe du Conguel extends out for more than half a mile. The trail circles this entire tongue of land. Views of the Teignouse lighthouse, Belle-Île, Houat and Hoëdic islands. Ruins of seaweed ovens dot the slabs.
Port Haliguen combines a fishing harbor with a pleasure marina. The 36-foot lighthouse was inaugurated in 1856.

activities.text: Ride the Tire-Bouchon, a tourist train that links Auray to Quiberon along the coast. The journey travels the entire peninsula with sea views.
Grande Plage stretches out facing Belle-Île-en-Mer. This south-facing beach offers supervised swimming in summer. Tiralo accessibility chairs available for people with reduced mobility.
From Port-Maria, catch ferries to Belle-Île-en-Mer, Houat, or Hoëdic. Boats make several daily crossings in season.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: Rennes-le-Château — Village of mysteries, 80 inhabitants, on a rocky spur. Abbé Saunière built a lavish estate here (1885–1917) with funds of unknown origin. Church of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine with the statue of the devil Asmodeus.
Tour Magdala — Neo-Gothic tower built by Abbé Saunière in the early 20th century. Library and rampart walk, panoramic views over the upper Aude valley.
Aude Gorges — Spectacular canyon between Quillan and Axat. Road winding between limestone cliffs along the Aude River. Pierre-Lys gorges and Saint-Georges gorges.

activities.text: Rafting on the Aude — 7 to 17 km descent between Axat and Quillan. Class III–IV rapids, "triple drop" and "flipper" passages. Suitable from age 6–12 depending on the route.
Abbé Saunière estate visit — Museum, Villa Béthanie, Tour Magdala, gardens. Information panels on the mystery. Church accessible free of charge.

days_plan.itin_title: Aude Road Trip: Carcassonne, Cathar Country & the Mediterranean

visits.text: Saint-Corentin Cathedral.
Museum of Fine Arts.
Faience workshops.
Old town.
Doëlan: fishing port, green and red lighthouses, walk on both banks
Port Manec'h: beach and white cabins, panorama over the Aven cove
Anse de Rospico: creek and beach, ideal at mid-tide
Thatched cottages of Kerascoët: traditional hamlet with granite stones and hydrangeas
Kercanic: lane with thatched cottages and neighboring wild coastline
Concarneau: walled city, ramparts and seafront promenade (Sables Blancs/Cornouaille beaches)
Quimper: Saint-Corentin cathedral, Saint-Corentin square, Kéréon street, bishop's palace ramparts, gardens
Pointe Saint-Hernot: belvedere over Île Vierge beach (descent to the creek forbidden)
Unnamed cove on the trail to Morgat: white pebbles and translucent water
Cap de la Chèvre: panoramas, memorial and views of Palue beach
Morgat: harbor, large beach and villas
Fort des Capucins (Roscanvel): Vauban fortification on rocky islet
Camaret-sur-Mer: Vauban tower, boat cemetery, waterfront
Pen Hat Beach: long beach open to the Atlantic
Pointe de Pen Hir: cliffs, Tas de Pois and memorial

Saint-Corentin Cathedral, begun in 1239 and completed in the 15th century, has a nave deliberately offset from the choir - an architectural mystery. The most common explanation: builders aligned the choir with a pre-existing chapel.

The two 76-meter spires, added in 1856, were financed by public subscription. Between them, an equestrian statue of legendary King Gradlon, mythical founder of the city, has watched over the city since the 15th century.
Old Quimper displays half-timbered houses along Rue Kéréon, Place au Beurre, and Place Terre au Duc. Sculpted signs - a mermaid, a dragon, a ship - recall medieval guilds.

Quimper faience factories have perpetuated the tradition of hand-painted 'little Breton' since 1690. More than three centuries of continuous production make Quimper France's oldest operating faience manufactory.
The Museum of Fine Arts, facing the cathedral, houses a collection of French and European painting from the 14th to 20th century, as well as an important collection dedicated to the Pont-Aven school.

The English Garden, laid out in 1852 on the former parish cemetery, adjoins Saint-Sauveur basilica. Behind high granite walls, a collection of exotic plants thrives in protection from wind. Palms, banana trees, and camellias prosper in this unexpected microclimate.

activities.text: Cornouaille Festival (July).
Banks of the Odet.
Coastal walk between Port Manec'h and neighboring creeks
Tour of Concarneau ramparts and viewpoint over the harbor
Stroll through old Quimper at the end of the day
Hiking on the GR34 between Saint-Hernot and neighboring coves
Kayak/canoe rental from Morgat to sheltered coves (weather dependent)
Sunset at Pointe de Pen Hir
Follow the Odet riverbanks on foot from downtown. The river, lined with bourgeois residences and overhanging gardens, has been called 'France's prettiest river.'
Climb Mont Frugy (70 m), a wooded hill in the city's heart. From the summit, the panorama embraces the cathedral, slate roofs, and the confluence of the Odet and Steir.
The Cornouaille Festival, end of July, is the largest gathering of Breton culture: fest-noz, pipers, bagadoù, and dances from all of Brittany invade the town center for a week.

days_plan.itin_title: Finistère, Brittany Road Trip: Breton Headlands, Ponant Islands & Coastal Heritage

Brittany's Wild Coast: Pink Granite, Île de Bréhat & Sentier des Douaniers
Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: The Château de Rambouillet, a 14th-century fortress turned royal then presidential residence, preserves exceptional rocaille woodwork and the chamber where François I died in 1547. The first G6 summit was held here in 1975.

The Queen's Dairy, commissioned by Louis XVI for Marie-Antoinette between 1785 and 1787, houses Pierre Julien's sculptural group "Amalthea and the Nymph" in a neoclassical setting of marble and stucco.
The Shell Cottage conceals beneath its thatched roof one of Europe's finest mother-of-pearl and seashell decorations, created between 1779 and 1780 for the Princess de Lamballe.

The National Sheepfold, created by Louis XVI in 1786, houses France's only flock of Rambouillet merinos, direct descendants of sheep imported from Spain. Cows, goats, horses, and poultry complete the educational farm.

activities.text: Hike in Rambouillet forest, 14,550 hectares of oaks and pines classified as a "protected forest." The Étang d'Or trail or the Coupe-Gorge loop are among the most pleasant routes.
Visit Espace Rambouillet to observe deer, does, roe deer, and wild boar in semi-freedom across 250 hectares of forest. The Forest of Eagles features a birds of prey free-flight show.
Stroll through the château gardens, 150 hectares labeled "Remarkable Garden" with canals, six islands, a French garden, and an 18th-century English garden. Park access is free.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

visits.text: Enter the heart of Réalmont to discover this royal bastide founded in 1272 on Philip the Bold's orders. The arcaded square, bordered by a double row of covered galleries, preserves the geometric rigor typical of medieval bastides.

Notre-Dame-du-Taur church occupies a unique place: born from a 17th-century Protestant temple, converted to a Catholic church in 1628. Its quadrangular bell tower dates from 1712, and the nave shelters four richly decorated chapels on each side.

Spot the Fontaine de la Fréjaire, a traditional 17th-century spring, and the 1880 wash-house. These small heritage elements mark a signposted historical circuit passing corbelled houses and traces of former fortified gates.

Walk the perpendicular streets, signature of southwestern bastides. Here, every façade tells of builders past: half-timbered houses, upper floors wider than ground level, details carved in brick and stone.
The small Protestant temple, discreet but historically charged, recalls that Réalmont was the scene of conflicts between Catholics and Huguenots during the Wars of Religion.

activities.text: Wednesday mornings, Réalmont hosts the Tarn's oldest market. Local producers spread cured meats, cheeses, fruits, and vegetables beneath the arcades. Friendly atmosphere guaranteed.
Reach the waterfalls of Arifat, a few kilometers southeast of Réalmont. A wooded trail leads to these forest cascades, ideal for a refreshing break.
Go cycling or mountain biking on the rolling trails of central Tarn. Lake Bancalié, 15 minutes from Réalmont, offers canoeing, pedal boats, and fishing in a preserved natural setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn Road Trip: Albi & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral soars skyward with 2,303 statues crowning its facade. Built in the 13th century, this Gothic masterpiece witnessed the coronation of 29 French kings.
The Palais du Tau houses the cathedral's glittering treasury. Once the archbishop's residence, it transformed into a royal palace on coronation days.
Step inside the Basilique Saint-Remi, where Romanesque meets Gothic. Its 11th-century nave leads to a soaring Gothic choir, where Saint Remi's tomb takes center stage.

activities.text: Descend into the Taittinger cellars, carved from ancient Gallo-Roman chalk quarries 20 meters beneath the city streets.
Wander through 18 kilometers of Pommery cellars, where contemporary art installations emerge from the chalk alongside aging champagne.
Explore the Veuve Clicquot caves, where ventilation chimneys pierce through the chalk right up to street level above.

The Ultimate Guide to Alsace Christmas Markets: Enchanted Winter Villages Itinerary

visits.text: Richelieu is a unique masterpiece of 17th-century urban planning. Founded in 1631 by the Cardinal and designed by Jacques Lemercier (architect of the Sorbonne), this "ideal city" follows a grid plan enclosed by ramparts and moats, accessible through three monumental gates.

Walk down the Grande Rue, 12 meters wide, lined with 28 identical townhouses—all listed as Historic Monuments. Regularity, symmetry, and perfect alignment: the Cardinal's spirit is readable in every façade.

The market halls, completed in 1638, are a fine example of functional architecture from the Grand Siècle. They still host a market on Friday mornings, opposite the Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Church in classical style.

Step into the Espace Richelieu, housed in a restored townhouse, for an interactive exhibit on the Cardinal, his city, and new towns. 3D glasses let you immerse yourself in the vanished splendor of the château.

The Richelieu Museum displays art collections that belonged to the Cardinal, a great patron and collector: portraits by Philippe de Champaigne, engravings by Jean Marot showing the château as it was, and a model of the town.

Stroll through the château park, 475 hectares enclosed by walls. Of the palace that inspired Versailles, what remains is the Dome Pavilion, the orangery, the cellars, and the entrance bridge. Nearly 2,000 workers labored on this titanic construction project.

activities.text: Hop on a bike along the Richelieu-Chinon Greenway, 20 km on a former railway line through unspoiled nature in the Loire-Anjou-Touraine Regional Nature Park.
Walk around the ramparts and moats. The fourth gate, a fake, was created solely to respect the ensemble's symmetry—a detail that sums up the Cardinal's spirit.
In summer, browse the craft shops and antique dealers installed in some fifteen boutiques around the city.

days_plan.itin_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: The Cathedral of Sainte-Marie in Rieux, despite its small size, was the seat of a bishopric. Built in the 14th century, it presents a rare octagonal plan. Its tower-belfry dominates the Arize valley.
The medieval bridge spans the Arize River. Rebuilt several times over the centuries, it links the two banks of Rieux.

activities.text: The Volvestre is known for foie gras and ceramics. Pottery workshops continue an ancient tradition. You can visit some workshops by appointment.
The Arize River is renowned for trout fishing. The shaded banks offer lovely spots to fish or simply walk.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Four Roman columns stand isolated in a field. Remains of a 1st-century ancient temple, they testify to the importance of the Gallo-Roman city of Riez. Gray granite contrasts with surrounding lavender fields, creating a timeless tableau.

The 5th-century Merovingian baptistery is one of France's oldest Christian buildings. The stone octagon houses an immersion baptismal font. Reused Roman columns support the vault of this architectural gem classified as a historic monument.

Walk through old town streets where medieval gates and Renaissance facades follow one another. Porte Ayguières and Porte Sanson from the 14th century guard the fortified town entrance. Fountains and washhouses punctuate shaded squares.
The Clock Tower dominates the central square. The sundial adorns the facade of this former medieval watchtower. Arcades of bourgeois houses shelter shops and craftsmen on the ground floor.

The 16th-century Sainte-Maxime chapel nestles on a hill away from the village. The classified building offers a remarkable example of Provençal religious architecture. The panorama embraces Riez and the Valensole plateau.
Riez-la-Romaine — ancient remains (temple columns), old baptistery and medieval heart.
Gypsum plasterwork route (molded plaster decorations) on remarkable facades and interiors.
Roman columns.
Museum.

activities.text: The heritage discovery circuit winds through Riez and surroundings. Explanatory panels mark the route between Roman remains, medieval buildings and restored washhouses. Allow two hours for this cultural walk through local history.
Lavender fields surround Riez from mid-June to mid-July. Country roads offer multiple viewpoints over these purple expanses. The heady perfume accompanies walks on foot or by bike across the plateau.

The Wednesday morning weekly market brings Riez center to life. Local producers offer lavender honey, goat cheeses and local products. The Provençal atmosphere is in full swing under the plane trees of the square.
Heritage loop between private mansions, staircases and sculpted porches.
Walk towards the hills of Val d'Asse (view over plateaus).
Valensole Plateau (lavender in summer).
Provençal market.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages
Forcalquier & the Lure Valley: Lavender Fields, Gorges & Hilltop Villages
Verdon Gorge Road Trip: Moustiers-Sainte-Marie, Castellane & Turquoise Waters

visits.text: The old town of Riom-ès-Montagnes spreads its historic houses around the parish church in the atmosphere of an authentic mountain town. The nerve centre of the Gentian country, this small town retains the character of Cantal villages where lava stone bears witness to the territory's volcanic origins.

The Maison de la Gentiane et des Plantes d'Auvergne reveals the secrets of this iconic plant with its yellow root that grows on high-altitude pastures. Interactive museography, a botanical garden and an educational distillery trace the history of the artisanal harvest and transformation into liqueur. The yellow gentian, hand-picked on the summer pastures, remains a powerful symbol of mountain Auvergne.

activities.text: A visit to a gentian distillery reveals the ancestral techniques for producing the famous liqueur. The roots macerate for several years before distillation to release their characteristic bitter aromas. A comparative tasting between different expressions (Avèze, Salers Gentiane) allows you to appreciate the nuances of this quintessentially Auvergnat spirit.

Hiking on the plateau offers beautiful escapes through summer pasture landscapes where Salers cattle graze. These vast green expanses dotted with abandoned burons tell the pastoral story of Cantal. Trails wind between heather moors and flowering meadows with views of the surrounding mountains.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions

visits.text: Riquewihr, the pearl of the Alsatian vineyard, is listed among France's Most Beautiful Villages. Its half-timbered houses from the 13th to the 18th century form an outstanding architectural ensemble.
The Dolder, a 13th-century fortified gate, rises to 25 metres. This tower-belfry once housed the belfry and the town bell. A museum sits at the top.
The Tour des Voleurs dates from the 13th century. A former prison, it still holds its instruments of torture. A testimony to medieval justice.
The Château des Wurtemberg-Montbéliard houses the Communication Museum. Renaissance architecture from the 16th century.
Cobbled main street leading to the Dolder tower, colorful houses with corbelling.
Successive enclosures and gates, transverse alleys towards the ramparts.
Wine districts in contact with planted hills.
Riquewihr Christmas Market
Traditional half-timbered houses and decorated medieval streets

Push through the Porte Haute and climb rue du Général-de-Gaulle, Riquewihr's single artery. The 16th and 17th-century half-timbered houses, painted yellow, blue or red, display oriels, wrought-iron signs and interior courtyards with wooden galleries.
The Tour Dolder (1291), a 25-meter-high sandstone belfry, guarded the town's main entrance. It houses a small local history museum with models and old engravings.
The Tour des Voleurs, corner tower of the ramparts, preserves a torture chamber and medieval dungeon. The exhibition traces judicial practices of the period.
The Maison Liebrich (1535), with its half-timbered courtyard, Renaissance well and old press, is one of the village's most complete architectural ensembles.
The ramparts, nearly intact around the entire perimeter, enclose an urban fabric frozen since the 16th century. Riquewihr suffered no major destruction during wars.

activities.text: Push open the carriage gates. Inner courtyards hide wine cellars. Around fifteen producers still make the grand cru wines Schoenenbourg and Sporen.
The Grand Cru vineyard trail winds through the vines. In summer, guided tours by winemakers are followed by tastings in the cellars.
In December, the Christmas market fills the narrow streets. Mulled wine, gingerbread, and crafts in a magical atmosphere. The Christmas shop is open year-round.
Ramparts–suburbs–vineyards loop (3–4 km).
Photographic survey of emblematic facade decorations and bay windows.
Discover handmade ornaments and regional crafts
Taste the wines of Schoenenbourg, the Grand Cru overlooking the village: Riesling of great finesse, Muscat and Pinot Gris. Winemaker-growers open their cellars all along the main street.
The marked wine trail climbs between rows of vines to the panorama over the village encircled by ramparts and the Alsace plain in the background.
In December, Riquewihr's Christmas market takes over the medieval alleys: mulled wine, bredele, handicrafts and lights in a postcard setting.
