days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Joseph-Déchelette Museum. This art and archaeology museum occupies a beautiful 18th-century townhouse. Collections trace Roannais history from prehistory onward. Gallo-Roman ceramics, archaeological artifacts from the Joeuvres site, paintings, and sculptures fill the galleries. Joseph Déchelette, an eminent early 20th-century archaeologist, contributed enormously to local heritage knowledge. The museum notably preserves bronze statuettes from the 1st century BCE discovered at the Celtic oppidum of Joeuvres.

Marina and Roanne-Digoin Canal. The Loire riverbanks, redesigned in 2021, create a pleasant promenade just steps from downtown. Water features, slides, and sports fields enliven the embankments. The marina welcomes barges and river cruise boats. The Roanne-Digoin canal connects the Loire to the Saône—a route beloved by cyclists on the Véloire path. Contemporary architecture seamlessly integrated into the landscape completes this urban development.

Roanne Old Town. Shopping streets, Halles Diderot, and Place du Marché form the historic heart. The covered market hosts local producers, charcutiers, cheese-makers, and market gardeners. On Saturdays, the grand weekly market spills into adjacent streets. Historic quarters with bourgeois houses and restored façades testify to the past prosperity of this 35,000-inhabitant city positioned at the crossroads of Burgundy, Beaujolais, and Forez.

activities.text: Roanne Gastronomy. Roanne enjoys worldwide renown for Maison Troisgros, a three-Michelin-star restaurant since 1968, now located in Ouches at the Domaine du Bois sans Feuilles estate. César Troisgros perpetuates the family tradition. Le Central, the Troisgros family's downtown brasserie opposite the train station, serves inventive home-style cuisine in a convivial atmosphere. The Praluline—a pink praline brioche created in 1955 by Auguste Pralus—is still sold warm at Halles Diderot every morning. Numerous quality restaurants throughout downtown.

Roanne Market. On Saturdays, the market takes over downtown. Producers from the upper Beaujolais, Forez, and Côte Roannaise offer charcuterie, goat cheeses, organic vegetables, and AOC wines. A lively atmosphere where residents and visitors mingle. Halles Diderot operates every morning with permanent shops.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Rocamadour — Black Virgin & gleams.
Abbey of Sylvanès — Songs & nave.
Saint-Cirq-Lapopie — last view from the top of the village.
Rocamadour — Religious city clinging to the cliff: small square, pilgrims' stairway, chapels.
Sanctuaries of Rocamadour — discovery of the Black Virgin and troglodytic chapels.

Rocamadour unfolds on three levels clinging to a cliff face: the commercial village below, the sanctuaries midway, the castle at the summit. France's second most-visited religious site draws over one million visitors annually. The Grand Staircase of 216 steps, which pilgrims climb on their knees, connects the main street to the chapels above.

The sanctuary comprises seven chapels gripping the rock wall. The Chapel of Notre-Dame houses the Black Virgin, a 12th-century walnut statue darkened by time and candle smoke. Above the entrance, the miraculous 8th-century bell reportedly rang to announce sailors' rescues at sea. Ex-voto model ships hang from the vault.

The Romanesque-Gothic Basilica of Saint-Sauveur preserves the relics of Saint Amadour in its crypt. Legend says his body was found intact beneath the threshold of the Virgin's chapel. In the rock beside Notre-Dame Chapel, a sword embedded in the cliff is said to be Durandal, the legendary weapon of Roland.

Take the Way of the Cross from the sanctuaries: fourteen stations climb through the trees to the castle ramparts. From the crenellations, your view plunges into the Alzou canyon and sweeps across the entire citadel below.

Descend through the medieval city. Rue de la Couronnerie, the sole commercial thoroughfare, passes beneath the fortified gateways of Figuier and Viguier. Honey-stone facades have sheltered shops and workshops since the Middle Ages.

The Gouffre de Padirac opens 103 meters deep into the limestone plateau. An elevator or staircase descends to the underground river. The visit alternates one kilometer walking through galleries and one kilometer by guided boat. The Grand Dome chamber soars 94 meters high; the Lake of Rain glitters beneath stalactites. Discovered in 1889, the site welcomes over 500,000 visitors yearly.

activities.text: Access: public (Rocamadour)
Access: public (Sylvanès)
Way of the Cross to Rocamadour castle — panorama over the Alzou canyon.
L'Hospitalet viewpoint — overall view of the site.

At the Rocher des Aigles, over 400 birds representing 60 species live on the cliffs facing Rocamadour. Free-flight demonstrations launch eagles, vultures, condors, and falcons above the canyon, followed by macaws and cockatoos.

Walk the cliff-top promenade along the rock face. Several viewpoints offer successive perspectives of the citadel, valley, and plateaus. The most famous, at L'Hospitalet, frames the postcard view of Rocamadour.
Themed guided tours explore the citadel from different angles: general discovery, in pilgrims' footsteps, or tales of miracles. Town of Art and History guides lead these excursions.

days_plan.itin_title: Occitanie Mysteries Road Trip: Cathar Legends & Hidden Secrets of Southern France
Bastide Villages of France: Cliffside Abbeys & Medieval Fortified Towns
Lot Itinerary: Cahors, Rocamadour & the Lot Valley

visits.text: Route to Le Chalard, a fortified village dating from the 11th century, famous for its religious remains and mining past.
Visit to the Maison de l'Or, an interactive museum tracing the history of the Limousin gold mines.
Discovery of the Romanesque church of Le Chalard and the monks' cemetery with its sculpted tombs.
Stop at Château de Châlus-Chabrol, the emblematic place where Richard the Lionheart died in 1199.

The Château de Rochechouart rises on a rocky spur formed by an asteroid impact 210 million years ago. The gatehouse and keep date from the 13th century, the main building from the 15th century. The Renaissance gallery with twisted columns opens onto the Graine valley. The contemporary art museum housed within its walls preserves more than 1,300 works.

On the château's first floor, the Galerie d'Hercule reveals rare late-15th-century murals. In the hunting hall, venery scenes alternate between colored paintings and grisailles. A space opened in 2017 offers 3D reconstructions of the Rochechouart lords' genealogy.

The Espace Météorite Paul Pellas, housed in the Maison de la Réserve, devotes 150 m² to the asteroid impact. 210 million years ago, a celestial body 1.5 km in diameter struck the ground at 72,000 km/h. The Rochechouart-Chassenon astrobleme is France's only recognized impact crater.

Push open the door of Église Saint-Sauveur, consecrated around 1060, a former priory of Charroux Abbey. Its walls are entirely built of impactites, rocks transformed by the meteoritic shock. Its helical spire, erected between 1767 and 1774, rotates 45° on its octagonal base and rises 20 meters high.

Inside the church, 15th-century frescoes stand alongside Nicolaï Greschny's Byzantine paintings, created in 1969 in the nave. The sacred art museum, housed in the gallery, gathers liturgical objects from Limousin.

activities.text: Walk through the streets of Châlus and panorama over the valley from the castle ramparts.
Crossing the Périgord-Limousin Regional Natural Park via secondary roads, with photo stops in the hamlets.

Follow the Meteorite Circuit, a 2 km interpretive loop through town. Panels point out impactites used in house facades, château walls, and church foundations. The rock reveals geological history beneath your feet.

The National Nature Reserve of the Astroblème, created in 2008, protects the crater's geological outcrops. The International Center for Research on Impacts (CIRIR), established since 2016, hosts geologists from around the world. Field trips are sometimes open to the public.
Walk down to the Graine valley for a peaceful stroll. Wooded banks contrast with the rocky cliffs of the château spur. Remarkable viewpoint from the old bridge below.

days_plan.itin_title: A Road Trip Through the Heart of Limousin: Historic Castles, Porcelain & Countryside
Haute-Vienne Circuit: Limoges, Porcelain & Historic Villages

visits.text: Village clinging to the rock; Saint-Barthélémy chapel and tower of the old castle.
Medieval vestiges emerging along the narrow alleyways.
Hamlet of Sauveplantade nearby, Romanesque micro-heritage.

activities.text: Short loop around the rocky peak (2–3 km) with interpretation stops.
Wandering through the upper/lower alleyways to read the settlement on the rocky ridge.

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: The Royal Rope Factory of Rochefort, built between 1666 and 1669, measures 374 meters long – more than the height of the Eiffel Tower. This manufactory supplied ropes to the Royal Navy for two centuries. The International Sea Center presents the arsenal's history and seamanship techniques.

The Hermione, replica of the frigate that took La Fayette to America in 1780, was rebuilt over 17 years in the Louis XV dry dock. The project brought together traditional ship carpentry skills. Visit the ship with explanations about life for the 300-man crew.

The National Naval Museum occupies Hôtel de Cheusses, Rochefort's oldest civilian building. Ship models built at the arsenal, navigation instruments, figureheads. The arsenal produced 550 ships between 1666 and 1927, including France's first submarine (Le Plongeur, 1863).

activities.text: Accro-mâts, in the Louis XV dry dock, recreates the Hermione's masts. A treetop adventure course at 30 meters height to experience the sensations of 18th-century topmen. Spectacular final zip line.

Stroll through the Arsenal gardens: the Garden of Returns, the Navy Garden and the King's vegetable garden. Palm trees, Virginia tulip trees, begonias – plants brought back from maritime expeditions. Peace and shade facing the Charente.

The Rochefort transporter bridge (1900), the last of its kind in France, connected both banks of the Charente by a suspended gondola. Listed as a Historic Monument in 1976, restored between 2016 and 2020. Gondola crossings available.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: Rochefort-en-Terre was voted 'France's Favorite Village' in 2016. Its cobbled streets lined with stone and half-timbered houses, overflowing with geraniums and hydrangeas, form a postcard setting.

The castle, built in the 12th century and remodeled in the 17th, was restored in the early 20th century by an American painter who made it his residence. He installed art collections and transformed the gardens into flowered terraces overlooking the Gueuzon valley.

The Notre-Dame-de-la-Tronchaye church houses a miraculous statue of the Virgin, found in the 12th century in a hollow oak trunk - hence its name. The 16th-century Flemish altarpiece in polychrome limestone is classified as a Historic Monument.
Place du Puits, at the heart of the town, is surrounded by 16th and 17th-century houses. Sculpted lintels, ornate dormers, and wrought-iron signs recount five centuries of craftsmanship.
The old market halls, converted into a cultural space, preserve their medieval wooden framework. Temporary exhibitions are presented there in season.

Rochefort-en-Terre stands on a rocky spur overlooking the Gueuzon valley. Voted France's Favorite Village in 2016. Classified among The Most Beautiful Villages of France and designated a Small Town of Character.
The château was rebuilt in the early 20th century by American painter Alfred Klots. Built on the ruins of a 12th-century fortress with salvaged materials. Neo-Gothic style.

The château park offers panoramic views over the village rooftops. Gardens arranged on terraces. The Naïa Museum occupies one wing of the château and presents over 300 works of visionary and fantastic art.

Place du Puits is surrounded by overhanging houses from the 16th and 17th centuries. Restored half-timbered façades. Geraniums and ivy overflow from window boxes. Pedestrian historic center in summer.

The Church of Notre-Dame-de-la-Tronchaye blends Romanesque and Flamboyant Gothic styles. Former chapel enlarged in the 16th and 17th centuries for a college of canons. Façade and choir stalls are classified.
Cobbled lanes climb between flowering granite houses. Rue Saint-Michel and Place des Halles concentrate artisan shops and art galleries. Stylized wrought-iron signs.
Café Breton is a historic café housed in a medieval building. Authentic atmosphere.

activities.text: Take the trail that descends toward the Gueuzon valley from the castle gardens. The path follows the stream under a canopy of oaks and beeches.

Walk through the flowered streets following the marked heritage circuit. Each house competes in floral displays - the tradition dates back to the early 20th century, when an American artist launched a facade competition.
Continue to the dry moat overlook behind the castle. The view plunges over the slate roofs of the village and the Morbihan countryside.
Since 1945, the flowering tradition has continued. Alfred Klots created the flowering window contest in 1911. Residents compete with creativity to adorn balconies and façades.
Artisan workshops line the lanes. Potters, embroiderers, glassmakers, and sculptors share their expertise. La Maison des Artisanes brings together local creators.
The Étang du Moulin Neuf lies a 15-minute walk away. Recreation area offering canoe-kayaking, paddleboarding, pedal boats, and a zip line in 37 wooded acres.
In December, the Christmas market transforms the village. Illuminations, decorated trees, and artisan stalls create a magical atmosphere.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage
Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

visits.text: The Soulages Museum opened in 2014 with nearly 500 works by the Rodez-born painter. The architecture by Catalan firm RCR Arquitectes features Corten steel that develops a patina over time. The galleries alternate between varying heights and half-light to showcase Soulages' creative periods.

Notre-Dame Cathedral required 300 years of construction, from the 13th to the 16th century. Its bell tower reaches 87 metres and offers a 360° view after climbing 400 steps. The interior houses ancient and contemporary stained glass windows, a monumental organ, and richly carved choir stalls.

The Fenaille Museum holds the largest collection of statue-menhirs in Europe. These sculptures from the 3rd millennium BC remain enigmatic. The building occupies the Hôtel de Jouéry, saved from demolition in the early 20th century by Maurice Fenaille.

activities.text: Follow the historic centre trail available from the tourist office on Place de la Cité. The numbered route takes you past the Maison d'Armagnac, the bishop's palace, and Renaissance façades.

The market takes place on Wednesday and Saturday mornings. You'll find Aveyron specialities there: farçous, aligot, and Aubrac beef. The brasseries in the centre serve these dishes throughout the week.

days_plan.itin_title: Aveyron Road Trip: Causses, Tarn Gorges and Villages

visits.text: Rogliano gathers seven hamlets scattered across the mountains between 110 and 500 meters elevation. Bettolacce, Magna, Vignale, and Olivo reveal medieval chapels and square towers. The Church of San Michele in Bettolacce features a bell tower separated from the main building following the Pisan tradition.

Macinaggio centers around its marina, the largest in Cap Corse. This is where Pasquale Paoli landed in 1790 after 20 years in exile. The marina hosts shops and artisans in a peaceful atmosphere. Offshore, the Finocchiarola islands are classified as a nature reserve.

Barcaggio spreads its blonde sand beach at the tip of Cap Corse. The isolated hamlet faces the Giraglia islet crowned by its lighthouse. Corsican cows sometimes graze on the sand. The end-of-the-world atmosphere contrasts sharply with the bustle of the east coast.

activities.text: The customs officers' trail runs from Macinaggio toward Centuri for 35 kilometers of wild coastline. The first section to Tamarone beach crosses maquis and secret coves. Count on 3 hours to Barcaggio with spectacular views of the sea and islands.

The beaches of Macinaggio and Tamarone attract swimmers with their crystalline waters. Fine sand bordered by pines and eucalyptus. Popular snorkeling spot for observing fish and rocky seabeds in the marine reserve.

days_plan.itin_title: Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Discover this imposing collegiate church built from 837 onwards. Listed as a Historical Monument since 1840, it blends Romanesque and Gothic architecture. Admire the 14th-century murals in the choir and the embroidered tapestry of the Mystery of the Passion from the 16th century.

Immerse yourself in 4,000 years of footwear history in this former 17th-century convent. Romans was France's luxury shoe capital. The museum displays 16,000 pairs from around the world, including creations by Charles Jourdan and André Pérugia.

Wander the cobbled streets of the historic center, designated a City and Land of Art and History. Admire the 47-meter-high Jacquemart Tower built in 1370, and visit the Old Bridge spanning the Isère since the 11th century. The Sunday morning market was voted France's favorite market.

Explore this medieval village ranked among France's Most Beautiful Villages and voted the French People's Favorite Village 2025. Founded in 1070 around the abbey that became a major pilgrimage site. Navigate the maze of picturesque cobbled alleys and discover artisan workshops.

Visit this remarkable abbey church built between the 12th and 15th centuries, considered one of Dauphiné's most impressive Gothic achievements. Listed as a Historical Monument since 1840, it houses a magnificent sculpted portal and the main altar containing the reliquary of Saint Anthony of Egypt.

activities.text: Discover shoe manufacturing workshops still in operation. Observe every step of shoemaking. Workers share Romans' long tradition and the current revival of small local businesses.

Follow the playful trail of 12 giant shoes scattered throughout Romans' city center. These monumental sculptures pay tribute to the local shoe industry's history. The route covers approximately 3.4 kilometers and is accessible to all.
Housed in the former novitiate and Great Stables, the museum presents two permanent exhibitions on the abbey's medieval history and cloister gardens. Discover the abbey's medieval garden.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir

visits.text: Museum of Sologne in Romorantin-Lanthenay housed in the Chapter Mill beside the Sauldre. This ethnographic museum unveils the secrets of a fascinating territory through an immersive sensory journey. Collections trace Sologne's history, its natural environment of heaths and ponds, its pink-brick architecture, and ancestral customs. Old trades, hunting, and poaching are evoked through authentic objects and detailed reconstructions. Temporary exhibitions regularly enrich the visit. The connection to François I reveals Romorantin's prestigious past when it nearly became the kingdom's capital.

Renaissance heritage of Romorantin testifying to the era when François I envisioned establishing his capital here. The Saint-Pol hotel preserves a remarkable spiral staircase and Renaissance galleries. The chancellery presents a sculpted façade with medallions and friezes. Half-timbered houses line the old town's narrow streets. Canals and bridges spanning the Sauldre lend Venetian charm to the city. Saint-Étienne church dominates the town with its high tower. The remnants evoke Leonardo da Vinci's mad project to divert the Loire and create a grand navigable canal.

Matra Automobile Space in Romorantin celebrates the history of this innovative brand that marked French automotive racing history. Displayed models trace Matra's technical and stylistic evolution since the 1960s. Competition cars victorious at the 24 Hours of Le Mans stand alongside production models like the Bagheera and Murena. Prototypes reveal pioneering engineers' audacity. Period documents and photographs recount this French industrial adventure born in Sologne.

activities.text: Romorantin market on Friday mornings in Place de la Paix animating the entire town center. Sologne producers offer game, poultry, goat cheeses, and locally grown vegetables from family farms. Specialties like Easter pies and fruit tarts delight food lovers. Flowers and vegetable seedlings attract amateur gardeners. The market's convivial atmosphere enables exchanges with locals and discovery of regional products. Cafés open their terraces to welcome regulars for Sunday aperitifs.

Walk through the Sauldre valley winding through wild Sologne. Marked trails follow the river lined with alders and weeping willows. Shimmering ponds attract herons, egrets, and kingfishers in an aquatic ballet. Forests of maritime pines and oaks shelter roe deer and wild boar. Heath landscapes evoke Maurice Genevoix's descriptions in Raboliot. The preserved silence invites contemplation and observation of intact nature.

Discovering Sologne architecture characterized by red-brick houses and flat-tile roofs. Traditional farms present enclosed courtyards with dwellings, barns, and stables arranged around them. Bull's-eye dormers illuminate grain lofts. Monumental chimneys testify to heating's importance in this humid region. Villages preserve Romanesque churches, communal washhouses, and restored bread ovens. This preserved vernacular architecture constitutes authentic rural Sologne's visual identity.

days_plan.itin_title: Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Round Hall.
Saint-Lazare Cathedral.

activities.text: Malsaucy Pond.
Saint-Laurent Island.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: Roquebrune-Cap-Martin — medieval village, alleyways and 10th-century castle (exteriors).
Le Corbusier Promenade — customs officers' path along the cape's coves.
Villa E-1027 (exteriors) — modernist architecture icon by the sea.

activities.text: Coastal walk and swimming breaks in sheltered coves (depending on season).
Ascent to Mont Gros for panorama over Monaco and the Italian Riviera.

days_plan.itin_title: French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary

visits.text: The Roquefort Société caves welcome over 100,000 visitors a year. The one-hour guided tour takes you through natural caves carved beneath the Combalou rock. The fleurines naturally ventilate the caves at 10°C with 80% humidity.

Penicillium roqueforti develops spontaneously in the caves. This mould gives the cheese its characteristic blue-green marbling and flavours. The master refiners carefully select and cultivate their own strains.

Roquefort was the very first AOC in history, granted in 1925. It celebrates its centenary in 2025. The AOP requires raw Lacaune ewe's milk, daily pasturing within the Roquefort area, and ageing in natural caves.
Ascent to Cordes-sur-Ciel, medieval city with cobblestone streets and artisan workshops.
Discovery of the Roquefort aging caves in Roquefort-sur-Soulzon.

activities.text: A tasting of the three Roquefort AOP cheeses concludes the visit. The caves also offer workshops pairing wine and cheese. The standard tour costs €7.50, or €15 for the tour with a guided tasting.
The village is home to seven Roquefort producers. Maison Gabriel Coulet offers a free self-guided tour with a presentation film. The Papillon caves also provide discovery tours.
Tasting of local cheeses in the village of Roquefort.

days_plan.itin_title: Aveyron Road Trip: Causses, Tarn Gorges and Villages
Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages

visits.text: The Notre-Dame-de-Croas-Batz church (16th century) is one of Brittany's most richly decorated. Its Renaissance bell tower, with two superimposed galleries and lantern, bears ship sculptures - ex-votos from shipowners who financed construction.
Shipowners' and privateers' houses line the harbor and Rue Amiral Réveillère. Their sculpted granite facades display maritime details: anchors, rigging, ship prows. Some date from the 16th century.

The Exotic Garden, planted on a rock facing Île de Batz, houses 3,500 plant species from the southern hemisphere. The Gulf Stream warms the coast: cacti, palms, and proteas grow here outdoors, at London's latitude.

The Johnnies House traces the epic of Roscoff pink onion merchants who, from 1828, crossed the Channel by oar to sell their harvest in England. They traveled by cart, onion braids over their shoulders - the quintessential 'Frenchman' image.

The old port, protected by a long jetty, offers views of Île de Batz and the lighthouse. Sainte-Barbe chapel, from the 16th century, stands at the jetty's end - sailors came to pray before putting to sea.

activities.text: Cross to Île de Batz (15 min by boat). The island circuit on foot (10 km) passes the colonial garden, lighthouse (198 steps, 360° view), white sand beaches, and ruins of Romanesque Sainte-Anne chapel.
Follow Roscoff's coastal path eastward to Pointe de Bloscon. Rocks sculpted by erosion, multicolored seaweed, and low-tide pools form a natural aquarium.
Visit the seaweed discovery center. The Léon coast produces 70% of French edible seaweed. Cooking workshops allow you to taste them: seaweed tartare, kombu butter, sea lettuce salad.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Saints-Pierre-et-Paul church (12th century) is one of the finest Romanesque edifices in Alsace. Its frieze of human and animal figures runs along the external cornice. Inside, sculpted capitals blend foliage, masks and fantastical motifs.
The Maison romane (circa 1152), on rue du Général-de-Gaulle, is considered one of the oldest stone civic constructions in Alsace. Its façade preserves Romanesque arcading and twin windows.
Four medieval gates survive in the ramparts: Porte du Lion, Porte de l'École, Porte Basse and Porte de la Vierge. Each retains sculpted door crowns, a unique vestige of Rosheim's medieval décor.
The six-bucket well on Place de la Mairie, and the 16th and 17th-century half-timbered houses complete a dense and homogeneous intra-muros heritage.
Follow the marked heritage route: panels explain the history of this former free imperial city, fortified as early as the 13th century.

activities.text: The Alsace Vineyard Green Way leaves from Rosheim on a disused railway line. By bike or on foot, it crosses vineyards and orchards to Saint-Nabor.
Drive up to Mont Sainte-Odile (13 km): the Pagan Wall, a 10-km megalithic enclosure, rings the summit. The monastery offers a panorama over the Alsace plain.
Rosheim winegrowers cultivate mainly Riesling and Pinot Gris. Cellars open along the main street offer tastings.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: La Piscine in Roubaix is a former 1932 Art Deco Olympic pool transformed into a museum of art and industry. A sheet of water remains from the pool, reflecting a colored glass ceiling depicting the sun. The old shower cabins now house a vast ceramics collection, and rooms display paintings, sculptures and textiles.

In Croix, Villa Cavrois is a manifesto of modernist architecture. Built between 1929 and 1932 for a textile industrialist, its 60-meter yellow brick façade overlooks a reflecting pool. The interior, entirely designed by the architect, features central heating, telephones in every room, and indirect lighting—visionary luxuries for the era.

Cross through Parc Barbieux, a 34-hectare landscaped garden designed in the 19th century. Its paths wind between rolling lawns, flower beds and century-old trees. A canal runs through the entire park.
The Condition Publique, a former 19th-century warehouse where wool was weighed and processed, has become a cultural and arts venue. Its vast red brick halls host exhibitions and performances.

activities.text: Follow the blue line painted on the ground from Roubaix station: it leads straight to La Piscine, crossing downtown and its converted industrial façades.
Roubaix was nicknamed the "city of a thousand chimneys" for its textile mills. Walk among the old red brick factories, some converted into lofts or cultural spaces.
The gardens of Villa Cavrois, a few hundred meters from the villa, extend the walk through a geometric landscape dotted with contemporary structures.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

visits.text: Gros-Horloge — This 14th-century Gothic belfry houses one of Europe's oldest astronomical clocks, with a mechanism dating from 1389. The Renaissance arch built between 1527 and 1529 spans the pedestrian street with its 2.50-meter golden dial depicting a 24-ray sun on a star-studded blue background. A single hand points to the hour while a globe indicates the phases of the moon.

Place du Vieux-Marché — It was in this square that Joan of Arc was burned on May 30, 1431. The Sainte-Jeanne-d'Arc church, inaugurated in 1979, features bold architecture shaped like an inverted flame and houses the Renaissance stained glass windows from the former Saint-Vincent church destroyed during the war.

Saint-Ouen Abbey Church — A masterpiece of Rayonnant Gothic built between the 14th and 16th centuries, this former Benedictine abbey impresses with its 137 meters length and its 14th-century stained glass windows among the most complete in France. Its grand Cavaillé-Coll organ from 1890 has 64 stops.

Musée Le Secq des Tournelles — Housed in the former 15th-century Saint-Laurent church, this museum unique in the world presents 12,000 pieces of ornamental ironwork from the 3rd to 19th century: signs, locks, grilles, everyday objects testifying to the craftsmanship of master blacksmiths.

Panorama Côte Sainte-Catherine — From this 150-meter hill overlooking the left bank, embrace the entire view of Rouen: the cathedral painted by Monet, the spires of Gothic churches, the meanders of the Seine. The viewpoint immortalized by the Impressionists in the 19th century.

Rouen Cathedral — Monet painted this Gothic masterpiece more than 30 times to capture its changing light. Built between the 12th and 16th centuries, its 151-meter cast-iron spire makes it France's tallest. The Lady Chapel and the tombs of Norman dukes bear witness to eight centuries of history.

Palais de Justice de Rouen — This flamboyant Gothic building from the late 15th century was the seat of the Exchequer of Normandy. Its western facade, ornate with sculpted gables and pinnacles, survived the 1944 bombings. The Salle des Pas Perdus reveals medieval vaults.

Musée des Beaux-Arts de Rouen — This museum founded in 1801 houses a major collection of paintings from the 15th to 21st century. Works by Caravaggio, Velázquez, Monet, Sisley and a room dedicated to Géricault born in Rouen illustrate five centuries of European art.
Rouen — stand beneath the lace-like Gothic facade Monet painted dozens of times at Notre-Dame Cathedral
Rouen — walk beneath the Great Clock's Renaissance arch and cross the Place du Vieux-Marché where Joan burned
Rouen Museum of Fine Arts — discover masterpieces from Caravaggio to the Impressionists
Museum of Ceramics — trace Rouen's world-famous faience tradition
Historial Jeanne d'Arc — immerse yourself in Joan of Arc's trial and martyrdom through multimedia storytelling

activities.text: Historial Jeanne d'Arc — Housed in the archbishop's palace where Joan was condemned then rehabilitated, this immersive scenographic journey retraces the destiny of the Maid through testimonies, projections and reconstructions of the 1431 trial.

Rue Eau-de-Robec — This picturesque cobbled street runs along a canal where dyers once washed their fabrics. Its half-timbered houses from the 15th and 16th centuries, restored after the 1944 bombings, plunge the stroller into medieval Rouen.

Jardin des Plantes de Rouen — This 8.5-hectare botanical garden created in 1840 houses more than 5,600 plant species, tropical greenhouses and a rose garden. A green lung in the heart of the city, conducive to strolling among botanical collections and century-old trees.

Aître Saint-Maclou — This unique ossuary from the 16th century is a rare testimony to the plague epidemics. Its half-timbered galleries surrounding a courtyard display macabre sculptures: skulls, bones, gravedigger's tools carved into the beams.

Panorama XXL — This 32-meter-high rotunda hosts giant 360° panoramas. Past exhibitions have transported visitors to ancient Rome, Monet's Rouen or the Amazon. A unique immersive artistic experience in France.

Seine Riverbanks — The redeveloped left bank offers 3 kilometers of walks from the Pierre-Corneille bridge to the Île Lacroix. Guinguettes, floating gardens and barges transformed into cultural venues bring life to the quays.
Half-day walking circuit — lose yourself in the timbered heart of historic Rouen

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Maritime Road Trip: Cliffs of Étretat, Rouen and Jumièges Abbey
Seine-Maritime Road Trip: Cliffs of Étretat, Rouen and Jumièges Abbey
Complete Normandy Road Trip: Dramatic Cliffs, D-Day Beaches & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Notre-Dame of the Assumption Church in yellow sandstone marries the Romanesque transept from the 11th century with a 13th-century Gothic nave. Its rose window with twenty lancets illuminates the western facade.
The Smile of Rouffach carved in stone frames the former sacristy door. Two delicate faces—a young girl and boy—have gazed at the faithful from the choir since medieval times.
The Witches' Tower raises its walls on the old medieval ramparts. Topped with a stork's nest, it recalls the witchcraft trials that once darkened this town.
The Recollets Church built in the 13th century by Franciscan friars expresses the austerity of mendicant orders. An exterior carved pulpit allowed preachers to address crowds gathered in the square.
Isenbourg Castle overlooks Rouffach from its vineyard-covered spur. Built by the Merovingians in the 5th century, it served as a residence for Dagobert II.

activities.text: The Vorbourg Grand Cru wine trail winds between vine rows on limestone hillsides. Gewurztraminer and Riesling flourish on this sun-drenched terroir.
Stroll through Place de la République surrounded by Renaissance houses with stepped gables. The Town Hall with its twin pediments and the former Grain Hall testify to past prosperity.
The Notre-Dame de Schauenberg sanctuary watches over the valley from the forest. The path climbs through vineyards before plunging beneath beech trees.

days_plan.itin_title: Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route

visits.text: The ruins of Château de Rougemont crown the Montagne des Boules at 736 meters altitude. Built in the late 12th century by Count Frédéric II of Ferrette, it guarded the southern gateway to Alsace and the Roman road from Langres to Basel. Besieged in 1375 by Enguerrand de Coucy's mercenaries, it was abandoned and later demolished on Louis XIV's orders in 1673. Restored between 1977 and 1980, the ruins have been a classified historic monument since 1996.

The Chapelle Sainte-Catherine, rebuilt in 1876, stands beside a spring once believed to cure eye ailments. In the 18th and 19th centuries, pilgrimages here were so popular that offerings collected were 75 times greater than those at the parish church.
From the summit, the panorama stretches from the Vosges to the Jura with views of the Swiss Alps on clear days. Rougemont nestles against the mountain at an average elevation of 450 meters.

activities.text: Climb to the castle through forest trails from the Plainot picnic area. This 3-hour circuit traverses 1,249 hectares of communal forest integrated into the Natura 2000 site and the Ballons des Vosges Regional Natural Park.
Follow the botanical trail at Mont Marty. Discover Vosges flora with valley views. This 247-hectare Natura 2000 site preserves forest habitats.

days_plan.itin_title: Territoire de Belfort Road Trip: The Citadel and the Lion

visits.text: Roussillon — village of ochres, colorful facades at the foot of the former quarries.
Ochre cliffs and quarry faces (accessible areas).
Roussillon ranks among France's Most Beautiful Villages. Its ochre-rendered facades display every shade from pale yellow to blood red, drawn from pigments extracted in nearby quarries.

The Sentier des Ocres, nicknamed the "Giants' Causeway," winds between ochre cliffs sculpted by erosion and former mining in red, orange, and yellow. Two marked routes of 30 and 50 minutes cross this mineral landscape shaded by pines.
The Conservatoire des Ocres et Pigments Appliqués, housed in the old Mathieu factory, traces the history of Provence's ochre industry. Demonstrations of pigment production and hands-on workshops.
The Église Saint-Michel dominates Place de la Mairie with its square bell tower. From the nearby orientation table, the gaze sweeps across the Vaucluse plateau, Luberon mountains, and Ventoux.

Six miles away, the Colorado Provençal of Rustrel unfolds 75 acres of wilder ochre formations. Fairy chimneys, the Cirque du Sahara, and the White Desert compose a landscape worthy of the American West.

activities.text: Ochre trail (developed route) — chromatic immersion.
Walk in the pine forests and viewpoints over the Claparèdes plateau.
Follow the Belvédère circuit at Rustrel's Colorado Provençal. This two-hour trail climbs through forest to a panorama overlooking orange dunes and fairy chimneys.
Stroll through art galleries and painters' studios in the village. Ochre has inspired artists for centuries: natural pigments, watercolors, and colored earth appear in canvases.
Late in the day, head to the Castrum overlook to watch the setting sun ignite the ochre cliffs. The colors shift in intensity minute by minute.

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour
Vaucluse: Avignon, Luberon Villages & Ventoux Routes

visits.text: Royan, a seaside resort rebuilt after the 1945 bombings. The 1950s architecture, called 'Les Cinquante Glorieuses', now holds the Ville d'Art et d'Histoire label. Modernist villas, curved seafronts, luminous concrete.

Notre-Dame Church of Royan (1958), a brutalist concrete masterpiece by Guillaume Gillet. A 45-meter elliptical nave, inverted V-shaped vault, abstract stained glass. Controversial at its construction, it is now a listed Historic Monument.

Royan central market, a concrete and glass structure by Louis Simon and André Morisseau (1956). Undulating dome 52 meters in diameter, spectacular natural light. Seafood, orchard fruits, Charentes specialties. One of the finest covered markets in France.

Royan's seafront stretches across 5 beaches: Grande Conche, Foncillon, Chay, Pigeonnier, Pontaillac. Promenade along modernist villas, casino, congress center. Elegant seaside atmosphere facing the Gironde estuary.

activities.text: Guided tour 'Royan 1950s'. The tourist office offers architectural tours with commentary: the Parc district villas, congress center, Protestant temple, bus station. A fresh look at 20th-century heritage.

Grande Conche beach, 2 km of fine sand in an arc. Lifeguarded in summer, surf and sailing schools, terraces facing the ocean. The Cordouan lighthouse, 'Versailles of the sea', stands on the estuary horizon.
Royan-Le Verdon ferry. The 20-minute Gironde estuary crossing offers a unique view of both the Charente and Médoc coasts. Option to continue to Cordouan lighthouse at low tide (guided excursion).

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: Abbaye de Royaumont — 13th‑century Cistercian abbey with cloister, chapter house and landscaped grounds; major cultural festival venue.
Asnières‑sur‑Oise — Village lanes and riverside mills near the abbey estate.

activities.text: Attend a chamber‑music rehearsal or garden event (check calendar); respectful silence in cloister.
Tea room in the former monastic refectory (afternoon).

days_plan.itin_title: Parisian Countryside: Day Trips to Auvers-sur-Oise, Chantilly & Fontainebleau

visits.text: Chapel of the Holy Spirit (treasure).
Belfry.
Old town.

activities.text: Bay of Somme.
Marquenterre Nature Reserve.

days_plan.itin_title: A Road Trip Through the Somme Valley: Cathedrals, History & River Landscapes

visits.text: Joséphine de Beauharnais purchased Château de Malmaison in 1799. Between 1800 and 1802, alongside the Tuileries, it became the seat of French government where Bonaparte received his ministers.
Architects Percier and Fontaine redecorated the château in antique style. The Council Room shaped like a military tent, the library, and Joséphine's oval bedroom exemplify the Consulate style.
The second floor presents objects from Napoleon's exile in Saint Helena: the campaign bed on which his body was displayed, his furniture, and death mask.

activities.text: Joséphine designed the park in English landscape style with help from Scottish gardeners. She cultivated every rose variety known at the time. The restored rose garden now features 150 antique varieties.
Parc des Impressionnistes evokes Giverny with its water garden. Monet, Renoir, and Sisley painted along Rueil's riverbanks.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: 14th century ramparts and Notre-Dame-des-Pommiers chapel.
Old shaded streets and small squares with stone houses.
Route des Défilés: limestone corridor carved into the rock (viewpoints).

activities.text: Pedestrian loop within the walls with survey of defensive elements.
Panoramic stops along the Défilés (car circuit with walking access).

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: The 18th-century Château de Sablé commands the river from its promontory. It replaced the former strategic medieval fortress.
The neo-Gothic Notre-Dame church preserves exceptional late 15th-century stained glass windows: the Crucifixion, the life of Christ, and Mary Magdalene.
The half-timbered medieval houses of the Saint-Nicolas quarter reveal intricate ironwork and decorative roof finials. The winding lanes captivate visitors.
The Marble Ecomuseum traces marble-working activity from the 17th to 20th centuries. Discover the quarries, tools, and iconic creations.
The cookie workshops perpetuate the tradition of golden, crumbly sablé biscuits. Tours available to savor the scent of fresh butter.

activities.text: Walk along the banks of the Sarthe from the marina, the most vibrant in western France.
Take a river cruise departing from Sablé. The navigable Sarthe reveals its rolling landscapes.
Visit the weekly market to sample rillettes, goat cheeses, and homemade pastries. Authentic Sarthe flavors.

days_plan.itin_title: Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Écomusée de Marquèze: Exceptional immersion in an authentic 19th-century Landes hamlet, accessible only by historic train from 1903-1910 (Monument Historique carriages) from Sabres. After a 10min journey through the forest, discover the 25-hectare airial where 30 to 40 people once lived. Half-timbered manor houses and Landes farmhouses dating from the 18th and 19th centuries, sheepfolds, water mill on stilts relocated from Geloux, bread ovens under centuries-old oaks.

Traditional craft demonstrations: Costumed interpreters explain pine resin tapping, spinning, weaving, bread making, pastoral life with stilt shepherds. Traditional Gascon games (palet, rampeau, nine-pins). The ecomuseum testifies to the evolution of the Landes landscape, from wet moorland to industrial forest imposed by Napoleon III in 1857. Tasting of pastis landais baked in wood-fired oven.

Le Pavillon: Contemporary building presenting permanent exhibition on the history of Landes de Gascogne and annual temporary exhibition. Modern architecture contrasting with the airial's traditional buildings. Interactive and wheelchair-accessible museum route. Video projections and sound testimonies complete the visit.

activities.text: Historic train journey: Boarding at Sabres station in 1903-1910 carriages classified as Historic Monuments. 10min forest crossing on the former Sabres-Labouheyre-Mimizan line. Rear platform recommended on return for panoramic view. Regular departures throughout the day. Single ticket includes train and airial access.

Participatory workshops: Introduction to Landes stilts, Gascon games, straw weaving, artisan soap making according to schedule. Activities for all ages. Activity booklets for children transforming the visit into a treasure hunt. Theatrical scenes on certain days with costumed actors. Digital tour with tablets available at reception.

Full day at the ecomuseum: On-site dining with Landes specialties. Shaded picnic area. Craft product shop (pastis landais, soaps, honey). Allow 4 to 6h to fully enjoy the site. Themed guided tours on certain days. Hours 10am-7pm in high season (April 1 - September 28). Booking advised for groups.

days_plan.itin_title: Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: Saignon — eagle's nest above Apt, cobbled alleys, gates and fountains.
Saignon Rock — impregnable belvedere over the Apt valley.

activities.text: Ascent to the rock by the stairs (360° view).
Route along the ramparts and the Clock Tower (ext.).

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour

visits.text: Saint-Affrique stretches along the banks of the Sorgues in the heart of the Grands Causses Regional Natural Park. The Pont-Vieux, listed as a Historic Monument, connects the two banks. The centre retains stone houses, small squares, and vaulted passageways.

The Rocher de Caylus offers a panoramic view over the town and surrounding hills. A cross tops this landmark site. The Notre-Dame de la Miséricorde Church features a tall Gothic spire visible from afar.

The Maison de la Mémoire du Pays Saint-Affricain displays objects, stories, and photographs of daily life in times past. The Tribunal des Arts occupies the former courthouse and exhibits works by local artists.

activities.text: The Saturday morning market brings the town centre to life. Producers sell local cheeses (Pérail, Roquefort, Recuite), charcuterie, and regional specialities. The atmosphere is friendly and Aveyron delicacies are plentiful.

The landscapes around Saint-Affrique range from blazing red rougiers to wild causses and green valleys. The Rougier de Camarès to the south offers spectacular red-earth terrain. Hiking, mountain biking, and rock climbing are all available in the area.

days_plan.itin_title: Aveyron Road Trip: Causses, Tarn Gorges and Villages

visits.text: Fortified abbey and hamlet in golden stone.

activities.text: Village walkway and short viewpoints.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: Saint-Amand-les-Eaux: baroque abbey tower & thermal park.

activities.text: State forest walk + thermal relaxation.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-France: Opal Coast Cliffs, Medieval History & Great War Sites

visits.text: The Château de Montrond dominates the Cher from its rocky spur. Built in the 11th century, rebuilt in the 15th, it belonged to the Princes of Condé. The keep, curtain walls and towers offer a good overview of military fortifications from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance. The interior houses the Musée Saint-Vic (archaeology, regional history). Guided tours in summer.

The fortress witnessed major moments in French history. In 1569, during the Wars of Religion, it held against Protestant troops. In 1651, the Great Condé took refuge there after the Fronde. In 1652, the young Louis XIV came to besiege it. The curtain wall still bears traces of cannonballs.

Saint-Amand-Montrond calls itself the "City of Gold." The town has 300 goldsmiths and jewelers, a quarter of French national production. The craft has been present since the 19th century; today it mixes tradition and contemporary creation. Several workshops welcome visitors by appointment. The Cité de l'Or, opened in 2019, explains working techniques, history and showcases creations.

activities.text: The Cher and Berry Canal crosses Saint-Amand. Towpath, locks, canal bridges: a pleasant 5 km walk follows the waterway. You can spot herons, grebes, sometimes a kingfisher. The canal, dug between 1830 and 1840, connected the Loire to the Allier; barges transported coal, wood, wine.

Saint-Amand's Saturday morning market is one of Berry's liveliest. Local producers, cheeses, charcuterie, vegetables, artisan breads. In season, asparagus, strawberries, melons from nearby farms. Also clothing, household goods. Covered market + outdoor stands.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: Saint-Andiol — village of the Rhône corridor, straight streets and religious heritage.
Small squares and irrigation canal on the edge of farms.

activities.text: Countryside route towards the orchard-olive grove terroir.
Heritage trail (oratories, washhouses).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Gothic abbey (14th century) dominating the town; sculpted facade and adjoining cloister.
Cobbled streets with half-timbered houses, small squares and remnants of ramparts.
Viewpoints over the Isère plain and the edge of the Vercors.

activities.text: Heritage loop within the walls (2–3 km) between abbey, collegiate church and ramparts.
Hillside path for landscape reading towards the western Vercors.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: The Romanesque House, built around 1150, is France's oldest surviving civilian building. Restored by Viollet-le-Duc in the 19th century, it houses a museum dedicated to prehistory and folk traditions.
Explore medieval lanes where half-timbered houses and carved facades follow one another. The Maison de l'Amour displays two lovers carved in stone since the 15th century.
Descend to the Bessarel quarter where old tanneries survive. Canals once channeled water for treating hides that made the town's fortune.
The 19th-century market hall rises at the square's center. The Sunday market has attracted pilgrims and residents for centuries.
Reach the belvedere at the foot of Roc d'Anglars. This 90-meter limestone cliff dominates the confluence of the Aveyron and Bonnette rivers.

activities.text: Paddle the Aveyron Gorges by canoe. Sheer cliffs, ancient bridges, and natural beaches line the emerald river.
Climb routes on the limestone cliffs. Roc d'Anglars and Pech Dax offer climbs for all levels.
Browse the Sunday morning market renowned for local products. Goat cheese, honey, and charcuterie spread beneath the hall and across the square.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: The Saint-Avold American Cemetery and Memorial, inaugurated in 1960, is the largest American World War II cemetery in Europe. On 46 hectares of perfectly maintained lawns, 10,489 white marble crosses and Stars of David align in impeccable symmetry, honoring American soldiers who fell during the liberation of France, Luxembourg, and Germany in 1944-1945. The memorial chapel in Vosges sandstone displays battle maps and the Wall of the Missing with 444 names. An overwhelming place of remembrance.

The Saint-Nabor basilica, built between 1755 and 1764, is a baroque jewel in Vosges sandstone. Its 60-meter bell towers dominate the city, topped by bulbous domes typical of Central Europe. The interior amazes with stucco decorations, gilded woodwork, and trompe-l'oeil frescoes. The main organ, built in 1782 by Jean-Conrad Sauer, is one of the most beautiful baroque organs in Lorraine. The crypt houses the relics of Saint Nabor.
Ébersviller — Illuminated outdoor nativity scene near Saint-Pierre church (1878).
Boulay-Moselle — Saint-Étienne Church (1782): nativity scene at Mary's altar, remarkable organ.
Longeville-lès-Saint-Avold — Saint-Magne Church (neogothic), restored 1905/06 organ, sculpted stations of the cross.
Saint-Avold — Saint-Nabor Abbey Church: traditional nativity scene (according to period).
Saint-Avold — Sainte-Jeanne-d'Arc, Saint-Joseph and Saint-Jean-Bosco Churches: nativity scenes (worship service hours).
Folschviller — Sainte-Barbe Residence: traditional nativity scene (15/12–14/01, 2pm–5pm).
Altviller — Village nativity scene with dressed figurines (patchwork club).

activities.text: Visit the Saint-Avold mining museum, installed in the former Merlebach mine. The exhibitions retrace 150 years of coal extraction (1856-2004): miners' equipment, gallery reconstruction, pneumatic tools, and documentation on working conditions. Educational circuit in surface buildings, testimonies from former miners. The mining towers, industrial heritage from the 20th century, dominate the landscape.

Stroll in the Vallon du Parc, a 15-hectare landscaped park surrounding the Château de Beausoleil. Tree-lined paths, ornamental ponds, rose gardens, and century-old trees compose a green setting. Children's playgrounds, picnic areas, and sports facilities. The Baroque-style castle (18th century) houses administrative services. Free access year-round, ideal for family walks.
Saint-Avold — Urban walk between the abbey church, stained glass windows and neighborhood nativity scenes.
Organ or Christmas carol listening (according to parish schedule).

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass
The Moselle Nativity Route: A Festive Christmas Road Trip Through Border Villages

visits.text: Saint-Béat is the marble village. Quarried since Roman times, this white marble was used for numerous monuments including the Paris Opera Garnier. The village church is entirely in marble. The old quarries on the mountainside can be visited.
The 11th-12th century château dominates the town. Its ruins testify to Saint-Béat's strategic importance controlling the passage to Spain.

activities.text: The Spanish border is very close. The valley narrows between mountains. The landscapes become truly mountainous with peaks exceeding 2,000 meters.
Hikes depart from Saint-Béat toward surrounding peaks. The trails often follow ancient Roman roads. The Garonne here is just a mountain torrent.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: Saint-Jacques Basilica (unique Romanesque rotunda in France).
George Sand and Vallée Noire Museum.
White Tower.
Saint-Roch Hospice Museum.

activities.text: Painter artists.
Creuse Gorges.
George Sand's House in Nohant (nearby).

days_plan.itin_title: Indre, France: Secret Berry Region and Vallée Noire Rural Villages

visits.text: Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges, labeled "Most Beautiful Villages of France," "Great Occitanie Site," and "Remarkable Heritage Site," occupies a promontory at 515 meters altitude overlooking the Comminges plain. The medieval city unfolds in winding, steep streets around the cathedral, with a fortified enclosure called "scepte" that gathered the episcopal palace, canonical houses, cemetery, and cloister. The city walls incorporate numerous stones and sculptures reused from ancient Lugdunum Convenarum.

The Cathedral of Sainte-Marie, classified as a Historic Monument in 1840 and inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1998 as part of the Ways of Saint James, is a Romano-Gothic edifice whose construction dates to around 1100. Bishop Bertrand de l'Isle (1083-1123), canonized in 1218, had the Romanesque cathedral and first cloister built. In 1307, Bertrand de Got, who became Pope Clement V, launched reconstruction of the Gothic apse and choir, and had Saint-Bertrand's relics transported in 1309.

The cathedral interior holds exceptional treasures. The carved Renaissance choir stalls, commissioned by Bishop Jean de Mauléon (1523-1551), are among France's finest. The organ, built in the 16th century at an angle on five Corinthian oak columns, rises to sixteen meters high and has three keyboards, a thirty-note pedal board, forty stops, and 2,621 pipes - it is considered one of Europe's most beautiful classical organs. The treasury preserves embroidered copes offered by Clement V, including the Cope of the Passion depicting scenes from Christ's passion, and Saint-Bertrand's pastoral staff, carved from a narwhal tusk.

The Romano-Gothic cloister from the 12th to 14th centuries, adjoining the cathedral, consists of four galleries from distinct periods: the western Romanesque gallery is the oldest, the southern and eastern galleries date from the first half of the 13th century, and the northern gallery, the only one vaulted, dates from the 14th century. Its openings onto nature, pierced in the early 20th century, offer an unexpected panorama over the Pyrenees. A stuffed crocodile, an ex-voto brought from the Holy Land in the 14th century, hangs in one of the galleries.

The remains of Lugdunum Convenarum, a Gallo-Roman city among the most important in Roman Aquitaine, extend at the hill's foot. Founded in the Augustan era, the city had up to ten thousand inhabitants at its peak before being destroyed in 585 during Frankish succession wars. Excavations, conducted from 1913 to 1970 then resumed from 1985 to 2006, have uncovered a theater of five thousand spectators from the 1st century, a temple of imperial cult in Pyrenean marble, a forum, baths, and a Christian basilica. The Augustan trophy, in white Saint-Béat marble, is one of the most complete found in France. The upper town ramparts, from the 5th century, are listed as a Historic Monument.

The Basilica of Saint-Just de Valcabrère, classified as a Historic Monument and inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List like the cathedral, is an isolated Romanesque edifice in the middle of fields, a few hundred meters from Saint-Bertrand. Built on the site of a Roman necropolis whose stones it reuses, it is mentioned as early as Bishop Bertrand's time (1083-1123). Remains of a cloister and annex buildings testify to a former regular canonical house.

Sainte-Marie Cathedral dominates Saint-Bertrand from its rocky pinnacle. Built from the 11th century and transformed through the 16th, it blends Romanesque and Gothic. The 66 oak choir stalls (16th century) feature remarkable sculptures. The monumental organ, 16 meters high, is one of Europe's finest. It rests on five columns and its case depicts the labors of Hercules. The treasury displays embroidered copes gifted by Pope Clement V.

The 12th-century cloister has a unique feature: openings to the surrounding landscapes created in the early 20th century. This Romanesque gallery offers views of mountains and valley. At the center, the Evangelists' Pillar bears zodiacal sculptures on a Roman column recovered from the ancient site.

The ancient site of Lugdunum Convenarum extends across the plain. This prosperous Roman city had 30,000 inhabitants. You'll see vestiges of the forum, theater, baths, and covered market. Ruins of an early Christian basilica testify to the site's early Christianization.

The Basilica of Saint-Just de Valcabrère lies 2 km below. This 12th-century Romanesque church was built with stones salvaged from the Roman site. Its simplicity and Tuscan setting amid meadows create a peaceful atmosphere. It's also a UNESCO World Heritage site.

The Cathedral of Sainte-Marie, a classified Historic Monument since 1840 and inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List as part of the Ways of St. James of Compostela, has dominated the village since the 11th century. Bertrand de l'Isle erected the Romanesque cathedral around 1100; it was enlarged in the 14th century by Bertrand de Got, future Pope Clement V, who imposed the Gothic style. The bell tower gives the edifice the air of an impregnable fortress.

The Renaissance choir houses 66 oak choir stalls carved in the 16th century under Bishop Jean de Mauléon, considered among the finest in France. The monumental organ, also commissioned by Mauléon, rises 52 feet on five Corinthian columns; it has 3 manuals, 40 stops, and 2,621 pipes. The treasury preserves copes embroidered in opus anglicanum offered by Clement V, and St. Bertrand's pastoral staff made from narwhal tusk.

The cloister, built in the 13th century and remodeled under Clement V, has the distinctive feature of galleries open to the surrounding nature. It served as a prayer space and burial ground for canons. The western Romanesque gallery is the oldest, while the 14th-century north gallery is the only vaulted one. At the center, a stuffed crocodile recalls the legend of St. Bertrand slaying a monster.

The Gallo-Roman archaeological site of Lugdunum Convenarum spreads across the plain at the foot of the cathedral. Capital of the Convenae founded in the 1st century BC, the city included a forum, theater, market, and baths that made it a little Pyrenean Rome. A trophy of Augustus, an exceptional sculpted composition, was erected around 16 BC after victories over the Aquitanians.

The Basilica of Saint-Just de Valcabrère, a few hundred yards away, is one of the oldest Christian churches in southern Gaul. Built largely with stones from the Roman site on an ancient necropolis, it's inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List. Its Romanesque architecture and countryside setting reminiscent of Tuscany make it a jewel of serenity.

The medieval Upper Town reveals itself on foot through picturesque lanes leading to the cathedral. Les Olivétains, a former monastery of monks from Monte Oliveto in Italy, now houses the tourist information office, a bookshop, a local products boutique, and contemporary art exhibition halls.

Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges occupies a promontory at 515 m elevation, facing the Pyrenees. For 13 centuries, this tiny village of 250 inhabitants housed the bishopric seat of Comminges. Its history reaches back to the Roman city of Lugdunum Convenarum, founded in the 1st century BCE.

The cathedral of Sainte-Marie, inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage, blends Romanesque and Gothic. In the 11th century, Bertrand de l'Isle erected a first Romanesque cathedral. In the 14th, Bertrand de Got—future Pope Clement V—transformed it by imposing the southern Gothic style.
Inside, the Renaissance choir stalls (16th century) form one of France's finest woodwork ensembles. Count over 300 carved oak panels depicting secular themes, including the labors of Hercules.

The 16th-century classical organ, uniquely angled, rests on five Corinthian columns. Its case rises to 16 meters. It has 2,621 pipes, three keyboards, and 40 stops. Abandoned during the Revolution, it was restored in the 20th century.

The cloister, built in the 13th century, possesses a unique feature: its openings to the surrounding nature, pierced in the early 20th century. The western Romanesque gallery is the oldest; the northern vaulted gallery dates from the 14th century.

In the plain at the village foot, ruins of Lugdunum Convenarum spread: forum, baths, ancient theater, and early Christian basilica. A trophy sculpted around 16 BCE commemorates Augustus's victories over the Aquitanians.
Walk to the basilica of Saint-Just de Valcabrère, a few hundred meters away. Built largely with recovered Roman stones, it stands in a setting some compare to Tuscany.

activities.text: Devote the morning to the cathedral, taking time to admire the carved choir stalls, climb to observe the monumental organ, and tour the cloister to the openings onto the Pyrenees - morning light is particularly beautiful there.

Descend to the ancient site of Lugdunum Convenarum to walk among the remains of the theater, forum, and baths. A single ticket sold at the Musée Les Olivétains gives access to the cathedral, basilica, and archaeological site.
Walk to the Basilica of Saint-Just de Valcabrère via the path through fields - the gradual approach to this solitary Romanesque edifice in its green setting is one of the visit's highlights.
Visit the Musée Les Olivétains, installed in a former convent, which offers a common ticket office, bookstore, exhibitions, and local products. Guided tours can be reserved on site.
If the schedule permits, attend a Festival du Comminges concert in the cathedral: the acoustic qualities of the organ and nave give works performed here exceptional resonance.
Wander the medieval lanes of the fortified village. Noble houses, vaulted passages, and ramparts tell 2,000 years of history. The three entrance gates blend into the rock itself.
The Festival du Comminges takes place in July and August. Classical music concerts resonate in the cathedral, showcasing the exceptional organ. The acoustics of the space are magnificent.

Four historical walks are offered (30 minutes to 2 hours): the town and its suburb, the archaeological promenade, the three sanctuaries, and the medieval city. The brochure is available at the cathedral reception.

The Festival du Comminges brings the cathedral and basilica to life each summer with classical music and organ concerts in an exceptional acoustic setting. The Renaissance organ, restored thanks to the festival, recovers a sound aesthetic close to that of the 17th century.

Hikes in the Pyrenean foothills with views of Pic de Cagire, Pic du Gar, and the Garonne basin. Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges, at 1,690 feet elevation, offers panoramas over the surrounding mountains and marks a stop on the Ways to Compostela.

Four marked walks link Saint-Bertrand to Valcabrère (from 30 min to 2h). The archaeological walk crosses the Roman ruins; the three sanctuaries circuit links cathedral, early Christian basilica, and Saint-Just.
In summer, the Festival du Comminges animates the cathedral and basilica with classical and sacred music concerts. The restored organ rediscovers its 17th-century sonorities for an evening.
The former Olivetan convent, on the cathedral square, houses a cultural center with temporary contemporary art exhibitions, specialized bookshop, and local products.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: From Tarbes to Cirques and Valleys
Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees
Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: Lourdes, Gavarnie & Pic du Midi
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Notre-Dame Collegiate Church. For over 600 years, this Gothic masterpiece has crowned Saint-Bonnet-le-Château from its hilltop perch. Built between the early 15th and 16th centuries, it impresses through austere grandeur and sheer scale. From the parvis, sweeping views embrace the Forez plain, the Massif Central, the Pilat mountains, and on clear days, the Alps themselves. The lower chapel preserves early 15th-century murals among the finest in France. The crypt holds mysteriously preserved natural mummies discovered in a 17th-century vault—bodies that refuse to decay.

Medieval Fortified Town. 14th-century ramparts still encircle portions of the medieval core. Cobbled lanes lined with 15th- and 16th-century burgher houses testify to past prosperity. The Porte Louis Mandrin and Porte de la Châtelaine mark the old fortified gateways. The village retains its medieval character through aristocratic residences, vaulted passages, and hidden squares. The ensemble speaks of tanners, weavers, armorers, and locksmiths who once made this town thrive.

International Pétanque and Boules Museum. Set in the town center, this museum celebrates Saint-Bonnet as the birthplace of OBUT boules, created in 1955. That year, locksmith Frédéric Bayet partnered with mechanic Antoine Dupuy to create the marque de la 'boule à jouer'—the playing ball that would conquer the world. Exhibitions trace manufacturing techniques, different types of boules, and the game's history. Saint-Bonnet has mastered metalworking for centuries; OBUT simply channeled that craft into spheres.

activities.text: Rail Adventure Greenway. A family-friendly voie verte follows a former railway line between Estivareilles and Saint-Marcellin-en-Forez. This multi-kilometer path winds through the Forez countryside. A cheerful railway worker mascot accompanies visitors along the trail. A vintage 1950s tourist train also runs for families—children especially love it.

Medieval and Renaissance Heritage Walk. Self-guided walk with map available at the Tourist Office. Questionnaire-game for children. Ramparts promenade offering surrounding views. Weekly Friday market where local producers sell regional specialties.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Céneri-le-Gérei — "painters' village" on the Sarthe.
The 11th-century Romanesque church commands the village from its rocky spur. Its 12th and 14th-century frescoes, restored in 2006, are masterpieces.
The church's stations of the cross, created by Christian Malézieux, features fourteen stations instead of the usual twelve to mark the year 2000.
Walking around the choir, discover the beehive carved into the stone. Bees have protected the church since the 9th century.
The 15th-century Chapel of Little Saint-Céneri rises in a vast meadow. Its chestnut framework forms an inverted boat hull.
Legend has it that young women who stick a pin in Saint Céneri's statue feet will find a husband within the year.
Cross the stone bridge for the iconic perspective of the perched church. A magnificent view over the Sarthe.
The Auberge des Soeurs Moisy, converted into a museum, evokes the Saint-Céneri School. 19th-century painters lodged here.

activities.text: Left bank/right bank loop & stone bridge.
The miraculous fountain, born from Saint Céneri's prayer, supposedly heals certain eye diseases according to legend.
Follow the 'Saint-Céneri sur le Motif' educational trail leading to locations favored by painters of the Saint-Céneri School.
Hike in the Alpes Mancelles from Saint-Céneri. The Haut-Fourché rocks, Toyères cliff, and natural amphitheater await.

days_plan.itin_title: Normandy's Classic Coast: Étretat Cliffs and Bocage Countryside Villages
Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Route Najac → Saint-Cirq-Lapopie through valleys and gorges — photo stops on viewpoints.
Saint-Cirq-Lapopie — climb through the cobbled streets, corbelled houses and art workshops.
Church of Saint-Cirq-Lapopie — forecourt as viewpoint over the Lot valley.
Stroll through the cobbled streets of Saint-Cirq-Lapopie, classified among the most beautiful villages in France.

Saint-Cirq-Lapopie clings to a limestone cliff 100 meters above the Lot River. France's Favorite Village, it boasts thirteen listed historical monuments and fewer than 200 residents. Houses from the 12th to 15th centuries, with brown-tile roofs, cascade toward the river below.

Climb to the Rocher de Lapopie, the village's highest point. Ruins of a 10th–12th-century fortress crown the summit. The 360° panorama embraces the Lot Valley, limestone cliffs, and the village rooftops spread beneath your feet.

The 12th-century fortified church dominates the village from its rocky promontory. Its bell tower doubled as a defensive structure during troubled medieval times. Inside, simple furnishings and understated decor invite quiet contemplation.

Descend Rue de la Couronnerie, the main medieval thoroughfare lined with artisan workshops and stone-arched houses. Place du Sombral, the village heart, offers a shady rest stop. At the far end, the Porte de la Pélissaria opens onto the path leading down to the Lot.

The former Mariniers Inn, perched on the cliff edge, once enchanted a Surrealist poet who settled here and famously declared he never wanted to be anywhere else. His house-studio, now an artists' residency, is recognizable by its facade hanging over the void.
Pass through the Porte de Rocamadour, a fortified gateway in the medieval ramparts. Remnants of the defensive wall are still visible along the path that circles the upper village.

Saint-Cirq-Lapopie clings to a cliff 100 meters above the Lot River. A village of 13 classified historic monuments, it was elected France's Favorite Village in 2012. Its houses from the 13th to 15th centuries blend half-timbered façades, ochre stone, and brown-tiled roofs.
Climb to the Rocher de Lapopie at the village summit. From here, a 360° panorama: the ochre roofs below, the Lot's loop glittering between green cliffs, and the Quercy causse on the horizon.

The fortified church has dominated the village since the 13th century. Its elevated position and thick walls recall that it also served as a refuge during attacks. Inside, modest altarpiece and furnishings contrast with the architecture's strength.

Poet André Breton discovered Saint-Cirq one June evening in 1950 and made it his summer residence. The Daura-Breton Houses shelter a contemporary art center and panoramic gardens overlooking the valley.
Descend via rue de la Pélissaria, lined with medieval arcades and Renaissance mullioned windows. Artisan shops—wood turners, leatherworkers—perpetuate the trades that brought prosperity to the town.
The Rignault Museum occupies a traditional village house. Its flower gardens offer an intimate view of the roofs and river, far from the main street's crowds.

activities.text: Viewpoints of Saint-Cirq (high viewpoint) — sunset photo session.
Short walk on the towpath (Bouziès, section carved into the rock) — easy round trip.
Observation of the panorama over the Lot valley at sunset.

Walk the towpath between Bouziès and Saint-Cirq-Lapopie, carved into the cliff face 80 meters above the Lot between 1843 and 1847 for horses pulling barges. Along the way, a 30-meter bas-relief sculpted into the rock depicts the valley's fauna, flora, and fossils. The route passes through the manual lock at Ganil.

Board a traditional flat-bottomed gabare from Bouziès. These historic boats navigate the Lot, passing through locks with commentary on river navigation history and views of the cliffs and perched village.
Rent a canoe, kayak, or stand-up paddleboard at the river's edge below the village. Outfitters offer routes of varying lengths, with shuttle service or loop options.
Join the towpath below the village. This walk follows the Lot along an old route where horses once pulled cargo boats. Flat, shaded trail, ideal for families.
In summer, Saint-Cirq-Lapopie's beach at the village foot offers supervised swimming in the Lot, with a fine sand beach and views of the cliffs.
Outfitters along the Lot offer canoe or stand-up paddle descents. The stretch between Bouziès and Saint-Cirq passes through sculpted cliffs and the Défilé des Anglais.
The Chapelle Sainte-Croix loop (3.3 km) starts above the village and crosses the Quercy causse. Unusual view of Saint-Cirq from above.

days_plan.itin_title: Bastide Villages of France: Cliffside Abbeys & Medieval Fortified Towns

visits.text: Cathedral.
Pipe and Diamond Museum.
Bienne Gorges.
Village resort.
Fort des Rousses (comté cheese caves).
Lake of Rousses.
