days_plan.itin_title: Jura Mountains Road Trip, France: Comtois Traditions & Emerald Lakes

visits.text: Catherine de' Medici acquired the estate in 1577. Louis XIV gifted it to his brother Philippe d'Orléans in 1658. The château, set ablaze in 1870 during the Franco-Prussian War, was razed in 1891.
The Grande Cascade, a 17th-century hydraulic masterpiece, spans 92 meters. Jets, bubbling fountains, and basins compose a water spectacle. The Grand Jet basin shoots water over 40 meters high.
Pavillon de Breteuil houses the International Bureau of Weights and Measures. Two exemplars of the meter and kilogram standards are preserved here.

activities.text: The 460-hectare national park unfolds with formal French gardens designed by Le Nôtre, groves, and terraced allées. The summit at 161 meters offers sweeping views over Paris.
The Rock en Seine festival takes over the estate each summer.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: The marina features 1,885 berths, Europe's third-largest port by capacity. Developed since 1967 with three protected basins, modern harbor master's office, and services for boaters.
The Saint-Cyprien Collections display 19th- and 20th-century paintings. Eugène Boudin, Barbizon School, Utrillo, Marquet, Modigliani, and François Desnoyer enrich the galleries.
The Botanical Garden spans five hectares in the Villa des Capellans park. Over 800 plant species, bamboo grove, antique roses, and contemporary sculptures.
The Saint-Cyprien Resort Golf offers an 18-hole and a 9-hole course. Links-style atmosphere with views of the Pyrenees and Mediterranean.

activities.text: Practice sailing or motorboating. The Yacht Club offers lessons and boat rentals for cruising along the coast.
Enjoy the water sports center on the golf lake. Water skiing, wakeboarding, towable tubes, paddleboarding, and windsurfing available.
Relax on the long fine sandy beach. Six kilometers of Blue Flag coastline with beach clubs and entertainment.
Discover the port fountain that cleans the waters. Built in 1991, it draws seawater and injects it into the harbor to eliminate odors.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: The first masterpiece of Gothic architecture, the cathedral basilica houses over 70 sculpted recumbent effigies from the 12th to 16th centuries. Forty-two kings and thirty-two queens rest beneath its vaults, from Dagobert to Louis XVI.

Descend into the crypt to discover the burial site of Saint Denis, martyred around 250 AD. Eight effigies commissioned by Saint Louis stand alongside the monumental tomb of François I and Catherine de Medici.

The Paul Éluard Museum of Art and History occupies a former Carmelite monastery founded in 1625. Its collections trace the history of the 1871 Paris Commune, the Hôtel-Dieu apothecary, and the life of the surrealist poet.
Step into the Fabrique de la Ville, an educational center dedicated to archaeology and excavations that reveal two thousand years of Saint-Denis history.
The Saint-Denis market brings together nearly 220 permanent merchants. Stalls overflow with spices, fabrics, and products from around the world.

activities.text: Follow Saint-Denis's historic trail: 20 markers chart the route between the Stade de France and the basilica, tracing 2,000 years of history along the canal.
The Street Art Avenue runs along the Saint-Denis canal for 5 km between the Stade de France and Parc de la Villette. Some forty monumental murals bring color to the banks.
Stroll through Parc de la Légion d'Honneur in the heart of downtown. In spring, the Tulip Festival transforms the lawns into a botanical rainbow.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-Saint-Denis Circuit: Royal Basilica and Urban Culture

visits.text: Visit of the Cathedral of Saint-Dié-des-Vosges and the cloister
Discovery of the Pierre-Noël Museum and the Celtic Camp of la Bure

activities.text: Visit of the Trainland museum, on the history of miniature trains

days_plan.itin_title: Vosges Abbeys and Mountains: Monastic Heritage and Green Valley Silence

visits.text: Lac du Der, Europe's largest artificial lake, spans 4,800 hectares. Created between 1964 and 1974, it regulates Marne River floods upstream from Paris.
The Village-Musée du Der chronicles the story of three villages submerged beneath the lake. The half-timbered church from Nuisement-aux-Bois was dismantled and reassembled piece by piece.
Half-timbered churches dot the region. Built from wood and cob, these 15th-, 16th-, and 17th-century structures—like the one in Châtillon-sur-Broué—represent unique architectural heritage.
Saint-Dizier's château, now the sub-prefecture, dates from the 13th century. Three towers connected by curtain walls survive from the medieval fortifications.
Notre-Dame church preserves an Entombment sculpture. 16th-century half-timbered houses surround it.
The Petit Paris façade at 478 avenue de la République displays Art Brut style. Created with pottery shards and seashells, it exemplifies 20th-century folk art.

activities.text: Observe common cranes from October through March. Between 200,000 and 350,000 birds migrate through annually, with 20,000 to 30,000 wintering on the lake—one of Europe's great wildlife spectacles.
Cycle the 38-kilometer lake circuit. Bike paths and greenways traverse the Champagne bocage and follow the feeder canal from Saint-Dizier.
Relax on one of six sandy beaches. Sailing, windsurfing, and waterskiing complement swimming and sunbathing.
Follow the Route des Églises à Pans de Bois. Eleven timber-framed churches comprise this architectural heritage unique in France.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: The medieval village of Saint-Émilion has been a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1999. Perched on a rocky promontory, it preserves cobbled streets, ramparts, and honey-colored stone houses. The village welcomes over one million visitors annually. Take time to wander the lanes discovering artisan shops, wine cellars, and ancient buildings.

Saint-Émilion's Monolithic Church is Europe's largest underground church, carved from limestone in the 11th-12th centuries. The Gothic bell tower, standing 68 meters high, can be climbed for panoramic views of the village and vineyards (118 steps). The church interior can only be visited on guided tours organized by the tourist office. The dimensions are impressive: 38 meters long, 20 meters wide, 11 meters high.

The King's Tower, a 13th-century Romanesque keep, is the only remaining vestige of Saint-Émilion's château. Standing 32 meters tall, it's open for self-guided visits. The 118 steps lead to the top where you'll discover 360° views over the village, tiled roofs, surrounding vineyards, and the Dordogne Valley. It's Saint-Émilion's best viewpoint.

The Cordeliers Cloister is a 14th-century former Franciscan convent transformed into a sparkling wine cellar. The underground galleries, carved from limestone, now house Crémant production. The visit combines historical heritage with discovery of traditional sparkling winemaking methods. Tasting included in the visit. The cloister garden is highly photogenic.

Saint-Émilion's catacombs form a network of underground galleries developed during the Romanesque period. These former limestone quarries served as burial sites and ossuaries. The guided tour reveals the fascinating history of these mysterious places. The atmosphere is special with constant coolness (14°C) and plays of light and shadow.
Medieval city and monolithic church bell tower (UNESCO).
Porte Brunet and panorama over the vineyards.

activities.text: Visit and tasting at a Saint-Émilion wine château. The appellation counts 82 classified grands crus in a small area, creating an exceptional concentration. Family estates and grand domains alike offer guided tours of cellars and vineyards. Tastings help you understand the appellation's typical blends (predominantly Merlot, with Cabernet Franc and Cabernet Sauvignon). Reservations essential.

Saint-Émilion Wine Route circuit. Several marked routes cross the vineyard between prestigious châteaux and family properties. The UNESCO-listed vineyard landscape remains intact. You can follow the circuit by car, bicycle (rentals available), or tourist train. Views over the hillsides are magnificent. Plan stops for tastings at châteaux that interest you.

Tasting Saint-Émilion macarons, a local specialty since the 17th century. These small almond cakes, different from Parisian macarons, have a soft texture and pronounced almond flavor. Several village pastry shops offer them. It's a pleasant sweet break after visiting the village. They keep well and make good souvenirs to bring home.

Cycling through Saint-Émilion's vineyards. The Roger Lapébie bike path, built on a former railway line, connects Sauveterre-de-Guyenne to Bordeaux passing through the vineyard. The route is flat and easy, perfect for family outings. Bike rentals available in Saint-Émilion or neighboring villages. Allow 2-3 hours for a leisurely loop with photo stops.
Guided tasting in a Saint-Émilion wine cellar.

days_plan.itin_title: Gironde Road Trip: Bordeaux, Vineyards & Arcachon Bay
Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: Puits Couriot Mining Museum. This remarkable museum occupies an authentic mining site that operated until 1973. Deep underground, reconstructed galleries bring the miners' world to life through machinery sounds and atmospheric lighting. The iconic 'hanging room,' where workers suspended their gear between shifts, captures the daily rhythm of a workforce that once numbered 1,500 at this single pit. Through artifacts, photographs, and firsthand accounts, the exhibitions chronicle Saint-Étienne's coal mining saga—a legacy that shaped the soul of this industrial city.

Museum of Art and Industry. Three thematic galleries showcase the region's industrial genius. The cycle exhibition traces bicycle evolution from primitive wooden draisines to cutting-edge composite racing machines—remarkably, France's first bicycle was built right here in 1886. The arms collection presents centuries of weaponry from the royal manufacture, displaying swords, rifles, and muskets as both historical artifacts and works of art. The textile section celebrates Saint-Étienne's renown for ribbon-making and passementerie, crafts that once employed thousands.

Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art. France's second-largest contemporary art collection lives here, with nearly 20,000 works spanning movements from 1960 onward. Geometric abstraction, Nouveaux Réalistes, Pop Art, and Art Brut dialogue across Didier Guichard's striking black ceramic-tiled building. Rotating exhibitions draw over 60,000 visitors annually to this beacon of international contemporary art in the heart of industrial France.

Saint-Étienne Historic Center. Place Marengo forms the beating heart of urban life, its Belle Époque bandstand and tree-lined esplanade hosting markets and gatherings. Along Rue des Martyrs de Vingré, 18th-century townhouses preserve their exposed timber frames and carved stone facades. The Grand'Église, the city's sole Gothic survivor built in 15th-century Forez sandstone, shelters a Renaissance Entombment sculpture and a soaring flamboyant Gothic choir—a spiritual anchor in this city of industry.

activities.text: Cité du Design. Born from the spectacular conversion of the old arms factory, the Cité du Design hosts the International Design Biennial every two years. Permanent and rotating exhibitions explore how design intersects with innovation and manufacturing. The site embodies Saint-Étienne's remarkable industrial transformation—now recognized as a UNESCO Creative City of Design, proof that old factories can become crucibles of creativity.

Renovated District Walk. The Saint-Charles quarter brilliantly reimagines former industrial wastelands as vibrant urban spaces. Throughout the city, playful 'test bench' installations—sculptural benches designed by contemporary artists—invite unexpected pauses. Around Châteaucreux station, modern architecture and redesigned public squares create a vision of post-industrial urban renewal done right.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Étienne-du-Grès — gateway to the Alpilles between Crau and piedmont, peaceful village.
Side streets and small squares away from traffic flows.

activities.text: Agricultural paths toward the foothills (view of ridges).
Heritage trail (washhouses, oratories).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Château de Saint-Fargeau, a 'giant of pink brick,' unfolds its five corner towers crowned with bell turrets around a pentagonal courtyard. Its origins date to 980, when the Bishop of Auxerre built a fortified hunting lodge here.

Tour the furnished apartments of La Grande Mademoiselle, cousin of Louis XIV, exiled here in 1652. The wooden library, trophy room, and reconstruction of her bedroom transport you to the Grand Siècle.
The château's timberwork, open to the public, forms a spectacular labyrinth of beams. An attic full of old-fashioned toys is arranged under the rafters—children can handle the toys from yesteryear.
The château chapel preserves wall paintings and a grand stone staircase. The 120-hectare English-style park extends behind the ramparts.

Twenty-five kilometers away, the Guédelon construction site builds a fortified castle using only 13th-century techniques. Stonemasons, carpenters, and blacksmiths have worked before visitors' eyes since the late 1990s.

activities.text: In summer, the château's historical pageant brings together 600 volunteers and 50 horsemen to retrace 1,000 years of history in 90 minutes. On Friday and Saturday evenings in July-August, the château blazes at nightfall.
Lake Bourdon, the Yonne's largest lake, spreads at the village's foot. Supervised swimming in summer, hiking trails, and fishing enliven its wooded shores.
On Thursday summer evenings, candlelit night tours of the château reveal private apartments. Costumed characters guide visitors between legend and reality.

days_plan.itin_title: Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: Saint-Florent - the Corsican Saint-Tropez
Citadel of Saint-Florent
Santa Maria Assunta Cathedral in white limestone
Désert des Agriates - maritime shuttle
Lotu Beach - paradise cove
Saleccia Beach - turquoise water and pine forest

The Saint-Florent Citadel overlooks the gulf from its 1440 construction. A circular edifice 30 meters in diameter flanked by round and square towers, built by Janus Campofregoso to survey the bay. The interior is open for visits in July and August. The esplanade offers panoramic views of the harbor and the Cap Corse coastline.

The Church of Santa Maria Assunta, former cathedral of the Nebbio, rises at the edge of Saint-Florent. A 12th-century Romanesque building classified as a Historic Monument since 1840. Sober and elegant architecture typical of the Pisan style. Limestone golden in the Mediterranean sun.

The historic center unfolds its lanes around Place Paoli bordered by century-old plane trees. Founded in the 18th century by Pasquale Paoli as a free port to rival Genoese Calvi, Saint-Florent preserves its grid layout. The covered market offers local products and crafts.

activities.text: Stroll through the narrow streets and around the port
Swimming and relaxation on paradise beaches

The Agriates Desert stretches across 15,000 hectares between Saint-Florent and L'Ostriconi. Maritime shuttles reach the beaches of Lotu and Saleccia several times daily from the harbor. Turquoise waters, white sand, and maquis compose a paradisiacal landscape. Return trips available late afternoon.

The Patrimonio wine route crosses vineyards and estates just 10 minutes from Saint-Florent. AOC Patrimonio produces powerful reds, fresh whites from Vermentinu grapes, and sweet Muscat wines. Seven communes display their limestone terraces. Tastings available at the cellars.

La Roya beach borders the town center with fine sand and calm waters. Ideal for families with a supervised swimming area. Starting point for the customs trail toward the Agriates beaches. Parking available nearby in low season.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Corsica Road Trip: Granite Cliffs, Mountain Passes & Island Beaches
Upper Corsica Road Trip: Cap Corse and Balagne

visits.text: Village perched on the gorges of the Couze Pavin; castle and medieval paintings.
Wash houses, old bridge and cliff-top paths above the river.
Mineral spring and surrounding archaeological remains.

activities.text: Couze gorges trail (3–5 km, moderate elevation change).
Observation route of volcanic architecture and corbelling.

days_plan.itin_title: The Volcanoes of Auvergne: A Road Trip Through Medieval Towns & Lunar Landscapes

visits.text: The Cathédrale Saint-Pierre dominates the Place d'Armes with its two square towers rising over 80 metres. Built between the 14th and 15th centuries in dark lava stone, it holds the record for the highest Gothic cathedral in Europe by altitude (892 m at the forecourt). The massive austerity of its façade contrasts with its interior treasures: the "Beau Dieu noir", a 12th-century walnut-wood Christ, and an organ that resonates during regular concerts testify to its spiritual grandeur.

The upper town stands like a stone vessel on its basaltic promontory at 900 metres altitude. Labelled City of Art and History, it reveals cobbled lanes, Renaissance townhouses and medieval ramparts in a setting of volcanic stone. The ancient fortified gates recall its motto: "None took me by force but the wind". From the heights, the view plunges down to the Ander valley and the Cantal mountains.

The Musée de la Haute-Auvergne, housed in the former episcopal palace, presents ethnographic and archaeological collections tracing the territory's history. Discover pastoral traditions, local craftsmanship and testimonies of daily life in this historic capital of Haute-Auvergne.

activities.text: The weekly market fills the upper town in a convivial atmosphere. Auvergne cheeses, artisanal cured meats, honeys and regional products are displayed on the stalls of local producers. Cantal gastronomy reveals all its mountain generosity here.

The ramparts circuit follows the natural and medieval fortifications that once protected the city. This walk reveals the vertiginous basaltic escarpments, preserved fortified gates and panoramas over the surrounding valleys. The defensive dimension of Saint-Flour appears in all its strategic force.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions

visits.text: Reignac — Troglodyte castle.
Château de Fougeret — Sessions & voices.

activities.text: Access: public (Reignac)

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine's Haunted History: Cursed Castles & Prehistoric Cave Legends

visits.text: The Collegiate Church of Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Gaudens dates from the 11th century. Its Romanesque bell tower and sculpted portal are remarkable. Inside, historiated capitals narrate biblical scenes.
The municipal museum presents local archaeology and sacred art collections. You'll also see works on the history of Saint-Gaudens.

activities.text: Thursday morning market is one of the most important in Comminges. Mountain and plain producers gather to sell poultry, cheeses, and vegetables.
Walk in the Garonne valley which begins to narrow here. The Pyrenees draw closer and the landscape changes with the first mountain reliefs.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Garonne Road Trip: From Toulouse to the Pyrenees

visits.text: En route, stop at the Museum of the Royal Estate of Marly: scale models and engravings trace the history of Louis XIV's vanished château and the workings of the famous Marly Machine.

Visit the remains of the Marly Machine, dubbed the "eighth wonder of the world" when built between 1681 and 1684. Its 14 hydraulic wheels, each 12 meters in diameter, pumped water from the Seine to feed Versailles' fountains.

The Château of Saint-Germain-en-Laye houses the National Museum of Archaeology and its 29,000 objects spanning Paleolithic to Merovingian times. The Lady of Brassempouy, a tiny ivory face carved 21,000 years ago, is the centerpiece.
The Sainte-Louis Chapel, built between 1230 and 1238, is a jewel of Rayonnant Gothic that inspired Paris's Sainte-Chapelle. Its tall stained-glass windows flood the nave with light.

Walk along the Grande Terrasse designed by Le Nôtre: 2.4 kilometers in a straight line with panoramic views over the Seine Valley and western Paris. On clear days, you can spot the La Défense skyline on the horizon.

activities.text: Follow the Impressionists' Path from Bougival to Chatou along the Seine. Enameled plaques reproduce paintings created at each spot, including Monet and Renoir's La Grenouillère.
Browse the Saint-Germain-en-Laye market, one of the finest in Yvelines, to taste regional produce from the Île-de-France.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

visits.text: Saint-Gilles fishing port is the Atlantic coast's premier sardine harbor. Trawlers unload sardines, anchovies, and hake every morning, filling the quays with the sharp tang of the sea.

Lose yourself in the narrow lanes of Vieux Saint-Gilles, the oldest quarter in town. Rue Torterue, the main artery since medieval times, retains stone houses built from ballast unloaded by merchant ships.
Climb to the top of Tour Joséphine, the town's first lighthouse built in 1851 at the request of sixteen sea captains. From its base, ferries depart for Île d'Yeu.
Cross the Pont de la Concorde, built in 1952 to unite two formerly rival towns. A sailor statue marks the tidal scale etched into the bridge.
Saint-Gilles Church, restored in 1971, houses a Stations of the Cross by Henry Simon and striking stained glass. Free guided tours run throughout summer.
The Remblai promenade borders the Grande Plage for 2.2 miles. Walk to the Villa Notre-Dame belvedere for sweeping views over both harbors, the beach, and Boisvinet cove.

activities.text: Tour the Atelier de la Sardine, classified as a Site of Remarkable Taste. The museum traces artisanal canning from catch to hand-packed tin: fishing, selection, hand-filleting, and sealing.
Walk or cycle the Corniche Vendéenne between Boisvinet and Saint-Hilaire-de-Riez. Belle Époque seaside villas perch above rocky coastline, gazing out over the open Atlantic.
Discover the salt marshes of Saint-Hilaire-de-Riez. Salt workers harvest white gold from shallow pans and explain the difference between coarse salt and prized fleur de sel.
Hop aboard a rail-bike on a disused railway track. These pedal-powered draisines glide through Vendée countryside for several miles, crossing marshland and hedgerow bocage.

days_plan.itin_title: Vendée Road Trip: Noirmoutier Island, Puy du Fou & Atlantic Coast

days_plan.itin_title: Ariège Pyrenees Road Trip, France: Cathar Castles & Prehistoric Cave Art

visits.text: Gellone Abbey (UNESCO).
Medieval village.
Most Beautiful Villages of France.
Red lake (rusty lands).
Mourèze Cirque.
Discovery of the medieval village of Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert.
Visit to Gellone Abbey and walk in the gorges of the Hérault.

Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert occupies the depths of a cirque of white cliffs, where the Verdus meets the Hérault. The village owes its name to William, Duke of Aquitaine and companion of Charlemagne, who founded a monastery here in 804 after receiving a relic of the True Cross from the Pope.

The abbey of Gellone, inscribed as World Heritage as part of the Ways of St. James, possesses an 18-meter-high nave. The Romanesque cloister, partly dispersed in the 19th century (its finest arcades are now in New York's Cloisters Museum), nevertheless retains intact charm.
From the Place de la Liberté, shaded by a century-old plane tree, narrow lanes climb between golden stone houses. Spot the Romanesque windows, carved lintels, and remains of the fortified wall.

What's the connection between an 11th-century bridge and the devil? Legend has it that the Evil One built the Devil's Bridge in one night, on condition of receiving the first crosser's soul. The monks sent a dog across. The structure, France's oldest Romanesque bridge, is inscribed as World Heritage.

The Cirque de l'Infernet frames the village with vertical limestone walls reaching 300 meters. The Fenestrettes trail, carved into the cliff, links the village to the causse via a 200-step staircase cut into rock.
Clamouse Cave, a few minutes downstream, offers an underground network of aragonite crystals and eccentric formations. The guided tour lasts about an hour in naturally cool galleries.

activities.text: Weaver (Savonnerie Manufacture).
Devil's Bridge.
Hiking.
Swimming.
Sailing.
Mountain biking.
Lunar landscapes.
Swimming in the waters of the Hérault at Pont du Diable.
Outfitters offer canoe descents through the Hérault gorges, from Devil's Bridge downstream. Turquoise water, limestone cliffs, and passages between rapids compose a route accessible to beginners.
The Fenestrettes trail (roughly 3h loop) climbs into the cliff via a vertiginous staircase, crosses the causse, and descends by a forest path. Plunging view of the village and Cirque de l'Infernet.

The Devil's Bridge beach, below the Romanesque bridge, attracts swimmers from early fair weather. Emerald waters, pebbles, and cliffs compose an unexpected canyon setting forty minutes from Montpellier.

days_plan.itin_title: Hérault, France: Mediterranean Beaches and Languedoc Wine Country
Southeast France Road Trip: Gorges du Verdon and Perched Villages
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Medieval Fortified Village. Perched on a porphyry rocky outcrop, Saint-Haon-le-Châtel preserves its 14th-century ramparts—a configuration unique in the Loire. At just 87 hectares, it's the department's smallest commune. Seventeen towers punctuate the medieval walls. Cobbled lanes lined with timber-framed houses, Renaissance manors like the Fleur de Lys with its original turrets, and 17th- and 18th-century townhouses compose this Village of Character. The Pelletier townhouse, a beautiful Renaissance dwelling, leans against one of the rampart towers.

Saint-Eustache Romanesque Church. This massive 12th-century Romanesque edifice anticipates the Gothic style with its pointed arches and lancet windows. The bell tower rises over the nave's first bay, dominating the village. 15th-century chapels were added on the north side. A 17th-century five-sided chevet with tall round-arched windows replaced the original. Statuary and murals adorn the interior. A porch adjoining the west façade provides access to the historic cemetery, which offers exceptional panoramas from the hilltop.

Petit Chateaumorand and Gardens. This seigneurial residence opens during guided tours. The medieval garden, reconstructed in the 1990s, presents medicinal and aromatic plants cultivated in the Middle Ages. Didactic panels explain plant uses. Garden access is free. The Sundial House, Maret House, and Murette House complete the village's remarkable architectural heritage.

activities.text: Village Guided Tour. Historical walks offered year-round, even at night for special atmosphere, by reservation. Guides lead visitors through streets, alleys, interior courtyards, ramparts, and the medieval garden. Anecdotes and historical explanations enrich the visit. Jean-Jules Jusserand, French ambassador to the United States from 1903 to 1925, vacationed in Saint-Haon-le-Châtel. A street and tower bear his name.

Medieval Treasure Hunt. A scavenger hunt for families with children. 'The Lost Cannonball of Charles VII' adventure plunges participants into the village's history in 1440, when Charles VII confronted his son Louis XI. Capucine and Colline guide treasure hunters through medieval lanes to recover the king's favorite cannonball. Booklet sold at the Tourist Office.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: The Cirque de Consolation is a wild 350-meter-deep reculée with magnificent limestone cliffs, in the heart of the Doubs Horloger regional natural park. This is where the Dessoubre is born, fed by the springs of Lançot, Tabourot, and Source Noire. The Minimes monastery, built in 1670 with stones from the castle of Châtelneuf-en-Vennes destroyed during the Ten Years' War, forms a 40-meter square. The 1682 chapel preserves art objects and the mausoleum of Ferdinand-François de Rye.

The Lançot waterfall plunges 47 meters into the Cirque de Consolation. It is fed during heavy rains or snowmelt. The path leading there passes through a magical atmosphere of streams, tufa formations, and small caves. The lush vegetation creates an atmosphere conducive to contemplation.

Saint-Hippolyte, a character town of Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, nestles at the confluence of the Doubs and Dessoubre (the 'Revirot'). Freed by Jean II de la Roche in 1298, it preserves its 14th-century collegiate church of Notre-Dame where the Shroud of Turin was kept for 35 years (1418-1452), the 18th-century Ursuline convent, and 16th and 17th-century mullioned houses. It is the historic capital of the Franche-Montagne.

activities.text: The Roche du Prêtre viewpoint offers a vertiginous panorama over the Cirque de Consolation and the Dessoubre valley, 350 meters below. Accessible by car or on foot via a sporty hike. According to legend, a priest was thrown from the top of the cliff by the friends of a giant he had locked in a cave. Picnic tables provided.

Descend the Dessoubre valley to Saint-Hippolyte. This picturesque 33 km valley, where many water mills once sang, offers exceptional environmental richness. It is paradise for fishermen (trout, grayling) and walkers who appreciate the ambient calm. In summer, the cool water invites you to dip your feet.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: Fort de Socoa (Ciboure): defensive complex on the bay shore.
Ciboure: Saint-Vincent church, market and old fountain; stroll through the town.
Saint-Jean-de-Luz: large beach, jetty, port and historic center.
Pointe de Sainte-Barbe: landscaped park and panorama over the bay.
Discovery of the town of Saint-Jean-de-Luz and its fishing port.
Excursion to Sare to take the Rhune train to the summit.

The Église Saint-Jean-Baptiste houses a stunning baroque altarpiece in gilded wood crafted between 1663 and 1669. Its three tiers of carved oak galleries are quintessentially Labourd, creating an intimate ship-like interior.

Maison Louis XIV, built in 1643, hosted the Sun King in May 1660 before his wedding. Its pink sandstone facades and corner towers exemplify 17th-century shipowner architecture when Basque corsairs grew wealthy.
Step inside the Maison de l'Infante where Marie-Thérèse of Austria stayed before becoming Queen of France. Its two galleries with five arcades each draw inspiration from Italian Renaissance palazzos.
Wander along Rue de la République where pink brick shipowners' mansions line this pedestrian artery that once connected Bayonne to Spain in the days of maritime trade.

activities.text: Gentle coastal walk between Ciboure, Socoa and Saint-Jean-de-Luz (round trip depending on time).
Panoramic observation of the Pyrenees and the Basque coast from the summit of La Rhune.
The Port des Pêcheurs comes alive at dawn when trawlers unload anchovies, tuna, and hake from the Bay of Saint-Jean, continuing centuries of fishing tradition.
Ride the petit train de la Rhune that climbs to 905 meters in 35 minutes. At the summit, wild pottok ponies and griffon vultures roam freely across the mountain grasslands.
Watch a pelota basque match at the port's fronton where players wield the chistera and bare hands in this traditional game passed down through generations.

days_plan.itin_title: Béarn & Basque Country: Pyrenean Passes to Atlantic Coast Soul
Southwest France Journey: Atlantic Coast to Pyrenees Mountain Peaks
Pyrénées-Atlantiques Road Trip: Basque Country & Béarn

visits.text: The Cathédrale Saint-Jean-Baptiste, founded in the 6th century, rebuilt in the 11th, and enlarged in the 15th, possesses one of France's oldest timber frames (wood dated to 1075). In the choir, 82 walnut Gothic stalls carved in 1498 depict saints, apostles, fauna, and flora—each one different from its neighbor.

The cloister, built around 1450 between the cathedral and the canons' refectory, unfolds its tufa vaults reinforced with local gypsum ribs. From the south bay, you access the Romanesque crypt, rediscovered in 1958 beneath the Gothic choir.

The neoclassical portico (1771) shelters the cenotaphs of three of the first princes of the House of Savoy: Humbert the White-Handed, founder of the dynasty, Amadeus I, and Boniface. The bell tower, a former 11th-century capitular keep, lost its Gothic spire during the Revolution.

The Musée Opinel occupies nearly 700 m² dedicated to the famous Savoyard knife. From the old forge to modern workshops, the exhibition traces the adventure of a tool created in 1890 in the nearby hamlet of Gévoudaz, today distributed in over 70 countries. Free entry, personalized engraving in the boutique.

Opposite the cathedral, the former bishop's palace (listed Historic Monument) houses the Musée des Costumes, Arts et Traditions Populaires. The collection of traditional Maurienne costumes, among the Alps' most original, displays embroidered headdresses, festive aprons, and dresses from the Arvan valleys.

Stroll through the historic center: the cathedral square hosts the market, lanes reveal the Tabellion block (medieval tribunal), the Art Deco festival hall (1933) that became the Théâtre Gérard Philipe, and at the town entrance, two giant Opinel knife sculptures mark local pride.

activities.text: Excursion to the Lacets de Montvernier. This spectacular road chains together eighteen tight hairpins on a vertical wall above the Maurienne valley. Plunging view guaranteed, a legendary Tour de France passage since 2015.
Cycling on the Maurienne greenway. The bike path follows the Arc through the valley, linking villages between orchards and valley-floor meadows. E-bike rental available on-site.

Tasting of Mauriennais specialties: Saint-Jean local cheese, diots (smoked sausages cooked in white wine), corn polenta, and crozets (small square buckwheat pasta). Restaurants around the cathedral square offer these traditional dishes.

days_plan.itin_title: Savoie from Lakes to Glaciers: Yenne to Haute-Maurienne

visits.text: Village of Saint-Jean-du-Gard, typical Cévennes town in the heart of Cévennes National Park. Schist houses with slate roofs tier along the Gardon. The 12th-century Romanesque church stands beside a Protestant temple testifying to Cévennes Huguenot history. Paved streets lined with artisan workshops wind between fountains and shaded squares. Tuesday morning market animates the center with local products and friendly atmosphere. The multi-arched medieval bridge spans the Gardon offering views of surrounding mountains.

Musée des Vallées Cévenoles – Maison Rouge, ethnographic collection tracing traditional lifestyles. Reconstructions present authentic Cévennes interiors: rustic furniture, daily utensils, regional costumes. The silk-farming department evokes the epic of magnaneries and flourishing silk industry until 1900. Thematic rooms document terraced agriculture, sheep farming, century-old chestnut groves. The Camisard space relates Wars of Religion and Protestant resistance in the 18th century. Temporary exhibitions deepen intangible Cévennes heritage.

Atlantide Parc, family water park and leisure center on 12 acres. Play pools, water slides, and lazy river refresh during hot summer days. The wellness area offers spa, hammam, and jacuzzis in green surroundings. Land activities include mini-golf, trampolines, inflatable structures for children. Shaded picnic areas under plane trees allow family lunches. The park blends aquatic relaxation and entertainment in preserved natural environment.

activities.text: Hike the Stevenson Trail (GR70) crossing the Cévennes. The Scottish writer covered 137 miles in 1878 with his donkey Modestine, recounted in "Travels with a Donkey in the Cévennes." The mythical trail winds through chestnut groves, schist ridges, deep valleys, and isolated hamlets. Stages around Saint-Jean-du-Gard discover typical Cévennes landscapes: cultivated terraces, pastoral drailles, mountain panoramas. Gîtes d'étape dot the route welcoming hikers. Donkey rental perpetuates the Stevensonian tradition.

Discover Cévennes chestnut groves, cultivated forests shaping terraced landscapes. The chestnut tree, the "bread tree," ensured Cévennes subsistence providing flour, building wood, and heating. Century-old orchards with gnarled trunks tier on slopes arranged in terraces supported by dry-stone walls. Autumn sees fallen chestnuts gathered and transformed into cream, jam, flour. Clèdes, vaulted buildings for drying, dot the chestnut groves. Interpretive trails explain this heritage silviculture inscribed by UNESCO.

Visit a traditional magnanerie, silkworm breeding building. Restored magnaneries testify to prosperous silk-farming industry in the 18th-19th centuries. Vaulted rooms sheltered racks supporting millions of worms devouring mulberry leaves. The complete process—from egg to cocoon, silk reeling, weaving—unfolds through exhibitions and demonstrations. Mulberry trees planted on terraces fed seasonal breeding operations. The Cévennes silk epic exported to Lyon enriched the region before declining against Asian competition.

days_plan.itin_title: Gard Road Trip: Roman Nîmes, Pont du Gard & Camargue Wilderness

visits.text: The Porte Saint-Jacques, inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage list, marks the historic entrance for pilgrims. Since the Middle Ages, it has opened onto the route through the Ports de Cize passes toward Roncevaux.
Climb to the Citadel fortified by Vauban in the 17th century. From its ramparts rising 70 meters above the town, views plunge onto pink sandstone roofs and the Nive River winding below.
The Église Notre-Dame-du-Bout-du-Pont displays Gothic architecture beside the Nive. Its ogival vaults have sheltered pilgrims since the 14th century on their journey to Compostela.
The Rue de la Citadelle winds between half-timbered houses with overhanging upper floors. Its worn cobblestones have felt the tread of thousands of pilgrims heading to Compostela.
Visit the Prison des Évêques which presents an exhibition on medieval pilgrimage to Compostela. The 13th-14th century building tells the Camino's story through artifacts and displays.

activities.text: The pilgrim welcome office on Rue de la Citadelle provides information about crossing the Pyrenees. Over 60,000 walkers pass through annually on their way to Roncevaux.
Walk the aerial wooden gallery built for Louis XIV's wedding procession. It follows the Nive from the Porte Notre-Dame, suspended above the rushing waters.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Atlantiques Road Trip: Basque Country & Béarn

places.name: Saint Jean Saint Maurice Sur Loire

visits.text: Château de la Roche. Anchored to its rocky outcrop in the middle of the Loire since the 13th century, this iconic gorge château appears to float on water when the river runs high, or to sit on a Scottish crag when autumn brings low waters. Theatrical guided tours feature costumed actor-guides portraying Monsieur and Madame Roustan, who owned the estate from 1900 to 1930. Period room settings transport visitors into the Belle Époque and the château's history. The four-leaf clover, a good-luck symbol, adorns façades and interior decoration. Two escape games unlock the château's secrets.

Medieval Village of Saint-Maurice. Perched on a promontory overlooking the Loire, the medieval town preserves its 12th-century donjon rising 17 meters. A spiral staircase climbs to the summit offering 360-degree panoramas of the Villerest dam waters and Loire meanders. Castle walls, the 17th-century Manoir de la Mure with its sculpted lintel doorway and finely decorated stair tower, and the Sundial House compose this Village of Character. Rue Guy de la Mure, lined with ivy-covered houses, offers a peaceful atmosphere.

Saint-Maurice Church. The choir entirely covered with classified 13th-century frescoes constitutes an exceptional pictorial ensemble. In a window embrasure on the south wall, a painting depicting Saint James attests that Saint-Maurice stood on the Compostela pilgrimage route. The Cluny/Le-Puy-en-Velay Jacquaire route still crosses the village. Saint-Jean's church, rebuilt around 1870, preserves its 12th-century bell tower-porch, sole witness to the Benedictine priory dismantled during the Revolution.

Joeuvres Archaeological Site. On the Loire's right bank, this hamlet shelters a Celtic oppidum inhabited since prehistoric times. Excavations led notably by Joseph Déchelette in 1911 revealed two 1st-century BCE bronze statuettes representing a horse and a wild boar, visible at Roanne's Joseph-Déchelette Museum. Ionian and Phocaean amphora shards prove Mediterranean trade via the Rhône and Ardèche. A bronze workshop operated on this strategic site.

activities.text: Pêt d'Âne Viewpoint. In the commune of Vézelin-sur-Loire, this panoramic site offers the finest view of the Loire's meanders. A contemplation bench faces the river's grandest bend. Below, kayaks and paddleboards glide on the wild river. The medieval silhouettes of Saint-Jean-Saint-Maurice-sur-Loire create a living postcard. Parking and easy access from the road.

Ridge Trail. A short walk offering the best views of the Loire meanders and Saint-Jean-Saint-Maurice tower. A high-altitude route overlooking the river. Trails through woods and meadows. Several artisan artists with studios in the village open by appointment.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire Discovery: Wild Gorges and Industrial Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Jeannet — balcony village and trail starting points toward the Baou.
Baou de Saint-Jeannet — limestone summit with Var-coastal panorama.
Discovery of the perched village of Saint-Jeannet and its typical cobblestone streets.
Hike to the Baou de Saint-Jeannet offering a panorama over the Côte d'Azur.

activities.text: Hiking (round trip to summit plateau) — easy rocky passages.
Equipped climbing sites (with supervision).
Purchase of artisanal ravioli at Raviolis des Baous, local specialty to take away.

days_plan.itin_title: French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary
Côte d'Azur Secrets: Perched Villages and Mountain Escapes

visits.text: The Collégiale de Saint-Junien, one of the largest and oldest Romanesque churches in Limousin, was built from the 11th to 13th centuries in local granite. Its tomb of Saint Junien, carved around 1100 in La Rochefoucauld limestone, bears on three faces the twenty-four elders of the Apocalypse and Christ in a mandorla.

In the nave, look up: the fresco of the twenty-four elders of the Apocalypse, from the 12th century, echoes the tomb's iconography. The Saint-Martial chapel preserves Romanesque paintings showing the display of relics followed by pilgrims seeking healing.

The Chapelle Notre-Dame-du-Pont, in Flamboyant Gothic style, has guarded the Vienne bridge entrance since 1451. Enlarged thanks to the generosity of King Louis XI, who came on pilgrimage in 1463, it remains a place of popular devotion.

The Cité du Cuir, opened in late 2025 on the Vienne riverbank at a former tannery site, traces the complete luxury glove manufacturing cycle. The immersive museum route runs from raw hide to finished product, passing through reconstructed workshops.

The Maison des Consuls, built in the 14th century, testifies to the medieval town's prosperity. A few steps away, the Bourse du Travail on Place Lénine recalls Saint-Junien's working-class social history, a glove-making town since the 11th century.

activities.text: Every seven years, Saint-Junien celebrates the Ostensions septennales, inscribed on UNESCO's list: 1,500 costumed participants parade through town in procession around the relics. Four Swiss guards watch over the tomb year-round — a unique feature in Limousin.

Follow the Glane riverbanks to the Corot site, classified as a Natural Area of Ecological Interest. The 2 km trail crosses one of the Vienne's largest islands, where painter Corot once set up his easel.
Visit a glove-making workshop to observe artisan craftsmanship, from cutting leather to assembling gloves. Saint-Junien has supplied the greatest fashion houses since the 19th century.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Vienne Circuit: Limoges, Porcelain & Historic Villages

visits.text: Saint-Lary-Soulan was born from the 1963 merger of the villages of Saint-Lary and Soulan to enable the ski resort's expansion. Located in the Aure valley and classified as a Land of Art and History, the village is a historic stop on the Way of Saint James. The main street bears the name of Vincent Mir, founder of the resort. The Pyrenean architecture of its stone houses and enhanced facades, the Pic Lumière cable car and the Vignec gondola linking the village to the slopes compose an authentic mountain setting.

The Maison du Patrimoine, located at 41 rue Vincent Mir on the Tourist Office square, houses several museum spaces dedicated to Pyrenean heritage: traditions, fauna, architecture, old-time schools and livestock farming. Upstairs, an interactive 3D map allows immersion in the valley's trails, passes, and lakes. Temporary exhibitions of painting, photography, and sculpture are presented throughout the year. Guided village tours are organized by the Aure-Louron Land of Art and History association.

The Church of Saint-Bertrand, built between 1950 and 1952 and consecrated in October 1952, replaced the old Saint-Hilaire church. Nearby, the Sainte-Marie Chapel and the Romanesque chapels from the 11th and 12th centuries in surrounding villages testify to the valley's rich religious heritage. The restored Debat Mill can be visited, as can the Moulin de la Mousquère in Soulan village, renovated and dating from the Middle Ages.

Soulan, a preserved and sunny pastoral village, dominates Saint-Lary from the heights toward the ski resort. Three kilometers away, Vielle-Aure offers a typical village with cobbled streets, a 12th-century Romanesque church, and the Château de Moulor with its keep and chapel, also from the 12th century. Further on, Ancizan (six kilometers), a former village of clothiers and weavers, preserves the Saint-Blaise-et-Saint-Martin church. Gouaux and Grailhen offer a remarkable exhibition and breathtaking view of the peaks, with the Gouaux goat farm to visit.

The Rioumajou Valley, accessible from the Frédancon parking lot at 1,380 meters altitude (twelve kilometers from Saint-Lary), is an easy two-hour round-trip family hike on a forest track following the Neste du Rioumajou. The pastoral valley unfolds with vast meadows crossed by a stream winding to the Hospice du Rioumajou, a refuge-restaurant at 1,560 meters altitude with 27 sleeping spaces. Labeled "Esprit Parc national," it is open from June to September. For more experienced walkers, the Balcon de l'Hospice (1,969 m) offers a viewpoint overlooking the site, accessible in two and a half hours round trip. Vehicle access is regulated from July to August between 12 pm and 4 pm.

The Néouvielle Nature Reserve, created in 1936 and one of France's first nature reserves, covers 2,313 hectares between 1,800 and 3,091 meters altitude. It shelters seventy lakes (Aubert, Aumar, Orédon, Cap-de-Long, l'Oule), record-breaking black pines for longevity and altitude, 1,250 vascular plants, 370 animal species, and 570 algae species. Access is via the lakes road from Saint-Lary, with shuttles between Orédon and Aubert in season. Bivouacking is authorized from 7 pm to 9 am in specific zones, dogs and swimming are prohibited.
Stroll through the village of Saint-Lary-Soulan, renowned for its friendly atmosphere and stone chalets.
Exploration of the landscapes of the Aure valley, in the heart of the Pyrénées National Park.

The Pyrenees National Park Visitor Center occupies the Tour Hachan, a typical building in the village heart. Renovated in 2014, the three-story museum space presents the forests of the Aure valley: riparian woodland along the Neste, beech-fir forest, and the hooked pine forest of the Néouvielle Nature Reserve—Europe's highest forest. Touch-and-feel displays, soundscapes, and scent stations complete the sensory discovery.

The Heritage Center, an interpretation facility opened in July 2017, presents the cultural riches of the Aure valley in a blend of tradition, authenticity, and modernity. Located in the village center near the tourist office, it complements your exploration of local Pyrenean heritage.

The town hall occupies the Maison Fornier, a manor dating from 1629. The last owner conditioned the sale on housing the town hall there, which happened in 1974. In front of the building, a bear fountain recalls the historical presence of the plantigrade in the Pyrenees. The village maintains an architectural unity of wood-and-schist buildings, even recent ones.

The Néouvielle Nature Reserve, created in 1936 among France's first, protects a unique granite massif between 5,905 and 10,141 feet elevation. It counts over 70 glacial lakes, 570 species of algae, and hooked pines setting records for longevity and altitude. Accessible via the lakes road from Orédon, the site shelters marmots, griffon vultures, bearded vultures, and the extremely rare Pyrenean desman.

Lakes Aubert (7,047 feet) and Aumar, separated by a tongue of land, offer sumptuous panoramas in the heart of the reserve. The Laquettes trail from Orédon (1h45 round trip, 755 feet elevation gain, easy) threads through a chaplet of small natural lakes sheltering rich fauna. The Col d'Aumar and Hourquette d'Aubert offer viewpoints over the massif for more seasoned hikers.

The Saint-Lary ski area spans three sectors: Pla d'Adet (5,577 feet), Espiaube (6,234 feet), and Vallon du Portet, totaling 62 miles of slopes and 59 runs between 5,413 and 8,251 feet elevation. In summer, the Pla d'Adet cable car provides access to numerous hiking trails and panoramas over the Aure valley.
Saint-Lary-Soulan occupies the bottom of the Aure valley at 830 m elevation, a few kilometers from Spain. Vincent Mir street crosses the historic heart with its stone and slate houses.
The church of Saint-Barthélemy and its typical bell tower dominate the valley. The village sits on one of the Pyrenean passages of the Ways of St. James, spared from the Wars of Religion.
The Heritage House recounts mountain traditions of the Aure valley: pastoral migration, traditional materials (slate, wood, stone), and the lives of generations who built these villages.
Climb to Soulan, a hamlet perched above the resort. Gray slate roofs, old-fashioned wash house, and window geraniums compose an authentic Pyrenean postcard with stunning views of the summits.
Tramezaïgues, nearby, hides a Romanesque church, narrow lanes between black stone houses, and castle ruins. The village preserves thermal springs purchased by the municipality in the 1960s.

activities.text: Stroll through Saint-Lary's streets starting from the Maison du Patrimoine, then climb toward Soulan village for a sunny panorama over the Aure valley and its peaks.
Hike in the Rioumajou Valley to the Hospice, an easy and bucolic two-hour round-trip walk along the stream, ideal for families - the refuge restaurant serves cuisine labeled "Esprit Parc national."
Take the lakes road toward the Néouvielle Reserve to discover Lakes Aubert and Orédon in their setting of thousand-year-old black pines - shuttles facilitate access in summer.
Visit the villages of Vielle-Aure and Ancizan to discover traditional Pyrenean architecture, cobbled streets, and Romanesque churches, before stopping at the Gouaux goat farm.
Thrill-seekers will find a wide choice of activities in Saint-Lary: canyoning, rafting on the Neste, mountain biking in the bike park, paragliding, via ferrata, and downhill electric scooters.
Relaxing moment at Sensoria Rio: bubble beds, massage jets and panoramic hammam.
Access to the Sensoria wellness area with jacuzzi, sauna and mountain views.

Relax in the thermal waters of Sensoria: indoor and outdoor pools, jacuzzis, saunas, and hammams with mountain views. The naturally warm waters, diverted from the old Tramezaygues spa, soothe rheumatism and muscle tension after hiking.

Hike in the Rioumajou valley, one of the wildest in the Pyrenees, or climb toward the lakes of the Néouvielle reserve on a hut-to-hut trek (5 staffed refuges: Orédon, Bastan, La Glère, Campana de Cloutou, Aygues-Cluses, totaling 226 beds in summer).

Cycling over legendary Tour de France cols: Col du Portet and Col d'Azet starting from Saint-Lary, regularly tackled by the Grande Boucle. Mountain biking possible on a vast network extending into Spain via Zona Zero.

Discover the villages of the Aure valley: Vielle-Aure and its stone houses, Guchen and its traditions, Sailhan and its typical architecture. Together they form the Art and History Region of the Aure and Louron valleys.
The Rioumajou valley, classified Natura 2000, follows beautiful forest tracks along the torrent. Family-friendly walk to the Hospice de Rioumajou, a former shepherds' shelter.
The Néouvielle Nature Reserve counts 70 high-altitude lakes, endemic fauna (marmots, chamois), and forests of mountain pine. Lake Orédon is accessible by road, starting point for numerous hikes.
The Sensoria Rio thermal center taps a natural sulfurous water spring. Heated pools, waterfalls, jacuzzis, and hammams in a setting recreating Pyrenean canyons.
The Agos lakes, accessible by a suspension bridge over the Neste d'Aure, offer swimming in emerald-colored water surrounded by mountains. Perfect for cooling off in summer.

Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

Ancient enclosure and clustered habitat on the edge of the basaltic plateau.

activities.text: Canoe break on the Vézère (easy section).

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: The Collégiale de Saint-Léonard, inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List as part of the Routes of Santiago de Compostela, dominates the town from its seven-story bell tower rising 52 meters. Pass through the Limousin portal to discover the barrel-vaulted nave, the octagonal lantern tower, and the vast choir with ambulatory encircled by seven radiating chapels.

At the heart of the collegiate church, Saint Léonard's tomb is covered with chains of 'freed prisoners.' Tradition holds that women touch the saint's bolt to have their prayers answered. Small booties are still placed on the tomb in thanks.

The baptistery rotunda, vaulted with a cupola resting on eight columns, was erected around 1100, during the time of the First Crusade. It illustrates Limousin Romanesque architectural mastery at its finest.

The Moulin du Got, Limousin's last working paper mill, brings to life handmade papermaking and printing techniques from the 15th to 20th centuries. Take home a souvenir made from paper crafted on-site.

The Musée Gay-Lussac, labeled Maison des Illustres, honors the chemist born here in 1778. Personal clothing, laboratory instruments, and publications trace the life and work of this scientist who gave his name to several fundamental laws of gas physics.

activities.text: Roam the lanes of the medieval town between the round tower and square tower. Gothic facades, secret passages, and remnants of fortified gates mark the route. Saint-Léonard is classified among France's 'Plus Beaux Détours.'
Walk down to the old 13th-century stone bridge over the Vienne. The small 4 km loop offers views of the viaduct and surrounding countryside — ideal for a post-meal stroll.

Taste the massepain de Saint-Léonard, a biscuit made from ground almonds, sugar, and egg white. Legend says this Mediterranean-flavored delicacy was brought back by pilgrims returning from Compostela.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Vienne Circuit: Limoges, Porcelain & Historic Villages

visits.text: Cathedral (UNESCO).
Cloister.

days_plan.itin_title: Ariège Pyrenees Road Trip, France: Cathar Castles & Prehistoric Cave Art

visits.text: The abbey church founded in the 5th century was rebuilt in the 17th century in Gothic style by the Benedictines of Saint-Maur after the Wars of Religion.
The 17th-century rood screen, sculpted woodwork, and sixteen-lobed monolithic baptismal font testify to the richness of the building.
The 7th-century crypt houses the relics of Saint Léger. Its barrel vaults and Romanesque capitals are listed as Historic Monuments.
The cloister and chapter house now host exhibitions and cultural events.

activities.text: Visit the National School for Active Non-Commissioned Officers created in 1963, a unique training ground for the French Army.
Stroll along the banks of the Sèvre Niortaise between half-timbered houses and 16th-century mansions.

days_plan.itin_title: Deux-Sèvres Circuit: Marais Poitevin and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Mont-Dol (panorama).
Champ-Dolent Menhir.
Chateaubriand Castle.
Tranquil Lake.

The ramparts of Saint-Malo, listed as a Historic Monument since 1886, form a 1,754 m loop around the walled city. Built in the 12th century by Bishop Jean de Châtillon, they were reinforced by Garangeau following Vauban's plans from 1691.
The Saint-Vincent Cathedral blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Inside, modern stained glass windows recount the history of the corsair city. Jacques Cartier's tomb is located here.

Enter through the Grand'Porte, the oldest gate in the city (12th century). Above it, the statue of Our Lady of the Grand'Porte: according to legend, she stood against the flames in 1661 and stopped the fire.
The castle of Saint-Malo, built in 1424 by the Dukes of Brittany, is recognizable by its corner turrets. Duchess Anne of Brittany wanted it 'shaped like a carriage.'
Climb the Tour Bidouane, a 15th-century horseshoe-shaped powder magazine. From there, the view encompasses Grand Bé, Petit Bé, and the entire bay.
From the Holland Bastion, spot the mastiff niches below the walls. Every evening, these guard dogs were released around the city to prevent any intrusion.
Fort National, built by Garangeau in 1689, stands on a rocky islet facing the ramparts. Accessible only at low tide via a sand causeway.

activities.text: Oyster farms.
Guided bay crossing.
Spring tides.
La Mère Poulard Inn.
Walk the complete circuit of the ramparts at sunset. Allow a good hour for the 1,754 m. Start at Porte Saint-Thomas to take in views of the Sillon, Fort National, then Grand Bé.
At low tide, cross the sand causeway to the Grand Bé islet. Check tide times: the sea rises quickly and cuts off access in 30 minutes.
The great Sillon beach stretches 3 km facing the walled city. Rows of wooden posts (breakwaters) create a unique landscape at low tide.

days_plan.itin_title: Ille-et-Vilaine, Brittany: Saint-Malo and Medieval Walled Towns
Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

Banks of the Isère and confluence of the Bourne, tree-lined walks.

Ancient route on the Roman road (Gallo-Roman traces).

activities.text: Ridge path above the town for views over Verdon and plateaus.
Heritage circuit (gates, towers, old houses).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: The Île de Ré bridge, 2.9 km long, has connected the mainland to the island since 1988. Toll on entry (free on exit). The crossing offers a first view of the salt marshes and the black and white bell tower of Ars-en-Ré.

The fortifications of Saint-Martin-de-Ré, built by Vauban between 1681 and 1691, form a 14 km star-shaped rampart. UNESCO World Heritage since 2008, they could shelter the entire island population during an English invasion. Walking or cycling the ramparts is spectacular.

The port of Saint-Martin-de-Ré, nestled within the fortified walls, has quays lined with terraces. Convicts bound for Cayenne departed from here – the citadel served as a depot. Climb the church tower for a panoramic view of the island.

The Baleines Lighthouse, at the western tip of the island, stands 60 meters tall. 257 steps lead to the top – 360° view over the ocean and island. The name comes from whales that once stranded on this coast. The old Vauban tower (1682) and a lighthouse museum complete the site.

activities.text: Île de Ré by bike: 110 km of cycle paths connect the island's ten villages. Rentals available in every village. The Saint-Martin → Baleines Lighthouse route (15 km) crosses salt marshes and pine forests.
Visit the salt marshes of Loix or Ars-en-Ré. Salt workers harvest fleur de sel by hand using age-old techniques. Guided walks in the marshes, explanations of the work and tastings.
Île de Ré beaches: fine sand on the south coast (Bois-Plage, La Couarde), wilder to the north. Fish traps, semi-circular stone walls, catch fish at low tide – an ancestral technique still practiced.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: Valley village nestled at the foot of the ridges; church and adjacent hamlets.
Meadows and streams at the bottom of the valley, views of the cliffs.

activities.text: Hamlets and stream banks loop (3–4 km).

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: Saint-Martin-Vésubie, nicknamed "the little Switzerland of Nice," opens the gates to Mercantour National Park: 3,600 hectares of forests, peaks exceeding 3,000 meters.
Stroll through the alpine village alleyways: wooden chalets, murmuring fountains, authentic shops at the foot of the mountains.
The Alpha Wolf Center "Le Temps du Loup" reveals pack life: three habitats allow observation of these majestic predators at feeding time.
Continue to the Sanctuary of Madone de Fenestre: this high-mountain pilgrimage site offers spectacular views of Gélas, the highest peak in the Alpes-Maritimes.
Vésubia mountain park offers indoor climbing, indoor canyoning, caving, and wellness facilities year-round.
Excursion to Alpha park to observe European wolves in semi-freedom.
Walk in the village of Saint-Martin-Vésubie and discovery of its mountain architecture.

The Prals Lakes trail winds toward beautiful flowering pastures: moderate difficulty, about four hours of walking.
Head for Trécolpas Lake: 9.5 kilometers through Boréon Valley, picturesque forests, rolling meadows, and mountain streams.
Alpine wildlife watching: brown trout in the lakes, chamois on the ridges, golden eagles soaring in the pure sky.
Canyoning or aqua hiking in crystal gorges: jumps, natural slides, rappel descents into turquoise pools.

visits.text: Saint-Étienne church preserves Ligier Richier's absolute masterpiece: the Sepulcher, composed of thirteen figures slightly larger than life, carved from Euville stone between 1554 and 1564. The dead Christ, carried by Nicodemus and Joseph of Arimathea, is surrounded by Mary Magdalene, the Virgin, and the Holy Women. Classified as a historic monument as early as 1840.

The Benedictine Library, on the second floor of the former abbatial palace, is considered one of France's five most beautiful libraries. Its two architecturally remarkable rooms contain 8,780 books, including 74 manuscripts from the 9th to 16th centuries and 86 incunabula. Some volumes still bear the scars of a 1915 shell.

Saint-Michel abbey church, founded in the 8th century, preserves a Romanesque tower-porch. Inside, Ligier Richier's Swoon of the Virgin - two life-size walnut wood figures - shows Mary fainting in Saint John's arms after Christ's death.

The Museum of Sacred Art, in the monks' former refectory, gathers religious objects, paintings, and sculptures from the 13th to 19th centuries deposited by departmental communes. The Saint Elisabeth attributed to Ligier Richier is an exceptionally refined piece.

Walk through Saint-Mihiel's Renaissance streets: the Gondrecourt mansion with its gargoyles representing a ram, dog, and lion; the Bousmard mansion (1520); Ligier Richier's house; the 16th-century Café des Arcades. An open-air museum of Lorraine architecture.

activities.text: Hike to the Seven Rocks, limestone cliffs over twenty meters high overlooking the Meuse valley. The 7-kilometer trail crosses forests and rock formations with panoramic viewpoints.
The Meuse Greenway follows the river: a bike and pedestrian path crossing several picturesque villages. Bike rental shops offer equipment suitable for the whole family.
Taste local specialties: croquets and rochers de Saint-Mihiel, traditional dry cookies that accompany Lorraine coffee.

visits.text: Descend into the submarine Espadon moored in the fortified lock. This 77-meter vessel became the first French submarine to reach the North Pole in 1964, surfacing through the Arctic ice cap.

Inside the submarine base, Escal'Atlantic recreates the world of transatlantic ocean liners. Luxury cabins, engine rooms, and artifacts from the legendary Normandie bring the golden age of ocean travel back to life.
The Chantiers de l'Atlantique shipyards sprawl across 250 acres. A giant gantry crane lifts 1,400-ton blocks to assemble the world's largest cruise ships in a modern marvel of engineering.
Climb to the rooftop terrace of the fortified lock. The 360-degree view sweeps across the harbor, the Loire estuary, and the elegant bridge that spans the wide river.

activities.text: Head to the waterfront and its fine sandy beaches. A redeveloped promenade, colorful beach huts, and open views to the Atlantic horizon make for pleasant seaside wandering.
The Écomusée chronicles Saint-Nazaire's industrial and maritime history. Post-war reconstruction, shipbuilding heritage, and working-class life unfold through photographs and artifacts.

days_plan.itin_title: Loire-Atlantique Road Trip: Nantes and the Jade Coast

visits.text: Perched on Mont Cornadore, Saint-Nectaire's Romanesque church ranks among Auvergne's five major examples. Its lava stone nave, topped by a dome and flanked by two facade towers, shelters 103 polychrome sculpted capitals of striking expressiveness. The treasury constitutes one of France's most remarkable Romanesque metalwork ensembles: the gilt copper and enameled reliquary bust of Saint Baudime, the Notre-Dame-du-Mont-Cornadore Virgin, and several reliquaries testify to medieval Auvergne's artistic radiance.

The Grottes du Cornadore reveal 1st-century Gallo-Roman baths carved into rock. The route recreates the Roman bathing ritual: from the tepidarium (warm room) to the caldarium (hot room), passing two perfectly preserved bathtubs from the original twenty. Millennial stalactites, an ancient pool, and hot mineralized CO2-rich water basins punctuate the guided visit. Six daily tour times from 10:30 AM to 5:30 PM, open year-round except December 25 and January 1.

The Maison du Fromage dedicates discovery space to Saint-Nectaire PDO, one of France's oldest cheeses. Traditional production, terroir history, and tasting explain why this unpasteurized pressed cheese, aged on rye straw, became the region's gastronomic emblem.

Saint-Nectaire-le-Bas spreads its villas and parks along more than forty thermal springs. The 19th-century spa development left architectural heritage still visible in former bathhouse facades and shaded walkways connecting the springs.

Perched atop Mont Cornadore, Saint-Nectaire's Romanesque church ranks among Auvergne's five great masterpieces. Its lava stone nave, crowned by a dome and flanked by two facade towers, shelters 103 polychrome sculpted capitals of striking expressiveness. The treasury constitutes one of France's most remarkable Romanesque metalwork ensembles: Saint Baudime's copper, gilt, and enamel bust-reliquary, the Virgin Notre-Dame-du-Mont-Cornadore, and several reliquaries testify to medieval Auvergne's artistic radiance.

The Cornadore caves reveal 1st-century Gallo-Roman baths carved into bedrock. The route recreates the Roman bathing ritual: from the tepidarium (warm room) to the caldarium (hot room), passing two perfectly preserved bathtubs among the twenty the original complex contained. Millennial stalactites, an ancient pool, and hot mineralized CO2-rich water basins punctuate the guided visit. Six daily tour slots from 10:30 AM to 5:30 PM, open year-round except December 25 and January 1.

La Maison du Fromage dedicates an exhibition space to Saint-Nectaire PDO, one of France's oldest cheeses. Traditional production, terroir history, and tasting help explain why this pressed uncooked cheese, aged on rye straw, became the region's gastronomic emblem.

Saint-Nectaire-le-Bas spreads its villas and parks along more than forty thermal springs. The spa's 19th-century development left an architectural heritage still visible in former bathhouse facades and shaded alleys connecting the springs.

activities.text: Attend music concerts in Saint-Nectaire's Romanesque church, programmed year-round. The nave's exceptional acoustics magnify sonorities and offer a musical experience in an extraordinary heritage setting.

Join a guided tour of Saint-Nectaire's Romanesque church offered in summer. Guides detail the 103 capitals' iconography, decode biblical and secular carved scenes, and present the metalwork treasury's masterpieces.

Hike around Mont Cornadore with views over the Monts du Sancy and Couze Chambon valley. Several marked trails leave from the village and reveal volcanic landscapes, thermal springs, and high pastures.

Attend music concerts in Saint-Nectaire's Romanesque church, programmed throughout the year. The nave's exceptional acoustics magnify sound and offer a musical experience in an extraordinary heritage setting.

Join a guided tour of Saint-Nectaire's Romanesque church offered during summer season. Guides detail the iconography of all 103 capitals, decode biblical and secular scenes carved in stone, and present the treasury's major metalwork pieces.

Hike around Mont Cornadore with views over the Sancy mountains and Couze Chambon valley. Several marked trails depart from the village and reveal the volcanic landscape, thermal springs, and high-altitude pastures.

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral, built from the 12th to 16th centuries, is France's last Gothic masterpiece. Its 1558 astrolabe clock still tracks the heavens with precision.
The Sandelin Museum occupies an 18th-century mansion. Its fine arts collections and 750 ceramic pieces form one of France's most impressive assemblages.
The 20-hectare public garden spreads across former ramparts. French formal gardens, English landscape gardens, arboretum, cascades, and an open-air theater.
Saint-Bertin Abbey ruins testify to the town's medieval religious importance. Founded in the 7th century, it was dismantled after the Revolution.
The 18th-century town hall, nicknamed "the coffee grinder" for its cubic shape topped by a cupola, now houses an Italian-style theater.

activities.text: Board a bacôve for a journey through the Audomarois marshes. This flat-bottomed boat navigates 160 kilometers of UNESCO-listed watergangs (canals).
Visit the Marsh House to understand the exceptional biodiversity: 200 bird species including white storks, grey herons, and kingfishers.
Wander the medieval lanes of the historic center. Yellow brick and stone facades, elegant townhouses, and lively squares reveal Flemish architecture.

visits.text: Pass through the 14th-century Vence Gate: machicolations, arrow slits, a cannon from the battle against Charles V embedded in the wall.
Rue Grande crosses the fortified village from end to end: art galleries, artist studios, medieval facades where Picasso and Chagall once strolled.
Place de la Grande Fontaine comes alive around its four-serpent urn: wash house under the arches, beating heart of the village since 1850.
The Chapel of the White Penitents shines with Folon's works: mosaics, stained glass, contemporary sculptures in a 17th-century setting.
The Collegiate Church of the Conversion of Saint Paul blends Romanesque and Baroque, sober choir and gilded chapels.
Climb to the 16th-century bastion: panorama of the Baou mountain chain, Mont Chauve, and hinterland hills.
In the cemetery rests Marc Chagall, grave number 152, row C: the painter spent his final years in this village he loved so much.
Saint-Paul-de-Vence — ramparts, artisan streets and views over the valley.
Maeght Foundation — sculptures and modern works outdoors and in galleries.
Cagnes-sur-Mer — Haut-de-Cagnes, Grimaldi castle and Renoir museum.

Walk through the flowered alleys and ramparts of the medieval village of Saint-Paul-de-Vence.
Visit to the Maeght Foundation and its collection of modern and contemporary art.

activities.text: The Maeght Foundation unveils 13,000 modern and contemporary artworks: Miró, Giacometti, Braque in a unique architectural setting.
Walk the Chemin de Ronde along the ramparts: plunging view over village rooftops and distant mountains.
Place du Général de Gaulle comes alive under century-old plane trees: legendary pétanque games where Montand and Ventura once played.
Continue to Tourrettes-sur-Loup, the violet village 15 minutes away: cobbled lanes, stone houses, Violet Festival in March.
Art galleries line every alley: paintings, sculptures, ceramics, the masters' spirit still lingers.
