days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: The Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule vineyard extends over 640 hectares producing AOC wines since 2009. The terroir cultivates unique Tressallier grape, rare white variety found almost exclusively here. Winegrowers perpetuate ancestral tradition dating back to Romans and Middle Ages when Saint-Pourçain wines supplied royal court and popes.

The Vineyard and Wine Museum occupies a renovated old building presenting viticulture history and winemaking techniques. Collections display traditional tools, historical documents and bottles tracing wine evolution over centuries. Educational tours explain Tressallier grape specificity and local terroir characteristics.

The Sainte-Croix church (12th-13th centuries) dominates city with its massive bell tower. Romanesque architecture displays carved capitals and sculpted portal characteristic of period. Interior shelters remarkable stained glass windows and liturgical objects testifying to religious heritage richness.

Old Saint-Pourçain reveals paved streets lined with stone houses (15th-18th centuries) and winegrower residences. The historic center preserves medieval character with narrow streets, small squares and ancient fountains. Stroll discovering facades and details testifying to wine town past prosperity.

activities.text: Wine cellar visits and tastings allow discovering Saint-Pourçain AOC in authentic setting. Winegrowers present their cuvées (whites, rosés, reds) including rare Tressallier expressing limestone terroir. Direct sales and explanations on vineyard work enrich the oenological experience.

Walk along Sioule discovering old mills and wash houses lining the river. Green banks invite peaceful strolls in nature. Footpaths allow exploring valley where water carved picturesque path through limestone.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: The Saint-Quentin Basilica soars with its 83-meter spire. This Gothic masterpiece from the 12th-15th centuries shelters relics of Saint Quentin. The interior dazzles with its luminosity and extraordinary dimensions with a 34-meter high nave. Stained glass windows tell the saint's martyrdom.

Explore the largest Art Deco heritage in France along the architectural circuit. Facades rebuilt after World War I display geometric motifs, bow windows and sculptural decorations characteristic of the 1920s-1930s. The former Manufacture building, town hall and theater illustrate this artistic wealth.

The Antoine-Lécuyer Museum preserves the world's largest collection of pastels by Maurice-Quentin de La Tour. The 18th-century portraitist immortalized personalities of his time in intimate works of stunning realism. The museum also displays Flemish and French paintings from the 15th to 18th centuries.

The Marais d'Isle natural reserve extends over 120 hectares in the heart of the city. Peat bogs, ponds and humid meadows shelter remarkable fauna and flora. A nature trail with interpretation panels runs through this preserved wetland.

activities.text: Walk along the canal and Somme banks. The towpath converted into a promenade invites peaceful strolls through greenery. Pleasure boats and fishing spots enliven this waterfront.

Discover the underground city sheltering 45 kilometers of medieval quarries and wartime refuges. Guided tours reveal this mysterious underground world beneath Saint-Quentin streets. Chalk walls bear witness to centuries of extraction and wartime hiding.

Visit the butterfly conservatory sheltering over a thousand tropical butterflies flying freely in a greenhouse recreating their natural habitat. Exotic plants and warm climate transport visitors to distant lands.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature

visits.text: The priory church (1722) surprises with its three onion-domed bell towers that draw a baroque silhouette in the hollow of the Vosges hills. Inside, the Silbermann organ of 1746, a listed Historic Monument, is the only authentic survivor of Jean-André Silbermann's work.

The Haute Chapelle, a 12th-century Romanesque construction, overlooks the village from a wooded relief. According to legend, the mule transporting Saint Quirin's relics from Rome stopped here in 1049 and refused to go further.
Walk around the priory to find the miraculous fountain below. For centuries, it has been attributed with healing powers for skin diseases.
The archaeological site of Croix Guillaume, accessible by a marked forest trail, reveals a Gallo-Roman hamlet: traces of dwellings, necropolis, sandstone quarries and cult remains.

In Lettenbach, the Verriers chapel (1756), rococo style, sports an onion-domed bell tower and folk art stained glass. The monks had established a glassworks here in the 15th century that became a Royal Manufacture under Louis XV.

activities.text: Take the Club Vosgien marked trails around ponds and deciduous forests. The village counts 75 listed or registered buildings, from Lorraine farms to wayside crosses.
Seven churches and chapels scattered around the village form the "7 Roses" circuit. Each tells its story, between Christianized Celtic sanctuaries and forest hermitages.
In summer, the Silbermann Musical Days offer organ recitals in the priory church: a rare moment in an exceptional setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Est Road Trip: Vineyards, Ramparts and Forests

visits.text: Mandelieu-la-Napoule: seaside castle (interior & gardens).
Forêt du Grand Duc (Mandelieu): mimosas (winter period) and forest trails.
Mont San Peyre: viewpoint over the bay of Cannes and the Lérins islands.
Corniche d'Or (Estérel): panoramic route and stops at coves.
Selection of calanques: Saint-Barthélémy, Notre-Dame, Maupas, Maubois, Île des Vieilles, coves of l'Aiguille.
Cap Roux: hiking departure point and viewpoints over red rocks & sea.
Saint-Raphaël: old town/port and coastal trail from Santa Lucia to Calanque du Fournas.

San Rafeu church, a 12th-century Romanesque structure, is a classified historic monument. Its foundations rest on a site occupied since Roman times. The adjoining presbytery houses the municipal archaeological museum, with collections ranging from prehistory to underwater archaeology.

Climb the 129 steps of the San Rafeu Tower, a 13th-century fortified tower standing 25 meters high. From the summit, the 360° panorama embraces the basilica's domes, the red rocks of the Estérel, the Mediterranean, and Saint-Tropez Bay—a view worth every step.

The Basilica of Notre-Dame de la Victoire, with its Byzantine domes, has dominated the seafront since the late 19th century. Its neo-Romanesque architecture blends golden stone and pink sandstone from the Estérel.

The archaeological museum displays amphorae, anchors, and objects recovered from wrecks off the coast. One section is devoted to the Paleolithic with vestiges discovered in the region—the deep past made tangible.

The old harbor and its daily Provençal market compose an animated Mediterranean tableau. The shaded lanes of the 'village quarter' preserve the atmosphere of an old peasant hamlet—old Provence amid the resort.

activities.text: Sea kayaking from Agay bay (weather and supervision permitting).
Cap Roux hike (Estérel): marked trail, views over Mercantour/Estérel/Mediterranean.
Snorkeling at Calanque du Fournas (Saint-Raphaël).

Take the Corniche d'Or, a 40 km road between Saint-Raphaël and Cannes. Under umbrella pines, the red porphyry rocks of the Estérel plunge into the turquoise Mediterranean. Stops possible at the coves of Agay, Dramont, and Anthéor—one of France's most spectacular coastal drives.

The Agay roadstead, sheltered between Cap Dramont and Pointe de la Baumette, offers calm waters ideal for swimming, kayaking, and paddleboarding. The sandy beach is bordered by pines and red rocks—postcard Riviera.
Six dive clubs offer outings around the Golden Islands, Cap Dramont, and offshore wrecks. The seabed of the Cap Roux reserve shelters groupers, brown meagres, and gorgonians in protected waters.

Hike in the Estérel massif toward Pic de l'Ours or Mont Vinaigre (614 m, the highest point). Trails wind between red rocks, fragrant maquis, and panoramas over the coast—volcanic drama meets Mediterranean blue.

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour

visits.text: Colette's birthplace, in the village heart, has been restored according to the writer's own descriptions. Wallpaper, parquet, woodwork, and vegetable garden recreate the setting of her childhood in Puisaye.

The Musée Colette occupies the château rebuilt in the 17th century. It offers a sensory discovery of the writer's life: manuscripts, photographs, personal objects, and immersive artistic installations.

The Tour Sarrasine, an ovoid 11th–12th century keep, is the last vestige of the old medieval fortress. Colette evokes it in 'Claudine at School': 'the Saracen tower, thick, low, sheathed entirely in ivy, crumbling at the top.'
The village church, recognizable by its absent bell tower, stands on the main square. Dating from the 13th century, it's part of the 'Following Gabrielle's Footsteps' trail through the village.

On the road to Moutiers, the Poterie de la Bâtisse perpetuates ten generations of know-how. The old 18th-century reclining kiln and 1930 workshop are still in operation. Colette's pencil pot is among the iconic creations.

activities.text: Take the 'Following Gabrielle's Footsteps' walk through the village. The one-hour route passes places evoked in Colette's work, from the Petit Saint-Jean washhouse to woods that 'ripple to infinity.'
Puisaye has been the land of potters since the Middle Ages. Visit the open workshops of Saint-Amand-en-Puisaye and discover the region's characteristic blue stoneware.

The Puisaye countryside—a bocage of ponds and forests—lends itself to peaceful hikes. Sunken lanes bordered by hedges lead from village to village through a landscape Colette described as 'the most beautiful country in the world.'

days_plan.itin_title: Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: Discovery of the medieval village of Saint-Savin and its Benedictine abbey overlooking the valley.
Walk in the Val d'Azun and observation of preserved landscapes.

The Abbey of Saint-Savin-sur-Gartempe, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1983, is nicknamed the "Romanesque Sistine Chapel." Look up: 700 square meters of 11th–12th-century frescoes cover the vault 17 meters overhead, unrolling the Old Testament from Creation to Moses.

The bell tower-porch presents an Apocalypse cycle, while the crypt preserves scenes from the lives of Saints Savin and Cyprien, two martyred brothers from the 5th century who gave the village its name.

Explore the monastic building: the former monks' cells, refectory, and monastic garden offer insight into the spiritual and material daily life of a Benedictine abbey founded under Charlemagne in the 9th century.
The 14th-century Gothic spire, rebuilt in the 19th century, rises nearly 80 meters. From the banks of the Gartempe, the panorama of the abbey and village is stunning.

activities.text: Sensory experience at the Jardins des Bains: Babylon hammams, Emerald Forest and Mesopotamian Ziggurat.
Follow the Valley of the Frescoes along the Gartempe River. Several Romanesque churches dot the route, each adorned with medieval wall paintings: Saint-Germain, Antigny, Jouhet.
Discover the abbey with an immersive tablet-guided tour. Three routes of 30 min, 1h, or 1h30 are available, with an animated version for children.
Walk along the Gartempe at the foot of the abbey. The wooded path lets you observe the river and access beautiful viewpoints of the Romanesque chevet.

days_plan.itin_title: The Pyrenees Spa Trail: Thermal Baths from Ax-les-Thermes to Bagnères-de-Luchon
Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Suliac has been classified as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages since 1999. The narrow lanes, so tight that two people cannot pass side by side, wind between granite houses with arched doorways and thatched roofs. Fishing nets still hang from the facades.
The 6th-century church, founded by the monk Suliau, houses stained glass windows, wooden sculptures, and maritime ex-votos left by the families of Newfoundland fishermen.
Walk down the Ruette des Petits Puits - a 17th-century well gives the lane its name. Legend says it concealed an underground passage connecting the church to the harbor.
At the harbor, dories - flat-bottomed boats of the Newfoundland fishermen - sway facing the Rance River. Sailors from Saint-Suliac departed each year to fish for cod off the coast of Newfoundland.
The Beauchet tidal mill, listed as a Historic Monument, used tidal energy to grind grain. Rebuilt in stone after a fire, it operated until 1980.

At low tide, stone foundations emerge in the Vigneux cove. Listed as a Historic Monument since 1986, this site is believed to be an ancient fortified Viking camp where longships sheltered on the landward side.

activities.text: Climb to the summit of Mont Garrot (73 m) for a 360° panorama over the Rance estuary, the harbor, and the Viking remains below.

Reach the Grainfollet oratory via the coastal path. In 1874, fishermen promised to build this sanctuary if all returned safely from Newfoundland. Twenty years later, the vow was fulfilled. At sunset, the view over the Rance is sublime.
The Saint-Suliac peninsula loop follows the old salt marshes, Beauchet mill, and the Chablé menhir (5 m high, nicknamed 'Gargantua's tooth'). Warning: some passages are submerged at high tide.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Historic center: Gothic church, corbelled houses and market halls.
Ramparts and gates; panorama over the Monts du Lyonnais.

activities.text: Heritage loop within the walls (2–3 km).
Ridge path to a high point for landscape reading.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Île d'Oléron, the largest French Atlantic island (30 km long). The free viaduct (1966, 3 km) links it to the mainland. Varied landscapes: pine forests in the south, salt marshes in the north, fine sand beaches on the west coast.

The Chassiron lighthouse, at the northern tip of the island, has worn its black and white stripes since 1836. 224 steps to the lantern – views of Fort Boyard and Île d'Aix on clear days. The spiral garden at the lighthouse's base echoes oyster shell patterns.

Le Château d'Oléron, former stronghold at the island's entrance. The Vauban citadel guarded the estuary. Today, its ramparts house an artisan and local produce market (summer). The colorful port cabins have become artists' studios.

Fort Boyard, oval fortress built between 1801 and 1857 between Oléron and Île d'Aix. Never used militarily, it became famous through the TV game show. No visits inside, but cruises circle it – an iconic silhouette set on the ocean.

activities.text: Cruise around Fort Boyard. Departures from Boyardville or Saint-Denis-d'Oléron. Full circuit of the fort, passing near Île d'Aix. Commentary on construction history and filming anecdotes.

Oyster tasting at La Cotinière port, the leading artisanal fishing port in Charente-Maritime and France's sixth largest. Auction in the morning, tasting shacks in the afternoon. Oléron's 'fines de claire' and 'spéciales' oysters have an incomparable briny flavor.

Île d'Oléron beaches: Grande Plage at Saint-Trojan, Les Saumonards at Boyardville, Vert-Bois in the south. Maritime pine forests stretch to the sand. The little Saint-Trojan train crosses the forest to Gatseau beach.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: The Musée de l'Annonciade, housed in a 16th-century chapel, holds a world-class collection: Pointillist, Nabis, and Fauvist paintings. Signac, Matisse, Derain, and Marquet are all represented—a reminder that Saint-Tropez was a major center of avant-garde painting.

The Citadel, erected in 1602 under Henri IV, has dominated the harbor for four centuries. The hexagonal keep, a historic monument since 1921, houses the Museum of Maritime History. Models, artifacts, and immersive scenography recount the Tropezian sailors—from whaling to trade with the Ottoman Empire.

Place des Lices, shaded by century-old plane trees, has been the village's beating heart since the 19th century. On Tuesdays and Saturdays, the Provençal market takes over the square. The rest of the time, pétanque games animate the café terraces.

Notre-Dame de l'Assomption church, with its characteristic ochre and pink bell tower, has watched over the village since the 16th century. Inside, the bust of Saint Torpès recalls the founding legend of the town.

From the Citadel ramparts, about thirty peacocks roam freely. The plunging view over Tropezian rooftops, the naval cemetery, and the gulf composes one of the coast's most beautiful panoramas—peacocks included.

activities.text: Follow the coastal path from Graniers beach. This seaside trail hugs the coves and headlands, offering panoramas between pine groves and turquoise waters. Swimming is possible in the wild coves—nature's own infinity pools.
The old harbor invites aimless wandering: fishing boats mingle with yachts, and colorful facades reflect in the water. Head to Quai Jean-Jaurès for the permanent spectacle of maritime life.

Push on to Ramatuelle, a medieval village perched on Paillas hill overlooking Pampelonne Bay. Its spiral lanes and ramparts offer a tranquil counterpoint to Tropezian bustle—old Provence above the glitz.

days_plan.itin_title: Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: Saint-Vaast-la-Hougue, voted France's Favorite Village in 2019, juts into the sea like a ship's prow. Its Vauban quay runs alongside an active fishing port—third-largest in the Manche department—where trawlers unload their daily catch.

Walk the causeway from the Sailors' Chapel—the choir of the original 11th-century church dedicated to Those Lost at Sea—to La Hougue Fort. The 66-foot Vauban tower, a UNESCO World Heritage site since 2008, commands the bay from its granite promontory 130 feet above sea level.

Board the amphibious boat to reach Tatihou Island, 70 acres of protected wilderness. Its twin Vauban tower—69 feet tall, 66 feet in diameter—once crossed fire with La Hougue's to seal the bay after the naval defeat of 1692.

Tatihou's Maritime Museum houses archaeological collections from shipwrecks of the royal fleet sunk during the 1692 Battle of La Hougue. Everyday objects, cannons, and wreckage tell the story of this defeat at the hands of the Anglo-Dutch fleet.

Tatihou's gardens shelter remarkable flora protected within granite dikes and walls. Palm trees from the Val de Saire, exotic plants, and wildflowers share space with a bird sanctuary hosting over a hundred nesting species.

activities.text: Walk to Tatihou at low tide, following the submersible path through oyster beds. At high tide, the amphibious boat hoists itself onto wheels for the return journey on land—a uniquely Norman mode of transport.

Discover the oyster beds between Saint-Vaast and Tatihou in the Cul de Loup inlet. Saint-Vaast oysters, renowned for their hazelnut taste, can be sampled right at the source from local oyster farmers along the port.
In summer, the Traversées de Tatihou festival brings maritime music concerts to the island. Experience the unique atmosphere of an island festival accessible only by sea.

days_plan.itin_title: Manche Road Trip: Cotentin Peninsula & Mont-Saint-Michel

Church of Saint-Véran and porch decorated with sculpted monsters

Discovery of local crafts.

visits.text: Departure from Limoges and journey to Coussac-Bonneval through the rolling landscapes of southern Haute-Vienne.
Guided tour of Château de Bonneval, medieval fortress inhabited by the same family for nearly a millennium.

activities.text: Walk through the town of Coussac-Bonneval, with stop at the main square and view of the castle moats.
Stroll through the local market of Saint-Yrieix-la-Perche, renowned for its local products and traditional madeleines.
Climb up the Tour du Plô to admire the medieval rooftops and the Limousin countryside.

Local produce break (local products) on the village square.

days_plan.itin_title: French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary

visits.text: Sainte-Croix-du-Verdon — village built on a rocky promontory at the exit of the Gorges du Verdon.
Picturesque old houses, flowered squares and 16th-century parish church.
Village belvedere — 180° panorama over the lake and surrounding mountains.

activities.text: Water sports center — windsurfing, kayak, pedal boat or sailing on the turquoise waters.
Hiking towards the hills overlooking the lake or sunset stroll on the pier.
Tuesday morning market and local products on the church square.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Lake Sainte-Croix: A Guide to Watersports & Village Visits
Verdon Gorge Road Trip: Moustiers-Sainte-Marie, Castellane & Turquoise Waters

Small squares and houses built against the monastic structures.

activities.text: Loop of the Carthusian hamlets (3 km).
Forest trail at the edge of Pilat for viewpoint.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Listed among France's Most Beautiful Villages, Sainte-Énimie clings to the slopes of the Tarn gorges with its limestone houses. Cobbled calades climb between archways, vaulted passages, and stone stairways.

The former Benedictine monastery, founded in the 6th century according to the legend of Saint Enimie, preserves a Romanesque chapter house and a Gothic ribbed-vault refectory. The "Vieux Logis" museum recreates daily life in the old Cévennes.

The Burle spring gushes at the village's heart. Legend tells how Enimie, a Merovingian princess afflicted with leprosy, was healed by these miraculous waters. The resurgence drains the Sauveterre causse.
Take the path up to Sainte-Énimie's hermitage. The remains of the cave chapel overlook the gorges. The panorama plunges to the Tarn 500 meters below and opens across the causses.

Below Sainte-Énimie, the hamlet of Castelbouc huddles beneath ruins of a castle perched on a rocky spur. Houses seem glued to the cliff face. The Castelbouc cave, on the Tarn's left bank, is one of Europe's largest flooded cavities.

Sainte-Énimie clings to the flank of the Sauveterre causse, between 600-meter-high cliffs. According to legend, the Merovingian princess Énimie, sister of King Dagobert, was cured of leprosy by bathing in the Burle spring and founded a monastery in the 6th century.

The Burle spring gushes at the village heart in a turquoise-water basin. This karst resurgence, explored by divers through 400 meters of underground galleries, constitutes one of the major outlets of the Sauveterre causse.

The church of Notre-Dame-du-Gourg, backed against the causse, dates from the 12th century and was remodeled in the 14th. Its Romanesque portal with round arch and two voussoirs opens onto a three-bay nave. Inside, a chapel illustrates Saint Énimie's story in contemporary ceramics.
The chapter house of the former Benedictine monastery, restored in 951, housed the monks' refectory and passing pilgrims. Its walls preserve acanthus decorations and carved human faces.
The wheat hall preserves one of the last stone grain measures in Gévaudan. The old village around the hall reveals its half-timbered houses, vaulted passages, and broad stone steps worn by centuries.

Castelbouc, a troglodyte village one kilometer upstream, can be visited from the riverside path. Its houses are pressed against the cliff, dominated by ruins of a medieval castle destroyed in 1592 to prevent it serving as Protestant refuge.

activities.text: Les Détroits form the Tarn gorges' narrowest passage. Cliffs squeeze to within a few meters. Best discovered by flat-bottomed boat or canoe when light plunges between the walls.

Drive to Point Sublime, a natural viewpoint on the Sauveterre causse. Your gaze plunges 400 meters into the Tarn canyon. The ochre and gray rock changes hue with the hour. Accessible by road or trail from the Saint-Chély cirque.
Descend by flat-bottomed boat, propelled by a boatman, through the gorges' most confined section. Silence, rock, and water's reflection compose an almost surreal scene.
The hermitage trail climbs from the Tarn bridge to the cave where Énimie supposedly retreated. Short but steep (45 min round trip), it offers a plunging panorama of the village and river's bend.

Outfitters offer Tarn canoe descents on several routes (from 30 min to over 5h). The stretch between Sainte-Énimie and La Malène crosses the Défilé des Détroits, the gorges' narrowest and most spectacular passage.

Aven Armand, 30 minutes by car on the Méjean causse, shelters a forest of 400 giant stalagmites, the largest reaching 30 meters. The funicular descent accesses an underground hall of cathedral dimensions.

Saint-Chély-du-Tarn, one kilometer downstream, offers a spectacle of cascades plunging into the Tarn from the cliff. Its 11th-century Romanesque church and semi-troglodyte chapel of Cénaret complete the visit.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Opened in 1927, the Russian Cemetery is the largest Orthodox necropolis in Western Europe. More than 15,000 Russian émigrés who fled the 1917 revolution rest here.
Rudolf Nureyev, Serge Lifar, Andrei Tarkovsky, and Princess Obolensky number among the 5,200 graves. Princes, artists, and resistance fighters lie alongside entire families.

The Church of Our Lady of the Dormition was inaugurated in 1939. Its green roof symbolizes the earth, its blue dome the heavens. The architecture draws inspiration from 15th and 16th-century Novgorod.
The portico features a fresco of the Assumption; the dome shows Christ bestowing blessings. The crypt houses the tombs of bishops and architect Albert Benois.
Orthodox crosses, carved steles, and frescoes testify to the spiritual richness of the Russian diaspora. Birches, spruces, and pines create an authentically Russian atmosphere.

activities.text: Stroll among the graves beneath the towering birch trees. The Russian-style landscaping with small benches and trees creates a pastoral setting unique in France.
The municipal park runs along the Orge on the edge of town. Walking paths and playgrounds invite a nature break after visiting the cemetery.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne Journey: Castles and River Valleys

visits.text: Sainte-Suzanne crowns a rocky spur rising 70 meters above the Erve valley. Listed among France's Most Beautiful Villages and as a Small Town of Character, this fortress was the only stronghold to successfully resist the assaults of William the Conqueror in the 11th century.

Step into the castle courtyard to discover the Renaissance lodge, built between 1608 and 1613 by Guillaume Fouquet de la Varenne, Henri IV's Postmaster General. It now houses the CIAP (Centre for Architecture and Heritage Interpretation) with scale models, audiovisuals and tactile displays exploring Mayenne's heritage.

The 11th-century quadrangular keep, erected by the Beaumont family from around 1020, stands protected by round towers equipped with arrow slits—the flour tower and the powder tower. The entrance was on the first floor via a ladder, designed to protect the lord during attacks.

Walk the patrol path along the double rampart walls. The 360° view sweeps across the Coëvrons hills, the Mayenne hedgerow countryside and the Erve valley. Head to the Watch Tower and West Tower for the finest panoramas over the town's rooftops.

The church, remodeled in 1884, preserves a Renaissance portal and remarkable statues from the 14th to 17th centuries, including those of Saint John the Baptist and Saint Suzanne, patron saint of engaged couples.

Push open the door to the municipal museum, housed in the former 17th-century courthouse. Nine rooms trace 3,000 years of local history through models, weapons from the Hundred Years' War and elements of Celtic vitrified walls. The centerpiece: France's oldest suit of armor, dating from 1410-1430, restored by the Musée des Invalides.

Descend toward the Grand Moulin, the oldest mill in the lordship. Transformed from a grain mill into a paper mill, it's still run by a master papermaker who crafts pure rag paper by hand using 13th to 18th-century techniques. The town once boasted 16 paper mills from the 17th to 19th centuries.

activities.text: The Mills Walk follows the Erve for 3.6 km below the fortified town. This family-friendly path passes the vestiges of old water mills installed along the river.
Visit the Erves dolmen, Mayenne's oldest monument. This Neolithic megalith, approximately 6,500 years old and classified in 1889, once sheltered the burials of 14 individuals.
Climb to Tertre Ganne in the late afternoon. This former strategic post from the Hundred Years' War offers the finest panorama of the medieval town and castle—spectacular at sunset.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: The Arch of Germanicus (19 AD), a two-bay Roman arch that marked the entrance to the bridge over the Charente. Moved stone by stone in 1843 to escape demolition. Dedicatory inscriptions to Tiberius, Germanicus and Drusus Caesar are readable on the attic.

The Gallo-Roman amphitheater of Saintes (1st century) could hold 15,000 spectators. Built into a hillside valley, it retains its tiers, vomitoria and elliptical arena. Summer concerts and shows in this ancient setting.

The Abbaye aux Dames (11th-12th century), the first women's monastery in Saintonge. Romanesque facade sculpted with grimacing heads and fantastic animals. Conical bell tower covered in stone scales. Now a cultural center and home to an early music festival.

Saintes old town stretches between the Charente and the hillsides. Saint-Pierre Cathedral (rebuilt after the Wars of Religion), 18th-century mansions, medieval lanes. Wrought iron halls for the market.

activities.text: Guided tour of Gallo-Roman Saintes. The tourist office offers a complete circuit: Arch of Germanicus, Saint-Saloine baths, amphitheater, archaeological museum. Mediolanum Santonum was capital of the Aquitaine province.

Cruise on the Charente departing from Saintes. Traditional gabares or electric boats head upriver toward Cognac. Meadow landscapes, weeping willows, grey herons. Commentary on the history of cognac river transport.
Pineau and cognac tasting. Regional producers open their cellars for guided visits. Pineau des Charentes, a blend of grape must and cognac, is enjoyed chilled as an aperitif.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge

visits.text: Salernes — capital of ceramics, known for its production of hexagonal floor tiles.
Old town — Provençal streets, fountains and Roman bridge over the Bresque.

activities.text: Visit to a pottery workshop or the Terra Rossa museum.
Lively Sunday morning market on the central square.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages

visits.text: The village of Salers displays its Renaissance houses of black lava stone around the Place Tyssandier d'Escous. Perched at 950 metres altitude, this Most Beautiful Village of France preserves its 16th-century heritage intact: turrets, carved lintels, mullioned windows and ramparts recall its status as the former seat of the Bailliage des Hautes Montagnes d'Auvergne. The church of Saint-Mathieu houses a 15th-century Entombment and Aubusson tapestries.

The Puy Mary raises its pyramidal silhouette to 1,787 metres at the heart of the Cantal massif. Labelled Grand Site de France, this iconic summit offers a 360° panorama from its orientation table over radiating glacial valleys, triangular summer pasture plateaux and the rocky puys of Europe's largest stratovolcano (2,700 km²). A 30-minute paved trail from the Pas de Peyrol (the highest road pass in the Massif Central at 1,589 m) leads to this exceptional viewpoint reaching as far as Mont Blanc on a clear day.

The Esplanade de Barrouze opens a dizzying balcony over the Maronne valley and the Cantal mountains. This grassy terrace, a true Salers postcard view, reveals the Puy Violent and the entire chain of puys in a landscape where the green of pastures meets the blue of distant ridges.
Perched village with dark lava stone houses, ramparts and gates; central square lined with mansions.
Saint-Mathieu Church and sloping streets toward the suburbs.
High points on the puys and pastures of the High Plateau.

activities.text: Tasting Salers PDO cheese is a must in this town that gave the cheese its name. Produced exclusively on farms and in summer from raw milk of Salers cows, this cheese aged at least 3 months reveals an incomparable rustic intensity. Farms offer visits to burons (traditional mountain dairies) and meetings with producers.

The hike to the summit of Puy Mary follows a paved trail with steps and risers climbing 195 metres of elevation gain in 30 minutes. The Grand Site territory offers 350 km of waymarked trails, from the GR®400 circling the massif to family-friendly loops. The most daring aim for sunrise or sunset for a grandiose spectacle over the sleeping volcano.

The Plomb du Cantal, the massif's highest peak at 1,855 metres, can be reached from the Le Lioran resort by cable car. This mechanical ascent offers a spectacular alternative for hikers to access the ridges of Europe's largest volcano and contemplate the Chaîne des Puys, the Cézallier and the Monts du Forez.
Salers hill loop (3–5 km) with views over the Maronne valley.
Heritage route within the walls and reading of turrets and watchtowers.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions
The Volcanoes of Auvergne: A Road Trip Through Medieval Towns & Lunar Landscapes

visits.text: The Belle Époque thermal baths in Spanish-Moorish style, built in 1894, dominate the spa quarter. Their water contains 300 grams of salt per liter—ten times saltier than seawater.
Descend into the Bayaà crypt where the salt spring gushes, 200 million years old. This fountain has belonged to the Parts-Prenants shareholders since 1587, a unique medieval collective ownership.
The Musée du Sel traces 35 centuries of salt history in a 17th-century Salies house. The legend of the boar explains how hunters discovered the salt spring.
The Salines produce 2,000 tons of salt annually. This white PGI salt is essential for curing authentic Bayonne ham, giving it its distinctive flavor.
The Église Saint-Vincent blends 11th-century architecture with Flamboyant Gothic style. Its 18th-century altar dominates the nave, restored after a devastating fire.

activities.text: Indulge in thermal treatments recognized by the French Academy of Medicine in 1891. The water rich in 26 trace elements treats rheumatism and gynecological conditions.
Stroll along the Saleys River that winds between half-timbered houses on stilts. Salies is nicknamed the Béarn Venice for its stone bridges and waterside charm.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Atlantiques Road Trip: Basque Country & Béarn

visits.text: Grande Saline (UNESCO).
Thermal baths.
Fort Saint-André.
Old town.

activities.text: Mountain biking in the forest.
Visit to diamond cutting workshops.
Hike to the Flumen waterfalls.

days_plan.itin_title: Jura Mountains Road Trip, France: Comtois Traditions & Emerald Lakes

visits.text: Priory of Saint-Martin-de-Salles: Romanesque cloister, church and conventual buildings.
Wine-growing village with golden stone facades; alleys and small gardens.

activities.text: Walking loop "cloister–village–vineyards" (3 km, very easy).
Short climb to a viewpoint over the Beaujolais hills.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Reach the Montenvers site aboard the little red cog railway in service since 1909. At 1,913 meters altitude, discover the Mer de Glace—the largest glacier in the French Alps, stretching 7 kilometers down the valley. Visit the Ice Grotto accessible via more than 400 steps carved into the glacier itself.

Discover Samoëns, a charming village classified among France's most beautiful flowered villages. The heart centers around the Place du Gros Tilleul, where a massive linden tree planted in 1438 still provides shade. Admire the Church of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption, completed in 1555—a monument to centuries of village devotion.

Explore this exceptional 3.7-hectare Alpine botanical garden, classified as a Remarkable Garden of France. Gifted in 1906 to her native village by Marie-Louise Cognacq-Jaÿ, the garden showcases over 2,500 mountain plant species along 1.5 km of winding trails. The Château Chapel offers panoramic views over the Giffre Valley.

activities.text: Board the historic red train that climbs from Chamonix to the Montenvers site facing the Mer de Glace. The narrated journey reveals the dramatic history of mountaineering that transformed this valley—from 19th-century pioneers to modern alpinists.

Descend the metal staircase (more than 400 steps) to access the grotto carved fresh each year into the glacier. Marvel at the ice sculptures and translucent blue walls—a magical world deep within the living glacier.

Wander this unique Alpine garden where every sense awakens. The serpentine path leads through meticulously recreated Alpine ecosystems—from rocky outcrops to lush meadows—revealing how mountain plants adapt to harsh conditions with breathtaking beauty.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Savoie Road Trip: Alpine Lakes & Mont Blanc

visits.text: Sancerre sits on its rocky butte like a ship's prow overlooking the Loire. From the Tour des Fiefs (14th century), the panorama sweeps 360°: Loire Valley, vineyards terraced like amphitheaters, Pouilly-Fumé hills across the river, Morvan on the horizon. The climb is worth it. 183 steps, stunning view at every level.

The old town is lovely to walk through. Stone houses, cobbled streets, hidden passages. The Saint-Jean Gate (15th century) is the last medieval gate standing. The Saint-Père-la-None Church towers over the square; inside, beautiful 15th-century frescoes recently restored. Several viewpoint terraces offer stunning views of the vineyards.

The Maison des Sancerre is the essential stop to understand the appellation. Interactive museum, tasting workshop, vineyard explanation. You'll learn everything about terroirs (terre blanche, caillottes, silex), grape varieties (Sauvignon for whites, Pinot noir for reds and rosés), vinification. At the end, commented tasting of 3 wines. Booking recommended in high season.

Sancerre has over 300 winegrowers. Many cellars welcome visitors, often by appointment. Some favorites: Domaine Vacheron (organic, biodynamic), Domaine François Cotat (legendary whites), Pascal Jolivet (contemporary cellar, beautiful view). Direct sales, commented tastings. Allow 1h per cellar.

activities.text: Crottin de Chavignol is Sancerre's other star. This small goat cheese (AOC since 1976) comes in 5 stages of aging: fresh, semi-dry, dry, very dry, "stone." Dozens of producers around Sancerre. Visit a farm, watch milking, taste cheese at different stages. The Dubois-Boulay farm in Chavignol opens daily in summer.

The "Route du Crottin" is a 32 km circuit through the Sancerre vineyards. It connects Sancerre, Chavignol, Verdigny, Bué — the four main wine-producing villages. Signs, explanatory panels, viewpoints. Can be done by car or bike (hilly, allow 3-4 hours). Very beautiful in May-June (vines in flower) and September (harvest).

The Loire flows 8 km from Sancerre. Several river ports for walks: Saint-Satur, Saint-Thibault, Tracy-sur-Loire. The banks are wild, the river wide, migratory birds stop here. At Saint-Thibault, the 11th-century Romanesque church is a gem.

days_plan.itin_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route

visits.text: Grostenquin — Exhibition of 150 nativity scenes from 5 continents, large Provençal nativity scene (~45 m²).
Destry — Nativity scene with antique figurines (50–60 cm), recent restoration.
Herny — Saint-Étienne Church (1829): traditional nativity scene (seasonal opening).
Créhange — Luxembourg Family Nativity Scene: ~7 m², 130 figures and automatons.
Bambiderstroff — Saint-Félix de Nole Church: wood nativity scene/Palestinian landscape (side altar).
Raville — Saint-Barthélemy Church (1758): bobbin lace, Tiffany and ceramic nativity scenes.
Bionville-sur-Nied — Historic nativity scene of the Kahl family (1910) restored.
Sanry-sur-Nied — FICI santon makers' workshop: monumental nativity scene and workshop visit (by appointment).

activities.text: Photo circuit of Romanesque and neo-Gothic churches of the Pays de Nied.
Purchase of santons and Christmas crafts at FICI santon makers (according to opening hours).

days_plan.itin_title: The Moselle Nativity Route: A Festive Christmas Road Trip Through Border Villages

visits.text: Meursault — tour of the village and church square, view of the vineyard
Puligny-Montrachet — walk through the climats around the village
Chassagne-Montrachet — discovery of the village and wine paths
Santenay — end of the itinerary and viewpoint over the valley

Hot air balloon flight over the Côte de Beaune (takeoff from Beaune/Pommard area, depending on conditions)

days_plan.itin_title: Burgundy's Grand Crus Route: Prestige Vineyards & Historic Wine Cellars

visits.text: The Franciscan monastery emerges at the end of a steep path: France's only Baroque convent, its cloister with Mexican hacienda airs houses 17th-century frescoes depicting Saint Francis.
Push open the door of Saint-Sauveur Church: ornate Baroque decor, monumental columns, an Italian organ from 1847 carried up by mules from Nice.
The alleyways and "pountin" wind between fountain squares and wash houses: vaulted passages, vertiginous staircases, the village seems to tumble into the valley.
Three fortified castles once watched over Saorge, "the lock of the Roya," a stronghold reputed impregnable. Ruins still dominate the village.
Admire the purple lauze rooftops quarried locally: tall colorful houses cascade like a waterfall of stones.

activities.text: Mercantour National Park reveals its treasures: hike to Bronze Age prehistoric engravings, 5,000 years old.
Board the Train des Merveilles on the Nice-Tende line: tunnels, viaducts, vertiginous panoramas, one of France's most beautiful railway sections.
Refresh yourself at the Sémite pool: crystal-clear spring water nestled in a green setting, a secret paradise for swimmers.
Follow the Baroque and historic organ route from village to village: every church in the Roya Valley holds its treasure.
Sit down at one of the village restaurants to savor herb ravioli and Saorge specialties.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure

visits.text: Labourdine houses and square; departure Petit Train de la Rhune (depending on season).
The Église Saint-Martin raises its five-tiered bell tower at the heart of the village. Its sculpted bell ranks among France's most ornately decorated, a masterpiece of Basque craftsmanship.
The Grottes de Sare burrow into the mountain for 900 meters. The son-et-lumière guided tour reveals stalactites, stalagmites, and traces of Paleolithic occupation dating back millennia.
Maison Ortillopitz, built in 1660, perfectly illustrates traditional Basque architecture. Its wooden galleries and period furnishings tell the story of rural Basque life across the centuries.
Follow the Galtzada, a medieval route that once linked Bayonne to Spain. Stone bridges cross mountain streams through a green valley haven.

activities.text: Ascent to La Rhune (train or hike) — sea-mountain panorama.
Hike the Camino de Santiago paths that have wound through Sare since the Middle Ages. The GR8 and GR10 trails offer panoramic loops around La Rhune mountain.
Explore Ainhoa and Ascain, authentic Basque villages classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages. Their half-timbered houses frame pelota courts where locals still gather.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Pyrénées-Atlantiques Road Trip: Basque Country & Béarn

visits.text: Medieval city, Saint-Sacerdos cathedral and stone slab alleyways.

Sarlat holds the world record for density of protected monuments: 65 classified buildings packed into just 11 hectares. France's first historic preservation zone under the Malraux Act (1964), the town is a maze of honey-colored stone townhouses, medieval alleys, and slate-roofed buildings that seem frozen in amber. Walking these streets feels like stepping onto a film set—which, in fact, it often is.

The Maison de La Boétie, built in the 16th century, ranks among Sarlat's most beautiful Renaissance facades. Mullioned windows, pilasters, and sculpted medallions adorn the stonework. This was the birthplace of Étienne de la Boétie in 1530—Montaigne's closest friend and author of the revolutionary essay Discourse on Voluntary Servitude.

Sainte-Marie Church underwent a dramatic transformation by architect Jean Nouvel, who converted the medieval structure into a covered market. A panoramic glass elevator now rises through the bell tower, offering 360-degree views over Sarlat's slate rooftops. Nouvel's massive Corten steel doors sparked heated debate—but the view is undeniable.

activities.text: Gourmet market (truffle, foie gras) depending on day.

Sarlat's market is legendary throughout Périgord. Wednesday morning it fills Place de la Liberté; on Saturday it sprawls through the entire old town. Foie gras, winter truffles (December through March), walnuts, wild mushrooms, tangy goat cheeses, and charcuterie crowd the stalls. The truffle market alone draws connoisseurs from across France.

The Manoir de Gisson at Place des Oies is the only classified private mansion in Sarlat open for tours. Furnished with period pieces, it reveals how wealthy 17th-century merchant families lived. The spiral staircase tower connects three floors of elegant rooms—a rare glimpse into private life behind these stone facades.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites
Dordogne Road Trip: Cave Art, Medieval Fortresses & Périgord Delights

visits.text: The Peace stained glass window by Marc Chagall, created between 1974 and 1976 for the 13th-century Cordeliers chapel, rises 12 meters high and spans 7.5 meters wide. This is the largest stained glass window ever designed by the artist, a hymn to life and reconciliation in celestial blue tones, emerald green, and flamboyant red. Allegorical figures (tree of life, prophets, animals) intertwine in poetic composition. Natural light animated by 600 m² of glass transforms throughout the day.

The Sarrebourg museum, installed in the former Cordeliers convent, presents Gallo-Roman archaeology and regional collections. Mosaics from the 2nd-3rd centuries, funerary steles, and ceramics attest to Roman Sarrebourg's importance. The medieval section displays sculptures, liturgical furniture, and paintings from the 15th to 18th centuries. The lapidary garden brings together fragments of ancient buildings.

The Sarrebourg canal marina, on the Marne-Rhine canal, offers boat rides and canal cruises. The port hosts 120 pleasure boat berths and welcomes cruise boats. Waterside promenades, nautical activities (canoe, pedal boat), and cycle paths along the canal. The Boat Museum traces the history of canal navigation and traditional trades. Boat rentals available for exploring the canal.

activities.text: Walk in the forest of Sarrebourg, 3,500 hectares of oaks and beeches crisscrossed by 50 km of marked trails. The Sentier des Sources (8 km) discovers the springs feeding the Sarre, with footbridges over streams and forest clearings. The Lorraine sandstone peaks offer panoramic views. Medium difficulty, 2h30 walking, signposting and maps at the tourist office.

Explore the historic center where the Saint-Barthélémy church (18th century) displays baroque altarpieces and an 18th-century organ. The pedestrian streets preserve 18th and 19th-century bourgeois houses. The Place du Marché, surrounded by arcaded facades, hosts a market on Tuesday and Friday mornings. The town hall (1770) in classical style faces the park with centuries-old trees.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: The Faience Museum occupies the former Moulin de la Blies, reconstructed in 2007 around the listed 1880 Winter Garden. This 750 m² metal and glass structure shelters 2,500 pieces tracing 200 years of ceramic production: earthenware services, decorative panels, Art Nouveau vases, and Art Deco creations. The collections present the evolution of techniques and styles from 1790 to the 1990s, when the last Sarreguemines kilns shut down.

The Casino des Faïenceries, an Art Nouveau jewel from 1927, amazes with its ceramic decorations: mosaics, friezes, and monumental panels by master ceramist Alexandre Sandier. The grand hall, completely covered in earthenware, evokes Sarreguemines' golden age when 3,000 workers produced 25 million pieces per year. The building now houses temporary exhibitions on ceramic history and industrial heritage.

The Faience Garden (Jardin des Faïenciers) displays monumental ceramic panels in an 8,000 m² landscaped park. The route presents 150 decorative pieces: Art Nouveau friezes, company signs, stove tiles, and architectural elements salvaged from demolished buildings. Each panel illustrates a facet of earthenware art: advertising, architecture, technical virtuosity. Free access year-round.

activities.text: Stroll through the German district (Deutsches Viertel) built between 1870 and 1918 during the German annexation. Neo-Gothic buildings, half-timbered houses, and bourgeois villas with Art Nouveau facades line the streets. The Sainte-Croix church (1886) in red sandstone, the town hall (1895) with its 46-meter tower, and the Protestant temple (1897) illustrate Wilhelminian architecture. A unique cross-border architectural heritage.

Cross the Saar footbridge to Germany and walk along the riverbanks connecting France and Saarland. The promenade links Sarreguemines to Saarbrücken through 15 km of greenways. Medieval mills, locks, and old factories punctuate the route. Cycling possible, bike rentals available on the French side. A border walk illustrating the Franco-German reconciliation.

visits.text: The Saulges cave valley is the only prehistoric site presenting decorated caves north of the Loire. Carved into 320-million-year-old limestone by the Erve river, this small canyon shelters 22 known cavities, classified Natura 2000, frequented by humans for at least 300,000 years.

Margot cave, classified Historic Monument since 1926, is the only decorated cave open to visitors in western France. In 2003, archaeologist Romain Pigeaud discovered over 200 prehistoric engravings from the Upper Paleolithic (~25,000 years ago): horses, bison, woolly rhinoceros and engraved birds—the latter extremely rare in cave art.

Rochefort cave, a human-sized chasm, reveals an archaeological excavation site, spectacular concretions (stalactites, stalagmites) and an underground lake. Excavations have uncovered a Solutrean habitat dated 25,000 to 20,000 years before present.

The Prehistory Museum, opened in 2017, traces the life of the Erve valley's first inhabitants through original archaeological collections: laurel leaves, spear points, reindeer antler harpoons, ibex plaquette. An immersive 3D dome allows virtual visits to Mayenne-Sciences cave, closed to the public, which contains drawings of bison and mammoths 27,000 years old.

Saint-Pierre church, in Saulges village, is a building constructed between the 8th and 10th centuries. A few minutes' walk away, the Céneré oratory perpetuates the memory of the hermit who evangelized the valley.

activities.text: Take hiking trail n°33 from the museum. It crosses the canyon passing Japanese stepping stones over the Erve, follows the limestone cliffs and offers plunging views of cave entrances nestled in the rock faces.
The canyon cliffs count a hundred climbing routes from 3a to 7c, on walls reaching 25 meters. A popular venue for initiation and recreational practice.

The Natura 2000 valley shelters wild orchids, dragonflies, rare butterflies and one of western France's most important bat colonies. Ouessant sheep maintain the site ecologically. Take time to observe wildlife at dusk.

days_plan.itin_title: Mayenne Circuit: Hedgerows and Medieval Towns

visits.text: The château-palace of the Dukes of Anjou has watched over the Loire since the 14th century. Its Gothic silhouette was immortalized in the Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry, one of medieval Europe's most celebrated illuminated manuscripts.

The Cavalry School has perpetuated French equestrian tradition since 1763. Its 18th-century buildings, classified as historic monuments, represent one of Europe's finest examples of military equestrian architecture.
The Tank Museum assembles over 200 military vehicles—one of the world's most significant collections of armored machinery.
The 12th-century Church of Saint-Pierre preserves rich liturgical furnishings and medieval sculptures that speak to centuries of devotion.

activities.text: Saumur's sparkling wine cellars extend for kilometers through the tuffeau limestone. Maison Bouvet-Ladubay, founded in 1851, offers tours through its subterranean galleries where méthode traditionnelle wines age in darkness before their fine bubbles see daylight.
The Loire à Vélo cycling route passes through Saumur. Landscaped quays follow the royal river to neighboring châteaux through vine-covered countryside.

The Saumur-Champigny vineyards cascade down limestone slopes. Cabernet Franc, Chenin Blanc, and Chardonnay grapes produce the renowned red, white, and sparkling wines that have made this region famous.

days_plan.itin_title: Maine-et-Loire Road Trip: Anjou and Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: The Château des Rohan stretches its neoclassical façade over 140 metres. Nicknamed the Little Alsatian Versailles, it was built by Nicolas Salins de Montfort after the fire of 1779.
The museums occupy the castle. Gallo-Roman and medieval archaeological collections, a Louise Weiss section on European integration, art, and history.
The rose garden spreads through the park. Created in the 19th century, it boasts over 550 varieties. In June and July, an explosion of colours and fragrances.
The locks of the Marne-Rhine Canal line up at Saverne. The Saint-Louis-Arzviller boat lift allows barges to cross a 44-metre height difference.

activities.text: Stroll along the canal. The marina faces the castle. The landscaped banks invite a leisurely walk.
The botanical garden brings together 2,500 plant species. Created in 1931, it is freely accessible. Medicinal and aromatic plants and an orchid collection.
Drive up to the Saverne pass. A crossing point between Alsace and Lorraine since Roman times. Panoramic view of the Northern Vosges.

days_plan.itin_title: Alsace and the Wine Route: Strasbourg to the Vosges

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Alpes Majesty: High Mountain Passes, Ski Resorts & Alpine Valleys

visits.text: Colbert acquired the Sceaux estate in 1670. The current château, rebuilt in 1856 by the Duke of Trévise, houses the departmental museum. Collections evoke French art from Louis XIV to Napoleon III.
The Pavillon de l'Aurore preserves a dome painted by Charles Le Brun. The Orangerie, built by Jules Hardouin-Mansart, measures 80 meters long.
Walk through the woods to Parc de Saint-Cloud. The national estate spreads across 460 hectares along the Seine.

activities.text: The 181-hectare Parc de Sceaux unfolds formal French gardens. André Le Nôtre exploited the terrain's relief to create two perspectives: the château axis and the Grande Cascade descending toward the Octagon Basin.
Montretout offers panoramic views over Paris and the Seine valley.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral, built between 1210 and 1310, is the jewel of Norman Gothic architecture in Orne. Its spires soar to 230 feet. The choir, a masterpiece of Île-de-France Gothic, is bathed in light from magnificent ancient windows. Two Michelin stars.
The Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, built in 1854 in neo-Gothic style, was the first in France dedicated to that title. Its interior decoration and distinctive lighting set it apart.

The Palais d'Argentré, built in 1778 for the bishop who tutored the future Louis XVIII, displays neoclassical facades and ordered gardens. It testifies to the clergy's splendor in the Age of Enlightenment.

The Departmental Museum of Religious Art, housed in a 14th-century listed building, displays metalwork, sculptures, paintings, and liturgical vestments from the Middle Ages to today, drawn from rural Orne churches.
Visit the Cours des Fontaines, a classified site with an 18th-century washhouse. This verdant haven follows the remnants of the old fortified wall.
Explore Sées to spot its 13 listed historic monuments, including the remains of the 11th-century Church of Saint-Pierre and the 17th-century chapel of the Hôtel-Dieu, adorned with paintings on wood.

activities.text: The Haras National du Pin—nicknamed the 'Versailles of Horses'—sprawls across 2,470 acres 12 miles from Sées. Founded in 1715 by order of Louis XIV, it houses red-brick stables, a ceremonial saddlery, and a collection of listed horse-drawn carriages.
From June to September, the 'Thursdays at Le Pin' present different horse breeds in the Aure riding hall. Equestrian shows, farrier demonstrations, and carriage rides complete the experience.
The Écouves forest, a few miles from Sées, peaks at Signal d'Écouves (1,355 feet), the highest point in western France. Marked trails wind through sessile oak and beech groves.

days_plan.itin_title: Orne Road Trip: Norman Bocage and Prestigious Stud Farms

visits.text: The Church of Sainte-Madeleine dominates Segré with its 30-meter-high neo-Byzantine dome. Classified stained glass windows flood the interior with colored light.
From the church esplanade, views sweep across the town and the confluence of the Oudon and Verzée rivers. These two waterways flow through this settlement founded in ancient Roman times.

The Château de la Lorie, built during Louis XIII's reign, stands as the northernmost of the Loire châteaux. Its grand salon, entirely composed of marble, evokes princely palaces with its elegant opulence.
The historic center preserves ancient houses and classified churches. Rue Pasteur features a half-timbered dwelling listed as a historic monument—a rare survival of medieval domestic architecture.

activities.text: The Mine Bleue in Noyant-la-Gravoyère descends 126 meters underground into an authentic slate quarry. Guided tours reveal the harsh working conditions of miners and the extraction techniques for the prized blue slate that roofed countless buildings.
The Oudon riverbanks offer shaded walks through rolling landscapes. The trail follows the peaceful river as it meanders through verdant countryside.
The local market showcases producers from the Angevin terroir. Artisan workshops and gastronomic events regularly animate the town with regional flavors and crafts.

days_plan.itin_title: Maine-et-Loire Road Trip: Anjou and Loire Valley Châteaux

visits.text: Séguret ranks among France's Most Beautiful Villages. Its cobbled calade lanes climb at the foot of the Dentelles de Montmirail, between honey-colored stone houses and vine trellises.
Pass through Porte Reynier, the fortified village's main entrance. The 15th-century belfry stands out with its unique wrought-iron spire, visible from far across the valley.
The 17th-century baroque Fontaine des Mascarons flows in the central square. Four sculpted faces spout water into a stone basin worn smooth by the centuries.
The Église Saint-Denis, built between the 10th and 13th centuries, houses a gilded wooden altarpiece and medieval frescoes. Its Romanesque bell-wall towers over the village rooftops.
Climb to the feudal castle ruins crowning the rock. The 360° panorama embraces the Rhône Valley, vineyards, and the jagged crests of the Dentelles de Montmirail.
The Place des Arceaux below surprises with its natural pergola formed by plane trees planted around 1860, whose branches have fused together over time.

activities.text: Hike into the Dentelles de Montmirail from Séguret. Trails wind between limestone cliffs and pine forests, with passages carved through rock.
Taste AOC Côtes-du-Rhône Villages Séguret wines directly in the village cellars or surrounding estates. The clay-limestone terroir yields powerful reds and fruity rosés.
In December, Séguret transforms into a living nativity scene: villagers reenact scenes from the Nativity in the lanes by torchlight. A unique Provençal spectacle.

days_plan.itin_title: Vaucluse: Avignon, Luberon Villages & Ventoux Routes

visits.text: The Humanist Library holds 670 volumes from Beatus Rhenanus. Listed as UNESCO Memory of the World in 2011, it is the only library of a great humanist to have survived intact.
Admire the 7th-century Merovingian lectionary. It is the oldest manuscript preserved in Alsace. The library also houses 550 incunabula.
The Church of Sainte-Foy dates from 1094. A Rhenish Romanesque building, it is part of the Romanesque Route of Alsace. Three-aisled nave and an octagonal tower.
The Church of Saint-Georges displays its Flamboyant Gothic style. Built between the 13th and 15th centuries, it once housed the medieval parish library.
Sélestat Christmas Market
Exhibits related to the historical origins of the Christmas tree

activities.text: From Sélestat, admire the Haut-Koenigsbourg Castle perched at 757 m.
Stroll through the historic centre. Renaissance houses line the streets. In December, it was here that the first mention of the Christmas tree appeared in 1521.
Follow the thematic displays across the city
Observe suspended decorated trees in public squares

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral soars above Senlis, built between 1153 and 1191 with its Virgin Portal—a masterpiece of 12th-century Gothic sculpture. Its 1240 Gothic spire pierces the sky at 78 meters, dominating the cityscape.
The Gallo-Roman ramparts from the 3rd century encircle the historic heart for a kilometer. Fifteen towers survive from this six-hectare enclosure built after the Germanic invasions of 275.
The Royal Château stands against the Gallo-Roman walls on the site where Hugh Capet was elected King of France in 987. Medieval vestiges bear witness to this founding royal residence.
The Gallo-Roman arena dates from the 1st century when the town was called Augustomagus. As the only preserved amphitheater in northern France, it testifies to the city's early Romanization.
The Museum of Art and Archaeology occupies the former episcopal palace. Gallo-Roman vestiges and votive offerings from the forest temple of Halatte trace two thousand years of local history.

activities.text: Stroll through medieval lanes past 15th and 16th-century half-timbered houses. Rue de la Tonnellerie, de la Tannerie, and du Chat Haret still bear the names of ancient crafts.

days_plan.itin_title: Oise Circuit: Imperial Châteaux, Ancient Forests & Living History

visits.text: Visit to the Abbey of Saint-Pierre de Senones, a prominent Benedictine site

activities.text: Walk through the old borough of Senones

days_plan.itin_title: Vosges Abbeys and Mountains: Monastic Heritage and Green Valley Silence

visits.text: Closing loop: final tour through the historic center of Sens
Sens Cathedral of Saint-Étienne is the world's first Gothic cathedral. Construction began in 1135, predating Notre-Dame de Paris. Its nave was the first to employ ribbed vaulting on a grand scale.
The transept's stained glass, created between 1500 and 1530, forms an exceptional ensemble. Two immense rose windows and 12th-century glass panels rival those of Chartres or Bourges in quality.
The Cathedral Treasury, one of Europe's richest, displays 15th-century Flemish tapestries, Thomas Becket's chasuble, and the Holy Shrine—a Byzantine ivory reliquary casket.
The 13th-century Palais Synodal and the former Archbishops' Palace form a complex of 4 listed buildings. The Museums of Sens present collections spanning Paleolithic to contemporary eras.
The covered market of Sens, in the town center, shelters terroir product stalls beneath a Baltard structure. The neighboring Pays d'Othe region supplies cider and apples.
Half-timbered houses and Gallo-Roman vestiges dot the old town. Sens, formerly Agedincum, was the capital of the Senones Gallic tribe—those who took Rome in 390 BC.

activities.text: Purchase of local products at a local market (according to schedule)
Climb the 330 steps of the cathedral's south tower. At the summit, 66 meters high, the view plunges over the glazed roofs of the Palais Synodal, the square, and the Yonne valley.
The Moulin à Tan, a former tannery mill, houses a botanical park with rose garden, arboretum, and tropical greenhouses. The 'winter garden' recreates an equatorial forest atmosphere.
In summer, a free sound and light show is projected onto the cathedral façade on Friday and Saturday evenings. The portal sculptures come alive under colored lights.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul
Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: The Manufacture de Sèvres has produced porcelain since 1756. Founded under Louis XV with Madame de Pompadour's patronage, it supplied European royal courts and still serves the French Presidency.

The workshops reveal the secrets of Sèvres blue. 120 ceramists master about thirty trades: wheel throwing, molding, painting, gilding. Pastes and glazes are crafted on-site using time-honored techniques.
The National Ceramics Museum gathers 55,000 pieces from the Middle Ages to today. Sèvres porcelain, faience, stoneware, and pottery from around the world compose a reference collection.

activities.text: Join the Parc de Saint-Cloud through the gardens. The Manufacture occupies a site bordering the national estate.
The Seine embankments offer peaceful views of the river. Walk between Sèvres and Saint-Cloud.

Friday morning farmers' market (April to December).

days_plan.itin_title: Forcalquier & the Lure Valley: Lavender Fields, Gorges & Hilltop Villages

visits.text: The Sisteron citadel crowns the rocky spur blocking the Durance valley. The imposing fortress displays its bastioned enclosures and keep over eight centuries of military architecture. The underground staircase of 258 steps carved into rock in the 19th century links the town to the citadel in a mysterious ascent.

Notre-Dame-des-Pommiers cathedral blends Provençal Romanesque and Lombard influences. The sober 12th-century building displays a harmoniously proportioned nave. Side chapels house Baroque works and the 19th-century great organ resounds during summer concerts.

Walk through old town streets tiered between Durance and citadel. 14th-century medieval towers punctuate the former ramparts' layout. Renaissance fountains and fortified gates mark this labyrinth where Provençal town atmosphere reigns.

The Baume rock rises facing the citadel on the other side of the Durance. Horizontal limestone strata give the impression of a stack of slices. This remarkable geological site dominates the cluse where the valley narrows.

Medieval watchtowers punctuate the old town's perimeter. Five of them were preserved thanks to Prosper Mérimée. Round outward and open toward the town, they testify to Sisteron's medieval defensive system.

activities.text: The Sisteron via ferrata winds on the Baume rock walls. Cables, ladders and aerial footbridges allow a vertiginous ascent. The equipped route offers thrills safely with plunging views over the Durance and citadel.

Paragliding takes off from surrounding heights. The Durance valley's powerful thermals carry wings in an aerial ballet. The panorama embraces citadel, Durance and Alpine valleys in an unforgettable flight.

The Route Napoléon crosses Sisteron on the Emperor's return historic route. On March 5, 1815, Napoleon crossed the town without resistance during his march to Grenoble. A museum in the citadel traces this epic episode of French history.

Hiking trails radiate around Sisteron. The Baume rock ascent offers a sporty route rewarded by an exceptional panorama. The nearby Méouge gorges offer swimming and water hiking in a preserved setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages

visits.text: Saint-Jean-des-Vignes Abbey displays its Gothic facade with two 75-meter spires. Founded in 1076, this Augustinian monastery experienced brilliant medieval prosperity before Revolutionary sale. The ruins preserve remarkable Gothic architecture with refectory, cloister and chapter house. A museum presents abbey life and heritage conservation.

The Saint-Gervais and Saint-Protais Cathedral mixes Romanesque and Gothic styles over four centuries of construction. The south transept displays pure Gothic while other parts retain Romanesque elements. The Merovingian crypt, among France's oldest, shelters sarcophagi and archaeological vestiges.

Explore the 12th-century underground Saint-Léger crypt beneath the old abbey. This Romanesque space preserves remarkable carved capitals. Vaulted galleries create a mysterious atmosphere charged with history.
Stroll along the Aisne River banks and canal. Promenades follow the water through greenery. Locks and boats enliven this fluvial landscape offering peaceful views.

activities.text: Visit the arsenal museum presenting French military heritage. Collections include weapons, uniforms and equipment from medieval times to present. Interactive displays explain French army evolution.
Walk the Clovis Path retracing Frankish king's history who was baptized in Reims but spent time in Soissons. Interpretation panels dot this heritage circuit through the historic city.
Cycle the Aisne greenway converted from an old railway. The flat route suitable for all levels winds through countryside and villages. Several loops allow half-day or full-day rides.
