visits.text: Founded in 1010, Saint-Pierre Abbey at Solesmes dominates the banks of the Sarthe. A sacred center of Gregorian chant since 1837.
Attending a sung office provides an unforgettable spiritual experience. The voices of the monks resonate throughout the chapel.
The "Saints of Solesmes," two groups of statues, are masterpieces of 15th and 16th-century French sculpture.
The village of Solesmes reveals itself on foot. Attentive strollers discover colorful sculptures by Claude and Marie-Madeleine Gruer adorning the facades.
From the bridge, enjoy the view of the abbey commanding the Sarthe. An exceptional panorama over the valley.

activities.text: Continue the walk along the tranquil path beneath the abbey to Cri Cri Beach. A peaceful riverside escape.
Explore the Alpes Mancelles from Solesmes. Gentle hills, steep peaks, and a wild river compose this unique landscape.
The abbey bookshop offers religious works and monastic products. Open outside of service times.

days_plan.itin_title: Sarthe Road Trip: Le Mans and the Loir Valley

visits.text: The Abbatiale Saint-Pierre-Saint-Paul de Solignac is a unique case in Limousin: its three-bay nave is covered with hemispherical domes on pendentives, in the manner of Périgord churches. The Benedictine abbey, founded between 632 and 638 by Saint Éloi, goldsmith and advisor to King Dagobert, was Limousin's most powerful from the 10th to 13th centuries.

Look up at the choir capitals: griffins seized by men, figures battling serpents, and stacked palmettes stand out in limestone. The nave capitals, more archaic, show checkered patterns and animal heads.

The oak choir stalls, carved between 1457 and 1484, rank among Limousin's most remarkable. Flip the misericords: profane scenes appear — grimacing faces, mocking characters, and licentious figures hidden beneath the monks' seats.

In the right transept arm, a 15th-century fresco depicts Saint Christopher carrying the Christ Child, inspired by the Golden Legend. Donors' coats of arms and a detailed ship complete the composition.

The Château de la Borie, a 17th-century Renaissance residence, houses the Fondation La Borie dedicated to sound and music arts. Its garden of sounds, set in a 7-hectare park, blends sound installations and outdoor sculptures.

activities.text: Cross the 12th-century Romanesque bridge, built by monks for Compostela pilgrims. Its three ogival arches and two cutwater piers carved to break the Briance current span the river with timeless grace.

Wander the medieval village lanes, among half-timbered houses and stone foundations. The abbey's turbulent history — Saracen and Norman raids, Wars of Religion, Revolution — left scars that Benedictine monks, returned in 2021, work to heal.
Take a section of GR 654 toward the Pont-Rompu, a 13th-century vestige on the old Roman road. The 6 km loop follows the Briance through preserved bocage landscape.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Vienne Circuit: Limoges, Porcelain & Historic Villages

visits.text: The Old Bridge has spanned the Bévéra since the 13th century: symbol of Sospel, it served as a toll on the Salt Route to Italy.
Enter Saint Michael's Cathedral: the 17th-century Baroque jewel retains its Romanesque bell tower, golden frescoes illuminate the nave.
Fort Saint-Roch opens its depths: 2,000 meters of underground galleries, remnant of the Alpine Maginot Line carved from 5,000 m³ of concrete.
Complete your exploration at Fort de l'Agaisen, another fortified structure bearing witness to World War II defenses.
The trompe-l'oeil facades of the old town display ochre and pink hues, legacy of neighboring Liguria.

activities.text: Lace up your boots for the Bévéra Valley: the trail climbs toward the mythical Col de Turini, the Mediterranean and the Alps share the horizon.
Hop on an electric mountain bike on Mercantour circuits: gentle routes for beginners or single tracks for experts.
The Piaon gorges await canyoning enthusiasts: rappel descents, natural slides, wild landscapes.
On Thursday mornings, Place des Platanes comes alive: goat cheeses, mountain honey, olive oil from the hills.
Challenge the Route des Grandes Alpes by bike: legendary passes succeed one another beneath the pines, with Turini as the crowning glory.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure

visits.text: The Abbey Church of Sainte-Marie, a masterpiece of Romanesque art, crowns the town with its three domes on pendentives. Founded in the 10th century by Benedictines following the Abbey of Saint-Géraud d'Aurillac, the current church was constructed between 1145 and 1150.

The Romanesque portal, relocated inside the abbey church for protection from the elements, represents a treasure of medieval sculpture. The tympanum recounts the legend of Theophilus; the trumeau interweaves Isaac's sacrifice and original sin. The pillar of the prophet Isaiah, all movement and flowing drapery, is a unique piece of Romanesque art.

Inside, a painting attributed to Chasseriau, "Christ in the Garden of Olives" (1844), and a monumental Stoltz organ (1855), listed as a Historic Monument, complete the visit. The acoustics beneath the domes naturally amplify sound.

Explore Souillac's historic center, crossed by seven viaducts spanning streams and ravines. Ancient alleyways lead to the 19th-century market hall, still active on market days, and to the Dordogne riverbanks where the old river port once stood.

activities.text: Walk along the Dordogne riverbanks downstream from Souillac. The path follows the river through woods and meadows, with views of the hillsides and town rooftops.
The Town of Art and History offers themed guided tours of Souillac and the abbey church, highlighting monastic history and Romanesque sculpture.
Souillac hosts a renowned summer jazz festival. Open-air concerts, performances in the abbey church, and events at various venues animate the summer season.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot Itinerary: Cahors, Rocamadour & the Lot Valley

visits.text: The Basilica of Notre-Dame-de-la-Fin-des-Terres is a 12th-century Romanesque art jewel, UNESCO World Heritage listed. Built to welcome pilgrims on the Way of Saint James, it was buried by dunes in the 18th century then completely excavated in the 19th. The Romanesque architecture is remarkably preserved with sculpted capitals. The sober luminous interior invites contemplation. Classical music concerts are regularly organized here.

Soulac's Old Village counts about 500 Belle Époque villas built between 1860 and 1930. These pink brick houses, with their sculpted eaves, canopies, arabesques, and colored stained glass, testify to the seaside resort's heyday. Two visitor circuits reveal the finest: the Soulac villas circuit (1.5 hours) and the architectural circuit (1 hour). Maps available at the tourist office. Some villas bear pretty feminine names.

Soulac's seafront stretches over 7 kilometers of fine sandy beaches. The landscaped promenade runs along supervised beaches with ocean views and distant Cordouan Lighthouse. Breakwaters—concrete slabs installed in the 1930s to combat erosion—create natural seawater pools at high tide. Several accesses descend to beaches from the promenade. Restaurants and ice cream shops line the seafront.

A 4-meter-tall replica of the Statue of Liberty stands on the seafront facing the ocean. Like the New York original, it was created in the Bartholdi workshops. She gazes toward America and the Côte d'Argent dunes. It's a friendly landmark and popular photo spot. A memorial to the northern Médoc fortress stands nearby, recalling German occupation.

activities.text: Excursion to Cordouan Lighthouse, nicknamed the Versailles of the Seas or King of Lighthouses. Built starting in 1584 under Henri IV, it's France's oldest lighthouse still in operation. Standing 68 meters tall, it's located at sea 7 km from shore. UNESCO World Heritage listed since 2021, it can be visited from April to September. The boat excursion lasts 3.5 hours with 1.5 hours on-site visit. Landing is done feet in the water. Impressive interior with royal apartments and chapel.

Swimming at Soulac beaches. The resort has several supervised summer beaches: central beach, Naïades beach, Amélie du Nord beach. Atlantic waves attract surfers and bodyboarders. Surf schools offer lessons on two beaches. Beaches are wide and clean, with fine sand. Beware of baïnes, dangerous currents typical of the Atlantic coast. Always swim in supervised areas.

Visit to Pointe de Grave, the northern tip of the Médoc peninsula where the Gironde meets the Atlantic. A monument commemorates the 1917 American troop landing. The site offers spectacular views over the estuary, ocean, and Cordouan Lighthouse. It's the starting point of the GR8 trail running up the entire Atlantic coast. A ferry connects Pointe de Grave to Royan in Charente-Maritime (20-minute crossing). Wild landscapes of dunes and forests.

Cycling through pine forest. Soulac has a network of bike paths winding through the Landes forest or leading toward the estuary. Routes are shaded and pleasant, away from beach heat. Several marked circuits reveal heritage and nature. Bikes, rosalies, and tandem rentals available in town. Paths are flat and accessible to all.

Visit the Soulac Archaeology Museum. This small museum presents the history of the Médoc Point from Antiquity to medieval times. Collections include objects discovered during local excavations: ceramics, tools, coins, architectural elements. Several rooms trace the basilica's history and the Saint James pilgrimage. Modest admission. Guided tours possible by reservation.

days_plan.itin_title: Gironde Road Trip: Bordeaux, Vineyards & Arcachon Bay

visits.text: The Souvigny priory, dependency of Cluny Abbey, ranks among the five most important Cluniac sites with Cluny, Paray-le-Monial, Vézelay and La Charité-sur-Loire. The priory church Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul (11th-15th centuries) combines Romanesque and Gothic. Its two bell towers, one Romanesque and the other Gothic, symbolize architectural evolution over four centuries of construction.

The Bourbon Necropolis shelters tombs of Louis II de Bourbon (†1410) and wife Anne Dauphine d'Auvergne, and of Charles I de Bourbon (†1456) and wife Agnès de Bourgogne. These sculpted black marble gisants testify to ducal power and artistic refinement of the 15th century. The tombs constitute exceptional funeral art treasures classified as Historic Monuments.

The Zodiac Column (12th century), unique in France, rises 5.30m displaying sculpted capitals representing signs of the zodiac, months of the year and agricultural labors. This Romanesque masterpiece illustrates medieval cosmic vision linking celestial time and earthly rhythms. A rare and precious testimony of Romanesque symbolic art.

The Saint-Marc Museum occupies former prior's building (17th century) presenting Souvigny priory history and treasures. Excavated capitals, liturgical objects and historical documents trace spiritual and artistic life of this major Cluniac center. Temporary exhibitions highlight medieval heritage and sacred art.

activities.text: Walk the historic village discovering stone houses (17th-18th centuries) and Saint-Marc church (11th-12th centuries). Narrow streets reveal ancient facades and small squares where priory past resonates. The village preserves an authentic monastic atmosphere.

The Tronçais Forest, one of the most beautiful oak forests in Europe, extends over 10,600 hectares just 20 km from Souvigny. Marked trails wind through three-century-old trees including oaks exceeding 40 meters. Ponds, glades and forest roads invite hiking and nature discovery.

visits.text: The European Museum of Beer occupies the former provisions store of Stenay citadel, transformed into a malthouse in the 19th century. Labeled "Museum of France" and listed as Historic Monuments, it displays 55,000 objects across 2,500 square meters. Six sequences trace brewing history from Mesopotamian origins (12,000 years ago) to the present day.

The museum's highlight: the advertising posters room reveals how graphic art served brewers. It notably features a lithograph by Czech artist Alfons Mucha (1897), created for Bières de la Meuse of Bar-le-Duc, in Art Nouveau style.

Stenay's Saint-Joseph church, rebuilt after Great War destruction, stands out for its sober architecture. The city's coat of arms, adorned with a devil, recalls this former stronghold of the Counts of Bar's rich past.

activities.text: The museum's botanical garden presents Lorraine's only hop garden, surrounded by aromatics and spices used in brewing. The visit stimulates sight, smell, and touch.
End at the museum tavern for a tasting of craft beers with top, bottom, or spontaneous fermentation. Local specialties accompany the glasses: beer sausage, cheese, and Stenay madeleines.
Hop on a bike along the Meuse Greenway, a cycle path part of EuroVelo 19. The section from Stenay follows the river through a Natura 2000 zone rich in birds and valley-floor landscapes.

days_plan.itin_title: Meuse Circuit: Verdun and the Citadels

visits.text: The Grande Île, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1988, unfolds its historic centre around Notre-Dame Cathedral. La Petite France and its canals form an exceptional medieval urban ensemble.
Notre-Dame Cathedral dominates the city with its 142-metre spire. A masterpiece of Gothic architecture, it helped spread this style eastward across Europe.
The Palais Rohan houses three museums in an 18th-century building: the Decorative Arts Museum, the Fine Arts Museum, and the Archaeological Museum, all under one roof.
The Parc de l'Orangerie covers 26 hectares. Created in 1804, it features a Joséphine pavilion and a mini-farm. Storks have made it their home.
The German Quarter showcases its Wilhelmian architecture. Built between 1871 and 1918, it embodies the ambition of the Reichsland. The Neustadt was listed as a UNESCO site in 2017.
The Ponts Couverts date from the 13th century. Three medieval watchtowers mark the entrance to La Petite France. This defensive ensemble once protected the city.
Strasbourg Christmas Market
Historic squares and traditional wooden stalls
Illuminated Christmas tree on Place Kléber
Additional exploration of Strasbourg Christmas markets

activities.text: Head to the European Quarter. The European Parliament symbolises Strasbourg's role as a capital of Europe. The modern architecture contrasts with the old town.
The Alsatian Museum recreates daily life in Alsace from the 18th to the 20th century. Furniture, costumes, religious objects, and folk traditions are on display.
If you visit in December, Strasbourg's Christmas market transforms the city. One of the oldest in Europe, it has been held since 1570.
Take a boat trip on the Ill river. Batorama boats have been running since 1947, cruising along the Grande Île and then the Neustadt.
Place Kléber is the beating heart of Strasbourg. The statue of General Kléber stands at its centre. In winter, the great Christmas tree is erected here.
The Barrage Vauban offers panoramic views from its rooftop terrace. Built in the late 17th century, it could flood the surrounding areas in case of attack.
Explore the various themed Christmas markets across the city centre
Discover local crafts showcased on Place des Meuniers
Visit remaining themed festive areas

visits.text: The château de Sully-sur-Loire rises with its massive towers beside the Loire, surrounded by water-filled moats fed by the Sange River. This 14th-century fortress marks the gateway to the valley of kings.

Step through the door of the keep built by Guy de La Trémoille. The great lower hall, the hall of honor, and the king's chamber succeed one another across three levels. The intact 14th-century broken-barrel vaulted ceiling crowns the upper hall along its entire length.

On the first floor, the Psyche apartments preserve six 17th-century tapestries recounting the story of the goddess whose beauty surpassed Venus herself. Restored in 2007, they rank among the château's treasures.

The petit château, residence of the Dukes of Sully from the 16th century onward, houses the tomb of the duke and his wife Rachel de Cochefilet. Furniture, paintings, and engravings evoke the era of Henri IV.
Walk the ramparts to look down over the moats and the Loire. Here the young Louis XIV took refuge in March 1652 during the Fronde, and here Voltaire spent his exile in 1715.

The 19 rooms of the circuit reveal seven centuries of history: from the medieval garrison hall to the 19th-century grand salon, passing through the yellow dining room and the furnished chambers of the duke's descendants.

The Château de Sully rises in medieval splendor on the banks of the Loire. This 14th-century fortress, inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage list, preserves a remarkable barrel-vaulted timber roof and Renaissance apartments where Voltaire once sought refuge.
The château park invites leisurely wandering. Water-filled moats, centuries-old trees, and Loire River views create an atmosphere of timeless romance.
The Église Saint-Ythier mingles Romanesque and Gothic styles. The 12th-century nave and Gothic choir house the burial vaults of the Lords of Sully.
Château de Sully-sur-Loire, a medieval fortress rising from its park with formidable towers and moat
Furnished interiors of Château de Sully-sur-Loire, revealing centuries of aristocratic life
The keep and King's Chamber at Sully-sur-Loire, where royal guests once lodged
The Petit Château on the Sully-sur-Loire estate, an intimate secondary residence

activities.text: Stroll through the 25-hectare departmental park surrounding the château. The Sange River, the Marçon ponds, and shaded paths shelter nearly 90 bird species and beavers.
Each year in May and June, the Sully and Loiret International Music Festival brings the château's halls alive with classical and contemporary concerts.
Each June, the Classical Music Festival brings the château to life with evening concerts. Music fills the great medieval hall beneath the historic chestnut timber framework.
Walk or cycle along the Loire riverbanks. The Loire à Vélo route passes through Sully between the levees and the river's wooded islands.
Stroll through the 42-hectare departmental natural park surrounding Sully-sur-Loire

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Châteaux of the Loire Valley
Loiret Road Trip: Orléans & Loire Valley Châteaux
The Unmissable Châteaux of the Loire Valley

visits.text: Suresnes American Cemetery, established in 1917, shelters 1,541 burials from World War I and 24 unknown soldiers from World War II. A chapel watches over the white Carrara marble crosses.

The crosses align in a V-formation on Mont-Valérien's slopes. A wall of the missing perpetuates the memory of 974 soldiers. This is the only American military cemetery in Europe commemorating both World Wars.

activities.text: 4,800 vines spread across Mont-Valérien's slopes, continuing a winemaking tradition dating back to Roman times. The climb rewards you with an unforgettable view of the Eiffel Tower.
Terrasse du Fécheray offers a 180° panorama over Paris. This verdant oasis is cherished for its natural beauty.
Walk along the Seine from the dam and lock. The 185-meter river structure controls the waterway. The embankments preserve a bucolic atmosphere.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-Seine Road Trip: Royal Heritage & Gardens

visits.text: Talloires-Montmin nestles in Lake Annecy's most beautiful bay. Cézanne, Napoleon III, and Churchill succumbed to the charm of this village nicknamed the Pearl of the Lake.
The former 11th-century Benedictine priory now houses an American university campus. Its terraced gardens descend to turquoise waters.
The 17th-century Abbey was built by Benedictine monks on the site of a 9th-century monastery. It overlooks the marina.
The Roc de Chère nature reserve preserves 68 hectares of forests and cliffs. Trails lead to viewpoints offering plunging views over the lake.
Saint-Germain's Hermitage and its cave nestle in the cliff. This pilgrimage site offers an exceptional panorama of Talloires and the lake.
The Angon Waterfall plunges 60 meters down a cliff in a green setting. The path follows the rock face to the base of this impressive cascade.

Clinging to the cliff face 150 meters above the lake, this 11th-century hermitage offers vertiginous views over Talloires Bay. The steep 40-minute trail rewards the climb with a perspective that captures why monks chose this dramatic aerie for contemplation.

Talloires boasts several lovely beaches along its pristine shores. The municipal beach offers magnificent views of Duingt Castle and the mountains beyond. The crystalline waters beckon for swimming in an idyllic Alpine setting.

Set in a 17th-century former convent in Thônes, this museum brings to life traditional Savoyard valley culture. Discover the fascinating story of Reblochon cheese, born in this valley during the 13th century and still crafted using ancestral methods.

activities.text: Canyoning in Angon Canyon is the region's signature activity. Rappels under waterfalls, natural slides, and jumps spice up this aquatic descent.
Take off paragliding from the Forclaz Pass to soar over the lake and mountains. Tandem flights offer unforgettable sensations facing the Alpine panorama.
The Roc de Chère hike winds through a forest with varied atmospheres: Mediterranean pine groves and mountain beech forests coexist on this promontory.
Rent a kayak or paddleboard to explore Talloires Bay from the water and discover coves inaccessible by road.

Drive up to Col de la Forclaz (1,150 m), which commands the finest panorama over Lake Annecy. The viewpoint offers a bird's-eye perspective plunging down to Talloires Bay—the postcard view that launched a thousand photographs.
Visit one of the local fromageries to witness the artisanal production of Reblochon AOP cheese. Sample this creamy treasure straight from the cheesemaker—it's a world apart from supermarket versions.
The 3 km trail winds through forest before reaching spectacular 60-meter waterfalls. A suspension bridge brings you face-to-face with the cascading torrents—thrilling and photogenic in equal measure.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc
Haute-Savoie Road Trip: Alpine Lakes & Mont Blanc

visits.text: Talmont-sur-Gironde, a village of 100 inhabitants perched on a rocky promontory. Listed as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages, it overlooks the Gironde estuary. Lanes lined with hollyhocks, white houses with blue shutters, artisan shops.

Sainte-Radegonde Church of Talmont (12th century), Romanesque Saintonge style, stands at the cliff edge. Its apse overlooks the estuary – the sea has eaten away the cemetery. Sculpted facade, single nave, golden light. One of the most photographed churches in France.

The carrelets of Talmont, fishing huts on stilts equipped with square nets. A traditional estuary technique for catching shrimp, eels and mullet. Some can be rented overnight – a unique sunset experience.
Maritime bastide, Sainte-Radegonde church and estuary cliffs.

activities.text: Talmont market (summer). In the village lanes, local producers and artisans. Pineau, cognac, jams, soaps. Festive atmosphere on summer evenings with concerts on the square.
Talmont cliff trail. 3 km walk along the estuary, between carrelets and vineyards. View of the Meschers cliffs and their troglodyte caves on the other side of the Gironde.
Coastal path to the carrelets (depending on tides).

visits.text: The Jardin Massey, classified as a "Remarkable Garden," spans eleven hectares in the city center. Designed in the 19th century by botanist Placide Massey, former director of the Trianon nurseries in Versailles, it features centuries-old trees, an orangery, free-roaming peacocks, and the remains of the cloister from the Saint-Sever-de-Rustan abbey, whose 15th-century capitals are classified as a Historic Monument.

The Musée Massey occupies the former residence of the botanist, recognizable by its Moorish tower offering a panorama over the Pyrenees mountain chain. On the first level, the International Hussars Collection brings together more than 15,000 objects tracing four centuries of history of this elite cavalry, from the 16th to the 20th century, across thirty countries.

The second level of the museum presents a fine arts collection assembled in the 19th century by deputy Achille Jubinal. It features works from the Italian, Flemish, Dutch, and French schools from the 15th to the 20th century, with paintings by Girolamo del Pacchia, Frans II Francken, Baron Gérard, and Jean-Léon Gérôme.

The Birthplace of Marshal Foch, at 2 rue de la Victoire, is an 18th-century Bigourdan house classified as a Historic Monument. Its exterior gallery with balusters, marble-framed windows, and carved wooden staircase exemplify local architecture. Ferdinand Foch spent his first twelve years here before becoming Marshal of France, Great Britain, and Poland.

The Cathedral of Notre-Dame de la Sède is the oldest monument in Tarbes. Largely remaining Romanesque, it blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Inside, the Baroque high altar combines local green and red marble, modeled after that of Saint Peter's in Rome. You can also discover Louis XVI's will engraved on a black marble plaque.

The Haras de Tarbes, created by decree of Napoleon I in 1806, occupies eight hectares in the heart of the city. Its Empire-style stables, collection of horse-drawn carriages, ceremonial saddlery, and the Maison du Cheval trace the history of breeding the Anglo-Arab horse, the emblematic breed of the Hautes-Pyrénées born here from the crossbreeding of local mares and oriental stallions.
Walk in the historic center of Tarbes, around the town hall and fountains.
Excursion to Lourdes to visit the Notre-Dame sanctuary and the Grotto of Massabielle.

Jardin Massey unfolds across 27 acres of lawns, pebble canals, and centuries-old trees right in the city center. Classified as a "Remarkable Garden," it shelters a 15th-century cloister brought stone by stone from Saint-Sever-de-Rustan Abbey, its sculpted capitals illustrating scenes from the Old and New Testaments.

Step inside the Musée Massey, an oriental-style building crowned with an observation tower overlooking the Pyrenees. Its international Hussars collection brings together 17,000 objects tracing 400 years of light cavalry history across 30 countries. One hundred and thirty period-uniformed mannequins guide you through the chronological journey.

Upstairs, the Fine Arts gallery showcases major works from the Italian, Flemish, and Dutch schools of the 16th-17th centuries, alongside French paintings from the 18th-19th centuries. Rotating exhibitions reveal pieces normally kept in storage.

Head to Marshal Foch's birthplace at 2 rue de la Victoire. This 18th-century Bigourdan house, a classified Historic Monument, preserves portraits, documents, and gifts from Allied nations honoring the marshal's role in World War I. Notice the exterior gallery with its balusters and the carved wooden staircase.

Notre-Dame-de-la-Sède Cathedral, one of Tarbes' oldest buildings, blends Romanesque and Gothic styles dating from the 12th century. Inside, a baroque marble baldachin draws inspiration from St. Peter's in Rome. On a black marble plaque, Louis XVI's testament is engraved in full.

The Haras de Tarbes occupies 20 acres in the heart of the city. Founded in 1806 under Napoleon, this stallion depot features Empire-style stables housing a collection of horse-drawn carriages, an ornate saddlery, and the House of the Horse. Its façades and roofs are listed as Historic Monuments.

activities.text: Stroll through the shaded pathways of Jardin Massey to observe the peacocks, then climb to admire the Pyrenean panorama from the museum's Moorish tower.
Tour the rooms of the Musée Massey, taking time to examine the ornate Hussar uniforms, reconstructed on 130 mannequins representing 30 different nations.
Follow the heritage trail marked by studs in the ground through the historic quarter: from the Foch House to the cathedral, then toward the stud farm, each stop reveals a chapter of Tarbes history.
Attend a guided tour of the Haras to access the stables and see the horses at work - on certain days, the farrier still strikes iron in his forge.
Relaxation in the Massey gardens and visit to the Hussars museum.

Follow the heritage trail marked by studs in the pavement. From Place de Verdun to Rue Maréchal-Foch, then Rue Abbé-Torné, the façades tell the city's story: timber-framed houses, the imperial lycée, and the former prefecture.
Circle the garden by horse-drawn carriage—a brief ride that lets you discover rare tree species and free-roaming peacocks without breaking a sweat.

The covered Halles Marcadieu market brings together local producers and Pyrenean specialties. Sheep's milk cheeses, gâteau à la broche (spit cake), black pork of Bigorre, and Tarbais beans compose an authentic gourmet tableau.

days_plan.itin_title: Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: From Tarbes to Cirques and Valleys
Southwest France Journey: Atlantic Coast to Pyrenees Mountain Peaks
Hautes-Pyrénées Circuit: Lourdes, Gavarnie & Pic du Midi

visits.text: The Museum of Wonders unveils 5,000 years of history: archaeological collections, Bronze Age rock engravings, alpine ethnology in a modern setting.
Lose yourself in the medieval village of Tende: houses tier like an amphitheater on the hill, cobbled lanes wind between lauze roofs and stone facades.
The Collegiate Church of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption raises its Romanesque bell tower and Baroque decor at the heart of the town, testament to past riches on the Salt Route.
Climb to the ruins of Lascaris Castle and the Clock Tower: the panorama embraces the Roya Valley and Mercantour peaks.
The Vallo Alpino Museum traces the military stakes of this border region during World War II.
Discover the Honey House: bees and their products are part of the agricultural heritage of these alpine valleys.
Journey aboard the Train des Merveilles connecting Nice to Tende.
Visit to the Musée des Merveilles dedicated to prehistoric rock engravings.

activities.text: The Valley of Wonders awaits hikers: over 50,000 rock engravings scattered across the slopes of Mont Bégo, an open-air museum unique in Europe.
Mountain bike the High Salt Route: the ancient mule track winds at 2,000 meters altitude between forts, chapels, and customs posts.
Board the Train des Merveilles from Tende station: vertiginous tunnels, suspended viaducts, one of France's most beautiful railway lines.
Hike in Fontanalba Valley: engravings describe the pastoral life of Neolithic shepherds, chamois and marmots populate the alpine meadows.
Head to the hamlet of Castérino, gateway to archaeological sites and starting point for alpine hikes.
Guided hike in the Vallée des Merveilles to observe rock engravings.

visits.text: Saint Thiébaut Collegiate Church unites all three forms of Rhenish Gothic. Built from the 13th to 16th centuries, it rivals Strasbourg Cathedral in sculptural richness.
The west portal's carvings number over 500 figures across three tympana. The Life of the Virgin, the Nativity of the Magi Kings, and the Crucifixion unfold in stone.
The stone lace spire soars to 78 meters. Locals claim it's the most beautiful in Alsace. Inside the choir, 15th-century choir stalls carve 169 characters.
Fifteenth-century stained glass filters light through eight 15-meter-high windows. The choir preserves the most extensive ensemble of medieval stained glass in Alsace.
The Witch's Eye watches over Thann from the ruins of Engelbourg Castle. In 1673, Louis XIV ordered its destruction. The main tower, split open, forms a cyclopean eye at 432 meters elevation.
Thann Christmas Market
Decorations around the Saint-Thiébaut collegiate church

activities.text: The Rangen vineyard climbs volcanic slopes facing due south. This entirely classified Grand Cru produces Rieslings and Gewurztraminers with pronounced mineral character.
Wander the old town among ancient houses. The Saint Thiébaut Fountain flows in the square at the collegiate church's foot.
Climb to Engelbourg Castle via the path starting from Bungert. Panoramic views sweep across Thann, the Vosges, and Mulhouse's urban sprawl.
Attend open-air festive concerts and exhibitions

days_plan.itin_title: Haut-Rhin Road Trip: Colmar and the Southern Wine Route

visits.text: Thiers, France's cutlery capital for over six centuries, clings its carved half-timbered houses and private mansions to a rocky spur facing the Chaîne des Puys. The protected sector runs from rue de la Coutellerie to the Saint-Jean quarter via covered passages called pedde, typical of this vertical city. Historic cutlers' shops and artisan workshops dot the route. Today, 2,000 jobs and 80% of French knife consumption still originate from Thiers.

The Cutlery Museum, the former Auvergne region's fourth most visited museum, unfolds across three sites: the Maison de l'Homme des Bois, a classified medieval building, and the Maison des Consuls downtown trace seven centuries of cutlery through objects, demonstrations, films, and sound-and-light shows. The third site, the Vallée des Rouets, is visited two miles upstream in the Durolle gorges.

The Vallée des Rouets, rated two stars in the Michelin Green Guide as 'worth a detour,' preserves the last functioning rouet: this grinding mill allowed blade polishers to sharpen knives lying belly-down over the wheel, earning them the nickname Yellow Bellies. The hiking trail along the Durolle gorges crosses wild natural landscapes punctuated by industrial ruins and the Chez Lyonnet museum.

Le Creux de l'Enfer, a contemporary art center of national interest opened in 1988, occupies a former cutlery factory closed in 1956 in the Durolle gorges. Recognizable by the red devil painted on its facade, this space marries industrial heritage and contemporary creation in a spectacular setting of cliffs and waterfalls. The surrounding Vallée des Usines preserves former cutlery ruins along the river, including the Maison de l'Aventure Industrielle in the May factory.

The preserved quarter winds from rue de la Coutellerie to the Saint-Jean neighborhood through covered passages called pedde, typical of this vertical town. Historic cutlers' shops and artisan workshops line the route. Today, 2,000 jobs and 80% of French knife consumption still originate from Thiers.

The third site, the Vallée des Rouets, can be visited three kilometers upstream in the Durolle gorges.

The footpath along the Durolle gorges traverses wild nature punctuated by industrial vestiges and the Chez Lyonnet museum.

Recognizable by the red devil painted on its facade, this venue marries industrial heritage with contemporary creation in a spectacular setting of cliffs and waterfalls. The surrounding Vallée des Usines preserves former cutlery ruins along the river, including the Maison de l'Aventure Industrielle in the May factory.

activities.text: Workshop: build your own knife at the Cutlery Museum. Participants assemble their own Le Thiers® knife, a protected brand recognizable by the T logo engraved into the blade. A unique artisanal souvenir from France's knife capital.

Hike From Hell to the Wheels, a 7.5-mile loop connecting the Vallée des Usines to the Vallée des Rouets along the Durolle gorges. The interpretive trail reveals secrets of papermakers, tanners, and cutlers who harnessed the river's hydraulic power for centuries.

Discover Le Thiers® knives in the town's workshops and boutiques. This protected brand encompasses pocket, table, and kitchen knives, each piece engraved with the maker's name. The Coutellia festival in May gathers over 230 art cutlers and manufacturers worldwide across 27,000 square feet of exhibition.

Craft your own knife at the Cutlery Museum. Participants assemble their own Le Thiers® knife, a protected brand recognizable by the T logo engraved in the blade. A unique artisanal souvenir from the French knife capital.

Hike From Hell to the Rouets, a 12-kilometer loop connecting the Vallée des Usines to the Vallée des Rouets along the Durolle gorges. The interpretive trail reveals secrets of the papermakers, tanners, and cutlers who harnessed the river's hydraulic power for centuries.

Discover the Le Thiers® knife in workshops and boutiques throughout town. This protected brand encompasses pocket, table, and kitchen knives, each piece engraved with the maker's name. The Coutellia festival in May gathers over 230 art cutlers and manufacturers from around the world across 2,500 square meters of exhibits.

days_plan.itin_title: Ardèche's Natural Wonders: An 18-Stop Road Trip of Gorges & Enchanting Villages

visits.text: The Tour aux Puces, a massive 14th-century donjon 30 meters high, dominated the Moselle valley with its 4-meter-thick walls. This remnant of the medieval fortifications houses the Thionville municipal museum, with Gallo-Roman collections and exhibits on 1,000 years of border history. From the top, the panorama extends from Luxembourg to Germany. The tower owes its name to a flea market that was held at its feet.

Vauban's casemates, designed between 1679 and 1687, plunge into 500 meters of underground galleries dug into the rock. These defensive tunnels could accommodate 1,200 soldiers and controlled access to the Luxembourg border. The vaulted chambers, powder magazines, and countermine wells tell the story of 17th-century military engineering. The temperature stays constant at 12°C year-round.

activities.text: Walk along the Moselle riverbanks, redesigned between 2010 and 2015 into green promenades. The riverside path connects the medieval Cloister Park with contemporary gardens, passing by the 18th-century Château de Guentrange and its French garden. Plane trees, rose gardens, and playgrounds line the 3 km of walkways. In summer, outdoor cafes and river shuttle boats enliven the quays.

Explore the historic center where the Saint-Maximin church (12th-16th centuries) displays a flamboyant Gothic facade topped by a 54-meter bell tower. The pedestrian streets of the old town preserve 18th and 19th-century bourgeois houses with colored facades. The Place du Marché, bordered by 18th-century arcades, hosts a market on Wednesday and Saturday mornings, perpetuating a 700-year tradition.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: The Château de Thoiry, built in 1559, functions as an architectural sundial: at the solstices, sunlight passes straight through the entrance hall. Its period-furnished salons complement the wildlife park.
Thoiry's botanical gardens cover 95 hectares labeled "Remarkable Garden." Formal gardens attributed to Le Nôtre, English gardens, and a rose garden compose a varied landscape ensemble.

activities.text: Drive through the 8-kilometer safari amidst the African reserve: lions, bears, elephants, and giraffes roam in semi-freedom. Allow 45 minutes to an hour.
Explore the zoo on foot: over 1,300 animals of 150 species spread across themed enclosures. The tunnel beneath the lion enclosure offers a thrilling viewpoint.
In winter, the Thoiry Lumières Sauvages festival illuminates the park with thousands of giant lanterns depicting animals and landscapes.

days_plan.itin_title: Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

visits.text: This spectacular Alpine valley stretches between the Bornes massif and the Aravis chain. Limestone peaks soaring beyond 2,700 meters form a dramatic natural amphitheater—raw Alpine grandeur at its finest.

As the Reblochon capital, Thônes has preserved its traditional Savoyard market town character. Wander the historic center's narrow lanes and visit the 18th-century baroque Church of Saint-Hippolyte with its ornate interior.
This small neo-Gothic chapel from 1861 stands in magnificent Alpine surroundings at the hamlet of Les Confins. It marks the trailhead for numerous mountain hikes into pristine wilderness.

activities.text: Hike from Les Confins hamlet to this charming mountain lake nestled at 1,430 meters. The easy 2 km trail meanders through flower-studded meadows and spruce forests—quintessential Alpine scenery without the crowds.
The Lake Annecy Golf Club offers an exceptional 18-hole course with stunning views across the lake to the mountains—where the challenge of the game meets breathtaking Alpine beauty.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Savoie Road Trip: Alpine Lakes & Mont Blanc

visits.text: Discovery of the biological reserve of the Monts d'Azur and wildlife observation.

activities.text: Safari on foot or by carriage to approach bison, horses and deer in semi-freedom.

visits.text: The castle of the Dukes of La Trémoille has dominated the rocky promontory since the 8th century. Jacques Lemercier redesigned it in the 17th century for Marie de La Tour d'Auvergne.
The Collegiate Church of Notre-Dame was built by Gabrielle de Bourbon-Montpensier from 1503 to 1515 in Flamboyant Gothic style with Renaissance influences.
The Church of Saint-Médard preserves its 12th-century Romanesque façade and sculpted portals. The 56-meter Gothic bell tower dominates the town.
The half-timbered houses of Place Saint-Médard and Rue du Château include the 15th-century Hôtel des Trois Rois.

activities.text: Descend toward the collegiate chapel via Rue Imbert and Rue du Château where small houses and mansions stand side by side.
Contemplate the breathtaking panorama over the Thouet River and the Pont des Chouans from the heights.
Visit the Henri-Barré Museum housed in a mansion in the historic center.

days_plan.itin_title: Deux-Sèvres Circuit: Marais Poitevin and Romanesque Heritage

visits.text: Fosse Dionne (Tonnerre): circular karst spring
Hôtel-Dieu de Tonnerre: great hall and timber framework

Fosse Dionne has intrigued visitors since antiquity. This vauclusian spring forms a turquoise pool whose known gallery plunges 61 meters deep over 360 meters. A circular half-rotunda washhouse, listed as a Historic Monument, has surrounded it since 1758.

The Hôtel-Dieu, founded in 1293 by Marguerite de Bourgogne, is Europe's longest medieval hospital. Its patients' hall stretches 90 meters beneath original timberwork. The 15th-century Entombment sculpture is preserved here.

Climb to Saint-Pierre Church, perched on the hill overlooking Tonnerre. Its architecture blends flamboyant Gothic and Renaissance. The interior houses an antique organ, an 18th-century pulpit, and polychrome stained glass.
Notre-Dame Church, in the town center, presents a mix of Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its stones bear witness to Tonnerre's different construction eras—a town destroyed and rebuilt multiple times.
The medieval-inspired gardens, adjoining the Hôtel-Dieu, feature boxwood hedges, hornbeams, and yews. Medicinal plants are identified according to their period uses.
Ten kilometers away, Château de Tanlay rises from its moat amid a vast park. This Burgundian Renaissance residence houses a trompe-l'oeil room and the League Tower adorned with allegorical frescoes.

activities.text: Heritage trail in the center of Tonnerre
The Canal de Bourgogne cuts through Tonnerre's heart. Take the towpath on foot or by bike for a waterside stroll past locks and barges.
Tonnerrois winemakers open their cellars for tastings. The AOC Bourgogne Tonnerre and Bourgogne Épineuil reveal a discreet but quality terroir.
On Wednesdays and Saturdays, Tonnerre's market offers snails, gougères, Chaourçois cheese, and Armançonnettes—local sweet specialties.

days_plan.itin_title: The Essential Burgundy Road Trip: Wine Villages, Cathedral Cities & Medieval Soul
Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: Cathédrale Saint-Étienne was built between 1221 and 1496. Its flamboyant Gothic facade, erected between 1475 and 1496, ranks among the finest in eastern France.
The cathedral's Gothic cloister measures 54 meters long and 42 wide. It's one of the largest in France.
The cathedral towers rise to 62 meters. The spires planned to reach 90 meters were never built.
The 13th-century Collégiale Saint-Gengoult impresses with its bright interior. Its clear glass windows and 16th-century cloister invite contemplation.
Vauban's fortifications have encircled the town since 1678. Star-shaped bastions, casemates, and glacis testify to the marshal's military genius.

activities.text: Toul's cellars have produced vin gris for centuries. This typically Lorraine rosé can be tasted at estates in the surrounding area.
Walk along the Marne-Rhine Canal that runs through Toul. The banks offer a peaceful stroll at the foot of the ramparts.

days_plan.itin_title: Meurthe-et-Moselle Road Trip: Art Nouveau Nancy & Fortified Cities

visits.text: Behind the monumental 18th-century gateway, the National Maritime Museum showcases ship models, galleys, and paintings tracing four centuries of naval tradition. The museum reopened with immersive scenography, including a 3D reconstruction of the Arroyo shipwreck that brings maritime archaeology to life.

Board the cable car for a six-minute ride and 378-meter ascent to the summit of Mont Faron. At the top, the Memorial Museum of the Provence Landing recounts the August 1944 operation through period artifacts and multimedia exhibits that honor the liberation forces.

Notre-Dame de la Seds Cathedral, founded in the 5th century, blends Romanesque and Gothic elements with a unified Gothic nave, a bell tower crowned by a campanile, and an 18th-century organ. The side chapels house the Chapel of the Virgin and the Corpus Domini chapel.

Built in 1524 on Louis XII's orders and classified as a historic monument since 1947, the Royal Tower rises with seven-meter-thick walls and moats—a rare example of Italian 'torrione' fortification. It hosts cultural events in summer against a backdrop of Mediterranean vistas.

The Toulon Opera House, erected over 150 years ago on Place Victor Hugo, seats up to 1,100 spectators. Its classical facade and renowned acoustics make it one of the jewels of the old town, hosting everything from opera to ballet.

Step into the Hôtel des Arts TPM, a 400 m² space dedicated to contemporary art. Rotating exhibitions alternate between paintings, sculptures, and installations from emerging and established artists. Admission is free.

activities.text: Wander through the stalls of Cours Lafayette market, open Tuesday through Sunday. Herbs de Provence, olives, soaps, and fresh produce line the stands in a quintessential Provençal market atmosphere buzzing with local color.

Embark on a narrated one-hour boat tour of Toulon's harbor. You'll discover military vessels at anchor, fortifications guarding the bay, mussel farms in Lazaret Bay, and the haunting naval cemetery—a floating journey through maritime history.

Head to the Mourillon beaches, bordered by landscaped gardens, lawns, and playgrounds. Beyond, the coastal path leads to the wild coves of Méjean and Magaud—secluded inlets at the foot of pine-studded cliffs where the Mediterranean feels gloriously untamed.

days_plan.itin_title: Var Road Trip: French Riviera & Green Provence

visits.text: Discovery of the Capitole de Toulouse and the main square.
Visit to the Saint-Sernin basilica and the Jacobins convent.
Stroll along the Garonne and the lively quays.

Place du Capitole has been Toulouse's beating heart since the 12th century. Its 135-meter neoclassical façade houses both city hall and the theater. The Occitan cross inlaid in marble on the ground celebrates the region's distinct identity. Step inside the Capitole for free to discover the Salle des Illustres, where monumental frescoes chronicle Toulouse's storied past across soaring walls.

Basilique Saint-Sernin stands as the largest intact Romanesque church in all of Europe. Built between the 11th and 13th centuries, this UNESCO World Heritage site served pilgrims walking the Way of Saint James. Its octagonal bell tower soars 64 meters above the city. Inside, carved capitals and a vast ambulatory still echo with the footsteps of medieval travelers.

The Couvent des Jacobins dates from the 13th century. Its southern Gothic architecture culminates in the Palm of Stone—a 28-meter column whose ribbed vaults fan out like a tree beneath the ceiling, one of medieval architecture's most stunning achievements. The peaceful cloister invites contemplation. Between 11am and 3pm, sunlight streams through stained glass, illuminating painted walls in shifting colors.

La Cité de l'Espace plunges you into the universe of space exploration. A full-scale Ariane 5 rocket commands attention at the entrance. Inside, the Planetarium and IMAX theater transport you to the heart of the cosmos. Interactive exhibits explain actual space missions and let you touch real meteorites brought back from beyond Earth.

Hôtel d'Assézat ranks among Toulouse's most magnificent Renaissance mansions. Built in 1555 for a merchant enriched by the woad trade, its interior courtyard showcases exquisite Renaissance decoration. The building now houses the Bemberg Foundation, displaying old master paintings alongside modern works.

activities.text: Discovery of the Aéroscopia museum and the Cité de l'Espace.

The quays along the Garonne make for a lovely riverside walk. The 17th-century Pont Neuf is Toulouse's oldest bridge. At night, it lights up beautifully, and the view from the quays becomes magical as pink brick buildings reflect in the water. Walk or cycle while watching the city glow.

Marché Victor Hugo opens every morning except Monday. This covered market is a temple of Toulouse gastronomy where the region's finest producers gather. You'll find foie gras, cassoulet, local wines, and artisan cheeses. Upstairs, restaurants let you taste everything on the spot.

Try cassoulet, THE dish of Toulouse. This slow-cooked ragout of white beans, duck confit, and Toulouse sausages simmers for hours. It's a hearty celebration of Gascon tradition. Restaurants throughout the center offer their own recipes, each slightly different. Pair it with a Fronton or Gaillac wine.
