days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages
The Most Beautiful Villages of Provence: Luberon, Alpilles & Verdon

visits.text: Saint-Tugdual Cathedral, built from the 13th to 15th century in Caen stone, schist, and granite, blends three eras: the Romanesque Hastings tower (12th century), Gothic nave, and 60-meter openwork spire (1785) adorned with playing card motifs - financed, it's said, by Louis XVI's lottery.

The 15th-century cloister, blessed in 1468, is the most complete in Brittany. Its 46 Gothic arches, stone flying buttresses, and wooden vault form an irregular trapezoid. It served as a place of prayer, access to Saint Yves' tomb, and covered market.

Saint Yves' tomb, patron saint of lawyers and the poor, is the object of a great pardon every third Sunday in May. Born in 1253 in Minihy-Tréguier, canonized in 1347, he's celebrated by a proverb: 'Saint Yves was Breton, a lawyer and not a thief - an admirable thing to the people.'

The choir stalls, sculpted between 1509 and 1512 by two craftsmen, one from the Rhine valley, present a fantastic bestiary on the misericords. Hidden with residents during the Revolution, they escaped destruction.

Ernest Renan's birthplace, at 20 Rue du même nom, is a 16th-century half-timbered shipowner's house converted to a museum. The writer was born there in 1823 - his 'Life of Jesus' (1863) caused scandal and earned him the label 'European blasphemer' from the Pope.

The Calvary of Protestation (1904), in kersanton stone, was erected in response to Renan's statue installed on Place du Martray facing the cathedral. The trilingual inscription - Latin, Breton, French - proclaims 'This man was truly the son of God.' A stone summary of the war between clericals and secularists.

activities.text: Stroll through the historic center classified as a Protected Sector. Place du Martray, Rue Renan, and Ruelle Saint-Yves display 57 half-timbered houses from the 15th and 16th centuries - one of Brittany's best-preserved ensembles.
Descend to Tréguier port, nestled in the Jaudy estuary. Two former shipowners' towers once marked the town entrance. The Saint-François footbridge connects both banks.
Reach Minihy-Tréguier on foot (2 km) to see the Minihy church, where Saint Yves was rector, and remains of Kermartin manor where he was born and died. It's the starting point of the annual pardon.

days_plan.itin_title: Brittany Road Trip: Historic Villages, Sea and Heritage

visits.text: Trévoux, former capital of the Principality of Dombes, unfolds its medieval heritage along the right bank of the Saône. The town knew its golden age under the Princes of Dombes who maintained an independent court and their own parliament from the 15th to 18th centuries. The castle perched on the rock, rampart vestiges, and narrow streets climbing the hillside testify to this prestigious past.

The Château de Trévoux, partially restored, dominates the city from its rocky outcrop. The fortified enclosure, round towers, and keep evoke medieval architecture. The site houses a museum retracing the history of the Principality of Dombes through objects, documents, and reconstructions. The terrace offers panoramic views of the Saône, surrounding plains, and distant Alps.

The former Parliament of Dombes, built in the 17th century, served as the seat of sovereignty for this autonomous principality. The building, with its classical facade and period interior layout, hosts exhibitions on Dombes' judicial and political history. The wood-paneled council chambers and ancient courtrooms transport visitors into the 18th century. Guided tours reveal surprising anecdotes about this unique institution in France.

The Church of Saint-Symphorien, rebuilt in the 19th century in neo-Gothic style, houses an exceptional collection of religious furniture from demolished Dombes churches. Carved altarpieces, period statues, and golden reliquaries form a remarkable ensemble. The recently restored stained glass windows depict scenes from local religious history.
Trévoux, former capital of the Principality of Dombes, raises its medieval towers above the Saône. The City of Art and History label crowns this exceptional heritage.
The Castle has dominated the town since the 14th century. Its octagonal tower offers a splendid panorama over the Saône valley and the Beaujolais hills.
The Parliament of Dombes sat here until the Revolution. The restored rooms evoke the independence of this principality that even minted its own currency.
The Carré Patrimoines houses the apothecary of the former hospital, a remarkable collection of faiences and ointment jars in their period woodwork setting.
Cross the footbridge spanning the Saône to contemplate the only town in the Saône Valley with a full southern exposure. The mirror effect on the water creates a striking tableau.
Steep alleyways lead to artist and artisan workshops. The Rue des Arts emblem marks galleries and studios where sculptors and painters open their doors.

activities.text: Walk the Heritage Trail that winds through old town. The marked route passes by Renaissance houses, ancient mansions, and medieval vestiges. Information panels reveal the history of the Principality of Dombes and daily life of its inhabitants. The climb to the castle offers breathtaking views of surrounding landscapes at each turn.

Cruise the Saône aboard a traditional gabarre, these flat-bottomed boats that once transported goods. The cruise offers a different perspective on the city and river landscapes. Skippers, passionate about local history, recount river anecdotes and evolution of river transport. The calm waters and preserved nature create a relaxing atmosphere.

Visit the Museum of Old Trévoux, housed in a beautiful 18th-century mansion. The collections illustrate daily life in the principality: period furniture, work tools, traditional costumes. A room dedicated to the famous Trévoux dictionary, published in the 18th century, explains the importance of this monumental work in French language history.

Explore the covered market and local shops offering Dombes specialties: pond fish, frog legs, duck foie gras. Producers explain the particularities of this marshy land dotted with a thousand ponds. The Friday morning market overflows with fresh products and creates a friendly atmosphere. Tastings allow discovery of this unique gastronomy.
Pick up the discovery trail at the tourist office. Each station on the circuit reveals a piece of the history of this Lyonnaise Monaco.
The Voie Bleue follows the Saône for 700 km from Luxembourg to Lyon. Hop on a bike to ride the section through the town.
The family activity booklet transforms the visit into a treasure hunt for children ages 6 and up.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains
Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: Troglodyte village of Trôo tiered on three levels along the hillside overlooking the Loir. Dwellings carved into limestone tuffeau tier from the valley to the hilltop. Steep lanes and stone staircases wind between still-inhabited cave houses. The exceptional underground heritage includes cellars, mushroom farms, and former refuges. The preserved rock architecture testifies to a thousand-year-old way of life unique in the Loire Valley. Underground galleries maintain constant temperatures summer and winter.

Saint-Martin Collegiate Church of Trôo dominating the village with its elegant 12th-century Romanesque bell tower. The church preserves remarkable murals and sculpted capitals. The building testifies to this fortified village's past religious importance. Contemporary stained glass brings a modern touch to Romanesque architecture. The vaulted crypt conceals overlooked architectural treasures. Ancient baptismal fonts and pious statues recount the place's spiritual history. The panorama from the forecourt embraces the entire Loir valley.

Talking Well of Trôo constitutes the village's most famous curiosity. This 45-meter-deep well dug through limestone rock possesses astonishing acoustic properties creating a spectacular prolonged echo. Visitors amuse themselves testing the sound phenomenon by calling into the depths. Local legends attribute these mysterious voices to an enchanted spring or ghosts. The sculpted medieval wellhead testifies to well-diggers' expertise. This unusual place fascinates young and old with its unique acoustic mystery.

activities.text: Butte aux Anglais overlooking Trôo and offering exceptional 360-degree panoramas over the Loir valley. This medieval feudal mound constituted the fortified village's strategic defense point. The climb via paths reveals limestone hillside vegetation. The summit unveils a postcard landscape with the tiered village, winding Loir, and green meadows. The orientation table helps identify visible landmarks. Sunset from this natural belvedere creates unforgettable atmospheres.

Cave Yuccas troglodyte eco-museum presenting daily life in carved dwellings. Reconstructions show the ingenious arrangement of caves into comfortable living spaces. Tools, furniture, and everyday objects illustrate past living conditions. Explanations detail tuffeau excavation and fitting techniques. Various reconstructed rooms reveal kitchen, bedroom, and provision cellar. This captivating visit plunges into local history and the region's unique vernacular architecture.

Hiking through Trôo's limestone hillsides on marked trails overlooking the valley. Paths wind between vineyards, dry meadows, and downy oak groves. Mediterranean flora surprises with wild orchids and aromatic plants. Successive viewpoints offer changing panoramas over the Loir and surrounding villages. Former tuffeau quarries testify to stone exploitation. The 2 to 3-kilometer loop reveals the natural riches of preserved hillsides.

days_plan.itin_title: Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Troyes reveals its medieval history through nearly 456 half-timbered houses with multicolored facades in the district called Bouchon de Champagne (Champagne Cork). The historic quarter was rebuilt after the devastating fire of May 24, 1524 that destroyed a third of the city, showcasing Renaissance builders' ingenuity. Ruelle des Chats (Cat Alley) winds between facades so close the roofs nearly touch — a reminder of when taxes were calculated by ground surface, pushing houses to grow vertically. Carved beams, bold overhangs and cobbled courtyards at Maison du Dauphin and Hôtel du Lion Noir show the merchant city's wealth.

The cathedral of Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul dominates Aube with impressive dimensions: 114 meters long, 28 meters high under the vaults. But its luminous display truly captivates: 1,500 m² of stained glass windows — equivalent to two handball courts — transform the building into a glass lantern. Built from 1200 to the 17th century and never fully completed (the South tower was never built), it showcases the excellence of the Champagne School of stained glass. Nearby, the church of Sainte-Madeleine, oldest of Troyes' sanctuaries, preserves a 16th-century carved rood screen unique in France along with windows illustrating the Creation and the Tree of Jesse.

In the impressive 18th-century Hôtel-Dieu-le-Comte, the Cité du Vitrail celebrates an extraordinary heritage: Aube holds 40% of the world's stained glass reserves. Permanent and temporary exhibitions reveal the art of colored light from the Middle Ages to today. Nearby, the Maison de l'Outil et de la Pensée Ouvrière occupies the elegant 16th-century Hôtel de Mauroy, lovingly restored by the Compagnons du Devoir. A contemporary display showcases 12,000 ancestral tools from the 17th-19th centuries — rasps, planes, chisels — witnesses to the trades that shaped France.

activities.text: Historic hosiery capital since the Middle Ages, Troyes continues its textile legacy through four outlet centers totaling 200 shops. Marques City, McArthurGlen in Pont-Sainte-Marie, Villages de Marque and Marques Avenue in Saint-Julien-les-Villas offer major brands with discounted items and end-of-series products. The heritage of Troyes' textile industry lives on between smart shopping and economic history.

Four mornings a week (Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday), Troyes comes alive with traditional markets. Les Halles welcome local producers offering Troyes andouillette (IGP certified sausage), creamy chaource AOC cheese, Côte des Bar champagne and ratafia. Facing the cathedral, Cellier Saint-Pierre has been distilling Prunelle de Troyes since 1840 — an artisanal liqueur made from wild sloe berries macerated in alcohol. Secret recipe, ancestral method, exceptional bottle.

days_plan.itin_title: Aube Circuit: Champagne, Medieval Heritage and Orient Forest Lakes

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral of Tulle. Built from 1103 on the site of a Merovingian abbey, it blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its octagonal spire bell tower rises between 73 and 75 meters depending on sources - it's the tallest in Limousin. Inside, the Great Organ from 1839 is listed as a Historic Monument, and the large blue stained glass window by Jean-Jacques Grüber (1979) tells the story of the Lunade, a procession that ended a plague epidemic in the 14th century.

13th-century Gothic cloister. The only remaining cloister in Bas-Limousin, it adjoined the former Saint-Martin Abbey. The "gallery of angels" features sculpted vaults. The chapter house preserves two 14th-century murals depicting the Last Supper and Christ's Entry into Jerusalem. Listed as a Historic Monument since 1840.

Cité de l'Accordéon and Heritage Center. Opened in April 2024 in the former Bank of France, it presents three exhibition paths: the accordion (Tulle is the French capital of the instrument with the Maugein manufacture since 1919), lace in "poinct de Tulle" and the history of the Arms Manufacture. Interactive museum with audio guide available in Occitan.

Loyac House. Architectural masterpiece from the 16th century located in the Enclos quarter. The facade blends Renaissance and Flamboyant Gothic styles, adorned with pediments sculpted with plants and animals (lion, greyhound, wild boar, mermaid). Two watchtowers frame the columned doorway.

activities.text: Stroll through the Trech quarter and the Enclos. Tulle's medieval heart revolves around the cathedral. Sloping streets, staircases, tall 15th-16th century houses with corbelling and wooden balconies. Don't miss the Coin des Clampes fountain, "the meeting place of the gossipers" in Occitan, immortalized by a 1984 sculpture.
Tulle Market. The banks of the Corrèze come alive on Wednesday and Saturday mornings. Local products, friendly atmosphere along the river.

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley

visits.text: Porte de France and well-preserved walls, center grouped around the church.
Winegrowers' quarter and lanes toward the hills.
Houses with colorful roofs visible from the town entrances.

activities.text: Ramparts and medieval gates circuit (2–3 km).
Wine trail to the neighboring hillsides (3–4 km).

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: Caesar's Tower (13th century). Circular keep 18 meters high. The 63 steps of the spiral staircase lead to the top offering a 360° panorama over the Corrèze causse. Turenne was the seat of a powerful viscounty for 10 centuries, virtually independent from the Kingdom of France: the viscounts minted coins and levied taxes. On May 8, 1738, Charles-Godefroy, the last viscount riddled with gambling debts, sold everything to Louis XV. End of the saying "Happy as a Turenne subject".

Treasure Tower (13th century). Rectangular keep with buttresses measuring 9.50m by 12.50m where the viscounty's archives and treasure were kept. The Guards' Room, 10 meters high under vaulted ceiling, features a beautiful fireplace and a collection of Louis XIII salt chests.
Collegiate Church of Notre-Dame Saint-Pantaleon. 17th-century church built by the viscounts of Turenne. The interior contains a gilded altarpiece and period woodwork.

activities.text: Climb via Rue Droite. The main street climbs from the bottom of the village to the towers. Houses with turrets, watchtowers and Renaissance windows testify to past prosperity. Good shoes recommended, the slope is steep and the cobblestones sometimes slippery.

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley

visits.text: Utah Beach Landing Museum stands on the exact spot where American troops stormed ashore on June 6, 1944. Ten chronological sequences trace the preparation and execution of D-Day. An authentic B-26 Marauder bomber dominates a dedicated hangar, its riveted fuselage gleaming under spotlights.

Step out of the museum and walk across the sands of Utah Beach. At low tide, remnants of the Atlantic Wall—concrete bunkers, beach obstacles—emerge from the dunes like ghosts of war. More than 23,000 soldiers landed here in a single day.

In Sainte-Mère-Église, look up: a parachutist mannequin hangs from the church steeple, commemorating the night of June 5-6, 1944, when paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne dropped onto the village. The church's stained glass windows illustrate this dramatic D-Day episode.

The Airborne Museum, facing the church tower, spreads across five buildings with immersive exhibits. Climb aboard an authentic C-47 aircraft that participated in the June 6 operations, and relive the paradrops through a flight simulator that pitches and rolls.
Find Milestone Zero of the Liberty Road on Sainte-Mère-Église's town square. This marker inaugurates the historic route tracing the Allied advance from Normandy all the way to Bastogne in Belgium.

activities.text: Follow the 90 'In Honor Of' memorial panels scattered across 7 coastal communes around Utah Beach. Each panel pays tribute to the units and soldiers who fought in this sector, their names etched in stone against the sea wind.

Explore the German battery at Crisbecq in Saint-Marcouf, one of the Atlantic Wall's best-preserved fortifications. Its reinforced concrete casemates housed cannons capable of firing on Allied ships offshore at Utah Beach.
Visit the village of Sainte-Marie-du-Mont to see its distinctive church tower, a landmark visible for miles that served as a guide for American paratroopers scattered in the darkness of D-Day.

days_plan.itin_title: Manche Road Trip: Cotentin Peninsula & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Saint-Pierre Abbey Church. Former Benedictine abbey church built from 1030, consecrated in 1095. The gabled bell tower, typically Limousin, rises from a square base to an octagonal plan. The 11th-century crypt, unique in Bas-Limousin, housed the relics of Breton saints Léon and Coronat, transferred here for protection from Vikings. Listed as Historic Monument in 1840.
Bécharie Gate. 14th-century fortified gate, sole remnant of the medieval ramparts that protected the town.

activities.text: Walk on the rocky promontory. Uzerche is nicknamed the "Pearl of Limousin". The local saying goes "Who has a house in Uzerche has a castle in Limousin". The village perched on a spur overlooks a meander of the Vézère. The towers and turrets of noble houses testify to the city's past importance. Panoramic view from the Lunade esplanade.

days_plan.itin_title: Corrèze Road Trip: Villages and Dordogne Valley

visits.text: Duchy and protected sector around the place aux Herbes.
Source of Eure, origin of the Roman aqueduct to Nemausus.
Route of private mansions and medieval towers.

Pont du Gard, masterpiece of Roman engineering inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1985. The three-tiered aqueduct bridge rises 161 feet high and stretches 902 feet across the Gardon River. Built in the 1st century to carry water from Uzès to Nîmes over 31 miles, it illustrates ancient hydraulic mastery with a gradient of only 40 feet. The 52 superimposed arches use limestone blocks weighing up to six tons assembled without mortar. The 408-acre preserved site offers a museum, garrigue trails, Gardon beaches, and summer sound and light shows.

Mémoires de Garrigue trail around Pont du Gard, a 0.9-mile loop through Mediterranean landscape. The path discovers Roman aqueduct remnants punctuating holm oaks, Aleppo pines, vineyards, and olive groves. Educational panels explain underground canal construction, Roman techniques, and garrigue ecosystem. Aromatic plants—thyme, rosemary, rockrose—perfume the stony path. Rocky outcrops reveal urgonian limestone quarried by ancient builders. The shaded walk invites contemplation of the monument from different viewpoints.

Duché d'Uzès, France's first duchy created in 1565. The ducal palace's Renaissance facade overlooks Place aux Herbes bordered by medieval arcades. The 11th-century Tour Bermonde, a rectangular keep, stands beside the Gothic Saint-Hubert chapel. Historic apartments reveal period furniture, Flemish tapestries, and family memorabilia of the Dukes of Uzès. 14th-century vaulted cellars host temporary exhibitions. The reconstructed medieval garden cultivates medicinal and aromatic plants. The private residence still inhabited by the ducal family offers guided audio tours.

Tour Fenestrelle in Uzès, France's only circular bell tower dating from the 12th century. The 138-foot cylindrical tower features three stories of twin bays opening to the four cardinal points. The exceptional Romanesque architecture served as a bell tower for the medieval cathedral destroyed during the Wars of Religion. Climbing 135 spiral staircase steps leads to a panoramic platform embracing the Eure valley, garrigue, and Cévennes. The bells once rhythmed religious life and agricultural activities of the town.

Place aux Herbes, the vibrant heart of Uzès surrounded by medieval arcades and golden-stone ochre facades. The Provençal market on Wednesday and Saturday mornings animates the paved square beneath century-old plane trees. Stalls offer local specialties: black truffle in winter, aged Pélardon, garrigue honey, Picholine olives. Café terraces invite watching the ballet of shoppers and pétanque players. Shopping streets radiate from the square toward Renaissance mansions and potter workshops perpetuating Uzès ceramic tradition.
Discovery of the Pont du Gard, masterpiece of Roman engineering listed as UNESCO World Heritage.
Stroll through the historic center of Uzès, France's first duchy, and visit of the Fenestrelle tower.
Pont du Gard: crossing the site and viewpoints over the ancient aqueduct.
Uzès: duchy, arcaded squares and medieval streets.

Uzès holds the title of France's first duchy since 1565. Preserved thanks to the Malraux law in the 1960s, the town blends medieval, Renaissance, and classical architecture in a compact perimeter easily explored on foot.

The Duchy of Uzès (ducal castle) is still inhabited by the ducal family—a rarity in France. The visit reveals the Gothic chapel with polychrome stained glass, the Renaissance façade of the main building, furnished apartments, and vaulted cellar.

The Bermonde Tower, an 11th-century keep rising to 42 meters, offers from its summit a panorama over the historic center's roofs and surrounding garrigue. It's one of three feudal towers marking the powers that reigned over Uzès: the king, the bishop, and the duke.

The Fenestrelle Tower, bell tower of Saint-Théodorit Cathedral, is France's only round Romanesque Lombard-style campanile. Standing 42 meters high, it aligns six levels of paired windows. It's often compared to the Leaning Tower of Pisa for its elegance and slight tilt.

The Place aux Herbes, the town's beating heart, is ringed by arcades beneath which Wednesday and Saturday markets are held. Century-old plane trees, a central fountain, and pastel façades compose a setting often described as Tuscan.

The Medieval Garden of Uzès gathers more than 450 medicinal, aromatic, and edible plants in a monastic setting, in the shade of old stones. A tower accessible with the ticket offers a little-known view over the citadel's roofs.

Medieval lanes overflow with Renaissance mansion houses: carriage gates, spiral staircases, mullioned windows. The Hôtel d'Entraigues, among others, illustrates the discreet elegance that earns Uzès the nickname 'Stone Beauty.'

activities.text: Urban heritage itinerary connecting the place aux Herbes, the Duchy and the belvederes.
Walk to the source of Eure and reading of the aqueduct departure (gentle round trip).

Swimming in the Gardon River beneath the Pont du Gard's arches. Developed beaches 650 feet from the monument offer supervised swimming areas in summer with play areas for children. The river's clear, cool waters invite refreshing dips after visiting the site. Shaded banks provide picnic areas under tamarisk trees. Swimming facing the ancient bridge creates a unique experience blending heritage and nature. The moderate current allows floating on tubes and family water games.

Uzès truffle market from November to March, meeting place for truffle hunters and dealers. Every Saturday morning on Place aux Herbes, the black diamond market gathers local producers selling fresh tubers weighed discreetly. The hushed transaction atmosphere contrasts with the square's usual liveliness. Gard truffles, melanosporum variety, rival those from Périgord and Vaucluse. Restaurants offer truffle menus celebrating the precious fungus. The Maison de la Truffe organizes discovery workshops and truffle-hunting demonstrations.

Visit potter workshops perpetuating Uzès ceramic tradition since antiquity. Artisans shape utilitarian and decorative pieces on the wheel in characteristic red clay. Ancestral techniques coexist with contemporary creations: Provençal jars, glazed tableware, sculptures. Demonstrations reveal precise gestures of throwing, glazing, and traditional kiln firing. Workshop-boutiques dot historic center streets offering original local production. Poterie du Mas de Rouvière perpetuates family know-how for five generations.
Walk along the Gardon and viewpoints of the aqueduct from the panoramic trails.
Swimming/relaxing by the Gardon River (depending on season) below the aqueduct.
Gourmet walk at Uzès market (dates according to calendar).

The Pont du Gard, 25 minutes by car, is the world's tallest Roman aqueduct (49 meters) and one of France's most visited monuments. A World Heritage site, it spans the Gardon River in a garrigue setting.
The Eure valley, at Uzès' foot, preserves vestiges of the Roman aqueduct that tapped springs to supply Nîmes over 50 kilometers. A walk descends to the springs and still-visible regulation basin.

Saturday morning's market at Place aux Herbes is renowned throughout the region. Black truffles in winter, olives, goat cheeses, honey, and charcuterie compose a Gard terroir basket, completed by a glass of AOP Duché d'Uzès wine.

days_plan.itin_title: Cèze Valley Road Trip, France: Ancient Gorges & Perched Medieval Villages in Provence
Gard Road Trip: Roman Nîmes, Pont du Gard & Camargue Wilderness
Roman Provence Itinerary: Uzès, Nîmes, Arles and Orange
Languedoc-Roussillon, France: Medieval Carcassonne, Vineyards and Mediterranean Coast
Occitanie's 13 Most Beautiful Villages

visits.text: The Puymin and Villasse archaeological sites form the largest Gallo-Roman complex open to the public in France. At Puymin, the Maison à l'Apollon Lauré spreads across 21,500 square feet of ruins, and the 1st-century BCE ancient theater still hosts summer performances.
Across the avenue, the Villasse quarter reveals the Rue des Boutiques lined with ancient shops, the 32,000-square-foot Maison à la Tonnelle, and public baths with their basins and lead pipes.
The Musée Théo Desplans, located on the Puymin site, gathers over 2,000 objects from excavations: Roman marble statuary, mosaics, ceramics, and architectural elements.

Cross the single-arched Roman bridge that has spanned the Ouvèze for two thousand years. It links the lower town to the steep lanes of the medieval Haute-Ville, dominated by the ruins of the Counts of Toulouse's castle built in 1195.
The 11th-century Romanesque Cathédrale Notre-Dame de Nazareth preserves an apse vaulted with a cul-de-four and a cloister with carved columns. Its apse rests on repurposed ancient foundations.
Lose yourself in the calades (cobbled streets) of the Haute-Ville. Fortified gates, mossy fountains, a belfry, and shaded squares compose an intact medieval scene atop the rock.

activities.text: The Tuesday morning Provençal market floods the lower town's streets. Olives, seasonal truffles, Ventoux goat cheeses, and herbes de Provence fill the stalls.
Visit wine estates around Vaison to taste Côtes-du-Rhône Villages. The vines climb in terraces on the Ventoux foothills.
Loop hike from the Haute-Ville toward the surrounding hills. The trails cross garrigue, olive groves, and lavender fields with views of the Dentelles de Montmirail.

From Vaison, the Mont Ventoux road via Malaucène climbs to the summit at 6,273 feet. The observatory and orientation table crown a panorama stretching from the Alps to the Mediterranean. The landscape shifts from cedar forest to the white stone desert of the final hairpins.

days_plan.itin_title: Vaucluse: Avignon, Luberon Villages & Ventoux Routes

visits.text: Discovery of Hérival priory, 13th-century vestige in the heart of the valley

activities.text: Walk in the Val-d'Ajol valley and visit to craft workshops

days_plan.itin_title: Vosges Abbeys and Mountains: Monastic Heritage and Green Valley Silence

visits.text: Val d'Isère stretches a kilometer in the heart of Haute-Tarentaise, ringed by summits topping 3,700 m. Wander the village center's lanes and admire stone chalets with lauze-slab roofs that remain faithful to traditional rural architecture.

The église Saint-Bernard-de-Menthon, built in the 11th century of cut stone, towers at the village center. Simple and massive, it has marked the rhythm of Avalin life for nearly a thousand years. In front, the larch mission cross (1847) marks Chapelle Saint-Jean, built to protect the village from avalanches descending from Solaise.

Continue to Le Fornet, an authentic hamlet at the valley's far end (2,000 m). Stone chalets pressed close together, absolute silence: here you touch raw mountain, before the road attacks the hairpin turns of the Iseran pass.

Take the Col de l'Iseran road (2,764 m), the highest paved pass in the French Alps. The panorama sweeps across the glaciers of Vanoise and Gran Paradiso on the Italian side. At the summit, a stone chapel marks the border between Tarentaise and Maurienne.

Parc National de la Vanoise, France's first national park (created 1963), protects 535 km² of core zone. More than 1,400 plant species and remarkable fauna are recorded: ibex, chamois, marmots, bearded vultures, and golden eagles.

Chapelle Saint-Barthélemy, in the hamlet of Laisinant, shelters a restored painting of the Virgin and Child. Built before 1633, it offers a fine starting point for park trails. Nearby, a tapped spring supplies the resort with drinking water.

activities.text: Hike to Refuge du Fond des Fours. From Pont Saint-Charles, the trail crosses the Malpasset gorges, rejoins Val d'Isère village, and climbs the Manchet valley in the heart of the National Park. The refuge (2,537 m) offers a panorama of the Méan Martin glacier.

Family hike to Lac de l'Ouillette (2,350 m). This turquoise alpine lake is reached in 45 minutes from the top of the Solaise cable cars, significantly reducing effort. Beautiful panorama over the Bellevarde rock.
Mountain biking or e-biking on the bike park trails linking Tignes and Val d'Isère. Over 220 km of marked trails between technical descents and panoramic rides overlooking mountain lakes.

days_plan.itin_title: Savoie from Lakes to Glaciers: Yenne to Haute-Maurienne

visits.text: The Cians Gorges cut through the mountain on the road to Valberg: white limestone cliffs at the start, then wine-red schist appears at Pra d'Astier.
The Daluis Gorges, Nice's Colorado: Regional Nature Reserve with 70 mineral species, vertiginous walls of red pelites 250 million years old.
The Bride's Bridge spans the void, 17 tunnels pierce the red rock: one of the most beautiful roads in the Alpes-Maritimes.
Valberg, a family resort with Green Snowflake certification, spreads its chalets between ski slopes and Mercantour trails.
The planetary trail guides young and old through the stars: educational panels, alpine views, playful discovery of the solar system.
Admire Mont Mounier from the resort viewpoints: this emblematic peak dominates the alpine meadows and larch forests.

activities.text: Hiking at the gates of Mercantour: marked trails for all levels, from family walks to ascents toward legendary passes.
Mountain biking and road cycling on alpine circuits: technical descents or panoramic routes, rental shops offer full equipment.
Sunrise snowmobile outing: hot coffee facing snowy peaks, then relaxation in a jacuzzi with views of the slopes.
Night hike to observe the stars: a sky expert guides your gaze toward constellations, far from any light pollution.
The eco-responsible resort invites disconnection: streetlights off at midnight, free shuttles, carpooling encouraged.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure

visits.text: Château de Valençay (Talleyrand).
Animal park.
"Venice of Berry".

activities.text: Valençay AOC cheese tasting (pyramid).
Walk along the Creuse.

days_plan.itin_title: Indre, France: Secret Berry Region and Vallée Noire Rural Villages

visits.text: Wander through Old Valence with its cobblestone lanes, weathered stone houses, and shaded squares. The monumental fountain stands as the city's iconic symbol. This historic center, designated a City and Land of Art and History, brims with architectural treasures waiting to be discovered.

Visit Valence's oldest monument, built between 1063 and 1099. Pope Urban II consecrated this Romanesque cathedral in 1095. The building showcases characteristic Auvergnat Romanesque architecture with its imposing bell tower-porch.

Marvel at this Renaissance masterpiece built around 1530. The mansion takes its name from the numerous sculpted heads adorning its façade: busts of Roman emperors, medallions of the Church Fathers, and allegorical figures. The inner courtyard is freely accessible year-round.

Stroll across this vast tree-lined esplanade created in the 1770s. This panoramic terrace overlooks the Rhône River and offers spectacular views of the Vivarais mountains and the ruins of Crussol Castle. The site houses the famous Peynet Kiosk, a listed Historical Monument.

Relax in this 7-hectare botanical garden opened in 1905. Designated a Remarkable Garden since 2006, it shelters over 700 century-old trees from around the world, water features populated with swans, and remarkable statuary.

The Cathédrale Saint-Apollinaire, founded in the 11th century, was faithfully reconstructed in the 17th century after destruction during the Wars of Religion. Inside, multicolored stained glass bathes the nave in gentle, shifting light.

At 57 Grande Rue stands the Maison des Têtes—a sight that stops every passerby. This mansion, built around 1530, bridges the late Gothic and Renaissance periods. Its façade sculptures represent the Winds, Fortune, Time, Theology, Law, and Medicine.

Step into the corridor of the Maison des Têtes: its vaulted ceiling sits beside medallion busts of Roman emperors. In the interior courtyard, the Church Fathers appear in medallions beneath the gallery arches.

The Musée de Valence, Art et Archéologie adjoins the cathedral. Perched at the edge of the city's first terrace, it offers sweeping landscape views while presenting collections spanning from prehistory to contemporary art.

Parc Jouvet spreads across 7 hectares below the Champ de Mars. This "Remarkable Garden" combines formal French style in its central zone with English landscape design in its winding paths. Plane trees tower over 40 meters high, while a rose garden and water features bordered by exotic plants complete the scene.
The Armenian Heritage Center traces the history of the Armenian exodus and the community's arrival in Valence during the 1920s. It's a place of memory—spare, dignified, deeply moving.

activities.text: Discover a little-known side of Valence by exploring 17 kilometers of open-air canals. The most famous route, the Épervière Canals (5.8 km), connects 4 major natural spaces and reveals the city's greener side.

Explore the collections of this museum inaugurated in 1850, housed in the former episcopal palace. The museum presents art and archaeological collections spanning multiple periods: regional antiquities and fine arts from the 16th to 20th centuries.
Sample local specialties: caillette (pork and chard pâté), Dauphiné ravioles, and pogne (orange blossom brioche). Visit the traditional market to meet local producers face-to-face.

Head to the Champ de Mars esplanade, inaugurated in 1862. The historic kiosk, now a listed monument, frames a perspective of Crussol Castle and the Vivarais mountains—a vista protected as a natural site since 1942.

Wander through the lanes of old Valence around Place des Clercs. Renaissance townhouses, covered passages, and shaded squares unfold one after another. Le Pendentif, a 16th-century funerary monument, surprises with its unusual form.
Sample the Suisse, a shortbread cookie shaped like a little person and perfumed with orange blossom—a Valence specialty. Pastry shops in the city center keep this tradition alive.
The Parc Jouvet miniature train, in service since 1967, loops around the park. Kids also love the playground, trampoline, and aviary.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence Drôme Road Trip: Medieval Villages & Local Terroir
Rhône-Alpes Circuit: Perched Villages and Mountain Peaks

visits.text: The market hall on Place Nationale has hosted markets every Tuesday morning since Edward I founded the bastide in 1283. Its arcades shelter farmers and craftspeople beneath ancient timbers.
Lavoir del Theron is the oldest and most unusual of three washhouses. Listed as a Historic Monument, it recalls an era when washerwomen gathered to scrub linen and share village news.
Lavoir Saint-Bernard completes this water heritage. Restored and flower-lined, it remains a gathering place for residents.
Notre-Dame Church, rebuilt in 1902, presents neo-Renaissance style. Its 1865 organ by Vincent Cavaillé-Coll and a 17th-century gilded Virgin and Child adorn the Gothic interior.
A traditional dovecote illustrates Gascon rural architecture. Its distinctive silhouette once punctuated agricultural estates throughout the region.

activities.text: Follow the Canal des Deux Mers cycle route. Port-Canal Jacques-Yves-Cousteau offers a shaded stop for cyclists and boaters.
Explore the public garden within the former Capuchin convent grounds. Fountains and plantings reflect the town's three-flower classification.
Discover orchards spreading across the Garonne valley. Quercy melons, Agen prunes, and Moissac Chasselas ripen under the Southwest sun.

days_plan.itin_title: Tarn-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides and Orchard Country

visits.text: The Valenciennes Museum of Fine Arts houses a prestigious collection of 17th-century Flemish painting, dominated by Rubens (Triptych of Saint Stephen, Descent from the Cross), Van Dyck and Jordaens. The Place Carpeaux at the museum's heart showcases sculptures by the celebrated Valenciennes artist.

Saint-Géry Church, Valenciennes' main church, houses the statue of Notre-Dame du Saint-Cordon. According to legend, in 1008 the Virgin appeared to plague-ravaged residents and encircled the city with a protective scarlet cord. The epidemic ceased immediately.

The Notre-Dame-du-Saint-Cordon Basilica (1852-1864), in neo-Gothic style inspired by Amiens and Chartres, dominates the city with its octagonal spire. Its three-level nave offers luminous transparency. Interior decoration was entrusted to local artists.
Walk through the streets of Old Valenciennes, recently renovated. Eight information totems line the route, recounting the history of the oldest streets in this former fortified Hainaut city.
The museum's archaeological crypt presents Gallo-Roman and medieval antiquities found in the Valenciennes region: bronzes, pilgrimage badges and bishops' crosiers testify to the city's long history.

activities.text: Stroll through the Rhônelle garden, a landscaped park following the river south of downtown. Its willow- and plane-lined paths offer a peaceful setting after visiting the museum.
Valenciennes, birthplace of painter Watteau and sculptor Carpeaux, boasts numerous ornate façades. Look up at Place d'Armes and its pilastered buildings to spot traces of this artistic past.

In September, the Tour du Saint-Cordon gathers thousands of pilgrims who follow the legendary path of the Virgin's protective cord through city streets, to the song "Reine des Cieux" (Queen of Heaven).

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

visits.text: Saint-Pierre Cathedral stretches over 360 feet in length. Its 17th-century baroque furnishings create a striking contrast against the Gothic architecture.

Walk along the medieval rampart walkway. The formal French gardens of La Garenne cascade down terraced slopes beneath the fortifications. In spring, Japanese cherry trees explode in clouds of pink blossoms.
La Cohue once housed the medieval market halls. Today the Fine Arts Museum displays works ranging from 19th-century Breton artists to contemporary creations.
The Saint-Vincent Gate was rebuilt in 1747 by engineer Duchemin. Its three tiers of granite marked the main entrance to the fortified city.

Wander the cobblestone lanes of the historic center. Half-timbered houses with overhanging upper floors date from the 15th and 16th centuries. In Place Henri IV, look for the carved busts of Vannes and his wife.
The Constable's Tower rises as the tallest in the city walls. Its large mullioned windows reveal its dual purpose: defensive tower and later, ducal residence.

activities.text: The market takes over Place des Lices on Wednesday and Saturday mornings. Kouign-amann, far breton, and fresh seafood from the Gulf await.
From the harbor, board a boat cruise through the Gulf of Morbihan. Ferries serve Île aux Moines and Île d'Arz.
Follow the coastal path from the Conleau peninsula to the village of Séné. The nature reserve marshlands shelter elegant avocets and white spoonbills.

days_plan.itin_title: Morbihan Road Trip: Gulf, Carnac & Breton Coast

Viewpoints of the southern ridges of Vercors.

activities.text: Plateau loop on white trails (6–8 km, very gentle slope).
Landscape reading of combes and karst at the edge.

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies

visits.text: Pass through the Porte de France, a medieval remnant through which Joan of Arc left Vaucouleurs on February 23, 1429, to join Dauphin Charles VII at Chinon. Over 13 meters high with 2-meter-thick walls, it's the last of the four gates in the fortified enclosure.

Climb to the castle chapel on the town heights. The crypt houses the statue of Notre-Dame des Voûtes, before which Joan came to pray. The 26 stained glass windows from the Nancy workshop Höner, Benoît et Janin trace Joan's epic journey.

The Joan of Arc Museum, housed in the Town Hall wing, preserves over 300 pieces: drawings, prints, stained glass cartoons, bronze sculptures, and posters. The museum's four sections explore Joan's different symbolisms - virgin, warrior, and martyr.

Next to the Porte de France, the Pagis Towers testify to the city's fortified past. The first castle, built in 1026 by Étienne de Vaux, had 17 rampart towers. Only the King's Tower and the English Tower survive in the lower town.
The 1848 Town Hall contains a monumental painting by Scherrer (1886) depicting Joan's departure, and six Aubusson tapestries inaugurated in 1990 illustrating six stages of Joan's epic.

activities.text: Follow the discovery circuit of Joan of Arc heritage through Vaucouleurs streets: from the Porte de France to the linden tree where Joan reportedly rested, each stop features explanatory panels.
Saturday's weekly market brings together local producers and artisans. Find mirabelles, jams, cheeses, and charcuterie from the Meuse terroir.
Stroll along the Meuse valley. The communal forest surrounding Vaucouleurs offers shaded trails for a nature break between historical visits.

days_plan.itin_title: Meuse Circuit: Verdun and the Citadels

Creutzwald — Villa Notre-Dame de la Clairière: nativity scene prepared by volunteers.
Creutzwald — Church of Sainte-Croix du Centre: stained glass windows and restored nativity scene (circa 1900).

days_plan.itin_title: The Moselle Nativity Route: A Festive Christmas Road Trip Through Border Villages

visits.text: Vaux-en-Beaujolais, the real Clochemerle made famous by Gabriel Chevallier's satirical novel, has kept the soul of a Beaujolais wine village where life flows peacefully. The novel, published in 1934, depicted the colorful rivalries and picturesque characters of a wine village. The town embraced this literary identity by creating a circuit retracing locations described in the book. Golden stone houses and flower-filled alleys preserve authentic charm untouched by time.

The famous public urinal, at the heart of literary controversy, stands on the church square as a symbol of local humor. The monument, erected as homage to the novel, became a pilgrimage destination for literature lovers. A nearby panel recounts the story of this scandalous facility that divided the fictional village. The Church of Saint-Pierre overlooks this unusual square with its Romanesque bell tower.

The Musée Clochemerle, housed in the old town hall, immerses visitors in the universe of Gabriel Chevallier's novel. Period objects, photographs, and excerpts recreate the atmosphere of the 1930s and the story's colorful characters. The collection includes original editions, translations into dozens of languages, and film adaptations. A wine tasting room completes the visit with local Beaujolais.

Walk the Heritage Trail that winds through vineyards and hamlets. Information panels reveal the history of golden stone houses, vaulted wine cellars, and bread ovens. The circuit passes by the wash house where village women gathered, crosses vineyards stretching to the horizon, and climbs to belvederes offering views of surrounding valleys.

activities.text: Taste Beaujolais wines at family estates that have cultivated vines for generations. Independent winegrowers open their cellars to explain their work and passion. Tastings include different cuvées to understand terroir diversity. The warm welcome and informality typical of Beaujolais make each visit a moment of authentic sharing. Some estates offer picnics in the vineyards with a view.

Attend a reading of excerpts from Clochemerle at the village café, organized regularly by a local theater troupe. Actors bring the novel's colorful characters to life with humor and authentic local accent. The informal atmosphere encourages exchanges between spectators who share their memories of reading the book. A Beaujolais tasting follows the performance.

Cycle through surrounding vineyards on small roads where cars rarely pass. The gentle terrain makes cycling accessible to everyone. The route connects several wine hamlets, passes through century-old vines, and offers spectacular views of Mont Blanc on clear days. Stops at independent winegrowers allow discovery of production diversity.

Visit during the Fête Raclet in October, celebrating Beaujolais gastronomy. Village producers offer tastings of new wines, local charcuterie, and regional cheeses. Street entertainment, concerts, and wine-related games create a festive and friendly atmosphere. The tradition of mâchon beaujolais, this hearty breakfast accompanying morning tastings, delights the curious.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: Former fortified town; narrow streets, stone houses and remains of walls.
Views over vineyards and meadows of the Albarine valley.

activities.text: Round trip to the Buizin vats: giant's potholes and waterfalls (marked trail).
Short loop in the old village and high points (2 km).

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: The Château de Vaux-le-Vicomte was born from the collaboration of three artists in service to Louis XIV's finance superintendent: architect Le Vau, landscape architect Le Nôtre, and painter Le Brun. This 17th-century masterpiece directly inspired the Palace of Versailles.
On the ground floor, the reception salons, library, and king's chamber reveal grandiose decor: exceptional tapestries, period furniture, and ceilings painted by Le Brun.
Climb to the château's dome for a panoramic view over the 33 hectares of formal gardens. The perspective drawn by Le Nôtre extends over three kilometers to the Hercules statue.
In the basement, the period kitchens and cellars remain intact. A permanent exhibition traces Le Nôtre's genius using a large audiovisual model of the garden.
The Carriage Museum assembles coaches, carriages, and harnesses from the 17th to 20th centuries. The collection illustrates the art of travel and aristocratic transport.

activities.text: Tour the formal gardens by electric cart. Flower beds, boxwood embroidery, pools, and fountains unfold across 33 hectares enclosed by a 13-km perimeter wall.
On summer Saturday evenings, 2,000 candles illuminate the gardens for candlelit evenings. A gold and silver fireworks display concludes this magical nocturnal promenade.
Walk to the Hercules statue at the top of the perspective. The viewpoint embraces the garden's different terraced "plateaus" down to the château: the perfect picnic spot with a view.

days_plan.itin_title: Seine-et-Marne Circuit: Fontainebleau and Royal Châteaux

visits.text: Trinity Abbey of Vendôme founded in 1033 by Count Geoffroy Martel after seeing three stars fall into a well. This Benedictine abbey grew rapidly powerful, housing up to one hundred monks by the 12th century. The abbey church impresses with its small cathedral dimensions harmoniously blending Romanesque and Gothic architecture. The 80-meter Romanesque bell tower has dominated the town for nine centuries. The flamboyant façade completed in 1508 by Jean de Beauce constitutes a masterpiece of stone carving ablaze with sculptural detail. The preserved cloisters, chapter house, and remnants testify to past splendor.

Old Town of Vendôme winding between the Loir's branches forming several islands connected by stone bridges. Medieval lanes reveal half-timbered houses, Renaissance mansions, and flower-filled interior courtyards. The fortified 14th-century water gate guarded access to the walled city. Restored washhouses evoke everyday life of yesteryear along the banks. Terraced gardens descend to shaded riverbanks. The peaceful atmosphere of this city of art and history invites leisurely wandering far from tourist crowds.

Château de Vendôme dominating the town from its rocky promontory. The romantic ruins testify to the power of the Counts of Vendôme. Medieval ramparts offer a panoramic walk over the Loir valley. The Saint-Georges collegiate church preserves beautiful Renaissance stained glass. The Poitiers tower constitutes the most imposing element of the fortifications. Gardens landscaped within the enclosure invite contemplation. The public park provides free access to remnants and exceptional viewpoints over the town.

activities.text: Walking along the Loir's branches flowing through Vendôme and creating an exceptional bucolic setting. Landscaped banks offer shaded paths lined with weeping willows. Green islands connected by stone bridges invite discovery of secret corners. Restored mills and old tanneries recount past economic activity. Reflections of old façades in clear water create changing tableaux throughout the day. Strategically placed benches let you admire the ballet of swans and ducks.

Gardens of Vendôme offering green havens in the historic town's heart. Ronsard Park unfolds its lawns and flowerbeds at the foot of medieval ramparts. The château's terraced gardens overlook the Loir valley offering panoramic views over the meanders. Green spaces landscaped along the water invite peaceful rest and contemplation. Centuries-old trees provide welcome shade during hot summer days. Rose gardens perfume the air in June, creating a romantic atmosphere for strollers.

Vendôme market held Friday mornings on Place de la Paix animating the entire town center. Colorful stalls offer farm products, Sologne goat cheeses, Vendôme rillettes, and locally grown seasonal vegetables. Producers sell poultry, honey, artisanal jams, and traditional Easter pies. Flowers, fabrics, and bric-a-brac objects complete the diverse offerings. The convivial atmosphere and conversations among regulars create an authentic provincial market feel. Cafés open their terraces to welcome browsers.

days_plan.itin_title: Loir-et-Cher Itinerary: Royal Châteaux and the Loir Valley

visits.text: Venelles — belvedere village north of Aix, views of Sainte-Victoire.
Old center — shaded streets and small squares.

activities.text: Wooded loop on the Venelles hills (marked trails).
Panoramic route at sunset towards the belvedere.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: Descend into 7 kilometers of galleries carved beneath Vauban's citadel at the end of the 19th century. An augmented reality headset puts you in the boots of a 1916 soldier: discover the ovens that produced 28,000 rations daily and the ardent chapel where Corporal Thin designated the Unknown Soldier on November 10, 1920.

The World Center for Peace occupies an 18th-century episcopal palace, partially destroyed in 1916 and later restored. Its temporary exhibitions explore Franco-German relations and human rights. The formal French garden at the rear offers an open view over the city.

Step inside Notre-Dame Cathedral, built from the 10th century onward. Its Romanesque-Gothic blend houses a gilded baroque baldachin, restored after the Great War bombardments. Modern stained glass filters colored light into the nave.

Fort Douaumont, the most powerful structure in the fortified complex, fell to German hands on February 25, 1916. Walk through the command room, chapel, combat galleries, and inscriptions soldiers left on the walls. Interior temperature hovers around 7 to 10°C.

The Douaumont Ossuary, inaugurated in 1932, rises like a gigantic shell above 15,000 white crosses. Its 46-meter tower dominates the battlefield. Through the oculi in the base, you glimpse the remains of 130,000 unidentified French and German soldiers.

Renovated in 2016 for the centenary, the Verdun Memorial displays over 2,000 authentic objects at the former station of the destroyed village of Fleury-devant-Douaumont. A 100-square-meter shattered screen reconstructs the battlefield's convulsions. From the top-floor terraces, the panorama reveals scars still visible beneath the forest.

The Trench of Bayonets preserves the memory of June 12, 1916: according to legend, a company of the 137th regiment was buried alive by bombardment, their bayonets left stuck in the ground. A sober monument has protected the site since 1920.

activities.text: Walk the Meuse quays at dusk, between stone bridges and facades rebuilt after 1918. The reflection of lights on the river offers a soothing contrast after visiting the battlefields.
Follow the Sacred Way, the former supply route that linked Bar-le-Duc to Verdun during the battle. Milestones carved with poilu helmets mark the 56-kilometer historic route.
Pass through the Porte Chaussée, a 14th-century fortified gate that was part of the city's original ramparts. Used as a prison from 1755 to 1860, it marks the entrance to old Verdun.

The Princerie Museum, housed in a 16th-century mansion, brings together archaeological and artistic collections spanning from prehistory to the 19th century. Sacred art enthusiasts will find remarkable pieces here.

Visit Fleury-devant-Douaumont, a village taken and retaken 16 times in two months. Signs indicate the location of the town hall, school, and church. It's one of nine villages classified as "died for France."

days_plan.itin_title: Meuse Circuit: Verdun and the Citadels

visits.text: Claude Monet's House and Gardens in Giverny. Normandy's second-most visited site, this Impressionist sanctuary was the master's refuge for 43 years. The Clos Normand unfolds its flower beds beneath rose-covered arches, while the water garden reveals the iconic Japanese bridge and water lilies that inspired the monumental canvases. The pink stucco house preserves the reconstructed studio, the yellow dining room with its Japanese print collection, and the kitchen with its blue Rouen tiles.

Museum of Impressionisms Giverny. Steps from the Monet Foundation, this contemporary museum presents rotating exhibitions dedicated to Impressionism and its global influence. The building harmonizes beautifully with landscaped gardens that extend the spirit of the place.

Vernon's Old Mill. Perched on the pillars of a 12th-century medieval bridge, this 16th-century half-timbered house seems to defy the laws of balance. A historic monument since 2025, this suspended waterwheel mill immortalized by Monet is one of France's last inhabited bridges. Facing it, the Château des Tourelles once guarded the fortified town's entrance.

Notre-Dame Collegiate Church of Vernon. This church of mixed styles bears witness to eight centuries of religious architecture. The Romanesque façade neighbors Gothic vaults and Renaissance additions. Inside, admire the ancient stained glass windows and the flamboyant rose window.

Old Vernon and Rue Potard. Spared by bombings, this medieval street has preserved its 15th and 16th-century half-timbered houses. The Archives Tower, the castle's former keep, dominates Place de l'Ange. A heritage trail punctuated by interpretive markers retraces this royal city's history.

Eure Valley and its villages. Heading back toward Vernon, pass through the charming Eure valley villages: Chambray, La Croix-Saint-Leufroy, Houlbec-Cocherel. These preserved hamlets bear witness to rural, authentic Normandy.

Pacy-sur-Eure and the Eure Valley Railway. This tourist steam or diesel train covers 22 km of bucolic landscapes between Pacy and Breuilpont. The period station and historic rolling stock transport travelers into the railway atmosphere of the early 20th century.

activities.text: Bike ride along La Seine à Vélo. The cycling route connects Giverny to Vernon following the river. From Vernon station, shuttles and bike rentals allow car-free access to Giverny. The journey crosses landscapes that inspired the Impressionists.

Château de Bizy in Vernon. Nicknamed Normandy's little Versailles, this 18th-century château hosted Louis XV and the Bonaparte family. The monumental stables and park with fountains by Pierre Contant d'Ivry are worth the detour.

Final stroll through Giverny. Before leaving Eure, return to wander the Impressionist village. Visit Claude Monet's grave in the small cemetery near the church, where the father of Impressionism has rested since 1926.
Local produce shopping. Farmhouse cider, Calvados, Camembert, Livarot, and Pont-l'Évêque: Eure's cheese shops and cider houses offer the authentic flavors of Normandy.

days_plan.itin_title: Eure Road Trip: From Giverny to Normandy's Finest Medieval Villages

visits.text: Versailles, Petit Trianon — "Adventure" (1901).
Blandy-les-Tours — Screams/chains, All Saints' Day.
Château de la Solitude — Ruins & rumors.

The Palace of Versailles, a UNESCO World Heritage site, unfolds its 2,300 rooms around the Marble Court. The King's Grand Apartments stretch across seven salons dedicated to the planets, adorned with polychrome marble and ceilings painted by Le Brun.
Step into the Hall of Mirrors: 73 meters long, 357 mirrors facing 17 arched windows, completed by Hardouin-Mansart in 1684. Morning light creates the most spectacular effect here.
The Queen's Apartments preserve Marie-Antoinette's bed and the Nobles' Salon. The ceiling of the Grand Couvert depicts the four cardinal virtues.
Don't miss the Royal Chapel, Hardouin-Mansart's masterpiece completed in 1710. Its white stone Corinthian columns rise across two levels beneath a vault painted by Antoine Coypel.
The Grand Trianon, a pink marble palace built by Mansart in 1687, served as Louis XIV's retreat from court ceremony. Its formal gardens open onto a peristyle with pink and green columns.

The Petit Trianon, gifted by Louis XVI to Marie-Antoinette in 1774, houses refined neoclassical interiors. Just behind it, the Queen's Hamlet recreates a Norman village with a farm, mill, and dairy, built between 1783 and 1786.

activities.text: Access: public (Trianon)
Access: public (Blandy)
Access: private ext. (Solitude)
Wander through the gardens designed by Le Nôtre: intricate parterres, shaded groves, fountains, and vistas stretching to the 1,670-meter-long Grand Canal.
Experience the Musical Fountains Show: fountains dance to Lully and Rameau's compositions throughout the park's groves.
Rent a bike or rowboat to explore the Grand Canal. A full circuit by bike takes about 45 minutes and offers sweeping views of the palace's western façade.
Stroll through the Petit Trianon gardens: the Temple of Love, the Belvedere, and the English garden compose the pastoral landscape Marie-Antoinette desired.

days_plan.itin_title: Haunted Île-de-France: Occult Paris and Royal Ghost Stories
Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages
Yvelines Road Trip: Versailles and Impressionist Villages

activities.text: Countryside loop around hills and bocage hedgerows.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: The Château de Verteuil has overlooked the village from its rocky spur for centuries. Owned by the La Rochefoucauld family for 1,000 years (sold in 2020), it hosted Charles V who planted a yew still standing today. Visit the chapel and main courtyard.
The Moulin de Verteuil at the foot of the castle, with its waterwheel still turning. Now a restaurant with a terrace by the water. The castle + mill + Charente view = the perfect photo.

The church of Saint-Médard (12th century) hides a life-size Entombment in polychrome terracotta. Seven figures around Christ, attributed to the workshop of Germain Pilon. One of the Charente's hidden treasures.

The village lanes lead to the fairground shaded by lime trees, on the banks of the Charente. The Maison du Sénéchal (15th century) with its mullioned windows, remains of the old Protestant temple, wash houses. A Petite Cité de Caractère.

activities.text: Castle visit. Access to the main courtyard and chapel (self-guided or guided depending on availability). Tickets from the wine merchant at the bottom of the drive.
Lunch at the Moulin de Verteuil. Terrace facing the waterwheel, local cuisine. Booking advised at weekends. Alternative: Jeux de Pots overlooks the Charente.
Hike around the castle. 6.6 km loop through the countryside and hamlets, returning along the Charente banks. Easy, 1h30–2h. Start from the castle car park.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: The Vertus church rises at the village center. Its white stones echo the omnipresent chalk that defines this landscape.
Medieval ramparts still encircle part of the village. These ancient fortifications tell the story of a walled wine town.
Mont Aimé dominates the plain to the south. This isolated chalk hill offers sweeping views across the Côte des Blancs and its 20-kilometer ribbon of vines.

activities.text: Follow paths winding through the hillside vineyards. Chardonnay reigns supreme here—97% of Vertus's premier cru vineyards are planted with this noble white grape.
Visit winemakers specializing in blanc de blancs champagne. The exposed chalk bedrock gives these wines their distinctive mineral edge.

days_plan.itin_title: Marne Road Trip: Reims, Épernay and the Champagne Route

visits.text: The fortified churches of Thiérache form a unique heritage ensemble. Sixty buildings were fortified in the 16th and 17th centuries by the villagers themselves to resist constant raids. Watchtowers, loopholes and refuge rooms testify to exceptional religious military architecture. Burelles, Prisces with its 25-meter keep, and Parfondeval offer the most remarkable examples.
Vervins preserves remains of its old fortifications. The upper town reveals its strategic past as a border city with traces of ramparts still visible in some streets.
The Thiérache bocage rolls between meadows and hedges. Red brick villages dot this preserved rural landscape where fortified churches dominate the green horizons.
Follow the signposted tourist route of fortified churches on the Pays de Thiérache map. This orange circuit crosses the valleys of Brune and Serre linking the most spectacular buildings.

activities.text: The Thiérache region cultivates dairy farming traditions. Maroilles cheese, emblematic of the terroir, is produced in local farms. Some dairies offer visits and tastings of this strong-smelling cheese with distinctive flavor.
Walk the marked trails connecting fortified churches through the bocage. Several loops allow half-day or full-day hikes through this preserved rural heritage.
Visit craft workshops perpetuating traditional know-how. Local artisans work wood, forge iron and create pottery according to ancestral methods.

days_plan.itin_title: Aisne Circuit: Gothic Cathedrals and Picardy Nature

visits.text: The Verzenay lighthouse rises 25 meters above an ocean of vines. Built in 1909 as a champagne marketing stunt, it now houses the Museum of Vines.
Climb 101 steps to the top. The viewing platform offers 360-degree views across the Montagne de Reims and its rolling sea of vineyards.
The Verzenay windmill watches over the slopes. Owned by Maison Mumm, it stands guard above grand cru Pinot Noir parcels.

activities.text: Hike trails winding through the vineyards. These UNESCO-listed slopes reveal centuries of viticultural craftsmanship.
Visit the lighthouse tasting room, where local winemakers pour their cuvées with vineyard views stretching to the horizon.

days_plan.itin_title: Marne Road Trip: Reims, Épernay and the Champagne Route
