visits.text: Thermal spa.
Belle Époque heritage.
Basilica of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine and summit esplanade.
Ramparts and ancient gates with views over the hill and valleys.
Grand'rue and stone houses of the upper town.
The Basilica of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine, a UNESCO World Heritage site, crowns the hill of Vézelay. Its narthex tympanum, the 'Pentecost,' is a masterpiece of 12th-century Romanesque sculpture.

The basilica's Romanesque nave displays exceptional historiated capitals: over one hundred biblical and allegorical scenes carved on the columns. Summer solstice sunlight traces a path along the nave floor.

The crypt houses relics attributed to Mary Magdalene, which made Vézelay a major pilgrimage site from the 11th century. Bernard of Clairvaux preached the Second Crusade here in 1146 before King Louis VII.
Climb rue Saint-Étienne from Porte Neuve at the village base. Golden stone houses, art galleries, and artisan workshops succeed one another up to the basilica square.
Vézelay's ramparts, still visible at several points, testify to the site's strategic importance. Porte Neuve and Porte Sainte-Croix frame the hilltop village.

activities.text: View over the Morvan.
Village of character.
Walk down to Saint-Père and its wash houses then return via the marked trail.
Belvedere path: short loop around the hill inspired by pilgrimage routes.
From the terrace behind the basilica, a 360° panorama opens over the Morvan, the Cure valley, and wooded hills. On clear days, the view extends for dozens of kilometers.
Vézelay is the starting point of the Via Lemovicensis, one of four French routes to Santiago de Compostela. Walk the first kilometers of the GR 654 through Burgundian countryside.
Vézelay's artisan workshops—potters, painters, sculptors—enliven the village year-round. Push open gallery doors scattered through the lanes to discover local creations.

days_plan.itin_title: Nièvre, France: Morvan Hills and Ducal Castle Heritage Routes
Burgundy Villages Tour: Medieval Stone and Golden Vineyard Landscapes
Yonne Circuit: Northern Burgundy & Chablis Wine Country

visits.text: The old town of Vic-sur-Cère nestles against the east slope of the valley at 680 metres altitude, sheltered by a spectacular rocky and wooded chaos. Built of lava stone and roofed with schist slabs, this spa village retains the authentic charm of Cantal mountain towns. A renowned climatic resort, it offers a green setting ideal for recharging.

The Rocher des Pendus towers over Vic-sur-Cère and offers an exceptional viewpoint over the upper valley. The nearby Puy Griou rises before the Élancèze and the Peyre-Arse in a grandiose panorama over the Cantal summits. This perspective reveals the full majesty of the volcanic cirque.

activities.text: The Cascades du Pas de Cère tumble through a spectacular canyon where tumultuous water has carved the volcanic rock. The fitted trail follows the gorges in a cool, green atmosphere, revealing successive waterfalls in an impressive mineral setting. The roar of water echoes between the basaltic walls.

The Pas de Cère canyon offers thrill-seekers a canyoning descent through the wild gorges. Jumps, natural slides and rappels follow one another in the riverbed between vertical walls of black lava. Local outfitters supervise this spectacular aquatic activity.

days_plan.itin_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions

visits.text: The Georges de La Tour museum, inaugurated in 2003 in a contemporary building, pays tribute to the master of chiaroscuro born in Vic in 1593. The permanent exhibition presents a collection of 17th-century paintings, contextualizing La Tour's work within the Baroque movement. Temporary exhibitions explore influences and contemporaries. Didactic multimedia spaces explain the painter's revolutionary technique: controlled light, mystical atmospheres, and humble models treated with nobility.

The Saint-Marien collegiate church from the 13th-15th centuries preserves Renaissance stained glass windows from the 16th century and remarkable liturgical furniture: 18th-century stalls, 1749 Wegmann organ, and baroque paintings. Its squat 50-meter bell tower dominates the mechanical tile roofs of the village, a sandstone sentinel watching over the former salt marshes that made Vic's fortune from the 11th to 17th century with 27 salt works producing 60,000 tons of salt per year.

activities.text: Discover the history of salt in the Saulnois region, land of 400 salt springs exploited since Gallic then Gallo-Roman times. The salt marshes of Vic, Moyenvic, and Marsal produced 'white gold' in the Middle Ages by solar evaporation in lead pans. A little-known heritage that shaped the Lorraine economy until the 18th century, controlled by the bishops of Metz who drew immense revenues from it. The flat country of shimmering ponds as far as the eye can see preserves this unique landscape.

Stroll through the streets of Vic-sur-Seille, a characterful village of 1,200 inhabitants with houses of pink Vosges sandstone. Ancient salt works including Gallic briquetages, 16th-17th-century Renaissance mansions, sandstone fountains, and wash houses tell the story of the prosperity of a city that exported its 'white gold' by river to Nancy, Metz, and even Burgundy. Partially preserved medieval ramparts.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: The Hall des Sources (1903) displays its Art Nouveau metal structure, a true vessel of glass and steel designed by Charles Le Cœur. Its ironwork signed by Émile Robert reproduces the park's thistles, while five thermal springs gush forth: Célestins, Lucas, Hôpital, Chomel and Grande Grille. Mineral water can be tasted free of charge at the bars installed in this luminous hall.

The Vichy Opera (inaugurated in 1903) houses an Art Nouveau hall with 1486 seats decorated by Léon Rudnicki. Inside the dome, the faces of famous artists like Sarah Bernhardt adorn the ceiling. This Congress Palace-Opera, classified as UNESCO World Heritage, combines today historic and contemporary spaces in a unique setting in France.

The Thermes des Dômes, recognizable by their neo-Moorish dome, rank Vichy among major thermal resorts. Built between 1899 and 1903, these first-class thermal baths offer 46 treatment cabins in a preserved Belle Époque decor. The waters rich in sodium bicarbonate have treated digestive ailments and rheumatism for 2000 years.

The Parc des Sources extends around the eponymous Hall, created in 1812 by decree of Napoleon I. Its wrought-iron covered galleries (1899-1903) connect the park to the Congress Palace-Opera. The 700-meter-long promenades allow strolling in this green lung where thermal architecture dialogues with nature.

The Napoleon III Park (1861) extends its 7.8 hectares of English gardens along a 2.5 km dike protecting from Allier floods. Rare and exotic species (cedars, sequoias, Judas trees) populate this romantic haven. The imperial chalets in colonial style, built between 1863 and 1864, testify to Napoleon III's stays who made Vichy the queen of spa towns.

activities.text: The Grand Café Casino, nestled in the Parc des Sources near the Opera, invites you to try your luck at poker, roulette or one of the 100 slot machines. This Belle Époque establishment perpetuates the playful tradition of the thermal resort, attracting spa guests and visitors in a festive and friendly atmosphere.

The thermal quarter reveals its Art Nouveau facades and covered passages with film-like allure. Rue Alquié aligns its English-style houses, Rue de Belgique exhibits its baroque facades, while the Napoleon III chalets of colonial inspiration recall the splendor of the Second Empire. Vichy architecture offers an assumed bourgeois side, legacy of the thermal golden age.

The Allier riverbanks invite strolling along the artificial lake created in 1963. Plage des Célestins, guinguettes and green spaces offer relaxation and leisure by the water. The promenade continues on 4 km of developed cycle paths, perfect for enjoying the golden hour by the river.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: Viens — medieval fortified town with ramparts (11th–13th c.) and Clock Gate.
Narrow streets, tall houses and covered passages.

activities.text: Ramparts tower and belvedere over the Albion plateau.
Rural path to terraces and fields (short loop).

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour

visits.text: Port d'Albret marine lake: Created artificially between 1966 and 1975 over 40 hectares, this body of water stretches between Vieux-Boucau and Soustons. The central wooded islet nicknamed Temptation Island remains inaccessible but provides a bird refuge. The name Vieux-Boucau means old mouth, a memory of when the Adour flowed out here before 1578.

Promenade du Mail: Connecting downtown to the lake's outlet, this alley lined with maritime pines features restaurants, bars and ice cream shops. A summery laid-back atmosphere reigns on this pedestrian artery. Unobstructed view of the lake and water activities. Spectacular sunsets from the jetty.

The three beaches: Grand Plage in the town center (urban then wild), Sablères beach to the north (high dunes, naturism tolerated), and the marine lake beach with calm, warm waters. Each beach offers a different atmosphere. Lake waters are 3-4°C warmer than the ocean, ideal for families.

activities.text: Swimming in the marine lake: Lifeguarded beach in season with calm waters maintained at constant level. Pleasant temperature higher than the ocean. Ideal for young children and water sports beginners. Inflatable games installed in summer. Lifeguard station and restrooms on site.

Water activities on the lake: Rental of pedal boats, paddleboards, kayaks and small sailboats. The lake's protected waters allow safe practice for beginners. Sailing lessons for children and adults in July-August. Family-friendly and convivial atmosphere.

Vieux-Boucau markets: Daily morning market except Sunday with local producers. Special evening markets in summer (crafts, clothing). Festive atmosphere with musical entertainment. Landes specialties and fresh products. Set-up from 6pm for evening markets.

Golf de Pinsolle nearby: 18-hole course in a setting of pines and ponds. Accessible to players of all levels. Driving range, pro shop and restaurant on site. Greenfees vary by season. Booking advised in high season.

days_plan.itin_title: Landes Road Trip: Atlantic Coast, Pine Forests & Gascon Heritage

visits.text: Mountain village heart; squares, galleries and high rooftops.
Views of the plateau and cliffs of Grande Moucherolle.
Vercors: Bourne gorges, belvederes and geological points of interest.
Passerelle du Drac (Himalayan bridge): crossing and viewpoints over the Drac.

activities.text: Urban loop and balcony path (3–4 km).
Walk along the edge toward alpine meadows.
Vercors scenic route (cliffs, tunnels and combes).
Short hike around Villard-de-Lans (alpine pastures and limestone pavements).

days_plan.itin_title: Royans-Vercors, France: Alpine Villages and Dramatic Gorge Balconies
Europe's Volcanic Landscapes: Auvergne, Eifel & Lake Como Comparison

visits.text: Villars — round village approached by a shaded avenue, fountain and peaceful small squares.
Old center — traces of the fortified town and arched alleyways.

activities.text: Country walk towards hillsides and dry stone walls.
Photo route at sunset on the Claparèdes plateau.

days_plan.itin_title: Luberon, Provence: Fifteen Hilltop Villages and Provençal Countryside Tour

visits.text: The Bird Park of Villars-les-Dombes brings together over 3,000 birds of 300 different species in a green setting of 35 hectares. Immersive aviaries allow close encounters with the rarest species.
Walk the interpretation trail at Chapelier Pond where two ornithological observatories offer prime viewpoints for watching the wild birdlife of the Dombes.
Notre-Dame des Dombes Abbey stands with its Cistercian buildings amid the ponds. The monks' footpath invites a meditative stroll through this landscape of water and sky.
Discover the educational farm where farmyard animals mingle with cows and horses. Children participate in daily care and bread-making workshops.
The land of a thousand ponds spreads its water mirrors as far as the eye can see. These artificial bodies of water dug by monks in the Middle Ages shape a landscape unique in France.

activities.text: Rent bikes and ride the Fairy of a Thousand Ponds circuit, winding between bodies of water where clouds are reflected.
Take off in a hot air balloon to contemplate from the sky this aquatic checkerboard dotted with farms with red-tiled roofs.
Try canicross hiking with sled dogs who guide you along the paths bordering the ponds.
Horse-drawn carriages offer guided tours through the Dombes, set to the tranquil pace of Percheron horses.

days_plan.itin_title: Grand Tour of the French Alps: From the Thousand Ponds to Mont Blanc

visits.text: The Château de Villebois-Lavalette crowns its hilltop with seven round towers visible for miles. Medieval fortress reworked during the Renaissance, two-storey Romanesque chapel. Guided or self-guided tour with booklet.
The 17th-century covered market hall stands against the castle walls. Chestnut timber frame, stone pillars. On Saturday mornings, the market comes alive: cheeses, poultry, garden vegetables.
The village retains some fine old houses, a restored Romanesque church, and an end-of-the-world feel. At the far edge of the Charente, the Périgord is only a few kilometres away.

activities.text: Guided tour of the Château de Villebois-Lavalette. The association's guides bring history to life: two-storey Romanesque chapel (pilgrims below, lords above), medieval towers, 17th-century residence. Family escape games available.
Saturday morning market. Under the 17th-century hall, local producers and village atmosphere. Goat's cheese, free-range chickens, seasonal vegetables, honey. A real country market.
Hike around Villebois. Waymarked trails through wooded hills. Mixed-farming landscapes, isolated farms, views of the castle. Several loops from 5 to 12 km.
Drive back to Angoulême on back roads. Through southern Charente: vineyards, honey-stone villages, rolling hills. 40 km in about an hour at a gentle pace.

days_plan.itin_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days

visits.text: Villecroze — medieval village with flower-lined streets and stone arcades.
Natural troglodytic caves and waterfall in the municipal park.
Saint-Victor Chapel (Musical Academy site).

activities.text: Walk in the shaded park and its natural pools.
Thursday morning market under the plane trees.

days_plan.itin_title: Provence's Haut-Var: Verdon Gorge, Waterfalls & Medieval Stone Villages

visits.text: Villedieu-les-Poêles — copper workshops & bell foundry.

Explore Villedieu-les-Poêles, a remarkable town bearing the prestigious 'Villes et Métiers d'Art' label for its extraordinary artisan heritage dating back to the Middle Ages. This living museum of traditional craftsmanship has been renowned for centuries for its exceptional copperwork, with workshops still producing magnificent handcrafted pieces using ancestral techniques passed down through generations.

Visit the Cornille Havard bell foundry, one of France's last remaining traditional bell foundries where master craftsmen continue the ancient art of bell casting. Witness the fascinating process of creating these resonant instruments using methods virtually unchanged since medieval times, and learn how these workshops have supplied bells to churches and cathedrals throughout France and beyond.

Cornille Havard Foundry perpetuates nine centuries of bell-making tradition. The listed 19th-century workshop produces over a hundred monumental bells annually. This is where the bells installed in Notre-Dame Cathedral during its 2013 restoration were cast, their voices now ringing across Paris.

Step into the Copper Workshop, France's last atelier to work copper using traditional coppersmithing and boilermaking techniques. Craftsmen shape saucepans, jam-making basins, and decorative objects with hammers, just as the 'Sourdins' did centuries ago—a nickname earned because the metalworkers were deafened by the constant clangor.

The Knights of Malta Commandery recalls Villedieu's five centuries as an independent enclave of the Order of Saint John of Jerusalem. The interior courtyard, medieval buildings, and herb garden recreate the atmosphere of this 12th-century commandery.

Enter the Cour du Foyer, one of many interior courtyards that give the town its character. These passages between granite houses once sheltered copper craftsmen's workshops. About twenty such courts survive, connected by a maze of lanes.

Notre-Dame Church of Villedieu blends Romanesque and Gothic styles. Its 15th-century porch and octagonal bell tower dominate the town. Inside, the carved wooden pulpit and stained glass windows illustrate the town's religious history.

Villedieu bears the 'City and Crafts of Art' label. Beyond copper and bells, the House of Pewter demonstrates the working of this metal using ancestral methods: casting, turning, chasing. The pieces produced here are unique creations.

activities.text: Arts and crafts trail (historic center).

Discover the renowned Saint James workshops, home to the iconic French knitwear brand celebrated for its authentic marinière stripes and premium wool sweaters. Tour the production facilities to witness skilled artisans creating these timeless garments, then browse the boutique for beautifully crafted pieces embodying Norman maritime heritage.
Wander the old town lanes following the courts and workshops circuit. Each vaulted passage reveals a cobbled courtyard where copper once rang against anvils from dawn to dusk.
Villedieu's market runs every Tuesday morning on place de la République. Norman farm products, farmhouse cider, Villedieu andouille sausage, and local cheeses fill the stalls.

Witness a bronze pour at Cornille Havard foundry. Guided tours let you follow every stage of bell-making: from the earthen mold to the final unveiling, when the bell emerges from its centuries-old cocoon.

days_plan.itin_title: Normandy's Classic Coast: Étretat Cliffs and Bocage Countryside Villages
Normandy's Bay of Mont-Saint-Michel: Coastal Drives & the Sacred Abbey
Manche Road Trip: Cotentin Peninsula & Mont-Saint-Michel

visits.text: Lake Villefort's 127 hectares nestle in the Cévenol mountains, born from a dam built between 1956 and 1964 on the Bayard valley. Its Blue Flag-certified waters are bordered by developed beaches and an 8.5-km loop trail.

The Château de Castanet, a 16th-century historic monument, was preserved during the dam's flooding. Its name comes from the Occitan "castan" (chestnut tree). Open for self-guided visits in summer, with temporary exhibitions in the vaulted rooms.

La Garde-Guérin, listed among France's Most Beautiful Villages, is a medieval castrum perched at 900 meters elevation. Founded in the 12th century by the Bishop of Mende, this fortified settlement protected travelers on the Voie Régordane. Its cobbled streets, lined with mullioned-window houses and slate roofs, remain intact.

Climb the five levels of La Garde-Guérin's keep, a 12th-century watchtower standing 21.5 meters high. From the summit, your gaze plunges into the Chassezac gorges 400 meters below and extends across the Vivarais and Gévaudan uplands.

The Chassezac gorges, a 7-km granite canyon, cut 400 meters below the plateau. From the viewpoint accessible by trail, the view into the sheer walls is breathtaking. Locals call it "the Devil's lair."

activities.text: Swimming and water sports on Lake Villefort: sailing, windsurfing, canoe-kayak, pedal boats. Lifeguarded beach in July-August.
Villefort's via ferrata unfolds on cliffs above the lake. Two routes (easy and difficult) link ziplines and suspension bridges, with the lake as backdrop.
Fishing on Lake Villefort: brown trout, rainbow trout, and perch populate its waters. Accessible banks and calm zones make it a prized mountain fishing spot.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère Circuit: Tarn Gorges and Cévennes

visits.text: UNESCO-listed Villefranche-de-Conflent unfolds its pink marble ramparts dating from the 11th century. Vauban created a unique double covered walkway with bastions and fortified gates.

Fort Libéria towers 180 meters above the town. Built by Vauban in 1681, it's reached via an underground staircase of 734 steps. A garrison of 100 men, chapel, powder magazines, and dungeons unfold in succession.
The Canalettes Caves reveal limestone draperies, eccentric formations, and millennial concretions. From the Cupules corridor to the White Room, water has sculpted wonders.
The Church of Saint James preserves its 11th-century Romanesque architecture. Sculpted portal and capitals testify to Catalan Romanesque art.

activities.text: Board the Yellow Train. This narrow-gauge line climbs to 1,600 meters altitude through bridges, tunnels, and spectacular Pyrenean landscapes.
Stroll through the cobbled streets. Pink marble facades, artisan shops, and café terraces create a medieval atmosphere.
Hike toward the Canigou massif. Several trails start from Villefranche toward the peaks and high-altitude lakes.

days_plan.itin_title: Pyrénées-Orientales Road Trip: French Catalonia and the Vermilion Coast

visits.text: Cross the drawbridge of the Saint-Elme Citadel: this 1557 fortress commissioned by the Duke of Savoy now houses shaded gardens and small museums.
The walls of Saint Peter's Chapel tell the story of the fishermen's patron saint: vibrant frescoes, complete decor painted in the 1950s by a famous Menton artist.
The old town clings to the hillside: cobbled lanes, colorful shutters, vertiginous staircases typical of the County of Nice.
Walk through Rue Obscure, a 130-meter vaulted passage plunged in shadow: this ancient 13th-century walkway served as shelter during bombings.
Saint Michael's Church displays its Baroque splendor beneath 18th-century vaults, with a historic organ enthroned in the gallery.
Continue to the Royal Port of La Darse, former military harbor of the Kings of Sardinia where the rope factory and shipbuilding basin remain.
Villefranche-sur-Mer — old pastel town and sloping streets down to the waterfront.
Saint-Elme Citadel (ext.) — 16th century bastion and municipal museums.

activities.text: Lay your towel on Marinières beach: fine sand, calm waveless waters, panoramic view of the harbor and the Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat peninsula.
The colorful facades of Quai de l'Amiral Courbet blaze under the sun. Settle on a terrace facing the Mediterranean.
Walk along the ramparts via the Chemin de Ronde: walls plunge into the sea, the sun sets on the horizon.
Dive into the Villefranche harbor, one of the deepest in the Mediterranean: the seabed attracts divers and freedivers from around the world.
Drive up to the corniches for postcard panoramas: the Basse Corniche offers the classic view, the Moyenne Corniche dominates from above.
Marinières Beach — swimming/snorkeling in the harbor (clear waters).
Walk from quai de la Santé to port de la Darse (photo spots).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure
French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary

visits.text: Villefranche-sur-Saône, economic capital of Beaujolais, charms with its Rue Nationale lined with Renaissance facades and inner courtyards. Founded in the 12th century by the Lords of Beaujeu, the town prospered through trade and viticulture. The arcaded houses, sculpted corbels, and hidden courtyards testify to past wealth. The 500-meter-long main street concentrates architectural treasures accumulated over centuries.

Notre-Dame des Marais Collegiate Church stands out with its impressive facade and 55-meter-high bell tower dominating the city. Built from the 13th to 15th centuries, it showcases the evolution of Gothic style. The ribbed vaults, stained glass windows, and carved capitals create a majestic interior space. The recently restored organ ranks among the finest in the region.

The Municipal Museum Paul Dini houses an exceptional collection of modern and contemporary art. Works by Renoir, Dufy, Picasso, and local artists illustrate artistic movements of the 20th century. Temporary exhibitions showcase emerging artists and current trends. The building itself, a beautifully restored 18th-century mansion, is worth the visit.

The Covered Market, built in the 19th century, buzzes with activity every morning except Monday. The metal and glass structure shelters stalls overflowing with local products: Beaujolais wines, regional charcuterie, mountain cheeses, seasonal vegetables. Exchanges between producers and customers perpetuate the tradition of direct sales. The festive atmosphere and authentic smells create a total immersion in Beaujolais gastronomy.

activities.text: Explore the inner courtyards hidden behind Renaissance facades of Rue Nationale. These secret spaces, once economic heart of the city, reveal spiral staircases, sculpted galleries, and ancient wells. Some courtyards have been magnificently restored and now house artisan shops and artist studios. Guided tours reveal the history of merchant families who built their fortunes here.

Stroll along the Saône on the newly developed waterfront. The shaded promenade offers views of the river and surrounding hills. Play areas, picnic areas, and flowered gardens invite rest. Swans and ducks enliven the peaceful waters. The path connects to walking trails extending along the riverbanks.

Visit during the Beaujolais Nouveau festival in November, when the city becomes the epicenter of worldwide celebrations. Producers set up stands offering tastings of the new vintage. Concerts, wine-related games, and fireworks animate the streets. The festive atmosphere attracts thousands of visitors who share a glass around street braziers.

Take a walking tour of street art that has transformed many facades in recent years. Local and international artists created murals depicting Beaujolais history, wine culture, and urban life. The works, scattered throughout the city, offer a contemporary artistic journey contrasting with Renaissance heritage. Maps available at the tourist office guide visitors through this open-air gallery.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: Castle.
Saint-Cyr-Sainte-Julitte Church.
Gustave-Roussy Institute.

activities.text: Russian market.
Park.
Residential neighborhoods.

days_plan.itin_title: Val-de-Marne, France: A Road Trip to Pleasure Gardens & Historic Lakeside Châteaux

visits.text: On the banks of the young Seine, Villenauxe-la-Grande represents authentic rural Champagne. This peaceful agricultural town has preserved its parish church, stone washhouses and traditional houses that witness a life paced by seasons and field work. The modest but informative Heritage House traces local history and Champagne traditions — viticulture, livestock farming, crafts. Restful stop in preserved countryside.

activities.text: Seine riverbanks arranged as shaded promenade: flat paths following river meanders through wet meadows, willow groves and rustling reeds. Anglers find quiet spots to catch pike, zander and carp in fish-rich waters. Ideal family route for picnics, wildlife watching (grey herons, moorhens, kingfishers) and waterside flora. Absolute rural calm, far from tourist bustle.

days_plan.itin_title: Aube Circuit: Champagne, Medieval Heritage and Orient Forest Lakes

visits.text: LaM (Lille Métropole Museum of Modern, Contemporary and Outsider Art) houses over 8,000 works by Braque, Picasso, Modigliani, Klee and Miró. Its outsider art collection, France's largest, comes from the donation of the L'Aracine association.

LaM's sculpture park spreads across 23,000 m² of greenery. You'll encounter a monumental mobile by Alexander Calder, a sculpture by Picasso, and works by Richard Deacon, nestled among trees and lawns.
The Château de Flers, a 17th-century Flemish manor surrounded by moats, houses the tourism office. Its brick and stone façade sits within a peaceful small park where ducks patrol.
The Asnapio archaeological park recreates outdoor habitats from the Neolithic to the Middle Ages using period techniques: Gallic houses, Gallo-Roman farms and medieval constructions.
The Windmill Museum, set beside the chain of lakes, traces the history of water and windmills in the Flemish region through models, tools and archival documents.

activities.text: Circle Lac du Héron on foot or by bike: 4.6 km of easy trails through a 110-hectare regional nature reserve. Grey herons, grebes and kingfishers inhabit the shores.
The Forum of Sciences features a planetarium and interactive exhibitions on science and nature. Shows under the planetarium dome last about 45 minutes.
Visit the Héron farm beside the park to discover its heritage orchard: over 700 varieties of regional apples, 450 pear varieties, and educational beehives.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Circuit: Lille, Belfries and Flemish Heritage

visits.text: Fort Saint-André crowns Mont Andaon facing Avignon. This 14th-century royal fortress marked the border between the Kingdom of France and papal lands. Its twin towers frame a fortified gate. From the ramparts, the panorama covers the Palais des Papes, Mont Ventoux, and the Alpilles.

Step through the gates of the Chartreuse du Val de Bénédiction, France's largest charterhouse. Founded in 1352 by Pope Innocent VI, it sprawls across five acres with three cloisters, Matteo Giovannetti frescoes in the chapel, and the founding pope's mausoleum.
The Tour Philippe-le-Bel guarded the western end of Avignon's bridge on the French side. Climb its spiral staircase for a commanding view of the Rhône and Avignon's rooftops.

The gardens of Abbaye Saint-André, landscaped atop Mont Andaon, blend Italian-style terraces, centuries-old olive trees, and rose gardens. The Romanesque chapel ruins offer a silent setting facing the papal palace.
The Collégiale Notre-Dame houses a 14th-century ivory altarpiece and a copy of Enguerrand Quarton's Pietà, a masterpiece of medieval Provençal painting.

activities.text: Follow the path connecting Fort Saint-André to Tour Philippe-le-Bel along the ramparts. The walk winds through quiet medieval lanes with views of both banks of the Rhône.
In summer, the Chartreuse hosts artist residencies and performances in its cloisters. Check the schedule for the Centre National des Écritures du Spectacle based there.
Settle onto a terrace in Villeneuve's heights to watch the sunset over Avignon. The low-angled light sets the Palais des Papes' golden stone ablaze.

days_plan.itin_title: Vaucluse: Avignon, Luberon Villages & Ventoux Routes

visits.text: The Pont Vieux (or Pont des Cieutat) dates from 1282. Its irregular arches have spanned the Lot River for over seven centuries, once defended by three fortified towers.
The Chapelle Notre-Dame-du-Bout-du-Pont in rosy brick welcomed river boatmen. This pilgrimage chapel stands sentinel at the medieval bridge entrance.
Place Lafayette forms the heart of this bastide founded in 1264. Its covered arcades shelter cafés and shops around the market hall.
The Porte de Paris and Porte de Pujols are twin square towers that guarded the bastide's entrance, complete with portcullises and machicolations.
The Romano-Byzantine Église Sainte-Catherine consecrated in 1937 preserves splendid 14th- and 15th-century stained glass from the earlier church.
Admire the half-timbered houses in the old center. Their overhanging upper floors gained space without increasing property taxes.

activities.text: Visit the Place Lafayette market to sample Agen prunes, farmhouse cheeses, and seasonal vegetables.
Head to the waterfront activity center to rent a canoe, pedal boat, or electric boat on the Lot River.
Walk the Lot riverbanks along the towpath. These trails once served to haul barges loaded with wine and timber.

days_plan.itin_title: Lot-et-Garonne Road Trip: Medieval Bastides & Villages

visits.text: Basilica of the Sacred Heart (Romanesque).
Chapel of the Visitation.
Tower of Charles the Bold.

activities.text: Roman gates.
Bonaparte High School.

days_plan.itin_title: Saône Valley, France: Medieval Abbeys, Wine and Comtois Heritage

visits.text: The Canadian National Memorial at Vimy Ridge rises from the ridge captured in April 1917. Two 27-meter pylons bear the names of 11,285 Canadian soldiers who vanished in France with no known grave.
Walk through reconstructed trenches in their original 1917 positions. At some points, Canadian and German lines were separated by a mere 25 meters of no man's land.
Descend into the Grange Tunnel, one of 14 underground passages dug before the battle. The longest stretched 1,700 meters through solid chalk.
Notre-Dame-de-Lorette necropolis crowns a 165-meter hill as France's largest military cemetery. More than 40,000 soldiers rest in these fields.
The Ring of Memory forms a 345-meter ellipse. On 500 golden panels, 580,000 names of soldiers from all nations are inscribed in strict alphabetical order—no rank, no nationality, just names.

activities.text: Visit the Souchez interpretation center to search the soldiers' database. Each file records name, birth date, recruitment office, and burial location.
Vimy Memorial Park covers 107 hectares of undulating ground. The crater-pocked earth preserves shell scars, and sections remain off-limits due to unexploded ordnance.
Explore the ruins of Mont-Saint-Éloi Abbey. Its two 44-meter towers, shattered by 1914–18 bombardment, command views across the plain toward Vimy and Lorette.

days_plan.itin_title: Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: Villa Médicis.
Baltard Pavilion.
Banks of Marne.

activities.text: Lake Daumesnil.

visits.text: Vouvant, classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages, is Vendée's only fortified town. Over half a mile of ramparts encircle the medieval citadel built on a rocky spur above the river La Mère.
Climb the 122 steps of Tour Mélusine, a 13th-century circular keep rising 118 feet. Two domed vaulted chambers and 360-degree views over forest and bocage reward the ascent.
The Romanesque church of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption possesses a sculpted portal of exceptional richness for the Lower Poitou. Inside, the Lusignan chapel is said to hold the tomb of Lord Geoffroy II.
Pass through the Poterne, the only fortified gate to have survived the centuries. From here, flower-lined lanes descend toward the river between lime-washed houses and artists' workshops.
Explore the Antre de Mélusine, a museum space devoted to the legend of the fairy who was half-woman, half-serpent. According to the tale, she built Vouvant castle in a single night.

activities.text: Hike in the Mervent-Vouvant forest, Vendée's largest woodland with 12,000 acres of oak and beech. The Orée de la Forêt trail departs from Place du Bail.
Paddle down the river La Mère by kayak or canoe. The calm water winds between wooded cliffs and the meanders that made Vouvant a strategic defensive site since the 11th century.
Try the Bocage Loop, a family-friendly 2.5-mile trail starting from Place du Bail. The path crosses the village, open farmland, and Vendée hedgerow country in 90 minutes.

days_plan.itin_title: Vendée Road Trip: Noirmoutier Island, Puy du Fou & Atlantic Coast

visits.text: The Grange du Massacre marks where, on March 1, 1562, François de Guise and his troops attacked Protestants gathered for worship. Between 25 and 80 deaths ignited the Wars of Religion that would ravage France for decades.
The Protestant Museum occupies the former temple. Panels, display cases, and video presentations trace the Protestant community's history and the Wars of Religion through the 1598 Edict of Nantes.
The Protestant temple was inaugurated in 1889, built against the massacre barn. A commemorative plaque recalls the tragic events of 1562.
Notre-Dame church displays Romanesque architecture. The circular 19th-century market hall testifies to the town's commercial vitality.

activities.text: Explore Wassy's historic center. The former theater on Place Marie-Stuart dates from when the town became a sub-prefecture in 1790.
Head to nearby Lac des Leschères. Hiking trails and cycling paths crisscross the surrounding countryside.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Marne Discovery: Langres & Historic Heritage

visits.text: Wimereux: first seaside resort of the Opal Coast, colorful Victorian villas.
The 1.5-kilometer promenade borders the beach, lined with Belle Époque villas and blue-and-white beach cabins. It captures the atmosphere of early seaside bathing culture.
Wimereux preserves 300 Anglo-Norman Belle Époque villas. Bay windows, ornate balconies, colorful ceramics—each residence displays unique character.
The Opal Coast's oldest seaside resort developed after 1862 with the railway's arrival. Tramway, casino, and golf course attracted aristocracy and bourgeoisie.
Notre-Dame Church with its stained glass and architecture testifies to the resort's 19th-century prosperity.

activities.text: Promenade pier & blue-white cabins, water sports.
Head to Pointe aux Oies, bordered by dunes. On clear days, the English coast materializes offshore. This wild space is prime territory for spotting grey seals and harbor seals.
Wimereux Golf Course, created in 1901 and rebuilt after 1918, offers an 18-hole course with stunning sea views.
Practice water sports: kitesurfing, windsurfing, land yachting. The wind sweeping the coast creates ideal conditions.
Follow the Imperial Trail, a 14-kilometer loop starting from the Column of the Grande Armée. A walk between cliffs and dunes.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-France: Opal Coast Cliffs, Medieval History & Great War Sites
Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: Wissant: fishing village between Cap Blanc-Nez and Cap Gris-Nez.
Cap Blanc-Nez rises 134 meters in chalk cliffs above the Channel. On clear days, the English coast appears just 35 kilometers away. The Dover Patrol Monument honors 2,000 Franco-British soldiers.
Ten kilometers south, Cap Gris-Nez—45-meter clay and sandstone cliffs—marks the closest point to England. The two capes form a Grand Site de France since 2011.
Between the capes, Wissant Bay stretches 12 kilometers of fine sand. This resort is renowned for kitesurfing and windsurfing, benefiting from a venturi effect created by the capes.
Three kilometers from Cap Gris-Nez, Audresselles has kept its fishermen's houses with blue shutters and tarred foundations. Colorful flobarts—traditional beaching boats—still put to sea.
The crans—notches in the cliffs—dot the coast: Cran aux Oeufs, Cran Poulet, Cran du Noirda. These wild pebble coves reveal fossils and are perfect for shore fishing.

activities.text: Land sailing / board / low tide walk towards the two Caps.
The GR120 trail links both capes in 16 kilometers along the clifftops. Limestone grasslands shelter orchids, rock roses, and bitter gentian.
In Wissant, schools offer kitesurfing and stand-up paddle lessons. The immense beach at low tide lets you escape the crowds.
From the summit of Cap Blanc-Nez, watch for grey seals in the waters below. The site is also a major observation point for migratory birds in spring and autumn.

days_plan.itin_title: Hauts-de-France: Opal Coast Cliffs, Medieval History & Great War Sites
Pas-de-Calais Road Trip: Opal Coast & Historic Belfries

visits.text: The Abbey Church of Saints Peter and Paul was founded around 660. The second-largest Gothic building in Alsace after Strasbourg Cathedral. Romanesque bell tower from 1075.
The never-completed Gothic cloister houses an 11th-century Romanesque chapel. Ancient frescoes and an 11-metre mural painting: Saint Christopher carrying the infant Jesus.
The Maison du Sel dates from 1448. A former civic hospital, it impresses by its proportions. Its monumental roof was used for collecting the salt tax.
The Bruch quarter runs along the Lauter river. The 16th-century Maison de l'Ami Fritz is reflected in the water. Wissembourg's own charming Little Venice.
Old center crossed by the Lauter, half-timbered houses and old city gates.
Abbey church of Saints-Pierre-et-Paul, great Gothic nave at the heart of the village.
Ramparts district and walkways along the water.
Wissembourg Christmas Market
Festive displays across the historic centre

The abbey church Saints-Pierre-et-Paul, founded around 660, is the second largest Gothic edifice in Alsace after Strasbourg Cathedral. Its Romanesque belfry from the 11th century is the oldest part. The Dubois baroque organ (1766), the largest in Alsace, was restored in 2012.

The adjoining Gothic cloister houses a reproduction of the "Christ of Wissembourg," considered the world's oldest figurative stained glass (the original is at the Musée de l'OEuvre Notre-Dame in Strasbourg).

The Maison du Sel (1448), former bourgeois hospital, impresses with its proportions and atypical roof. Extensively restored in the 18th century, it's one of the town's most remarkable civic buildings.
Reach the Bruch quarter, former marshland. The Maison de l'Ami Fritz (16th century) mirrors itself in the Lauter, its richly carved half-timbering framing mullioned windows.
The Musée Westercamp traces local archaeology and border history (1870). It houses an exceptional collection of popular imagery from the Wentzel manufactory.
The Hôtel Stanislas housed the exiled King of Poland from 1719 to 1725. Its sober façade conceals an interior that was long that of a sovereign in residence.

activities.text: Walk the ramparts. Wissembourg's green belt retains towers and fortified gates. A member of the Décapole league since 1354, the town once defended itself against invasions.
The Maginot Line can be explored at the Schoenenbourg fortress. The largest open fort, it could shelter 630 men. Three kilometres of underground galleries.
The German border runs through Wissembourg. The vineyard extends into the Palatinate. Wissembourg cellars have been producing crémants and sparkling wines since 1970.
Pedestrian loop of the ramparts and canals (3–4 km).
Gentle climb to viewpoints for panoramas over the Palatinate forest.
View seasonal parades and Christmas performances
Walk the tour of the ramparts: abbey defensive walls, imposing Schartenturm tower, urban enclosure and north moat. A fitness trail with 13 stations completes the loop.
Stroll along the Lauter quays, the river that flows through the old town. Half-timbered houses reflect in the water, forming Wissembourg's "Little Venice."
Wissembourg is the gateway to the Northern Vosges Regional Nature Park, a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. Hiking trails and mountain bike paths leave directly from town toward the Mundat forest.

visits.text: Yenne is a medieval town built between the Rhône and the Dent du Chat peak. A marked trail with 29 points of interest winds through the historic center: the Chambéry Gate, Novalaise Gate, salt granary, and noble houses from the 15th-18th centuries reveal layers of history in weathered stone.
Step inside Yenne's church, a listed Historic Monument. Its baroque furnishings blend with older elements in a hushed atmosphere that invites contemplation.

Follow the Balcon de Yenne trail—part of the Santiago de Compostela pilgrimage route—up to the Notre-Dame de la Montagne viewpoint. The vista plunges into the Pierre-Châtel gorge, a protected natural site where the Rhône squeezes between cliffs at the border of Ain and Savoie.

The Pierre-Châtel gorge shelters ruins of a 13th-century charterhouse that became a military fortress in the 1800s. From the trail's second viewpoint, you can clearly make out the structure nestled in the canyon below.

Head to the Jongieux-Marestel hillsides, a vineyard classified as national heritage for its scenic beauty. Terraced vines overlook the Rhône. The slopes produce Roussette de Savoie (Altesse grape) and Mondeuse, a bold red wine.

activities.text: Balcon de Yenne hike: the trail climbs through boxwood forest to three successive viewpoints over the Rhône and Pierre-Châtel gorge. Return via the hamlets of Chevru and Curtelod.
Wine tasting in the Jongieux cellars. Marestel vintages and Mondeuse reds are sampled at local producers' estates, set between manicured slopes and Lake Bourget panoramas.
Canoe-kayak on the wild upper Rhône at the foot of the Pierre-Châtel gorge. Whitewater threads through a landscape of cliffs and forests, ranked among the region's most acclaimed paddling routes.

days_plan.itin_title: Savoie from Lakes to Glaciers: Yenne to Haute-Maurienne

visits.text: Yvoire spreads its ramparts and flower-lined lanes on a promontory jutting into Lake Geneva. This 14th-century fortified village ranks among France's Most Beautiful Villages.
The castle has dominated the lake since 1306 when Count Amédée V of Savoy fortified this strategic point. Private property, it can be admired from the fishing port.
Pass through the Nernier Gate topped by its watchtower to enter the medieval town. Cobbled lanes wind between stone houses with flower-bedecked balconies.
Saint-Pancrace Church raises its onion dome covered in stainless steel that shines like a beacon on the lake. Pastel-colored interior frescoes illuminate the nave.
The Garden of Five Senses occupies the castle's former vegetable garden. This plant labyrinth gathers 1,300 varieties chosen to stimulate each of the senses.
The marina welcomes boats from Switzerland while the small fishing port retains its authenticity with colorful skiffs.
The Faucille Pass peaks at 1,323 meters on the Jura ridge. The panorama embraces Lake Geneva, Mont Blanc, and the entire Alpine chain.
Chamonix: stroll in the historic center at the foot of Mont-Blanc.
Chamonix Alpine Museum: collections on mountaineering and first ascents.
Yvoire: medieval town on the shores of Lake Geneva, discovery of the fortified alleys.
Garden of the Five Senses in Yvoire: sensory trail organized by themes.

Explore this fortified medieval village founded in the early 14th century by Count Amadeus V of Savoy. The walled town has preserved more than 700 years of history intact—ramparts, fortified gates, and cobbled lanes cascading with geraniums. Classified among France's Most Beautiful Villages.

Admire the rectangular keep that has guarded the peninsula since the 14th century. Built between 1306 and 1311, the castle's mission was to monitor Lake Geneva's strategic waters. Owned by the d'Yvoire family since 1655, it remains a private residence and cannot be toured—but its imposing exterior dominates every photo.

Enter this unique 3.7-hectare garden classified as Remarkable by France's Ministry of Culture. Open to the public since 1988, this garden celebrates plants through the five senses in a labyrinth inspired by medieval monastery gardens. More than 1,500 plant varieties create a living tapestry of color, texture, and fragrance.

Stroll the picturesque harbor where boats of the Compagnie Générale de Navigation depart for Swiss shores. The port offers magnificent views of the castle, flower-draped ramparts, and the lake with the Alps providing a majestic backdrop—postcard Savoy in every direction.

activities.text: The ferry links Yvoire to Nyon in Switzerland in twenty minutes. This crossing offers a unique viewpoint of the fortified village with the Alps as backdrop.
Stroll through pedestrian lanes lined with artisan shops and art galleries. Restaurants serve lake fish on shaded terraces.
The Garden of Five Senses offers a unique sensory experience where textures, fragrances, flavors, sounds, and colors mingle in a plant setting.
The Faucille Pass toboggan run descends over a kilometer with slopes reaching 37 percent. This descent ranks among Europe's longest.
Aiguille du Midi cable car: panoramic ascent over the Mont-Blanc massif.
Panoramic transfer Chamonix → Yvoire along Lake Geneva (viewpoint stops).

Wander this garden-labyrinth where every sense awakens. Touch the soft textures of foliage, breathe in the perfume of roses and aromatic herbs, marvel at the colorful compositions. Children receive a discovery quiz to guide their sensory exploration.

Lose yourself in the maze of cobbled lanes draped with geraniums, admire the architectural details of stone houses, pass through fortified gates. Every corner reveals another photogenic perspective—medieval beauty preserved in amber.

Embark on a Lake Geneva cruise from Yvoire harbor. Several options: crossing to Switzerland, a circuit of the Petit Lac, or a narrated cruise along French and Swiss shores—a perspective on the lake that reveals why humans have prized these waters for millennia.

Village craft center — Lace and lentil products from the plateau.

activities.text: Short hike to La Roche Merveilleuse belvedere (late afternoon light).
Spa soak or wine tasting (local chenin/viognier micro‑production).
Optional summit attempt to Piton des Neiges (very early start; experienced hikers).

days_plan.itin_title: Réunion Island Tour: Piton de la Fournaise Volcano and Cirques

visits.text: Salazie — Voile de la Mariée waterfalls and fern canyons; viewpoints along RD48.
Hell‑Bourg — Restored Creole villas (Maison Folio) and village museum.

activities.text: Easy loop hike around Hell‑Bourg (2–3 h, early start to avoid clouds).
Cassava cake and bonbon piment tasting in a village snack.

days_plan.itin_title: Réunion Island Tour: Piton de la Fournaise Volcano and Cirques

visits.text: Saint‑Denis — Barachois waterfront cannons and Creole townhouses on Rue de Paris (19th c.).
Jardin de l’État — Botanical collections and natural‑history museum in a colonial garden.
Back to Saint‑Denis — Street art lanes and last Creole boutiques.

activities.text: Evening cari and rhum arrangé tasting; book a table on Rue Maréchal Leclerc.
Short seaside jog on the Barachois promenade at sunrise.
Final seaside walk at Barachois; airport drop‑off.

visits.text: Saint‑Paul market (Fri–Sat) — Spices, fruits and Creole street food.
Saint‑Gilles‑les‑Bains — Aquarium and marina promenade.
Maïdo road — Belvedere over the Mafate cirque; panoramas at 2190 m (arrive at sunrise).
Savanna distillery — Rum tasting and botanical garden (check hours).

activities.text: Lagoon snorkeling at l’Ermitage (inside reef only; heed lifeguard flags).
Sunset on Boucan Canot boardwalk.
Paragliding over the lagoon (weather‑dependent; certified operator only).

visits.text: Étang‑Salé — Black‑sand beach and petrified lava cliffs.
Saint‑Pierre — Waterfront market and Creole temple façades on Rue des Bons‑Enfants.

activities.text: Snorkel the protected lagoon (when sea is calm; never swim outside marked area).

visits.text: Piton de la Fournaise — Hike from Pas de Bellecombe to the caldera rim with views of Dolomieu crater.
Grand Brûlé — Coastal lava flows and N2 road segments rebuilt over recent eruptions.

activities.text: Stop at Notre‑Dame des Laves chapel near Piton‑Sainte‑Rose.
